site_title: UBS expands wealth service to target Australia’s mining capital
summary: UBS has established offshore desks in Singapore to cater to its clients in Australia and Japan, expanding its wealth service to the country's mining capital, Perth. The bank has appointed Tim Clemenger as its first client adviser for wealth management in Perth, aiming to tap into the city's estimated 20 billionaires and 100 people worth over $100 million. UBS plans to grow its high-net-worth money in Australia, which grew 7.9% in 2023, and increase its staff in the country to over 900.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A sign and logo of the Swiss giant banking UBS is seen in Lausanne on February 6, 2024. Swiss banking giant UBS posted net income of 1.4 billion USD (1.3 billion euros) on October 30, 2024, the company said in a statement, smashing third-quarter forecasts. (Photo by Fabrice COFFRINI / AFP)
Two years ago, UBS acquired Credit Suisse after its old rival collapsed, sparking calls for stricter regulation in the industry to prevent the risk of another banking crisis.

site_title: Country Garden posts narrower loss in 2024 after write-off
summary: Country Garden Holdings reported a narrower loss of 32.8 billion yuan (S$6.1 billion) in 2024, down from a record 178 billion yuan loss in 2023. The developer made significant write-offs on underdeveloped properties and completed homes, laying the groundwork for the smaller loss. Country Garden is seeking broad creditor support for its debt restructuring plan and expects to reach an agreement by the end of February. The company is counting on a turnaround in operations to avoid liquidation, with its next wind-up hearing scheduled for May 26.

images.alt_text: A man stands outside the construction site of a residential complex being built by Chinese real estate developer Vanke in Nanjing in China’s eastern Jiangsu province on February 13, 2025. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Nine themes set to reshape portfolios
summary: US President Donald Trump's post-election promises and key regulatory decisions are set to reshape portfolios in 2025. Fintech and financials are expected to thrive due to economic growth, reduced regulation, and fintech initial public offerings. The demand for immersive, personalized experiences in consumer space, AI-driven innovations, and increased digitalization will drive growth. Other key themes include the circular economy, smart grids, mobility, water, biodiversity, and smart materials and manufacturing, which are expected to be impacted by structural change, reshoring trends, and technological advancements.

images.alt_text: Robot arms are seen at work on a car production line at a factory of FAW-Volkswagen company in Qingdao, in eastern China's Shandong province on March 12, 2025. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT
BYD’s European Union tariff is 27%, including the standard 10% import levy.
WorldFirst chief executive officer Clara Shi believes that by partnering with banks, fintech companies can offer cost-effective solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises expanding overseas.

site_title: Could Trump serve a third term? Probably not
summary: President Donald Trump, at 78, may be mulling a third term but the 22nd Amendment to the US Constitution bars a president from serving more than two terms, making such a scenario highly unlikely. Most constitutional scholars disagree with Trump's claims, and any serious effort to amend the document would send the country into uncharted territory. Trump's remarks have sparked a longshot resolution in the House and increased his odds of winning the 2028 presidential election, now standing at six to one according to offshore bookmaker BetOnline.ag.

images.alt_text: IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva said the Fund may slightly downgrade its global economic forecast for this year of 3.3 per cent, adding it does not currently predict a recession.
US President Donald Trump's order establishes an office within the Department of Commerce called the United States Investment Accelerator, which will encourage companies to make large investments.

While factory-order and retail-sales data have held up so far, there are signs that purchasing managers are rushing to get orders in before the price hikes begin to take effect, likely on Apr 2.

site_title: GE2025: Parties unveil slew of new faces over the weekend
summary: Singapore's ruling People's Action Party (PAP) and opposition Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) announced new candidates ahead of the general election, expected before mid-2025. The PAP introduced new faces in Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC, including business development director Diana Pang, while the SDP plans to contest Marsiling-Yew Tee GRC. Other parties, including the Singapore People's Party (SPP), also announced their intentions to contest in Bishan-Toa Payoh GRC and Potong Pasir SMC. The PAP's lineup for Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC includes two current MPs and a new face, while the SDP will put up a "good slate" for the election.

images.alt_text: (Clockwise from top left) Mr Jeffrey Siow, Mr Dinesh Vasu Dash, Ms Jasmin Lau, Mr Shawn Loh, Ms Goh Hanyan and Mr Foo Cexiang.
This change is to account for inflation, the Elections Department said on Mar 27.
He is making great effort to renew the leadership team and the party, PM Wong tells media in an interview capping of his visit to Hanoi.
Progress Singapore Party NCMP Leong Mun Wai will take over as party chief from Ms Hazel Poa, who will be the party's vice-chair.

site_title: Temasek-backed 65 Equity Partners makes Europe foray with Swiss pharma merger
summary: Asset manager 65 Equity Partners, backed by Temasek, has backed the acquisition of Swiss pharmaceutical ingredient maker Healthcare Advanced Synthesis (HAS) by Cerbios-Pharma, marking its first deal in Europe. 65 Equity will become a 40% shareholder in the merged entity, valuing the combined company at approximately $380 million. The deal is part of the firm's strategy to expand in the contract development and manufacturing organisation sector, which has seen large drugmakers outsourcing these functions.

images.alt_text: Tan Chong Lee, chief executive of 65 Equity Partners, said: "Our goal is not to just focus on domestic businesses, but to open up the funnel."

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Smart money moves - Key considerations before switching jobs
summary: In Singapore, 67% of employees are considering a job change within the next 12 months, surpassing the global average. Before making a switch, it's crucial to consider financial factors, including industry dynamics, overall rewards packages, and emergency strategies. Companies are becoming increasingly competitive in providing employee benefits, such as personalized packages, flexibility, and support for wellbeing. Non-financial factors like workplace culture, skill development, and job security also contribute to overall employee satisfaction. Experts advise evaluating current financial situations, leveraging networks, and researching potential employers to make informed career decisions.

images.alt_text: How to get financially prepared for retrenchment.
Even investing in property should be diversified.
What to do when geopolitical events affect your investments?

site_title: Granite Asia, PE firm form US$100 million JV targeting Japan expansion opportunities
summary: Granite Asia and Japan-listed private equity company Integral Corporation have formed a US$100 million joint venture, Granite-Integral, to target Japan expansion opportunities. The JV aims to facilitate two-way expansion, helping companies navigate Japan's regulatory landscape and business complexities, while also supporting Japanese enterprises seeking growth outside the domestic market. Led by CK Choun and Joe Yan, the partnership combines Granite Asia's technology sector expertise with Integral Corporation's market knowledge to drive cross-border synergies and accelerate market entry.

images.alt_text: Granite Asia will be led by senior managing partners Jenny Lee (above) and Foo Jixun.
Launched in October 2024, the Design AI and Tech Awards recognises businesses that use design and technology to create innovative solutions for real-world challenges.

site_title: Thai Premier Paetongtarn’s support climbs to 30.9% in poll
summary: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's support increased to 30.9% in a recent poll, surpassing the previous 28.8%. This rise comes after she survived a no-confidence vote in parliament. The opposition leader, Natthaphong Ruengpanyawut, received 25.8% support. The poll, conducted by the National Institute of Development Administration, involved 2,000 Thais nationwide. Paetongtarn's father, Thaksin Shinawatra, is facing an ethics case, but he remains confident that the court will clear his daughter's suspension as prime minister.

site_title: OpenAI finalises US$40 billion funding at US$300 billion value
summary: OpenAI has finalized a US$40 billion funding round at a US$300 billion valuation, the largest in history. Backed by Microsoft and SoftBank Group Corp., the AI developer plans to complete a corporate restructuring by the end of the year, giving its for-profit arm independence from the nonprofit governing body. OpenAI expects to triple its revenue to US$12.7 billion this year, driven by surging subscriptions to its consumer and business versions of ChatGPT.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk says in a post on X that the combined company would be valued at US$80 billion.
Dan Neary, Meta’s vice-president for the region, assumed the role in 2013 and oversaw the rapid expansion of the company’s user base from Australia to Greater China and South-east Asia.
SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman attend an event to pitch AI for businesses in Tokyo, Japan, Feb 3, 2025.
While revenue is soaring, OpenAI is also confronting significant costs from the chips, data centres and talent needed to develop cutting-edge AI systems.

site_title: OCBC should sell Chulia Street properties so assets can be redeveloped to benefit Singapore
summary: OCBC Bank's shareholders may be concerned about the bank's performance relative to market leader DBS, with OCBC's return on equity (ROE) at 11.1%, 13.7%, and 13.7% in 2022, 2023, and 2024, respectively. The bank's ownership of 63, 65 Chulia Street and 18 Church Street in Singapore's Central Business District (CBD) is under review, with plans to redevelop the properties potentially yielding a new landmark Grade A office-led integrated development. However, redevelopment plans have been put on hold due to concerns over a huge capital outlay, including land betterment charges, construction costs, and professional fees. Selling the properties could help the bank realize some benefits and redeploy capital to more strategic investments, while also benefiting Singapore's state coffers through increased property taxes.

images.alt_text:
khls18 - OCBC Centre South in the foreground.


Credit:  GOOGLE MAPS

site_title: GE2025: Former AIC chief spotted with East Coast GRC MPs; first public servant new face seen on the ground
summary: Former Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) chief Dinesh Vasu Dash, 50, accompanied East Coast Group Representation Committee (GRC) MPs for a mosque visit in Chai Chee on March 31, sparking speculation he has joined the ruling party and will be fielded in the upcoming elections. He was seen with Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong, and other East Coast GRC MPs. Tong said Dinesh and Hazlina Abdul Halim, a former Make-A-Wish Singapore CEO, are "getting a good sense of the community" and building connections with sitting MPs.

site_title: Gold may enter overbought territory after recent rapid gains
summary: Gold prices have surged to record highs, surpassing $3,000 per ounce for the first time in history. The surge is driven by economic uncertainty, including inflation fears, trade tensions, and geopolitical risks. Central banks, particularly in Asia, are also buying gold to diversify their foreign exchange reserves. Despite the strong performance, some analysts warn that gold may be entering overbought territory, with a possible technical pullback on the horizon.

images.alt_text: Spot gold climbed 0.2 per cent to US$3,061.72 an ounce, as of 0035 GMT, after hitting a record high of US$3,063.20 earlier in the session. Bullion is up 1.3 per cent so far this week.

site_title: Thailand's economic activity slows in February, central bank to assess quake impact
summary: Thailand's economic activity slowed in February due to a decline in manufacturing and tourism, according to the central bank. The earthquake that struck Bangkok on Friday, centered on Myanmar, may further dent tourism, but its impact is still being assessed. Foreign tourists dropped 13.9% in February, and manufacturing declined 1% month-on-month. Shares in Thai hoteliers fell, and the central bank has introduced relief measures for those impacted by the quake, with the next rate meeting scheduled for April 30.

images.alt_text: Japanese tourists (in the center) visit Wat Arun or the Temple of Dawn on the eve of Lunar New Year, as the high-profile alleged kidnapping of a Chinese actor and similar crimes stoked worries over tourism and security in Bangkok, Thailand January 28, 2025. REUTERS/Chalinee Thirasupa

Rescue workers are lifted on a crane during search-and-rescue operations at the site of an under-construction building collapse in Bangkok on March 31, 2025, three days after an earthquake struck central Myanmar and Thailand. (Photo by Chanakarn Laosarakham / AFP)

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Understanding potential issues within CDL’s upcoming AGM
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) is set to hold an AGM on April 23, amid internal conflicts between its executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and CEO Sherman Kwek. The power struggle led to allegations of a boardroom coup and accusations of overreach by Catherine Wu, a Kwek Leng Beng advisor. CDL's corporate governance practices are under scrutiny, with investors questioning the company's ability to deliver shareholder value amidst internal disruptions. The AGM will be an opportunity for the company to address these issues and strengthen investor confidence, according to a podcast analysis by Ben Paul.

images.alt_text: The pall of uncertainty hanging over CDL could begin to clear when it holds its AGM on Apr 23.
CDL shares would probably garner a higher market valuation if the company aggressively monetised assets, and focused on more income-generating businesses
Will the new MAS Singapore market review measures succeed?

site_title: Yangzijiang Financial places S$139.3 million in treasury shares for maritime investments
summary: Yangzijiang Financial has raised S$139.3 million through a placement of treasury shares at S$0.72 apiece, agreeing to divest 193.5 million shares. The sale represents a 111% premium to the average buyback cost and will be used to redeploy funds for maritime investments, in line with the company's strategy to capitalize on industry tailwinds driven by increasing decarbonization.

images.alt_text: As of Friday (Feb 28), the counter ended the week at a closing price of S$2.38, plunging  26.1 per cent or S$0.84 from the closing price of S$3.22 on Feb 21 one week prior.
The arbitration proceedings relate to orders made by customers for 10 vessels worth US$900 million.
On Feb 21, the USTR office proposed to hit Chinese-built vessels entering US ports with fees of up to US$1.5 million.
Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was one of the Singapore Exchange’s top-performing stocks in 2024.
Yangzijiang Financial said it continues to diversify and reduce its exposure to China.

site_title: China factory activity expands before expected Trump tariffs
summary: China's factory activity expanded in March with a PMI of 50.5, beating economists' forecasts, just before the US is expected to impose reciprocal tariffs. The expansion is a welcome relief for the world's No 2 economy, but China has warned it will retaliate if the US proceeds. The non-manufacturing measure rose to 50.8, indicating growth in the construction and services sectors. China's policymakers are preparing for a potential tariff shock and may need to unleash stimulus to meet its 5% growth target.

images.alt_text:

The announcements follow Chinese authorities’ pledge in early March to issue 500 billion yuan in special sovereign bonds to replenish capital at the nation’s biggest state-owned banks.

site_title: Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’ is set to whack US economy
summary: US President Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, set to be announced on April 2, will likely slow economic growth, raise prices, and worsen inequality. The tariffs, which will increase the effective tariff rate to about 8%, will hurt America's trading partners, including China, Canada, and Mexico. The move is expected to lead to higher inflation, with Goldman Sachs predicting a 0.8% to 1.3% decrease in year-on-year growth rate. The tariffs will also disproportionately affect low-income households, with the Yale Budget Lab estimating a 2.5% decline in disposable income for the poorest households.

images.alt_text: New Hyundai vehicles at the Port of Tacoma in Tacoma, Washington, US, on Thursday, March 27, 2025. President Donald Trump signed a proclamation to implement a 25% tariff on auto imports, expanding a trade war designed to bring more manufacturing jobs to the US and setting the stage for an even broader push on levies next week. Photographer: David Ryder/Bloomberg

site_title: Constitution provides for NMPs to step down to stand in elections: Shanmugam
summary: Singaporean Minister for Law K Shanmugam clarified that under the country's Constitution, Nominated Members of Parliament (NMPs) can step down to join a political party and run for election. He emphasized the importance of NMPs being independent and of character. Shanmugam's comments come after NMPs Raj Joshua Thomas and Syed Harun Alhabsyi resigned, sparking concerns about the independence of NMPs. The Minister stated that the Constitution provides for NMPs to join parties and participate in elections, citing the intentions of former Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew.

site_title: China property giant Vanke reports annual loss of US$6.8 billion
summary: China property giant Vanke reported an annual loss of US$6.8 billion, citing falling sales and shrinking profit margins despite Beijing's efforts to revive the housing market. The company attributed the losses to "expansion inertia" and aggressive investment, and has seen a shakeup of its top management. Vanke's revenue fell 26% year-on-year to US$47.3 million, and the company faces a concentrated repayment of its public debts, further intensifying liquidity pressure.

images.alt_text: A man stands outside the construction site of a residential complex being built by Chinese real estate developer Vanke in Nanjing in China’s eastern Jiangsu province on February 13, 2025. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Japan's Nikkei closes near 8-month low on US tariff jitters
summary: Japan's Nikkei share index closed near an eight-month low, falling 4.05% to 35,617.56, due to US tariff jitters ahead of a potential announcement by President Donald Trump. The Nikkei posted its biggest daily decline since September 30, with all 33 industry sub-indexes on the Tokyo Stock Exchange declining. Investors were in a risk-off mode, selling off shares, with chipmakers and automakers leading the losses. The broader Topix index fell 3.5% to 2,658.73, with investors awaiting clarity on the US tariff plan.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei closed 0.5 per cent higher at 37,780.54.

site_title: China to recapitalise 4 big banks with 500b yuan
summary: China's Finance Ministry plans to inject 500 billion yuan into four state banks, Bank of Communications, Bank of China, Postal Savings Bank of China, and China Construction Bank, through share placements. The move aims to boost the banks' capital buffers and support the economy amid record-low margins and rising bad debt. The banks will issue new shares at a premium of 8.8% to 21.5% above their closing levels, and the Ministry will sell its first batch of special sovereign bonds to support the injections. The move is expected to bring long-term returns for investors and maintain financial stability.

images.alt_text: The PMI figures serve as a snapshot of China’s economic health just before the Trump administration is expected to press ahead with reciprocal tariffs.

site_title: Private-markets access for retail investors is mostly good – but with caveats
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) is seeking feedback on a regulatory framework to allow retail investors to access private-market funds. Private-market funds offer diversification benefits and higher risk-adjusted returns, but come with higher fees and limited liquidity. Retail investors should be cautious of factors such as policing of marketing and practices, advisory processes, and potential conflicts of interest. The MAS proposes two vehicles for retail access: direct funds and fund of funds, with risk limits, concentration limits, and leverage limits. The framework aims to balance investor protection with the need for enhanced returns and diversification benefits.

images.alt_text: MAS seeks feedback on proposals giving retail investors access to private market assets
Small and medium enterprises are often underserved by traditional banks. Private credit has an important role to play in filling this gap.

site_title: Anime and mascots: Japan hopes ‘oshikatsu’ rage will open consumer wallets
summary: Japan's "oshikatsu" phenomenon, where fans support their favorite celebrities, anime characters, and mascots, is driving consumer spending and potentially boosting the country's economy. A recent survey estimated 14 million people, or 11% of Japan's population, are engaged in oshikatsu, spending an average of 250,000 yen (S$2,284) annually. This could contribute 3.5 trillion yen to the economy, despite only accounting for 2.1% of total retail sales. The trend is expected to continue, with non-essential spending holding its own despite inflation, and is seen as a positive factor for Japan's economy amid rising external risks.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba speaks during a press conference at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo on October 9, 2024. Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba dissolved parliament on October 9 ahead of October 27 snap elections, banking on his honeymoon popularity and a fragmented opposition to lead his scandal-tainted party to victory. (Photo by David Mareuil / POOL / AFP)
The Nikkei fell 4.05 per cent to 35,617.56, its lowest close since August 6, the day after the index posted its biggest single-day rout since the 1987 Black Monday crash.
Last year, car and car parts accounted for a little over one-third of Japan’s exports to the US, its biggest export destination.
The cost of rice in Tokyo surged 92.4 per cent in March, a sign of the pain households were feeling from rising living costs.

site_title: Trump threatens secondary tariffs on Russian oil if unable to make deal on Ukraine
summary: US President Donald Trump threatened to impose secondary tariffs of 25-50% on Russian oil if a deal cannot be reached on stopping the bloodshed in Ukraine. Trump stated he would take action if he believes Russia is responsible for the conflict and if a ceasefire is not achieved. He plans to speak with Russian President Vladimir Putin this week and warned that the tariffs could start within a month. The move comes after Putin suggested Ukraine could be placed under temporary administration, effectively pushing out President Volodymyr Zelenskiy.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 2 cents higher, or 0.03 per cent, at US$73.02 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: US: Stocks mixed as traders shake off tariff uncertainty
summary: US stocks closed mixed on Monday, reversing earlier declines to close 1.0% higher at 42,001.76, as traders shook off uncertainty surrounding Donald Trump's imminent tariff announcement. The S&P 500 Index gained 0.6% to 5,611.85, while the tech-focused Nasdaq Composite Index fell 0.1%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average posted its worst quarter since 2022, despite a surge in volatility.

images.alt_text: NEW YORK, NEW YORK - MARCH 25: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange during morning trading on March 25, 2025 in New York City. Stocks continued to rise a day after the Dow Jones closed over 600 points as the market anticipates President Donald Trump's plan to possibly hold back from implementing some of his wide-ranging tariff plans.   Michael M. Santiago/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Michael M. Santiago / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: ‘A Working Man’ tops North America box office as ‘Snow White’ ticket sales melt
summary: Jason Statham's action film "A Working Man" topped North America's box office with an estimated $15.2 million, surpassing Disney's "Snow White" remake, which saw a significant drop in ticket sales from $45 million to $14.2 million. "Snow White" is the year's first major box office disappointment, while other new releases, including "The Chosen: Last Supper Part I" and "The Woman in the Yard," performed well, with "Death of a Unicorn" earning $5.8 million.

images.alt_text: Actress Rachel Zegler, who stars as Snow White, attends a premiere for the film in Los Angeles, California, March 15, 2025.

site_title: Stocks slide; bonds, gold buoyed as tariffs stoke recession fears
summary: Global share markets fell sharply on Monday as US President Donald Trump announced tariffs would cover all countries, sparking recession fears. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 290.65 points, or 0.68%, to 41,293.25, while the S&P 500 lost 56.93 points, or 1.01%, to 5,524.77. Gold prices surged to a new record, and sovereign bonds and the Japanese yen gained as investors sought safe havens. Economists warn of a higher risk of a recession, with Goldman Sachs now predicting a 35% chance of a US recession.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks initially jumped last September due to optimism over additional economic stimulus.

site_title: Sinarmas Land minorities should be incensed by lowball offer from its controlling shareholder
summary: Sinarmas Land, a Singapore-based property developer, has received a lowball offer from its controlling shareholder, Lyon Investments, which is linked to the Widjaja family. The offer price of S$0.31 per share is 12.7% above the current market price and a 73.9% discount to the company's net asset value (NAV) as of June 30, 2024. Minority shareholders are urged to be cautious, as the offer may not adequately compensate them for potential future value unlocking. The offer's success depends on the independent financial adviser's (IFA) opinion and the acceptance rate, with a 90% acceptance threshold allowing the offeror to compulsorily acquire the remaining shares and delist the company.

site_title: Renault, Nissan further loosen ties to support Japanese firm's turnaround
summary: Renault and Nissan have agreed to further amend their 20-year-old partnership to allow for a 10% shareholding, down from 15%, to aid Nissan's recovery under new CEO Ivan Espinosa. Nissan will also exit its investment in Renault's electric vehicle unit Ampere and cease car production in India, focusing on sales and service. Renault plans to buy out Nissan's majority stake in their Indian business, with the deal expected to be completed by the end of the first half of this year.

images.alt_text: Nissan Motor incoming Chief Executive Officer Ivan Espinosa wants to cut development for the first car in a family of cars to 37 months, while the second car or third car would take just 30 months.

site_title: Oil prices climb 2% to five-week high on Russia, Iran supply worries
summary: Oil prices rose 2% to a five-week high on Monday due to concerns over potential supply disruptions from US President Donald Trump's threats to impose tariffs on Russia and Iran. Brent futures increased $1.11 to $74.74 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude rose $2.12 to $71.48 a barrel. The rising risk of supply risks and potential trade wars are fueling market uncertainty, with some analysts predicting Trump may not follow through on his threats, limiting price gains.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump says: “If Russia and I are unable to make a deal on stopping the bloodshed in Ukraine, and if I think it was Russia’s fault ... I am going to put secondary tariffs on oil, on all oil coming out of Russia."

The industry is still benefitting from disruptions to trade flows ranging from tariffs and sanctions to the crisis in the Red Sea, while the biggest players are also beginning to reap the rewards of billions of dollars invested in assets and diversification into new markets, helping to cushion the decline in trading profits.

site_title: Failure not always a stepping stone to success
summary: Singapore's increasing corporate bankruptcies are not a natural result of entrepreneurship, but rather a sign of a flawed system that fails to support entrepreneurs. The assumption that all business failures are learning experiences ignores the harsh reality for many business owners who struggle to recover. Failure can have severe personal, financial, and structural consequences, particularly for those who fund their ventures with personal savings or loans. A smarter approach to entrepreneurship should focus on providing access to better financial knowledge, business acumen, and mental resilience to ensure that entrepreneurs can take calculated risks and build sustainable businesses.

site_title: US tariffs causing anxiety but no ‘dramatic’ economic impact: IMF chief
summary: US tariffs under President Donald Trump are causing "a lot of anxiety" but are not expected to have a dramatic global economic impact, according to IMF Managing Director Kristalina Georgieva. The IMF may downgrade its global economic forecast to 3.3% this year, but does not predict a recession. Despite market turmoil and a decline in US consumer confidence, recent data shows no warning signs for the American economy. Georgieva notes that the tariffs are forcing countries to take steps to build resilience through their own policies.

site_title: Heart-throb Richard Chamberlain, star of ‘The Thorn Birds’, dies aged 90
summary: Richard Chamberlain, the 1960s heart-throb and star of TV dramas "The Thorn Birds" and "Shogun," has died at 90. He passed away in Hawaii on March 29 due to complications from a stroke. Chamberlain's six-decade career spanned theatre, films, and television, earning him the nickname "king of the mini-series." He was nominated for four Emmys and appeared in iconic roles such as Dr. Kildare, Captain von Trapp, and Hamlet. Chamberlain publicly revealed his homosexuality at 68, finding relief and acceptance in his later years.

images.alt_text: Emergency medical workers pronounced Michelle Trachtenberg dead without giving a cause. Police said foul play was not suspected.
Roberta Flack in recent years had lost her ability to sing because of ALS, known as Lou Gehrig’s disease, which she was diagnosed with in 2022.

site_title: Singapore companies in Myanmar, Thailand largely unaffected by earthquake
summary: A strong earthquake in Myanmar, one of the strongest in a century, occurred on Mar 28, causing widespread damage and over 1,700 deaths. The quake also affected Thailand, with a skyscraper in Bangkok collapsing and at least 18 people killed. However, Singapore companies operating in Myanmar and Thailand reported minimal disruptions, with only minor damage to properties and a few staff members injured. Most businesses, including banks and conglomerates, have resumed operations, with some expecting short-term disruptions due to critical infrastructure damage.

images.alt_text: International tourist arrivals are expected to drop by 10-15 per cent or even more in the next two weeks as the 7.7 earthquake on Friday (Mar 28) shook buildings in Bangkok and other Thai tourist hot spots, spooking prospective travellers, the Thai Hotels Association says.
Rescue personnel at the site of a building that collapsed following a strong earthquake, in Bangkok.
Rescue teams at a construction site where a building collapsed in Bangkok after an earthquake. A powerful earthquake had rocked central Myanmar earlier.

site_title: Housing dream turned nightmare weighs on Australian voters ahead of national election
summary: Australia's centre-left Labor government faces a hung parliament in the May 3 national election, with working-class seats in Sydney and Melbourne forecast to be lost. The pursuit of the "Great Australian Dream" of home ownership is hurting families with high mortgage payments, as the Reserve Bank raised interest rates 13 times since 2022. Housing and living costs top voter concerns, with Labor promising energy bill rebates, tax cuts, and free doctor visits, while the conservative Liberal and National coalition vows to introduce a "Lower Immigration and More Homes for Australians Bill."

images.alt_text: australia housing Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg

site_title: France’s Le Pen defiant after five year election ban
summary: French far-right leader Marine Le Pen was convicted and banned from running for president in 2027 for five years after a court found her guilty of creating fake jobs at the EU parliament to employ assistants working for her party. Le Pen vowed to appeal the decision and maintain her political ambitions, despite being deemed "eliminated" from the presidential race. The conviction has been condemned by the Kremlin, Elon Musk, and hard-right European politicians, with some calling for the decision to be overturned at the ballot box.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde speaks to the media following the Governing Council's monthly monetary policy meeting in Frankfurt, Germany, March 6, 2025. REUTERS/Jana Rodenbusch/File Photo

President of the parliamentary group of the French far-right Rassemblement National (RN) party, Marine Le Pen (L) arrives her lawyer Rodolphe Bosselut (C) at the Paris courthouse for her trial verdict on suspicion of embezzlement of European public funds, in Paris, on March 31, 2025. A French court sentenced on March 31, 2025 far-right leader Marine Le Pen to a five-year ban on running for office with immediate effect, throwing into doubt her bid to stand for President in 2027. (Photo by Alain JOCARD / AFP)

site_title: GE2025: Shanmugam on former NMPs joining political parties; ex-AIC CEO spotted in East Coast GRC
summary: Minister for Law K Shanmugam confirmed that Nominated Members of Parliament (NMPs) can join political parties and run for election under Singapore's Constitution. He emphasized that NMPs must be independent and chosen for their character. Following NMPs Raj Joshua Thomas and Syed Harun Alhabsyi's recent resignations, Shanmugam noted that constitutional documents had envisioned NMPs joining parties and participating in elections. He declined to comment on whether fellow NMP Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim would be fielded elsewhere, stating he was "unlikely to be here."

images.alt_text: Gabriel Lam (left), chief operating officer of Shalom International Movers, and Ng Shi Xuan, director of battery company Powermark Battery and Hardware, at the OCBC SeniorCare event at Bukit Canberra.

From left: Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim, Nee Soon GRC MP; Marine Parade MP Tan See Leng; Diana Pang, chairman of Fengshan Women's Executive Committee and People's Association Women's Integration Network Council; and Geylang Serai MP Fahmi Aliman at Eunos on March 30.
This is in line with the party’s practice of refreshing between a quarter and a third of its slate each term.

(From left) MP Louis Ng, Dr Syed Harun Alhabsyi, Law and Home Affairs Minister K. Shanmugam, MPs Derrick Goh and Carrie Tan, and Mr Jackson Lam speaking to the media outside Ahmad Ibrahim Mosque on March 31.

site_title: More funds and products expected, as market awaits details about Singapore’s S$5 billion equities push
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has announced a S$5 billion Equity Market Development Programme (EQDP) to boost the local fund management industry and trading liquidity. Analysts expect more funds to launch, with some citing tax incentives and a focus on Singapore stocks as key draws. However, challenges remain, including limited diversification opportunities and relatively lower returns compared to broader indices. Industry players note that proper execution and investor protection are crucial for the programme's success, and its impact will depend on a proper understanding of the scope of the measures.

images.alt_text: S-Reits could lose out from family office investment scheme exclusion.
Singapore's assets under management grew exponentially from S$25.6 billion in 1991 to S$5.41 trillion as at 2023.
A deeper look at the Straits Times Index's gains this year suggests the rally is primarily driven by banks.
Tan Chong Lee, chief executive of 65 Equity Partners, said: "Our goal is not to just focus on domestic businesses, but to open up the funnel."

site_title: Chinese stocks power ahead of emerging peers amid AI frenzy
summary: Chinese stocks have surged over the past six months, breaking a multi-year slump, while broader emerging-market equities have largely flat-lined. The divergence is attributed to a tech frenzy driving Chinese gains, rather than an improving economy. The MSCI China Index has jumped 30% since August, while emerging markets excluding China have dropped 7%. This divergence is unlikely to have a significant spillover impact on other emerging markets, according to experts. The Chinese stock rally is driven by consumer spending and optimism, but is threatened by the potential for higher US tariffs.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Investors wait for China's stock market to open in front of an electronic board at a brokerage house in Beijing, China, January 8, 2016. REUTERS/Jason Lee

site_title: UK’s Starmer in ‘productive’ talks with Trump before crunch week
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer held "productive" talks with US President Donald Trump on Sunday, discussing a potential economic prosperity deal ahead of the looming US tariffs. The UK seeks an exemption or reduction in tariffs, which Trump branded "Liberation Day" and will be unveiled on Wednesday. The move could harm UK growth and lead to tax increases in the autumn. Starmer and Trump agreed to continue negotiations and keep up collective pressure on Russian leader Vladimir Putin.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves speaks about her plans for Britain's economy in Eynsham, Britain, January 29, 2025. REUTERS/Peter Cziborra/Pool/File Photo

site_title: Straits Times Index: Race to 4,000 points
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) has broken the 4,000-mark for the first time in its 59-year history, closing at 3,972.43 points on March 28. Market watchers believe this marks a significant psychological threshold, indicating strong investor confidence and a favorable economic climate. The STI has been on a tear in the past year, driven by optimism over the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) measures and the Fed's interest rate cuts. Analysts expect the STI to continue riding above 4,000 points sooner rather than later.

site_title: PAP’s slate of new faces shapes up with 30 likely names; party could field younger group, more women
summary: The People's Action Party (PAP) is set to field a new slate of candidates for the 2025 Singapore general election, with around 30 new faces, including senior civil servants, C-suite executives, and long-serving grassroots volunteers. The average age of the candidates is around 40, with about 40% being female, a significant increase from previous years. The party is aiming to refresh between a quarter and a third of its slate each term, as per its practice. The new slate is expected to reflect the priorities of Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, who emphasized leadership renewal and increasing female representation in Parliament.

images.alt_text: From left: Muhammad Faishal Ibrahim, Nee Soon GRC MP; Marine Parade MP Tan See Leng; Diana Pang, chairman of Fengshan Women's Executive Committee and People's Association Women's Integration Network Council; and Geylang Serai MP Fahmi Aliman at Eunos on March 30.

site_title: Retail investors likely to face higher fees and less transparency in private market funds
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has launched a consultation on opening private market funds to retail investors. While private assets can offer higher returns over the long term, retail investors may face higher fees, less transparency, and less liquidity. This move aims to give retail investors more options to invest in the fast-growing private assets market.

images.alt_text: MAS seeks feedback on proposals giving retail investors access to private market assets

site_title: Regulators flag serious compliance issues at Australian Exchange
summary: Australia's markets regulator and central bank have identified serious compliance issues at exchange operator ASX related to trade settlement, which need immediate action. The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) and Australian Securities and Investments Commission (ASIC) highlighted concerns over ASX's remediation actions following a December incident, including settlement delays. ASIC directed ASX to engage an expert to review its Clearing House Electronic Subregister System. The regulators' assessment has been lowered, emphasizing the need for ASX to resolve the issues to maintain trust in the country's main exchange.

images.alt_text: ASX’s group executive of listings, Blair Beaton, said dual-class shares had not been allowed in Australia previously which was placing the domestic market at a disadvantage compared to its major global rivals.

site_title: Mapletree Industrial Trust banks on diversification, balance to deliver sustainable returns
summary: Mapletree Industrial Trust, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, is focusing on diversification and balance to deliver sustainable returns. The trust's CEO, Lily Ler, stated that while the demand for data centers is growing, MIT is not aiming to become a 100% data center Reit. Instead, the trust will continue to maintain its Singapore industrial portfolio, which has seen resilience through various cycles. MIT plans to grow its data center business through acquisitions, particularly in Europe and Asia, with a focus on hyperscale and colocation-provider tenants. The trust aims to recycle capital from divesting non-core properties and redeveloping data centers with lower power capacity.

images.alt_text: Gross revenue was up 2 per cent to S$177.3 million for the quarter, from S$173.9 million in the year-ago period.

khls18 - OCBC Centre South in the foreground.


Credit:  GOOGLE MAPS
OVER the five trading sessions from Mar 7 to 13, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks.

site_title: World powers focus on resource-rich Central Asia
summary: World powers, including the EU, US, Japan, and Russia, are focusing on Central Asia due to its rich natural resources, particularly critical minerals for clean energy technologies. The region has major environmental challenges and a poor human rights record. China and Russia have long-standing interests, with China becoming the region's leading trade partner. The EU is promoting democracy and regional economic integration, with a focus on the Middle Corridor transport route. The bloc is hosting its first summit with Central Asia, showcasing its Global Gateway initiative, which aims to disburse $300 billion by 2027. Other powers, including the US, Japan, and Turkey, are also engaging with the region, intensifying competition for influence.

images.alt_text: epa11401536 South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol, alongside first lady Kim Keon Hee, waves before boarding his plane as they embark on state visits to Turkmenistan, Kazakhstan and Uzbekistan through 15 June at Seoul Air Base in Seongnam, south of Seoul, South Korea, 10 June 2024.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT
ST Engineering makes foray into Central Asia with Kazakhstan defence vehicle contract

site_title: Germany's DHL to acquire US pharma logistics firm Cryopdp
summary: DHL has agreed to acquire US pharmaceutical logistics firm Cryopdp, part of its efforts to grow in the pharma sector. The deal, valued at a three-digit million-euro sum, will strengthen DHL's Life Sciences and Healthcare segments. The companies also announced a strategic partnership to enhance supply chain service offerings for the global life sciences and healthcare sector, subject to regulatory approvals. The acquisition is expected to boost DHL's revenue in the pharma sector, which generated $5.41 billion in 2024.

site_title: ECB’s Lagarde says keeping inflation in check is a ‘constant battle’
summary: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde emphasized the ongoing battle to keep inflation at 2% amid uncertainty from US President Donald Trump's planned trade policy announcement. Despite six interest rate cuts since June, policymakers remain divided on future moves, with Lagarde urging caution and analysis of data. Lagarde believes that Trump's trade policies will harm the global economy, but sees the situation as an opportunity for Europe to take steps towards independence in defense, energy, and finance.

images.alt_text: The commission is set to publish a report next year on the banking system in the single market, including on its competitiveness.

site_title: Chinese contractor of collapsed Bangkok building under scrutiny
summary: A 30-storey building in Bangkok, Thailand, collapsed on March 28 after a 7.7-magnitude earthquake, killing over 100 people and injuring many more. The building, under construction by China Railway No10 Engineering Group, has drawn criticism for its poor construction quality and raised questions about the awarding of major government contracts to Chinese companies. An investigation team has collected samples of construction materials and is focusing on the quality of steel bars used in the structure. The Thai government has ordered a committee of experts to investigate the cause of the collapse and promised to hold accountable those responsible.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: 4 China state banks plan 520b yuan placements to add capital
summary: China's four largest state banks plan a total of up to 520 billion yuan in private placements to boost core tier-1 capital, following the government's pledge to issue 500 billion yuan in special sovereign bonds. The banks, including Bank of Communications and China Construction Bank, will sell shares to the finance ministry and other investors at a premium between 8.8% and 21.5% above their closing levels. The move aims to strengthen the banking system and support the economy, as lenders face record-low margins and rising bad debt.

images.alt_text: Banks typically remove bad debt from their balance sheets by writing them off or selling them to bad asset managers.

site_title: Europe: Shares fall, record monthly losses as Trump touts sweeping tariffs
summary: European stocks plummeted 1.51% to 533.92 points, extending losses to a fourth straight session, due to US President Donald Trump's announcement of sweeping tariffs on all countries, sparking fears of a global economic slowdown. Investors fled to safe-haven assets like gold and the Japanese yen. Analysts predict uncertainty and volatility will persist, with Goldman Sachs lowering its GDP forecast and adding a rate cut. Despite a 5.2% gain in the first quarter, the Stoxx 600 index is at its lowest close in two months.

images.alt_text: German share price index DAX graph is pictured at the stock exchange in Frankfurt, Germany, February 13, 2025.    REUTERS/Staff
The Dow Jones Industrial Average reversed an earlier decline to close 1.0 per cent higher at 42,001.76, as did the broad-based S&P 500 Index, which gained 0.6 per cent to 5,611.85 on Monday.

site_title: Clear policies, financing needed for green shipping fuels: maritime players
summary: Industry players emphasize the need for clear regulations and finance mechanisms to boost green shipping fuels, such as ammonia and methanol, to drive a sustainable energy transition. A strong outcome at the IMO's MEPC 83 meeting, set for April, is seen as crucial to sending a market signal on sustainability. Industry leaders stress the importance of carbon pricing and early investments in green fuels to create price parity between fossil and green fuels, and to avoid a delayed energy transition.

images.alt_text: A Pyxis electric harbour craft charging at Marina South Pier.

site_title: South Korea’s short-selling ban has ended; will global investors flock back?
summary: South Korea's 17-month ban on short selling has ended, allowing the US$1.7 trillion stock market to open up to international investors. The move is expected to progress the country's bid to be upgraded from emerging to developed-market status, as many global investors allocate assets based on this classification. The resumption of short selling may improve market access and attract more foreign investors, potentially boosting the country's economy.

images.alt_text: epa11972963 A financial monitor at the Korea Exchange in Seoul, South Korea, 19 March, 2025. Korea's KOSPI hits an intraday high of 2,625.59, up 13.25 points, in early trading, led by tech and bio stocks despite Wall Street losses.  EPA-EFE/YONHAP SOUTH KOREA OUT

site_title: Treasuries are the standout play as Trump’s trade war heats up
summary: US Treasuries have outperformed stocks this quarter, heading for a more than 2% gain, as the intensifying global trade war heightens risks of a sharp growth slowdown in the US. The S&P 500 fell about 5% during the same period. Investors are shifting their asset allocation to bonds over global equities due to policy uncertainties and downside risks to economic growth. The yield gap between five-year and 30-year bonds has widened to its widest level since 2022, as investors bet on tariffs boosting inflation and dragging down economic growth.

images.alt_text: The US dollar remains solidly entrenched as the world’s key currency, used for the majority of central bank reserves and for the purchase of commodities such as oil, in large part because no significant alternative has emerged.

site_title: Thai authorities probe collapse at quake-hit construction site
summary: Thai authorities are investigating the collapse of a Bangkok construction site that killed at least 18 people and left dozens missing. The 7.7-magnitude earthquake, centered in Myanmar, caused widespread destruction, but Bangkok's high-rise buildings were largely unscathed. Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra has expressed concerns over the collapse, questioning the design and material quality of the building. An investigation into the incident is underway, with a group of experts to report back to the prime minister this week, and concerns have also been raised about Thailand's emergency response system.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Condominium buildings are seen in Bangkok, Thailand, September 25, 2018. REUTERS/Athit Perawongmetha/File Photo

site_title: As Trump sinks the US dollar, a once-unthinkable worry grips markets
summary: US President Donald Trump's escalating tariffs and efforts to roll back globalization are causing confidence in the US dollar to wane, leading to a decline in its value against other currencies. The dollar has dropped against all but a handful of major currencies over the last three months, with the Bloomberg dollar index down nearly 3%. Speculators are betting against the US dollar, and investors are shifting cash to European stocks and other havens. The US dollar's central role in the global financial system is being reevaluated, and some experts warn that it could lose its safe-haven status, although it remains a key currency due to its liquidity.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which had rallied strongly between September and January, is headed for a roughly 4 per cent drop. It was last up 0.05 per cent at 104.28.

site_title: Temasek, GIC to buy ‘significant stake’ in clinical research provider Novotech
summary: Temasek and GIC have agreed to acquire a significant stake in clinical research provider Novotech, with existing investor TPG also reinvesting through its TPG Asia fund. The deal aims to help Novotech pursue organic growth and merger and acquisition opportunities, with the fresh funds earmarked to accelerate global growth. Novotech, which provides access to clinical trial destinations and patient populations for biotech and pharmaceutical companies, is well-positioned for growth in the Asia-Pacific market, where demand for clinical trials is forecast to grow at 15% per year.

65 Equity manages about US$3.3 billion and typically writes cheques of US$50 million to US$150 million to back family-owned and founder-led companies.

site_title: Aid rushes into Myanmar after earthquake kills over 1,600, ravages cities
summary: A 7.7-magnitude earthquake has struck Myanmar, killing over 1,600 people and injuring 3,400, with the death toll potentially rising to 10,000. The quake has ravaged cities, damaged critical infrastructure, and slowed humanitarian operations. International aid has poured in, with neighbours Thailand, India, China, and Singapore sending warships, aircraft, and rescue personnel. The US has pledged $2 million in aid, while the Indian army plans to set up a field hospital in Mandalay. The opposition National Unity Government has called for a two-week ceasefire to focus on rescue operations.

images.alt_text: Commuters drive past a building that collapsed, in the aftermath of a strong earthquake, in Mandalay, Myanmar, March 30, 2025. REUTERS/Stringer

International tourist arrivals are expected to drop by 10-15 per cent or even more in the next two weeks as the 7.7 earthquake on Friday (Mar 28) shook buildings in Bangkok and other Thai tourist hot spots, spooking prospective travellers, the Thai Hotels Association says.

site_title: Giving a leg up for small businesses using sustainability
summary: Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can benefit from impact investing, with Bitcoin cited as a successful example of a completely impact-focused investment. To create a positive impact, SMEs must define philanthropy, ESG, and impact investing, and provide clarity on their mission and values. The Sustainable Seedling Summit highlighted the importance of these concepts, particularly for SMEs, which account for 71% of national employment. A new project, Sustainable Oil Palm Replanting in Indonesia (Sopri), aims to support 400 smallholder farmers in sustainable oil palm replanting, providing financing and resources to promote responsible land use and prevent deforestation.

site_title: Trump threatens Russia oil penalties in bid to persuade Putin
summary: US President Donald Trump is threatening to impose "secondary tariffs" on Russian oil exports if Vladimir Putin refuses a ceasefire with Ukraine, potentially disrupting global oil markets and adding to inflationary pressures. Trump also maintained pressure on Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to agree to a deal giving the US access to Ukraine's resources. The threat comes amid a recent surge in Russian crude exports and amid efforts to end the war in Ukraine.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 77 cents, or 1.05 per cent, at US$73.79 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore’s carbon credit tender receives bids totalling more than S$1.3 billion
summary: The Singapore government's tender for carbon credits received bids totaling over S$1.3 billion, with Trafigura's carbon trading arm emerging as the highest bidder at close to S$300 million. The government aims to offset 500,000 tonnes of emissions with nature-based carbon credits, meeting its national climate target of 60 million tonnes by 2030. The tender was the first of its kind, with the government launching a request for proposal in September last year to procure carbon credits.

site_title: Temasek weighs sale of testing firm Element Materials
summary: Temasek Holdings is weighing the sale of Element Materials Technology, a UK-based testing company it acquired in 2022 for over $7 billion, including debt. The Singapore state investment company is working with advisers to solicit interest from strategic parties. Element has over 9,000 employees and 270 laboratories in 30 countries, primarily serving the aerospace and defense industries. The sale is at an early stage, with no certainty of a deal.

site_title: S-Reits with China retail assets log mixed 2024 performance, may benefit from consumption push
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) with retail assets in China posted a mixed 2024 performance, with stable occupancies but negative rental reversions. Despite near-term headwinds, some S-Reits reported improvements in shopper traffic and tenant sales. China's retail sales grew 4% year-on-year in January-to-February, and forecasts predict 5% growth in 2025. S-Reits with retail assets are expected to benefit from government initiatives boosting domestic consumption and long-term retail demand.

site_title: Trump signs order aimed at attracting corporate investments of more than US$1 billion
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order creating the United States Investment Accelerator within the Commerce Department to encourage large investments of over $1 billion in the US, aiming to reduce regulations and speed up permitting. The order aims to bolster domestic semiconductor production and follows Trump's criticism of the Chips Act, a bipartisan $52 billion program signed by his predecessor Joe Biden. The new office will deliver benefits for taxpayers and facilitate collaboration across national laboratories and state governments.

site_title: Japan's parliament passes Budget a day before new fiscal year starts
summary: Japan's parliament passed the $770 billion Budget Bill on March 31, just a day before the new fiscal year starts, after Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba's minority coalition revised the budget twice due to opposition demands. The budget was amended to include higher household subsidies and a halt on raising high medical expenses, sparking internal party opposition. Despite the passage, Ishiba's coalition faces a low approval rating and potential defeat in the upcoming July upper house election, potentially forcing it to form alliances with opposition parties.

images.alt_text: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba speaks during a press conference at the prime minister's official residence in Tokyo on October 9, 2024. site_title: What Warren Buffett and Li Ka-shing hoarding cash tells us
summary: Warren Buffett and Li Ka-shing, two renowned investors, are hoarding cash amid speculation of a potential financial downturn. Berkshire Hathaway's cash pile is a record $334 billion, and CK Hutchison Holdings is deleveraging, potentially becoming debt-free after selling its ports to a BlackRock-led consortium. Both Buffett and Li have a history of selling at the right time, with Buffett's investments yielding over $30 billion in profit and Li's divestments, such as selling a skyscraper in Hong Kong, also yielding significant returns. The pair's caution suggests that good deals may be available after market corrections, but the reasons behind their decisions remain unclear.

images.alt_text: The decision to hire law firm Paul Hastings marked a shift for CK Hutchison – the Hong Kong conglomerate has worked on many of its deals with law firms such as Freshfields and Linklaters before.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens sharply lower on tariff worries
summary: US stock indexes opened sharply lower on March 31, with the S&P 500 losing 1.01% to 5,524.77 and the Nasdaq Composite falling 1.58% to 17,039.68. The decline was attributed to mounting concerns over the Trump administration's upcoming tariff plans, which investors believe could harm the global economy.

site_title: China, Japan, South Korea renew free-trade call, now to build ties
summary: China, Japan, and South Korea have reaffirmed their commitment to a free trade agreement, despite US tariffs set to take effect on car imports on April 3. The three countries agreed to deepen economic ties and cooperate on trade, amid rising tensions with the US. The move contrasts with the US' "America First" policies, with China seeking to promote openness and cooperation. The nations also pledged to strengthen the Regional Comprehensive Economic Partnership and enhance trade and investment in Asia. The meeting comes ahead of a potential escalation of US tariffs, which could impact sectors including semiconductors and pharmaceuticals.

images.alt_text: The stock market stumble also came as investors digested inflation data released earlier on Friday.

site_title: South Korea short-selling resumption set to entice global funds
summary: South Korea is set to lift its 17-month ban on short selling on Monday, allowing hedge funds and global investment banks to resume trading strategies that could boost liquidity and help the country's bid to be upgraded to developed status. The move is expected to attract global investment, with several firms planning to buy more Korean shares, and could lead to a narrowing of the "Korea discount" in stock prices. Analysts predict heightened volatility in the near term, but long-term benefits are expected to outweigh any near-term volatility, with some firms forecasting a 4% gain in the Kospi stock benchmark.

images.alt_text: Singapore shares close lower despite earlier crossing 4,000-mark for the first time

site_title: Marine Le Pen barred from 2027 French presidency run
summary: Marine Le Pen, leader of the National Rally party, was barred from running in the 2027 French presidential election after being found guilty of embezzlement and diverting millions of euros in EU funds. She was sentenced to 2 years in prison, with 2 more suspended, and given a 5-year election ban. This ruling complicates her ambitions to succeed Emmanuel Macron in 2027, potentially opening a power vacuum within the French far-right.

site_title: OCBC commits S$2 million to support the elderly
summary: OCBC has launched the OCBC SeniorCare programme, committing over S$2 million to support over 180,000 seniors aged 60 and above over three years. The programme aims to empower the elderly through four essential pillars: health, wealth, literacy, and lifestyle. The initiatives will be progressively announced throughout its duration, covering solutions to pressing senior needs gleaned from the bank's data and feedback from staff and charity partners.

site_title: Singapore’s sustainability legal services market to treble to at least S$450 million by 2033: PwC study
summary: Singapore's sustainability legal services market is projected to treble to S$450-500 million by 2033, growing at a compound annual rate of 10% per annum, according to a PwC study. This growth is driven by new legal workstreams created by sustainability-related requirements, such as carbon markets and sustainability disputes, as well as additional requirements being introduced to existing legal work. Key areas of growth include green finance and capital projects, with opportunities expected to come from regulatory influence, incentives, and penalties, as well as Singapore lawyers' influence in South-east Asia.

images.alt_text: Aerial view of Kawasi Village on Obi Island, where Harita Nickel's operations are located.

Among the seven Asia-Pacific markets the report analysed, Australian companies had the highest number linking ESG metrics to executive pay at 92 per cent. This was followed by Singapore at 82 per cent, and then Japan at 74 per cent.

site_title: UBS has no intention of leaving Switzerland, says compliance chief
summary: UBS has no plans to leave Switzerland, according to the bank's compliance chief Markus Ronner. This comes amid debate on stricter regulation following UBS's acquisition of Credit Suisse two years ago. In a debate with lawmakers, Ronner stated UBS has a close relationship with its home country and "certainly has no plans to leave Switzerland." The bank has also floated the idea of capping the future size of its investment bank as a concession to tougher capital requirements.

site_title: Massive quake is latest blow to Thai tourism hit by safety woes
summary: A 7.7-magnitude earthquake in Thailand is expected to lead to a 10-15% drop in international tourist arrivals in the next two weeks, according to the Thai Hotels Association. The quake, which occurred on March 28, has shaken buildings in Bangkok and other tourist hotspots, causing safety concerns among prospective travelers. The tourism industry already faces dwindling Chinese visitors due to travel safety concerns, and the earthquake's impact is expected to hurt the economy, which relies on tourism for 13% of its GDP.

site_title: Airbus wins £150 million contract to land European rover on Mars
summary: Airbus has won a £150 million contract to develop a landing platform for the ExoMars mission, a UK-built rover aimed at searching for signs of life on Mars. The European Space Agency (ESA) awarded the deal, marking the first of its kind for Europe, and the contract will create about 200 jobs in the UK space sector. The rover, named Rosalind Franklin, will launch in 2028 and will be able to drill into the Martian surface to collect samples and record data, advancing Europe's space know-how and understanding of the solar system.

images.alt_text: The 17 new planes come on top of 21 737 MAX 8 aircraft which Japan Airlines ordered in March 2023.

site_title: Frasers Property ‘closely monitoring’ aftermath of Myanmar quake
summary: Frasers Property Ltd, a Singapore-listed company, is closely monitoring the aftermath of a 7.7 magnitude earthquake in Myanmar, which caused a skyscraper to collapse in Bangkok. The company's employees in Bangkok are safe, and its hospitality properties, including One Bangkok, have resumed operations. Detailed inspections are underway, with a focus on the safety and well-being of employees, tenants, and residents.

images.alt_text: 曼谷市中心的壹曼谷项目由泰国TCC资产和星狮地产联合发展，投资额达32亿美元。（星狮地产提供）
Rescue personnel at the site of a building that collapsed following a strong earthquake, in Bangkok.

site_title: Human activity disrupting ocean CO2 absorption: study
summary: Scientists estimate 30% of human-released carbon dioxide is absorbed by oceans, playing a crucial role in climate regulation. A new study finds commercial activities like bottom trawling and dredging disrupt this process, reducing ocean carbon absorption by 2-8 million tonnes of CO2 annually. These human activities limit the water's alkalinity, reducing its capacity to absorb carbon dioxide. The study suggests that managing economic activities can lead to "easy gains" in CO2 uptake, highlighting the need for better management to preserve the ocean's carbon sink efficiency.

images.alt_text: Icebergs and ice sheet in the Baffin Bay near Pituffik, Greenland on July 19, 2022. Global sea ice cover reached a historic low in February 2025, Europe's climate monitor said, with temperatures spiking up to 11 deg C above average near the North Pole as the world continued its persistent heat streak.

site_title: Trade uncertainty is increasing the risk of a US recession
summary: Trade uncertainty is heightening the risk of a US recession as the Trump administration's tariff plan remains unclear. Key industries, such as manufacturing and consumer goods, are struggling to adjust to potential price hikes, leading to stockpiling and delayed orders. Consumer sentiment is also plummeting, with a recent survey showing over 70% of Americans anticipating tariffs and driving up living expenses. Economists warn that uncertainty is creating a self-fulfilling prophecy, with fears of a recession potentially leading to a downturn.

site_title: Commodity traders still rake in billions as profit bonanza wanes
summary: Commodity traders, such as Vitol, Trafigura, Mercuria Energy, and Gunvor, continue to generate significant profits despite lower earnings compared to the peak years of 2022-2023. The industry benefits from disruptions to trade flows and investments in assets and diversification into new markets, cushioning the decline in trading profits. While profits are lower, the largest players remain among the highest-earning companies in history, with combined profits of over $50 billion in 2022 and 2023.

images.alt_text: The move is likely to reduce the government’s future obligations and minimise risks related to gold prices.

site_title: Why tariff fears have copper following gold to record high
summary: US copper prices have reached record highs due to fears of tariffs on copper imports. Following President Trump's executive order to investigate potential tariffs, copper shipments to the US accelerated, with 500,000 tonnes en route in late March, exceeding normal monthly volumes. The tariffs could be introduced sooner than expected, potentially leading to a painful end for traders. Copper stocks at the Comex reached multiyear highs, and analysts predict the premium over international benchmark prices will widen further. The tariffs aim to revive the US copper industry and ensure security of supply for this critical material.

images.alt_text: BYD electric cars waiting to be exported in Shandong, China. US President Donald Trump's tariffs is set to take effect on April 2 - with duties to be collected from April 3 - and impact foreign-made cars and light trucks.

site_title: GE2025: Tan See Leng introduces potential candidate for Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC
summary: Singapore's upcoming General Election 2025 may see the introduction of a new face in the Marine Parade-Braddell Heights GRC. Business development director Diana Pang, a long-time volunteer in the East Coast GRC, has been identified as a potential candidate by Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng. Pang chairs various community initiatives and has 19 years of experience in audit and business advisory. The introduction comes amidst electoral boundary changes, which may impact the incumbent People's Action Party (PAP) team. The PAP and the Workers' Party are expected to contest the GRC, setting the stage for a multi-cornered fight.

images.alt_text: (Clockwise from top left) Mr Jeffrey Siow, Mr Dinesh Vasu Dash, Ms Jasmin Lau, Mr Shawn Loh, Ms Goh Hanyan and Mr Foo Cexiang.

site_title: Square pegs in round holes – mental health and performance at the workplace
summary: Mental health has become a critical issue in the modern workplace, with increasing awareness of its impact on employee well-being and productivity. Despite this, stigma and fear of judgment often prevent employees from discussing their mental health concerns openly. Companies like Salesforce, Unilever, and EY have implemented transparent promotion frameworks and comprehensive mental health training programs to foster a supportive and inclusive work environment. These initiatives aim to reduce stigma, promote empathy, and improve mental health outcomes, resulting in increased employee engagement, retention, and productivity.

images.alt_text: Leaders who understand the value of mental health strategies can foster a supportive work culture that encourages open conversations about mental health.

A study conducted by the American Bar Association and Hazelden Betty Ford Foundation revealed some rather startling statistics: About 28 per cent of lawyers struggle with some level of depression, 19 per cent experience symptoms of anxiety, and 21 per cent qualify as problem drinkers.
A recent casual question by Elmo on X about people's well-being elicited an unexpected torrent of responses.
Kindness is a strength, a management tool.

site_title: DBS Foundation commits S$7.3 million for new programme to support 6,000 vulnerable seniors
summary: DBS Foundation has launched a S$7.3 million programme to support 6,000 vulnerable seniors in Singapore over the next two years. The programme aims to tackle social isolation and insufficient nutrition by providing two nutritious meals every week, activities, workshops, and supermarket shopping trips. The initiative follows DBS Foundation's efforts to focus on ageing, as Singapore is expected to become a super-aged society by next year. The programme is part of DBS Foundation's SG60 celebrations, which have already committed S$3.8 million and deployed 2,000 staff volunteers to run community markets across 24 towns.

images.alt_text: POSB's Support Your Heartlands carnival promotes financial literacy to families and seniors in the heartlands.

site_title: Privatisation on the horizon for S-Reits with low liquidity, mostly overseas assets
summary: The Singapore real estate investment trust (S-Reit) market is undergoing consolidation with possible exits of smaller Reits and listings of bigger ones. Observers say those with low liquidity and mostly overseas assets are more vulnerable to privatisation. Higher interest rates may make under-valued Reits more attractive for privatisation, with some analysts predicting the sector could consolidate and become more vibrant over the next five years.

site_title: Deloitte veteran Chaly Mah to take over as chairman of NEA
summary: Former Deloitte Singapore chairman Chaly Mah will take over as chairman of the National Environmental Agency (NEA) on April 1, 2025, succeeding Lee Chuan Seng. Mah's expertise spans various industries and he will also become the new chairman of PUB. Chan Lai Fung, a 36-year veteran in the public service, will take over as PUB chair, bringing diverse expertise from her previous roles. Both appointments will take effect on April 1, 2025.
