site_title: Women and finance: How embracing risk can unlock greater success
summary: Women tend to change jobs less frequently, limiting opportunities to renegotiate pay. Embracing calculated risks, such as investing in alternative assets or making bold career moves, is crucial for success. Historically, women have been perceived as more risk-averse, but this can lead to stagnation and underperformance. Professionals who take thoughtful risks are better positioned to drive innovation, achieve financial independence, and create lasting impact in today's competitive landscape. By embracing risk, women can unlock greater success and overcome the limitations of being risk-averse.

images.alt_text: For women, the smartest financial and career decisions often come from embracing change. and making courageous choices.

site_title: GE2025: COO of Shalom Movers, director of battery business introduced as new faces for PAP in Sembawang GRC
summary: Minister for Health Ong Ye Kung announced two new candidates for Sembawang GRC ahead of the upcoming General Election. They are Gabriel Lam, COO of Shalom International Movers, and Ng Shi Xuan, director of Powermark Battery and Hardware. The candidates were introduced at an OCBC SeniorCare event at Bukit Canberra, where they met with elderly residents and expressed their excitement to represent the constituency. The Sembawang GRC currently consists of five divisions and will be split into a single-member constituency at the general election by November.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after data fans inflation worries
summary: Wall Street's main indexes fell on Friday, March 28, as data showed underlying price pressures rose more than expected, fueling concerns about inflation. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 53.9 points, or 0.13%, to 42,245.82, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also fell. This comes amid the Trump administration's tariff policies, which are expected to further stoke inflation.

site_title: Yen gains, gold hits peak as tariff uncertainties lift safe-haven bids
summary: The Japanese yen gained 0.37% to 149.280 against the US dollar, reaching a 148.7 high, amid uncertainty over US tariffs and inflation. Gold hit a fresh peak of $3,128.06, while the euro is set for a 4.5% rise this quarter. The US dollar index remained stable, and markets are cautious ahead of US payrolls data and the announcement of reciprocal tariffs. This uncertainty has led to a shift away from risky assets and towards safe-haven assets like gold and the yen.

images.alt_text: The euro was 0.3 per cent higher at US$1.0787 after touching a three-week low of US$1.0733 in early trading.

site_title: PM Wong committed to govt-citizen partnership, says ‘more open society will strengthen Singapore’
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of a more open and participatory society, stating that a stronger social compact and deeper sense of belonging can be achieved through citizen engagement. He highlighted the government's commitment to partnering with Singaporeans, citing examples of policy changes and initiatives shaped by citizen suggestions. Wong acknowledged the need for healthy debates and disagreements, while emphasizing the importance of unity and cohesion. He called for continued engagement, including youth panels, citizens' panels, and community projects, to create a better future for Singapore.

images.alt_text: In the past two years, there have been various forms of assistance to support its citizens with immediate cost-of-living concerns, with more help expected at the upcoming Budget, he says
He is making great effort to renew the leadership team and the party, PM Wong tells media in an interview capping of his visit to Hanoi.

site_title: NCSS, social service agencies push for more regular volunteerism
summary: The National Council of Social Service (NCSS) aims to increase the number of regular volunteers in Singapore to one in two by 2030, up from the current one in three. A 2024 study found that regular volunteers have a higher quality of life, with better psychological well-being and close social relationships. NCSS is partnering with social service agencies and corporates to develop robust volunteer management practices and create long-term commitment. This includes the "Project V" initiative, which matches corporates with social service agencies to provide sustained volunteer support, and the "Volunteer Champions" programme, which engages regular volunteers from various business units.

images.alt_text: Roots & Wings, developed by Chang Mei Yee (left) and Liang Yanjie, has won Singapore Design Awards 2025.
Outgoing chief executive of DBS Piyush Gupta says companies should take a longer-term approach to CSR.

site_title: Indonesians are feeling market gloom ahead of major Eid holiday
summary: Indonesia's market turmoil ahead of the Eid al-Fitr holiday has led to economic worries and reduced consumer confidence. The Jakarta Composite Index is among the world's worst performers this year, with the rupiah reaching its weakest level since the Asian financial crisis. Retail sales are expected to contract, and consumer goods imports shrank 20% in the first two months of the year. Many Indonesians are postponing spending, including travel, and businesses are cutting costs due to weak nickel prices and rising raw material costs.

images.alt_text: Stock market information displayed at the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. The benchmark Jakarta Composite Index was mixed in early trading Wednesday, as investors digested the Tuesday selloff. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Thailand passes quake stress test, but property and investor cracks show
summary: Thailand's capital narrowly escaped significant damage from a 7.7-magnitude earthquake on March 28, but the collapse of a 30-storey building under construction in Bangkok has raised concerns about the country's disaster preparedness and property market. Regulators and market players have launched damage control efforts to calm nerves, with the banking system and insurance industry appearing to have held steady. The quake is likely to deepen the slump in Bangkok's already fragile real estate market, particularly the condominium sector, with potential buyers becoming more cautious.

International tourist arrivals are expected to drop by 10-15 per cent or even more in the next two weeks as the 7.7 earthquake on Friday (Mar 28) shook buildings in Bangkok and other Thai tourist hot spots, spooking prospective travellers, the Thai Hotels Association says.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights report for March 28, 2025, provides an update on the tanker and dry bulk market. The Capesize market started the week on a firmer note but gradually softened as activity failed to gain momentum. Panamax and Ultramax/Supramax markets saw solid gains, while Handysize and Clean markets showed mixed performance. LNG and LPG markets declined, with most routes experiencing a drop in rates. The Suezmax market turned back up in the Atlantic, with the rate for the 130,000 mt Nigeria/UK Continent voyage increasing by 7 points to WS102.92.

site_title: Who are the six public service leaders to resign ahead of GE2025 so far?
summary: Six public service leaders in Singapore have resigned ahead of the 2025 general election, sparking speculation they may join politics. The resigning officials include Permanent Secretary Jeffrey Siow, AIC CEO Dinesh Vasu Dash, MOH Deputy Secretary Jasmin Lau, Budget Director Shawn Loh, Smart Nation and AI policy Director Goh Hanyan, and Private and Future Mobility Transport Director Foo Cexiang. Their resignations, which take effect between March 31 and April 6, have fueled speculation about their potential entry into politics.

site_title: UOB denies allegations of improper conduct by ex-Yang Kee Logistics CEO
summary: UOB has denied allegations of improper conduct by former Yang Kee Logistics CEO Ken Koh, calling his claims "baseless and defamatory". The bank has issued a warning letter to Koh and will take "appropriate actions" against him and anyone who publishes these allegations. UOB stated that it acted in the best interests of the company, and the bank will defend itself against any unfounded claims.

In 2023, South Korea contributed US$10.9 billion – or 4.7 per cent – of total FDI into Asean.
MAS seeks feedback on proposals giving retail investors access to private market assets

site_title: The realpolitik of Trump’s tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariff policy is driven by realpolitik rather than classical economics. The goal is to shift burden sharing with the rest of the world, particularly with China, which Trump views as the US' most critical geostrategic threat. Trump aims to reduce China's trade advantage to match the US average of 3% tariffs, while maintaining supply-chain independence and weakening the dollar to support re-industrialisation. This strategy prioritises security and power projection over economic concerns, and Trump is willing to use tariffs as a tool to achieve these objectives, even if it means hurting certain groups or industries.

Singapore's STI index crossed the 4,000-mark for the first time, while Indonesia's Widjaja family announced plans to delist Sinarmas Land from the Singapore Exchange, resulting in a 23.6% surge in the company's shares.

site_title: Smaller states can’t tell big powers what to do, but they do have agency, says SM Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean stated that smaller countries, like Singapore, have agency despite being unable to dictate to big powers like the US and China. Teo emphasized that the current global uncertainties have increased the motivation for countries to form partnerships, including those with the US and China. He advised that countries should develop relationships that welcome economies with shared principles and abide by the same rules, building blocks for smooth trade and investment.

site_title: UK gallery to return Nazi-looted painting to heirs of Jewish collector
summary: The Tate Britain gallery in London is set to return a 1654 oil painting, "Aeneas and his Family Fleeing Burning Troy," to the heirs of a Belgian Jewish art collector, Samuel Hartveld, who fled Antwerp with his family in 1940. The painting was looted by the Nazis and was acquired by the Tate in 1994. A special panel, established by the UK government, has ruled the painting was "looted as an act of racial persecution" and has arranged for its return. The handover date has not been confirmed, but Hartveld's family is "deeply grateful" for the decision.

images.alt_text: A monumental artwork by Vajiko Chachkhiani reflects on the crisis of mass migration.

site_title: Newly minted DBS CEO Tan Su Shan keeps eye on 15-17% ROE target
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest lender, has appointed Tan Su Shan as its new CEO, succeeding Piyush Gupta after 15 years at the helm. Tan aims to achieve a return on equity (ROE) target of 15-17% through structural growth strategies, focusing on wealth management, financial institutions, and intra-Asian trade. Gupta expects DBS to hit the ROE target if interest rates remain close to 4% and the bank returns excess capital to shareholders. Tan will oversee a three-year share buyback program to reduce excess capital.

site_title: US withdrawal from climate deals an opportunity for Indonesia and Vietnam to restrategise: analyst
summary: The US withdrawal from climate deals with Indonesia and Vietnam may not hinder the energy transition in the region, with momentum expected to continue driven by rising energy demand and increasing competitiveness of renewable energy. Analysts say the US withdrawal could provide an opportunity for Indonesia and Vietnam to re-strategize and rethink financing mechanisms and policy reforms. Despite the US withdrawal, financial institutions such as OCBC and UOB expect the energy transition to continue, with a focus on supporting renewable energy projects and innovative technologies.

site_title: Ceva Sante Animale nears fundraising at 9 billion euro value
summary: French animal health firm Ceva Sante Animale is nearing a fundraising round valued at 9 billion euros, with Canadian pension fund PSP Investments significantly raising its stake. Financial investors including Singapore's Temasek and Tethys Invest, a company linked to the Bettencourt Meyers family, will also participate. Ceva Sante's CEO, Marc Prikazsky, will retain majority voting rights. The deal is advised by Lazard and Rothschild & Co, with a potential announcement in the coming days.

site_title: Singapore’s mobile data price war: ‘You lose out if you don’t switch’
summary: Singapore's mobile data prices have plummeted over the past decade, with the average cost of 1GB dropping from over S$4 in 2017 to under S$0.10 today, a reduction of over 90%. This is due to intense competition among the three major telcos, Singtel, StarHub, and M1, as well as the entry of new players such as MVNOs (Mobile Virtual Network Operators) like Simba and Circles.Life. The state of competition has made Singapore one of the most affordable countries in the world for mobile data, with residents enjoying some of the lowest rates globally. Industry experts expect prices to stabilize or increase modestly in the future to ensure telcos remain profitable.

images.alt_text: Commuters in a train servicing the East West Line on Oct 1, 2024.

site_title: Buyback consideration notches higher; ISOTeam CEO increases stake
summary: Institutional investors in Singapore were net sellers of stocks from Mar 21 to 27, with a total outflow of S$151 million. This marks a significant increase from the S$18 million outflow over the preceding five sessions. The sectors experiencing the highest net institutional inflow were real estate investment trusts and industrials, while financial services saw the most net institutional outflow. The total net institutional outflow for 2025 year to Mar 27 stands at S$1.6 billion.

images.alt_text: From a sector perspective, industrials again experienced the highest net institutional inflow, while financial services saw the most net institutional outflow.

site_title: Navigating the shifting Asian private credit market landscape: Where quality matters more than quantity
summary: The Asian private credit market landscape is shifting, with investors reassessing the region's role in their portfolios. A cautious tone has emerged due to a challenging fundraising environment, evolving geopolitics, and complex regulatory frameworks. Instead of focusing on quantity, investors are being urged to prioritize quality by targeting well-structured transactions, resilient sectors, and optimal loan sizes. This approach will help investors uncover attractive opportunities in the region, where understanding the nuances and dynamics is key to success.

site_title: 2025 GWM Ora 07 review: An Ora of calm
summary: The GWM Ora 07, a sleek and quirky electric vehicle, has been reviewed. The car's low and wide stance, soft curves, and pastel tones evoke a sense of calm, but its practicality is lacking. The rear seats are spacious, but the boot is small, and the steering can be unresponsive at times. Despite its flaws, the Ora 07's personality, courtesy of its simulated engine sounds and whimsical features, makes it a charming and attention-grabbing car. With a range of 570 km and a price of $199,999, the Ora 07 is a unique offering in the EV market.

images.alt_text: The A3 has had a makeover that keeps things fresh while preserving the car’s attitude.

site_title: The UK’s key housing target at the mercy of wary homebuilders
summary: The UK's largest homebuilders have told investors they expect to sell around 65,000 homes in 2025, falling short of the government's 1.5 million homes target over five years. This would result in a 25% shortfall, with the UK on track to build about 225,000 homes in 2025. Affordability constraints and slower interest rate cuts are cited as major concerns, with analysts warning of skills shortages and the need for help for first-time buyers to boost homeownership.

images.alt_text: London remains the least affordable UK region, with 90 per cent of local authorities recording house prices equal to over 12 times annual earnings.

A sign for stamp duty savings outside newly completed homes in Chelmsford, UK, on Thursday, March 13, 2025. site_title: Blackstone mulls small stake in US TikTok spinoff: sources
summary: Private equity firm Blackstone is evaluating a small minority investment in TikTok's US operations, discussing a proposal to spin off the business into a separate entity and dilute Chinese ownership to below 20% threshold required by US law. The plan aims to resolve the fate of the app used by nearly half of all Americans, which has been on hold since a law required ByteDance to divest TikTok by January 19 or face a national security ban. The White House has been involved in the deal talks, with US Vice-President JD Vance expecting the general terms of an agreement to be reached by the April deadline.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump earlier this month said the United States was in talks with four groups interested in acquiring TikTok.

site_title: Agency for Integrated Care chief steps down ahead of general election, ECDA CEO to take over
summary: Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) chief Dinesh Vasu Dash has stepped down ahead of the upcoming general election, citing a desire to "pursue other opportunities". He will be succeeded by Tan Chee Wee, who will take over on May 1. This move follows a string of resignations by senior government officials, fueling speculation that they will be fielded as candidates in the general election.

images.alt_text: Jeffrey Siow is the fourth and most senior civil servant to resign ahead of the upcoming general election.
Dinesh Vasu Dash, 49, has helmed AIC since 2023 – first as CEO-designate, before taking on the role officially in February 2024.

site_title: Oil slips on recession fears but posts third weekly gain
summary: US oil prices fell on Friday due to recession fears, but gained for a third consecutive week after the US increased pressure on Opec members Venezuela and Iran. US President Donald Trump plans to announce reciprocal tariffs targeting imports, effective April 2, sparking concerns about a global recession. However, high-frequency oil demand indicators have held up relatively well, and oil prices have rebounded from multi-month lows. Brent crude futures rose 1.9% and WTI rose 1.6% on a weekly basis, with Brent up over 7% and WTI up over 6% since hitting lows in early March.

site_title: Blackstone's higher £330 million offer for London's 'Can of Ham' tower rejected, source says
summary: Blackstone's £330 million offer for London's "Can of Ham" tower has been rejected by Nuveen, the building's owner, following a previous £300 million offer that was also refused last year. Nuveen is seeking a higher price, citing robust leasing activity in London, and may choose to hold on to the building to see how market conditions play out. The rejection is a test of whether buyers and sellers can agree on price in the European office market, which has seen low sale volumes since 2009.

site_title: Surrey Hills Holdings terminates employment of founder Pang Gek Teng for ‘wrongdoings and fraud’
summary: Surrey Hills Holdings, a Singapore-based food and beverage company, has terminated the employment of its founder Pang Gek Teng due to "wrongdoings and fraud." Pang, 36, will be replaced by Koh Chew Chee as interim CEO. The company will conduct further investigations into the extent of losses suffered. Pang has admitted to her wrongdoings and is seeking legal advice. Despite her termination, Pang expressed her commitment to the industry, stating she remains strong in her convictions.

site_title: Myanmar death toll from earthquake rises to over 1,000 as junta appeals for aid
summary: A 7.7 magnitude earthquake struck Myanmar on March 28, killing over 1,000 people and injuring thousands more. The country's military government declared a state of emergency in six provinces, including the capital Naypyidaw and Mandalay. Rescue teams, including foreign aid from the US, India, and other countries, arrived in Myanmar to assist in the search for survivors. The death toll is expected to exceed 10,000, with economic losses potentially exceeding the country's annual output. In neighboring Thailand, at least nine people were killed, with 30 trapped under debris in Bangkok.

images.alt_text: Rescue teams at a construction site where a building collapsed in Bangkok after an earthquake. A powerful earthquake had rocked central Myanmar earlier.

site_title: Chinese EVs’ market share across Europe drops to two-year low
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) manufacturers saw their market share in Europe drop to a two-year low in February, with 6.9% of registered EVs made by Chinese companies. This is a decline from January's 7.8% and the lowest since February 2023. The European Union's imposition of 27% tariffs on Chinese-made EVs has hindered growth, as established manufacturers such as Volkswagen captured the majority of the market rebound. BYD and SAIC Motor Corp's MG have been working to build the EU into an export stronghold, but the tariffs have caused a levelling-off of Chinese market share.

summary: Elon Musk's xAI has acquired Twitter's social media platform X for $33 billion, combining the two companies in a deal valued at $80 billion. The all-stock deal aims to ease Musk's ability to train his AI model, Grok. Musk announced the transaction in a post on X, stating that the deal combines the futures of xAI and X. The acquisition marks the latest consolidation of Musk's power, following his ownership of Tesla and SpaceX.

site_title: US consumer spending rises in February; core inflation firmer

This rebound, however, may not alleviate concerns about a recession, as business and consumer sentiment have deteriorated significantly. The economy's core inflation rate remains firm, with the Personal Consumption Expenditures price index increasing 0.4% in February. Economists warn that the ongoing trade tensions, including tariffs, could lead to inflation and economic contraction.

The banks' efforts to reduce emissions and transition to more sustainable practices are crucial for achieving net zero targets, with the global steel sector expected to increase demand by 32% by 2050.

site_title: Tourism with a twist: More young adults turn to community-based travel to make friends
summary: Young adults are turning to community-based travel to make friends while exploring the world. Companies like The Travel Intern, Sotravel, and The Outside offer curated tours that cater to the needs of Gen Zs and millennials. These tours, often led by experienced guides and facilitators, aim to create meaningful connections among participants. Social media platforms like TikTok have fueled this trend, with influencers showcasing community-focused travel experiences. As a result, nearly half of Gen Z and millennial travelers plan to take between one and three trips this year, and people under 35 increased their travel spending by 47% in 2024.

site_title: Star Entertainment’s Sydney casino licence suspension extended till September
summary: Star Entertainment's Sydney casino licence has been suspended until at least September 30 by the New South Wales Independent Casino Commission. The suspension was extended due to uncertainty around the company's financial situation, despite steady improvements in its remediation efforts. The company is seeking a debt refinancing proposal worth up to A$940 million, which may be hindered by the licence suspension. Tariff fears, combined with higher-than-expected inflation data, led to concerns of an economic slowdown and potential global recession.

site_title: Elon Musk is wrong about GDP
summary: Elon Musk's tweet suggesting a more accurate measure of GDP would exclude government spending has sparked debate. The concept of GDP, which measures productive output, is not as straightforward as Musk implies. Government spending was initially included in GDP due to theoretical and practical reasons, including John Maynard Keynes' macroeconomic theory and the need to understand and stabilize the economy. The value of goods and services is determined by market transactions, but unpaid work, quality improvements, and bundled services can be overlooked. A more accurate measure of human progress should focus on direct surveys, such as the World Happiness Report, rather than modifying GDP.

Collins says the tariffs, which have already been imposed on steel and aluminum, will lead to a direct and time-limited price increase, followed by a more persistent impact on inflation. The Fed has a dual mandate to control inflation and unemployment, and if inflation remains above target, the Fed may pause rate cuts, keeping borrowing costs elevated.

summary: Employers in Singapore are shifting away from academic qualifications when hiring, with nearly 8 in 10 job vacancies in 2024 not listing them as the primary consideration. The proportion of vacancies where academic qualifications were not the main hiring criterion rose to 78.8% in 2024, up from 74.9% in 2023. Employers now prioritize skills-based hiring, ranking relevant experience and skills as top factors. The report also found that PMET job vacancies continue to rise, with the sector accounting for 57.7% of job vacancies in 2024.

site_title: Children’s Aid Society breaks ground on residential care and therapeutic services facility

The $25 million project, funded by $16 million in donations, will offer dedicated spaces for family visits, counselling, and therapy services, as well as hostel-style accommodations for older youths. site_title: Why do stocks gains come at night?
summary: A long-standing market anomaly, known as overnight drift, has puzzled researchers for decades, with stocks gaining most of their value at night and losing it during the day. A recent study by Victor Haghani, Vladimir Ragulin, and Richard Dewey found that the anomaly is strongest for "meme stocks" that generate retail excitement, and that retail investors' late-night orders contribute to inflated opening prices. In contrast, China is the only country where the overnight drift is reversed, suggesting a possible link to its unique stock trading laws. The study's findings have sparked debate about the true cause of the anomaly, with some attributing it to coordinated market manipulation by large quantitative firms.

The decline was attributed to 238.6 million shares worth S$281.7 million changing hands, with a total of 1.3 billion shares traded.

site_title: Upskilling employees is a key step in digital transformation for SMEs: Low Yen Ling
summary: Singaporean SMEs can succeed in digital transformation by upskilling their employees, according to Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling. The government has introduced the SkillsFuture Workforce Development Grant to support workforce transformation, focusing on job redesign. Experts emphasize the importance of integrating digital tools, identifying pain points, and building a change-ready organization. Low also highlighted the potential of generative artificial intelligence (AI) to help SMEs overcome manpower constraints, with the government taking a pragmatic approach to AI's ethics and safety.

images.alt_text: The post-Budget discussion featured (from left) Oriental Remedies Group co-founder and CEO Beatrice Liu, Xero Asia managing director Koren Wines, and Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling as speakers, with BT deputy news editor Anita Gabriel as moderator.
Oriental Remedies Group's co-founder Beatrice Liu (pictured) said the company collaborated with NTUC and e2i to identify ways to modernise and drive business growth.  PHOTO: VERON WONG

site_title: Nippon, US Steel offer increased investment to Trump officials to close deal, Semafor reports
summary: Nippon Steel and US Steel are in talks with the White House to secure a deal preserving their $14 billion merger, with Nippon offering to increase its $2.7 billion upgrade investment to up to $7 billion. The Japanese steelmaker's offer aims to secure billions more in investments into Rust Belt facilities. US President Donald Trump previously agreed to an investment deal instead of a purchase, with Nippon Steel pledging to keep its headquarters in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, and maintain a minority stake in US Steel. Negotiations continue between the parties.

images.alt_text: Hock Seng Hoe Metal managing director Sam Chee Keong (centre) and executive director Chan Lee Ying (left of centre) at the company's celebration of its 10th anniversary.
The OCBC Bank Holland Village branch is seen on Feb 26, 2025.
Trump has threatened to impose a duty of as much as 25 per cent on all copper imports.
Hyundai Steel shares initially jumped more than 5 per cent on the news but reversed early gains to drop 4.4 per cent later in the session as US President Donald Trump praised the company’s plan.
Although steel demand is increasingly keyed to infrastructure, rather than the private property developments, that’s becoming less metal-intensive as the economy matures.

site_title: From AI to ESG: Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua’s take on the big trends
summary: Keppel CEO Loh Chin Hua outlines the company's plans for the future, focusing on capturing opportunities in infrastructure, digitalization, and artificial intelligence (AI) amid climate change and the energy transition. Keppel aims to hit S$200 billion in funds under management by 2030 and has evolved its infrastructure business to focus on renewables, clean energy, and decarbonization. The company will also continue to grow its data center portfolio and invest in digital infrastructure such as subsea cables. Loh is confident in Keppel's ability to thrive in a volatile operating environment, driven by its deep operating capabilities and access to diverse capital pools.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Singapore 7 and 8, located in the Keppel Data Centre Campus at 82 Genting Lane. Basic earnings per share is up 41.9 per cent at S$0.349, from S$0.246 previously.

site_title: US economy grew 2.4% last quarter, faster than previous estimate
summary: The US economy expanded at a 2.4% annualized rate in the fourth quarter, faster than the previous estimate, driven by upward revisions to net exports, government spending, and business investment. Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of GDP, grew at 4% but was lower than expected. The personal consumption expenditures price index excluding food and energy was revised down to 2.6%, a decrease from previous estimates. The government's gross domestic income rose 4.5% after a 1.4% increase in the third quarter.

images.alt_text: The number of people receiving benefits after an initial week of aid, a proxy for hiring, decreased 25,000 to a seasonally adjusted 1.856 million during the week ending March 15.

site_title: Keppel eyes better market valuation as it sheds ‘conglomerate discount’
summary: Keppel, a global asset manager, is aiming for a better market valuation as it sheds its "conglomerate discount" through its ongoing transformation. Under CEO Loh Chin Hua's Vision 2030 strategy, the company has refocused on investment strategies and sold assets worth S$11.7 billion to date. Earnings quality has improved significantly, with recurring income rising to 72% of net profit. Keppel aims to hit S$100 billion in funds under management by 2026 and S$200 billion by 2030, with a focus on asset monetisation and pivoting its real estate segment.

images.alt_text: Keppel DC Singapore 7 and 8, located in the Keppel Data Centre Campus at 82 Genting Lane. Basic earnings per share is up 41.9 per cent at S$0.349, from S$0.246 previously.

site_title: Growing Singapore border demand boosts Malaysian bus firm’s IPO
summary: Malaysian bus operator HI Mobility raised RM116 million (S$34.8 million) in an initial public offering (IPO) valuing it at US$137 million. The company, which operates the largest cross-border bus services between Malaysia's Johor state and Singapore, expects increased traffic at the border to drive growth. Revenue rose 73% to RM207.7 million in 2024, with nearly half coming from Singapore. The IPO marks a rare success story in Malaysia's public transport landscape dominated by state-linked firms, with CEO Lim Chern Chuen attributing success to automation and technological solutions.

images.alt_text: An AirAsia plane undergoing maintenance at Subang, Malaysia, July 15, 2024. Flight AK128, an Airbus A320, was on its way to Shenzhen but turned back to Kuala Lumpur International Airport due to “an abnormal indication in one of the engines”.
UMS Integration and Grand Venture Technology, two Singapore-listed seminconductor manufacturers, have received the green light for a secondary listing in Malaysia.

site_title: Powerful quake in South-east Asia kills more than 20 people; Thailand’s stock exchange suspends trading
summary: A 7.7 magnitude earthquake struck central Myanmar, killing over 20 people and triggering evacuations in Thailand and Vietnam. The earthquake also caused a building to collapse in Bangkok, prompting rescue efforts. In response, Thailand's stock exchange suspended trading for the afternoon session. The quake's epicentre was approximately 17.2 km from the Myanmar city of Mandalay.

images.alt_text: A drone view shows a flooded area following the impact of Typhoon Yagi, in Chiang Rai in the northern province of Thailand, September 13, 2024. REUTERS/Anupong Intawong TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY SEARCH "REUTERS FLOODS 2024" FOR THIS STORY. SEARCH "REUTERS YEAR-END" FOR ALL 2024 YEAR END GALLERIES.

site_title: Trump’s tariff plans propel safe-haven gold to record high
summary: US President Donald Trump's fresh tariff plans have sparked fears of a global trade war, driving gold prices to a record high of US$3,063.20 an ounce. Gold rose 0.2% as spot gold climbed 0.2% to US$3,061.72 an ounce, with bullion up 1.3% so far this week. Uncertainty surrounding tariffs, potential interest rate cuts, and geopolitical conflicts have fueled gold's surge in 2025, with the precious metal seen as a hedge against economic and political uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Concerns over Trump’s tariff policies have catapulted gold to a record high of US$3,057.21 on Mar 20.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims edge lower
summary: US weekly jobless claims decreased by 25,000 to 1.856 million for the week ending March 15, while the jobless rate appears to have held steady at 4.1% in March. Initial claims for state unemployment benefits fell to 224,000 for the week ended March 22, beating economists' forecasts. Low layoffs have maintained the labor market's solid footing, despite President Trump's trade policy and government spending cuts.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People walk past a restaurant, with a hiring sign outside, in Washington, DC on October 5, 2023. The US private sector added more jobs than anticipated in January, payroll firm ADP said on February 5, 2025, as consumer-facing job creation surged. Private sector employment increased by 183,000 jobs last month, ADP said in a statement, sharply above the market consensus of 155,000, according to Briefing.com. (Photo by ANDREW CABALLERO-REYNOLDS / AFP)

site_title: Market jitters and state fund Danantara’s gamble: Can Indonesia win back investors?
summary: Indonesia's economic policies are causing market jitters as investors navigate uncertain shifts. The rupiah has hit its lowest point since the Asian financial crisis, and foreign institutional investors have fled the market, leading to a 8.4% decline in the Jakarta Composite Index. President Prabowo Subianto's policy maneuvers are adding fuel to the fire, prompting investors to step back. The government's fiscal deficit is a concern, with a 30% drop in tax revenue and a steep budget cut. Meanwhile, the newly formed Danantara fund, led by a "dream team" of high-profile figures, aims to channel investments into priority projects, but its control over state-owned assets has sparked unease in the market.

images.alt_text: The Financial Services Authority and the Indonesia Stock Exchange announced the easing of share buyback policies to anticipate market volatility.
Indonesia's heavy reliance on steel imports, especially steel products from China, leaves it especially exposed to the trade diversion risks.

site_title: Porsche, Mercedes face 3.4 billion euros hit from Trump auto tariffs
summary: Porsche and Mercedes-Benz Group face a potential 3.4 billion euros hit from new US tariffs on imported cars, with the duties potentially wiping out nearly a quarter of their 2026 operating earnings. The tariffs, set to take effect on April 3, threaten to upend the European auto industry's reliance on exports to the US market, with German carmakers being the hardest hit. Manufacturers may need to raise prices or shift more production to the US to offset the impact, which could damage an industry already grappling with rising costs and muted demand.

site_title: SingPost up 7.7% after divestment of Australian logistics business
summary: SingPost shares surged 7.7% after the company completed the sale of its Australian logistics business, Freight Management Holdings, for A$1 billion (S$845 million), generating higher-than-expected gross proceeds of A$781.5 million and an estimated gain of S$289.5 million. The sale will be used to reduce debt, and SingPost has announced a strategy reset, focusing on its postal and e-commerce logistics business in Singapore, international e-commerce logistics, and two major non-core assets.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of Singpost logo

site_title: Sinarmas Land soars 23.6% on privatisation offer
summary: Sinarmas Land shares surged 23.6% to S$0.34 after the company received a S$0.31 per share privatization offer from an entity controlled by Indonesia's billionaire Widjaja family. The offer values the Singapore-listed property developer at S$1.32 billion, representing a 12.7% premium over its last traded price. The offeror currently holds 70.3% of the total issued shares.

site_title: Euro steady as Trump’s car tariffs loom next week
summary: The euro remained steady against the US dollar, rising 0.3% to $1.0787 after touching a three-week low due to looming US car tariffs. The tariffs, set to take effect next week, are expected to widen a global trade dispute and could negatively impact US growth and stoke inflation. However, some analysts believe the tariffs may not be as severe as expected, potentially benefiting the euro. The US dollar index fell 0.29% to 104.34, while the yen and Mexican peso weakened against the dollar.

images.alt_text: The dollar index, which had rallied strongly between September and January, is headed for a roughly 4 per cent drop. It was last up 0.05 per cent at 104.28.

site_title: MAS seeks feedback on proposals giving retail investors access to private market assets
summary: MAS is seeking feedback on proposals to give retail investors access to private market assets, which have traditionally been the domain of wealthy individuals and institutional investors. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has issued a consultation paper proposing a long-term investment fund framework for private markets, allowing retail investors to channel funds into these illiquid investments. Two potential structures are being considered: direct funds and long-term investment funds-of-funds (LIFFs), with MAS seeking views on regulatory requirements and the scope of private market investment assets.

images.alt_text: The Goldman Sachs headquarters in New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Meta’s Asia-Pacific chief quits after a decade-long growth spurt
summary: Meta Platforms is losing its Asia-Pacific chief, Dan Neary, after a decade-long tenure overseeing the company's rapid expansion in Australia, Greater China, and South-east Asia. Neary, who led the company's business across the region, announced his departure citing personal reasons. During his tenure, Facebook's user base in Asia grew from 35% to 50% of the global advertising reach, with Instagram and WhatsApp expanding rapidly across the region. Neary's departure comes as Meta seeks to compete with AI giants like OpenAI and DeepSeek, with CEO Mark Zuckerberg planning to spend hundreds of billions on AI infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Meta is investing heavily in artificial intelligence infrastructure, seeking to better compete in a fast-moving race against the likes of OpenAI and Google as well as upstarts such as Hangzhou-based DeepSeek.
The Magnificent Seven stocks – Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, Amazon.com, Tesla, Alphabet and Meta – are seen as particular beneficiaries of AI.

Both Meta and Apple have been in the European Commission’s crosshairs since last year for potential breaches of the Digital Markets Act which could cost companies as much as 10 per cent of their global annual sales.
Meta plans to work on its own humanoid robot hardware, with an initial focus on household chores.
Most Meta employees have been told they would receive about 10 per cent less equity this year, FT reported.
Meta plans to work on its own humanoid robot hardware, with an initial focus on household chores.
Meta had relocated its Singapore staff to new offices at Marina One (above), after opting not to renew its lease for seven floors of office space at South Beach Tower.

Meta Platforms said on Thursday (Feb 13) that it will allow classified ad firms in Europe to pay to place their listings on Facebook Marketplace. The cost will be based on the number of times a user clicks on a button within the listing.
The change extends the so-called useful life period of certain servers and networking assets to five and a half years, from the four to five years it previously used.

site_title: Asia Economic Summit 2025: Navigating innovation, policy in Asean
summary: Asean's top leaders will convene at the Asia Economic Summit 2025 in Jakarta, Indonesia, to explore the impact of tech, policy, and investment trends on the region's future. The digital economy has surged to $263 billion in 2024, with AI-driven innovations reshaping e-commerce. However, recent corporate scandals have raised concerns about regulatory shifts and funding. The summit aims to address these concerns by examining technological advancements, regulatory landscapes, and investment strategies to ensure long-term growth in an increasingly competitive landscape.

site_title: Musk says US$1 trillion in US spending cuts possible without touching services
summary: US billionaire Elon Musk claims he can achieve a $1 trillion reduction in federal spending without impacting services, as part of his role as Trump's cost-cutting czar. Musk's goal aims to slim down the current $7 trillion federal spending level to $6 trillion. However, budget experts say this is unlikely to be achievable without touching entitlement programs such as social security, which Trump has vowed not to cut. Musk's Department of Government Efficiency must find significant savings to meet this target.

site_title: Companies can do well and do good at the same time with right CSR practices: Piyush Gupta
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta emphasizes the importance of corporate social responsibility (CSR) practices in achieving both profit and purpose. He argues that companies can do well and do good by adopting a longer-term approach to CSR, understanding the right trade-off for their specific situation. Gupta cites DBS Foundation's efforts to uplift vulnerable communities and nurture businesses for impact, highlighting the bank's commitment to making a positive impact. The City of Good summit, which brought together over 1,000 participants, aims to foster collaboration and innovation in CSR practices.

images.alt_text: St Lukes ElderCare, which participated in Great Singapore Give, says the campaign helped it reach a wider audience.

site_title: Lululemon plunges as US struggles weigh on sales outlook
summary: Lululemon shares plummeted 11% in extended trading after the yogawear brand delivered a disappointing sales outlook for the year ahead, citing slower US sales and macroeconomic concerns. The company expects fiscal year sales of $11.15 billion to $11.3 billion, below Wall Street analysts' expectations. CEO Calvin McDonald is working to lift demand by expanding product assortment and entering new categories, but faces challenges from fluctuating fashion trends and supply chain costs amid a trade war. The company remains committed to its long-term sales target of $12.5 billion by 2026.

images.alt_text: The Adidas Samba has been the hottest sneakers for the past couple of years.
Consumer and business sentiment has been rising since the election but inflation expectations have climbed as well.
The company, which pioneered the athleisure category, has attracted a number of rivals which are now offering products such as yoga pants at lower prices.
Lululemon has benefited from its more targeted approach in its second-largest market China, where it has about 130 stores.

site_title: US: Stocks extend losses on auto tariff shock
summary: US stocks fell on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 Index losing 0.4% and 0.3%, respectively. The announcement of 25% auto tariffs by President Trump, set to take effect next week, caused global market jitters. Analysts say the tariffs will likely raise costs for consumers and have delivered a shock to global markets. Investors are awaiting more details on April 2, which Trump has vowed to impose reciprocal tariffs. Shares in major automakers Ford, General Motors, and Stellantis declined, with Ford falling 3.9%, General Motors 7.4%, and Stellantis 1.2%.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 19, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Singapore fund inflows surge 167% to S$7.6 billion for 2024: Morningstar
summary: Singapore fund inflows surged 167% to S$7.6 billion in 2024, driven by fixed income and allocation funds, which drew S$758.8 million in net inflows in Q4. Interest in money market funds fell significantly, while equity funds saw a rebound with S$171.8 million in net inflows. Despite underperforming global stocks, CPFIS-included funds delivered a positive return of 11.3% for investors. Looking ahead, Morningstar advises investors to consider longer-term bonds and emerging markets debt to mitigate tariff risks and capitalize on interest rate declines.

images.alt_text: Over the one-year period ended September 2024, CPFIS funds registered a positive return of 14.7 per cent.

site_title: ‘Like playing chess’: Oriental Remedies Group co-founder on getting digitalisation right
summary: Oriental Remedies Group, a traditional Chinese medicine provider, has successfully digitalised its operations through the adoption of artificial intelligence tools and cloud systems. The company prioritised digital solutions that support human resources functions, such as learning management systems and cloud-based platforms for administrative tasks. CEO Beatrice Liu compared the digitalisation process to playing chess, noting that some steps will bring faster results. The company is also experimenting with AI-powered tools to enhance customer engagement, including an AI programme that analyzes tongue images for basic health assessments.

images.alt_text: The post-Budget discussion featured (from left) Oriental Remedies Group co-founder and CEO Beatrice Liu, Xero Asia managing director Koren Wines, and Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling as speakers, with BT deputy news editor Anita Gabriel as moderator.

The Business Times Budget Roundtable 2025 was moderated by BT's deputy news editor Anita Gabriel (extreme right). The three panellists were (L-R) Beatrice Liu, co-founder and CEO of Oriental Remedies; Koren Wines, managing director of Xero Asia; and Low Yen Ling, Minister of State for Trade and Industry.
The GenAI Playbook aims to make AI adoption more accessible for enterprises across different stages of digital maturity.

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says the government’s partnership with enterprises will become increasingly important for Singapore’s growth as the world faces a more dangerous, turbulent and volatile external environment.
DPM Gan also gave details of the S$1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund, which PM Wong had said would provide “more financing options for high-growth local enterprises”.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 28)
summary: Singapore introduced incentives for electric heavy vehicles, offering S$40,000 per vehicle under the Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme and Electric Heavy Vehicle Charger Grant. Industry players expect this to spur adoption and accelerate the introduction of more models. Meanwhile, Indonesia faces mounting pressure due to a declining rupiah and a recent equity market meltdown. Singapore's Straits Times Index hit a record high of 4,000, despite closing lower on Friday.

images.alt_text: Feburary's manufacturing output data missed economists' expectation of a 7 per cent expansion.

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as autos suffer more tariff-fuelled losses
summary: Asian markets experienced a mixed day on Friday as the US announced steep levies on vehicle imports, fueling recession fears and a potential global trade war. Toyota, Honda, Nissan, and Mazda suffered significant losses, with Tokyo stocks sinking over 2% and other Asian markets also falling. The US tariffs, set to take effect on April 2, have sparked concerns over inflation and prompted investors to seek safe havens, such as gold. Analysts warn that negotiations with Washington may temper the duties, but uncertainty remains, leading investors to wait-and-see.

images.alt_text: (FILES) The logo of Japan's Toyota Motor is displayed at a dealership in Tokyo on February 9, 2022. Shares in Japan's biggest car companies fell on March 27, 2025, after US President Donald Trump announced a 25 percent tariff on auto imports to take effect next week. The world's top-selling automaker Toyota dropped 3.7 percent as the Tokyo market opened, while Nissan shed 3.2 percent and Honda fell as much as 3.1 percent. (Photo by Kazuhiro NOGI / AFP)

site_title: The art of perfect vibes: How NYC’s hottest restaurants got that way
summary: New York City's hottest restaurants have reached unprecedented levels of demand, with waitlists often exceeding 7,300 people, double the number of seats at Carnegie Hall. To achieve this, top-tier establishments employ a winning formula that includes a party vibe, cozy interiors, relaxed service, and comfort food. Design elements such as soft lighting, banquettes, and bric-a-brac create an immersive atmosphere, while service staff are trained to be friendly and approachable. Owners also prioritize building a community by keeping tables open for walk-ins and maintaining a consistent level of quality over time, rather than relying on short-term buzz.

images.alt_text: Chef Paul Marcon of France prepares a dish during the Grand Final of the Bocuse d’Or gastronomic competition.  French domination of the contemporary culinary world is built into modern history.
While typically associated with “highbrow” cuisine, champagne goes wonderfully with foods such as pizza and fried chicken.
The owner and chef Sal Lamboglia at Cafe Spaghetti in Brooklyn. Modest and relatively inexpensive, Lamboglia's Brooklyn restaurant embodies the spirit of mom-and-pop Italian joints.

Patrons drink at the Ten Bells Bushwick in New York, Nov. 18, 2022. Like its forebear in Manhattan, the Ten Bells Bushwick is dark and moody, a great place to wile away an evening. (Karsten Moran/The New York Times)

site_title: Indonesia seeks to calm investors after stocks, rupiah slide
summary: Indonesia seeks to calm investors after its stock market and rupiah currency slumped, with the rupiah falling to its weakest since 1998 due to concerns over government policy, fiscal position, and growth prospects. President Prabowo Subianto will meet with investors to address concerns, promising to improve communication and reassure investors about the government's fiscal policies and the newly set up sovereign wealth fund. Bank Indonesia is ready to stabilize the currency, citing a fundamentally strong economy, and is preparing to deregulate the real sector to encourage the manufacturing industry.

images.alt_text: Indonesia launched an effort this year to improve governance of its forest and palm oil cultivation after facing criticism that the plantations are a major driver of deforestation.

site_title: Core inflation in Japan’s capital hits 2.4%, stays above BOJ’s target
summary: Core consumer inflation in Tokyo's capital reached 2.4% in March, exceeding the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) target and fueling market expectations of a near-term interest rate hike. Food costs surged 5.6% in March, with rice prices increasing 92.4% from the previous year. The BOJ has maintained its 2% inflation target, but Governor Kazuo Ueda has indicated that borrowing costs will be raised if wage gains continue to support consumption and allow firms to raise prices. The BOJ will closely monitor the Tokyo CPI data in its next policy meeting on April 30-May 1.

images.alt_text: Bags of rice are displayed for sale at a supermarket in Tokyo on February 7, 2025. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)

site_title: Australian PM calls general election for May 3
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a general election for May 3, pitting his centre-left Labor party against right-leaning candidate Peter Dutton. The election comes as Albanese struggles to sell his economic vision, with polls showing a neck-and-neck contest on issues like climate change and housing. The two candidates have contrasting ideas on decarbonisation and emissions reduction, with Albanese advocating for renewable energy subsidies and Dutton pushing for nuclear power. The election will determine Australia's future direction, with economic concerns and housing affordability expected to dominate the contest.

images.alt_text: The Albanese-led Labor government has been announcing a slew of measures aimed at pleasing families and businesses grappling with high costs as it seeks to win a second term.

Data from the Australian Bureau of Statistics on Wednesday showed the monthly consumer price index was flat in February from January. The annual pace, however, slowed to 2.4 per cent from 2.5 per cent, versus forecasts for no change.

site_title: Oil approaches one-month highs as investors assess supply, trade war risks
summary: Oil prices rose 0.3% on Thursday, with Brent crude futures reaching $74.03 a barrel, as investors assessed a tightening of crude supplies and new US tariffs. US President Donald Trump's plan to implement 25% tariffs on imported cars and light trucks effective next week and new tariffs on Venezuelan crude raised concerns about demand. India's Reliance Industries halted Venezuelan oil imports, while Asian bank DBS expects prices to remain low due to uncertainty over US policy and tariff wars. US crude inventories showed tighter supplies, with stockpiles falling by 3.3 million barrels last week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Saudi Aramco logo is pictured in Paris, France, February 1, 2024. REUTERS/Benoit Tessier/File Photo
Brent crude futures settled up 77 cents, or 1.05 per cent, at US$73.79 a barrel on Wednesday.

site_title: Optimising your digital assets
summary: As Q2 approaches, businesses should reassess their digital infrastructure to ensure optimal performance, security, and cost efficiency. A thorough data audit identifies redundant, obsolete, and trivial data, while optimising storage systems with cloud-based or hybrid models enhances flexibility and reduces costs. Strengthening cybersecurity measures, such as implementing zero-trust security and upgrading multi-factor authentication, is also crucial to protect sensitive information. Effective data governance and leveraging AI and automation can further improve workflows and productivity. By taking proactive steps, businesses can maintain a competitive edge and prepare for the next phase of the year.

images.alt_text: Singapore has cemented itself as a global digital hub, with cloud services and data centres forming the backbone of its digital economy.

site_title: Hong Kong February home prices fall for a third month
summary: Hong Kong's home prices declined for a third month in February, falling 0.9% to a nearly nine-year low, according to government figures. Prices have tumbled nearly 30% from a 2021 peak due to higher mortgage rates, a weak economic outlook, and poor demand. Authorities cut stamp duty for small home transactions, which may encourage first-time buyers and lift transactions by 5-10%. Realtors forecast home prices in 2025 could rise or fall 5% depending on interest rate cuts and trade tensions.

images.alt_text: Paul Chan (above), Hong Kong's financial secretary, emphasises artificial intelligence as a core industry.
Hong kong property housing Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
Hong kong property housing Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: SingPost completes A$1 billion sale of Australian logistics business
summary: SingPost has completed the divestment of its Australian logistics business, Freight Management Holdings (FMH), for A$1 billion, generating A$781.5 million in gross proceeds and an estimated S$289.5 million gain. The sale will be used to reduce debt and the company will announce a special dividend at a later date. With the completion, SingPost's wholly owned subsidiary and its subsidiaries will cease to be part of the group, necessitating a strategy reset focusing on its Singapore and international e-commerce logistics businesses.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of Singpost logo

site_title: Cantonese restaurant Black Pearl mixes classic and modern flavours
summary: Black Pearl, a modern Chinese eatery, offers a unique dining experience with its dramatic decor and nautical hues. The restaurant's menu combines classic Cantonese flavors with contemporary twists, featuring dishes such as Iberico pork char siew and deep-fried cod fillet in spicy pineapple chilli sauce. While the food is inconsistent, the kitchen's creativity and friendly service make it a promising venture. With a hardworking team and a nice view, Black Pearl has potential despite needing to tighten its kitchen ship. Rating: 6.5.

images.alt_text: The refurbished restaurant takes over from the group's steamboat eatery.

site_title: STI hits new high on Thursday, closes up 0.5% amid mixed regional trading
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) reached a new high, closing up 0.5% at 3,981.57 points, with ST Engineering and Sembcorp Industries leading gains. The industrials sector benefited from regional supply chain strengthening and reindustrialization efforts. Gainers outnumbered losers 274 to 218, with one billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changing hands.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong pushed higher a day after tanking more than two per cent on profit-taking and selling in the tech sector, while Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore and Wellington also advanced on Wednesday.
The manager of Paragon Reit will be holding an extraordinary general meeting on Apr 22 to vote on  the proposed privatisation by way of a trust scheme of arrangement.

site_title: GE2025: Maximum spending in election campaign raised to S$5 per voter to account for inflation
summary: Singapore's maximum spending limit for the upcoming general election has been raised to S$5 per voter, up from S$4, to account for inflation. The Elections Department made the change, which is the first revision since 2015. The limit applies to candidates contesting individual constituencies and group representation constituencies. Additionally, President Tharman Shanmugaratnam has designated 18 GRCs where at least one candidate must belong to a minority community. The next general election must be held by November, with most observers predicting it will take place by mid-year.

images.alt_text: Progress Singapore Party NCMP Leong Mun Wai will take over as party chief from Ms Hazel Poa, who will be the party's vice-chair.
Dinesh Vasu Dash, 49, has helmed AIC since 2023 – first as CEO-designate, before taking on the role officially in February 2024.
He is making great effort to renew the leadership team and the party, PM Wong tells media in an interview capping of his visit to Hanoi.
Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh called the boundary changes “one of the most radical redrawing of boundaries Singapore has seen in recent memory”.
Jeffrey Siow is the fourth and most senior civil servant to resign ahead of the upcoming general election.
There are a total of 2,758,095 electors in the registers, according to a statement from the Elections Department on March 24.
Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, on his first visit to Aljunied GRC since taking over Singapore’s top job, with ukulele players at the community event for seniors in Kovan Hub.

site_title: SK Hynix says some customers brought forward orders ahead of US tariffs
summary: South Korea's SK Hynix, the world's second-largest memory chipmaker, reported that some customers have brought forward orders ahead of potential US tariffs on semiconductors, which could lead to higher prices and dampen demand. The company had forecast a 10-20% decline in shipments of Dram and Nand flash memory chips in the first quarter. US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose tariffs on semiconductors and other products "in the neighborhood of 25%".

site_title: FairPrice Foundation goes the extra mile by committing S$1 million to Protein Pledge
summary: FairPrice Foundation has launched Protein Pledge, a $1 million initiative to distribute fresh protein to vulnerable communities via charity partners by 2030. The program aims to provide nutritious meals to over 46,000 beneficiaries this year, with fresh eggs being distributed regularly. The launch follows a recent study, "A Full Plate," which found that 53% of respondents preferred protein over staples like rice and noodles. The initiative is part of FairPrice Foundation's efforts to address the food and nutrition gap in Singapore, with a goal to bridge the gap for those in need by 2030.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, March 27, 2025
summary: US President Donald Trump imposes 25% auto tariffs, sparking trade war fears. Asian stocks decline as automakers face significant losses. Gold and oil prices rise due to tariff threats. Meanwhile, Cathay Cineplexes shuts down a Singapore outlet due to outstanding rent arrears. Market Focus Daily is a daily roundup of market movements and news from Singapore and the region, covering topics such as trade tensions, economic fluctuations, and business closures.

site_title: New World seeks HK$15.6 billion loan pledging prized Hong Kong asset
summary: Hong Kong developer New World Development has proposed using its prized asset, Victoria Dockside, worth around HK$88 billion, as collateral for an additional loan of up to HK$15.6 billion. The three-year loan terms aim to refinance existing debt and address liquidity pressure. Victoria Dockside, home to luxury mall K11 Musea, accounts for around 20% of New World's total assets. The move comes as the company faces a high debt burden and is in discussions on other potential loans to refinance borrowings set to mature this year.

images.alt_text: Located near the city’s famous Victoria Harbor and with a fashion-forward design incorporating arts and culture elements, K11 Musea is a popular destination for tourists.
New World has undergone two CEO changes in two months, with Adrian Cheng, stepping down in September, raising concerns over its corporate governance.
New World Development had consolidated net debt of HK$123.8 billion as at Jun 30, according to its 2024 annual report.

Concerns are growing over the financial state of New World Development controlled by the family of Hong Kong tycoon Henry Cheng.
New World has been embroiled in turmoil as investors question its ability to cope with one of the highest debt burdens among the city’s developers.

site_title: As Art Basel returns, Hong Kong is writing its own story
summary: Hong Kong's art scene is thriving despite economic and political uncertainty. The city's long-standing reputation as Asia's No 1 art capital was reaffirmed at Art Basel Hong Kong 2025, with strong sales figures from blue-chip galleries such as Hauser & Wirth, David Zwirner, and Pace. Local galleries like Ames Yavuz and PHD Group also performed well, with Singaporean artist Elmer Borlongan selling a painting for $330,000. The city's art ecosystem has expanded beyond the art fair, with public art installations and solo exhibitions featuring local and international artists. Women artists are also gaining recognition, with several galleries showcasing solo exhibitions.

images.alt_text: Supported by Art Basel and UBS, Singapore artist Ho Tzu Nyen used Artificial Intelligence to create lookalikes of Hong Kong screen legends, who will walk on the walls of M+ museum every night.

site_title: Saudi Aramco looks to invest in Indian refineries
summary: Saudi Aramco is in talks to invest in two Indian refineries, one planned by Bharat Petroleum Corp in Andhra Pradesh and another by Oil and Natural Gas Corp in western Gujarat, as India seeks to become a global refining hub. India aims to reduce its dependence on Western companies and secure a stable outlet for its crude imports. The investments could proceed regardless of Aramco's involvement, with the companies proposing to supply oil equivalent to three times Aramco's stake in each project.

site_title: US judge orders Trump admin to save ‘Signalgate’ chat
summary: A US judge, District Judge James Boasberg, has ordered the Trump administration to preserve messages from a Signal chat group used by top national security officials to discuss plans for an attack on Yemen's Huthi rebels. The ruling, made on Thursday, covers the period between March 11 and March 15, when National Security Advisor Mike Waltz set up the chat and added The Atlantic's editor-in-chief, Jeffrey Goldberg, by mistake. The administration had set some messages to disappear after one week or four days, raising questions about whether officials may have violated federal records law.

site_title: US auto tariffs to impact Thai auto parts exports: finance minister
summary: Thailand's auto parts exports will be affected by newly imposed US tariffs, with Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira stating that exports to countries producing cars will be reduced. Thailand, the largest autos production center in South-east Asia, hopes to negotiate sending parts directly to the US to avoid tariffs. The tariffs, announced by US President Donald Trump, expand a global trade war, prompting criticism and threats of retaliation from affected US allies. The impact on Thailand's exports is uncertain, with some manufacturers, like AAPICO Hitech, expecting limited effects.

site_title: Nio to raise HK$4 billion from equity placement to fund R&D
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio plans to raise HK$4 billion through a share placement to fund research and development of smart EV technologies and new products. The company will offer 136.8 million shares at HK$29.46 apiece, a 10% discount to its latest closing price. Net proceeds will strengthen the company's balance sheet and support general corporate purposes. The equity placement is subject to customary closing conditions and follows Nio's weak performance in the fourth quarter, with a record vehicle delivery but a net loss of 7.1 billion yuan.

site_title: China vice-premier pledges more policy support, says economy started 2025 well
summary: Chinese Vice-Premier Ding Xuexiang pledged stronger policy support to expand domestic demand and stabilize foreign trade and investment, citing a steady start to the year and a growth target of around 5% for 2025. The move comes amid US President Donald Trump's tariff salvos and foreign investors' concerns over China's post-pandemic recovery. Ding emphasized the need for greater institutional opening, easier market access, and support for the real estate and stock markets to boost consumption.

summary: Singapore will offer a S$40,000 incentive for businesses registering fully electric commercial vehicles weighing over 3,500 kg, with a S$30,000 grant for fast chargers. The Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme and Electric Heavy Vehicle Charger Grant will start in 2026, potentially leading to a "market standstill" in 2025. Industry players expect the incentives to spur adoption, but the delayed start may deter some purchases. The incentives aim to bring costs down and encourage more electric heavy vehicles, but the effectiveness may vary depending on vehicle weight and type.

site_title: Indonesia’s Widjaja family moves to delist Sinarmas Land from SGX; more large-cap exits on the horizon
summary: Indonesia's Widjaja family has made a voluntary cash offer to buy all remaining shares in Sinarmas Land, a Singapore-listed property developer, at S$0.31 per share, valuing the company at S$1.32 billion. The offeror, Lyon Investments, currently holds 70.3% of the shares and aims to delist the company from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). Trading in shares will be suspended if less than 10% of the shares are held in public hands. The move is expected to be followed by more large-cap exits on the SGX, with at least one multibillion-dollar company set to exit in the near future.

site_title: 🧑‍💼 4 things I’ve learnt as a Gen Z in the workforce
summary: Gen Z workers can learn valuable lessons from the author's career experiences. First, making a good impression is crucial, as it can set the tone for future opportunities. Second, getting your hands dirty and working hard is essential for career growth, but it's also important to be strategic with your time and effort. Third, there's no perfect job, and comparisons can be unproductive. Finally, staying humble and motivated can help you stay grounded and expand your knowledge horizons. By applying these lessons, Gen Z workers can set themselves up for success in their careers.

summary: China and Hong Kong stocks rose on Thursday, with tech and auto shares leading gains, despite a new US tariff threat on imported cars. The CSI300 index gained 0.3%, and the Shanghai Composite index added 0.2%, while the Hang Seng Index rose 0.4%. JPMorgan upgraded its market outlook on China, citing a 7% increase in its year-end target for the MSCI China index.

site_title: Digitalisation for SMEs: From adoption to transformation
summary:
Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can benefit from government initiatives, change management, and AI solutions to drive digital transformation. Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Low Yen Ling emphasized the importance of a whole-of-ecosystem effort, investing in ecosystem and infrastructure, talent, innovation, and trade. Key takeaways include:

* SMEs should leverage digital tools and AI to address specific pain points and drive growth.
* Change management and technical expertise are crucial for successful digitalization.
* SMEs should assess digital investments for value creation, beyond cost savings, focusing on efficiency and productivity.
* Singapore is actively working on AI governance and deployment, with a focus on safety, ethics, and business goals.
* SMEs should prioritize cybersecurity, starting with simple measures like strong passwords and multi-factor authentication, and evolving security measures as they grow.

site_title: Nissan’s new CEO says it needs partners and is open to Honda
summary: Nissan's new CEO, Ivan Espinosa, aims to arrest the company's financial free fall by partnering with other companies, including Honda, to develop electric vehicles and refresh its aging car lineup. Espinosa, who assumes his role on April 1, is open to collaborations with companies like Honda to drive Nissan's business vision. The company plans to roll out new and refreshed models in its next two fiscal years and start producing an unspecified new EV at its plant in Canton, Mississippi, starting late in fiscal year 2027.

site_title: Apple says Indonesia iPhone sales ban ends in April
summary: Apple announces that iPhone 16 sales in Indonesia will resume starting April 11, after the country lifted its sales ban. The ban was imposed in October due to Apple's failure to meet the 40% local parts requirement. Apple had previously invested $150 million in Indonesia to produce accessories and build a semiconductor research center. The ban also affects Google Pixel phones, which are not meeting the local parts requirement. The move marks a positive development for Apple in Indonesia, which is the country's largest economy.

site_title: Australia PM Albanese says election ‘imminent’ as government rushes to pass tax cuts Bill
summary: Australia Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced that an election is imminent, with the country's three-year term limits requiring a new parliament to be elected by May 17. The Albanese-led Labor government has been introducing tax cuts to win back voters, and a bill to reduce tax rates was passed in the parliament on Thursday. The opposition Liberal-National coalition is ahead in opinion surveys, but Albanese is confident that Australians want to move forward with an election.

site_title: Hong Kong lures investment firms Ardian, Arga seeking expansion
summary: Global investors are seeing signs of improving sentiment towards China, with investment firms Ardian and Arga planning to set up offices in Hong Kong to attract money from the region. Ardian, a Paris-based investment manager, is opening its fifth Asia office in Hong Kong, while Arga, a Stamford, Connecticut-based firm, is planning its fifth office globally in the city. Despite this, many long-term investors remain cautious due to concerns over a sustainable rally in China, with asset allocators hesitant to invest in China-focused private equity and venture funds.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is making plans to make a wealth connect programme with China’s Greater Bay area less restrictive and exploring whether it can extend its coverage to more mainland cities, Eddie Yue, chief executive of Hong Kong Monetary Authority, said on Wednesday.

site_title: BlackRock’s head of Asia-Pacific private credit Celia Yan to leave firm
summary: BlackRock's head of Asia-Pacific private credit, Celia Yan, is leaving the firm to pursue an external opportunity. Yan will remain at BlackRock until mid-June to ensure an orderly transition of her responsibilities. Her team has deployed over $200 million in 2024 and generated a 16% gross internal rate of return in the Asia-Pacific Credit Opportunities II fund. The transition will be led by Maheshwar Nataraj, Stephen Allan, Yik Ley Chan, Simon Chan, and Yue Lu, who will also take on greater leadership roles within the firm.

site_title: AirAsia flight to China turns back due to engine issue, lands safely
summary: AirAsia flight AK128, an Airbus A320, turned back to Kuala Lumpur International Airport after takeoff due to an abnormal engine indication. The flight, bound for Shenzhen, China, landed safely with no injuries reported. A damaged duct caused hot air to be released into the engine, not an engine fire. All 171 passengers were transferred to another aircraft, which landed at Shenzhen Bao'an International Airport. The initial aircraft is expected to return to service on March 31. Malaysia's aviation authority will investigate the incident.

summary: Lady Gaga announced a four-show tour in Singapore, with 200,000 fans expected to attend. Booking platforms have seen a surge in demand for flights and hotels, with hotel bookings tripling compared to the same period last year. Searches for flights to Singapore increased 8.9% week-on-week, with the top origin countries including London and Tokyo. Hotels expect bookings to peak closer to the concert dates in May, with the top five cities with the highest number of searches including Kuala Lumpur and Bangkok.

site_title: Foxconn plans EV event in Japan to woo manufacturers: sources
summary: Foxconn is set to hold a seminar in Japan on April 9 to outline its electric vehicle strategy, aiming to woo Japanese automakers and suppliers. The move comes after Foxconn clinched a deal with Mitsubishi Motors to make EVs for Oceania markets, including Australia. Foxconn's Chief EV Strategy Officer, Jun Seki, is expected to speak at the seminar, marking a significant shift in the Taiwanese company's five-year-old foray into electric vehicle manufacturing.

site_title: RBNZ board yet to recommend temporary governor to minister
summary: New Zealand Finance Minister Nicola Willis has yet to receive a recommendation from the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) Board on a temporary governor to replace Adrian Orr, who resigned on March 5. The RBNZ Board must make a recommendation within 28 days, but Orr's employment does not officially end until March 31. A decision on the appointment is expected after April 1, with Christian Hawkesby acting as acting governor until then.

site_title: Thai cabinet approves draft law for casinos and entertainment complexes: official
summary: Thailand's cabinet approved a draft law for casinos and entertainment complexes, paving the way for the country to build a major gaming industry. The draft law, set to be proposed in July, must still be approved by the Senate and the king. Anti-casino protesters expressed opposition to the move, with demonstrations held outside the Government House in Bangkok. The government aims to capitalize on the gaming industry, but faces resistance from those who oppose the expansion of gambling.

site_title: Auto industry rocked by Trump’s 25% tariffs on US imports
summary: US President Donald Trump announced 25% tariffs on all vehicles and foreign-made auto parts imported into the US, affecting nearly half of all cars sold in the country last year. The move is expected to increase production costs, leading to higher prices and fewer options for consumers, as well as job losses in the US. Automakers, including General Motors, Ford, and Stellantis, saw their shares slump, while Toyota, Honda, and Hyundai also fell. The tariffs are set to begin no later than May 3, with exemptions for vehicles with US content.

site_title: Plummeting into Signal-gate: Giving stupidity a bad name
summary: US national security officials, including Vice-President JD Vance and former national security adviser Mike Waltz, have been accused of mishandling classified information by discussing secret US military operations in Yemen on a Signal messaging app. The incident, known as "Signal-gate," has raised concerns about the Trump administration's handling of sensitive information. The chat group included high-ranking officials, including Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth and CIA chief John Ratcliffe, who failed to properly secure the conversation. The incident has been criticized as "sloppy, careless, and incompetent" behavior, with some lawmakers calling for those involved to be held accountable.
