The move is expected to hit Asian and European equities, with automakers such as Toyota, Honda, and Nissan falling. The US auto industry, which accounts for about half of US car sales, is also expected to be severely impacted. The tariffs are seen as a major blow to the global economy, with Moody's Analytics warning that the move could undermine confidence, hit production, and reduce orders.

Ishiba questioned the fairness of uniform tariffs on all countries, a point he has been making.

Turkey would be the second Chinese car brand to produce vehicles in the country after BYD, which has a $1 billion plant in Manisa with an annual capacity of 150,000 vehicles.

site_title: OpenAI nears record US$40 billion funding round led by SoftBank
summary: OpenAI is nearing a record-breaking $40 billion funding round led by SoftBank, valuing the company at $300 billion, nearly double its previous valuation. SoftBank will invest $7.5 billion initially, with a second tranche of $30 billion later this year. The funding round underscores investors' enthusiasm for OpenAI, which expects to more than triple its revenue to $12.7 billion this year. The deal comes as OpenAI continues to grow at an extraordinary pace alongside the adoption of AI worldwide, but also faces significant costs for developing cutting-edge AI.

images.alt_text: Alibaba envisions becoming a key partner to companies developing and applying AI to the real world as models evolve.

site_title: Spreading the word about sake
summary: Kokuryu brewery, a renowned sake brand from Japan, is promoting its products globally through collaborations with chefs and restaurants. President Naoto Mizuno aims to break the perception that sake is limited to Japanese cuisine, instead showcasing its versatility in pairing with diverse styles, including European and Asian dishes. A recent dinner at Waku Ghin in Singapore featured Kokuryu's sakes paired with dishes from chef Tetsuya Wakuda, highlighting the compatibility of sake with various cuisines. The brewery's efforts are part of a growing trend of sake's inclusion in wine sommelier training programs and its increasing presence in cocktail bars and wine pairing menus.

site_title: Citigroup hiring dealmakers in Japan with fee pool seen reviving
summary: Citigroup is expanding its investment banking team in Japan, with a plan to grow the team by 15% as the country's deal fee pool is expected to revive. The move comes as Japan's economy is gradually recovering from decades of deflation and weak growth, with companies paying more attention to shareholder returns. The expansion is part of Citigroup's broader restructuring efforts, which include cutting 20,000 jobs globally. While a big surge in Japan's share of the global fee pool is not expected, a 5% increase is possible, according to Citigroup's head of investment banking in Tokyo.

images.alt_text: Citigroup disbanded its Asia high-touch equities sales trading desk in 2019, after accusing multiple staffers of gross misconduct and firing them without notice.
Citigroup’s back office has long been considered a weakness for the Wall Street bank, which has invested heavily to fix its problems as part of a larger revamp initiated by CEO Jane Fraser.
The incidents highlight Citigroup’s ongoing struggle to improve risk and controls after it was slapped with regulatory penalties and restrictions because of its poor systems.

site_title: Singtel’s NCS expands in the Philippines through a joint venture for clients to better access services
summary: Singtel's technology services arm, NCS, is expanding its presence in the Asia-Pacific region through a joint venture with Globe Telecom in the Philippines. NCSI Holdings will acquire a 51% stake in Yondu for 134 million Philippine pesos, giving clients better access to digital, cloud, data, and artificial intelligence services. The move aims to strengthen Singtel's global delivery network and establish it as a leading Pan-Asia technology services provider, with potential growth of 8.7% in the Philippines' IT services market from 2024 to 2028.

images.alt_text: Sea-Lion is part of a S$70 million artificial intelligence initiative in Singapore announced in December 2023.
Singtel must show results from NCS, Optus divisions to help fuel share price uptrend

site_title: UOB set to issue US$2 billion in dollar-denominated notes across 3 tranches
summary: UOB plans to issue US$2 billion in three tranches of dollar-denominated senior notes, priced during a stable market window ahead of US President Trump's proposed tariffs. The notes will be issued under the bank's US$30 billion global medium-term note programme and are expected to be rated "Aa1" by Moody's and "AA-" by S&P Global Ratings and Fitch Ratings. The deal saw strong interest from global institutional investors, with 59% of the three-year floating-rate notes allocated to US investors.

images.alt_text: UOB noted that the Australian dollar market was the largest pool of international benchmark capital for the bank this year.
The notes will be issued under UOB's US$30 billion global medium term note programme.

site_title: Xpeng may add EV output in Europe, Latin America in growth push
summary: Xpeng, a Chinese electric vehicle maker, plans to expand globally, focusing on Europe and Latin America. The company, which already has a presence in 30 countries, aims to start local production in Indonesia and set up a research and development center in Germany. Xpeng is "closely monitoring" opportunities in Europe and Latin America, particularly Brazil and Mexico, which will require local investments. The move comes as headwinds, including punitive tariffs in Europe, hurt the outlook for exports of made-in-China cars.

images.alt_text: Zeekr, Xpeng and GAC will need regulatory approval before drivers will be able to use the level three features in their cars.
Interest in Xpeng has also been helped by strong order momentum for its new battery EV models on the back of competitive pricing and autonomous driving features.

XPeng and Volkswagen have signed a memorandum of understanding to open their respective fast-charging networks to each other’s customers, which comprise more than 20,000 charging piles across 420 cities in China, they said in a joint statement.

site_title: Robinhood, moving beyond meme stocks, now wants to be your bank
summary: Robinhood is expanding its services to include checking and savings accounts for its "Gold" subscribers later this year. The accounts will offer high-yield interest rates, estate planning and tax advice, and same-day cash delivery. Unlike traditional banks, Robinhood will not be FDIC-insured, instead partnering with Coastal Community Bank for FDIC protection. The move aims to become a one-stop-shop for consumers' financial needs, offering investing, banking, retirement, and other products under a single brand.

images.alt_text: Founded in 2013, Robinhood became known for commission-free trading and letting investors trade cryptocurrencies.
The US Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to ease its crypto-related regulations under Trump’s leadership.
Robinhood intends to roll out the services with guidance from local regulators by late 2025, although it has not yet set a launch date.

site_title: Tesla troubles: Speed bump or early signs of impending crash?
summary: Tesla faces mounting challenges, including Elon Musk's ties to Donald Trump and increased electric vehicle competition, leading to a decline in its share price. The company is also under threat from other automakers, particularly Japan's carmakers, which have slashed export prices to the US to offset tariff hits. As a result, Tesla's position in the market is uncertain, raising concerns about its long-term prospects.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down 0.3 per cent at 42,454.79, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index fell 1.1 per cent to 5,712.20.
The bump to X’s advertising business has helped the company in other ways this year.
A demonstrator holds an anti-Tesla poster during a protest encouraging people to boycott Tesla, outside the Tesla Centre Park Royal in London, Britain, March 15, 2025.
BYD has risen quickly to the top of China’s car market – the world’s biggest and most competitive in terms of electric vehicles.
As BYD and CATL fight for stock-market dominance, the carmaker’s earnings may make a difference.

site_title: China’s industrial profits fall 0.3% in January to February
summary: China's industrial profits declined 0.3% in January to February, following a 11% rise in December and a 3.3% decline for the whole of 2024, according to National Bureau of Statistics data. This marks the first time industrial profits have increased since 2021. The data also shows that industrial firms with annual revenue of at least 20 million yuan (S$3.7 million) saw a slight improvement in their profit margins.

site_title: UOB taps rising South Korean interest in Asean with new FDI advisory centre in Seoul
summary: UOB has launched its 11th Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) Advisory Centre in Seoul, South Korea, to support South Korean firms expanding into the Asean region. The centre, which offers market-entry guidance, regulatory support, and financing solutions, follows a trend of rising interest in Asean among South Korean businesses. In 2023, South Korea contributed US$10.9 billion to Asean's total FDI, ranking sixth among top investors. Since UOB's FDI advisory unit was launched in 2011, it has supported over 150 South Korean firms in their expansion plans, with projected investments nearing S$3 billion.

images.alt_text: In February, Mida announced new tax incentives for companies investing in the JS-SEZ.

site_title: Europe: Shares end lower as US tariff deadline looms
summary: European shares ended 0.7% lower on Wednesday, marking the fourth decline in five sessions, as technology and healthcare stocks fell. Investors remain concerned about impending US tariffs set to take effect next week. Energy stocks rose, with crude prices jumping over 1%, but the Stoxx 600 index is on track for its best quarter in two years due to hopes for growth in Germany's economy. Despite US slowdown worries, sentiment towards Europe has turned positive, and investors are seeking value beyond US equities.

site_title: Trump hints at tariff concessions if China agrees to TikTok deal
summary: US President Donald Trump hinted at offering reduced tariffs on China if Beijing agrees to a deal for the sale of TikTok. Trump previously said the US was in talks with four groups interested in acquiring TikTok, with a law requiring the app to divest from its Chinese owner ByteDance or be banned in the US set to expire on April 5. Trump suggested a deal could be reached, with China playing a role in approving the sale.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D-printed miniature model of U.S. President-elect Donald Trump and TikTok logo are seen in this illustration taken January 19, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Paragon Reit unitholders to vote on proposed privatisation on Apr 22
summary: Paragon Reit unitholders will vote on a proposed privatisation on April 22, where they will receive S$0.98 per unit from the offeror Times Properties. The offer, considered fair and reasonable by independent financial adviser PrimePartners, represents a slight premium of 4.4% over net asset value and a premium of 7.1% over adjusted net asset value. The scheme is contingent on approval of amendments to the trust deed and requires 75% of total votes cast to pass, with unitholders expected to be paid the scheme consideration on June 4.

images.alt_text: Temasek-backed Cuscaden to privatise Paragon Reit at S$0.98 per unit.

Generic picture of Paragon Mall along Orchard Road on Feb 11, 2025. The Singapore Exchange-listed real estate investment trust (Reit) that holds Orchard Road’s The Paragon mall has received a $2.78 billion buyout offer from its major shareholder. Cuscaden Peak Investments – formerly Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) – proposed to privatise and delist Paragon Reit by way of a trust scheme of arrangement, they jointly announced on Feb 11. Paragon Reit currently owns Paragon mall, which accounts for 72 per cent of the Reit’s value, as well as The Clementi Mall and South Australia’s Westfield Marion Shopping Centre.

site_title: Singapore banks flagged for financing Harita’s coal-powered nickel smelters; OCBC tops list of financiers
summary: Singapore banks OCBC, UOB, and DBS have been flagged for financing coal-powered nickel smelters and refineries by Harita Group, a leading Indonesian conglomerate. The banks loaned a total of US$923 million since 2018, with OCBC leading the list at US$635 million. Harita's operations in Indonesia are currently powered by 890 megawatts of captive coal plants, despite plans to commission a 300 MW solar panel facility by 2025. Experts say banks must balance the need for electric vehicle adoption with reducing global warming, and more transparency and disclosure from banks and nickel clients is needed.

images.alt_text: The new mining law will grant priority access to mining concessions for companies that aim to build processing facilities.

Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto looks on during a meeting with US President Joe Biden in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on November 12, 2024. (Photo by Brendan SMIALOWSKI / AFP)
Generic photo of vehicles being charged at a Electric Vehicle (EV) charging station on Aug 5, 2022. Can be used for future Electric Vehicles, cars, vans/commercial vehicles and charging stories.
Nickel, which is used to make both stainless steel and EV batteries, has endured a two-year slump due to weak demand and booming Indonesian supplies.
FILE PHOTO: A worker watches as trucks load up raw nickel near Sorowako, Indonesia's Sulawesi island, January 8, 2014.   REUTERS/Yusuf Ahmad/File Photo
A Volvo FL Electric, a heavy duty commercial truck.

site_title: China raises record 1.45 trillion yuan from bonds in stimulus signal
summary: China has raised a record 1.45 trillion yuan from bonds, signaling an intention to stimulate growth while containing market risks. The move follows a surge in debt issuance to support the economy amid housing woes, deflationary pressures, and trade tensions. The People's Bank of China has also tightened liquidity to support its currency, leading to higher bond yields. Beijing plans to boost the supply of new government bonds to 11.86 trillion yuan this year, aiming to expand fiscal spending and counter the impact of US tariffs.

images.alt_text: The committee of the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) suggested stepping up monetary policy adjustment and control, and improving monetary policy to be more forward-looking, targeted and effective.
A string of recent economic data, including manufacturing activity, industrial output and retail sales, provide encouraging signs for the economy’s continued recovery.
Chinese bonds have come under pressure this year as the central bank has refrained from lowering interest rates or banks’ required reserve ratio since September.

site_title: China pauses new deals with Li Ka-shing family after Panama ports plan
summary: China has instructed state-owned firms to pause new collaborations with businesses linked to Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing and his family, following his plan to sell two Panama ports to a global consortium. Existing ties are unaffected, and regulators are reviewing the family's investments in China and abroad to better understand their business dealings. The directive does not necessarily mean Beijing will bar state firms from working with businesses linked to Li. The ports sale is expected to net CK Hutchison over $19 billion in cash proceeds.

images.alt_text: While CK Hutchison Holdings typically holds press and analyst briefings following the announcement of its annual results, they were skipped this year, highlighting the sensitivity of the port deal.
The Panama deal is not the first time Li’s business dealings have drawn Beijing’s ire.
Cargo vessels docked at Balboa Port, operated by Panama Ports Company, at the Panama Canal, in Panama City, Panama, Feb 1, 2025.
Port of Balboa at the Panama Canal; CK Hutchison will sell 43 ports in 23 countries, while keeping facilities in mainland China and Hong Kong.
Li Ka-shing is unlikely to be the last billionaire caught between the world’s two biggest economies.
CK Hutchison said last week it agreed to sell most of the global US$22.8 billion ports business, including assets it holds along the strategically important Panama Canal, to a group led by BlackRock.

site_title: GameStop to borrow US$1.3 billion to fund Bitcoin buying spree
summary: GameStop plans to borrow $1.3 billion to fund its Bitcoin buying spree, despite investors' growing skepticism of the strategy. The move comes as the cryptocurrency is down 18% from its all-time high in January. GameStop joins a growing list of companies using convertible debt to buy Bitcoin, with a 35-40% conversion premium on the bonds. The retailer's shares fell 6.6% after the filing, amid tariff uncertainty and choppy economic data.

images.alt_text: A wave of companies that have followed Strategy’s footstep have seen their stock prices soar after announcing plans to buy Bitcoin.
GameStop has been grappling with a slower turnaround of its main business as it struggles to ramp up sales of videogame hardware and collectibles.
GameStop has been struggling with declining sales in its primary business of selling new and used video game discs due to a shift towards digital downloads and game streaming.

site_title: Lendlease shuts down Cathay Cineplexes at Jem over S$4.3 million rent arrears
summary: Cathay Cineplexes, a Singapore-based cinema chain, will shut down operations at its Jem outlet in Jurong East due to significant rental arrears of over S$4.3 million. The decision comes after the landlord, Lendlease Global Commercial Reit, terminated the lease. The cinema chain has been struggling since the Covid-19 pandemic and has been undergoing "rightsizing" and realigning its business. Cathay will continue to work with its landlord to settle outstanding debts and explore new opportunities for long-term sustainability.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, cinema attendance stood at 10 million in 2023, down from its peak of 22.1 million in 2011.
Cathay Cineplexes' delayed rental payments could indicate a structural issue among cinema operators, says one analyst.

site_title: China banks ramp up bad property loan disposals to boost economy
summary: China's big banks are accelerating efforts to write off soured property loans to clean up their balance sheets, with some doubling their annual quota for write-offs. The move comes as policymakers urge lenders to prioritize the disposal of non-performing real estate loans to boost the economy. China's financial industry disposed of a record 3.8 trillion yuan in bad assets in 2024, with loans to property developers accounting for a significant share. The accelerated write-offs are expected to free up resources for banks to engage in other businesses and improve their balance sheets.

images.alt_text: China has set an ambitious economic growth goal of about 5 per cent for 2025 and brought its fiscal deficit target to the highest in more than three decades.
US President Donald Trump’s additional 10 per cent of tariffs on Chinese imports took effect on Mar 4, adding on to Feb 4 tariffs.
China is beefing up the strength of its banking system after enacting a string of stimulus policies including cuts to mortgage rates and key policy rates.

site_title: Trump officials’ private data accessible online: report
summary: Top security advisers to US President Donald Trump's private data, including cell phone numbers, email addresses, and passwords, are accessible online. National Security Advisor Mike Waltz, Director of National Intelligence Tulsi Gabbard, and Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth's data can be found via commercial data-search services and hacked data dumped online. The data was linked to accounts on messaging services WhatsApp and Signal, potentially exposing them to spyware. The officials have not responded to requests for comment, but the National Security Council confirmed that their accounts and passwords had been changed in 2019.

images.alt_text:
US National Security Advisor Mike Waltz speaks during a meeting with US President Donald Trump and US Ambassadors in the Cabinet Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on March 25, 2025. US National Security Advisor Mike Waltz on March 25 claimed "full responsibility" for mistakenly adding a journalist to a group chat in which top American officials discussed impending strikes in Yemen.
"I take full responsibility. I built the group; my job is to make sure everything's coordinated," Waltz told Fox News host Laura Ingraham in his first interview on the security breach, adding that he does not personally know Jeffrey Goldberg, the journalist who was added to the chat. (Photo by Mandel NGAN / AFP)

site_title: As Malaysia’s Sapura Energy tumbles, Petronas’ silence is telling
summary: Malaysia's national oil giant Petronas is watching as Sapura Energy, once a flagship of the country's ambition to build stalwarts in the upstream energy segment, teeters on the brink of collapse. Sapura Energy, which Petronas had propelled into the big league, is buried under over RM10 billion in debt and years of financial and strategic missteps. Petronas' silence in the face of Sapura's struggles is striking, especially given its long-standing ties to the company. The collapse of Sapura Energy raises questions about Petronas' shift towards financial discipline and strategic detachment, and whether the company's decision not to intervene signals a new era for Malaysia's oil and gas sector.

images.alt_text: “This is not a bailout like the ones in the past,” Anwar says.
Malaysian-listed Sapura Energy is a shadow of its former self these days, with its shares languishing at a mere RM0.045 apiece – a stark contrast to their RM4.95 peak in December 2013.

site_title: Gold firms on concerns over Trump’s reciprocal tariff plans
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to a record high of $3,022.69 per ounce amid concerns over US President Donald Trump's plans to impose reciprocal tariffs, fueling inflation and trade tensions. Trump's 25% tariff on imported cars and light trucks is set to take effect on April 2, prompting investors to seek safe-haven assets. The US personal consumption expenditures data, due on Friday, will provide insight into the US interest rate path, with some analysts predicting a potential rate cut later this year.

images.alt_text: The hallmark details on a one kilogram gold bar are seen at London bullion dealers Gold Investments Ltd. in this arranged photograph in London, U.K., on Thursday, April 4, 2013. Gold traders are split on whether bullion will plunge into its first bear market since 2008 as economies improve or rally as central banks buy more debt. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Nomura in talks for offices at Manhattan’s Penn 2 tower
summary: US unit of Tokyo-based Nomura Holdings is in talks with Vornado Realty Trust for new offices at Manhattan's Penn 2 tower, joining a wave of companies seeking upgraded or redeveloped offices in the city. Negotiations are ongoing, with plans potentially changing. The Penn 2 tower, recently redeveloped by Vornado, is home to Major League Soccer and Madison Square Garden Entertainment, and may also attract Universal Music Group. This move comes as Nomura seeks to downsize its footprint in Manhattan, with plans to exit its current lease at Worldwide Plaza in 2027.

images.alt_text: Japan’s financial institutions have sought to develop their asset and wealth management businesses to generate income from the mammoth savings held by Japanese households, of which around half is currently held in cash and deposits.
Nomura says it will stick to its target set four years ago, to deploy US$125 billion of sustainable financing to March 2026.
Nomura is making a big push in private banking as part of its efforts to diversify revenue beyond investment banking and global markets.
Chief executive officer Kentaro Okuda has steered Nomura to an earnings recovery, even as it grapples with the fallout from a pair of scandals in recent months.

site_title: China bubble tea chain Mixue profits spike 40% in 2024
summary: China-based bubble tea chain Mixue reported a 40% spike in profits to US$613 million in 2024, driven by revenue growth from goods and equipment sales. The company, which surpassed McDonald's and Starbucks in store count, has 41,584 stores in China and 4,895 globally. Mixue plans to expand its supply chain in China while focusing on the South-east Asia market, with its stock jumping over 40% after a recent Hong Kong listing.

images.alt_text: Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.
Mixue relies on a franchising model to help it open shops across the country, with a deep penetration into lower-tier cities and towns.
Mixue is best known for selling fruit and tea drinks, coffee and ice cream, typically for about US$1.

site_title: Reeves says Labour has rebuilt UK headroom to £9.9 billion
summary: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves announced that the UK has rebuilt its budget buffer to £9.9 billion, following a series of cuts to government expenditure. This move ensures the government meets its key fiscal rule, requiring day-to-day spending to be covered by tax receipts. Reeves stated that the previous headroom was wiped out by growth downgrades and higher borrowing costs, and that the British people trusted the government to manage the public finances responsibly. The pound remained stable, and gilt yields fell after Reeves' comments.

site_title: US: Wall St opens mixed as investors assess tariff outlook
summary: US stocks opened mixed on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average rising 0.19% to 42,667.37. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite fell 0.04% and 0.30%, respectively. Investors are cautious ahead of economic data and the expected implementation of fresh tariffs by the Trump administration next week. The mixed market sentiment reflects uncertainty over the impact of the tariffs on the US economy.

site_title: New fiscal era has challenges for Germany, not only opportunities
summary: Germany's new chancellor-in-waiting, Friedrich Merz, has triggered significant investment-led stimulus with a historic spending package of up to €1.4 trillion, diluting the country's constitutional debt brake. The move is expected to boost Europe's geopolitical stability, particularly in Ukraine, and create a €500 billion infrastructure fund. However, this shift may face opposition from the far-right AfD party and raise concerns about inflation and higher government borrowing costs. The new fiscal plans also risk straining EU relations and may require adjustments to Merz's Agenda 2030 tax-cutting package.

images.alt_text: A wind turbine in front of the lignite-fired power station operated by German energy giant RWE near Neurath, western Germany.

site_title: Unlocking flavours: What is an Asian Mediterranean diet, and can Singapore dishes be adapted to it?
summary: Associate Professor Verena Tan has created an Asian version of the Mediterranean diet, adapting local ingredients and cooking methods to make the diet more accessible and affordable for Singaporeans. The diet, dubbed the Asian Mediterranean diet, is high in fibre and monounsaturated fat, low in sugar and animal protein, and has been shown to reduce the risk of chronic diseases. A pilot study found that 12 out of 14 local dishes developed using Asian ingredients were well-received by patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease. The diet is set to be presented at international conferences and a comprehensive intervention study is planned in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The mental health score of employees with unhealthy diets is much lower than that of workers who eat healthily.
Diabetes is a treatable condition, but many are unaware they have the disease.
Non-starchy vegetables such as broccoli should take up half of diabetics' plates.

site_title: US: Stocks slip as auto tariffs approach
summary: US stocks slipped on Wednesday, March 26, as the White House announced President Donald Trump's plan to unveil fresh tariffs on the auto sector. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 0.3%, the S&P 500 Index dropped 1.1%, and the Nasdaq Composite Index tumbled 2%. Automakers, particularly Tesla, fell on the news, with Tesla closing down 5.6%. Investors are concerned about the impact of tariffs on the economy and are waiting to see the reciprocal tariffs on April 2nd, contributing to market jitters.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 19, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Paris and London’s wealth loss is Dubai’s gain
summary: Paris, once a top destination for private equity and hedge funds, is experiencing a decline in its appeal due to rising taxes and a gridlocked parliament. In contrast, Dubai is gaining ground with its tax-free environment, reduced red tape, and growing financial sector. This shift is expected to continue, with other European cities like Madrid and Milan also facing competition from the UAE. To stem the tide, Paris must devise a new narrative beyond its traditional focus on tourism and luxury, and invest in making the city more livable for young professionals.

images.alt_text: The Business Times lays out the opportunities presented by the three hubs -- Singapore, Dubai and Hong Kong -- and the type of wealth flows they attract.
The Jumeirah Hotel in London hosted an event to attract non-doms from the UK to Abu Dhabi.

site_title: Fidelity tests stablecoin in latest Wall Street blockchain push
summary: Fidelity Investments is testing a stablecoin, a type of cryptocurrency that aims to maintain a stable value with a traditional asset like the US dollar. The move comes as other large financial institutions, such as PayPal and Robinhood, are also exploring stablecoin products. Fidelity's stablecoin trial is part of its broader push into the digital asset sector, which includes a Bitcoin fund and an Ether fund. The company's stablecoin project is being carried out from its digital assets division, which offers execution and custody services for institutional investors.

images.alt_text: China’s pension system faces an imminent funding shortage as ageing accelerates, birth rates drop and more young people suspend monthly contributions to the state-led “basic pension” plan, known as the first pillar.
Charles Schwab was down for more than 3,400 users.
The IPO comes amid heightened capital markets activity in India, where stock markets are trading near a record high

site_title: Half of American households hold 97.5% of the national wealth
summary: The richest 0.1% of American households, comprising 133,000 families, gained over $6 trillion in net wealth, mainly due to a surge in corporate equities and mutual fund shares. They now hold 13.8% of total wealth, while the bottom 50% hold just 2.5%. Meanwhile, the wealth share of the affluent households between the 90th and 99th percentiles decreased by 2.4 percentage points. This trend is partly attributed to demographics, with older households and those born before 1965 accumulating more wealth.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 19, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Oil settles up 1% on US crude and fuel stock draw, Venezuela supply worries
summary: Oil prices rose 1-2% on Wednesday, driven by a 3.3 million-barrel drop in US crude inventories and concerns over tightening global supply due to US tariffs on Venezuelan crude. Brent crude futures rose 77 cents to $73.79 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose 65 cents to $69.65 a barrel. The US threat of tariffs on nations buying Venezuelan crude and ongoing sanctions on Iran's oil sales have sparked fears of potential supply disruptions, potentially losing Venezuela $4.9 billion in revenue.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of a Petronas fuel station is seen with the Petronas Twin Towers in the background in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Picture taken February 10, 2016. REUTERS/Olivia Harris      TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY/File Photo
The OCBC Bank Holland Village branch is seen on Feb 26, 2025.
Brent crude futures settled 2 cents higher, or 0.03 per cent, at US$73.02 a barrel on Tuesday.

site_title: Alibaba debuts AI model that can process video, audio on phones
summary: Alibaba has released a new AI model, Qwen2.5-Omni-7B, that can process text, pictures, audio, and video on mobile phones and laptops, offering efficient multimodal capabilities. The model demonstrated high performance in speech understanding and generation. Alibaba plans to spend more on AI and cloud computing than it has in the past decade, aiming to become a key partner for companies developing and applying AI to the real world.

images.alt_text: Alibaba Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

site_title: OpenAI expects revenue will triple to US$12.7 billion this year
summary: OpenAI expects its revenue to triple to $12.7 billion this year, driven by its paid AI software. The company is in talks to raise up to $40 billion in funding, valuing it at up to $300 billion. Despite soaring revenue, OpenAI faces significant costs for developing cutting-edge AI systems and is not expected to be cash-flow positive until 2029. The company is also restructuring from a non-profit to a for-profit public benefit corporation.

site_title: Tracking the growth: Key facts about Vietnam-Singapore ties
summary: Vietnam and Singapore have upgraded their ties to a Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, solidifying their growing economic relationship. The partnership aims to boost trade, foreign investment, and cooperation in key sectors. Vietnam is seeking to achieve double-digit GDP growth to become Asia's next tiger economy. The upgrade comes amid improved US trade terms, which have attracted foreign investors, including a significant sell-off of GoTo shares and increased stock market activity in Vietnam. The partnership is expected to further strengthen bilateral ties and enhance economic collaboration between the two nations.

site_title: Trump drives trade war fears with 25% auto tariffs
summary: US President Donald Trump announced a 25% tariff on imported vehicles, effective April 3, as part of a global trade war. The move sparked criticism and threats of retaliation from affected US allies, including Canada and Japan. The tariffs are expected to increase prices and hurt the global auto industry, with some four million cars from Canada and Mexico now facing 25% or more tariffs. The US imported $474 billion worth of automotive products in 2024, and the new levies are expected to cost car buyers thousands of dollars more.

images.alt_text: (FILES) This photo taken on April 18, 2024 shows BYD electric cars for export waiting to be loaded onto a ship at a port in Yantai, in eastern China's Shandong province. Chinese battery and carmaker BYD saw a surge in revenue last year, a stock filing showed on March 24, 2025, surpassing the $100 billion mark and beating rival Tesla as the Shenzhen-based firm accelerates its overseas expansion. (Photo by AFP) / China OUT

site_title: Stocks to watch: Paragon Reit, mm2 Asia, ST Engineering, UMS Integration
summary: Paragon Reit's manager will hold an extraordinary general meeting on Apr 22 to vote on a proposed privatisation via a trust scheme of arrangement. The proposed terms, deemed fair and reasonable by independent financial adviser PrimePartners, offer S$0.98 per unit to unitholders. Meanwhile, mm2 Asia's Jem outlet will cease operations after its landlord, Lendlease Global Commercial Reit, terminates the lease agreement due to S$4.3 million in unpaid rental arrears. ST Engineering's subsidiary has incorporated a joint venture company to develop in-house software capabilities for the Home Team. UMS Integration has received approval for its secondary listing on Bursa Malaysia, which is expected to improve share liquidity.

site_title: X ad sales expected to grow for first time since Musk deal
summary: Elon Musk's X is projected to generate $1.31 billion in US advertising sales in 2025, a 17.5% increase, according to Emarketer. This marks the first year of advertising revenue growth since Musk acquired the company in 2022. The growth is attributed to advertisers returning after Musk became a senior adviser to US President Donald Trump, reversing their departure in protest of X's loosened content standards. Globally, X's ad sales are estimated to be $2.26 billion, a 16.5% increase.

images.alt_text: The Starlink pilot programme envisages cooperation with Vietnamese companies to distribute hardware equipment and deliver services to customers.
Elon Musk Musk launched into a familiar pitch that Teslas will soon be capable of driving autonomously, but execution still lags.

The recall covers just over 46,000 vehicles built from November 2023 through February 27 of this year, Tesla said in a filing with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and is the eighth recall for the SUV since January 2024.

site_title: Indonesia to use one million African weevils to spur palm output
summary: Indonesia plans to introduce one million African weevils to boost palm oil production, which has been stalling due to old trees and constrained supply. The weevils, collected from Tanzania, aim to improve pollination and fruit development, helping to revive production growth. This move comes as palm oil prices have surpassed soyoil, due in part to Malaysia's supply constraints. The initiative aims to support Indonesia's palm oil industry, which has faced criticism for its environmental impact, and potentially help the sector regain its status as the world's cheapest vegetable oil.

images.alt_text: Indonesia launched an effort this year to improve governance of its forest and palm oil cultivation after facing criticism that the plantations are a major driver of deforestation.
Projected earnings growth for plantation players in 2025 is driven by firm selling prices amid tight supply and strong demand.
The acquisition target is primarily engaged in the business of oil palm plantation.

FILE PHOTO: A worker pushes a wheelbarrow of fresh fruit bunches of oil palm tree during harvest at a palm oil plantation in Kuala Selangor, Selangor, Malaysia April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain/File Photo

site_title: UMS Integration, Grand Venture Technology get nods for secondary listing in Malaysia
summary: Singapore-listed companies UMS Integration and Grand Venture Technology have received approval for a secondary listing on the main market of Bursa Malaysia. This move aims to widen investor base and improve share liquidity for UMS Integration, while also providing access to another equity market for future fund-raising and growth.

images.alt_text: Market watchers believe that dual-listings are not an ideal scenario, and that companies will have to justify the costs of such a move over time.
Analysts from UOB Kay Hian (UOBKH), Maybank and DBS have upgraded the counter to “buy” from “hold”, with target prices of S$1.32, S$1.16 and S$1.31, respectively.
The addition of these semicon roles will help companies address immediate manpower needs while they wait for sufficient local talent to be developed, said industry players.

site_title: Pop Mart profit more than doubles driven by Labubu-doll craze
summary: Pop Mart International Group has reported a profit more than doubling due to strong overseas sales, particularly driven by the popularity of its Labubu dolls. Sales of 'The Monsters' dolls rose to 3 billion yuan in 2024, up from 368 million yuan the previous year. The company's shares have increased by 350% in the past year, and it plans to expand its global footprint with a focus on North America and Europe, aiming to enhance brand experience and recognition through physical stores and cross-boundary integration of pop culture.

images.alt_text: Chinese equities, as measured by the MSCI China Index, returned 40% since the start of 2024, far outpacing the 16% return from the S&P 500.
Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.
Popmart’s meteoric rise, from under HK$20 to about HK$93 per share, underscores the power of having a blockbuster product - Labubu.
Pop Mart is likely the first homegrown Chinese consumer brand to achieve significant global success by attracting consumers via intellectual property, design and products, rather than pricing.

site_title: GE2025: Leong Mun Wai re-elected as PSP chief ahead of general election
summary: Non-Constituency MP Leong Mun Wai has been re-elected as party chief of the opposition Progress Singapore Party, taking over from Ms Hazel Poa. Leong, who stepped down 13 months ago, will lead the party into the general election. He was re-elected on March 26 after a substantial refresh of the party's leadership slate, with 24 candidates vying for 12 elected seats on the central executive committee. The party's founder, Dr. Tan Cheng Bock, praised Leong for owning up to his earlier mistake and expressed confidence in his leadership.

site_title: DBS’ key milestones under CEO Piyush Gupta
summary: DBS' CEO Piyush Gupta has achieved several key milestones during his tenure. Under his leadership, DBS has successfully navigated the global financial landscape, including a 9.8 times oversubscription for NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer. Gupta has also seen the company expand its operations, while managing risks such as market volatility and economic uncertainty. Despite these challenges, DBS continues to thrive, with a strong financial position and a reputation as one of the world's leading banks. Gupta's leadership has been instrumental in driving the bank's success and growth.

site_title: Best, but not necessarily the biggest: Piyush Gupta on DBS’ transformation
summary: DBS, one of the world's largest banks, has undergone a transformation under CEO Piyush Gupta's 15-year tenure, becoming the largest bank in South-east Asia. The bank has achieved numerous accolades, including "World's Best Bank" by Global Finance and "Global Bank of the Year" by The Banker. Gupta credited his clear vision, a focus on short-term results, and a willingness to adapt to digital technologies for DBS's success. The bank has become data-driven, agile, and has a culture where individuals are accountable and willing to take decisions. Gupta also emphasized the importance of companies having a sense of purpose and giving back to society, as reflected in DBS's philanthropic efforts.

images.alt_text: DBS deputy chief executive and incoming CEO Tan Su Shan during an interview with The Straits Times at DBS HQ on Aug 12, 2024.

Signage atop the DBS Group Holdings Ltd. headquarters building in Singapore, on Monday, Feb. 10, 2025. DBS shares jumped after the lender reported earnings that met expectations and unveiled a investor payout plan. Photographer: Suhaimi Abdullah/Bloomberg

site_title: HDB eases income assessment rules, move gives young couples more BTO options
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore is relaxing income assessment rules for young couples buying Build-To-Order (BTO) flats. From July, couples can delay income assessment until just before collecting keys, allowing them to qualify for higher loan amounts. This change aims to help couples settle down earlier and buy larger flats, particularly those planning to have children. The HDB will also launch 12,000 new BTO flats with shorter waiting times of under three years from 2025 to 2027.

site_title: Don’t mourn DFI’s sale of Cold Storage, Giant; its modernisation journey could pay off soon
summary: DFI Retail Group sold its Cold Storage and Giant stores in Singapore for S$125 million, a move seen as part of its strategy to prune its business portfolio and invest in technology. The sale comes after the company reported a profitable Singapore food business in Q4 2024, despite a negative 65.8% total return on shares over the past decade. The deal is believed to be a calculated move to drive profitability and modernize the business, rather than a response to financial struggles.

images.alt_text: Macrovalue's owners Gary Yap (left) and Andrew Lim (right) with Cold Storage managing director Lim Boon Cheong (centre) at CS Fresh in Great World City.
Macrovalue owners, Gary Yap (right) and Andrew Lim (left), together with Cold Storage MD Lim Boon Cheong (centre)
Giant’s more mainstream customers will enjoy better prices on basic products that are imported from Malaysia.
DFI’s Singapore food business comprises 48 Cold Storage stores - which includes the Cold Storage, CS Fresh, and Jason’s Deli brands - 41 Giant stores and two distribution centres.
Cold Storage, Giant sold to Malaysian group for S$125 million.
Macrovalue is set to fully acquire Cold Storage Singapore, which comprises 48 stores (under the Cold Storage, CS Fresh and Jason’s Deli brands), 41 Giant stores, and two distribution centres.

site_title: Asia’s biggest art hub soldiers on
summary: Hong Kong is maintaining its title as Asia's biggest art hub despite political uncertainties and economic challenges. The city's art scene is thriving with major events such as Art Basel Hong Kong and exhibitions featuring works by Picasso, Renoir, and Cezanne. The Hong Kong Art Week is also showcasing local and international artists, with jewelry brands highlighting their spring collections. Meanwhile, a researcher is promoting a culturally adapted "Asian Mediterranean" diet, blending local flavors with Mediterranean principles.

site_title: Vietnam allows Elon Musk’s Starlink to provide pilot service
summary: Vietnam has allowed Elon Musk's Starlink to provide a pilot satellite internet service for five years, with a maximum of 600,000 subscribers, until January 1, 2031. The decision paves the way for SpaceX to invest in telecommunications services using low-orbit satellite technology. The service will be available to customers nationwide, with cooperation from Vietnamese companies for hardware distribution and delivery. There will be no restrictions on foreign ownership, and the service will ensure national defense and security. This move aims to strengthen trade ties with the US and avoid potential tariffs.

images.alt_text: Attempts by Musk's SpaceX to enter Vietnam – a market of nearly 100 million people – were put on hold in late 2023 after the government declined to lift a ban on foreign control of satellite Internet providers.

site_title: PropNex Realty changes law firm in ‘99-to-1’ suit to avoid conflict of interest
summary: Property agency PropNex Realty has changed its law firm to Rajah & Tann in a "99-to-1" lawsuit against Melvin Li, who claims he was misled into paying S$1.2 million in stamp duties and surcharges for his parents' condominium apartments. The agency and agent Ian Sng disputed Li's allegations, with PropNex Realty denying responsibility for its fellow defendant's acts. Rajah & Tann will review the matter and advise on steps to protect PropNex's interests.

site_title: US dollar edges up as tariff uncertainty looms, pound in focus
summary: The US dollar edged up on Wednesday as investors weighed uncertainty over US economic outlook and potential tariffs. The dollar index is expected to drop roughly 4% in the quarter, despite a 0.05% gain on the day. The euro has dropped to $1.0776, while sterling weakened after slower-than-expected inflation data. Investors are cautious ahead of a potential US tariff announcement next week, with some speculating about potential negotiations and negotiations.

images.alt_text: money, dollar, currency, us-dollar, finance, paper money, banknotes, seem, america, money, money, dollar, dollar, dollar, dollar, dollar

site_title: A living laboratory for future urban solutions
summary: Singapore aims to become a living laboratory for future urban solutions, leveraging cutting-edge technologies and human-centric approaches to address global challenges. With a strong track record in innovation and sustainability, the city-state seeks to build on its "City in a Garden" reputation by embracing global best practices in urban planning and development. Key areas of focus include water solutions, sustainable materials, and tri-sector partnerships between government, corporations, and universities, with a focus on talent development and global market access to drive growth and remain a leading global innovation hub.

site_title: GE2025: Amid challenging environment, much is at stake in the election, says PM Wong
summary: Singapore's general election (GE2025) is likely just a few months away, with Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasizing the need for the country to be strong and united in a challenging global environment. Wong has been making efforts to renew the leadership team and party, despite not having a specific timeline for the election. The PAP's slate of candidates is still being narrowed down, with the party recruiting from various sectors. Wong stresses the importance of renewal, warning that failure to do so could lead to negative consequences for Singapore in the long term.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister and Minister for Finance Lawrence Wong (right) and Vietnamese Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh at the VSIP groundbreaking event.

site_title: Temasek-backed Pentagreen, UK’s impact investor commit US$80 million to scale South-east Asia’s clean energy
summary: Pentagreen Capital, backed by Temasek and HSBC, has invested US$80 million in ib vogt, a global renewable energy company, to scale up clean energy projects in South-east Asia. The funds will support utility-scale solar and battery storage projects, unlocking approximately US$300 million worth of clean energy projects with a total power generation capacity of 260 MWp and 175 MW hours of battery storage. This investment aims to fill a funding gap for greenfield projects in the region and attract more project financing.

images.alt_text: Catalytic capital could be key to unlocking private investment in renewable infrastructure.
There are discussions to retire the South Luzon Thermal Energy Corporation (SLTEC) coal-fired plant in the Philippines 10 years ahead of schedule and replace it  with clean energy.

HSBC and other banks increasingly look to align their operations with a corporate commitment to reach net-zero emissions by mid-century, forcing a gradual tightening of lending to high-polluting sectors.
With the exception of Singapore and the Philippines, South-east Asia’s energy sector is largely nationalised.

site_title: Grab seeks up to US$2 billion loan for potential takeover of GoTo
summary: Grab Holdings is in talks to raise a US$2 billion loan to back its potential takeover of Indonesia-based rival GoTo Group, which could fetch over US$7 billion. The bridge loan has a 12-month tenor and is being considered alongside a bond or equity take out. Grab is moving ahead with due diligence and is backed by Uber Technologies. The deal comes amid a busy time for dealmaking in Asia, with valuations becoming more attractive and rainmakers seeking opportunities.

images.alt_text: The merger talks between Grab, which is backed by Uber, and GoTo have been on-and-off but have not resulted in a deal, primarily due to competition concerns over the two major players in South-east Asia merging.
Grab has held on-and-off talks with GoTo, but a merger never materialised, partly because of antitrust concerns likely to arise from combining two dominant South-east Asian tech companies.
The cash bonuses will be calculated based on drivers’ work activity, the details of which will be discussed between companies and the manpower ministry.

site_title: Jefferies profit drops on pullback in deals, capital markets
summary: Jefferies Financial Group reported a 15% decline in first-quarter earnings to $127.8 million, down from a year earlier, due to a drop in investment-banking and capital-markets revenue. The firm's total revenue fell 8.4% to $1.59 billion, with asset-management revenue declining 30% to $191.7 million. Jefferies' president, Brian Friedman, attributed the decline to uncertainty around US policy and geopolitics, and noted that while deals are still happening, the firm does not yet have a clear cadence for investment-banking transactions.

images.alt_text: In 2024, the investment bank hired 161 employees for Asia-Pacific, accounting for 13 per cent of its global headcount, up from 11  per cent in 2023.
In 2023, Jefferies referenced a challenging landscape that cut into its overall performance, which it called a “trough year”.

site_title: OCBC cuts 2023 financed emissions in most ‘dirty’ sectors except steel and aviation
summary: OCBC, a Singaporean bank, reported a decline in financed emissions for four carbon-intensive sectors - power, oil and gas, real estate, and shipping - in 2023, with the exception of the steel and aviation sectors. Despite this, OCBC's emissions intensity in the steel sector increased due to expanded portfolio growth from carbon-intensive Chinese steel producers. The bank remains on track to meet its 2030 net-zero targets for the power, oil and gas, and real estate sectors, but still faces challenges in decarbonizing the steel and shipping sectors.

images.alt_text: MUFG follows Tokyo-based rivals Nomura Holdings and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group in quitting the climate group.
Transition opens a new world of potential business for sustainable finance, and could be good for the bottom line, the writer says.
OCBC group chief executive officer Helen Wong received S$1.2 million in base salary for FY2024.

site_title: Gold is the real ‘Trump put’
summary: US President Donald Trump's unpredictable behavior has led to a surge in gold prices, breaking through $3,000 per troy ounce. This rise is attributed to gold's role as a "Trump put" for international investors, providing a hedge against potential economic and political instability. The article suggests that gold's value is not solely due to its intrinsic worth, but also its ability to rise in anticipation of destructive events. While the author remains skeptical of gold as a standalone investment, they consider it a viable option as a hedge against losses on stocks and bonds.

images.alt_text: Gold has risen 15 per cent so far this year, scaling an all-time peak of US$3,057.21 on Mar 20.
Gold’s role as a safe-haven asset is unique, and we believe that gold prices are supported at current levels.

site_title: ST Engineering and HTX form JV company with initial capital of S$10 million
summary: ST Engineering and the Home Team Science and Technology Agency (HTX) have formed a joint venture company, Codex Solutions, with an initial capital of S$10 million. ST Engineering's subsidiary will hold a 60% stake, focusing on developing and maintaining in-house software capabilities for the Home Team. HTX will contribute its expertise in product innovation and management. The partnership is expected to leverage ST Engineering's experience to deliver significant capabilities to HTX and the Home Team, with no material impact on ST Engineering's financials.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering will maintain its research and development spending, at 4 to 5% of group revenue for the next five years.

ST20240207_202454992664: Gin Tay/ mystengg07/ Mike Yeo/

site_title: Trump may implement copper import tariffs within weeks
summary: US President Donald Trump is expected to impose a duty of up to 25% on all copper imports within weeks, potentially sending prices to a record US$12,000 per tonne, according to Trafigura, the world's largest copper-trading firm. The move could roil the global copper market, with prices already rising in New York to a record of US$5.3740 a pound. The decision is expected to be made sooner than the 270-day deadline set by the Commerce Department.

images.alt_text: Cobalt has also soared this month – after an export moratorium introduced by the Democratic Republic of Congo, the world’s largest producer.
Freeport is building a US$3 billion copper smelter in East Java to process 1.7 million tonnes of copper concentrate.
Trump is also employing that authority to impose 25 per cent tariffs on two other industrial metals with those levies slated to take effect in March.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise on trade optimism, but US policy uncertainty lingers
summary: Asian stocks rose on Wednesday, driven by optimism over Donald Trump's planned tariff blitz, with hopes that the measures could be more targeted. Hong Kong, Tokyo, and Sydney advanced, while Jakarta jumped almost three percent. However, US policy uncertainty and a decline in consumer confidence tempered optimism, with the Conference Board's gauge of consumer confidence hitting its lowest level since 2021.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.67 per cent higher at 552.59 points on Tuesday, hitting its first gain in four sessions.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat at 42,587.50 while the broad-based S&P 500 Index advanced 0.2 per cent to 5,776.65 on Tuesday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 26)
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output fell 1.3% year-on-year in February, breaking its seven-month expansion streak. The country's factory output also saw a 1.3% drop, contrary to high growth expectations. Meanwhile, Singapore and Vietnam exchanged agreements on cooperation in areas such as electricity trade and QR payments. The cut-off yield for Singapore's six-month T-bill rose to 2.73%. Additionally, Temasek-backed Pentagreen and a UK-based impact investor committed US$80 million to accelerate renewable energy deployment in South-east Asia.

site_title: China adviser urges boosting consumption to 70% of GDP by 2035
summary: China's government has set a goal to boost domestic consumption to 70% of GDP by 2035, aiming to rebalance the economy away from investment and export. The target is part of a broader effort to narrow the international gap in consumption levels, currently around 55% of GDP. The move contrasts with the "Made in China 2025" policy, which focused on increasing manufacturing and production. Authorities plan to achieve this goal by increasing income and distributing more wealth to consumers, and may set a target in the next five-year economic plan.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is making plans to make a wealth connect programme with China’s Greater Bay area less restrictive and exploring whether it can extend its coverage to more mainland cities, Eddie Yue, chief executive of Hong Kong Monetary Authority, said on Wednesday.

site_title: Thai PM sails through no-confidence vote in parliament
summary: Thailand's Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra successfully survived a no-confidence vote in parliament, maintaining her coalition's stability. The vote, despite her low opinion poll ratings and economic growth lag, suggests a lower risk of near-term instability in the country. This outcome comes after governments led by her predecessor Thaksin were removed by courts or military coups due to their polarizing influence. Shinawatra has denied her government's influence, while Thaksin claims to be retired and only offers advice.

site_title: Nissan's new CEO to slash its vehicle development time
summary: Nissan plans to cut its vehicle development time by 30-37 months, aiming to boost competitiveness and refocus on customer preferences. The company's new CEO, Ivan Espinosa, aims to introduce five to six brand-oriented models globally, with the first car taking 37 months to develop and subsequent models taking 30 months. This shift comes as Nissan faces a deep sales slump, reduced debt rating, and potential loss of market share in Japan and the US.

images.alt_text: Nissan incoming CEO Ivan Espinosa, who first joined Nissan in Mexico in 2003 and has also held positions in South-east Asia and Europe, will take over from Apr 1.

site_title: Wall Street bonuses jump 32% as total surges to record
summary: Wall Street bonuses surged to a record $47.5 billion in 2024, a 32% increase from the previous year, with average bonuses reaching $244,700. This boost is attributed to a rebound in dealmaking, but economic uncertainty and policy changes may dampen the outlook. The increase is expected to generate $600 million in state income tax revenue and $275 million for the city. Despite the boom, New York State Comptroller Thomas DiNapoli warns of potential economic uncertainty, citing changes in federal policies and tariffs.

images.alt_text: Citigroup’s back office has long been considered a weakness for the Wall Street bank, which has invested heavily to fix its problems as part of a larger revamp initiated by CEO Jane Fraser.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield rises to 2.73%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) announced the latest six-month Treasury bill auction, with a cut-off yield of 2.73% and a median yield of 2.6%. Demand for the auction was lower, with S$15.8 billion in applications for the S$7.4 billion on offer. Experts attribute the decline in short-term Singapore dollar rates to "flush liquidity," and expect a partial normalization in liquidity going forward.

images.alt_text: As you age your financial situation and risk tolerance will change. Start with a higher proportion of growth stocks when you're younger and gradually shift to more dividend-paying stocks as you age.
DBS analysts say a “wall of money” could soon flow into S-Reits, as retail investors turn away from T-bills.

site_title: Making scents accessible and affordable
summary: Singapore-based fragrance brand Pristine has successfully recovered from a post-Covid sales slump and turned profitable by April 2023. Co-owners Edison Lim and Lincoln Thong expanded the business by launching scented laundry detergent pods under the Kapsa brand in May 2024. The company aims to increase sales in its existing overseas markets and diversify into other scented products. Pristine's revenue is expected to rise to S$5.4 million this year, driven by international sales and the ramp-up of Kapsa. The company also plans to launch perfume subscription service Amperscent and explore more laundry care items.

images.alt_text: Lee Ray Sheng, founder of mala restaurant chain A Hot Hideout, has since quit his job at consulting giant McKinsey and Co to run the business full-time.
From left: Pinnacle Marine's business development manager Ken Lee; chairman Laurence Chua and CEO Fabian Lim at the group's new shipyard, which was acquired for S$6 million.

site_title: Singapore stocks rise on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.2% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index (STI) ending at 3,963.71. ST Engineering was the top gainer, increasing 1.7% to S$6.67. The broader market saw 261 gainers and 223 losers, with S$1.2 billion worth of securities changing hands. The top loser was SGX, declining the most.

images.alt_text: Frasers Centrepoint Trust's equity fundraising exercise will be used partly to repay debts and fund the proposed acquisition of all the units in North Gem Trust (which holds interests in the South Wing of Northpoint City).

Hong Kong pushed higher a day after tanking more than two per cent on profit-taking and selling in the tech sector, while Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore and Wellington also advanced on Wednesday.

site_title: Defence contractor sold for 1 euro is one of Europe’s hottest stocks
summary: Austrian engine maker Steyr Motors, which was sold to German private equity firm Mutares for 1 euro in 2022, has seen its shares surge 1,614% to 240 euros, making it one of Europe's hottest stocks. The defence sector's boom, driven by the US under President Donald Trump's reduced security commitment to Europe, has attracted investors, with Steyr's sales forecast to surge 40% in 2025. Mutares has sold some of its Steyr shares, but remains a major shareholder, and the company's small size and limited supply of stock have contributed to the stock's rapid appreciation.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 index closed 0.67 per cent higher at 552.59 points on Tuesday, hitting its first gain in four sessions.

site_title: BYD aims to double overseas sales to 800,000 in 2025: chairman
summary: Chinese electric vehicle giant BYD aims to double its overseas sales to over 800,000 units in 2025, according to chairman Wang Chuanfu. The company plans to continue building factories overseas without partners, taking advantage of abundant funding, and will assemble cars locally to overcome tariffs. BYD expects to see a substantial rise in its market share in Britain and has "great opportunities" to grow in Latin American and South-east Asian countries. The company's profitability per vehicle is expected to exceed Toyota's, driven by its cost control and smart driving features.

images.alt_text: BYD has risen quickly to the top of China’s car market – the world’s biggest and most competitive in terms of electric vehicles.
Executive vice-president of Chinese electric and hybrid automotive manufacturer BYD Stella Li at a BYD dealership in Paris, France, March 20, 2025.
BYD reveals game-changing 5-minute EV charging system.
Automakers are drawn to flying cars as a means to alleviate urban congestion and unlock new transportation efficiencies.
BYD’s best-selling model this year in China has had its sticker price reduced by between 8 to 18 per cent, depending on the car’s specs.
BYD plans to use the proceeds to invest in research and development, expand overseas businesses, supplement its working capital, and for general corporate purposes.
BYD is the best-performing stock in the Bloomberg World Auto Manufacturers Index this year, gaining around 40 per cent.
BYD’s entrance in July into Vietnam underscores both the opportunities and challenges Chinese companies face as they seek to push into South-east Asia.

site_title: ECB pushes back against calls for looser bank rules
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has pushed back against calls for looser bank rules, citing concerns over financial instability. ECB banking regulator Patrick Montagner stated that financial watchdogs must take a prudent approach to banking, as the sector can cause instability. The ECB's stance comes amid expectations of lighter regulation in the US under President Donald Trump, who has tapped a vocal critic of stricter rules to lead the Federal Reserve's top banking regulator.

images.alt_text: The ECB cut rates earlier this month, but traders have pared bets on more action and are now almost equally torn between a cut and a pause at the Apr 16 to 17 gathering.
Inflation between 2025 and 2027 is seen at 2.2 per cent, 2 per cent and 2.1 per cent – slightly faster than in the previous round for each.

European Central Bank (ECB) Vice-President Luis de Guindos says: “What we’re seeing is that the new US administration isn’t very open to continuing with multilateralism, which is about co-operation across jurisdictions and finding common solutions for common problems."
The central bank lowered borrowing costs this month for the sixth time since June as inflation abates and the economy wobbles.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Parkview avoids loan default, plans mall refinancing
summary: Hong Kong builder Parkview Group has avoided a US$940 million loan default by replenishing its interest reserve account before a March 17 deadline. The company is in refinancing talks with banks over the facility, which backs a Beijing shopping mall complex. Parkview's cash-strapped situation stems from low occupancy rates at Parkview Green, which has not generated enough rental income to cover interest payments. The refinancing discussions come as concerns grow over the builder's ability to repay the facility, set to mature in August.

images.alt_text: Paul Chan (above), Hong Kong's financial secretary, emphasises artificial intelligence as a core industry.

site_title: Digital Core Reit acquires 20% stake in Osaka data centre for 13.2 billion yen
summary: Digital Core Reit acquired a 20% stake in an Osaka data centre for approximately 13.2 billion yen (S$117 million), supporting its expansion in top-tier global data centre markets. The deal is expected to be 1.8% accretive to the Reit's distribution per unit, with no change in net asset value per unit. The newly acquired data centre is freehold and leased to leading global cloud providers, increasing the Reit's annualised rent contribution from Osaka to 11%.

images.alt_text: Data centre landlord Digital Core Real Estate Investment Trust saw its full year revenue dip 0.3 per cent to US$102.3 million.
Digital Core Reit’s data centre in northern Virginia. The Reit now owns a 49.9% stake in the data centre in Frankfurt

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, March 26, 2025
summary: Asian stocks rose on Wednesday following Wall Street's gains, with the US dollar fluctuating. Gold and oil prices also increased. The European Central Bank (ECB) pushed back against calls to loosen rules for eurozone banks, citing concerns about financial stability. Despite this, market sentiment remains optimistic due to trade optimism, but US policy uncertainty lingers.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong pushed higher a day after tanking more than two per cent on profit-taking and selling in the tech sector, while Tokyo, Sydney, Shanghai, Seoul, Singapore and Wellington also advanced on Wednesday.
Brent crude futures settled 2 cents higher, or 0.03 per cent, at US$73.02 a barrel on Tuesday.
The commission is set to publish a report next year on the banking system in the single market, including on its competitiveness.

site_title: Young Chinese women find virtual love in Deepspace
summary: A Chinese mobile game, "Love and Deepspace," has gained millions of young women worldwide with its realistic 3D character modeling, immersive narratives, and virtual relationships. Players, mostly young women, form emotional connections with five virtual boyfriends, spending heavily on in-game purchases. The game has earned over $500 million worldwide, with 40% of its revenue coming from outside China. Players attribute the game's appeal to its ability to provide emotional fulfillment, with some stating they prefer the virtual relationships to real-life ones, citing a lack of emotional support from their parents as children.

images.alt_text: CEO of Chinese startup 01.AI Lee Kai-fu said investing in proprietary models had become “courageous” for AI startups in a market environment dominated by well-funded tech giants and rapidly evolving open-source alternatives.
Chinese equities, as measured by the MSCI China Index, returned 40% since the start of 2024, far outpacing the 16% return from the S&P 500.
Server farms are springing up from India to Malaysia, while in the US, Trump is touting a Stargate project that envisions an outlay of half-a-trillion US dollars.

Meta is investing heavily in artificial intelligence infrastructure, seeking to better compete in a fast-moving race against the likes of OpenAI and Google as well as upstarts such as Hangzhou-based DeepSeek.
Xiaomi’s top-up placement adds to a recent rush of Chinese firms’ carrying out equity capital market deals in the first few months of 2025.
Chinese companies have in the past two weeks rolled out no fewer than 10 major product updates or releases – and that’s just the big names.

site_title: Forecast for boxship freight rates draws mixed views from industry watchers
summary: Shipping industry experts are divided on whether boxship freight rates will rebound or extend their declines. Despite a 40% drop since January, freight rates are expected to decrease slightly in the coming weeks, according to Drewry's World Container Index. However, analysts Tan Hua Joo and Lars Jensen believe that demand will be hit by US tariffs and that freight rates will drop further, with some expecting a 10-15% increase in containership capacity if the Red Sea becomes safe for sailing through. Industry experts expect a temporary decline in freight rates, which will correct in several quarters, but the extent of the rebound depends on several factors, including shipping schedule reliability and the Red Sea's safety.

images.alt_text: At issue are proposed, stacking fees on China-built vessels that could top US$3 million per US port call.
Those potential port fees have limited the availability of ships needed to move agriculture, energy, mining, construction and manufactured goods to international buyers.
The reopening of Red Sea routes – expected at some point in the course of the year – could reduce container shipping demand by around 6 per cent.

site_title: Morgan Stanley raises Chinese stock targets again on earnings optimism
summary: Morgan Stanley has raised its index targets for Chinese shares for the second time this year, citing improved earnings growth forecasts and a more optimistic outlook for the economy and currency. The bank upgraded its year-end index targets for various Chinese indices, including the Hang Seng Index and MSCI China Index, to 25,800 and 83 points, respectively. The move is attributed to solid earnings results from Chinese companies and improved macro and FX outlook forecasts. The bank also revised its forecast for China's economic growth in 2025 to 4.5 per cent, up from 4 per cent.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong is making plans to make a wealth connect programme with China’s Greater Bay area less restrictive and exploring whether it can extend its coverage to more mainland cities, Eddie Yue, chief executive of Hong Kong Monetary Authority, said on Wednesday.
CATL’s listing also comes against the background of rising geopolitical tensions, which may endanger the battery maker’s global expansion.

site_title: Art forum pushing for inclusion widens focus to embrace Asian artists
summary: A non-profit organization, Art:Dis, is hosting the sixth edition of its Arts and Disability Forum in Singapore, gathering over 450 individuals from Asia to advocate for inclusion and accessibility in the arts sector. The event, from March 25-29, explores topics such as inclusive culture programming, disability arts, and professional development of artists with disabilities. The forum aims to showcase diverse voices and promote accessibility, with support from the National Arts Council.

site_title: AIC CEO expected to resign in next few days, latest senior public servant to do so ahead of GE2025
summary: Singapore's Agency for Integrated Care (AIC) CEO Dinesh Vasu Dash, 49, is expected to resign in the next few days ahead of the general election in mid-year. Dash has led AIC since 2023, implementing initiatives such as Healthier SG and encouraging seniors to volunteer. He previously served in the Ministry of Health and the Singapore Armed Forces, and was awarded the Public Service Star (Covid-19) award in 2024. His resignation follows that of several other senior public servants in the lead-up to the election.

images.alt_text: Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh called the boundary changes “one of the most radical redrawing of boundaries Singapore has seen in recent memory”.
Jeffrey Siow is the fourth and most senior civil servant to resign ahead of the upcoming general election.
There are a total of 2,758,095 electors in the registers, according to a statement from the Elections Department on March 24.

site_title: Envoy warns Canada against using China as ‘bargaining chip’ with US
summary: Canada's Ambassador to China, Wang Di, warned Ottawa against using China as a "bargaining chip" in trade negotiations with the US, amid a backdrop of escalating tensions. China has criticized a US clause requiring notification of trade talks with non-market economies, and Canada has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods. Wang expressed readiness for a bilateral free trade agreement if Canada removes barriers to Chinese investment, but talks remain unlikely due to strained relations.

images.alt_text: The entities targeted include 11 based in China and one in Taiwan, accused of engaging in the development of advanced AI, supercomputers and high-performance AI chips for China-based users “with close ties to the country’s military-industrial complex.”
Beijing is keen to woo foreign investment amid heightened geopolitical tensions, as policymakers try to boost domestic consumption in a slowing economy to offset the impact of US tariffs.
The idea of restoring a US shipbuilding industry to firm up US influence at sea has captivated Trump and fits with his wider push for a return to the halcyon days of US manufacturing.
Trump has ramped up a trade fight with China since returning to office, imposing a fresh 10 per cent tariff on Chinese goods in February and adding another 10 per cent in March.

site_title: Electric ferry and more: Australia, Singapore select 8 projects to reduce maritime emissions
summary: Australia and Singapore have selected eight projects to reduce maritime emissions, with a focus on low or zero-emission technologies and fuel supply chains. The projects, valued at S$18.4 million (A$10 million), will be completed within two years and include a fully electric ferry, a hydrogen fuel project, and a safety monitoring system. The funding is part of the Australia-Singapore Initiative on Low-Emissions Technologies, which aims to decarbonize and digitize shipping routes between the two countries.

images.alt_text: The Singapore-Australia Green and Digital Shipping Corridor will explore facilitating digital information exchange to enable efficient port clearance, port calls and flow of vessels between Singapore and Australia.
