site_title: DBS leading race to buy controlling stake in Indonesia's Panin Bank
summary: DBS Group is leading the bidding for a controlling stake in Indonesia's Panin Bank, which accounts for roughly 86% of the lender. The deal, if successful, would be the first under incoming CEO Tan Su Shan and propel DBS to rank among Indonesia's top 10 largest banks. DBS is competing with Malaysia's CIMB Group, and binding bids are due by end-April or early May. The stake is valued at approximately US$1.8 billion, with ANZ and the founding Gunawan family also interested in selling their shares.

images.alt_text: DBS deputy chief executive and incoming CEO Tan Su Shan during an interview with The Straits Times at DBS HQ on Aug 12, 2024.

site_title: India discontinues parts of gold deposit scheme amid rising prices
summary: India has discontinued parts of its gold deposit scheme due to rising gold prices, which have increased by over 15% this year. The Reserve Bank of India has amended its master directions to account for the changes. The government has dropped the five-to-seven year and 12-to-15 year deposit options, while banks can still offer short-term gold deposits. This move aims to reduce the government's future obligations and minimize risks related to gold prices. Existing deposits will continue until maturity.

images.alt_text: New Delhi estimates that reciprocal tariffs would hit 87 per cent of its total exports to the United States worth US$66 billion.
Sales during the quarter were 1,05,791 units; only Bengaluru and the National Capital Region defied the downtrend with a 10 per cent increase.
Since the introduction of the Production-Linked Initiative, India's manufacturing sector has decreased from 15.4 per cent to 14.3 per cent of the economy.

site_title: Indonesian rupiah to hit record low on fiscal woes: analysts
summary: Indonesia's rupiah is expected to hit a record low due to fiscal woes and investor unease over President Prabowo Subianto's populist spending measures. The currency has already touched a three-decade low and may weaken past the 16,950 per US dollar level set in 1998. Analysts attribute the decline to growing fiscal risks, social programmes, and US tariffs set to be unleashed next week. Indonesian policymakers have intervened to support the currency, but analysts predict further depreciation, with some speculating it could fall beyond 17,000 per greenback.

images.alt_text: The currency has slumped more than 3 per cent this year, making it one of the worst performers in emerging markets.
The yen’s fall from grace last year sent swarms of Singaporeans flooding the archipelago. This year, other Asian countries are likely to offer better bang for your buck.
The rupiah has come under mounting pressure this year, following Bank Indonesia’s unexpected rate cut in January.

site_title: Top China phonemaker wants 70% of sales from overseas by 2027
summary: Vivo, China's top smartphone maker, aims to increase overseas sales to 70% of revenue by 2027, up from over half currently. The company wants to tap into growing markets in South-east Asia and India, focusing on high-end gadgets priced above $600. Vivo is not ready for developed markets like the US and Western Europe, where sales through telecom operators dominate, but may consider entering those markets in 3-5 years. The company's growth priority is overseas, with chief operating officer Hu Baishan stating that "growth is the priority for our overseas team."

site_title: Alibaba teams up with BMW to develop AI for cars in China
summary: Alibaba and BMW have teamed up to develop AI for cars in China, with BMW adopting AI cockpit technology from Alibaba-backed Banma for its upcoming models. The technology features an intelligent personal assistant with enhanced voice recognition and trip planning capabilities, set to be rolled out in new models produced in China next year. Alibaba's Qwen model has previously been used in cars by Chinese automakers, and the company is investing over 380 billion yuan in AI infrastructure over the next three years.

site_title: Bitcoin rebound faces risk of ‘bull trap’ amid macro uncertainty
summary: Bitcoin's recent relief rally has reached a two-week high, but faces a risk of being a "bull trap" due to macro uncertainty and low volumes. The lack of bullish momentum, thin volumes, and ongoing macro tensions have traders cautious, with the Bitcoin funding rate turning negative and stablecoin lending rates dropping. Seasoned holders are holding their positions, creating "dead weight" in the market, and investors are waiting for a clear catalyst to push the price beyond current levels, such as US President Donald Trump's planned tariff announcement on April 2.

images.alt_text: Trump, who campaigned on promises to be a “crypto president,” has pledged to overhaul US rules on crypto.
The iShares Bitcoin ETP will debut with a temporary fee waiver of 10 basis points – reducing its expense ratio to 0.15 per cent until the end of the year.
Ether is the native token of the Ethereum blockchain, which underpins some of the most commercially significant decentralised finance tools in the digital assets industry.

site_title: Hong Kong to benefit more from capital flows out of China, central bank chief says
summary: Hong Kong is poised to benefit from increased Chinese capital flows in the coming years, according to Hong Kong Monetary Authority chief Eddie Yue. The city is planning to relax its wealth connect program with China's Greater Bay area and expand its coverage to more mainland cities. Yue expects southbound flows, or Chinese capital going out to the world through Hong Kong, to provide the next major opportunity for the financial hub, driven by a strengthening trend in Chinese investments overseas.

site_title: Indonesia accelerates transfer of confiscated palm plantations to state company
summary: Indonesia is transferring 536,211 acres of confiscated palm plantations to state company Agrinas Palma Nusantara as part of efforts to improve governance of its forest and palm oil cultivation. The move comes after criticism that the plantations are a major driver of deforestation. So far, prosecutors have handed over 438,000 acres of land to Agrinas, with more seizures expected. The effort aims to curb deforestation and promote sustainable palm oil production in the world's top palm oil producer.

images.alt_text: The acquisition target is primarily engaged in the business of oil palm plantation.
Projected earnings growth for plantation players in 2025 is driven by firm selling prices amid tight supply and strong demand.

site_title: Singapore’s factory output sees shock 1.3% fall in February, contrary to high growth expectations
summary: Singapore's manufacturing output fell 1.3% year-over-year in February, missing economists' expectations of a 7% expansion. The biomedical and electronics sectors drove the decline, with the electronics cluster contracting 6.4% year-over-year. Despite the disappointing data, experts predict a potential rebound in March due to low base effects, with 2025 industrial output growth forecast at 2.7%. Uncertainties remain due to US tariff threats, but the sector is expected to moderate slightly from the 5% growth recorded in Q4.

images.alt_text: SIPMM executive director Stephen Poh noted that while this was the 18th straight month of expansion for the overall manufacturing sector, there have been concerns over slowing growth in the last few months.
Geopolitical tensions, including from higher tariffs, remained the most-cited downside risk to the domestic outlook, flagged by all respondents.
On a seasonally adjusted, month-on-month basis, overall manufacturing output rose 4.5 per cent in January.

site_title: Couche-Tard sees strong interest in US stores for Seven & I deal
summary: Private equity firms are showing strong interest in buying about 2,000 North American convenience stores from Seven & i Holdings if Alimentation Couche-Tard succeeds in its $65.8 billion takeover bid. The potential buyers, mostly private equity investors, would have access to financial information to assess potential synergies and could enhance Couche-Tard's offer. The process aims to address US antitrust concerns and the companies have set a deadline for potential buyers to express their interest by the end of March.

images.alt_text: Seven & i has said it is engaging with Couche-Tard, but a core concern is that US competition authorities will not give the deal the green light given the overlap in the companies’ businesses.
Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc.'s founder Alain Bouchard speaks during a press conference on their bid for 7-Eleven convenience store operator Seven & i Holdings in Tokyo, Japan, March 13, 2025.

Couche-Tard has been pursuing Seven & i for months even as it has received a frosty reception from the Japanese retail giant, in what would be Japan’s largest-ever foreign buyout if the deal is completed.
The Circle-K owner has been pursuing Seven & i for months even as it received a frosty reception from the Japanese retail giant.

site_title: Ong Beng Seng’s guilty plea mention postponed
summary: Singapore property magnate Ong Beng Seng's guilty plea mention has been rescheduled to April 25 due to his terminal illness. The plea was initially set for April 2. Seng, 81, faces two charges of abetting offences under Section 165 of the Penal Code and obstruction of justice related to his dealings with former transport minister S Iswaran. The prosecution has no objection to the rescheduling, and Seng's lawyers will make representations by November 29.

images.alt_text: Iswaran (right) pleaded guilty to two charges of accepting gifts from Lum.
Ong Beng Seng is expected to be slapped with one charge under Section 165 where he is accused of abetting a public servant in obtaining of gifts, and one charge of obstruction of justice.

Ong Beng Seng faces one charge of abetting offences under Section 165 of the Penal Code, one charge of abetting the obstruction of justice, both in relation to dealings with former transport minister S Iswaran.

site_title: Vietnam’s state-backed Becamex to set aside 2.5 trillion dong to fund Singapore JVs
summary: Vietnam's state-backed Becamex IDC plans to set aside 2.5 trillion dong (S$130 million) to fund joint ventures with Singapore's Sembcorp Industries as part of a planned S$1 billion share sale. The funds will be used to develop industrial parks according to low-carbon standards, harness rooftop solar power, and distribute clean energy to factories. Becamex aims to treble its 2024 sales to 15 trillion dong by 2027, driven by its strategic land reserve preparations and potential growth from new eco-industrial parks. The company plans to sell 380 ha of industrial land this year and reduce its debt levels through the share sale.

images.alt_text: The State Bank of Vietnam, the country's central banks, directs certain established banks to take over underperforming lenders as part of a drive to overhaul the sector and ensure national financial security.

site_title: OCBC group chief executive Helen Wong’s pay in FY2024 up 5.8% at S$12.8 million
summary: OCBC group chief executive Helen Wong received a 5.8% increase in pay to S$12.8 million in FY2024, driven by a S$6.8 million bonus and deferred shares. The bank's full-year net profit reached a record S$7.6 billion, up 8% from the prior year, with OCBC proposing a slightly lower final dividend of S$0.41 per share. This brings the full-year dividend to S$1.01 per share, representing a 60% payout ratio.

images.alt_text: For the financial year 2025, OCBC is targeting a net interest margin (NIM) of around 2 per cent and a mid-single-digit loan growth.

site_title: Lee Shau-Kee’s sons get control of US$10 billion Henderson stake
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Lee Shau-Kee's sons, Peter Lee Ka-Kit and Martin Lee Ka-Shing, now control his US$10 billion stake in Henderson Land Development after his death at 97. The two sons appear as equal controllers of the shares through three vehicles and are the sole beneficiaries of the trust holding their father's stake. Lee's company, Henderson Land, has a market value of almost HK$109 billion. The move may stress test the company's leadership structure amid a property downturn, with experts warning of the need for a unified voice to respond to uncertainties.

images.alt_text: A self-made man in Hong Kong real estate, Lee Shau Kee was among the city’s richest people and firmly in the top 100 list of the world’s wealthiest billionaires.
Lee Shau-kee founded his property firm, Henderson Land, in 1976. He remained as chairman until his retirement in May 2019.

site_title: Food cooperation, industrial park upgrades are potential areas to explore in Singapore-Vietnam partnership: PM Wong
summary: Singapore and Vietnam are strengthening their partnership with a focus on industrial cooperation, food production, and renewable energy. The two countries signed agreements on electricity trade, QR payments, and digital development. Prime Minister Lawrence Wong stated that the Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP) will explore ideas to take the bilateral relationship to greater heights, including upgrading the Vietnam-Singapore Industrial Parks (VSIPs) and promoting food cooperation. The VSIPs will be upgraded with technology, powered by renewable energy, and more connected, with a potential expansion into third countries.

images.alt_text: He is making great effort to renew the leadership team and the party, PM Wong tells media in an interview capping of his visit to Hanoi.

General secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam To Lam made an official visit to Singapore earlier in March, where the countries upgraded bilateral relations to the highest tier of Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP).
Vietnam Singapore Industrial Park, a joint venture between Becamex IDC and Sembcorp, is an iconic partnership between the two countries.

site_title: Trust Bank rolls out money lock anti-scam feature Trust Lock
summary: Trust Bank has launched its "Trust Lock" feature, allowing customers to lock up to five Savings Pots to prevent withdrawals and require two-factor authentication for unlocking. This differs from other banks' money lock features, which typically allow customers to lock specific amounts of money within existing accounts or require visits to an ATM or bank branch to unlock funds. The feature has been activated for over 181,000 customers, locking S$15.8 billion in savings as of October 2024, in an effort to keep customers' money safe from scams.

images.alt_text: Losses from cryptocurrency-related scams surged to 24.3 per cent of total scam losses last year - from about 6.8 per cent in 2023.

The Singapore Police Force's (SPF) Anti-Scam Centre partnered six banks - DBS Bank, UOB Bank, OCBC Bank, Standard Chartered Bank, HSBC Bank, and GXS Bank - to thwart 1,444 scam cases and prevent potential losses of around S$73 million.

site_title: Apple boss hails ‘next generation of developers’ on China visit
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook visited Zhejiang University in eastern China, praising the "next generation of developers" and announcing a $5.5 million donation to provide students with technical and business training in app development. The visit comes as Apple seeks to boost its ties to China, where it lost its status as the best-selling smartphone brand last year. Cook also met with China's Commerce Minister and discussed business development, economic ties, and trade relations. Apple's Worldwide Developers Conference is set to announce redesigned iPhone, iPad, and Mac operating systems, with major enhancements expected later.

images.alt_text: The AI management shift has been months in the making and predates Apple announcing the Siri delays.

Google risks fines of up to 10 per cent of its global annual sales if found guilty of breaching the DMA.
Apple could face an investigation if regulators subsequently find that it has not followed through on the order that could lead to a fine as much as 10 per cent of its global annual sales.

site_title: Building long-term portfolio thinking through thought leadership
summary: Bank of Singapore has established a thought leadership offering through its independent investment advisory council, launched in May 2024. The CIO Global Advisory Council, comprising thought leaders from various firms and think tanks, provides global and regional perspectives to inform investment decisions. This approach enables clients to build long-term, diversified portfolios, leveraging the bank's unique position as an Asian private bank with global operations. The council's annual refresh ensures diverse perspectives and adapts to shifting market dynamics.

site_title: FCT’s private placement raises S$220 million to finance Northpoint City deal, repay debt
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) raised approximately S$220 million through a private placement, issuing 105.3 million new units at S$2.09 apiece, a 5.6% discount to its volume-weighted average price. The funds will be used to repay debts and acquire North Gem Trust, a private trust holding interests in the South Wing of Northpoint City, for around S$1.2 billion. FCT's total equity fundraising now stands at around S$421.3 million.

images.alt_text: Northpoint City mall

site_title: Australian inflation ticks lower in February, backs bets for more rate cuts
summary: Australia's consumer inflation slowed to 2.4% in February, down from 2.5% in January, beating forecasts for no change. The monthly consumer price index was flat, while the trimmed mean measure of core inflation rose 2.7%. The easing in home building costs and rents supports the case for more rate cuts in the months ahead.

images.alt_text: Treasurer Jim Chalmers in his fourth Budget also unveiled new efforts to boost economic resilience and competitiveness, acknowledging heightened new global risks from trade wars as well as geopolitical tensions.

Queesland Premier David Crisafulli speaks during the announcement of Games Delivery Plan for the 2032 Olympics and Paralympics, Brisbane, Tuesday, March 25, 2025. (AAP Image/Jono Searle) NO ARCHIVINGNo Use Australia. No Use New Zealand.
BYD has risen quickly to the top of China’s car market – the world’s biggest and most competitive in terms of electric vehicles.

site_title: Gold steady as concern looms over Trump’s reciprocal tariff plans
summary: Gold prices remained steady at $3,020.87 an ounce as market participants awaited US President Donald Trump's reciprocal tariff plans, fearing they would fuel inflation and hinder economic growth. The US consumer confidence index plummeted to its lowest in over four years, with households fearing a recession. Gold has risen 15% so far this year, reaching an all-time peak of $3,057.21 on March 20. The US administration may adopt reciprocal tariffs on April 2, intensifying trade tensions and potentially slowing economic growth. Federal Reserve officials are set to speak later, offering insights into monetary policy.

images.alt_text: Bullion, seen as a hedge against geopolitical and economic uncertainties, often thrives in a low-interest-rate environment.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Frasers Centrepoint Trust, Digital Core Reit, Nanofilm Technologies
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) raised S$421.3 million through an equity fundraising exercise, partly to fund the acquisition of North Gem Trust's units in Northpoint City. The trust also repaid debts with the raised funds. Digital Core Reit acquired a 20% stake in an Osaka data centre for US$86.7 million, expected to be 1.8% accretive to its distribution per unit.

site_title: US new-home sales rise slightly following weather-related plunge
summary: US new-home sales rose 1.8% in February to 676,000 annualized rate, rebounding from a low point in January due to better weather and sales incentives. Despite the increase, builders remain cautious due to high mortgage rates and increased home supply. Sales in the South and Midwest saw a 6.6% and 3.8% rise, respectively. However, builders are cutting prices and offering incentives to clear out spec homes, and mortgage rates are expected to fall slightly by the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Households fear a resurgence in inflation from President Donald Trump’s tariffs.
Heightened uncertainty grips US financial markets as punitive tariffs on key trading partners spark investor fears of rising inflation and a potential economic slowdown.
The focus on tariffs, as well as a surge in prices of basic staples such as eggs and the stock-market rout, is taking a toll on sentiment and inciting growth concerns.
Production at factories increased 0.7 per cent on a year-on-year basis in February.

site_title: Airlines booking jet repairs years in advance shows supply pain
summary: Airlines are booking jet repairs years in advance due to supply chain issues, with carriers opting for 10-year-plus maintenance contracts. Haeco, a leading jet overhaul and engine servicing firm, sees record sales and expects a "significantly" better year ahead. The company is investing $550 million in China to open the world's largest single-span hangars, capable of handling 18 aircraft at once. This trend is driven by the need for airlines to secure a slot for their aircraft and the impact of pandemic-related engine shortages on the industry's backlog.

images.alt_text: The ban comes as a spate of high-profile cabin fire incidents linked with power banks have happened over the past few months.

site_title: Japan’s corporate service inflation hits 3.0%, keeps BOJ rate hike bets alive
summary: Japan's service-sector inflation rose to 3.0% in February, exceeding expectations and keeping interest rate hike bets alive. The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is closely monitoring this indicator for signs of sustained wage gains leading to broader price hikes. BOJ Governor Kazuo Ueda stated that the central bank will continue to raise interest rates if higher wages lead to service price increases. Analysts predict the BOJ's next rate hike will occur in the third quarter, likely in July.

site_title: China floods the world with AI models after DeepSeek’s success
summary: China has flooded the global market with low-cost AI models after DeepSeek's success, undercutting premium offerings from Western companies like OpenAI and Alphabet's Google. Since January, Chinese tech leaders have rolled out 10 major product updates, including Baidu's Ernie X1 and Alibaba's AI agents. These open-sourced models are being used globally, including in the US and India, and are reshaping the market, threatening the massive infrastructure investments of US tech companies. The low-cost template may also shrink profits for Nvidia, leading to valuation adjustments.

images.alt_text: CEO of Chinese startup 01.AI Lee Kai-fu said investing in proprietary models had become “courageous” for AI startups in a market environment dominated by well-funded tech giants and rapidly evolving open-source alternatives.

FILE PHOTO: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration taken, February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The deals underscore the industry’s appeal in attracting a range of investors – from banks to real estate players – as the AI boom drives demand.

site_title: CATL gets China’s sign-off to proceed with Hong Kong share sale
summary: Contemporary Amperex Technology Co, Limited (CATL), China's top EV battery maker, received approval to proceed with a Hong Kong share sale. The company can issue up to 220 million shares, raising at least US$5 billion, amid rising geopolitical tensions that may impact its global expansion. This listing follows a surge in Hong Kong's stock sales this year, with over US$15 billion raised so far, and comes as the company faces a US Defense Department list of firms with alleged links to the Chinese military.

images.alt_text: As BYD and CATL fight for stock-market dominance, the carmaker’s earnings may make a difference.
CATL’s Hong Kong listing plan comes as the city sees increased interest for second listings from Chinese A-share companies, which are seeking to tap into overseas liquidity.

CATL’s Hong Kong listing plan also comes as the city has seen a surge of new offerings in recent weeks, with increasing interest for a second listing China’s from A-share companies, who are seeking to tap into overseas liquidity.

site_title: GameStop is latest public firm to jump on the Bitcoin bandwagon
summary: GameStop, a struggling video-game retailer, has approved a plan to add Bitcoin as a treasury reserve asset, joining a growing list of public companies experimenting with buying the digital asset. The move follows Strategy, an enterprise software company, which has acquired over $40 billion in Bitcoin and seen its share price soar. GameStop's CEO, Ryan Cohen, had previously hinted at the idea, and the stock rose 6% in after-hours trading. This move is part of a wave of companies inspired by Strategy's gambit to capitalize on the surge in Bitcoin.

images.alt_text: GameStop has been grappling with a slower turnaround of its main business as it struggles to ramp up sales of videogame hardware and collectibles.

site_title: US: Stocks gain on lingering hopes over Trump tariffs
summary: US stocks rose on Tuesday, driven by hopes that President Trump's upcoming tariffs might be narrower than expected. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 Index gained 0.2% and 0.5% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index rose 0.5%. Investors are awaiting further hints about Trump's tariff rollout, with markets waiting for the president's "reciprocal tariffs" on April 2. The gains come despite US consumer confidence falling for a fourth straight month and new home sales picking up less than expected.

site_title: How I learnt to stop worrying and love the volatility
summary: Investors are increasingly seeing uncertainty in the market, with rapid shifts in interest rate expectations and a focus on inflation and interest rates. To manage volatility, a healthy investment philosophy that looks beyond market fluctuations can be beneficial. This approach emphasizes time in the market over timing, mitigates behavioral biases, and frees up time for higher-risk investments. By staying calm, focusing on long-term goals, and separating facts from narratives, investors can compound returns over time and avoid the pitfalls of behavioral biases.

site_title: GE2025: WP chief Pritam Singh questions fairness of electoral boundaries report
summary: Workers' Party chief Pritam Singh questioned the fairness of Singapore's new electoral boundaries, calling them "one of the most radical redrawing of boundaries Singapore has seen in recent memory." Singh criticized the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee (EBRC) for not explaining its decisions, and called for the PAP government to make public the information on how people voted in individual precincts. He also referenced a remark by former Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong about the importance of individual wards and precincts in determining electoral outcomes.

images.alt_text: Jeffrey Siow is the fourth and most senior civil servant to resign ahead of the upcoming general election.

site_title: Creating portfolio resilience
summary: US President Donald Trump's rhetoric on tariffs has caused market volatility, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq experiencing negative returns of 1.9% and 5.8% respectively year-to-date. However, experts believe that diversification, particularly across asset classes, industries, and geographies, can help build portfolio resilience and generate respectable returns. The Vix, a market "fear gauge," signals rough waters, but not a bear market, and experts are optimistic on US and Asian equities, including China, and the artificial intelligence theme, despite volatility and inflation risks.

site_title: UK set to detail plans to fix public finances
summary: UK Finance Minister Rachel Reeves is set to detail billions of pounds in spending cuts in her Spring Statement on Wednesday to address the country's ailing public finances. The Labour government faces sluggish economic growth and rising borrowing costs. Reeves has warned that the world has changed since her inaugural budget in October. The cuts are expected to include reductions in welfare payments and government departmental budgets.

site_title: Japan Airlines orders 17 Boeing 737 MAX aircraft
summary: Japan Airlines has finalized a firm order for 17 Boeing 737 MAX 8 aircraft, adding to the 21 previously ordered in March 2023. The new order nearly doubles the airline's overall 737 MAX 8 orders. The value of the new order was not specified.

site_title: Ripple Labs says it settles with US SEC, will pay reduced US$50 million fine
summary: Ripple Labs has settled a US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) civil lawsuit, agreeing to pay a reduced fine of $50 million instead of the previously imposed $125 million. The settlement, which requires SEC approval, ends one of the SEC's highest-profile cryptocurrency cases and eases industry oversight. Ripple did not admit wrongdoing and will end an appeal related to $728 million of XRP sales to institutional investors. XRP, the fourth-largest cryptocurrency by market value, saw a surge in value following US President Donald Trump's return to the White House.

images.alt_text: The SEC lawsuit accusing Ripple of offering unregistered securities began in December 2020, four weeks before Trump ended his first White House term.
The crypto market has gained about US$1.2 trillion in market value since Trump’s election victory, CoinGecko data show.
XRP is a digital token that powers the XRP Ledger public blockchain.
The SEC has several major cases against crypto exchanges and issuers, accusing them of offering unregistered securities.

site_title: Dell’s workforce drops 10% in fiscal 2025
summary: Dell Technologies reported a 10% drop in its workforce to approximately 108,000 employees as of January 31, 2025, in an effort to reduce costs. The company reaffirmed its commitment to diversity and inclusion, despite President Donald Trump's criticism of such initiatives. This decline follows a 5% reduction in workforce in fiscal year 2024. Dell also forecast a decline in its adjusted gross margin rate for fiscal year 2026 due to increased costs for building AI servers in a competitive market.

images.alt_text: Stargate joins a race among leading tech companies to build up capacity of Nvidia’s latest chips.

site_title: The global path to net zero: A call for Asean+3 leadership
summary: Asean+3 nations, comprising the Association of Southeast Asian Nations and China, Japan, and Korea, are urged to take the lead in the global transition to a net-zero future due to the region's diverse strengths. The challenge lies in helping high-emission industries transition while safeguarding economic priorities. To address this, transition finance is crucial, but its current ambiguity hinders capital allocation. A clear regulatory framework and standardised taxonomy for transition finance are necessary to overcome the information gap and insufficient financial incentives. By doing so, Asean+3 can strategically allocate capital, drive decarbonisation, and position itself as a global leader in transition finance.

Creating a family legacy: managing
the burgeoning wealth in Asia
summary: The Asia-Pacific region has generated the majority of global wealth, with APAC wealth growing 177% since 2008 and APAC billionaires' wealth soaring 141% over the last 10 years. As wealth transfers across generations, family offices are increasingly seen as a key differentiator in managing family wealth across geographies and motivations. UBS notes an increase in Asian business families setting up family offices in APAC, with over 2,000 family offices in Singapore alone. Family offices can perform various roles, including investment management, legacy planning, and philanthropy. APAC family offices plan to diversify their portfolios, shifting capital to North America and APAC, and increasing investments in private equity, private debt, and hedge funds.

site_title: Bonds are still the perennial diversifier for portfolios
summary: Bonds continue to serve as a reliable diversifier for portfolios, particularly for investors with a horizon longer than 12 months. Historically, bonds have fulfilled their hedging function, with positive bond returns often prevailing during major US equity drawdowns. However, in 2022, the bond market was negatively impacted by the Federal Reserve's aggressive monetary tightening, leading to a 13% decline in the Bloomberg US Aggregate Bond Index. This event highlights the importance of considering the potential risks associated with rapid monetary policy tightening and elevated equity valuations. For investors with longer-term horizons, bonds remain a valuable component of a diversified portfolio.

site_title: As wealth transfers across generations, family offices look globally for opportunities
summary: Barclays Private Bank is capitalizing on the "great wealth transfer" as Asia-Pacific's Ultra High Net Worth (UHNW) and High Net Worth (HNW) families transfer wealth across generations. With an estimated US$5.8 trillion expected to change hands by 2030, Singapore has emerged as a wealth management hub, with many UHNW families setting up family offices. Barclays aims to be a long-term investment partner by providing holistic, multi-generational, and multi-jurisdictional coverage, as well as sustainable and impact strategies. The bank leverages its global franchise to deliver bespoke solutions, including a new booking centre in Singapore, to support clients' global connectivity and investment opportunities.

site_title: US imposes trade restrictions on dozens of entities with eye on China
summary: The US has imposed trade restrictions on 80 entities from countries including China, the UAE, and Iran, citing national security and foreign policy concerns. The entities, including 11 in China and one in Taiwan, were accused of developing advanced AI and supercomputing capabilities for China's military-industrial complex. They are restricted from obtaining US items and technologies without government authorization. The move aims to prevent US technologies from being misused for activities like high-performance computing, hypersonic missiles, and military aircraft training.

images.alt_text: Heightened uncertainty grips US financial markets as punitive tariffs on key trading partners spark investor fears of rising inflation and a potential economic slowdown.

While some argue that tariffs contribute to national security, the reality is that they raise costs and lower the quality of domestic production, undermining the very economies they are meant to protect.
Households fear a resurgence in inflation from President Donald Trump’s tariffs.
If everything Donald Trump said or pledged comes to pass, he would be in a position to win the Nobel Peace Prize. Or so he hopes.

site_title: Europe: Shares advance as softer US tariff hopes lift sentiment
summary: European shares rose 0.67% on Tuesday, marking their first gain in four sessions, as investors became optimistic about a softer US tariff stance. The Stoxx 600 index closed at 552.59 points. Most regional markets, including Spain and Germany, also ended higher, driven by gains in mining and healthcare stocks. The positive sentiment was fueled by the looming April 2 deadline for US President Donald Trump to adopt a more gentle tariff stance, lifting market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average was flat at 42,587.50 while the broad-based S&P 500 Index advanced 0.2 per cent to 5,776.65 on Tuesday.

site_title: Co-investing in private markets: a paradigm shift for ultra-wealthy investors
summary: Ultra-high-net-worth (UHNW) investors are increasingly turning to private markets for diversification, enhanced returns, and access to innovative ventures. The co-investment landscape is evolving to address challenges, offering curated opportunities and comprehensive information. Innovative solutions use technology, data, and curated networks to unlock exclusive access to institutional-grade opportunities. These solutions provide enhanced deal sourcing, streamlined due diligence, and increased transparency, empowering investors to make informed decisions. As private markets continue to grow, these solutions are shaping the future of co-investment, transforming it into a more accessible, efficient, and rewarding asset class for UHNW investors.

site_title: US judge sets June 23 trial date over Boeing crashes
summary: US District Court Judge Reed O'Connor has set a trial date of June 23 for Boeing over two deadly 737 MAX crashes in 2018 and 2019, resulting in 346 deaths. The trial follows a plea deal deadline of April 11 that was vacated by the judge, and comes after Boeing agreed to plead guilty to fraud in 2021. Boeing is still engaged in discussions with the Justice Department for an "appropriate" resolution, but no immediate reaction has been made by the families' lawyers.

site_title: Unlocking the potential of female-led businesses
summary: Financial institutions can help female-led businesses unlock their potential by providing connectivity, tailored advice, and education. In Singapore, one in four companies is owned by females, contributing to over 20% of total revenues. The funding gap for female founders is significant, with only 2% of US startup investments going to women-led ventures. Blended finance, which combines philanthropic and public capital, can address this gap. Building confidence and connections is crucial, with research showing that women lack social networks and role models. A three-pronged strategy of liquidity, longevity, and legacy can support women's financial journey, and empowering women is expected to contribute to the growth of society and economy.

summary: China has narrowed the AI development gap with the US to just three months in some areas, thanks to firms like DeepSeek, which has released a major upgrade to its V3 large language model. CEO Lee Kai-fu of 01.AI says the company's proprietary models have allowed it to innovate under constraints, catching up with the US. This is attributed to the challenges posed by Washington's semiconductor sanctions, which have forced Chinese firms to develop their own algorithms and improve efficiency.

images.alt_text: Tencent has joined Chinese tech peers including Alibaba Group Holding and Baidu to piggyback on DeepSeek’s success to win new users.

A shortage of global AI talent is becoming a bottleneck as industries and enterprises speed up adoption of artificial intelligence.
The pace of China’s open-source AI push has been relentless since the debut in January of DeepSeek R1.
Tencent’s five new 3D-content generators are built atop its Hunyuan3D-2.0 model, all of which it intends to open-source to users.

Nvidia has been a dominant player in AI computing in recent years, with its processors powering data centres that support chatbots and other tools. The company’s shares have been a safe bet for a long time, gaining nearly 900 per cent from the start of 2023 to late January.

site_title: Team Orchid Country Club reign supreme in second leg of BT Corporate Golf League
summary: The second leg of the BT Corporate Golf League took place at the Singapore Island Country Club's New Course, with Team Orchid Country Club (OCC) emerging victorious. Jaymie Ng of Team Boss fired a five-under 67, but OCC's Bryan Chen took the top spot with a 73 in the Competitive category, tying Ng's total. OCC's team effort secured the win with a total of 113 points, while Singapore Global Trust maintained the top spot in the standings with 219 points. The league continues with three rounds remaining.

site_title: Oil prices mixed as Russia-Ukraine truce offsets Venezuela supply worries
summary: Oil prices fluctuated on Tuesday, with Brent crude futures rising 2 cents to $73.02 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 11 cents to $69. A truce between Russia and Ukraine offset concerns about tightening global supply due to threatened US tariffs on Venezuela. The US agreed to push to lift sanctions on Russia in exchange for a pause in attacks. Oil prices remain well-supplied, with Opec+ planning to raise output for a second month, and concerns over global demand growth persist.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, March 25, 2025
summary: Asian stocks declined on Tuesday, weighed down by a drop in Chinese tech shares, despite a strong rally the previous day. Investors are optimistic about narrower-than-expected US tariffs, while the dollar hovered near a three-week high after upbeat economic data.

images.alt_text: In early trade on Tuesday, Tokyo, Sydney, Singapore, Taipei and Wellington stocks rose but Shanghai and Manila shares dropped.

site_title: Tariff Man doubles down
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade restrictions, known as tariffs, will harm the industries they aim to protect, according to economists. Tariffs raise costs and lower the quality of domestic production, undermining national economies. The Trump administration's policies have disrupted the multilateral trading system, with potential consequences including slower economic growth, higher inflation, and job losses in industries reliant on imports. summary: Standard Chartered Global Private Bank is innovating to redefine wealth management, offering tailored solutions to ultra-high-net-worth clients in a volatile market environment. Leveraging its global network and expertise, the bank provides curated solutions, including alternative asset classes and holistic wealth solutions. Foo Tian Ong, Regional Head, emphasizes the importance of personalized wealth advice and building long-term relationships to meet clients' diverse needs. The bank is growing its Relationship Manager bench and investing in technology to enhance the client experience, aiming to achieve US$200 billion of net new money from its affluent business.

site_title: Schneider Electric to invest over US$700 million in US to power AI boom
summary: Schneider Electric plans to invest over US$700 million in its US operations over the next two years, focusing on bolstering energy infrastructure to power AI growth, boosting domestic manufacturing, and strengthening energy security. The investment will be made through 2027, with plans to upgrade, expand, and open several facilities across the US, creating over 1,000 new jobs. This investment, combined with a previous US$440 million announcement, is expected to surpass US$1 billion this decade. The move comes amid tariff threats and a growing need for domestic manufacturing to power AI growth.

site_title: SP Group donates S$700,000 to St Andrews Autism Centre for supported youth employment programmes
summary: SP Group has donated S$700,000 to St Andrews Autism Centre (SAAC) for its "Dignity of Work" programme, which provides structured employment pathways for young people with moderate autism. The programme, funded through Community Chest, aims to train 400 youths in baking and kitchen operations, offering a full-year sponsorship and potential for permanent supported employment. The initiative addresses the "post-18 cliff" and provides a scalable model for alternative employment, allowing individuals with autism to develop life skills and become more independent.

site_title: Australia to build new 2032 Olympics stadium, Gabba to be scrapped
summary: Australia will build a 63,000-seat stadium and an indoor aquatic center for the 2032 Olympics in Brisbane, replacing the scrapped Gabba cricket ground plans. The new stadium will host major sporting events beyond the Olympics, while the aquatic center can accommodate 25,000 fans. The main athletes' village will be built at the Brisbane Showgrounds, with smaller villages on the Gold Coast and Sunshine Coast. The upgrades are part of a $4 billion infrastructure plan, with the goal of delivering "legacy" venues for future events.

site_title: Former LawSoc VP Chia Boon Teck was a commando, CID investigator, SIA cabin crew before settling in legal profession
summary: Former Law Society of Singapore Vice-President Chia Boon Teck has resigned after facing backlash over comments he made about a rape survivor. Chia, a veteran lawyer and co-managing director at Chia Wong Chambers, had previously held various roles including commando, CID investigator, and SIA cabin crew. He was also the president of the supercar club ExotiCars Club and chairman of several grassroots committees. Chia's comments were deemed "victim-blaming" and sparked calls for his resignation, which he eventually accepted.

images.alt_text: Chia Boon Teck, who was elected vice-president of the Law Society in August 2023, sparked an outcry where he was accused of “victim shaming".

site_title: Israel parliament approves budget as hostage families protest in chamber
summary: Israel's parliament approved the 2025 state budget in a 66-52 vote, avoiding snap elections that would have been triggered by the failure to approve the budget by March 31. The budget was passed amidst protests by families of hostages still held in Gaza, with about 24 believed to be alive, and opposition lawmakers holding signs demanding their release. The approval comes as Israel resumes its military campaign against Hamas in Gaza after a two-month ceasefire.

site_title: Haidilao operator Super Hi back in the red with US$11.6 million loss in Q4
summary: Super Hi International, the operator of Haidilao's international business, reported a net loss of US$11.6 million for the fourth quarter, despite a 10.4% year-on-year increase in revenue to US$208.8 million. The loss was attributed to a US$40.4 million net foreign exchange loss, partially offset by higher revenue from business expansion and operational efficiency improvements. The Singapore-based restaurant operator is dual-listed in Hong Kong and the US, and has 122 Haidilao outlets outside of China.

site_title: Public Bank’s Teh family scion identified as buyer in record S$94m Tanglin GCB deal
summary: A Singapore Good Class Bungalow (GCB) was sold at a record S$6,197 per square foot, totaling S$93.9 million, to Diona Teh Li Shian, a daughter of Public Bank's founder. The 1,408 sqm property near Orchard Road and various embassies is being built by Meir Homes. The sale price sets a new record for the city-state's luxury real estate market.

site_title: Second perm sec Jeffrey Siow resigns; most senior civil servant to step down ahead of GE2025
summary: Singapore's second permanent secretary, Jeffrey Siow, has resigned from the civil service ahead of the upcoming general election. Siow, 46, is the fourth most senior civil servant to step down, following a string of departures. He currently leads efforts to grow Singapore's economy and develop a productive workforce. Siow's resignation is part of a trend of public service leaders leaving the service before the election, with several other senior officials already departing.

site_title: US dollar slips from three-week high as tariff uncertainty lingers
summary: The US dollar index fell 0.22% to 104.07, reversing its gains from earlier in the session, due to lingering uncertainty about tariffs. US President Donald Trump said some countries might receive breaks from tariffs, soothing fears about a US growth slowdown. The euro reversed its fall to a three-week low, while the Australian dollar rose 0.51% on fresh tax cuts and cost-of-living relief. Investors await the Bank of Japan's monetary policy decision and the UK's spring statement, which may impact currency markets.

site_title: Trump’s World Liberty Financial crypto venture to launch stablecoin
summary: US President Donald Trump's World Liberty Financial is set to launch a US dollar-pegged stablecoin called USD1, fully backed by US Treasuries and designed to maintain a value of US$1. The stablecoin will be audited regularly by a third-party accounting firm and will be available on Ethereum and Binance Smart Chain blockchains. The launch comes after World Liberty raised over half a billion US dollars from selling a separate digital token. The move aims to provide seamless, secure cross-border transactions for sovereign investors and major institutions.

site_title: Navigating volatility, tariffs and tech
summary: Investors navigating 2025's volatility amid US tariffs face contrasting views. Strategists, including Bank of Singapore's Jason Moo, UBS's Young Jin Yee, and DBS Private Bank's Joseph Poon, remain optimistic on AI-driven growth despite valuation challenges. US assets, particularly equities and tech, are favored, with "overweight" positions in US and Asia ex-Japan equities. China's economic outlook has bottomed out, with signs of policy stimulus supporting the real estate market. Diversification, tactical trades, and asset allocation are key to mitigating tariff uncertainty. Gold and precious metals remain attractive as inflation hedges.

site_title: US consumer confidence tumbles again to lowest since early 2021
summary: US consumer confidence plummeted to its lowest level since early 2021, dropping 7.2 points to 92.9 in March. Concerns about higher prices and the economic outlook amid the Trump administration's escalating tariffs led to the decline. Expectations for the next six months also fell nearly 10 points to 65.2, the lowest in 12 years. The drop in confidence is attributed to households' fears of a resurgence in inflation from President Trump's tariffs.

images.alt_text: Heightened uncertainty grips US financial markets as punitive tariffs on key trading partners spark investor fears of rising inflation and a potential economic slowdown.

site_title: The continuing search for sustainable sand alternatives an imperative for Singapore
summary: Singapore, the world's largest importer of sand, faces a responsibility to find sustainable alternatives after Indonesia resumes sea sand exports. The country's 20-year ban has lifted, raising environmental degradation risks due to increased demand from mainland China and South-east Asian economies. Singapore has committed to sustainable sourcing and is exploring alternatives, such as empoldering and recycling construction debris. With the region's construction industry set to expand by 78% by 2034, the city-state must take a leading role in finding solutions to reduce its reliance on sand imports.

images.alt_text: Workers on a truck loaded with sand at the Sunda Kelapa Port in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Friday, July 12, 2024.

site_title: China is getting out of the woods, thanks to a structural shift in the equities market
summary: China's equity market is experiencing a structural shift, driven by corporate self-help and active shareholder enhancement activities, which have led to increased returns and valuation recovery. The MSCI China index's ROE has improved from 9% in mid-2023 to 11%, with potential for further growth, justifying an MSCI China re-rating. Technology breakthroughs, such as those from DeepSeek, are also contributing to the shift, with China poised to stay competitive in the global tech market. Morgan Stanley has increased its 2025 year-end China offshore index targets and moved MSCI China to equal weight.

images.alt_text: Chinese tech companies offer a better bargain and position investors to capture a larger share of the burgeoning tech market in China.

site_title: A shambolic leak reveals Team Trump’s contempt for allies
summary: US President Donald Trump's national security team, including Mike Waltz and Marco Rubio, expressed contempt for Europeans and insisted that allies should foot the bill for American military action. The comments were made in a Signal chat group, which was inadvertently shared with a journalist, Jeffrey Goldberg of The Atlantic magazine. The exchange suggested a lack of operational security and highlighted the Trump administration's tough stance on European allies. The leak has raised concerns about the administration's thinking on military action in Yemen and its relations with Europe.

site_title: The shine is back on gold – and gold mining stocks
summary: Gold prices reached an all-time high in early 2025, driven by strong physical demand and safe-haven appeal. Central banks' increased purchases of gold, hedging against inflation and geopolitical risks, also contributed to the surge. Gold mining stocks, although more volatile, offer a leveraged investment in gold and potentially cheaply valued growth opportunities. Investors may consider a mix of gold and mining stocks to balance risks and benefits. The outlook for gold miners remains positive, with solid margins and cash flow returns expected, despite operational risks and market uncertainties.

site_title: US fiscal strength on course for continued decline: Moody’s
summary: US government debt has become less affordable due to higher interest rates, according to Moody's. The ratings agency projects debt to gross domestic product will rise to 130% by 2035, and interest payments will account for 30% of revenue. This decline in fiscal strength is attributed to widening budget deficits and a decline in debt affordability, with Moody's warning that tariffs may hinder growth in the long term. The agency is the last major ratings agency to maintain a top, triple-A rating for US sovereign debt.

site_title: Ex-Fifa chief Blatter and Platini cleared in corruption case
summary: Former FIFA President Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini have been acquitted of corruption charges by a Swiss court for a second time, two and a half years after their initial acquittal. The case centered on a 2 million Swiss franc payment made to Platini in 2011, which prosecutors claimed was a bribe. Platini's lawyer stated that the case had "definitively failed" and that Platini should be left in peace. The acquittal ends the scandal that ended Platini's hopes of succeeding Blatter as FIFA president.

site_title: Singapore-Vietnam ties will strengthen, with deeper cooperation and like-minded partners: PM Wong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong has stated that the country's relations with Vietnam are at a high point, with economic cooperation being "stronger than ever." The two countries have upgraded their ties to a Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP), which aims to deepen cooperation in areas such as renewable energy, digital economy, and human resource development. summary: Insurance companies are shifting towards private assets to mitigate inflation and economic slowdown risks. According to a Goldman Sachs survey, 58% of insurers plan to increase their allocations to private credit over the next 12 months, driven by concerns over inflation, US economic slowdown, credit and equity market volatility, and geopolitical tensions. New Reit listings are expected, but their quality will determine their impact. Industry observers warn that listings must be of good quality, with a minimum value of S$1 billion, and a sponsor's expertise in managing the asset. summary: Upstarter Company has launched "Global Venture Play," a community aimed at boosting Asian startups' global investment and expansion. The initiative, centered in Singapore, seeks to address the undervaluation of Asian startups and attract international investors. Global Venture Play will host programs and events to facilitate Asian startups' entry into global markets, with a focus on deep-tech and impact-driven startups. CEO Jaehong Lee, a venture capitalist with extensive experience, will oversee the community, aiming to connect visionary founders with investors who understand their potential. site_title: OUE partners Tokyo Century to develop new hotel at Changi Airport’s T2

site_title: Average growth of 8% a year in last decade by Singapore’s general insurance sector

site_title: Temasek-backed insurance services firm Specialist Risk Group sets up Asia-Pacific hub in Singapore
summary: Specialist Risk Group (SRG), backed by Temasek and Warburg Pincus, has launched its Asia-Pacific operations in Singapore, establishing a regional hub. The company aims to deliver bespoke solutions for complex risks, focusing on specialty lines and property and casualty programs. SRG plans to expand into Malaysia, the Philippines, and Indonesia, driven by growing demand for specialist-led risk solutions in the region. The company seeks government approval to add these projects to the revised national power plan, which aims to increase the country's installed power capacity to 183-236 GW by 2030. summary: Vietnam is poised to shatter its visitation record, aiming for 23 million international arrivals by the end of 2025. The country's tourism sector is growing rapidly, driven by factors such as nonstop flights, luxurious hotels, and relaxed visa policies. Vietnam has regained 98% of its pre-pandemic tourism business, outpacing its neighbors, and is expected to edge out Malaysia as the most-visited country in South-east Asia by the turn of the decade.

site_title: No peace from this ‘peacemaker’
summary: US President Donald Trump has pledged to be remembered as a "peacemaker" president, but his efforts to settle the war in Ukraine and the Israel-Hamas conflict in Gaza have been met with rejection. Despite a 30-day ceasefire proposal, Russia and Ukraine failed to reach an accord, and Iran has yet to respond to Trump's diplomatic overtures. Trump's support for Israel and condemnation of Hamas have emboldened Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to invade Gaza, while his attacks on Houthi tribes in Yemen are unlikely to deter the regime. Trump's transactional diplomacy approach has failed to build diplomatic foundations for a Ukraine deal, making a stable peace agreement unlikely.

site_title: Norinchukin becomes latest big Japan bank to quit climate group
summary: Norinchukin Bank, a Japanese agricultural bank, has withdrawn from the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), joining peers Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group, Nomura Holdings, and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group in leaving the climate group. The move follows a wave of NZBA defections by US and Canadian banks, including JPMorgan Chase, Bank of America, and Royal Bank of Canada, since December. Norinchukin remains committed to net-zero efforts to address climate change issues.

site_title: Size and sponsor matter for investors in new S-Reit listings, say observers
summary: New S-Reit listings in Singapore will require at least S$1 billion in market capitalization to generate investor interest, say observers. Analysts note that investors are wary of smaller, locally listed Reits with foreign assets due to higher costs and potential market downturn difficulties. To attract investors, new listings will need to be sponsored by entities with a good track record, particularly those with operational experience and familiarity with managing real estate assets. The listing of larger Reits is expected to bring greater variety to the market and attract capital flows from global institutional investors.

images.alt_text: Excluding the impact of the divestment of Changi City Point and the asset enhancement initiative at Tampines 1, Frasers Centrepoint Trust's NPI was up 3.4 per cent in FY2024, with 7.7 per cent overall rental reversion.

site_title: ‘The customer wishes to be recognised’: Cold Storage, Giant in Singapore to focus on ‘superior’ customer service, says buyer Macrovalue
summary: Singapore's Cold Storage and Giant supermarkets will focus on "superior" customer service and elevated offerings after being acquired by Macrovalue, a Malaysian retail group, for S$125 million. The goal is to build better relationships with customers and create a human connection through staff training. Consumers can expect lower prices and a wider range of products as Macrovalue reaps economies of scale from larger import volumes. The acquisition is part of Macrovalue's efforts to expand its presence in Singapore, having already owned operations in Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Macrovalue owners, Gary Yap (right) and Andrew Lim (left), together with Cold Storage MD Lim Boon Cheong (centre)
Cold Storage, Giant sold to Malaysian group for S$125 million.

site_title: How you should invest through different life stages
summary: Investors should adjust their portfolios as they age, shifting from higher growth stocks to more dividend-paying stocks. The "100-minus rule" suggests allocating 80% of a 20-year-old's portfolio to stocks and 20% to bonds, decreasing to 30% stocks and 70% bonds by age 70. In the 20s-30s, focus on growth stocks, while in the 40s-50s, balance growth and income with dividend stocks. In the 60s and above, prioritize dividend stocks for passive income, and consider tweaking the approach based on personal preferences.

images.alt_text: Investing is a journey of continuous learning, where you gradually build the skills needed to navigate the stock market. There is no shame in taking your time to build wealth.
To diversify effectively, avoid over-concentration in sectors that are closely tied to the same economic cycles.

site_title: Alibaba’s chairman warns of a ‘bubble’ in AI data centre buildout
summary: Alibaba Chairman Joe Tsai warns of a potential bubble in data centre construction, citing the rapid buildout of server farms across Asia and the US as companies like Microsoft, SoftBank Group, and Amazon.com invest billions in AI development. Tsai notes that many projects lack clear customers, and critics question the spending, citing the lack of practical AI applications and the recent release of an open-source AI model at a lower cost.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Figurines with computers and smartphones are seen in front of the words "Artificial Intelligence AI" in this illustration taken, February 19, 2024. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The deals underscore the industry’s appeal in attracting a range of investors – from banks to real estate players – as the AI boom drives demand.

site_title: Nanofilm takes out 50 million yuan loan to fund Chinese subsidiary
summary: Nanofilm Technologies' wholly owned subsidiary, Nanofilm Vacuum Coating (Shanghai), has obtained a 50 million yuan (S$9.2 million) loan to fund working capital purposes. This is the second loan in less than two years, following a 50 million yuan loan in December 2023. The three-year loan will be secured by mortgage over two plants in Shanghai, corporate guarantee, and utility patents. The loan agreement includes conditions for early repayment if there's a change in company control or executive chairman Shi Xu's role. The loan is expected to have minimal impact on Nanofilm's consolidated earnings and net tangible assets.

images.alt_text: For the full year, Nanofilm’s revenue stood at S$204.3 million, 15.4 per cent higher than the S$177 million recorded the year before.
Nanofilm Technologies reappoints founder as CEO
Nanofilm acquires 2 German companies for 3.1 million euros

site_title: Malaysia’s Musang King eyes the throne in China after durian fallout in Thailand
summary: Malaysia's durian exports are poised to gain traction in China after the country tightened rules on Thai shipments tainted by a yellow dye scandal. China now requires additional lab tests for pre-harvested durians, potentially delaying shipments from Thailand and Vietnam. In contrast, Malaysia's tree-ripened durians, picked naturally, may enjoy a smoother path into China's booming market. Malaysian exporters expect rising demand for premium Musang King varieties, particularly with the temporary halt on Thai durian exports.

images.alt_text: Durian is packed for export at a port in Laem Chabang, Thailand, which is by far the fruit’s biggest exporting country.

Malaysia Agriculture and Food Security Minister Mohamad Sabu at the durian packaging and distribution warehouse in Shenzhen, China. The retail price of the fresh Musang King is priced at RM350 per fruit in Shenzhen.
Malaysia is not the only country producing Musang King durian but the taste and texture of Malaysian-grown Musang King are distinct due to the suitable climate and soil conditions.
FILE PHOTO: A man arranges durians at a market stall in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, July 10, 2019. REUTERS/Lim Huey Teng/File Photo

site_title: Another ‘Taobao’ moment helps China return to growth
summary: China's AI development is gaining momentum, with the emergence of companies like DeepSeek mirroring the "Taobao" moment in 2003, where a Chinese online e-commerce site challenged US dominance. Chinese equities have returned 40% since 2024, outpacing the S&P 500. Despite initial concerns over tariffs and geopolitical tensions, China's growing AI ecosystem is narrowing the valuation gap with US counterparts. Local governments are investing heavily in AI firms, and the country's unique advantages of talent, user base, and scalable platforms position it to capture market share.

images.alt_text: Server farms are springing up from India to Malaysia, while in the US, Trump is touting a Stargate project that envisions an outlay of half-a-trillion US dollars.

Alibaba Group Chairman Joe Tsai said on Tuesday there were clear signs China’s business entrepreneurs were more confident following a meeting with President Xi Jinping and that his company would re-commence hiring.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei snaps losing streak as tariff jitters ease
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average closed 0.5% higher at 37,780.54, snapping a three-day losing streak as US tariff concerns eased. The index briefly reclaimed the 38,000-point level, with the broader Topix touching an eight-month peak. Japanese equities followed US stock indexes, which rose sharply on Monday, despite uncertainty over the timing and specifics of upcoming tariffs.

images.alt_text: The Nikkei closed down 0.2 per cent at 37,608.49, while the broader Topix shed 0.5 per cent to sit at 2,790.88 after hitting an eight-month peak on Friday.

site_title: Japan’s Nomura Real Estate strikes deal with L&G to enter UK housing market
summary: Japan's Nomura Real Estate has struck a deal with Legal & General to build over 1,000 homes in the UK's rental housing market, its first foray into the UK market. The partnership will target central London sites, with Nomura investing hundreds of millions of pounds initially, and L&G providing the remainder. The project aims to address the UK's under-supplied rental housing market, where demand exceeds supply. The deal marks L&G's expansion into the rental housing market, with the firm planning to develop and operate the homes.

images.alt_text: London remains the least affordable UK region, with 90 per cent of local authorities recording house prices equal to over 12 times annual earnings.

site_title: Tesla’s EU sales plunge 49% year-on-year in first two months of 2025: industry body
summary: Tesla's European sales plummeted 49% year-on-year in the first two months of 2025, with new car registrations falling to 19,046 and a market share of 1.1%. The decline is attributed to ageing models and protests over Elon Musk's support for Donald Trump. Despite a 28.4% increase in overall electric vehicle sales, the EU market share for battery electric vehicles remains below the level needed for a transition to zero-emission mobility.

images.alt_text: BYD has risen quickly to the top of China’s car market – the world’s biggest and most competitive in terms of electric vehicles.
As BYD and CATL fight for stock-market dominance, the carmaker’s earnings may make a difference.
Elon Musk Musk launched into a familiar pitch that Teslas will soon be capable of driving autonomously, but execution still lags.

The recall covers just over 46,000 vehicles built from November 2023 through February 27 of this year, Tesla said in a filing with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and is the eighth recall for the SUV since January 2024.
Tesla has said it expects the vehicle business to return to growth this year, after a small drop in 2024.

site_title: Chocolate Finance takes S$500 million hit from 2 weeks’ run of redemptions; looking to return to business as usual
summary: Chocolate Finance, a Singapore-based fintech, faced a two-week run of redemptions resulting in S$500 million in net withdrawals, slashing its assets under management by 40%. Despite a "messy" communication, CEO Walter de Oude views the platform's handling of the withdrawals as a success, citing its automated and orderly manner. The asset manager is now focusing on regulatory checks and aims to return to "business as usual." De Oude acknowledges that more could have been done to clarify the platform's workings to customers, but emphasizes that customer monies are safe.

images.alt_text: Chocolate Finance paused all instant withdrawals on Monday (Mar 10).
The Monetary Authority of Singapore does not allow fund managers to operate as banks.
Chocolate Finance CEO Walter De Oude said Chocolate Finance appreciates its customers’ patience and remains focused on delivering a secure and rewarding financial experience.
The MAS has a two-stage test on what constitutes financial advice.
Resuming withdrawals is the latest step by Chocolate Finance to get the business back on an even keel.
Transactions made on AXS, and e-wallet top-ups are no longer supported, said Chocolate Finance.
Cash assets were approaching S$1 billion in Feb said Chocolate Finance CEO Walter de Oude.
Chocolate Finance founder and chief executive Walter de Oude assured that despite a spike in withdrawals, all requests are being processed in an orderly manner.
Founder and chief executive Walter de Oude explained that a spike in withdrawals would deplete the firm's liquidity buffer, which is why a temporary pause is required.
Instant withdrawals are temporarily unavailable at Chocolate Finance, which was founded by Walter de Oude.

site_title: Service-apartment operator charged over letting out private homes for short-term rental
summary: International Service Apartments and three senior management staff face 37 counts for illegally providing short-term accommodation in private residential properties without Urban Redevelopment Authority approval. The charges carry fines of up to S$200,000 per count. The company allegedly converted properties in various areas of Singapore for short-term rentals, violating the Planning Act. The URA will continue to investigate and take enforcement action against those found guilty, emphasizing its serious stance against such offenses.

images.alt_text: The new condo is located in District 5 and is conveniently accessible to the Central Business District and Orchard Road.

site_title: Trump admin includes journalist in group chat on classified Yemen strikes
summary: The US government confirmed that a journalist, Jeffrey Goldberg, was inadvertently included in a group chat discussing classified strikes against Yemen's Huthi rebels. The chat, which included Defence Secretary Pete Hegseth and other top officials, revealed details of the plan, including targets and attack sequencing. Goldberg, editor-in-chief of The Atlantic magazine, had hours of advance notice via the group chat on Signal. The leak sparked outrage among Democrats, who called for a full investigation, and raised concerns about the security breach.

images.alt_text: Drilling rigs at an oil well operated by Venezuela's state oil company PDVSA. Trump is imposing the move because Venezuela has sent “tens of thousands” of people to the US who have a “very violent nature.”
U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 19, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
Having more than tripled their American equity holdings to US$20 trillion over the past decade, foreigners now own 30 per cent of the US stock market, a record high.

site_title: Filmgarde Cineplexes shuts down last outlet at Kallang, exits industry
summary: Filmgarde Cineplexes, a Singaporean independent cinema, has shut down its last outlet at Leisure Park Kallang, marking its exit from the cinema business. The cinema, established in 2007, had previously closed its Bugis+ and Century Square outlets in 2022. Filmgarde cited declining cinema attendance and the rise of streaming platforms as reasons for its closure, but announced plans to "embark on a new chapter of development and adventure" in the film and culture industry. Only a few indie cinemas remain in Singapore, including The Projector, Carnival Cinemas, and EagleWings Cinematics.

images.alt_text: In Singapore, cinema attendance stood at 10 million in 2023, down from its peak of 22.1 million in 2011.
The cinema chain has five other existing outlets – Causeway Point at Woodlands, Downtown East at Pasir Ris, JEM at Jurong East, Century Square at Tampines and Clementi 321.
Cathay Cineplexes' delayed rental payments could indicate a structural issue among cinema operators, says one analyst.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to buy rest of Northpoint City for S$1.17 billion
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) has entered into unit purchase agreements to acquire the South Wing of Northpoint City for S$1.17 billion. The acquisition, through the purchase of North Gem Trust (NG Trust), will give FCT full ownership of the mall. The deal will be financed through a mix of new equity and debt financing, with a focus on delivering regular and stable distributions to unitholders. Following the acquisition, FCT will have control to implement asset enhancement initiatives and tenant mix strategies to unlock further value.

images.alt_text: The progress for Frasers Centrepoint Trust's Hougang Mall AEI is on track, with its main contract awarded within its budget.

site_title: Trump Media taps Singapore’s Crypto.com for Made-in-America ETFs
summary: Trump Media & Technology Group plans to launch "Made-in-America" exchange-traded funds (ETFs) tied to digital assets and US-focused investments, in partnership with Crypto.com. The products, available in the US, Europe, and Asia, pending regulatory approval, will include cryptocurrencies and technology supplied by Crypto.com. This collaboration comes after President Donald Trump's administration eased restrictions on the digital-asset industry, with the SEC abandoning or pausing high-profile cases against companies like Coinbase and Binance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Representation of the bitcoin cryptocurrency and a price chart are seen in this illustration taken October 24, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Crypto companies have long accused the SEC of overreach and of violating its jurisdiction.

site_title: Trump says auto tariff coming, teases reciprocal duty breaks
summary: US President Donald Trump announced tariffs on automobile imports, set to be unveiled on April 2, dubbed "Liberation Day". He hinted at reciprocal duties, with potential exemptions or reductions for countries that have imposed trade barriers on US products. Trump also signaled sector-specific tariffs on lumber and semiconductors, and a 25% tariff on Venezuelan oil imports starting April 2. The move has sparked confusion and concern among investors and foreign governments, with nations rushing to negotiate exemptions or concessions.

images.alt_text: The regulations stipulate what steps the Chinese government can take to enforce the countermeasures, such as banning or restricting individuals and organisations from import and export of related goods and technologies.
Trump has also pledged to pair those with sectoral tariffs on autos, semiconductor chips, pharmaceutical drugs and lumber.
The focus on tariffs, as well as a surge in prices of basic staples such as eggs and the stock-market rout, is taking a toll on sentiment and inciting growth concerns.

site_title: Indonesia intervenes as rupiah falls to Asian crisis lows
summary: Indonesia's central bank intervened in the currency market to defend the rupiah, which has fallen 3% against the US dollar this year due to global market uncertainties and concerns over the country's fiscal health and growth outlook. The rupiah reached its lowest level since the Asian financial crisis in 1998, with a low of 16,640 per US dollar. The bank has been intervening in the FX market every month this year to maintain balance and prevent a sharp decline.

images.alt_text: A clerk poses with Indonesian rupiah banknotes at a money changer in Jakarta on May 2, 2024. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)
Indonesia's heavy reliance on steel imports, especially steel products from China, leaves it especially exposed to the trade diversion risks.

Indonesia’s President Prabowo Subianto, who also serves as the chairman of the Great Indonesia Movement Party (Gerindra), celebrates the party's 17th anniversary with supporters in Bogor, West Java, on February 15, 2025 (Photo by ADITYA AJI / AFP)
The average yield premium on US dollar-denominated Indonesian corporate bonds hit around 144 basis points over Treasuries at Tuesday’s close, the highest level since September.

site_title: Cathay Pacific will comply with stricter rules on power banks
summary: Cathay Pacific Airways has announced it will comply with new regulations banning the use of portable power banks on flights due to safety concerns. The Hong Kong government's ban follows incidents of power banks causing fires on board aircraft. Cathay joins regional carriers like Singapore Airlines in adhering to the new rules, which also restrict the storage of power banks in overhead lockers. The airline acknowledged the importance of improving aviation safety and supporting measures to reduce risks associated with lithium battery-powered devices.

site_title: Singapore rolls out new standard for charging electric harbour craft
summary: Singapore has published a new standard, Technical Reference 136 (TR 136), for charging electric harbour craft (EHCs) in the country's ports. The standard, developed by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) and industry stakeholders, sets technical and safety requirements for charging infrastructure and battery swap systems. The goal is to establish robust charging infrastructure, ensuring safe and efficient services, and pave the way for wider EHC adoption. The standard is expected to have positive spillover effects and open upskilling prospects for the maritime workforce.

images.alt_text: “I think there will always be a living for us,” says Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong in response to a question by ambassador-at-large Chan Heng Chee at a fireside chat.
A new technical reference on methanol bunkering has been published to provide a framework for safe and efficient use of methanol as an alternative in bunkering operations, said MPA.
A charging point for electric harbour craft by Pyxis Maritime and SP Mobility under a pilot project initiated by the Maritime Port Authority of Singapore.
