site_title: Unlocking hidden opportunities in Chinese equities
summary: Chinese stocks, particularly tech companies, are gaining attention due to their strong earnings growth potential, rapid advancements in technology, and supportive government policies. The Nasdaq Golden Dragon China Index has risen 16.9% year-to-date, outperforming the US market. Chinese tech companies are undervalued and have far-reaching room to grow, offering a better bargain compared to US tech stocks. The Chinese government is also taking proactive steps to deregulate the economy, aiming to level the playing field for private firms and offer more support to entrepreneurs, further enhancing the attractiveness of Chinese equities.

images.alt_text: Elon Musk Musk launched into a familiar pitch that Teslas will soon be capable of driving autonomously, but execution still lags.
The HSI’s strong year-to-date performance has been driven by China’s economic policies, global market sentiments, and corporate performances.

Goodwin Gaw, chairman of Gaw Capital Partners (centre) and Oliver Weisberg, chief executive officer of Blue Pool Capital (right) during the Milken Institute Global Investors' Symposium; Hong Kong will eventually benefit from the integration of the so-called Greater Bay Area, says Gaw.

site_title: Jardine’s DFI says S$125 million sale of Singapore food business not price-sensitive, but investors disagree
summary: DFI Retail Group, the parent company of Cold Storage and Giant supermarkets, has sold its Singapore food business to Macrovalue for S$125 million. The transaction, expected to be completed in the second half of 2025, will focus the group's investment on its Guardian and 7-Eleven businesses in Singapore. The sale was not announced on the Singapore Exchange, as it is a secondary listing site, but the company's share price rose 6.2% following news of the deal. Macrovalue, a Malaysian retail conglomerate, will continue to drive growth of the acquired brands and ensure continuity of local management and operation teams.

images.alt_text: Cold Storage, Giant sold to Malaysian group for S$125 million.

site_title: EuroSports’ Scorpio Electric cuts staff amid e-bike delivery woes
summary: Scorpio Electric, a Singapore-based e-motorcycle startup, has conducted layoffs amid delivery woes. The company, which has yet to start delivering its flagship model, X1, has confirmed the staff reduction as part of "right-sizing" operations to focus on production. Scorpio Electric has faced delays and minimal revenue, with losses growing to S$3.3 million in FYE 2023. The company has raised US$15.7 million and is targeting international markets, including Europe and Asia-Pacific regions, where it has opened pre-orders.

images.alt_text: Singapore electric scooter company Scorpio says it is in collaboration with Shenzhen BYD Electronics to produce pre-production prototypes of the X1.

site_title: Temasek’s asset manager Seviora expands to the Middle East
summary: Seviora Group, an asset manager wholly owned by Temasek, has expanded to the Middle East by opening its first office in Abu Dhabi. The office will help tap into the region's growing asset management industry. Seviora now has a presence in Singapore, India, China, Indonesia, and the Middle East, with US$54 billion in assets under management. The move is seen as part of Temasek's international expansion plans, with CEO Jimmy Phoon stating the Middle East's strategic importance in growth plans. Seviora has appointed Sadiq Hussain as senior executive officer for its Abu Dhabi office.

images.alt_text: Temasek Holdings signboard
Temasek to set up asset management group Seviora with S$75b AUM

site_title: South Korea court dismisses impeachment of prime minister: Yonhap
summary: South Korea's Constitutional Court dismissed the impeachment of Prime Minister Han Duck-soo, reinstating him as acting president. The ruling came in a 5-1 vote, dismissing impeachment motions citing Han's refusal to appoint more judges and his role in martial law. Han thanked the court for its decision, which clears the way for President Yoon Suk Yeol's reinstatement. The court's decision has been closely watched ahead of a highly anticipated ruling on Yoon's impeachment, which is expected by mid-March.

images.alt_text: Climate change, ageing populations and trade are among the topics expected to be discussed, as well as working together on disaster relief and science and technology.
A variety of South Korean companies play an integral role in global supply chains, and semiconductor manufacturers form the crown jewel of South Korea’s export sector.
The figure comes a month after South Korea reported its fertility rate increased for the first time in nine years in 2024.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, March 24, 2025
summary: Asian investors struggled to kick off the week with strong gains, while gold prices remained steady due to increased demand for safe-havens. Sinopec reported a nearly 17% decline in its 2024 net profit, attributed to falling oil prices and electric vehicle sales. Market sentiment was also influenced by Fed optimism and upcoming 'Liberation Day' in Asia.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.
Tokyo stocks were flat while Shanghai, Singapore and Taipei shares were slightly higher on Monday.
Gold reached a record high of US$3,057.21 per ounce last Thursday as trade tensions fuelled safe-haven demand.
Sinopec expects crude oil production in 2025 to be 280.15 million barrels, or 767,530 bpd, and natural gas output of 1,450.3 billion cubic feet.

site_title: Jack Ma-backed Ant touts AI breakthrough built on Chinese chips
summary: Ant Group, backed by Jack Ma, has developed AI models using Chinese-made semiconductors that can train AI models 20% more efficiently, cutting costs by 20%. The models use the Mixture of Experts (MoE) approach and are comparable to Nvidia's H800 processor. Ant plans to leverage the breakthrough for industrial AI solutions, including healthcare and finance. The company's research paper claims its models outperformed Meta Platforms in certain benchmarks, but the findings have not been independently verified.

images.alt_text: Ant Group attributed the sizeable profit to a net investment gain, versus a loss from such activity the previous year.
Ant Group has opened positions related to humanoid robot systems and applications through its subsidiary, Shanghai Ant Lingbo Technology.
nt is expanding its business with AI-powered products in areas including dining, ride-hailing, entertainment services, health care and finance.

site_title: Malaysia maintains 2025 growth forecast at 4.5% to 5.5%, warns of rising risks amid protectionism
summary: Malaysia has reaffirmed its 2025 growth forecast at 4.5% to 5.5%, despite rising risks from global trade tensions and protectionism. Bank Negara governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour attributes sustained domestic demand, driven by investment activity and a strong labor market, as key growth drivers. However, he warns of potential risks to trade and growth from external factors, including escalating geopolitical tensions and protectionist measures. The central bank expects inflation to trend higher but remain manageable, with a forecast of 2-3.5% average headline inflation in 2025.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara governor Abdul Rasheed Ghaffour said heightened external uncertainties that could lead to a more moderate expansion of exports.

site_title: Chinese developer Sunac says to conduct second offshore debt restructuring
summary: China's property developer Sunac has confirmed it will conduct a second offshore debt restructuring, marking the first time the company has done so. This follows a liquidation petition filed by a unit of state-owned asset manager Cinda against Sunac for non-payment of a $30 million loan. Sunac completed its $9 billion offshore debt restructuring in 2023, but the new petition and second restructuring indicate a protracted battle facing the developer and the sector. A hearing is scheduled for April 28 for Sunac to show its progress on restructuring.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: A man walks past the logo of property developer Sunac at a residential compound in Beijing, China September 19, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo/File Photo
Investors have grown increasingly anxious about Sunac's upcoming interest payments amid sluggish sales, which sent its shares and US dollar notes to their lowest levels in months last week.

site_title: Oil prices hold steady as investors monitor Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks
summary: Oil prices held steady on Monday, with Brent crude futures down 8 cents to $72.08 a barrel, as investors monitored Russia-Ukraine ceasefire talks. The US delegation met with Russian officials on Monday, seeking progress toward a Black Sea ceasefire and broader cessation of violence. Despite expectations of progress, prices were pressured lower by concerns about future Opec+ production trends. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (Opec+) announced a new schedule for oil output cuts, which may lead to an increase in Russian oil to global markets.

images.alt_text: Wind and solar are the fastest growing sources of electricity worldwide. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo
US West Texas Intermediate crude futures rose US$0.21, or 0.3%, to US$68.28.

site_title: Tencent upgrades AI model to compete with DeepSeek, Alibaba
summary: Tencent has released an upgraded AI model, Hunyuan T1, to compete with DeepSeek's R1 in the generative AI market. The model, which debuted in its chatbot app Yuanbao, has cutting-edge logic and writing capabilities, rivaling state-of-the-art models. Tencent has adopted a two-pronged approach, combining in-house projects with open-sourced models, similar to its game publishing strategy. The company's AI efforts aim to win new users and compete with Chinese tech peers Alibaba and Baidu.

images.alt_text: The upgraded T1 model offers faster response times and enhanced capabilities for processing extended text documents, says Tencent in a post on its official WeChat account.
Tencent gained roughly 30 per cent or US$140 billion in market valuation so far this year, helped by a broader Chinese tech rally induced by the rise of DeepSeek.
Tencent’s five new 3D-content generators are built atop its Hunyuan3D-2.0 model, all of which it intends to open-source to users.
Three of the top five most downloaded free apps are AI bots, with ByteDance’s Doubao joining Tencent and DeepSeek.

site_title: DFI Retail Group sells Singapore food business, including Cold Storage and Giant, for S$125 million to Macrovalue
summary: DFI Retail Group has sold its Singapore food business, including Cold Storage and Giant, to Macrovalue for S$125 million. The deal includes 48 Cold Storage stores, 41 Giant stores, and two distribution centers. Following the divestment, DFI will focus on its Guardian and 7-Eleven businesses, aiming to drive growth and improve customer experience. The company expects the transaction to bring enhanced product ranges and competitive pricing for customers. Macrovalue will leverage its scale and procurement power to drive growth for the acquired brands, with the deal expected to complete in the second half of 2025.

images.alt_text: Cold Storage Singapore includes 48 Cold Storage stores under the Cold Storage, CS Fresh and Jason’s Deli brands.
CS Fresh is operated by mainboard-listed DFI Retail Group. The supermarket and retail store operator declared a final dividend of 7 US cents per share.
Despite returning to the black, DFI expects its supermarket revenue in Singapore to remain stable at best under heavy competition.

site_title: Asia credit market heats up as issuers rush to beat tariff wave
summary: Issuers in the Asia-Pacific region have rushed to sell US dollar bonds, with over $92 billion sold in the first quarter, the highest volume since 2022. This surge is driven by US President Donald Trump's planned tariff announcement on April 2, which has fueled uncertainty and investment in the bond market. Despite the threat of tariffs, Treasury yields have fallen, reducing funding costs for issuers, and credit spreads remain tight. Multiple issuers, including Korean and Malaysian companies, are seeking to lock in funding ahead of the tariff announcement.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei dips as looming US tariff deadline spurs caution
summary: Japan's Nikkei index closed down 0.2% at 37,608.49, while the broader Topix shed 0.5% to 2,790.88, as investors took a cautious approach to the looming deadline for implementing additional US tariffs, set for April 2. Despite US President Donald Trump's hint of flexibility, uncertainty kept investors on edge, with semiconductor-related shares dragging the market down.

images.alt_text: Tokyo stocks were flat while Shanghai, Singapore and Taipei shares were slightly higher on Monday.

site_title: Thai PM faces censure motion as opposition takes aim at father’s influence
summary: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra faces a no-confidence motion in parliament, with the opposition accusing her of taking direction from her father, Thaksin Shinawatra, a divisive former premier banned from office. Despite lukewarm ratings, Paetongtarn is firm in her position, and a ruling coalition commands a parliamentary majority, making the motion unlikely to succeed. The opposition focuses on the underperforming economy and household debt, while Paetongtarn insists her government is not under anyone's influence.

images.alt_text: An increased supply of cheap steel imports, coupled with the US’ tariff, will further intensify competition in Thailand.

Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra’s Pheu Thai party is proposing the so-called Landbridge project at a cost of about 1 trillion baht, to link two proposed seaports on either side of the country’s southern peninsula with a new highway and rail line.

A Thai national flag flies on a building as stacks of containers sit at the Port of Bangkok with the skyline of the city standing in the background, Thailand, on Monday, June 25, 2014. ThailandÕs trade figures are scheduled for release on Aug. 27. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

site_title: GE2025: Revised registers of voters certified, available for public inspection from Mar 25
summary: The revised Registers of Electors for Singapore's 2025 General Election (GE2025) have been certified and are available for public inspection starting March 25. The registers contain 2,758,095 electors, compiled based on electoral boundaries as of February 1, 2025. The changes were made in line with the Electoral Boundaries Review Committee's (EBRC) recommendations, paving the way for the next general election by November this year. Electors can check their particulars online or in-person at designated centers.

site_title: Under threat from Trump, Canada calls snap elections for April 28
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Mark Carney has called a national election for April 28, citing US President Donald Trump's threats to annex Canada. Carney, a former Goldman Sachs banker, warned that Trump wants to "break us" so the US can own Canada. The Liberal Party is seeking a fourth straight election victory, while Conservative Party leader Pierre Poilievre is positioning himself as a strong leader to counter US aggression. The election is seen as a tight race, with public opinion surveys suggesting it's between the Liberals and the Conservatives.

images.alt_text: Mark Carney, who replaced prime minister Justin Trudeau just last week, is set to announce the election date on Sunday, two government sources told AFP.

site_title: China promotes business potential to Apple, Pfizer and other US companies
summary: China is promoting business potential to US companies, including Apple and Pfizer, amid heightened geopolitical tensions and US tariffs imposed on Chinese goods. Vice-Premier He Lifeng met with company heads to reassure them of China's business environment and welcomed foreign investment. The meeting comes as China seeks to boost domestic consumption and offset the impact of US tariffs. China's economy is described as "highly resilient" and "full of vitality" by He, and the country is offering incentives, such as deeper supply-chain cooperation with Apple, to encourage investment.

images.alt_text: The idea of restoring a US shipbuilding industry to firm up US influence at sea has captivated Trump and fits with his wider push for a return to the halcyon days of US manufacturing.
Trump has ramped up a trade fight with China since returning to office, imposing a fresh 10 per cent tariff on Chinese goods in February and adding another 10 per cent in March.
Firms are already reacting, with Chinese companies cutting the export of small parcels in February.
The trade in small packages has boomed in recent years as US consumers took advantage of low-cost shopping apps such as Shein and Temu to use the loophole.
Those potential port fees have limited the availability of ships needed to move agriculture, energy, mining, construction and manufactured goods to international buyers.

site_title: Japan’s factory activity declines accelerate, services sag: PMI
summary: Japan's factory activity declined at the fastest pace in a year in March, with production and new orders contracting, according to a private-sector survey. The service sector also lost momentum, with business activity contracting for the first time in five months. Inflationary pressures remained high, with input and output charge indices expanding. The overall business outlook slipped to its lowest since August 2020, with firms citing rising costs, labor shortages, and uncertainty over global trade.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan would continue raising interest rates if the central bank’s outlooks on the economy and prices are likely to be achieved, BOJ Deputy Governor Shinichi Uchida said on Monday.

A separate index that excludes the effects of both fresh food and fuel costs, closely watched by the Bank of Japan as a broader price trend indicator, rose 2.6 per cent in February from a year earlier after a 2.5 per cent rise in January.
BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda says: “We will scrutinise how US trade policy unfolds, how it affects the US and other global economies, and how that all impacts Japan’s economic and price outlook.”
Japan's exports rose 11.4 per cent year-on-year in February, data showed, less than a median market forecast for a 12.1 per cent increase and following a 7.2 per cent rise in January.

site_title: Malaysia to tighten semiconductor regulations under US pressure: FT
summary: Malaysia plans to tighten semiconductor regulations under US pressure, with Trade Minister Zafrul Aziz stating that the US wants Malaysia to closely track high-end Nvidia chips entering the country to prevent them from being shipped to China. This move comes amid US investigations into the use of banned US chips by Chinese firm DeepSeek. Malaysia is also investigating a Singapore fraud case involving the shipment of servers linked to Nvidia chips, with possible breaches of local laws.

images.alt_text: Nvidia's position at the forefront of chips needed for AI, and the billions of dollars of spending that’s anticipated this year, could mean recent weakness is just a phase.
The pace of China’s open-source AI push has been relentless since the debut in January of DeepSeek R1.
Huang has been working to allay investor concerns over demand for Nvidia’s expensive AI chips
The Santa Clara, California-based company is working on a successor to its current design, but that will be a stopgap product.
Malaysia's headline inflation moderated to 1.5 per cent in February, but core inflation grew at a faster pace at 1.9 per cent.

The new cloud region will generate US$10.9 billion in new revenues and create 37,575 jobs in Malaysia by 2028, including 5,700 skilled IT positions, projects Laurence Si, managing director of Microsoft Malaysia.

site_title: Thai casino plan wins overwhelming support in public hearing
summary: Thailand is moving forward with plans to legalize casinos, with an overwhelming majority of 80% of public hearing respondents backing the proposal. The government aims to attract foreign investment and lift tax revenue, while tackling illegal gaming venues. The draft bill proposes limits on casino area, high entry barriers for locals, and stricter age and income requirements for gamblers. The government will incorporate suggestions from respondents into the bill before submitting it to the Cabinet for approval, with potential locations including popular tourist destinations like Bangkok and Phuket.

images.alt_text: A person inside a casino in the Philippines. Seven South-east Asian nations – Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos – have already legalised gambling to varying degrees.
A man stacks chips on a black jack table at Japan Casino School in Tokyo, Japan August 4, 2018. Picture taken August 4, 2018. REUTERS/Toru Hanai

Thailand’s potential as a gaming destination, with casinos proposed in the capital Bangkok, on the holiday island of Phuket, and three other sites, is underpinned by its role as a regional magnet for tourism.

site_title: Singapore committed to staying open on trade, international cooperation, amid maritime sector headwinds: SM Lee
summary: Singapore commits to staying open and competitive in the face of global headwinds, including protectionism, economic bifurcation, and climate change. Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasizes the importance of international cooperation and trade to support the country's economy, which relies heavily on the maritime sector. Despite potential slowdowns in global trade, Singapore aims to strengthen its maritime industry through investments in infrastructure, technology, and innovation, and expand its network of free-trade agreements to insulate itself from trade tensions. The country's goal is to continue making a living from maritime trade, leveraging its efficiency, technology, and human resources.

images.alt_text: Therese Soh
Tay Peck Gek
A container terminal at the Port of Singapore.

site_title: Singapore core inflation dips further to 0.6% in February, lowest in nearly 4 years
summary: Singapore's core inflation eased to 0.6% in February, the lowest in nearly 4 years, driven by slower price increases in non-cooked food and prepared meals. Core CPI, excluding private transport and accommodation, also dipped to 0.6% year on year, extending the sharp drop to 0.8% in January. Headline inflation fell to 0.9% year on year, down from 1.2% in the previous month. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and Ministry of Trade and Industry reiterated their inflation outlook, citing weaker global demand as a disinflationary drag.

images.alt_text: Lower inflation was recorded for the majority of categories in January.

site_title: Billion-dollar US levies on Chinese ships risk ‘trade apocalypse’
summary: The US Office of the US Trade Representative (USTR) is proposing levies of up to $3.5 million on Chinese ships docking in the US, aiming to curb China's dominance of the shipbuilding, logistics, and maritime industry. The proposed measures could disrupt global trade, causing chaos in the shipping sector, and potentially harming the US economy. Industry leaders argue that the levies would be devastating, making American goods too expensive internationally and diverting trade away from US regional hubs. The USTR hearing will begin on Monday, with the proposal sparking concerns of a "trade apocalypse."

images.alt_text: Trump has ramped up a trade fight with China since returning to office, imposing a fresh 10 per cent tariff on Chinese goods in February and adding another 10 per cent in March.
Firms are already reacting, with Chinese companies cutting the export of small parcels in February.

site_title: Tariff shift opens doors for Vietnam’s steel, but risks loom
summary: Vietnam's steel industry is navigating a complex landscape after the US imposed tariffs on Chinese steel, creating opportunities for Vietnamese steel producers to level the playing field against competitors. Vietnam's steel exports to the US surged 159% in 2024, with the country ranking among the US' top 10 steel suppliers. However, ongoing investigations and potential anti-dumping duties remain a concern, prompting some producers to cut back on US exports and seek alternative markets. Vietnamese steelmakers may need to adjust pricing strategies to maintain market share, potentially squeezing profit margins.

images.alt_text: Washington has already imposed anti-dumping duties on multiple Vietnamese steel exports and producers, in some cases even higher than 25 per cent
China’s sent the most steel overseas in nine years in 2024, as its producers turned to global markets to offset a deep construction slowdown at home.
India joins countries from Saudi Arabia to Vietnam and Chile in wielding trade measures to limit cheaper inflows, fuelled by a surge of steel coming from China. C

Vietnam posted a trade deficit of US$1.55 billion in February, after a US$3.02 billion surplus in January, the General Statistics Office said. It was only the third monthly deficit since the start of 2023, as per GSO and London Stock Exchange Group data.

site_title: French director unveils ‘Asterix’ series to stream on Netflix
summary: French director Alain Chabat has unveiled a 3D animated "Asterix" series on Netflix, based on the 1961 comic book "Asterix and the Big Fight." The series, consisting of five episodes, follows the adventures of Asterix and Obelix as they defend their village against Roman invaders. The show marks Chabat's return to the franchise, which has sold over 400 million copies worldwide, and will premiere on Netflix on April 30.

images.alt_text: Netflix paid “approximately US$44 million” for a show’s production between 2018 and 2019 helmed by Hollywood filmmaker Carl Rinsch.
Apple does not break down the subscribers for Apple TV+ but it is estimated to have reached 40.4 million at the end of 2024.
The AI management shift has been months in the making and predates Apple announcing the Siri delays.

site_title: Singapore debuts digital twin of its port
summary: Singapore has launched its Maritime Digital Twin (MDT), a virtual model of its port that aims to increase safety, efficiency, and sustainability in maritime operations. Developed by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, the MDT uses real-time data and artificial intelligence to optimize port efficiency and reliability. User trials are set to begin in the second half of 2025, with plans to expand to the wider industry and global maritime ecosystem in the future. The MDT will also serve as a virtual test bed for industry entities to develop maritime solutions.

images.alt_text: Singapore's ports are expected to break records for cargo throughput and bunkering in 2024, following 2023's performance.
Those potential port fees have limited the availability of ships needed to move agriculture, energy, mining, construction and manufactured goods to international buyers.
Digital bunkering will speed up the process of refuelling ships and save up to 40,000 man-days a year.

site_title: New ‘Snow White’ tops North American box office despite grumpy reviews
summary: Disney's live-action remake of "Snow White" topped the North American box office with an estimated $43 million, despite receiving harsh reviews. The film's budget was estimated at $250 million, making it one of the most troubled projects in Disney's history. While some critics called it "toe-curlingly terrible," others found it "surprisingly entertaining." The film's performance will be closely watched in the coming weeks.

images.alt_text: Cast member Rachel Zegler attends a premiere for the film "Snow White", in Los Angeles, California, U.S. March 15, 2025. REUTERS/Mario Anzuoni
Pattinson plays Mickey, who volunteers for hazardous space missions and, when killed, is repeatedly “reprinted” to be sent out again.
Collected over half a century by real estate agent Dwight Cleveland, the posters are to be auctioned by Heritage showrooms in Dallas on Mar 27 and 28.

Comic strip characters "Asterix and Obelix" displayed during an exhibition as part of the 52nd Angouleme International Comics Festival in Angouleme, France, Jan 31, 2025. French director Alain Chabat has again teamed up with the plucky Gauls for a 3D animated series that was presented on Sunday at a festival in Lille before it runs on Netflix.

site_title: Asia: Markets fluctuate as traders prepare for ‘Liberation Day’
summary: Asian markets fluctuated on Monday as traders prepared for US President Donald Trump's "Liberation Day" tariffs, set to kick in on April 2. Despite a report suggesting Trump may consider a more targeted approach, investors remained cautious, with Tokyo stocks flat and Shanghai, Singapore, and Taipei shares slightly higher. The uncertainty has led to a decrease in confidence, with the Federal Reserve warning of increased economic uncertainty and Chinese Premier Li Qiang preparing for potential shocks.

images.alt_text: The HSI’s strong year-to-date performance has been driven by China’s economic policies, global market sentiments, and corporate performances.

site_title: With brands from Eggslut to Haidilao closing outlets, are odds worsening for Singapore retail operators?
summary: Singapore's retail sector faces challenges as familiar brands like Eggslut, Haidilao, and Wild Honey close stores due to rising rents and weak sales. Despite this, mall vacancy rates remain low, with landlords able to renew leases or fill spaces at higher rents. Retail rents rose 3% in 2024, with prime space in Orchard averaging S$35.83 per square foot. Vacancy rates fell to 6.3% in the fourth quarter, the lowest in four years. New tenants are moving into vacated spaces, including performance running shoe brand On and athletic apparel retailer Foot Locker. However, market watchers say the reality on the ground is mixed, with some malls facing increasing competition and a slowdown in luxury spending post-pandemic.

images.alt_text: Taylor Swift fans hang around the outdoor area of Kallang Wave Mall, which generally sees high footfall  during the concert periods.
Marks & Spencer will be closing its Parkway Parade store on Feb 16 after more than two decades at the mall.
Boloni's new 5,000 square foot flagship showroom. The brand is targeting the high-end residential market.
Cathay Cineplexes' delayed rental payments could indicate a structural issue among cinema operators, says one analyst.

Ion Orchard as seen before the WWF Earth Hour Switch Off moment on March 23, 2024.

For an hour from 8.30pm on March 23, all non-essential lights were switched off at establishments along Orchard Road in a display of support for WWF Earth Hour Switch Off for the first time in the iconic shopping district. 

At Wisma Atria, a venue partner for the event, a festival of activities and performances – including thematic art performances, educational booths around climate change, and talks by WWF-Singapore’s subject matter experts - concluded with the symbolic switching off of lights within the shopping centre.

More than 1000 individuals and businesses around Singapore joined in the collective act  to pledge their commitment towards a climate-resilient future.

Lady Gaga receiving the Innovator Award during the iHeartRadio Music Awards at Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, California,  on March 17.  Singapore is the only Asian stop on her tour.

site_title: AI boom turns Asian data centres into magnets for loan deals
summary: Asia's data centre industry is experiencing a surge in funding, with major loans secured for expansion in Malaysia and other countries. The AI boom is driving demand, with the market expected to grow 32% annually to 2028, outpacing the US. Private credit and infrastructure funds are expanding financing avenues, and tech multinationals are diversifying investments beyond China. However, the industry faces uncertainties due to US tariffs and trade war risks, which could lead to higher financing costs and lower investor confidence.

images.alt_text: sever, digitization, mainframe
Malaysia is turning into a beneficiary of Asia’s growing need for data centres to support the boom in artificial intelligence.
Thaksin Shinawatra, the de facto chief of the ruling Pheu Thai Party, says: “We want to be competitive in data centres and AI.”
Oracle already has two cloud computing centers in Singapore, and last year announced a US$6.5 billion plan to build a similar facility in Malaysia.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UOB, SIA, Nio, Starhill Global Reit
summary: Stocks to watch: UOB, SIA, Nio, Starhill Global Reit. UOB's CEO Wee Ee Cheong's annual salary dropped 5.5% to S$15 million in 2024 despite a record net profit. SIA's proposed commercial cooperation with ANA was conditionally approved by the CCCS, while Nio's net loss widened to S$1.3 billion in Q4 2024. Starhill Global Reit secured a S$600 million loan from a club of banks for sustainability-linked facilities.

site_title: India’s US$23 billion plan to rival China factories to lapse after it disappoints
summary: India's US$23 billion Production-Linked Initiative to incentivize domestic manufacturing will lapse after just four years, disappointing the government's goal to rival China's factories. The program, which was launched to woo firms away from China, saw 750 companies sign up, including Apple supplier Foxconn and Reliance Industries. Despite this, the manufacturing sector's share in the economy has decreased from 15.4% to 14.3% since the program's introduction. The government has decided not to expand the program beyond 14 pilot sectors and will not extend production deadlines despite requests from participating firms.

images.alt_text: A vast luxury development called Lido City has also run into problems. In February, the Indonesian government halted the billion-dollar project over environmental violations.

site_title: Trump plans his tariff ‘Liberation Day’ with more targeted push
summary: US President Donald Trump plans to announce a "Liberation Day" tariff announcement on April 2, targeting countries or blocs with tariffs and non-tariff barriers. The tariffs will be reciprocal, excluding some countries and sectors, and will take effect immediately. The move is aimed at steering new investment to the US and generating revenue to offset tax cuts. The plan is narrower in scope than Trump's previous threats, but still poses uncertainty and potential retaliation from allied nations. Markets are expected to adjust to the new tariffs, with some experts warning of a potential economic slowdown.

images.alt_text: The focus on tariffs, as well as a surge in prices of basic staples such as eggs and the stock-market rout, is taking a toll on sentiment and inciting growth concerns.

site_title: Signs of weakness in Hang Seng have emerged
summary: The Hang Seng Index (HSI) has experienced a strong year-to-date increase of 23.42% due to China's economic policies, global market sentiments, and corporate performances. However, signs of weakness have emerged, including a bearish divergence and a fall in the Relative Strength Index (RSI) below the overbought level of 70, indicating diminishing momentum. Key support levels to watch are the 50% Fibonacci level at 22,895 and 38.2% level at 21,898, which could pose a risk of a decline if breached.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Bull statues are placed in font of screens showing the Hang Seng stock index and stock prices outside Exchange Square, in Hong Kong, China, August 18, 2023. REUTERS/Tyrone Siu/File Photo

site_title: Transforming and developing a bank, the Japanese way
summary: Mizuho Bank Singapore is undergoing a transformation process to enhance efficiency, streamline processes, and offer innovative solutions. The bank, with a focus on corporate clients, employs over 1,000 professionals in Singapore and aims to provide comprehensive financial solutions to its clients. CEO Josephine Lok emphasizes the importance of overseas working experience, citing a new scheme that posts staff overseas for six months to facilitate communication among colleagues. The bank also prioritizes sustainability and supports local businesses in their international expansion, with estimated gross profit of US$516 million for the year to March 2025.

images.alt_text: Transition credits are being piloted in two coal plants in the Philippines. One of these plants is the South Luzon Thermal Energy Corporation’s plant in Batangas, which is owned by Acen, the energy arm of Philippine Stock Exchange-listed Ayala Group.

site_title: Israel plans new airport in south, an hour from Gaza border
summary: Israel's Economic Affairs Committee has approved a plan to build a new international airport in Nevatim, about an hour from the Gaza border. The airport, which will take seven years to build, aims to alleviate traffic at Tel Aviv's Ben Gurion Airport and create around 50,000 jobs. However, the military and security establishment have opposed the project due to its proximity to a military airbase. The airport is expected to handle up to 15 million passengers annually, helping to bolster the economy in Israel's south.

site_title: Aussie dollar to snap losing streak on RBA stance, China support
summary: The Australian dollar is poised for its first annual gain since 2020, driven by the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) reluctance to ease interest rates and China's pledge to counter US levies with domestic spending. Market forecasts predict the Aussie will rise to 68 US cents by December, a 8.4% gain from Friday's close, and 65 US cents by the end of June. The currency's appeal is also boosted by US President Donald Trump's aggressive trade policy, which is expected to weaken the US dollar and hurt US economic growth.

images.alt_text: The Aussie rose 0.3 per cent to hit a one-week high of US$0.6354, having surged 1 per cent overnight.
The Aussie was flat at US$0.6272, having risen from a one-week low of US$0.6230 overnight to end the day 0.1 per cent higher.
The Aussie slid 1.9 per cent to US$0.6091 on Monday morning, breaking the January trough of US$0.6129.

site_title: Salvaging Qantas just the start as new CEO pledges more to come
summary: Qantas CEO Vanessa Hudson has pulled off an improbable victory, winning over disgruntled flyers, reporting super-sized profits, and delivering knock-out returns for investors. Hudson, the first woman to run Qantas, has turned industry male leadership tropes on their heads with her servant leadership approach. The airline expects to receive 18 new aircraft in 2025 and 21 in the following 12 months, with a further 100 new planes ordered by the end of the decade. Hudson's focus on passenger satisfaction and investment in the fleet has led to a 70% increase in Qantas's stock over the past 12 months.

site_title: China must fix fentanyl flow before US trade talks, senator says
summary: US Senator Steve Daines says China must take action to stop the flow of fentanyl precursors to the US before trade talks can proceed. Daines met with Chinese officials, including Premier Li Qiang, and stated that Beijing understands the US's request to stop the flow of these precursors. The US has imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, citing the fentanyl trade, but China claims the US has not outlined detailed steps to remedy its role. A high-level meeting between US President Donald Trump and Chinese leader Xi Jinping is expected before the end of the year, pending decisive actions from China.

site_title: Cost of living a global issue, so Singaporeans get extra help in Budget: PM Wong to Aljunied seniors
summary: Prime Minister Lawrence Wong announced additional measures in the 2025 Budget to help Singaporeans with cost-of-living pressures, a global issue. Senior couples above 60 will receive a total of S$2,400 in CDC and SG60 vouchers, while each household will get S$800 in CDC vouchers. Wong emphasized the need for collaboration to overcome challenges and work towards a better future. He also encouraged seniors to join digital clubs to improve their digital skills.

images.alt_text: Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong (left) was accompanied by East Coast GRC's anchor minister Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat during his first public walkabout in the constituency.

site_title: Re-election pledges to tip Australian budget back into red
summary: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers is set to deliver a budget with a deficit of around A$20 billion, reversing two years of surpluses. The budget will focus on cost of living measures, including extended electricity rebates and a shared equity scheme to help first home buyers. Analysts predict the deficit will be smaller than the initial A$26.9 billion projection, with Australia's debt-to-GDP ratio remaining relatively low. The budget comes ahead of the country's re-election, with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese seeking to boost household relief and address global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Jim Chalmers will unveil new cost-of-living assistance for Australians in the budget on Tuesday night.
The Australian government says it will expand income and price caps for its “Help to Buy” scheme to enable property purchases with lower deposits and smaller mortgages.

site_title: AI startup Perplexity confirms interest to buy TikTok
summary: US law orders TikTok to divest from Chinese owner ByteDance or be banned in the US. AI startup Perplexity has expressed interest in buying TikTok, citing its AI-powered search capabilities. Others in the running include Microsoft, Oracle, and a group led by MrBeast. Perplexity's acquisition would integrate its search engine with TikTok's video library, aiming to create the world's best search experience.

images.alt_text: The fate of the short video app used by nearly half of all Americans has been up in the air since a law took effect on Jan 19 requiring ByteDance to either sell it or face a ban on national security grounds.
The US is one of TikTok’s most important markets – it operates a sister service, Douyin, at home in China – and TikTok US was estimated last year to be worth as much as US$50 billion.
Vance did not provide any details on the participants in negotiations to purchase the app.
TikTok Live is one of the app’s most popular features, and has become even more central to the platform since the launch of TikTok Shop in late 2023.

site_title: Diverging US economic data begs the question: Is a slowdown coming?
summary: The US economy is experiencing diverging data, with "soft" surveys of household and business sentiment warning of a slowdown due to President Trump's trade policies, while "hard" data from government statistics suggests a more moderate cooling. Surveys show concerns over tariffs and price increases, but the Federal Reserve and OECD indicate the economy is still solid. Fed Chair Jerome Powell downplayed worries over inflation expectations, citing the lack of tight correlation between soft and hard data. Economists warn of a potential recession or stagflation, but the Trump administration's efforts to ease concerns have been slow.

images.alt_text: Many on Wall Street had gone into 2025 forecasting a stronger US dollar – at least in the first half of the year – thanks to the outlook for Trump’s policies and expectations for a limited number of Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts.

site_title: The steel squeeze: Asean at risk of becoming world’s steel dumping ground
summary: The US has imposed 25% tariffs on Chinese steel exports, diverting excess supply to Southeast Asia, potentially flooding the region with surplus steel. This could lead to a steel glut, triggering a price war and threatening local industries. Southeast Asian countries, including Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, and Singapore, are bracing for the impact, with some calling for protectionist measures to shield their domestic industries. China's steel production is expected to remain high, and the region's steel industry faces long-term challenges, with utilization rates below the global average and demand still struggling to recover from the pandemic.

images.alt_text: The US President Donald Trump ordered 25 per cent tariffs on aluminum and steel imports entering the United States, starting March 4.
Washington has already imposed anti-dumping duties on multiple Vietnamese steel exports and producers, in some cases even higher than 25 per cent
US President Donald Trump said on Thursday (Feb 27) in a social media post that drugs from the country’s North American neighbours are still entering “at very high and unacceptable levels.”
While the policies did boost Indonesia’s export earnings and created thousands of jobs, the surge in processing capacity has far outpaced demand for nickel.

Steelworks at South Korea's largest steelmaker POSCO in Pohang, South Korea, Feb 13, 2025. South Korea's industry minister Ahn Duk Geun travelled to Washington, D.C. earlier this week to push for an exemption from US steel tariffs and discuss ways to cooperate in energy and shipbuilding.

site_title: Cheap steel may flood Asean, threaten Malaysian producers: industry players
summary: Malaysia's downstream steel manufacturers, such as pipe and wire producers, face significant risk from cheap steel imports due to the US's expansion of tariff net. The new blanket tariff removes exemptions for key exporters, escalating trade tensions. Industry players call for measures to safeguard local producers, who have been operating under US tariffs since 2018. The move could lead to a surge in cheap steel imports, threatening Malaysian producers' competitiveness in the market.

images.alt_text: The US President Donald Trump ordered 25 per cent tariffs on aluminum and steel imports entering the United States, starting March 4.
The ministry’s decision followed an investigation into the products from China, India, Japan and South Korea.
From January to November, Malaysia’s trade grew by 8.7 per cent to RM2.6 trillion..

site_title: GE2025: Talks held to integrate plans for Joo Chiat, East Coast, says Edwin Tong
summary: Minister for Culture, Community and Youth Edwin Tong has held talks with East Coast GRC MPs to integrate plans for Joo Chiat, which was carved out of Marine Parade GRC. Tong aims to minimize disruption to residents while ensuring promised programs continue. He emphasized the importance of understanding residents' needs and has started meeting volunteers in other East Coast divisions. Deputy Prime Minister Heng Swee Keat, anchor minister for East Coast GRC, expressed support for Tong's involvement and plans for joint visits between their wards.

images.alt_text: SDP chief Chee Soon Juan addressing reporters in Sembawang West. In February, he announced his intention to run in Bukit Batok SMC, which has since been absorbed into the new Jurong East-Bukit Batok GRC.

site_title: SCWO raises S$450,000 for key programmes helping women, children in need
summary: The Singapore Council of Women's Organisations (SCWO) has raised S$450,000 for its core programmes, including Star Shelter and Maintenance Support Central, during its 45th anniversary celebration. These programmes provide aid to women and children experiencing domestic violence or financial insecurity. SCWO's chief executive, Koh Yan Ping, stated that the funds will help expand outreach, enhance advocacy efforts, and support member organisations, addressing evolving challenges faced by the community.

images.alt_text: The inductees for its 10th edition come from all sorts of fields and industries.
St Lukes ElderCare, which participated in Great Singapore Give, says the campaign helped it reach a wider audience.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: APAC real estate masterclass for profitable investments
summary: In a recent episode of "BT Money Hacks," host Howie Lim discussed real estate investment in the APAC region with Greg Hyland, head of capital markets APAC at CBRE. The conversation covered key trends, including the 'hotelification' of office spaces, growing importance of ESG compliance, and the resurgence of retail spaces. Hyland emphasized the importance of diversification, including asset and country diversification, and highlighted the long-term potential of ESG-compliant assets. The episode also stressed that real estate is best viewed as a long-term investment, with assets generally performing well over a 5-10 year period.

images.alt_text: What to do when geopolitical events affect your investments?
How to get financially prepared for retrenchment.
Can you manage your finances yourself or is help really needed?

site_title: Stumbling stock market raises spectre of dot-com era reckoning
summary: A stock market rally fueled by artificial intelligence (AI) is raising concerns of a potential bubble, echoing the dot-com era of 25 years ago. The Nasdaq 100 has lost over 10% and the S&P 500 briefly dropped to a correction level, sparking memories of the 2000 dot-com bubble. Unlike the Internet era, the AI boom is centered around profitable and stable tech companies, but their valuations are being questioned due to their high burn rates and lack of traditional metrics. Experts warn that investors may be experiencing greed and overvaluation, similar to the dot-com era, and that the true winners from AI may not be revealed right away.

images.alt_text: The upgraded T1 model offers faster response times and enhanced capabilities for processing extended text documents, says Tencent in a post on its official WeChat account.
Perplexity offers several services in addition to the paid and free versions of its search tool.
The AI management shift has been months in the making and predates Apple announcing the Siri delays.

site_title: Australia treasurer warns of ‘seismic’ US global economic shock
summary: Australia's Treasurer Jim Chalmers warns of a "seismic" impact of the new US administration's policies on the global economy, casting a shadow over the upcoming budget. The budget will include new cost-of-living assistance, including extended subsidies on electricity bills, and is expected to boost revenue slightly. Despite global economic chaos, Australia's economy is "turning a corner" with inflation down, real wages up, and unemployment low, according to Chalmers. The country is set to hold elections by May 17, with Prime Minister Anthony Albanese's centre-left Labor government neck-and-neck with the opposition in opinion polling.

images.alt_text: Jim Chalmers, Australia's treasurer, speaks during an interview at Parliament House in Canberra, Australia, on Sunday, May 12, 2024. The treasurer will release the budget on Tuesday night, when he is aiming to strike a balance between containing stubbornly high inflation in the near term and investing in Australia’s economic future over the years ahead. Photographer: Hilary Wardhaugh/Bloomberg

site_title: BYD earnings may move the needle in market-cap fight with CATL
summary: BYD's earnings may impact its market value as it fights for stock-market dominance with CATL. BYD's market value briefly surpassed CATL's but retreated on Friday, giving CATL back its lead. BYD trades at 20 times earnings, below its three-year average, while CATL trades at 83 times earnings, similar to Tesla. BYD's earnings may determine its position as China's most valuable non-state onshore stock, with a 7% stock slump highlighting the vulnerability of its shares to regulatory and geopolitical risks.

site_title: China says it’s prepared for shocks as US tariffs loom
summary: Chinese Premier Li Qiang stated that his country is prepared for potential economic shocks, including US tariffs, which are set to be announced next month. Li emphasized the importance of opening up markets and sharing resources among countries to mitigate instability and uncertainty. The US-China trade tensions have led to a decline in foreign investment in China, but officials are trying to attract businesses through initiatives such as the China Development Forum. China aims to achieve an economic growth rate of 5% in 2025, but economists warn that a trade war with the US could require substantial stimulus to meet this target.

images.alt_text: Climate change, ageing populations and trade are among the topics expected to be discussed, as well as working together on disaster relief and science and technology.

site_title: Data centres a possibility for Stoneweg European Reit under new sponsor
summary: Stoneweg European Reit, a Singapore-listed real estate investment trust, is exploring opportunities in the data centre sector with the help of its new sponsor, SWI Group. SWI Group, a partnership between Stoneweg and Icona Capital, has expertise in data centres and wishes to support Sert's strategy to rebalance its portfolio. Sert plans to invest in data centre development, with a substantial pipeline of development opportunities in data centres in Switzerland and Spain. The Reit's logistics and office portfolios are expected to benefit from improving valuations and rents.

images.alt_text: A logistics complex in Tilburg, the Netherlands, that is part of Stoneweg E-Reit's portfolio. The increase in the Reit's second-half portfolio value comes from its logistics and light industrial assets.

site_title: Tourist spending soars with packed Mice calendar but malls see mixed impact
summary: Tourism in Singapore reached an all-time high in 2024, with $22.4 billion in receipts in the first nine months, driven by a packed Mice calendar and exclusive sell-out concerts. However, the impact on tourist footfall in malls varied, with concerts contributing to higher foot traffic in nearby malls, but other Mice events not having a similar impact. Notably, tourist foot traffic in malls near event venues like Orchard remained unchanged.

images.alt_text: Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.
Lady Gaga Mayhem Tour shows could boost SIA Q1 earnings
Lady Gaga receiving the Innovator Award during the iHeartRadio Music Awards at Dolby Theatre in Los Angeles, California,  on March 17.  Singapore is the only Asian stop on her tour.
Lady Gaga performing at the Singapore Indoor Stadium in 2012. Her upcoming May concerts in Singapore will be her only Asia stop on her Mayhem tour.

Singapore’s 2025 tourism receipts to exceed pre-Covid levels, but arrivals still playing catch up

site_title: Ukraine says talks with US on war with Russia ‘productive’
summary: US and Ukrainian officials have concluded "productive and focused" talks in Saudi Arabia on de-escalating the Russia-Ukraine war, despite differing proposals for temporary ceasefires. The talks, led by US President Donald Trump, aim to pave the way for a breakthrough, but the Kremlin has warned of "difficult negotiations" ahead. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky urged allies to pressure Russia to end strikes, while Russian President Vladimir Putin proposed a halt in attacks only on energy facilities. Discussions between the US and Russia are set for Monday, with the goal of a possible resumption of the 2022 Black Sea grain deal.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump hailed the call as “good and productive” and insisted he had an “understanding” with Russian President Vladimir Putin to quickly work towards a complete ceasefire and a wider settlement to the three-year-old war.
US President Donald Trump speaks to reporters aboard Air Force One while flying to Washington, DC, from Florida, on March 16, 2025, above Virginia. (Photo by Brendan Smialowski / AFP)

site_title: Tencent launches T1 reasoning model amid growing AI competition in China
summary: Tencent has launched its T1 reasoning model, offering faster response times and enhanced capabilities for processing extended text documents. The upgraded model outperforms DeepSeek's R1 model in some knowledge and reasoning benchmarks, fueling competition in China's AI sector. Tencent's AI investments have increased, with the company announcing plans to boost capital expenditure in 2025, amid heightened rivalry in the AI landscape. The launch follows DeepSeek's introduction of comparable or superior performance at lower costs, marking a significant escalation in the AI competition in China.

images.alt_text: Tencent gained roughly 30 per cent or US$140 billion in market valuation so far this year, helped by a broader Chinese tech rally induced by the rise of DeepSeek.
Tencent’s five new 3D-content generators are built atop its Hunyuan3D-2.0 model, all of which it intends to open-source to users.
The pace of China’s open-source AI push has been relentless since the debut in January of DeepSeek R1.

site_title: Airlines, including SIA, resume most flights between Singapore and Heathrow after airport reopens
summary: Most flights between Singapore and London's Heathrow Airport resumed on March 22 after a significant power outage at the airport. Three out of four Singapore Airlines (SIA) flights scheduled to depart from Changi Airport on March 22 proceeded as planned, including SQ308 and SQ318. Two SIA flights to Singapore were cancelled, while two others departed as scheduled. British Airways (BA) and Qantas also operated flights as scheduled, with BA expecting around 85% of flights to operate normally. The power outage has prompted questions about the airport's critical infrastructure.

images.alt_text: Woldbye will step down as CEO of Copenhagen Airports by Sept 30 after 12 years in the role.

site_title: Thailand drafts law to speed up 1t baht transport link
summary: Thailand's government has proposed a multibillion-dollar transport project, the Landbridge, to link two seaports on the southern peninsula with a new highway and rail line. The project, costing around 1 trillion baht, aims to cut shipping times between the Indian and Pacific oceans. A special commission, chaired by Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra, will oversee development of the Southern Economic Corridor and find funding for the project, with completion targeted by 2030. Foreign investors will be allowed to own more than 50% of joint ventures to build infrastructure.

images.alt_text: A Thai national flag flies on a building as stacks of containers sit at the Port of Bangkok with the skyline of the city standing in the background, Thailand, on Monday, June 25, 2014. ThailandÕs trade figures are scheduled for release on Aug. 27. Photographer: Dario Pignatelli/Bloomberg

site_title: Traders bet on weaker US dollar for 1st time since Trump’s election win
summary: US traders have turned bearish on the dollar for the first time since Donald Trump's election, with $932 million in bets against a weaker dollar. This marks a sharp reversal from mid-January, when traders held $34 billion in wagers on a stronger dollar. The shift is attributed to uncertainty surrounding Trump's policies, which have led to a contractionary impact on the economy and monetary policy. This reversal challenges earlier forecasts of a stronger US dollar in the first half of 2025.

images.alt_text: The committee of the People’s Bank of China (PBOC) suggested stepping up monetary policy adjustment and control, and improving monetary policy to be more forward-looking, targeted and effective.

site_title: Indonesia needs stronger trade protections as China steel glut looms, says industry chief
summary: Indonesia is vulnerable to trade diversion risks due to its heavy reliance on steel imports from China, particularly automotive steel plates. US tariff hikes could lead to an influx of cheaper Chinese steel, overwhelming local producers amid Indonesia's growing automotive sector. The country's weak trade protections make it an attractive target for Chinese steel exports, with Asean countries being the primary target for export diversion expansion.

images.alt_text: Containers at a terminal in Tanjung Priok Port, Jakarta's main seaport, which handles large vessels and high cargo volumes, Jakarta, Indonesia, Jan 24, 2025.
Among Indonesia’s top commodities that are exported, palm oil shipments managed a modest growth of just 2.2%.

site_title: US tariffs deepen Thailand’s steel struggles amid rising imports and costs, say analysts
summary: Thailand's steel industry faces further disruption due to increased US tariffs and cheap steel imports, intensifying competition in the market. The industry's low capacity utilisation and escalating production costs pose significant challenges, with smaller operators at risk of shutting down. While demand for long steel is expected to recover in the construction sector, flat steel production is expected to expand at a slower pace. The government is urged to set anti-dumping policies to protect the local industry, which is less competitive compared to larger economies like China.

images.alt_text: India joins countries from Saudi Arabia to Vietnam and Chile in wielding trade measures to limit cheaper inflows, fuelled by a surge of steel coming from China. C

A key US security ally in the Indo-Pacific, Australia is a small global exporter of steel although it is the world’s largest exporter of the main steelmaking raw material iron ore.
The back-and-forth squabble between the US and Canada has further unsettled financial markets already battered by Donald Trump‘s focus on tariffs.

site_title: Existing ByteDance investors emerge as front-runners in TikTok deal talks
summary: US investors, including Susquehanna International Group and General Atlantic, are leading talks with the White House to acquire TikTok's US operations, potentially rescuing the app from a looming ban. The plan involves spinning off a US entity, diluting Chinese ownership, and ensuring US data is stored on Oracle's cloud servers. Existing investors, including Oracle, are also participating in the discussions, which aim to address concerns over national security and the app's ties to China.

images.alt_text: The US is one of TikTok’s most important markets – it operates a sister service, Douyin, at home in China – and TikTok US was estimated last year to be worth as much as US$50 billion.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market experienced a week of gradual strengthening, with positive momentum building. The Capesize Timecharter Average (C5TC) declined by $1,507 week on week, settling at $22,190. In the North Atlantic, a few INL breaching fronthaul cargoes with mid-April loading were fixed, reflecting $42,313 on the C9 route. In Brazil, rates started to improve since mid-week after more cargoes entered the market with second-half April dates. The Panamax market saw minimal visible activity, while the Ultramax/Supramax sector experienced slightly positive gains.

A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Mar 7, 2025).

site_title: Temasek-backed 65 Equity Partners sees global firms as possible source for IPO pipeline
summary: Singapore is emerging as an attractive listing destination for global firms, with Temasek-backed investment firm 65 Equity Partners playing a key role in this effort. The firm's Anchor Fund @ 65 has a mandate to scout for good-quality companies suitable for listing on the Singapore Exchange, and has already secured commitments from five portfolio companies to pursue listings. The firm hopes that as market conditions stabilize, interest rates decline, and investor appetite for stocks revives, more global firms will consider listing in Singapore, driven by the MAS's recent initiatives to create a more attractive environment.

images.alt_text: From left: Adrienne Teh, managing director; Francis Woo, chief corporate officer and managing director (Singapore); chief executive Tan Chong Lee; and investment principal Timothy Wee.

site_title: UK finance minister to stick to fiscal rules despite global turmoil
summary: UK finance minister Rachel Reeves plans to stick to fiscal rules despite global economic turmoil, raising the prospect of spending cuts to meet financial targets. Reeves aims to balance day-to-day spending with tax revenue by the end of the decade. To achieve this, she may cut 10,000 civil service jobs and save £2 billion annually. Reeves also expressed willingness to negotiate with the US over tariffs, but vowed to maintain the principle of taxing companies in the country where they operate. The UK seeks to avoid the impact of potential US import tariffs.

images.alt_text: A handout picture released by the BBC, taken and received on March 23, 2025, Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves appearing on the BBC's "Sunday with Laura Kuenssberg" political television show in London. The funds are targeted at training up to 60,000 more skilled construction workers to address labour shortages and help build 1.5 million homes, according to a statement on Saturday.

site_title: Wall Street investors with diversified bets are winning at last
summary: Wall Street investors with diversified portfolios are celebrating as years of stock gains have pushed American households' holdings in the asset class to a record high, relative to their overall financial exposures. The ongoing market disruption, including the tariff war, has led to epic rotations out of American equities, with the Treasury index climbing 3% this year and other assets such as gold and corporate debt performing well. This represents a long-awaited reversion to normalcy for diversification strategies, which have been crushed by the US stock advance since the financial crisis.

site_title: Nvidia investors look to CEO keynote to keep rebound going
summary: Nvidia investors are hoping CEO Jensen Huang's keynote speech will boost the stock's recent rebound, addressing concerns that the chipmaker's sales boom may be peaking. Despite a recent 9% year-to-date decline, Nvidia's position at the forefront of AI chips and billions of anticipated spending this year could mean recent weakness is just a phase. Analysts expect revenue to grow 57% and earnings per share to increase 52% for fiscal year 2026, offering a positive outlook for the company's shares.

images.alt_text: Huang has been working to allay investor concerns over demand for Nvidia’s expensive AI chips

site_title: S-Reits surge as banks decline; see beginnings of a rebound
summary: Singapore real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) have rebounded strongly, with the iEdge S-Reit Index gaining 5% over the past two weeks. Despite global market downturns and declining bank stocks, S-Reits have maintained an average distribution yield of 7.6%, outperforming the broader market. The sector has seen net institutional inflows of S$42 million, with the top gainers being Frasers Hospitality Trust and Frasers Centrepoint Trust. Analysts attribute the rebound to lower interest rates and favorable valuations, with the sector's average distribution yield and price-to-book ratio below historical averages.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust is the largest S-Reit in Singapore, and it holds a diversified exposure including office and retail assets.

site_title: Heathrow flights resume after closure causes global flight turmoil
summary: Heathrow Airport in London resumed flights on Friday after a fire knocked out its power supply, causing a global flight disruption. The fire forced the airport to close entirely on Thursday, stranding tens of thousands of passengers. Limited flights operated on Friday, focusing on relocating aircraft and bringing planes into London. Heathrow chief executive Thomas Woldbye apologized to affected travelers, stating the airport would be back to normal operation by Saturday. The incident has raised concerns about the airport's infrastructure and potential financial impact on airlines.

images.alt_text: Six of the 11 flights were cancelled, leaving thousands of passengers’ plans in disarray.
Around 70 firefighters had been tackling the blaze in the west of London, which caused a mass power outage at Heathrow Airport.

site_title: Melting glaciers: the tip of the iceberg in the global water crisis
summary: Glacier melt is accelerating at an unprecedented rate, with the world's glaciers losing mass at a rate 50% faster than in the past decade. If this trend continues, at least half of the world's glaciers will be completely lost by 2100, exacerbating global water stress and leading to devastating floods, typhoons, and droughts. A coordinated international effort is needed to address the interconnected issues of climate change and global water security, recognizing the critical role of glaciers in shaping the Earth's water cycle and supply.

images.alt_text: epa11379399 An Indian kid drinks water from a handpump on a hot day in New Delhi, India, 30 May 2024. The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued a heat red alert for Delhi, Rajasthan, Haryana, Punjab, and Madhya Pradesh. The IMD Director General M Mohapatra said they are checking the temperature sensor in Delhi's Mungeshpur automatic weather station to see if it is working properly, as there were temperatures of over 50 degrees Celsius recorded on 29 May.  EPA-EFE/RAJAT GUPTA
Climate action has to include managing water
Himalayan glaciers melting far faster this century: study
A study of 18,600 glaciers at 50 World Heritage sites – covering around 66,000 sq km– found that glaciers at a third of the sites were “condemned to disappear”.
The first-of-its-kind study raises new concern about how fast climate change is weakening Antarctica's floating ice shelves and accelerating the rise of global sea levels.

site_title: High costs limit plastic recycling in South-east Asia: Bain
summary: Plastic recycling in South-east Asia is hindered by high collection and sorting costs, with major markets capturing only 8-25% of plastic waste for recycling. The region's fragmented value chain and varying fortunes in plastic recycling pose significant challenges. Bain & Company calls for incentives, innovation, and education to improve the economics of recycling, citing potential solutions such as reverse recycling machines, subsidies for businesses, and technological advancements. The consultancy expects demand for recycled plastics to double-digit growth through 2030, but tighter international regulation on plastic waste imports could impact domestic capabilities.

images.alt_text: Capitol Optical keeps an eye on recycling

site_title: Australia government to expand scheme to help first-time property buyers as election looms
summary: The Australian government has announced plans to expand its "Help to Buy" scheme, aiming to enable more first-time homebuyers to purchase properties with lower deposits and smaller mortgages. The scheme's income and price caps will be increased, allowing over five million properties to fall under the new caps. The government also plans to invest A$54 million in advanced manufacturing of prefabricated and modular homes. The move comes ahead of the expected general election in May, with housing affordability a key issue. The scheme is expected to help build 1.2 million homes by 2030.

images.alt_text: In 2019, Mapletreee closed its Mapletree Australia Commercial Private Trust (Mascot) private fund, which raised A$654 million in equity.

site_title: Oil prices rise for second consecutive week on expected tighter supply
summary: Oil prices rose for the second consecutive week, with US West Texas Intermediate crude futures up 0.3% to $68.28 a barrel and Brent crude futures up 0.2% to $72.16 a barrel. The increases were driven by fresh US sanctions on Iran and the latest Opec+ output plan, which raised expectations of tighter supply. Analysts expect a 1 million barrels per day reduction in Iranian crude oil exports due to the sanctions, and a one million barrel per day reduction in overall global supply.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up US$1.22, or 1.72 per cent, at US$72 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: AstraZeneca invests US$2.5 billion in Beijing, undeterred by probe
summary: AstraZeneca invests $2.5 billion in a new research centre in Beijing, despite Chinese authorities investigating the company over alleged law breaches. The hub, which includes an artificial intelligence lab, will focus on early-stage research and is AstraZeneca's second in China. The investment reflects the company's commitment to the country's life sciences ecosystem, as CEO Pascal Soriot urged Beijing's Mayor to expand AstraZeneca's research and development in the capital.

images.alt_text: The transaction is expected to close in the second quarter of 2025, and does not impact AstraZeneca’s financial guidance for 2025

site_title: US: Stocks shrug off economic jitters to close higher
summary: US stocks closed higher on Friday, March 21, despite economic uncertainty, following US President Donald Trump's comments on tariff plans that included flexibility. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 rose 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite Index jumped 0.5%. However, FedEx's 6.5% decline and Nike's 5.5% drop were notable exceptions, attributed to lowered forecasts and revenue declines. Despite the volatility, markets reacted positively to Trump's comments, but analysts remain cautious about the ongoing trade uncertainties.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down less than 0.1 per cent at 41,953.32 on Thursday.

site_title: Stem cell treatment helped improve spinal cord injuries: Japan scientists
summary: Scientists at Tokyo's Keio University conducted the first clinical study using induced pluripotent stem cells, which improved motor function in two out of four patients with spinal cord injuries. The treatment aims to address the issue affecting over 150,000 patients in Japan, with 5,000 new cases annually. Researchers used the stem cells to stimulate healing in the damaged spinal cord areas, showing promising results for potential treatment of paralysis caused by serious spinal cord injuries.

images.alt_text: Yakin Medic’s plans come on the heels of several measures unveiled by the Monetary Authority of Singapore’s review group to revive the local bourse.

site_title: Gold smashes records but price easing expected in near term: market watchers
summary: Gold prices broke record highs of US$3,034.74 per ounce, fueled by heightened market uncertainties driven by escalating Middle East tensions and US President Trump's trade policies. The rally was a 37.3% increase from a year ago and a 22.2% rise year to date. However, market watchers expect prices to consolidate in the near term, following the easing to around US$3,030 per ounce.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Friday.

Elsewhere in Asia-Pacific, bigger players in major gold producing countries such as Australia, China and Indonesia – especially those with competent cash flow and cost management – have also been riding on the gold price surge.

site_title: Starhill Global Reit obtains S$600 million sustainability-linked loan for refinancing
summary: Starhill Global Reit has secured a S$600 million sustainability-linked loan for refinancing. The 5-year facility agreement includes S$300 million in term facilities and S$300 million in revolving credit facilities. The move is part of the Reit's proactive capital management strategy, with the refinancing expected to replace maturing debt and provide working capital. The transaction is not expected to impact the Reit's gearing, and units rose S$0.005, or 1%, to close at S$0.505 on the day of the announcement.

images.alt_text: Gross revenue was up 1.7 per cent to S$96.3 million for the half-year period, from S$94.6 million in the year-ago period.
Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust said in its Q3 results that VivoCity maintained a strong performance – despite an ongoing asset enhancement initiative – cushioning overseas headwinds.

site_title: Singapore Design Awards 2025 recognises projects helping youths in need
summary: The Singapore Design Awards 2025 recognized "Roots & Wings," a design project that pairs youth with seniors for a photography project, helping them explore the theme of "change" through a low-cost, accessible medium. The project aims to build confidence, resilience, and self-belief in the youth, while offering new coping perspectives and encouragement from the seniors. The winner received an additional $20,000 in funding to scale its prototype and further trial it with users, with the goal of fostering more interactions among the youth and seniors to discuss challenges and promote mental health.

images.alt_text: During the event facilitated by HSBC and Trybe, Singapore and US golfers Shannon Tan and Lauren Coughlin (top row, third and fifth from left, respectively) met with seven youths and talked about overcoming challenges.

site_title: Trump brand alternately loved, loathed worldwide
summary: US President Donald Trump's brand has experienced mixed success worldwide, with some successes in India and setbacks in Indonesia, Ireland, and Scotland. The Trump Turnberry golf resort in Scotland was vandalized with pro-Palestinian graffiti in response to Trump's proposal to take over the Gaza Strip. Trump's business ventures have also faced environmental violations, with a billion-dollar project in Indonesia halted in February. The Trump brand's global reputation remains polarized, with some countries embracing his business while others have criticized his policies.

images.alt_text: Sergio Garcia (fifth from left) with young golfers from Tanah Merah Country Club. With them is Patricia Quek, head of UBS Wealth Management Singapore (far left).

site_title: Beyond misconceptions: Why Asia-Pacific investment grade is a hidden gem
summary: Apac investment-grade (IG) credit has evolved into a robust asset class, anchored by the US$2 trillion Asia dollar bond market with 90% rated IG. Despite common misconceptions, Apac IG credit has demonstrated strong resilience, with zero direct defaults since the Global Financial Crisis. The region's asynchronous economic cycles provide natural portfolio hedging benefits. Apac IG offers attractive risk-adjusted returns, lower beta, and higher Sharpe ratios, making it an opportunity too big to ignore. Key themes include Chinese TMT, Australian banks, Japanese financials, and quasi-sovereign bonds, with potential for relative value and diversification benefits.
