Apollo manages about US$275 billion of investment-grade credit and its high-grade capital solutions business.

site_title: Japan, China, South Korea foreign ministers meet in Tokyo
summary: Japan, China, and South Korea's foreign ministers met in Tokyo, discussing topics such as climate change, ageing populations, and trade, as well as cooperation on disaster relief and science and technology. The meeting aims to strengthen economic ties and counter US trade tariffs looming over the region. The countries agreed to work together to overcome historical and territorial disputes, with a focus on pragmatic diplomacy and a potential trilateral leaders' summit by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: The USTR's proposed levy would effectively stop all of China's state-owned Cosco container ships from calling at US ports.
The world’s second-largest economy achieved 5 per cent growth in 2024.

site_title: Hamilton dominates Chinese GP sprint for first Ferrari win
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Chinese GP sprint for Ferrari, his first victory with the team. Starting from pole position, Hamilton took the chequered flag ahead of Oscar Piastri and Max Verstappen. This marks his maiden Ferrari win, on his second race weekend with the team.

images.alt_text: Ferrari's British driver Lewis Hamilton (C) celebrates after winning the sprint race while McLaren's Australian driver Oscar Piastri (background) leaves his car after coming in second in the sprint race of the Formula One Chinese Grand Prix at the Shanghai International Circuit in Shanghai on March 22, 2025. (Photo by Jade Gao / AFP)

site_title: Rescuing America’s economy from Trump
summary: US President Donald Trump's economic policies are at risk of destabilizing the global economy, potentially leading to a post-Brexit Britain scenario. Trump's approach, dubbed the "Mar-a-Lago Accord," aims to weaken the dollar in exchange for tariff relief and military protection. However, his aggressive behavior towards Mexico and Canada has made it unlikely that other countries will cooperate. Experts warn that the US may face similar economic consequences, and the only solution is to remove the problem – in this case, Trump from office.

site_title: Gold’s breakout moment: Opportunity or overvaluation?
summary: Gold prices recently hit an all-time high of above US$3,000 per ounce, driven by geopolitical and economic risks, including the ongoing Russia-Ukraine war and trade tensions. Central banks, particularly the People's Bank of China, have also been buying gold, supporting prices. However, high prices may lead to weakening physical demand for gold, and some analysts question whether gold is now overvalued. Despite this, gold's role as a safe-haven asset is seen as unique, and its prices are expected to remain supported for now.

site_title: Majority of Chocolate Finance withdrawal requests fulfilled, says fund manager
summary: Chocolate Finance has fulfilled the majority of withdrawal requests, with all customers receiving 100% of their capital and earned returns. The firm, which halted instant withdrawals in March due to high demand, will continue to process requests within three to six business days. Instant withdrawals remain suspended, with no specific timeline for their resumption. The Monetary Authority of Singapore is monitoring the situation to ensure orderly withdrawals.

images.alt_text: Entrepreneur Walter de Oude believes every Singaporean has spare cash earning next to nothing. Chocolate Finance steps in as a liquid alternative with higher yields.
Chocolate Finance's competitors say that there was no spike in withdrawals or enqueries following the suspension of instant withdrawals.

site_title: UK plans £600 million to train more skilled construction workers
summary: The UK government plans to invest £600 million over four years to train up to 60,000 skilled construction workers, addressing labour shortages and helping build 1.5 million homes. The funding includes £100 million for Technical Excellence Colleges and £165 million for construction courses. New foundation apprenticeships will be introduced in August. The move aims to boost infrastructure and stimulate the economy, with the construction sector facing significant shortages. The plan is part of the government's skills agenda, which also includes billions of pounds of spending cuts announced by Chancellor Rachel Reeves.

site_title: GE2025: SDP chief Chee Soon Juan to contest new Sembawang West SMC as party embarks on ‘Northern strategy’
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) chief Chee Soon Juan has announced his bid to contest the newly created Sembawang West Single Member Constituency (SMC) in the upcoming general election (GE2025). SDP chairman Paul Tambyah will also contest Bukit Panjang SMC for the second time. The party is embarking on a "Northern strategy" and returning to old stomping grounds. SDP will announce its candidates for Sembawang GRC "in due course" and contest other constituencies in the next two weeks.

images.alt_text: The newly elected members of the Progress Singapore Party's central executive committee: (front row, from left) Wendy Low, Leong Mun Wai, Tan Cheng Bock, Hazel Poa and A'bas Kasmani; (back row, from left) S Nallakaruppan, Jonathan Tee, Joseph Wong, Phang Yew Huat, Soh Zheng Long, Anthony Neo and Samuel Lim.
Singapore election 2025: The Electoral Boundaries Review Committee recommended 33 electoral divisions: 15 SMCs, up from 14 previously; and 18 four- and five-member GRCs, up from 17.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, March 21, 2025
summary: Asian stocks fell on Friday, March 21, 2025, due to deepening geopolitical worries and fears over US tariffs. Investors curbed their appetite for risk, leading to a downbeat end to the week. Safe-haven gold remained near record highs, while some central banks kept interest rates steady amidst global uncertainties.

images.alt_text: In early trade, shares in Hong Kong, Shanghai, Singapore, Taipei and Manila were in negative territory, while Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul and Wellington edged up.
The ECB cut rates earlier this month, but traders have pared bets on more action and are now almost equally torn between a cut and a pause at the Apr 16 to 17 gathering.
Non-yielding gold is historically considered a hedge against geopolitical and economic uncertainties, and thrives in a low interest rate environment.

site_title: Beijing simplifies marriages to encourage Chinese to wed
summary: China has simplified the marriage registration process to encourage couples to tie the knot and have children. The new measure allows people to register their marriage where they live, rather than traveling to their hometown, reducing travel and financial burdens. This is part of a series of initiatives to tackle the decline in births, including cash incentives and childcare infrastructure investments. The move aims to address the needs of younger generations and combat social stigma surrounding unmarried couples.

images.alt_text: Lamborghini hits record sales in India, led by the Urus SUV, which made up half of its sales.

site_title: London exhibit spotlights Victor Hugo’s lesser-known talent – drawing
summary: A new exhibition at the Royal Academy of Arts in London showcases the lesser-known talent of French author Victor Hugo as an illustrator. The "Astonishing Things: The Drawings of Victor Hugo" exhibition features around 70 drawings, including ink washes, graphite pencil, and charcoal works, made between 1850 and 1870. The exhibition highlights the connection between Hugo's artistic and literary work, with many drawings inspired by his own writings, such as "Les Miserables." The show runs until June 29, offering a rare glimpse into Hugo's private passion for illustration.

images.alt_text: Collected over half a century by real estate agent Dwight Cleveland, the posters are to be auctioned by Heritage showrooms in Dallas on Mar 27 and 28.

site_title: Hosen Group CEO Daniel Lim increases stake in the company
summary: Hosen Group CEO Daniel Lim acquired 716,000 shares at S$0.44 apiece, increasing his stake to 2.94% of the company. This follows his previous acquisition of 1,774,600 shares in December. Lim oversees brand building, procurement, and strategic growth for the company, which specializes in fast-moving consumer goods. Hosen Group reported FY2024 revenue of S$72.8 million, up 8.1% from FY2023, with a 23.5% gross profit margin. The company will continue to focus on cost management, operational efficiency, and new business opportunities to navigate the uncertain macroeconomic landscape.

images.alt_text: OVER the five trading sessions from Mar 7 to 13, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks.

site_title: Columbia University agrees to some Trump demands in attempt to restore funding
summary: Columbia University has agreed to some demands made by the Trump administration to regain federal funding that was pulled over allegations of antisemitism on campus. The university has agreed to reform its disciplinary process, hire security officers with arrest powers, and appoint a new official to review departments with Middle East programs. The move has been criticized by academics and students, who say it sets a "terrible precedent" for academic freedom and autonomy. The university's interim president, Katrina Armstrong, emphasized the need to ensure student safety and academic activities, but some have questioned the level of student and faculty input in the decision-making process.

images.alt_text: By voting last week to keep the US government running on President Donald Trump’s terms, Chuck Schumer dropped Democrats’ sole leverage.

site_title: France said to float using most powerful EU trade tool on US
summary: France is urging the European Union to deploy its most powerful retaliatory measure against the US if President Donald Trump uses tariffs to force policy changes, potentially using the "anti-coercion instrument" that allows for restrictions on trade and services. The US plans to impose sweeping tariffs on global partners starting April 2, targeting non-tariff barriers and the EU's value-added tax. The EU has not currently considered the anti-coercion instrument, but is preparing for a potential response.

images.alt_text: The ECB cut rates earlier this month, but traders have pared bets on more action and are now almost equally torn between a cut and a pause at the Apr 16 to 17 gathering.
In new projections this week, Fed officials said they expect slower growth and higher inflation in the year ahead, with risks tilted to the upside.

site_title: Singapore shares end Friday in the red as trade war fears escalate; STI down 0.1%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) ended Friday at 3,926.45, down 0.1% after a four-day winning streak, amid escalating trade war fears. The broader market saw decliners outnumber advancers 284 to 234, with 1.3 billion securities worth S$2 billion changing hands. Key regional indices were mixed, with Japan's Nikkei 225 and Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index declining, while the Kospi gained 0.2%. Local banks UOB rose 0.4%, while OCBC and DBS ended the day mixed.

site_title: Where have all the flowers gone?
summary: A writer, a refugee from Chile, reflects on the US's transformation since he arrived 48 years ago. He recalls being welcomed with kindness, receiving scholarships, and being offered jobs. However, he notes that the country has changed, with immigration officials now scrutinizing refugees. He laments the shift from a welcoming America to one that is increasingly hostile to Latin Americans and immigrants. The writer's nostalgic look at his past experiences highlights the stark contrast between the US's past and present attitudes towards refugees and immigrants.

Populists such as Trump appeal to voters’ deep-seated values and sensibilities by connecting to people’s identities, and by understanding much better than liberals the tribal nature of contemporary politics.

site_title: At least 11 flights between Singapore and London affected after Heathrow Airport closure
summary: At least 11 flights between Singapore and London have been cancelled or diverted due to the closure of Heathrow Airport until midnight on March 22, Singapore time. Six flights were cancelled, leaving thousands of passengers' plans in disarray. Airlines such as Singapore Airlines, Qantas, and British Airways have provided assistance to affected passengers, including hotel accommodation and alternative flights or land transport. The closure is attributed to a significant power outage due to a fire at a nearby electrical substation, and it is expected to cause significant disruption over the coming days.

images.alt_text: Around 70 firefighters had been tackling the blaze in the west of London, which caused a mass power outage at Heathrow Airport.

site_title: Coty to divest stake in Kim Kardashian’s beauty brand
summary: Coty will sell its 20% stake in Kim Kardashian's beauty brand SKKN by Kim to her underwear label Skims for an undisclosed amount. Coty will continue to work with Kylie Jenner's brand, Kylie Cosmetics, in which it owns a majority stake. The move marks the end of Coty's relationship with Kardashian's beauty business, which the company acquired in 2021 for $200 million.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 21)
summary: New tenants are moving into Orchard Towers in Singapore, drawn by lower rents and a prime location. Mapletree is considering the sale of its A$1.4 billion office portfolio in Australia. An executive condo site in Bukit Panjang has been launched for sale, with up to seven bids expected. COE premiums have increased, with some speculating they may continue due to commercial interests and macroeconomic factors. Additionally, Singapore has been ranked as the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year and has set up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia-Pacific.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell says that the Fed will hold interest rates steady for now.

site_title: Singapore’s competition watchdog gives green light to SIA-ANA cooperation for Singapore-Tokyo route
summary: Singapore's competition watchdog has conditionally approved a proposed commercial cooperation between Singapore Airlines (SIA) and All Nippon Airways (ANA) for the Singapore-Tokyo route. The decision comes after the airlines accepted commitments to not infringe competition laws. The proposed cooperation aims to improve connectivity and offer more competitive fares, while maintaining seat capacity on the route. The Competition and Consumer Commission of Singapore (CCCS) will monitor the situation, including the submission of an annual report and compliance with proposed commitments.

images.alt_text: The SIA plane was carrying 276 passengers and crew members, local media said.
Singapore Airlines proposes joint venture with Japan's ANA

site_title: About 20% of UOB’s lending portfolio exposed to nature-related risks
summary: UOB, Singapore's third-largest lender, has reported that approximately 20% of its corporate lending portfolio is exposed to nature-related risks, primarily in the building and construction, mining, and agricultural sectors. The bank has screened its portfolio using the Encore tool, developed by the World Wide Fund for Nature, and found that 60% of its sustainable financing portfolio already considers nature elements. UOB aims to scale both climate and nature financing to support companies in addressing climate issues and becoming more resilient in terms of nature issues.

Around half of global GDP is moderately or highly dependent on nature, according to the World Economic Forum.

site_title: Kuwait set to allow banks to offer mortgages for the first time
summary: Kuwait is set to allow banks to offer mortgages for the first time, a move expected to unlock a $65 billion market and provide a "structured framework" for home financing accessibility. The legislation, expected to be passed soon, would address a backlog of 103,000 requests and decade-long waits for government-subsidized housing. The move is seen as a transformative step, potentially boosting Kuwaiti lenders' profitability and spurring foreign interest in banking stocks.

images.alt_text: The property, known as the Rogers Building after the architect who designed it, spans more than 200,000 square feet (18,581 square metres) across 14 storeys.

site_title: Young, rich Indians drive surge in Lamborghini and Mercedes-Maybach sales
summary: Lamborghini and Mercedes-Maybach are experiencing a surge in sales in India, driven by a growing market of young, affluent Indians. Lamborghini, which had a record year in India in 2024, is exploring a fourth showroom in the country, while Mercedes-Maybach sees India as a potential top-five market by sales. The company's super luxury cars, such as the Urus SUV and the Huracan, are popular among younger buyers, with an average age of under 40 years. This demographic shift is driving growth in the luxury car market in India, which currently accounts for just over 1% of the four million vehicles sold annually.

Lamborghini is waiting for a clearer regulatory outlook in the European Union, as a review of the bloc’s ban on the sale of new internal combustion engine cars from 2035 is currently scheduled in 2026.
Bugatti previewed its plug-in hybrid Tourbillon hypercar in Singapore,  costing 3.8 million euros (S$5.4 million) before taxes.
Lamborghini delivered 8,411 cars in the first nine months of 2024, an 8.6 per cent increase compared to same period last year.

site_title: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong’s 2024 pay down 5.5% at S$15 million despite record net profit
summary: UOB CEO Wee Ee Cheong's annual salary for 2024 decreased by 5.5% to S$15 million, despite the bank reporting a record net profit of S$14.3 billion in 2024. The salary consists of a base salary of S$1.44 million and a bonus of S$13.56 million, with additional benefits totaling S$46,944. The bank's financial performance remained resilient, with total income up 3% year on year.

images.alt_text: UOB beats expectations with Q4 profit up 8.6% to S$1.52 billion; announces S$3 billion capital distribution package
Piyush Gupta will be retiring at the upcoming AGM “as part of the board renewal process”.

site_title: Europe: Shares end week higher; airlines hit by Heathrow closure
summary: European shares ended the week 0.5% higher, despite a decline in the third consecutive session, due to uncertainty over trade tensions and geopolitical conflicts. A fire at Britain's Heathrow Airport led to the closure of the airport and hit airline and travel stocks, with shares of British Airways parent IAG, Lufthansa, and Ryanair falling 1.9%, 1.7%, and 2.3% respectively. Basic resources miners were the biggest decliners, losing 2.6%, while industrials fell 1.5%. The European benchmark index closed higher for the week, despite concerns about weaker growth, higher inflation, and the Russia-Ukraine conflict.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.43 per cent lower at 552.98 points on Thursday.

site_title: Chinese EV maker Nio’s net loss deepens in Q4 despite record vehicle delivery
summary: Chinese electric vehicle maker Nio reported a net loss of 7.1 billion yuan in the fourth quarter, despite delivering a record 72,689 vehicles. This brings the company's full-year net loss to 22.7 billion yuan. Despite a 15.2% year-on-year jump in revenue to 19.7 billion yuan, the net loss widened 27.5% year-over-year. Nio's shares fell 7.7% to close at US$4.66 on Friday. The company plans to focus on enhancing profitability through cost reductions and scalable growth in 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: People look at the newly unveiled Onvo L60 SUV, the first vehicle of Chinese electric vehicle (EV) maker Nio's new lower-priced brand, in Shanghai, China May 15, 2024. REUTERS/Zoey Zhang/File Photo

site_title: New tenants moving into Orchard Towers as mall sheds sleaze
summary: Orchard Towers, a Singaporean mall, is slowly filling up with new tenants after shedding its sleazy image. The mall's first four floors are nearly 80% occupied, with businesses drawn by affordable rents and a prime Orchard Road location. New tenants include a pet-friendly cafe, a personal training gym, and a church, which purchased a 19,000 sq ft unit for S$54.5 million. The mall's management is trying to secure an anchor tenant for the basement, while existing tenants are taking up more space. A full revival of Orchard Towers requires a concerted effort by unit owners to align the tenant mix and drive change.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of Orchard Towers.

site_title: Tether engages ‘Big Four’ firm for long-awaited reserve audit
summary: Tether, the creator of the world's largest stablecoin, has engaged a Big Four accounting firm for a long-awaited audit of its reserves. The move comes as US President Donald Trump has expressed support for the audit, citing it as a top priority. Tether CEO Paolo Ardoino stated that Trump's stance should pave the way for the audit, which would improve transparency of the company's reserves. An audit would be the first for Tether, which currently releases quarterly reports but not a full audit.

images.alt_text: Much of Tether’s earnings come from investing its reserves backing stablecoins into US Treasuries, gold and other securities.
The rush to stablecoins will enhance the role of blockchain in payments on top of a slightly different product that major banks such as JPMorgan Chase have been exploring: deposit tokens.
Much of Tether’s earnings come from investing its reserves backing stablecoins into US Treasuries, gold and other securities.
Howard Lutnick is co-chair of President-elect Donald Trump’s transition team and Trump’s pick to run the Commerce Department.

site_title: Thai exports beat forecast in February but US trade uncertainty clouds outlook
summary: Thailand's exports rose 14.0% in February, beating forecasts, with a record high of $301 billion in 2024. The country aims to import more from the US to reduce its bilateral trade surplus, which was $35.4 billion last year. Despite a strong February, the outlook is clouded by US trade uncertainty, and the ministry forecasts a 2-3% annual growth in exports this year.

images.alt_text: A Thai national flag flies on a building as stacks of containers sit at the Port of Bangkok with the skyline of the city standing in the background, Thailand, on Monday, June 25, 2014. site_title: Winning Smart Shoppers: Shopee Brands Summit 2025 Sets the Stage for E-Commerce Growth
summary: Shopee hosted its Brands Summit 2025, a key event celebrating brand achievements and setting priorities for strengthening partnerships, optimizing content, and boosting customer engagement. The summit highlighted Shopee's integration of AI-driven innovations across content creation, discovery, and logistics, aiming to enhance seller operations and drive business growth. Key announcements include the launch of the Mini Feed feature, AI Generation Tool, and enhancements to Affiliate Marketing Solutions, as well as improvements to buyer experience through faster delivery and warehousing services. The summit reaffirms Shopee's commitment to empowering brands with cutting-edge technology and delivering seamless shopping experiences.

site_title: UK manufacturers are subdued about outlook as costs mount, CBI says
summary: UK manufacturers express subdued optimism due to rising costs, with the CBI's monthly balance for output expectations dipping to -2 in March. April's tax and wage increases are deterring customers from capital investments, despite an expected boost from increased defence spending in Europe. The headline industrial orders index slipped to -29, below its long-run average of -13, and the export order balance improved to a four-month high of -29.

images.alt_text: Make UK said its gauge of manufacturers’ confidence about the economic outlook over the next 12 months in its quarterly outlook survey dropped to 5.8 in the fourth quarter of 2024 from 6.8 three months earlier.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower on tariff woes
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 324.31 points, or 0.77%, to 41,629.01, amid ongoing tariff woes. FedEx adjusted its annual projections due to economic uncertainties, while investors weigh market outlook and US-EU tariffs. The S&P 500 lost 44.29 points, or 0.78%, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 171.73 points, or 0.97%. The declines follow recent tariff threats, contributing to a complex market landscape.

site_title: Nike Killshot is the next Adidas Samba
summary: Nike has introduced the Killshot, a gum-soled tennis shoe with a distinctive "Swoosh," as a potential successor to the popular Adidas Samba. The move aims to ease the pain of clearing out stale models, such as the Air Jordan 1 and Dunk, and capitalize on the buzz surrounding the Samba's popularity. The Killshot has gained traction on TikTok and in the film "Challengers," and is now enjoying stronger demand than the Samba. Adidas, however, remains a strong competitor, with its retro-shoe sales bolstering the company's sales and operating profit.

images.alt_text: Nike is in the midst of clearing out stale inventory through heavy discounting, a consequence of fading demand for some of its biggest sneaker franchises, including Air Force 1s and Dunks.
Nike is attempting to end a sales slump after a tumultuous year of corporate layoffs and the CEO change.

A logo at a JD Sports Fashion Plc store on Oxford Street in London, UK, on Tuesday, Oct. 1, 2024. JD Sports will be reporting their first-half results on Oct. 2. Photographer: Betty Laura Zapata/Bloomberg

site_title: ESR Group warns of plunge into US$730 million loss on asset and project revaluations
summary: Hong Kong-listed real asset manager ESR Group expects to report a net loss of about US$730 million for FY2024 due to marked-to-market losses in asset and project revaluations, mainly attributed to a US$320 million hit from newly completed properties in China. The group also recorded a decline in promote and transaction-based fees. Despite this, ESR noted its underlying business remains resilient, with sustained growth in core asset recurring fee incomes. The estimated net loss is not reflective of the expected long-term performance of the group.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong-listed real estate fund manager ESR Group has received a privatisation offer valued at HK$55.2 billion, the largest on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange since 2021.
ESR says its latest sustainability-linked loan will enable the group to achieve lower borrowing costs.

site_title: Musk urges Tesla employees to hold stock despite 50% drop in 3 months
summary: Elon Musk reassured Tesla employees that the company's shares, which have dropped over 50% in three months, will recover. During an all-hands meeting, Musk touted the potential for autonomous driving and launched into a familiar pitch about Teslas being "an eventual software update away from self-driving." He also joked about the backlash against him, saying employees don't have to "burn" their shares. Musk urged employees to hold onto their stock, and Tesla shares rose 1.8% shortly after the meeting, as the company prepares to launch new, more affordable models in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: The recall covers just over 46,000 vehicles built from November 2023 through February 27 of this year, Tesla said in a filing with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, and is the eighth recall for the SUV since January 2024.
Tesla has said it expects the vehicle business to return to growth this year, after a small drop in 2024.
After losing over US$5 billion after Trump’s re-election, Tesla short-sellers now hold just 2.5% of its public shares, far below the 23% historical average.
Tesla has made a big bet on autonomous driving, robotics and artificial intelligence as the primary business of selling EVs struggles.
In January 2024, Chancellor Kathaleen McCormick rescinded Elon Musk' pay package of stock options, calling it “unfathomable.”
Elon Musk’s net worth has dropped by more than US$130 billion since January, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.
In China – the world’s biggest EV market – Tesla is among the manufacturers struggling to keep up with domestic champion BYD.
BYD’s best-selling model this year in China has had its sticker price reduced by between 8 to 18 per cent, depending on the car’s specs.

site_title: Meituan’s revenue jumps 20% in a boost for global expansion
summary: Meituan, a Chinese meal delivery company, posted a 20% increase in quarterly revenue to 88.5 billion yuan, beating average projections. The company's outperformance suggests the restaurant delivery business remains resilient despite a domestic slowdown. Meituan is expanding abroad, particularly in Hong Kong with its Keeta app, and has shown initial success in Saudi Arabia. The company is exploring other international markets, including Europe and Southeast Asia, and is considering new initiatives to offset the impact of new social security costs on its China-based core local commerce margins.

images.alt_text: SGX now offers a total of 18 Singapore Depository Receipts including Ping An, Meituan and Xiaomi
Meituan reported revenue in the three months to Sep 30 at 93.6 billion yuan (S$17.3 billion), up from 76.5 billion yuan in the same period a year earlier.
Meituan had flagged to investors on Tuesday that price guidance for the 3.5-year bond was three-year Treasuries plus about 145 basis points.
Meituan’s secret weapon is its cheaper, group-based Pin Hao Fan platform for ordering meals.

site_title: China’s central bank says it will boost forex market resilience
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, plans to boost the resilience of its forex market by cutting banks' reserve requirement ratio and interest rates at the "appropriate time." The bank will also study creating new monetary policy tools to support technology innovation, consumption, and foreign trade. The move aims to strengthen the economy despite modest growth and potential challenges from US President Donald Trump's tariff hikes. The bank will keep liquidity ample and prevent currency overshooting risks, aiming for a reasonably stable yuan.

images.alt_text: A string of recent economic data, including manufacturing activity, industrial output and retail sales, provide encouraging signs for the economy’s continued recovery.
Chinese bonds have come under pressure this year as the central bank has refrained from lowering interest rates or banks’ required reserve ratio since September.
The PBOC has capped the yuan’s drop this year to its daily reference rate, which limits moves in the onshore yuan by 2 per cent on either side.
Gold has set successive records this year, though profit-taking temporarily dampened the rally last week.
Policymakers face increased pressure to unveil consumer-focused policies with a longer-term impact when China’s rubber-stamp parliament begins its annual meeting on Mar 5.

PBOC governor Pan Gongsheng said  that the central bank will guide financial institutions to increase investment in the private economy and will adopt an “appropriately loose” monetary policy to maintain ample market liquidity.

FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia’s Fore Coffee brews expansion plans with 379.8 billion rupiah IPO amid market jitters
summary: Fore Coffee, Indonesia's largest coffee chain, is expanding plans with an initial public offering (IPO) to raise 379.8 billion rupiah (S$30.7 million). Despite market volatility, CEO Vico Lomar remains confident, citing Indonesia's insatiable thirst for coffee as a growth driver. Founded in 2018, Fore Coffee has 217 outlets across Indonesia and Singapore. The IPO is set for April 11, with shares offered at a price range of 160 to 202 rupiah per share.

images.alt_text: The Financial Services Authority and the Indonesia Stock Exchange announced the easing of share buyback policies to anticipate market volatility.

site_title: Tesla recalls most Cybertrucks due to trim detaching from vehicle
summary: Tesla is recalling nearly 46,000 Cybertrucks due to a risk of an exterior trim panel detaching while driving, potentially causing a road hazard and crash. The recall, the eighth for the SUV since January 2024, covers vehicles built from November 2023 through February 27. Tesla will replace the affected panel with a new one that meets durability testing requirements. The recall may impact Tesla's stock, which has lost about half its value this year, amid rising competition and backlash against CEO Elon Musk.

images.alt_text: The plan comes as Xiaomi’s SU7 electric sedan and its Ultra race car version prove popular with buyers, shipping more than 200,000 units in less than a year.
Zeekr, Xpeng and GAC will need regulatory approval before drivers will be able to use the level three features in their cars.
The Magnificent Seven stocks – Apple, Microsoft, Nvidia, Amazon.com, Tesla, Alphabet and Meta – are seen as particular beneficiaries of AI.
Tesla has made a big bet on autonomous driving, robotics and artificial intelligence as the primary business of selling EVs struggles.
Tesla has said it expects the vehicle business to return to growth this year, after a small drop in 2024.

US District Judge Ellen Lipton Hollander of Maryland said Elon Musk’s Department of Government Efficiency was intruding into “the personal affairs of millions of Americans” as part of its hunt for fraud and waste under President Donald Trump.
After losing over US$5 billion after Trump’s re-election, Tesla short-sellers now hold just 2.5% of its public shares, far below the 23% historical average.

site_title: Rice price drop brings relief to billions, risk for farmers
summary: Global rice prices have dropped 15-year highs, bringing relief to billions of people, particularly in Asia, where the staple grain accounts for more than half the global population's diet. Favorable weather and India's rollback of export restrictions have led to a surge in global stockpiles, pushing prices down by over 30% since last year's peak. While this is good news for consumers, it poses challenges for farmers, who may be incentivized to plant less, risking a cut in supplies.

images.alt_text: A rice shop in Tokyo, Japan, Feb 14, 2025. Japan wants to boost overseas shipments of the staple, and make farming it more efficient, especially as the ageing population shrinks.

Government-stockpiled rice piled up at a warehouse in Saitama prefecture, Japan, Feb 18, 2025. Rice shortages driven by factors from poor harvests caused by hot weather to panic-buying over a “megaquake” warning last summer have caused prices to nearly double over a year.

Workers harvesting rice in Thailand using their sickles, before the threshing and winnowing. With climate change, rising sea levels are threatening rice fields and the region’s supply of the grain will come under more pressure.
The drone can apply fertiliser to plants in minutes, not only saving hours of work, but also reducing damage to crops.

site_title: Lloyd’s Register to sell modern tower and return to Victorian HQ
summary: Lloyd's Register, a maritime society formed in 1760, is selling its modern glass headquarters, the Rogers Building, for approximately £90 million. The 14-storey building spans over 200,000 square feet and will be vacated later this year to move into the neighboring Collcutt Building, which has undergone refurbishment. The sale is seen as an opportunity to modernize the landmark building in a market with limited new supply, following a sluggish London office market since 2022.

images.alt_text: Halifax said the average house in the third quarter of 2024 cost 6.55 times the mean annual full-time income, down from 6.62 in 2023 and a record high of 7.24 in mid-2022.

site_title: Japanese firms agree to 5.4% wage hike, top union group's second estimate shows
summary: Japanese companies have agreed to a 5.4% wage hike this year, the largest in 34 years, according to the Rengo union group's second estimate. This follows a preliminary reading of 5.46% and is slightly lower than expected. The agreement is expected to spread to smaller firms, aiming to maintain momentum in the labor market. This comes as the Bank of Japan considers interest rate hikes due to strong wage growth and inflation.

images.alt_text: When inflation in Japan started to accelerate in 2022, wage gains lagged the increase in import costs, which kept real wages and consumption lacklustre, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda told parliament.

site_title: COE premiums are higher than ever – will they continue this way?
summary: COE premiums in Singapore have reached record levels, with the Open category reaching S$158,004 in late October 2023. The prices have been steadily rising over the past two decades due to factors such as increasing demand from private-hire car fleets, aggressive bidding by major car brands, and macroeconomic factors like inflation and wages. Industry observers expect COE prices to continue rising, but there are mitigating factors, including the potential for private-hire cars to reduce COE demand. The government's decision not to remove private-hire cars from bidding in passenger car categories has also been cited as a reason for the continued pressure on COE prices.

images.alt_text: A passenger enters a Grab taxi private hire car outside Bishan Junction 8 December 11, 2020.
The allocation between private hire cars and private cars is best left to the market, said Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor.
A licence or special decal which private-hire car drivers who must display on their windscreens. Grab Affixing Centre at Midview City in Sin Ming Lane.
A new rule mandates a three-year lock-in period for recently acquired private hire cars in Singapore.
Generic photo of people browsing cars on display at car show The Car Expo, October 2024 in Singapore. PHOTO: DERRYN WONG ,BT
Certificate of entitlement (COE) premiums for passenger cars rose, while those for commercial vehicles and motorcycles remained flat.
Land Transport Authority (LTA) did not reveal specifics on the time frame of the additional COEs, nor on individual COE categories.

site_title: Mapletree Investments said to be considering sale of A$1.4 billion office portfolio in Australia: reports
summary: Mapletree Investments, a Temasek-backed real estate investment giant, is reportedly considering the sale of its A$1.4 billion Australian office portfolio, comprising 160,000 square meters of net lettable area. The potential divestment comes as post-pandemic optimism about the office market grows, and would be one of the largest real estate sales in Australia this decade. Mapletree's Australian office portfolio was assembled before the pandemic, and the sale could provide an entry point for new players, private investors, and value-add firms.

images.alt_text: Mapletree announces closing of Australian private trust of A$654m in fund equity
Mapletree Inv a top bidder for Aussie asset

site_title: Toyota’s new R&D unit signals its sharper India focus
summary: Toyota is setting up its first research and development (R&D) centre in India, its third R&D location in the Asia-Pacific region outside Japan. The facility, expected to start operations with 200 people in Bengaluru, will likely scale up to 1,000 engineers by 2027. This move signals Toyota's growing focus on India, which has become a crucial market for the company. The R&D centre will initially cater to the Indian market but could evolve into a global hub, similar to Mercedes-Benz's Bengaluru centre. Toyota is also doubling down on its partnership with Suzuki to integrate R&D and product development, with the upcoming Urban Cruiser EV being a key example.

images.alt_text: Toyota said it will launch three Toyota brand electric SUVs this year - new versions of the bZ4X, Urban Cruiser and C-HR+ - followed by three more in 2026.
Toyota's global output for January increased 6 per cent year-on-year to 781,729 vehicles, with domestic production up 22 per cent, offsetting an overseas production decline.
The batteries Toyota is buying from LG can be used in either EVs or hybrid vehicles.
Toyota, the world’s top-selling automaker, raised its profit forecast for the current year through March 2025 to 4.7 trillion yen (S$41.5 billion) versus 4.3 trillion yen expected previously.

site_title: Executive condo site in Bukit Panjang launched for sale
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) launched an executive condominium (EC) site in Bukit Panjang's Senja Close area for tender, with a 99-year lease tenure and potential for 295 residential units. The site has a maximum gross floor area of 30,478 sq m and a gross plot ratio of 3.0, with at least 500 sq m set aside for an early childhood development centre. The EC is expected to attract up to seven bids at tender close, with a land rate of S$700 to S$715 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: The 99-year leasehold privatre housing site in Bayshore Road can yield about 515 units.
More Singapore residents now live in private condos, spurred by upgrader buying, higher incomes and shifting preferences.
An artist's impression of executive condominium project Aurelle of Tampines

site_title: Tennis hotshots: Jack Draper, Mirra Andreeva blazing their way to the top
summary: British tennis stars Jack Draper and Mirra Andreeva have made a significant impact on the sport, with Draper winning his first Masters 1000 title at the BNP Paribas Open in Indian Wells and Andreeva becoming the event's youngest champion in over a quarter century. Draper, 23, outplayed top players including Carlos Alcaraz and Taylor Fritz, while Andreeva, 17, defeated Aryna Sabalenka, the world's number one, in consecutive three-set matches. Both players are on the rise, with Draper aiming to become a top contender and Andreeva poised to move higher in the rankings.

images.alt_text: Zimbabwean candidate for the presidency of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) Kirsty Coventry reacts after being elected during the 144th IOC Session on March 20 in Costa Navarino, Greece.
The two highest revenue-generating sports are basketball and football.

Arsenal midfielder Kai Havertz (in red) fights for the ball with Newcastle's Sven Botman in the Carabao Cup semi-final on Feb 5. The two clubs are likely to play at Singapore's National Stadium in July.

SPRINGFIELD, NJ - JUNE 25: Winner, Ruoning Yin poses with the trophy after the final round of the KPMG Women's PGA Championship at Baltusrol Golf Club on Sunday, June 25, 2023 in Springfield, New Jersey. (Photo by Darren Carroll/PGA of America)

site_title: Malaysia Airlines parent to buy 30 Boeing 737 MAX jets
summary: Malaysia Aviation Group, the parent company of Malaysia Airlines, has agreed to purchase 30 new Boeing 737 aircraft, including 18 737 MAX 8 and 12 737 MAX 10 planes, for delivery in 2029. The deal aims to modernize the airline's fleet and rebound from past setbacks, including two deadly disasters in 2014. The purchase is seen as a crucial step in restoring the airline's credibility and financial stability.

images.alt_text: The airline has suffered several setbacks this year, with reduced routes and manpower issues.

site_title: Asia: Markets skid into weekend as trade fears cast a pall
summary: Asian markets closed the day in negative territory, with shares in Hong Kong, Shanghai, and Manila declining, while Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, and Wellington edged up. The uncertainty surrounding US President Donald Trump's tariff agenda, despite dovish comments from the US Federal Reserve, continues to cast a pall over the markets. Investors remain nervous about the impact of tariffs, with the next wave of measures set to kick in at the start of April, and the White House's unpredictable approach to trade policy.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.43 per cent lower at 552.98 points on Thursday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down less than 0.1 per cent at 41,953.32 on Thursday.

site_title: Jollibee’s cafe-buying spree brews a showdown with startups
summary: Jollibee Foods Corporation, valued at $4.5 billion, has been expanding its cafe scene through acquisitions, including Tiong Bahru Bakery, Common Man Coffee Roasters, and Compose Coffee. The company aims to double its coffee retailing revenue to 30% by 2030. This move is seen as a response to the growing demand for coffee in the Philippines, with many local startups and foreign brands vying for the mid-market. Industry experts warn that JFC's scale and budget will make it difficult for startups to compete, but a "battle for the mid-market" is unfolding, attracting young, sophisticated coffee drinkers.

images.alt_text: The fast food chain, known for dishes such as fried chicken and sweet spaghetti.
Jollibee tends to grow its presence in countries with a large number of Philippine expats, analysts say.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Prudential, Top Glove, ValueMax, Fu Yu, BlackGold Natural Resources
summary: Top Glove, a Malaysian glove manufacturer, reported a net profit of RM30.3 million for its second quarter, reversing a net loss the year before. The company attributes its improved performance to recovering global demand and trade diversions due to US tariffs on Chinese glove exports. Meanwhile, Prudential announced a joint venture with an Indian health insurance company, and ValueMax raised S$71.7 million through digital securities. Fu Yu's largest shareholder requested the removal and appointment of directors at the company's upcoming annual general meeting. BlackGold Natural Resources was reprimanded by the Singapore Exchange Regulation for breaching listing rules.

site_title: Issue 140: GIC eyes grid opportunities; MAS updates on taxonomy adoption
summary: Singapore's sovereign wealth fund, Temasek, expects a structural shift in climate-adjusted future investments, with a focus on grid opportunities. To achieve this, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has updated its taxonomy adoption, aligning with the Paris Agreement's climate goals. The MAS also plans to deepen cooperation with the People's Bank of China in green and transition finance. Additionally, Singapore aims to sign a carbon credits transfer agreement with its first ASEAN country by the end of 2025, and is considering introducing carbon offsetting legislation for airlines.

site_title: Zara opens flagship store in China’s Nanjing with cafe and content creation studio
summary: Zara has opened its first Asia flagship store in Nanjing, China, featuring a cafe, content creation studio, and digital integration to encourage in-store spending. The 2,500 sq m store includes a salon, "fit check" studio for customers to create video content, and a coffee shop. The move follows Inditex's efforts to revitalize its retail network in China, where sales have been impacted by a spending slowdown and increased competition. The store's success will be closely monitored before potential expansion to other markets.

images.alt_text: Zara owner Inditex pointed to “very satisfactory” sales which hit 38.6 billion euros in 2024, a 7.5 per cent increase from the previous year.

epa10747804 Inditex founder Amancio Ortega attends the Casas Novas International Jumping Contest at the Coruna council of Arteixo in Galicia region, north-western Spain, 15 July 2023.  EPA-EFE/Cabalar

Zara owner Inditex reported a 7 per cent rise in sales for its first quarter to the end of April, an expected slowdown from a year earlier when the company benefited from a post-pandemic shopping spree.

site_title: US director accused of scamming Netflix out of millions
summary: Hollywood filmmaker Carl Rinsch has been indicted on charges of wire fraud and money laundering, accused of embezzling over $11 million from Netflix to fund his personal purchases, including luxury cars and cryptocurrency. Rinsch was hired to produce a science-fiction series for Netflix, but instead used the funds for lavish expenses. The alleged scam occurred between 2018 and 2019, when Netflix paid $44 million for the show's production. Rinsch could face decades in prison if convicted.

images.alt_text: Apple does not break down the subscribers for Apple TV+ but it is estimated to have reached 40.4 million at the end of 2024.
MrBeast has spent the past few years leveraging his fame on YouTube and other social platforms to build businesses that have nothing to do with media.

site_title: Judge stops Musk’s team from ‘unbridled access’ to Social Security private data
summary: A US federal judge has ordered a halt to Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) from accessing sensitive Social Security Administration (SSA) data, citing a violation of privacy laws. The SSA had granted DOGE staffers "unbridled access" to the records of millions of Americans, prompting the judge to rule that the agency had intruded into "the personal affairs of millions of Americans." The decision blocks DOGE from accessing SSA's systems, including the "crown jewels" Numident database, which contains personal information of everyone who has applied for or been given a social security number.

images.alt_text: After losing over US$5 billion after Trump’s re-election, Tesla short-sellers now hold just 2.5% of its public shares, far below the 23% historical average.

Elon Musk (above) and DOGE’s dismantlement of the US Agency for International Development (USAID) “likely violated the United States Constitution in multiple ways,” District Court Judge Theodore Chuang said.
Vance did not provide any details on the participants in negotiations to purchase the app.

site_title: Prabowo faces investor revolt over Indonesia’s economic path
summary: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto's populist spending measures, plans to dilute the central bank's independence, and aggressive policies against foreign businesses like Apple have sparked investor anxiety, causing a sudden market rout. The government's fiscal outlook, including a potential budget deficit and plans for a sovereign wealth fund, has raised concerns about the country's economic trajectory. Analysts warn that Prabowo's policies are at odds with the institutions put in place after the downfall of former dictator Suharto, threatening the country's democratic governance and investor confidence.

images.alt_text: Bank Indonesia’s mandate is currently supporting sustainable economic growth along with maintaining the stability of the rupiah currency and prices.

site_title: Flights cancelled after Indonesia volcano eruption
summary: At least seven international flights from Bali, Indonesia have been cancelled after Mount Lewotobi Laki-Laki volcano erupted, shooting dark ash 8 km into the sky. The eruption raised the volcano's alert status to the highest level and occurred for 11 minutes and nine seconds. The cancelled flights include six Jetstar flights bound to Australia and one Air Asia flight to Kuala Lumpur.

images.alt_text: While it takes time for changes on the wholesale level to feed through to shoppers, the price drop is already bringing relief to households struggling with otherwise high living costs.

epa11975210 Indonesian student activists carry a banner and placards during a protest against the revision of the country's military law in front of the Parliament building in Jakarta, Indonesia, 20 March 2025. site_title: Malaysia’s inflation eases to 1.5% in February, lowest in 13 months
summary: Malaysia's inflation rate eased to 1.5% in February, the lowest in 13 months, due to stable prices of administered items such as cooking gas, fuel, and public transport fares. Core inflation, excluding volatile items, rose to 1.9%, outpacing headline inflation. Economists expect manageable inflation pressures, citing easing commodity and energy prices. However, unforeseen events, such as escalated geopolitical tensions or unexpected oil supply cuts, could drive energy prices higher.

images.alt_text: The new cloud region will generate US$10.9 billion in new revenues and create 37,575 jobs in Malaysia by 2028, including 5,700 skilled IT positions, projects Laurence Si, managing director of Microsoft Malaysia.
Malaysian-listed Sapura Energy is a shadow of its former self these days, with its shares languishing at a mere RM0.045 apiece – a stark contrast to their RM4.95 peak in December 2013.

Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (centre) and British chip giant ARM Holdings CEO Rene Haas (second right) at a ceremony for the launch of a collaboration between Malaysia and ARM Holdings, Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, March 5, 2025.

site_title: Volkswagen is cutting thousands of jobs but still dwarfs global rivals
summary: Volkswagen is cutting 35,000 jobs over five years, with 1,900 positions at Porsche and 7,500 at Audi. Despite these moves, the company still employs more people than its global rivals, including Toyota (384,338) and Stellantis (worldwide 384,338). Volkswagen's bloated headcount is partly due to its in-house component production and plans to ramp up electric vehicle battery output. The company aims to reduce its workforce to remain competitive, but German labor laws will lead to attrition and retirements rather than layoffs.

images.alt_text: Volkswagen is seeking to win back the market share it’s lost to domestic carmakers such as BYD that focus on swiftly manufacturing tech-laden EVs that are popular with Chinese drivers.

A VW logo at the Autostadt customer center at the Volkswagen AG headquarters in Wolfsburg, Germany, on Tuesday, March 11, 2025. Volkswagen AG expects profitability to remain roughly flat this year as the German automaker contends with muted demand in Europe and worsening trade conflicts. site_title: Groundbreaking IOC chief Coventry confronts global intrigue and Trump
summary: Kirsty Coventry, a 41-year-old Zimbabwean two-time Olympic swimming champion, was elected as the first woman and first African to be president of the International Olympic Committee (IOC) on March 20 in Costa Navarino, Greece. Coventry faces significant challenges, including dealing with US President Donald Trump in the lead-up to the 2028 Los Angeles Summer Games. She vowed to use communication to address Trump's concerns, including on the issue of transgender athletes, and to make a collective decision with international federations on Russia's return to the Olympic fold.

images.alt_text: LA28 officials had no concerns about policies of the new Trump administration potentially disrupting preparations for the Olympics.
Sunday’s closing ceremony attracted a US audience of 20.8 million, more than double Tokyo’s.

site_title: 2025 Audi A3 Sedan review: This car made me drive 757 km for nasi kandar
summary: The 2025 Audi A3 Sedan has been reviewed, with the author praising its refined handling, smooth drivetrain, and premium cabin. The car's 1.5-liter engine produces 116 horsepower, making it suitable for Malaysian expressways. The A3's facelift has preserved its German premium brand's qualities, including its nicest cabin, best ride quality, and fluid handling. The car achieved a fuel efficiency of 6.2 L/100 km, and the author spent 757 km driving it, enjoying the experience and feeling ready to drive again. The Audi A3 Sedan is available in Singapore for S$201,999.

site_title: Tesla trade-ins on pace for record high amid Musk backlash
summary: Tesla is experiencing a record-high number of trade-ins amid public backlash against CEO Elon Musk's involvement in the Trump administration. According to Edmunds data, Tesla vehicles accounted for 1.4% of all traded-in vehicles in the first 15 days of March, up from 0.4% last year. The trend is expected to continue, with analysts attributing the decline in brand loyalty to Musk's increasing public involvement in government, Tesla depreciation concerns, and increased saturation in major areas.

images.alt_text: After losing over US$5 billion after Trump’s re-election, Tesla short-sellers now hold just 2.5% of its public shares, far below the 23% historical average.
Tesla has made a big bet on autonomous driving, robotics and artificial intelligence as the primary business of selling EVs struggles.
In January 2024, Chancellor Kathaleen McCormick rescinded Elon Musk' pay package of stock options, calling it “unfathomable.”

site_title: Thailand may yet embark on region’s most aggressive rate cuts
summary: The Bank of Thailand may implement the region's most aggressive rate cuts, potentially up to 100 basis points over the next year, as the country's economy faces headwinds from Donald Trump's trade war and a fading tourism boom. The central bank estimates the trade war could reduce GDP growth by up to half a percentage point. Analysts predict a dovish tone, with policymakers citing concerns over the economic outlook, and traders have priced in an additional 10 basis points of easing over the 12-month horizon.

images.alt_text: The central bank has said the bar would be high for a further cut as the level is consistent with the current economic outlook.
Piti Disyatat, Bank of Thailand deputy governor says the bank's latest cut is calibrated to be robust to many scenarios, including the escalation of tariffs.

site_title: China imports of US big cars plunge 70%; oil, gas, cotton and other commodity imports also collapse in new trade war
summary: China's imports of US big cars plunged 70% in the first two months of the year, while oil, gas, cotton, and other commodity imports also collapsed following the US-China trade war. The US has imposed export restrictions on high-tech machinery, leading to a 2.7% increase in overall US imports to $27 billion. Chinese companies are cutting exports of small parcels, and US firms are seeking price cuts to compensate for tariffs. Some US goods, such as soybeans, saw growth, while imports of machinery used to make semiconductors fell by a third.

images.alt_text: The trade in small packages has boomed in recent years as US consumers took advantage of low-cost shopping apps such as Shein and Temu to use the loophole.

site_title: China to add cobalt, copper in boost to state metal reserves
summary: China plans to boost its strategic metal reserves by adding cobalt, copper, nickel, and lithium, amid increasing demand for critical minerals and geopolitical tensions. The move aims to enhance the country's resilience in the face of global market volatility and supply disruptions. China's state stockpiler will purchase these metals, which can have a significant impact on market prices, to meet demand in crunch times and balance supplies. The plan was signalled in the National Development & Reform Commission's annual report earlier this month.

site_title: China’s restaurants race to the bottom in deflation-hit economy
summary: China's restaurant industry is struggling due to a deflationary economy, with many establishments closing or going out of business. Revenue growth in the food and beverage industry slowed to 5.3% in 2024, down from 20.4% in 2023. The industry is facing intense competition, with restaurants offering low prices to attract customers, leading to a vicious cycle of price wars and reduced profit margins. The government is prioritizing expanding domestic demand to offset the impact of US tariffs and a protracted property crisis, but concerns remain about a deflationary spiral.

site_title: Gems of Huaiyang cuisine at Imperial Treasure
summary: Imperial Treasure, a renowned Chinese restaurant group, has launched a new Huaiyang cuisine restaurant in Ion Orchard, Singapore. The refurbished space features a serene Chinese garden-inspired foyer and serves regional Chinese dishes, including sweet-sour crispy deep-fried cod fillet, tasty shredded tofu tossed in sesame oil dressing, and sliced Angus beef in a savoury tangy broth. The restaurant offers a unique introduction to Huaiyang cuisine, a style of cooking that spawned a generation of chefs with exceptional knife skills. With dishes tweaked for local palates, Imperial Treasure Huaiyang is an easy and authentic introduction to regional Chinese food.

site_title: Audemars Piguet sees growth in young and female collectors
summary: Audemars Piguet sees growth in young and female collectors, according to CEO Ilaria Resta. One year into her role, she reflects on the watchmaking industry's rich history and long-standing connections between brands. Resta attributes the industry's growth to partnerships and collaborations between watchmakers, a network that has endured since the early days of Swiss watchmaking. She is betting on this new analogue generation for growth, bringing nearly three decades of managing global consumer brands to luxury watchmaking.

images.alt_text: Kaws’ iconic character, Companion, playfully peers out from beneath the sapphire crystal.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip after global central banks flag economic uncertainty; Switzerland cuts rates
summary: European shares slipped 0.43% on Thursday, marking a reversal of four consecutive gains, as investors took profits and assessed interest rate decisions by major central banks. The Bank of England and Sweden's Riksbank held rates steady, while the Swiss National Bank cut its policy interest rate by 25 basis points. The US Federal Reserve kept its policy rates unchanged, citing higher uncertainty from President Trump's trade tariffs. European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde warned of rising stagflation risks due to US tariffs, leading to a decline in regional indexes, including the UK and Sweden's.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed down less than 0.1 per cent at 41,953.32 on Thursday.

site_title: Canada PM Carney to call April 28 snap election
summary: Canada's newly sworn-in Prime Minister Mark Carney is set to announce a snap election for April 28, capitalizing on a recent polling surge for his Liberal Party. The election comes amid intense pressure from US President Donald Trump's trade war and his repeated statements that Canada should not remain an independent country. Carney, a former central banker, aims to unite the Liberals and secure a strong mandate to address the economic turmoil. This will be his first campaign, with the Conservatives and other parties likely to focus on domestic issues rather than Trump's threats.

images.alt_text: After succeeding Justin Trudeau last week, Mark Carney conspicuously chose key European powers France and the United Kingdom, rather than the United States, for his first trip abroad.

site_title: South Korea’s early trade data show exports bouncing back
summary: South Korea's early trade data shows exports bouncing back, increasing 8.2% from a year ago in the first 20 days of March, with semiconductor exports rising 11.6% and automobile shipments increasing 3.7%. The trade surplus reached $1.1 billion, with unadjusted exports rising 4.5% and imports decreasing 1.4%. The data offers relief for policymakers, but concerns over US tariffs and global demand remain, with Samsung Electronics raising expectations for a recovery in the memory chip market.

images.alt_text: The figure comes a month after South Korea reported its fertility rate increased for the first time in nine years in 2024.

site_title: Central bankers move slowly through fog of Trump’s trade wars
summary: Central bankers are being impacted by US President Donald Trump's trade policies, with uncertainty surrounding interest rate cuts across the globe. Markets have pared back expectations of rate cuts, with the US Federal Reserve keeping rates unchanged and the Bank of England dropping its rate-cutting bias. The European Central Bank and Riksbank have also signaled a pause in rate cuts due to international uncertainty. The uncertainty is attributed to Trump's tariffs, a potential worldwide reciprocal tariffs program, and reordering of international defense pacts, making it difficult for central banks to predict interest rate movements.

site_title: Role of Indonesia central bank must be strengthened to support growth ambitions, top lawmaker says
summary: Indonesia's central bank must be strengthened to support the government's economic growth target of 8% by 2029, according to a lawmaker. The country's economic growth has hovered at around 5% in recent years. To achieve the target, the finance ministry and Bank Indonesia (BI) need to work together, with lawmakers considering measures to enhance BI's role in supporting sustainable economic growth and maintaining currency stability.

site_title: Capital World says Malaysian anti-graft body is probing transactions linked to its former subsidiary

The company's former executive director, Siow Chien Fu, has been remanded by MACC. Capital World claims it disposed of its 80% stake in MCM Studio in 2020 and is business as usual, with Jensen Siow, the executive director of its subsidiary Capital City Property, being interviewed by MACC.

Japan beat Bahrain 2-0, with Daichi Kamada and Takefusa Kubo scoring goals, to advance to the tournament in the US, Canada, and Mexico. Endo aims to make an impact at the World Cup, not just qualify, and the team will play two more qualifiers before the tournament.

site_title: Japan’s core inflation hits 3% in February, keeps alive BOJ rate-hike bets
summary: Japan's core consumer prices rose 3.0% in February from a year earlier, exceeding the Bank of Japan's 2% target and fueling interest rate hike bets. This marks the fifth consecutive month of inflation above the target, with the core CPI index increasing 2.6% from a year earlier. The BOJ has signaled its readiness to raise interest rates if inflation is sustained around 2%, with Governor Kazuo Ueda citing rising food costs and stronger wage growth as concerns.

site_title: Fu Yu’s largest shareholder makes new request to table motion to oust directors at AGM
summary: Fu Yu Corporation's largest shareholder, Victor Lim, has made a new request to table resolutions to oust and appoint directors at the company's upcoming annual general meeting (AGM). This is the third attempt by Lim, who owns 29.45% of the company's shares, to convene an extraordinary general meeting (EGM) due to the company's poor performance and falling share price. Fu Yu's board is taking legal advice on the validity of Lim's request and will update shareholders if there are developments.

site_title: Gold unchanged near record high as global uncertainties raise demand
summary: Gold prices held steady near a record high, supported by safe-haven demand amid geopolitical and economic uncertainty. The US Federal Reserve's hint at rate cuts this year also fueled appeal. Spot gold remained flat at $3,043.89 per ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.3% to $3,051.90. The price has climbed around 2% for the week, as investors seek a hedge against uncertainty.

site_title: Singapore bank sector may cut hiring amid volatile markets, global financial job losses
summary: Singapore's banking sector may cut hiring amid global financial job losses due to market volatility and concerns of a US recession. US banks, including Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs, are planning job cuts, which could ripple to Singapore. Recruiters suggest that roles in investment banking and trading are at risk. However, wealth management and private markets are expected to see hiring opportunities, driven by the growth of single family offices and private markets in Singapore.

site_title: US existing-home sales top estimates, rebound from bad weather
summary: US existing-home sales rebounded in February, exceeding estimates with a 4.2% increase to an annualized rate of 4.26 million, driven by a greater supply of houses and improved weather. Despite a 17% jump in existing home inventory, median sales price rose 3.8% to $398,400, a record for the month. Mortgage rates have not changed much, but more inventory and choices have released pent-up housing demand, according to NAR chief economist Lawrence Yun. However, home prices remain high, and housing remains unaffordable for many Americans.

The company expects fiscal third-quarter revenue of $8.8 billion and profit of $1.57 per share. Its high-bandwidth memory, or HBM, has become a vital piece of AI systems, with revenue crossing $1 billion in the second quarter. This would double its previous valuation of $15 billion. The startup has seen significant growth, tripling its valuation from $1 billion to $3 billion and then again to $9 billion. Perplexity offers a search tool, internal file search, and finance-related features, with nearly $100 million in annual recurring revenue and over 15 million active users. The company faces growing competition from Google and OpenAI.

While some ideas look promising, the industry is plagued by quackery, and the lack of regulation and investment hinders progress. Governments must create an environment for rigorous trials, rethinking medical regulation to focus on treatments that improve overall health, not just restore it. The company's new strategy focuses on consolidation and cost-cutting, with a 57% increase in full-year exports. Despite facing intense competition in China and tariffs in global markets, Geely expects continued profit and has no need to tap capital markets for funds.

site_title: FedEx cuts profit outlook again amid mounting economic woes
summary: FedEx lowered its full-year guidance for a third consecutive quarter due to weakening consumer confidence and potential fallout from the US trade war. The parcel company now expects adjusted earnings of $18 to $18.60 per share, below analyst estimates. FedEx faces sputtering package demand, with weakness from industrial customers and the expiration of its US Postal Service contract affecting volumes. The company's shares fell 5.7% in after-hours trading, following a 12% decline this year. FedEx is the latest US company to sound the alarm over economic uncertainty, with its shares impacted by US President Donald Trump's escalating trade proposals.

The company attributed the slowdown to intensified domestic competition and US tariffs, which are affecting its expansion. Net income rose 18% to 27.4 billion yuan. site_title: Airlines question Heathrow readiness after shutdown sparks global flight chaos
summary: Heathrow Airport was shut down on March 21 due to a massive fire at a nearby electrical substation, causing a power outage that affected the airport's systems. The blaze, which was brought under control by firefighters, knocked out the airport's power and backup system, stranding thousands of passengers worldwide. Airlines questioned the airport's readiness, with some flights diverted or cancelled, and industry experts warned of a financial hit costing tens of millions of pounds. The cause of the fire was not known, but energy minister Ed Miliband said it did not appear to be foul play.

The trade in small packages has boomed in recent years, with low-cost shopping apps like Shein and Temu allowing US consumers to avoid tariffs by declaring items under $800. The Trump administration is expected to cancel the "de minimis" exemption, but Chinese exports of such items are estimated to be around $23 billion last year.

site_title: Trump says India can’t avoid tariffs on Apr 2
summary: US President Donald Trump stated that India will face like-for-like tariffs on April 2, despite having a "very good relationship" with the country. India is considered one of the highest-tariffing nations in the world, according to Trump. Despite efforts by Indian officials to reduce trade barriers, Trump's statement suggests that the US will impose the same tariffs on India as they charge the US. Indian officials have been discussing reducing duties on various products, including automobiles and energy imports, in an attempt to appease the US.

site_title: Tariff inflation not a worry for the Fed – for now
summary: The US Federal Reserve left interest rates unchanged, citing no signs of hyperinflation or recession. Chairman Jerome Powell attributed this decision to uncertainty surrounding the impact of the Trump administration's trade war, which he described as "tariff-on, tariff-off." Powell emphasized the resilience of the US economy, citing strong employment data and muted inflation, and expressed confidence that the effects of tariffs would be transitory. The Fed reiterated its projections for two rate cuts in 2025, despite increased consumer inflation estimates.

site_title: Dollar higher as Fed signals no rush to cut rates, BOE holds rates steady
summary: The US dollar rose 0.5% against a basket of six currencies, nearing its five-month low, after the Federal Reserve signaled no rush to cut interest rates this year due to uncertainty around US tariffs. The Bank of England held interest rates steady, while the Swiss National Bank lowered its policy rate to 0.25%. The dollar index was 103.85, while the euro fell 0.5% to US$1.0849. Despite this, traders are pricing in 63 basis points of Fed easing this year, with a 50% chance of a third rate cut in July.

site_title: Apple shuffles AI executive ranks in bid to turn around Siri

This change aims to address the delays in releasing new features announced last June, including the ability to tap into user data. The shift is part of a broader effort to revamp Apple's AI efforts, which were a key topic of discussion among senior leaders at a recent offsite gathering.

A judgment found Karen Kwee was the beneficial owner of five properties, including two in Singapore and three in Australia and Canada, despite her father managing them. site_title: Nike sales beat estimates in new CEO’s first full quarter
summary: Nike's new CEO Elliott Hill's turnaround strategy is showing signs of success, as the company's revenue beat analyst estimates in its first full quarter under his leadership. Revenue fell 9% to $11.3 billion, better than the predicted 11% drop. The company is also clearing out stale inventory through heavy discounting, a result of fading demand for its biggest sneaker franchises. Nike shares rose 4% in after-hours trading, despite the stock being down 5% for the year. This positive result suggests Hill's efforts to guide the company back to growth are gaining traction.
