Nike Inc. shares sank after the sneaker company's full-year outlook missed expectations, stoking investor concerns about waning demand and competition from upstarts On and Hoka, as well as rival Adidas AG. Photographer Bing Guan/Bloomberg via Getty Images

site_title: Oil prices settle US$1 higher after US issues new Iran-related sanctions
summary: US oil prices rose on Thursday after the US issued new Iran-related sanctions, with Brent crude futures settling up 1.72% at $72 a barrel. The sanctions targeted Chinese refineries and vessels supplying crude oil to them, and came amid renewed tensions in the Middle East. The US dollar also rose, making crude more expensive for foreign buyers, but interest rate cuts are expected later this year. Analysts predict a "choppy upward drift" in oil prices, driven by stimulus measures in China and renewed hostilities in the region.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled up 22 US cents, or 0.31 per cent, to US$70.78 a barrel.

site_title: US: Stocks edge lower as Fed rally falters
summary: US stocks closed lower on Thursday, as a Fed-related rally falters, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down less than 0.1% at 41,953.32. The S&P 500 fell 0.2% to 5,662.89 and the Nasdaq Composite Index slipped 0.3% to 17,691.63. The decline comes ahead of potential tariffs next month, with President Trump planning to impose reciprocal tariffs on US trading partners on April 2. Accenture's shares slumped 6.7% after the Trump administration's cost-cutting drive affected its business.

images.alt_text: A television station broadcasts Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, speaking after a Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) meeting on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Wednesday, March 19, 2025. Federal Reserve officials held their benchmark interest rate steady for a second straight meeting, though they telegraphed expectations for slower economic growth and higher inflation. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

site_title: Creditors file over S$198m in claims against troubled Qoo10, but only S$34,650 recovered
summary: Creditors of Qoo10, a Singapore-based online marketplace, have submitted over S$198 million in claims, but only S$34,650 has been recovered. The company's total liabilities exceed its assets, valued at S$685.6 million, with most assets coming from its e-commerce platforms. The liquidator has received S$11.3 million in trade and other receivables, but the recovery of S$685.6 million is highly doubtful due to the company's restructuring and asset transfers. The liquidation process is ongoing, with no definitive timeline for its completion.

images.alt_text: MAS has suspended Qoo10’s payment services since Sep 23.
The company will be allowed to make payments to fulfil outstanding claims, but cannot take on new payment obligations, said MAS.
The police said on Sep 12 that reports were lodged against Qoo10 and Qxpress and that they are investigating.

site_title: Trump trade upheaval leaves foreign central banks guessing
summary: US trade upheaval under President Donald Trump has left foreign central banks uncertain about the global economic outlook. Fed officials predict slower growth and higher inflation, with risks tilted to the upside, due to Trump's fast-moving effort to rewire international trade. This has led to warnings from central banks globally, including the Bank of England, Bank of Japan, and European Central Bank, that US tariff measures and potential retaliation could harm growth and inflation. Economists predict a likely recession in Canada and Mexico, and warn of a global hard landing due to the proliferation of tariffs and trade policy-related uncertainties.

images.alt_text: Across the broader market, gainers outnumber losers 286 to 243 after 1.1 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changed hands.
BOJ governor Kazuo Ueda says: “We will scrutinise how US trade policy unfolds, how it affects the US and other global economies, and how that all impacts Japan’s economic and price outlook.”
FILE PHOTO: U.S. dollar banknotes are seen in this illustration taken March 10, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
FILE PHOTO: A view of the Bank of England and the financial district, in London, Britain, September 23, 2024. REUTERS/Mina Kim/File Photo

site_title: China’s US$150 billion of property debt restructurings stumble
summary: China's US$150 billion in property debt restructurings are facing challenges, with some developers struggling to meet payment obligations even after clearing key steps. Despite court approvals, fresh liquidity problems have led to restructurings stalling or failing. Companies like Kaisa Group Holdings, Powerlong Real Estate Holdings, and Yuzhou Group Holdings are seeking more time to shore up their liquidity. Experts warn that offshore creditors may only recover a small portion of their owed money if the property market continues to struggle, highlighting the continued risks to Chinese developers.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A UBS logo is pictured on the branch of the Swiss bank in Lucerne, Switzerland, June 14, 2024.  REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: ValueMax raises S$71.7 million through two digital securities commercial papers
summary: ValueMax Group raised S$71.7 million through two digital securities commercial papers, which closed on March 20. The papers, issued on March 3, received strong demand from investors, with the company's managing director Yeah Lee Ching subscribing for S$1.36 million. The company plans to list the digital securities on the ADDX digital platform and the Singapore's Digital Asset Exchange (SDAX) on March 21. ValueMax shares fell S$0.005 to close at S$0.52 on the day.

images.alt_text: Pixgeneric / generic pix of exterior facade of ValueMax Group , taken on 13 October 2021at 261 Waterloo Street .Industry piece on how pawnbroking industry is modernising.

site_title: CK Hutchison warns of geopolitical risks as profit falls and ports deal upsets China
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings reported a 27% decline in net income to HK$17.1 billion (S$2.9 billion) for 2024, missing analyst expectations. The company warned of a deteriorating global business environment due to geopolitical and trade tensions. The sale of its 43 ports to a consortium led by BlackRock has enraged Beijing, sparking uncertainty. The group will rein in capital spending and increase productivity to mitigate the impact of potential supply chain disruptions. Chairman Victor Li cautioned about volatile and unpredictable operating conditions, highlighting the sensitivity of the port deal.

images.alt_text: The Panama deal is not the first time Li’s business dealings have drawn Beijing’s ire.
Cargo vessels docked at Balboa Port, operated by Panama Ports Company, at the Panama Canal, in Panama City, Panama, Feb 1, 2025.
Port of Balboa at the Panama Canal; CK Hutchison will sell 43 ports in 23 countries, while keeping facilities in mainland China and Hong Kong.
Li Ka-shing is unlikely to be the last billionaire caught between the world’s two biggest economies.
CK Hutchison said last week it agreed to sell most of the global US$22.8 billion ports business, including assets it holds along the strategically important Panama Canal, to a group led by BlackRock.
The decision to hire law firm Paul Hastings marked a shift for CK Hutchison – the Hong Kong conglomerate has worked on many of its deals with law firms such as Freshfields and Linklaters before.

A view of the Balboa Port is pictured after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock Inc-backed consortium, amid pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump to curb China's influence in the region, Panama City, Panama, March 4, 2025. REUTERS/Enea Lebrun

A ship sails near the Balboa Port after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock-backed consortium, amid pressure from US President Donald Trump to curb China's influence in the region, Panama City, Panama, March 4, 2025.
The sale includes 90% of Panama Ports Company, which has operated the Balboa (pictured) and Cristobal ports in the Central American country for over two decades, CK Hutchison said.

site_title: Thai central bank eases mortgage rules to aid property sector
summary: The Bank of Thailand has relaxed mortgage rules to aid Thailand's struggling property sector. Lenders can offer 100% loans for first-time homebuyers of properties worth over 10 million baht and 100% loans for second-time buyers of properties under 10 million baht. The relaxed rules will be in effect from May 1, 2026, until June 30, 2026, to revive the sector amid weak demand and oversupply. This move aims to boost the economy, which is expected to grow slightly above 2.5% this year.

images.alt_text: The central bank has said the bar would be high for a further cut as the level is consistent with the current economic outlook.

site_title: Bank of England keeps rates on hold
summary: The Bank of England's Monetary Policy Committee voted 8-1 to keep interest rates at 4.5% and warned against assumptions of future cuts due to deep uncertainty in the British and global economies. The decision came despite escalating global trade tensions and a slowdown in China's GDP growth. Economists had mostly forecast a 7-2 vote to keep rates on hold.

images.alt_text: A customer holds her purse while making a purchase at a restaurant in London, U.K., on Friday, May 22, 2015. Credit and debit cards that can be used by tapping the reader are gaining users, and mobile apps are set to further boost the popularity of contactless paying. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

site_title: Artisanal Chinese tea gives matcha a run for its money
summary: Artisanal Chinese tea is gaining popularity in Singapore, with new specialty tea houses opening in the city-state. The trend reflects a growing demand for experiential pursuits and a slower pace of life. Experts note that younger, affluent consumers are seeking premium, immersive experiences, while the shrinking middle class is increasingly splitting between luxury and budget-conscious segments. Local tea brands are also embracing premium offerings, such as Golden Seed and Fort Sanctuary, which specialize in rare Oriental teas and Wuyi rock-essence tea. Despite challenges, the renewed appreciation for Chinese tea has the potential to become a longer-lasting trend, driven by the city-state's cultural appreciation and the desire to reconnect with traditions.

images.alt_text: Aman Residences Tokyo boasts a spa and 25-metre pool.

site_title: SGX RegCo reprimands BlackGold Natural Resources directors, CFO for breaches of listing rules
summary: The Singapore Exchange Regulation (SGX RegCo) has reprimanded BlackGold Natural Resources directors and CFO for breaching listing rules, citing inadequate internal controls and risk management systems. The company failed to disclose material information, including the expiration of its coal mine concession in Indonesia, which led to a suspension in trading. The regulator noted that the CFO and CEO were aware of the information but failed to escalate it to the board in a timely manner, resulting in a misleading announcement.

images.alt_text: Blackgold Natural Resources unveils board changes
BlackGold's proposed reverse takeover falls through

site_title: Why China is suddenly flooding the market with powerful AI models
summary: China is unexpectedly flooding the market with powerful AI models, contradicting expectations of retaliation against US sanctions on advanced AI technologies. Chinese tech groups Alibaba, Baidu, and Tencent have released open-source AI models, including DeepSeek R1, which can be downloaded, modified, and integrated. This move aims to sidestep US sanctions, decentralize development, and tap into global talent, potentially reshaping the AI industry's economic structure. By making AI models freely available, China seeks to compete with US companies built on proprietary models, but this strategy may also lead to trade-offs, including potential intellectual property theft.

images.alt_text: Industry watchers expect Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang to spotlight Nvidia’s latest Blackwell line of graphics processing units, including new updates in the works.
Baidu’s reasoning model excels in areas such as daily dialogs, complex calculations and logical deduction, it says in a statement on Sunday.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 20)
summary: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell announced the Fed will hold interest rates steady, providing Asian markets with a "breather" and increased certainty. Microsoft's $2.2 billion investment in Malaysia remains firm despite US policy uncertainty. Analysts are bullish on ST Engineering, hiking target prices due to a positive outlook and strong growth prospects. The real estate sector sees robust activity, but Singapore professionals' salaries lag behind regional peers. Top Glove, a Malaysian glove manufacturer, returned to profitability with a Q2 net profit of RM30.3 million.

site_title: Is it a bank? Is it a fund manager? Chocolate Finance meltdown highlights need for clear distinction
summary: Chocolate Finance, a Singapore-based wealth investing platform, has raised concerns over its marketing practices, which some say blur the lines between a fund manager and a bank. Industry experts warn that customers must carefully read the fine print to understand the true nature of the platform, which is licensed as a fund manager, not a bank. The firm's interest-bearing account and debit card, while similar to those offered by banks, are actually investment products that invest in fixed-income funds.

images.alt_text: Founder and chief executive Walter de Oude explained that a spike in withdrawals would deplete the firm's liquidity buffer, which is why a temporary pause is required.
Transactions made on AXS, and e-wallet top-ups are no longer supported, said Chocolate Finance.
The MAS has a two-stage test on what constitutes financial advice.

site_title: Hedge funds burned by Tesla short bets plot next steps
summary: Tesla's share price has dropped over 40% since December, resulting in a loss of around $550 billion in market value. Hedge funds, who lost over $5 billion after the 2020 US election, now hold only 2.5% of Tesla's public shares, significantly lower than their historical average. Many investors, including CEO of Kamet Capital Partners, view the current sell-off as temporary, while others, like CEO of Clean Energy Transition, have a moderate short position to manage risk. Analysts expect the stock to rise over 50% in the next 12 months, but some warn of a "bubble" in Tesla's stock price.

images.alt_text: Tesla has made a big bet on autonomous driving, robotics and artificial intelligence as the primary business of selling EVs struggles.
In January 2024, Chancellor Kathaleen McCormick rescinded Elon Musk' pay package of stock options, calling it “unfathomable.”
Elon Musk’s net worth has dropped by more than US$130 billion since January, according to the Bloomberg Billionaires Index.
In China – the world’s biggest EV market – Tesla is among the manufacturers struggling to keep up with domestic champion BYD.
BYD’s best-selling model this year in China has had its sticker price reduced by between 8 to 18 per cent, depending on the car’s specs.
Some investors have also grown worried that Musk’s foray into politics has become a distraction from his job as the EV giant’s CEO.
Tesla is coming off a tough 2024 in China, when it recorded its first-ever drop in annual shipments from the Shanghai plant since the facility started mass production in 2020.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors to outsource EV production to Taiwan's Foxconn
summary: Mitsubishi Motors plans to outsource the production of electric vehicles to Taiwan's Foxconn to lower production costs and shorten development periods. Foxconn aims to collaborate with Nissan and Honda, while Mitsubishi Motors is discussing software development for EVs with Honda and Nissan. A tie-up is set to be announced before the end of March. This move comes as Nissan is open to working with new partners after a proposed merger with Honda fell through.

site_title: ST Engineering on a tear; stock hits successive highs and is now more expensive than DBS and other leading blue chips
summary: ST Engineering's shares hit an intraday and all-time high of S$6.93, up 5.5% from its closing price of S$6.57. Analysts predict strong growth prospects, with RHB and CGS International raising their target prices to S$7.80 and S$7.40, respectively. The company aims to achieve revenue of S$17 billion and net profit improvement by 2029, driven by its defence segment, which is expected to surpass S$7.5 billion by 2029. This has fueled its price-to-earnings (PE) ratio to around 31.1, above other blue-chip counters.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering will maintain its research and development spending, at 4 to 5% of group revenue for the next five years.

site_title: ECB’s Lagarde spells out cost of trade war with US
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) president Christine Lagarde warned that a 25% tariff imposed by the US on European imports could lower eurozone growth by 0.3 percentage point in the first year, while retaliatory measures could increase this to 0.5 percentage point. The solution to a trade war lies in further trade integration with others, which could offset losses. Lagarde also welcomed Germany's massive spending plans, downplaying concerns about inflation.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says: “The level of uncertainty we are facing is exceptionally high. Maintaining stability in a new era will be a formidable task.”
The central bank lowered borrowing costs this month for the sixth time since June as inflation abates and the economy wobbles.

site_title: Tan Boon Liat Building’s S$1.15 billion collective sale closes with no bids
summary: The collective sale of the S$1.15 billion freehold Tan Boon Liat Building in Singapore has closed with no bids, entering a 10-week private treaty period due to conditions placed by the Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA). Expressions of interest were received, with parties exploring rezoning the site to residential with commercial use on the first storey and increasing the plot ratio to 4.9. A land betterment charge of around S$830-840 million is expected, bringing the land cost to S$1,888 per square foot per plot ratio.

images.alt_text: Tan Boon Liat Building – an industrial warehouse and showroom landmark located at the crossroads of Outram Road and Zion Road is up for collective sale. Cushman & Wakefield, the exclusive advisor and marketing agent for the property has put the site out for a public tender at a reserve price of $1.15 billion.

site_title: US: Wall Street slips as Fed boost proves short-lived
summary: US stock indexes fell on March 20, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average dropping 244.44 points, or 0.57%, to 41,727.18, amid concerns over US tariff policies and an uncertain economic backdrop. The S&P 500 lost 40.71 points, or 0.71%, to 5,634.40, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 162.59 points, or 0.95%, to 17,585.75. The Federal Reserve's decision to stick to its monetary easing plans was seen as a short-lived boost, with investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on March 7, 2025, in New York City. Wall Street stocks rose early March 7, digesting a mixed jobs report as markets seek a pivot from a rough period amid tariff uncertainty. The US added 151,000 jobs last month, up from January's revised 125,000 figure, but fewer than analysts estimates as unemployment ticked higher. (Photo by CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)

site_title: Nvidia to invest billions in US chip production over four years: FT
summary: Nvidia plans to invest around $500 billion in US-made chips and electronics over the next four years, according to CEO Jensen Huang. The investment will help the company manufacture its latest systems in the US, with suppliers including TSMC and Foxconn. Huang aims to increase supply chain resilience and address investor concerns over demand for Nvidia's expensive AI chips. The move could also accelerate the expansion of the US AI industry, with the Trump administration potentially providing support.

images.alt_text: Nvidia logo is seen in this illustration taken, January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration
DeepSeek’s focus on reasoning will increase the need for computation, helping drive demand for Nvidia chips, Jensen Huang says.
Stargate joins a race among leading tech companies to build up capacity of Nvidia’s latest chips.
The Santa Clara, California-based company is working on a successor to its current design, but that will be a stopgap product.
Industry watchers expect Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang to spotlight Nvidia’s latest Blackwell line of graphics processing units, including new updates in the works.

site_title: Asian markets get ‘breather’ with US Fed’s rate cut pause
summary: The US Federal Reserve has paused interest rate cuts, giving Asian markets a "breather" and more room for certainty. The decision is expected to benefit Singapore's banks and real estate investment trusts (Reits), with steady interest rates unlikely to impact corporate and sovereign bonds. Market observers, including Aberdeen Investments and JP Morgan Asset Management, anticipate two Fed rate cuts this year, with a bias towards more cuts rather than fewer. The pause in rate cuts is seen as a positive development for Asian markets, with some analysts predicting a stable market and reduced pressure on the Singapore dollar.

images.alt_text: A string of recent economic data, including manufacturing activity, industrial output and retail sales, provide encouraging signs for the economy’s continued recovery.
Non-yielding gold is historically considered a hedge against geopolitical and economic uncertainties, and thrives in a low interest rate environment.
The Fed’s interest rate decision was expected, but the central bank cut its growth forecast for 2025 and hiked its inflation outlook.
U.S. Federal Reserve Chair Jerome  Powell said the risk of recession had risen slightly in recent weeks.

site_title: Stanford, Harvard grads seek China AI startup jobs, says Manycore founder
summary: Manycore Tech, a Chinese AI startup, is attracting top talent from top US universities such as Harvard and Stanford due to its rising profile and lower cost AI model. The company's designation as one of China's "Six Dragons" has made it easier to attract candidates, with many graduates opting for China-based startups over Silicon Valley due to US immigration uncertainty. Manycore plans to add nearly 100 engineers to keep pace with rapid AI advances, highlighting the growing demand for AI talent worldwide.

images.alt_text: The pace of China’s open-source AI push has been relentless since the debut in January of DeepSeek R1.
NUS and SAP Labs will collaborate in training new AI researchers in Singapore.
The new Heineken GenAI aims to boost innovation in Singapore and global operations
Oracle will provide Singapore’s armed forces and defence ministry with an “air-gapped” isolated cloud computing infrastructure.
The Santa Clara, California-based company is working on a successor to its current design, but that will be a stopgap product.
Tencent’s five new 3D-content generators are built atop its Hunyuan3D-2.0 model, all of which it intends to open-source to users.
For all the buzz, the chatbot is only a prototype along the way to a loftier goal of AGI, or “artificial general intelligence” that surpasses the cognitive abilities of humans.
Samsung’s operating profit sank almost a third in the fourth quarter last year, owing to spending on research.
Beijing has previously estimated that there will be a record 12.22 million university graduates in 2025.
Baidu’s reasoning model excels in areas such as daily dialogs, complex calculations and logical deduction, it says in a statement on Sunday.

site_title: Indonesian lawmakers give military bigger role in government
summary: Indonesian lawmakers passed legislation expanding the military's role in government, allowing active-duty personnel to assume civilian positions, including within the Attorney General's Office. The revisions undo curbs installed after Suharto's dictatorship and raise concerns about democratic backsliding under President Prabowo Subianto. The changes were passed at breakneck speed, sparking protests and fears of democratic erosion. The move has drawn criticism from foreign investors, who have questioned Indonesia's direction under Prabowo.

site_title: Fernando Botero’s immersive show opens new IMBA Theatre in Singapore
summary: Fernando Botero's immersive art show is set to open at Singapore's IMBA Theatre at Gardens by the Bay, featuring large-scale projections, augmented reality, and interactive installations. The show will be accompanied by a traditional exhibition of Botero's paintings and drawings. The late artist's iconic figures, known for their exaggerated forms and volume, will come alive through monumental projections and interactive elements. The show is the first of its kind in Singapore, marking the city-state's entry into the large-scale, immersive experience market.

images.alt_text: Buy What You Love,  a handy book on art collecting that focuses on passion over profit.
Coming from a broken family, Kim Whye Kee has served three prison sentences.
Iris van Herpen's sculptural, surreal dresses takes centrestage  at the ArtScience Museum in Marina Bay Sands Singapore.

site_title: BlackRock fund’s forfeited China towers to be sold at 40% loss
summary: BlackRock's China office complex, previously valued at 1.2 billion yuan, is set to be sold at a 40% discount to 700 million yuan, resulting in losses for the US asset manager and banks backing it. The sale to DCL Investments, a Chinese distressed situation specialist, reflects the growing number of office buildings in China's biggest cities that are barely half-full, triggering rent cuts and slumping values. This transaction is part of a larger trend of foreign funds and companies paring exposure in China's property market amid the country's slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Port of Balboa at the Panama Canal; CK Hutchison will sell 43 ports in 23 countries, while keeping facilities in mainland China and Hong Kong.
The decision to hire law firm Paul Hastings marked a shift for CK Hutchison – the Hong Kong conglomerate has worked on many of its deals with law firms such as Freshfields and Linklaters before.
“We are complying with the new requirements including by highlighting our role as a ‘passive’ investor at the start of each engagement,” the company says.

site_title: UK first-time buyers surge amid cheaper borrowing
summary: UK first-time buyers surged to a record 341,068 loans over the 12 months through January, a fifth more than the previous year, as easing interest rates made houses more affordable. First-time buyers accounted for 54% of all mortgages, with average prices reaching £235,195. Cheaper borrowing costs boosted demand across the market, with average UK property prices increasing 3.7% to a record £294,818. The Bank of England is set to keep interest rates on hold, citing inflationary pressures and uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Tens of thousands of Britons are seeking to buy a house and risk more than £11,000 in extra charges if they miss the deadline.
First-time buyers in pricey areas such as London will be most affected when stamp duty thresholds become less generous

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Thomson Medical, Prudential, Trendlines, Ping An Insurance, Abundance International
summary: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, Thomson Medical, Prudential, Trendlines, Ping An Insurance, Abundance International. Sembcorp Industries' subsidiaries partnered with Prysmian to supply 1 GW of green electricity to Singapore, while Thomson Medical will develop a 300-bed hospital in Johor. Prudential reported a 11% year-on-year increase in new business profit, and Ping An Insurance saw a 47.8% rise in net profit. Trendlines terminated its CEO and director for allegedly embezzling $2.1 million.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp, Sarawak Energy partner Prysmian to supply Singapore with green energy
The project will be built in two phases, with construction on the hospital block and the central lift core to start by the end of the year or the first quarter of 2026.
Ping An’s insurance funds’ investment portfolio achieved a comprehensive investment yield of 5.8 per cent in 2024, up 2.2 percentage points year on year.
Stephen Rhodes, the group's founder and chair emeritus, will assume the roles and responsibilities of Trendlines Agrifood Innovation Centre following Anton Wibowo's dismissal.

site_title: Microsoft’s US$2.2 billion Malaysia investment solid amid US policy uncertainty
summary: Microsoft's $2.2 billion investment in Malaysia remains on track, despite global uncertainties, including US policy shifts. The company's Malaysia West cloud region, set to launch in Q2 2025, will create 37,575 jobs and generate $10.9 billion in new revenues by 2028. The investment supports Malaysia's digital transformation, including AI training programs and cybersecurity initiatives. Microsoft has not encountered operational disruptions in Malaysia due to US export controls on semiconductor chips.

images.alt_text: Tengku Zafrul Aziz, Malaysia’s Minister of International Trade and Industry, says: “We built a strong ecosystem around the semiconductor industry and it has been a major part of our exports.”
US trade tariffs on imports from China could hit Malaysia's burgeoning electronic chips market, says Malaysia's Investment, Trade and Industry Minister Zafrul Aziz.
South-east Asia’s potential cannot be ignored. While its AI industry is sputtering, its digital economy as a whole is growing in the double digits both by revenue and profit, according to a study.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim (second from left) and Minister of Digital Gobind Singh Deo at the launch of National AI Office on Thursday (Dec 12) in Kuala Lumpur.
Microsoft is also developing so-called reasoning models, which are designed to field more complex queries and display human-like problem-solving, the source says.
Microsoft’s results in late January underlined both why it has lately failed to excite investors, and also why few are throwing in the towel.
The push towards AI comes as videogame development costs continue to rise.

site_title: Google, Apple hit by EU regulatory crackdown
summary: The European Commission has issued charges against Google and Apple for breaching the Digital Markets Act (DMA), a landmark EU rule aimed at regulating Big Tech. Google faces fines of up to 10% of its global annual sales for allegedly restricting app developers from informing users of offers outside its app store and favoring its own services over rivals. Apple has been ordered to open its ecosystem to rivals, allowing other smartphone and virtual reality headset makers to connect with its iPhones and iPads. Both companies have pushed back, arguing that the measures will harm consumers and businesses.

images.alt_text: The 9a is being offered with the same 128 gigabytes of internal storage at the starting US$499 price or 256 gigabytes of storage for US$599.
Like Nvidia, Google also designs its own AI server chips, which it uses for internal research and development and also rents out to cloud customers.
Google will now have access to Reddit’s API for real-time, structured content, improving the accuracy and relevance of displayed information.
The startup provides cloud-based cybersecurity solutions powered by artificial intelligence that help companies identify and remove critical risks on cloud platforms.

site_title: Top Glove swings back to black with RM30.3 million Q2 profit
summary: Malaysian glove manufacturer Top Glove reported a net profit of RM30.3 million (S$9.1 million) for its second quarter, reversing a net loss of RM51.2 million in the year-ago period. Revenue rose 61% to RM883.7 million, driven by a sustained uptrend in glove orders and trade diversions due to US tariffs on Chinese glove exports. The company attributed improved profit margins to cost pass-through effects, better pricing, and increased production efficiency, with shares ending unchanged at S$0.275.

images.alt_text: Top Glove is optimistic about the recovery of the glove industry and expects orders to continue flowing in.

site_title: South Korea’s marriages jump, offering hopes for ageing nation
summary: South Korea reported a 14.8% increase in marriages in 2024, with over 222,000 couples tying the knot, the largest jump on record since 1990. This comes after the country's fertility rate increased for the first time in nine years in 2024. The rise may be attributed to government schemes encouraging marriage, such as parental leave compensation and mortgage interest rate reductions. The increased marriages offer hope for a nation struggling with a low fertility rate, which is contributing to an ageing population and fiscal burdens.

images.alt_text: Mortgage loan rates have also fallen since the Bank of Korea pivoted in October, making it easier to borrow money to buy homes
The decline at the beginning of this year coincides with the US implementing its export restrictions on cutting-edge semiconductors to China.

site_title: Hong Kong caps IPO margin loans amid heated retail demand
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has capped margin loans for initial public offerings (IPOs) at 90% of the IPO cost, requiring a 10% downpayment from retail investors to prevent excessive demand and potential losses. The move follows a recent market frenzy that triggered first-day share price pops and concerns about retail investors getting burned. The regulator aims to manage market risk and protect investors, after some brokers were found to have engaged in imprudent financing practices.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s monetary policy moves in lock-step with the United States as the city’s currency is pegged to the greenback in a tight range of 7.75 to 7.85 per US dollar.
The so-called indexed universal life policy allows premium holders to pledge assets, such as equities and bonds, to the insurance company as a custodian in lieu of paying cash.
While partial board lots are available to investors in Hong Kong, they are costlier than whole units because of infrastructure issues.

site_title: Ontario pension set to shut Hong Kong office in China retreat
summary: The Ontario Teachers' Pension Plan is closing its Hong Kong office due to rising geopolitical tensions, with some employees offered the opportunity to transfer to Singapore. The decision aims to reduce China exposure, with the pension fund planning to wind down "on-the-ground operations" over the next 18 months. The Hong Kong office will be shut down, while Ontario Teachers' will maintain a presence in Singapore and Mumbai.

images.alt_text: The Cheung Kong Center building, which houses the headquarters of CK Hutchison Holdings Ltd. and CK Asset Holdings Ltd., center, in Hong Kong, China, on Monday, March 17, 2025. Chinese authorities have begun looking into CK Hutchison's sale of its overseas port businesses, people familiar with the matter said, amid signs that Beijing is unhappy that the Hong Kong conglomerate divested its Panama operations under US pressure. Photographer: Leung Man Hei/Bloomberg

site_title: UK posts strong wage growth ahead of BOE rate decision
summary: UK wage growth remained strong, with average pay excluding bonuses rising 5.9% in the three months through January, in line with economists' expectations. Employment rose, defying fears of big job losses following Labour's budget hike in employment costs. The Bank of England is likely to keep interest rates on hold, citing a resilient demand for workers and concerns over a recent quickening in pay growth, which may lead to a resurgence in inflation.

images.alt_text: Brightmine said employers were cautious before April’s rise in payroll taxes and the median pay award in the three months to the end of February held at 3 per cent for the third consecutive rolling quarter.
Expectations of cheaper borrowing costs are easing some of the pressures on businesses.

site_title: HSBC’s revamp of key Asia division costs women senior roles
summary: HSBC has implemented a major overhaul of its Asia-Pacific division, resulting in women losing senior roles. Only two out of 15 new banking head roles were given to women, with Christina Ma and Amanda Murphy not selected for key positions. The restructuring aims to cut costs and complexity, with HSBC's new corporate and institutional banking division contributing $11.4 billion in pre-tax profits globally. Despite the lack of female representation in senior roles, HSBC has made efforts to increase female representation in other areas, with women holding 34.6% of senior leadership roles in 2024.

images.alt_text: A Hongkong Shanghai Banking Corporation (HSBC) company signage is seen on a building facade at the central business district in Singapore on March 14, 2025. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP)
HSBC Holdings CEO George Elhedery is finalising an investment-banking review worldwide that’s part of the firm’s biggest restructuring in at least a decade.
HSBC’s new CEO Georges Elhedery is undertaking a broad restructuring plan that includes winding down various businesses and slashing management ranks.
HSBC will incur US$1.8 billion in charges over the next two years as it embarks on the global restructuring programme that has seen the lender reduce management ranks.

site_title: Google launches US$499 Pixel 9a, rivalling Apple’s iPhone 16e
summary: Google has launched the US$499 Pixel 9a, a budget smartphone rivaling Apple's iPhone 16e. The new model features a 6.3-inch screen, improved battery life, and a new design with flat edges. The device also boasts a 48-megapixel main camera and a macro focus mode. The Pixel 9a is available in black, white, light blue, and pink, and will be sold in stores in April. This launch presents fresh competition in the lower-end phone space, where the Pixel 9a faces off against the iPhone 16e.

images.alt_text: Like Nvidia, Google also designs its own AI server chips, which it uses for internal research and development and also rents out to cloud customers.
Google will now have access to Reddit’s API for real-time, structured content, improving the accuracy and relevance of displayed information.
The startup provides cloud-based cybersecurity solutions powered by artificial intelligence that help companies identify and remove critical risks on cloud platforms.
Founded in 2017, AdHawk has created chips, hardware and software to enable advanced eye tracking.

site_title: Global funds exiting South-east Asia as Indonesia sell-off hurts safe haven appeal
summary: Global funds are rapidly exiting South-east Asia, pushing the MSCI Asean Index into a correction, as Indonesia's sell-off hurts the region's appeal as a safe haven. Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index has fallen 20% from a September record, with investors spooked by President Prabowo Subianto's consolidation of power and pessimism about Thailand's economy. The outflows underscore the region's diminished appeal at a time when Chinese stocks have gained traction, and investors are reassessing risk amid the US-China trade war and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: The Financial Services Authority and the Indonesia Stock Exchange announced the easing of share buyback policies to anticipate market volatility.
Wild price swings in stocks are a common and increasingly problematic feature of Indonesia’s equity market.

Traders walk as tickers display stock prices inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2015. Indonesian President Joko Widodo revamped his economic team in a cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday as China's currency devaluation spurred further declines in the rupiah. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: Hong Kong central bank keeps base rate unchanged as Fed holds steady
summary: The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) left its base rate unchanged at 4.75% on March 20, in line with the US Federal Reserve's decision to keep rates steady. Major banks maintained their lending rates, with HSBC at 5.25% and Standard Chartered at 5.5%. The HKMA stated that interest rates in Hong Kong may remain high for some time, and the Fed's interest rate cuts are uncertain. The monetary policy move is in lockstep with the US, with the Hong Kong dollar pegged to the US dollar in a tight range of 7.75-7.85 per US dollar.

images.alt_text: Supported by Art Basel and UBS, Singapore artist Ho Tzu Nyen used Artificial Intelligence to create lookalikes of Hong Kong screen legends, who will walk on the walls of M+ museum every night.
The so-called indexed universal life policy allows premium holders to pledge assets, such as equities and bonds, to the insurance company as a custodian in lieu of paying cash.

site_title: US: Stocks rise, Treasury yields tumble after Fed decision
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday after the Federal Reserve kept interest rates unchanged but cut its growth forecast for 2025 and hiked its inflation outlook. Treasury bond yields tumbled, leading to gains in the Dow Jones Industrial Average, S&P 500, and Nasdaq Composite Index. Despite the Fed's cautious tone, chair Jerome Powell expressed confidence in the US economic outlook.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 24, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Proposed US port fees on China-built ships begin choking coal, agriculture exports
summary: US President Donald Trump's proposed port fees on China-built ships could choke coal, agriculture, and energy exports, as vessels refuse to provide services due to the fees. The fees, up to $1.5 million, would target China-linked ships, potentially causing a 60-day halt in US coal exports worth $130 billion. This could also affect US energy exports, including oil and liquefied natural gas, and agriculture exports, such as corn and soybeans, potentially leading to significant job losses and increased costs for exporters.

images.alt_text: The meetings come as US tariffs escalate, highlighting Beijing’s drive to mend ties with global business leaders and mitigate disruptions.
A worker uses a forklift to move boxes of imported pork from the US at a cold storage warehouse in Shanghai, China, on Wednesday, March 5, 2025.

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 30: Shipping containers sit stacked in the Port of Newark on September 30, 2024 seen from New York City. A massive strike that could shut down ports across the East and Gulf coasts could begin at midnight as members of the International Longshoremen’s Association continue to make salary and other demands to the United States Maritime Alliance, which controls many of the ports across the country.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Vietnam to allow 49% foreign ownership of some banks
summary: Vietnam's government has announced a new decree allowing 49% foreign ownership of some banks, up from 30%, to quicken the State Bank of Vietnam's restructuring of troubled lenders. The new decree will take effect on May 19 and is aimed at encouraging foreign investment and strategic partnerships. This move comes after the transfer of two distressed banks, GPBank and DongA Bank, to other banks, and is seen as a step to boost the country's financial sector.

images.alt_text: A woman rides a motorbike past the State Bank of Vietnam in Hanoi on February 25, 2025. Across Vietnam, confused public sector workers are attempting to make sense of their new lives as ministries are merged and others are scrapped in an drastic attempt to slash billions of dollars from government budgets. (Photo by Nhac NGUYEN / AFP) / To go with 'VIETNAM-POLITICS-LAYOFFS,FOCUS'

FILE PHOTO: A logo of Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank (SCB) is seen in front of an under-construction building in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, November 30, 2023. REUTERS/Francesco Guarascio/File Photo
According to the Vietnam Food Association (VFA), Vietnam exported 1.15 million tons of rice in the first two months of 2025, up 10 per cent compared with the same period last year.
Securities companies will conduct a transition test from Mar 17 until Apr 11.

The much-anticipated partnership was announced at a joint press conference by Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Communist Party of Vietnam General Secretary To Lam, during the latter’s three-day official visit to Singapore that began on Tuesday.
GAIA solar farm in Long An province was Sembcorp's first utility-scale acquisition in Vietnam.

In recent years, Vietnam experienced a boom in renewable energy investments driven by generous feed-in tariffs, under which the state committed to buying electricity for 20 years at above-market prices.

Vietnam posted a trade deficit of US$1.55 billion in February, after a US$3.02 billion surplus in January, the General Statistics Office said. It was only the third monthly deficit since the start of 2023, as per GSO and London Stock Exchange Group data.
The dong has slumped more than 4 per cent against the US dollar this year, on track for its worst annual performance since 2015.

site_title: Europe: Shares extend gains to fourth session; all eyes on US Fed decision
summary: European shares rose 0.2% for a fourth consecutive session, driven by gains in industrials and energy stocks. The Stoxx 600 index extended its gains despite concerns over a global recession and the US Federal Reserve's interest-rate decision. German equities had jumped on Tuesday after the country's lower house approved a massive spending surge. Analysts say execution is key for the funding to materialize into long-term growth, and the Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 gained 0.61 per cent to close at 554.30 points, with European banks leading gains on Tuesday.

site_title: London city office sells to Strategic Value Partners at 62% discount to offer price
summary: Strategic Value Partners (SVP) agreed to acquire London's Senator office development at 85 Queen Victoria Street for over £60 million, a 60% discount from the initial asking price of £157 million in 2021. The property, fully refurbished but partially leased, is a rare sale in the market. Companies are focusing on newer, greener properties to encourage staff back to the office, leading to drops in valuation for older buildings. SVP's deal highlights a gradual return to the office market, with investors betting on rising rents and valuations due to the lack of new space.

images.alt_text: Tens of thousands of Britons are seeking to buy a house and risk more than £11,000 in extra charges if they miss the deadline.
First-time buyers in pricey areas such as London will be most affected when stamp duty thresholds become less generous
A row of terrace houses in Dorking, UK, on Monday, Nov. 25, 2024. The latest mortgage approval figures are due to be release on Friday, Nov. 29. Photographer: Jason Alden/Bloomberg

site_title: Why billionaire Li-Ka-shing’s Panama ports deal infuriated China
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's deal to sell his Panama Canal port assets to a consortium led by BlackRock has drawn the ire of Chinese President Xi Jinping, who believes Li acted against Chinese interests. The deal, worth $19 billion, is seen as a victory for US President Donald Trump, who has threatened to take over the Panama Canal. Li's conglomerate, CK Hutchison Holdings, will pocket the proceeds, while Li's fortune rose $1.3 billion following the announcement. Regulatory scrutiny has sent CK Hutchison shares tumbling, and China's top office in Hong Kong has signalled its displeasure with the deal.

images.alt_text: Cargo vessels docked at Balboa Port, operated by Panama Ports Company, at the Panama Canal, in Panama City, Panama, Feb 1, 2025.
Port of Balboa at the Panama Canal; CK Hutchison will sell 43 ports in 23 countries, while keeping facilities in mainland China and Hong Kong.
Li Ka-shing is unlikely to be the last billionaire caught between the world’s two biggest economies.
CK Hutchison said last week it agreed to sell most of the global US$22.8 billion ports business, including assets it holds along the strategically important Panama Canal, to a group led by BlackRock.

site_title: SoftBank Group to acquire Ampere Computing in US$6.5 billion AI-focused deal
summary: SoftBank Group is acquiring Ampere Computing, a US chip startup, in a $6.5 billion all-cash deal. Ampere makes data centre CPU chips based on Arm Holdings' architecture, used by firms like Oracle in cloud computing. Ampere's biggest investors, Oracle and Carlyle Group, will sell their positions. Under SoftBank's ownership, Ampere will partner with Arm to boost AI focus, with Renee James, Ampere's founder, excited about the deal.

images.alt_text: Malaysia, which packages roughly a tenth of the world’s semiconductors, has inked a pact to pay Arm Holdings US$250 million over a period of ten years for a slew of semiconductor-related licenses and knowhow.
The logo of SoftBank is displayed at a company shop in Tokyo, Japan January 28, 2025.  REUTERS/Issei Kato
SoftBank's discussions come as hyperscalers tap new financing methods to pay for soaring costs of AI hardware.

site_title: US Fed holds rates again, flags increased economic uncertainty
summary: The US Federal Reserve held interest rate cuts steady, citing increased economic uncertainty amid President Trump's stop-start tariff rollout. Fed Chair Jerome Powell noted a slight rise in recession risk, citing chaotic policy and unclear long-term effects of tariffs. The Fed trimmed its 2025 growth forecast and raised inflation outlook, while maintaining two rate cuts for the year. Policymakers expressed caution, with one governor rebelling against the decision to slow the balance sheet reduction pace.

images.alt_text: Michelle Bowman, a former community banker, was nominated by Trump to the Fed’s governing board in 2018.
On Wednesday, US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell may have to deliver some bracing news: the post-pandemic era of inflation may have been extended by the trade war.

Over the years, Fed policymakers and economists have made a range of suggestions about how to improve the dot plot, which has been published in its current form since well before Powell became chair in 2018.

site_title: Germany’s incoming government has embraced military Keynesianism
summary: Germany's incoming government has amended its constitutional "debt brake" to boost defense spending, allowing for unlimited military expenditure. This marks a shift towards military Keynesianism, prioritizing defense spending over climate investments and green technologies. The move is seen as a response to US President Donald Trump's re-election and the weakening of collective defense commitments. However, critics argue that this will lead to a reallocation of resources away from green technologies and towards the military sector, potentially fueling support for far-right parties and jeopardizing national security and climate objectives.

images.alt_text: German chancellor-in-waiting Friedrich Merz has vowed to strengthen Europe so that it can achieve independence from the US.
Beyond financing, Europe is equipped to provide most of the military supplies Ukraine needs, like tanks, guns, and ammunition.
The pan-European Stoxx 600 index closed up 1.1 per cent, at a record high, building on 10 straight weeks of gains.

site_title: Singapore’s capital market research scene trapped in ‘chicken-and-egg’ situation: DBS’ Han Kwee Juan
summary: Singapore's capital market research scene is facing a "chicken-and-egg" situation, where research is needed to boost trading activity but must also be financially justified. According to DBS' Han Kwee Juan, research is essential for investor interest, but it requires underlying capital market activities to be financially viable. To address this, executives need to be trained to effectively communicate their businesses' growth plans and valuations, and the government aims to galvanize equity market activity across sectors.

images.alt_text: Panellists DBS group head of institutional banking Han Kwee Juan (left) and Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah (centre) with moderator The Business Times deputy news editor Anita Gabriel (right).
Future-proofing businesses for resiliency was the theme of The Business Times Singapore Budget 2025 Dialogue.

site_title: Gold climbs to record high as Fed signals two rate cuts in 2025
summary: Gold reached a record high of US$3,055.31 per ounce on March 20, driven by the US Federal Reserve's signal of possible interest rate cuts by year-end. The Fed's decision to hold its benchmark overnight rate steady in the 4.25-4.5% range, despite expectations of two quarter-percentage-point rate cuts, boosted gold prices. Ongoing geopolitical and economic uncertainties, including US tariffs and tensions in the Middle East, have also contributed to the metal's rally, making it a hedge against uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Gold has gained over 15 per cent year-to-date.

site_title: Trendlines terminates subsidiary CEO Anton Wibowo for stealing US$2.1 million
summary: Trendlines Group has terminated CEO Anton Wibowo for allegedly stealing US$2.1 million from the company's subsidiaries, including Trendlines Agrifood Innovation Centre and Agrifood Fund. An independent investigation found that Wibowo misappropriated funds, mostly depositing them into his personal bank account. The company will consider legal action and asset recovery, and interim CEO Stephen Rhodes will oversee the Trendlines Agrifood Innovation Centre.

images.alt_text: Based on an initial assessment, Trendlines does not expect the amount involved in the suspected misappropriations to have a financial impact on the group for the current fiscal year.

site_title: Oil rises on US fuel demand, Fed rate decision caps gains
summary: Oil prices rose on Wednesday, with Brent crude futures up 22 US cents to $70.78 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude up 26 US cents to $67.16 a barrel, after the US government reported a draw in fuel inventories. However, the Federal Reserve's decision to hold interest rates steady capped gains. The Israeli military resumed ground operations in Gaza, sparking geopolitical risks and Mideast instability, which traders are refocusing on. The Fed also signaled it may reduce borrowing costs by half a percentage point by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: Brent futures fell 51 cents, or 0.7 per cent, to settle at US$70.56 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude fell 68 cents, or 1.0 per cent, to settle at US$66.90 on Tuesday.

site_title: Prudential eyes growth in India as it posts 2% decline in new business profit for FY2024
summary: Prudential reported a 2% decline in new business profit to $3.08 billion for FY2024, with 14 markets achieving double-digit year-on-year growth. The insurer is betting on India, aiming to expand its life and health businesses, with a joint venture with HCL Group's promoter company Vama Sundari Investments to operate a standalone health insurance business. Prudential's CEO Anil Wadhwani sees opportunities to create shareholder value, including the potential listing of its Indian joint venture, ICICI Prudential Asset Management, subject to market conditions and regulatory approvals.

images.alt_text: Prudential considers India to be a strategically important market with compelling growth prospects.
Prudential gives out S$3.5m in cash benefits, donations amid Covid-19

site_title: China holds benchmark lending rates steady as expected
summary: China's People's Bank of China (PBOC) held benchmark lending rates steady for the fifth straight month, matching market expectations. The one-year loan prime rate (LPR) remained at 3.1% and the five-year LPR unchanged at 3.6%. The decision was influenced by recent economic data showing signs of recovery and the PBOC's shift to an "appropriately loose" monetary policy stance. Despite concerns over the renminbi's value, it has managed modest gains against the US dollar this year.

images.alt_text: Chinese bonds have come under pressure this year as the central bank has refrained from lowering interest rates or banks’ required reserve ratio since September.
The PBOC has capped the yuan’s drop this year to its daily reference rate, which limits moves in the onshore yuan by 2 per cent on either side.
Gold has set successive records this year, though profit-taking temporarily dampened the rally last week.

site_title: Real estate sector sees robust activity, but Singapore professionals not ahead in salaries
summary: Singapore's real estate sector remains robust, with healthy investment and new home sales, but salaries for professionals lag behind regional peers. According to a Macdonald & Co. survey, the Republic's average annual median salary for the property sector is US$88,000, behind Vietnam (US$178,000) and other Asian countries. Despite this, the Singapore market is driving demand, with recent investment sales reaching S$25 billion.

images.alt_text: (FILES) A general view shows the city skyline in Singapore on October 25, 2023. A high-stakes father-and-son feud has plunged Singapore property giant City Developments Ltd into turmoil, with a private boardroom dispute for one of the city-state's wealthiest families erupting into public view this week. (Photo by Roslan RAHMAN / AFP) / To go with 'SINGAPORE-CONSTRUCTION-FAMILY,FOCUS' by Martin ABBUGAO

site_title: Australia employment posts surprise fall in February, jobless rate steady
summary: Australia's employment numbers fell 52,800 in February, missing market forecasts for a 30,000 rise, and annual jobs growth slowed to 1.9% from 3.5% in the previous month. Despite a steady jobless rate of 4.1%, the employment data was a surprise, and the Australian dollar dropped 0.3% to US$0.6340. The Reserve Bank of Australia still expects core inflation to reach 2.7% later this year, but the surprise employment data may prompt a rate cut in May, now priced at 78%, up from 70% previously.

images.alt_text: RBA Governor Michele Bullock (pictured) and her deputy Andrew Hauser have both said in recent weeks that the bank does not believe a series of rate cuts will be required.
The prospect of quickening inflation is a blow to both consumers and the government, which is keen for a cost-of-living crisis to ease ahead of an election due by May 17.

ASX’s group executive of listings, Blair Beaton, said dual-class shares had not been allowed in Australia previously which was placing the domestic market at a disadvantage compared to its major global rivals.
A survey from National Australia Bank showed its index of business conditions edged up 1 point to +4 in February, but remained below long-run averages.

site_title: Ripple Labs says US SEC ends appeal over crypto oversight
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) has ended its appeal over a court ruling that the regulator's prior chief had said would make it harder to oversee cryptocurrency markets. The decision comes after a July 2023 ruling that the XRP token sold by Ripple on public exchanges did not meet the legal definition of a security. Ripple Labs' CEO Brad Garlinghouse called the end of the SEC appeal a "resounding victory," while the SEC declined to comment on the matter.

images.alt_text: The SEC has several major cases against crypto exchanges and issuers, accusing them of offering unregistered securities.

site_title: Backing Asia’s chip champions in a riskier world
summary: Asia's semiconductor industry, led by Taiwan's TSMC, faces growing challenges including shifting trade policies, cybersecurity risks, and natural disasters. A powerful 7.4-magnitude earthquake in April 2024 and another earlier this year forced TSMC to temporarily halt facilities. The industry is poised for explosive growth, with AI-related revenue predicted to increase 45% annually over the next five years, driven by surging AI demand. To ensure resilience, companies must adopt strategies to mitigate these risks and capitalize on emerging opportunities.
