site_title: Nvidia CEO says company has not been asked to buy a stake in Intel
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang has denied that the company has been approached to purchase a stake in Intel, contradicting earlier reports. Huang stated that Nvidia was not invited to a potential consortium involving Intel, TSMC, and other companies. He also expressed confidence in demand for Nvidia's AI chips, citing a recent order of 3.6 million Blackwell chips from cloud service providers, and highlighted the growing need for computation driven by AI focus on reasoning. Nvidia's shares rose after the remarks, despite investors' concerns about the company's response to a shift in the AI market.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang delivers the keynote for the Nvidia GPU Technology Conference (GTC) at the SAP Center in San Jose, California, U.S. March 18, 2025.  REUTERS/Brittany Hosea-Small/File Photo

site_title: Access to funding, talent key to businesses’ transformation efforts: panellists
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 emphasizes the need for businesses to access funding and talent to transform and innovate, particularly in the face of geopolitical uncertainty and rising business costs. The government aims to support this by introducing policies such as the SkillsFuture Level-Up Programme and the ITE Progression Award, which grant training and financial support to workers. Panellists also highlighted the importance of reskilling workers and leveraging AI to drive transformation, with the government seeking to nudge AI adoption across different levels of society.

images.alt_text: Panellists DBS group head of institutional banking Han Kwee Juan (left) and Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah (centre) with moderator The Business Times deputy news editor Anita Gabriel (right).

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says the government’s partnership with enterprises will become increasingly important for Singapore’s growth as the world faces a more dangerous, turbulent and volatile external environment.

site_title: Apple ordered by EU antitrust regulators to open up to rivals
summary: EU antitrust regulators ordered Apple to open up its closed ecosystem to rivals, requiring access to its technology and mobile operating system for seamless connectivity. Apple responded by slamming the order, claiming it would hurt users and aid its rivals. The European Commission's landmark rules aim to rein in Big Tech power. Apple may face an investigation and fines up to 10% of its global annual sales if it fails to comply.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit alleged Apple violated antitrust law by coercing customers to use the company’s iCloud service to back up core data and device setting files.
Apple has denied wrongdoing and said it is a small player in India where phones that use Google’s Android system are dominant.
The move follows a warning to Apple in June that it must give developers effective means to steer users away from its App Store or face future penalties.
EU warns Apple to open up iPhone operating system

site_title: Nike’s chief strategy, communications officers exit in shakeup
summary: Nike's top strategy and communications executives, Daniel Heaf and KeJuan Wilkins, are leaving the company as part of a leadership shakeup under CEO Elliott Hill. Heaf's role is being eliminated, and his teams will be integrated into the finance department. Wilkins, who served for nearly 20 years, is also departing without a replacement. The company is attempting to end a sales slump after a tumultuous year of corporate layoffs and the CEO change, with Hill reshaping the company to return to its sports roots and rekindle relationships with retail partners.

images.alt_text: Nike has been scrambling to regain dominance in the market, shelling out money to introduce new products and to promote staple franchises such as Jordans and Pegasus.
Foot Locker predicted adjusted earnings of US$1.50 to US$1.70 a share for this fiscal year, falling short of analysts’ expectations.

site_title: From Trump’s ‘tariff tantrum’ to the Johor-Singapore SEZ: highlights from BT’s post-Budget dialogue
summary: The Singapore Budget 2025 Dialogue discussed key issues such as managing costs, the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariffs, and the success of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (SEZ). Second Minister for Finance and National Development Indranee Rajah emphasized the government's role as a catalyst, providing grants and financing schemes to support businesses. She encouraged companies to tap into the Productivity Solutions Grant and innovation schemes to reduce costs. The panel also touched on the potential of the JS-SEZ, highlighting the need for complementarity between Singapore and Johor.

images.alt_text: Future-proofing businesses for resiliency was the theme of The Business Times Singapore Budget 2025 Dialogue.
The surprise surplus in Budget 2025 was lifted by unexpectedly high corporate income tax takings, as well as the net investment returns contribution.

Prime Minister Lawrence Wong says the government’s partnership with enterprises will become increasingly important for Singapore’s growth as the world faces a more dangerous, turbulent and volatile external environment.
US President Donald Trump’s second act promises a return of the much-dreaded tariffs that put Asean smack in the crosshairs of collateral damage.

site_title: Top three floors at 20 Collyer Quay transact for S$91.8 million
summary: The top three floors of 20 Collyer Quay in Singapore's District 1 have been sold for S$91.8 million, or S$3,148 per square foot. The 29,160 square-foot floors are part of a 999-year leasehold office building owned by GuocoLand. The sale excludes leases of several office units sold to third parties. GuocoLand will take over the asset management of the units, with 100% effective interest in the 24-storey office block.

images.alt_text: GuocoLand can leverage Hong Leong's network in Malaysia as it pursues opportunities in Johor.
In August last year, GuocoLand obtained S$847.1 million in green financing that would go into financing its Upper Thomson (Parcel B) site.
CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust is the largest S-Reit in Singapore, and it holds a diversified exposure including office and retail assets.

site_title: Semiconductor firms call for EU Chips Act 2.0
summary: European semiconductor firms are calling for the European Commission to launch a "Chips Act 2.0" to address the industry's supply chain needs, including chip design, materials, and equipment. The initial 2023 Chips Act provided funding for manufacturing but failed to attract cutting-edge chipmakers. Industry groups Esia and Semi Europe urge the Commission to provide subsidies for suppliers to strengthen the industry. A new program is seen as a counterweight to larger state support in the US and China, with European firms citing the need to compete with Asian chip champions.

images.alt_text: (FILES) People walk beside a logo outside the Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company (TSMC) Museum of Innovation at its headquarters in Hsinchu on November 21, 2024. Taiwan will maintain its "key position" in the global semiconductor chip supply chain, the island's Premier Cho Jung-tai vowed on March 4, 2025, after TSMC announced a 100 billion USD investment in new plants in the United States. (Photo by I-Hwa CHENG / AFP)

site_title: Homage to nature or the future? This house is both, with colossal rooms to match
summary: A modern 7,042-square-foot house in Singapore was designed to pay homage to its natural surroundings, with a striking facade of tiered arches inspired by the curves of tree branches. The 7-story house, built by Czarl Architects, boasts colossal rooms and offers breathtaking views of the nearby MacRitchie Reservoir park. The design aims to blend seamlessly into the forest environment, creating a unique and harmonious living space.

images.alt_text: Dr Tan is one of a small number of landed homeowners who choose to keep their property in a single-storey form.
This old apartment in Laguna Park has been turned into a dual key home.
Originally built in the early 1970s, this intermediate terrace house has been totally transformed.
75 Maude Road had been left derelict for many years before being restored.

site_title: Polishing the image of the cleaning industry
summary: RS Facilities Services, a Singapore-based cleaning industry company, aims to polish the image of the sector through innovation and sustainability. Founded in 2013 by director Michelle Yap and operations director Tay Chin Chye, the company has grown to a workforce of 1,300 and achieved various accreditations, including the highest tier of National Environment Agency (NEA) licensing. Despite facing recruitment challenges due to the industry's negative image, RS is working to change perceptions by partnering with NEA to offer scholarships and introducing smart solutions to elevate its services.

images.alt_text: Tee Up Capital CEO Kelvin Low at the company’s flagship PPT Lodge 1A dormitory in Seletar North.
Buildo Engineering founder and managing director Mike Wong showcasing his cork construction products, which are greener than wood.

site_title: Inspiring stakeholder confidence in times of uncertainty
summary: Boards and management should use the annual general meeting to demonstrate proactive anticipation of changes and intentional action to shape the future of their organizations. In today's complex macro environment, characterized by Vuca (volatility, uncertainty, complexity, and ambiguity), companies face significant challenges, particularly uncertainty. To inspire stakeholder confidence, they must communicate compelling long-term and strategic plans. This will enable them to address risks and invest in long-term growth, ultimately shaping the future of their organizations.

images.alt_text: Beyond regular reporting, companies should leverage the AGM to demonstrate their ability to navigate a complex environment and articulate a strategic direction for the future.
Post-pandemic, allowing hybrid AGMs demonstrates that the board is flexible in meeting shareholders’ preferences, whether they value face-to-face interactions or the convenience of virtual sessions.

site_title: Thomson Medical to build 300-bed hospital in Johor, banks on JS-SEZ medical hub potential
summary: Thomson Medical Group plans to build a 300-bed hospital in Johor, Malaysia, with completion expected by 2030. The hospital, part of the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ), will focus on oncology, orthopaedics, and obstetrics and gynaecology. Construction is set to begin by the end of 2025 or early 2026. The hospital will have a location advantage, being the closest to the Causeway between Singapore and Malaysia, and is expected to attract medical tourists from Singapore and Indonesia. Thomson Medical Group has been looking for healthcare partners to develop the land around the hospital.

images.alt_text: Medical tourism in Asia is on the rise.
Facade of Thomson Medical Centre on Aug 29, 2022.
The quality of foreign operators that come to China will be also crucial for the development of the sector.
The Aljunied centre's capacity has increased to 28 dialysis stations from 18 stations previously, and can serve 168 patients, up from 108.
Eczema has been gaining in prevalence in Singapore over the last few years, as more patients become aware of the illness and look to treat the symptoms.
Gleneagles Hospital.
Patients can get their scopes done within 36 hours at Curasia's centres.

site_title: UBS sees China property turnaround coming sooner than expected
summary: UBS predicts China's property sector will recover sooner than expected, with home prices expected to "turn stable" at the beginning of next year. This is attributed to a pickup in second-hand home transactions, increase in premium land sales, and a more stable volume of home listings. The recovery is also seen as similar to the 2014-2015 rebound, with inventory turnover time in tier-one cities returning to 14 months. Regional developers in top-tier cities are expected to benefit, while those operating nationwide may struggle.

site_title: New Zealand exits recession as Q4 growth beats forecasts
summary: New Zealand's economy has exited recession, with a 0.7% growth in the fourth quarter, beating forecasts. Annual GDP decreased by 1.1%, but the improvement is not expected to change the central bank's planned rate cuts. Policymakers are seeking relief after a technical recession in the September quarter, with risks to growth rising due to US President Donald Trump's policies and a potential global economic downturn. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand is expected to cut rates just twice more, with some economists suggesting a possible rate cut below 3%.

images.alt_text: Pedestrians cross a street in a shopping district in Wellington, New Zealand. Photographer: Mark Coote/Bloomberg
New Zealand joins other nations in trying to hammer out free trade agreements with India.
Christopher Luxon’s centre-right government wants more foreign direct investment to boost economic growth ahead of a 2026 election.
Antonia Watson is among bank bosses speaking to the committee as part of its inquiry into banking competition.
The construction industry has struggled to recover after being impacted in early 2024 by rising costs for both materials and finance.

site_title: Singapore stocks close higher midweek ahead of Fed rate decision; STI up 0.3%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed 0.3% higher, ending at 3,908.31 points, as investors awaited the US Federal Reserve's interest rate decision. The STI rose despite a mixed performance in Asian markets and tech-led losses on Wall Street. Seatrium was the biggest decliner, while ST Engineering was the top gainer. The Monetary Authority of Singapore maintained a median growth forecast of 2.6% for 2025, citing private-sector economists' expectations.

images.alt_text: Ranamita Chakraborty
ST Engineering is eyeing a revenue of S$17 billion and a net profit improvement that outpaces its top-line increases by up to five percentage points annually over the next five years.
Projected earnings growth for plantation players in 2025 is driven by firm selling prices amid tight supply and strong demand.

site_title: In the US, a pastry chef attempts to crack an egg-free menu
summary: US pastry chef Annie Clemmons has been working on an egg-free menu after avian flu made eggs a luxury item. She uses aquafaba, the liquid from cooked chickpeas, as a substitute for egg whites and cornstarch for thickening. Prices for eggs have increased by over 59% and are now 45 cents per egg, with Clemmons' business struggling to maintain due to reduced demand. The White House has reported a drop in wholesale egg prices, but these have yet to be reflected in store prices.

images.alt_text: US wholesale egg prices are shattering records as an accelerating outbreak of bird flu in laying hens slashes supplies.

site_title: CareShield Life: affordable cover for a potentially long-term financial burden
summary: Singapore's CareShield Life long-term care insurance scheme provides affordable coverage for severe disability, with payouts increasing annually until age 67 or claim. The scheme, launched in 2020, offers higher payouts and can be paid for life or as long as claimant is unable to perform three ADLs. Unlike ElderShield, it doesn't require 30 years of premium payments before benefits can be claimed. The Ministry of Health has clarified inaccuracies in a WhatsApp message, stating CareShield Life can make payouts anytime a policyholder suffers from disabilities.

images.alt_text: An elderly walking up the stairs in the direction towards a 24-hr clinic at Hougang Village on Jan 10, 2020.
Financial planning is crucial when it comes to disability.

David Yip (right), head of accident and health business at Great Eastern and Willis Lau (left), Great Eastern financial representative and financial influencer speak to us about the importance of having disability insurance.

site_title: Siemens’ new Singapore factory on track despite move to cut 6,000 jobs globally
summary: Siemens is cutting over 6,000 jobs globally, with 2% of its workforce affected, mostly in its factory automation business. The company has no confirmed plans to lay off employees in Singapore, despite opening a new Tuas factory in 2025 or 2026. The factory will serve the growing South-east Asian markets and is not expected to be impacted by the job cuts. Siemens will implement the cuts "responsibly" through natural fluctuation, early retirement, and internal movements, and will support affected employees in finding new roles.

images.alt_text: The sale comes after Siemens said last year it could sell shares in Siemens Healthineers to pay for its US$10.6 billion acquisition of Altair Engineering.
Chief executive Roland Busch said the company had made a “promising start” to its 2025 fiscal year, which runs to the end of September.
FILE PHOTO: A sign with the logo of Siemens company is on display outside its office in Moscow, Russia, May 12, 2022. REUTERS/Evgenia Novozhenina

site_title: Where will be the next electric-vehicle superpower?
summary: Three Asian countries, Thailand, Indonesia, and Vietnam, are vying to become electric vehicle (EV) production hubs. Thailand's aggressive "EV 3.0" scheme has led to a 15% share of auto sales, while Indonesia aims to leverage its dominance in EV-making minerals and Vietnam relies on its national champion, VinFast. However, each country faces challenges, including net job losses in Thailand, tax giveaways in Indonesia, and VinFast's struggles to turn a profit. The region risks squandering resources and becoming assembly hubs, with only one potential winner emerging.

images.alt_text: BYD’s entrance in July into Vietnam underscores both the opportunities and challenges Chinese companies face as they seek to push into South-east Asia.
Governments in E
The new VinFast VF 6 at India's auto show in New Delhi; the company not disclose pricing for the VF6 and VF7 cars that it plans to launch in India.

site_title: Tencent sets HK$80 billion buyback after sales beat estimates
summary: Tencent Holdings reported a 11% revenue growth to 172.5 billion yuan (S$31.8 billion) for the three months ended December, exceeding projections. The company plans to spend at least HK$80 billion (S$13.6 billion) on share buybacks and proposes a 32% rise in annual dividends. Tencent aims to allocate a low-teens percentage of its 2025 revenue towards capital expenditures, including AI infrastructure, with a focus on in-house and open-sourced models. The company's market valuation has gained 30% or US$140 billion this year, driven by a broader Chinese tech rally.

images.alt_text: Tencent’s five new 3D-content generators are built atop its Hunyuan3D-2.0 model, all of which it intends to open-source to users.
Three of the top five most downloaded free apps are AI bots, with ByteDance’s Doubao joining Tencent and DeepSeek.

Tencent said that the Hunyuan Turbo S is able to reply to queries within a second, distinguishing itself “from DeepSeek R1, Hunyuan T1, and other slow thinking models that need to ‘think for a while before answering’”.

A giant screen shows news footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured), at a shopping complex in Beijing, China February 17, 2025. In a beta test, Weixin is testing access to DeepSeek for searches, Tencent said in a statement to Reuters.

site_title: Pfizer sells entire Haleon stake for US$3.24 billion
summary: Pfizer sells its entire stake in Haleon for approximately US$3.24 billion to institutional investors and the consumer healthcare firm. The sale represents 7.3% of Haleon's issued share capital. As part of the deal, Haleon agrees to buy back 44 million shares from Pfizer and sell 618 million shares to institutional investors. This marks the end of Pfizer's involvement in the company, which was spun off from GSK in 2022. Following the sale, BlackRock Investment Management becomes Haleon's largest shareholder with over 5% stake.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Pfizer company logo is seen at a Pfizer office in Puurs, Belgium, December 2, 2022. REUTERS/Johanna Geron/File Photo

site_title: US dollar rises ahead of Fed; Turkish lira drop reins in G10 currencies
summary: The US dollar rose 0.2% against a basket of currencies to 103.55, ahead of the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision, as investors sought safe-haven assets amid market volatility. The euro fell 0.3% to a five-month high of $1.091, while the yen weakened against the dollar following the Bank of Japan's decision to hold interest rates steady. The Fed's decision is expected to keep rates on hold, and investors are pricing in nearly 60 basis points of rate cuts by year-end, citing policy uncertainty and stagflation concerns.

site_title: From sci-fi to sustainability: The radical fashion of Iris van Herpen
summary: Iris van Herpen, a renowned Dutch fashion designer, is redefining couture with eco-conscious designs, showcasing her commitment to sustainability in her latest exhibition at the ArtScience Museum in Singapore. Her sculptural, surreal creations, worn by A-listers such as Lady Gaga and Beyonce, are not only visually striking but also push the boundaries of fashion and technology. Van Herpen's approach is slow and deliberate, releasing just one collection a year, and collaborating with scientists, environmentalists, and engineers to develop innovative, eco-friendly materials.

images.alt_text: Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.
O2genes is one of the players in the longevity market, specialising in oxygen therapy.

site_title: Beijing woos global executives as FDI slides, trade tensions build
summary: Chinese trade officials held meetings with global executives, including CEOs from PepsiCo, Airbus, and Bristol Myers Squibb, to boost investment in China despite a consumer slump and renewed trade tensions. US tariffs have escalated, prompting Beijing's charm offensive to mend ties with global business leaders. The meetings came after FDI plummeted 27.1% in 2024, with six US companies and European, British, and Australian multinationals participating. Officials assured global companies of China's long-term economic prospects, with some pledging to increase investment.

images.alt_text: Xi Jinping is trying to reverse foreign investment outflows and persistent economic weakness.
Chinese authorities will need to step in with forceful measures to help the property market bottom out, if Trump tariffs rise significantly, economists say.

A giant screen shows news footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured), at a shopping complex in Beijing, China February 17, 2025. REUTERS/Florence Lo

site_title: Tariff threats spur TSMC’s Taiwan peers to seek US expansion
summary: Taiwan's tech companies, including TSMC and Foxconn, are shifting manufacturing to the US amid US tariff threats, with investments totaling over $1 trillion since President Trump's second term. TSMC has pledged $100 billion to build five new US factories, while Foxconn is expanding production in Texas and Pennsylvania. Smaller Taiwanese companies, such as Wiwynn and Quanta Computer, are also investing in the US. Despite challenges, including union clashes and labor costs, these companies see the US as a key market and are seeking to establish a presence there.

images.alt_text: TSMC CEO CC Wei said that the company’s US$100 billion investment plan announced this week would not impact the chipmaker’s expansion in Taiwan amid concerns it could damage the island’s semiconductor industry.
Trump and TSMC announce US$100 billion plan to build five new US factories

Intel was among the largest beneficiaries of the US push to onshore critical chip manufacturing led by former president Joe Biden’s administration.

site_title: Hong Kong’s Link Reit should consider listing a Singapore-centric Reit on SGX
summary: Link Reit, Hong Kong's largest real estate investment trust, is considering listing a Singapore-centric Reit on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to achieve a better trading multiple and grow its fund management business. The trust owns properties in Hong Kong, China, Australia, Singapore, and the UK, but its Hong Kong-listed shares are trading at a 44% discount to its net asset value. A Singapore-listed Reit could command a better trading multiple, creating value for Link Reit's unitholders, and allow Link Asset Management to broaden its investor base and grow its fund management business.

images.alt_text: Will MAS review group's plan transform SGX or fall short?
“The Reit will be able to take the heavy lifting of our assets," says chief executive Kong Chee Min.

site_title: Singapore government will take industry feedback seriously as business ties grow more important: PM Wong
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the importance of partnerships with businesses in the country's growth phase, citing a turbulent and volatile external environment. The government will take industry feedback seriously, but not every request can be granted due to resource or policy limitations. Instead, the government will explain its position and find alternative solutions to address concerns. Key measures included providing relief for higher business costs and strengthening the enterprise ecosystem.

site_title: South Korea moves to curtail rising speculation in home market
summary: South Korea's government plans to curb rising speculation in the home market by designating areas with apartment buyers requiring permits. The move comes as apartment prices in high-income areas like Gangnam have jumped since easing rules on transaction permits. The government also plans to tighten regulations on housing loans to prevent a potential increase in household debt and fuel an economy struggling after President Yoon Suk-yeol's martial law declaration.

images.alt_text: The decline at the beginning of this year coincides with the US implementing its export restrictions on cutting-edge semiconductors to China.
South Korea’s acting President Choi Sang-mok ordered the government to more actively communicate with the US administration to resolve any misunderstanding over tariffs.
The latest tariffs add to trade measures introduced in Trump’s first term, removing exemptions for many nations and extending them to new categories of products.

site_title: Swatch CEO again floats idea of going private, sending shares up
summary: Swatch Group is exploring a potential take-private of the Swiss watchmaker, with CEO Nick Hayek stating that he hopes to find someone to "help take us private." Shares rose 4.3% after the comments, as the company faces challenges in a difficult market environment, including rising metal costs and weak demand in China. Hayek, who controls 44% of the voting rights, has previously suggested taking the company private but has not indicated he is willing to take on the debt needed to buy out other shareholders.

images.alt_text: Swatch Group posts sales rising by 5.2 per cent last year to 7.88 billion Swiss francs.
“I always said that taking the company private would be a nice thing to do and, at so ridiculous low share prices that we saw since quite some time, even more seducing,” Swatch CEO Nick Hayek said.
Like other luxury watchmakers, Swatch has been under pressure since soaring inflation caused consumers to curb their spending after a pandemic boom.

site_title: SAP Labs partners NUS to train AI researchers
summary: SAP Labs Singapore has partnered with the National University of Singapore (NUS) under the Industrial Postgraduate Programme to train nine AI researchers by the end of 2030. The programme, supported by the Economic Development Board (EDB), aims to strengthen Singapore's AI talent pipeline. This collaboration follows SAP Labs' earlier commitment to hire 200 AI engineers in Singapore, which has seen the company's headcount triple to 420 in the past three years.

images.alt_text: From left: Sea chairman and CEO Forrest Li, Education Minister Chan Chun Sing and NUS Board of Trustees chairman Hsieh Fu Hua at the opening of Sea Building and Sea Connect.
Oracle's new AI centre of excellence in Singapore will accommodate both large and small enterprises.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 19)
summary: Geopolitical tensions and higher tariffs remain a downside risk to Singapore's domestic outlook, with economists forecasting a 2.6% growth for the country in 2025. Despite this, resident employment grew last year, reversing the decline in 2023. The Singapore government will take industry feedback seriously as business ties grow more important, with PM Wong stating the government will address concerns. Indonesia has eased buyback rules to restore investor confidence after a sharp decline in the local stock market.

images.alt_text: Traders walk as tickers display stock prices inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2015. Indonesian President Joko Widodo revamped his economic team in a cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday as China's currency devaluation spurred further declines in the rupiah. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Wall Street opens higher ahead of Fed decision
summary: Wall Street opened higher on March 19, 2025, ahead of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 84.73 points, or 0.20%, to 41,666.04, while the S&P 500 gained 18.29 points, or 0.33%, to 5,632.95. The Nasdaq Composite also rose 84.20 points, or 0.50%, to 17,588.32. The gains come as investors await the Fed's decision, which has been influenced by trade policies and their impact on the economy.

site_title: Malaysia agrees to terms for restarting MH370 wreckage search
summary: Malaysia has agreed to terms with Ocean Infinity to resume the search for the wreckage of MH370, a Boeing 777 that vanished in 2014 with 227 passengers and 12 crew. The search will cover 15,000 sq km in the southern Indian Ocean under a "no find, no fee" principle. Ocean Infinity will receive $70 million if the wreckage is successfully located. The search contract, initially set to last 18 months, will allow the government to provide closure for the families of the MH370 passengers.

images.alt_text: Malaysia Airlines flight MH370 carrying 239 people disappeared from radar screens on Mar 8, 2014 while en route from Kuala Lumpur to Beijing.

site_title: UK's Intermediate Capital mulls sale of PSB Academy in Singapore, WSJ reports
summary: UK-based asset manager Intermediate Capital Group is planning to sell PSB Academy, a Singaporean tertiary education institution, citing exploration of options. The sale could value the institution at up to SGD 700 million. ICG acquired PSB Academy in 2018 for an undisclosed sum and manages assets worth approximately USD 107 billion. The firm has engaged corporate advisory firm Rippledot Capital Advisers to explore its options.

site_title: Ben & Jerry’s says parent Unilever decided to oust ice cream maker’s CEO over political stance
summary: Ben & Jerry's claims Unilever ousted CEO Dave Stever due to his commitment to the company's social mission and brand integrity, despite concerns about his job performance. The move escalates a battle over the subsidiary's independence on social policy issues. Unilever has blocked Ben & Jerry's from honouring Black History Month and supporting the release of a detained pro-Palestinian activist, leading to accusations of "new levels of oppressiveness." The dispute comes as Unilever prepares to spin off Ben & Jerry's and other ice cream brands later this year.

images.alt_text: The company and its advisers are evaluating a range of options including a listing in the US, which is the biggest market for its ice cream brands like Ben & Jerry’s.

site_title: Malaysia’s Silicon Valley ambitions face tough challenges
summary: Malaysia aims to become a major player in the global semiconductor industry, but faces significant challenges, including a talent crunch, funding problems, and supply chain gaps. The country has signed a major deal with British chip giant Arm Holdings to access its intellectual property and train 10,000 local engineers. Experts warn that Malaysia needs to overcome internal constraints to compete with top regional industry giants, including Taiwan, South Korea, and Japan, and notes that building semiconductor ecosystems will require time and careful planning.

images.alt_text: Oracle will provide Singapore’s armed forces and defence ministry with an “air-gapped” isolated cloud computing infrastructure.
Miri offers cost-competitive land, a skilled workforce, and abundant renewable energy, positioning northern Sarawak as a hub for green industries and advanced manufacturing.

Above: Johor Bahru's city centre, frequented by Singaporeans for shopping bargains. The city is being eyed by those looking for retirement homes and looking to get the best of both Malaysia and Singapore.

site_title: Indonesia corporate bond spreads hit six-month wide amid turmoil
summary: Indonesian corporate dollar bond spreads have widened to 144 basis points over Treasuries, the highest level in six months, amid a brutal stock market sell-off. The average yield premium has widened almost 16 basis points this month, underperforming bonds in other South-east Asian countries. Global funds pulled over $1 billion from the domestic bond market on March 17. The stock market decline, sparked by concerns over President Prabowo Subianto's populist agenda, has led to a sharp decline in Indonesian stocks, with the benchmark index falling 7.1% intraday.

images.alt_text: Traders walk as tickers display stock prices inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2015. site_title: Indonesia’s richest woman loses US$3.6 billion in just three days
summary: Indonesia's richest woman, Marina Budiman, lost $3.6 billion in three days after the stock of DCI Indonesia, where she is president commissioner, plummeted. DCI's shares had surged by $17 billion before falling by half, with the company's market value nearing $17 billion despite last year's revenue of just $112 million. The stock's price swings are attributed to its tight free float and narrow bid-offer spreads. The decline triggered a 30-minute suspension of Indonesia's benchmark stock index, amid concerns over President Prabowo Subianto's measures and uncertainties over the finance ministry's leadership.

images.alt_text: The Financial Services Authority and the Indonesia Stock Exchange announced the easing of share buyback policies to anticipate market volatility.
The average yield premium on US dollar-denominated Indonesian corporate bonds hit around 144 basis points over Treasuries at Tuesday’s close, the highest level since September.

Traders walk as tickers display stock prices inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2015. Indonesian President Joko Widodo revamped his economic team in a cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday as China's currency devaluation spurred further declines in the rupiah. site_title: Economists keep 2.6% forecast for Singapore’s 2025 growth; Indonesia slowdown to have ‘limited’ impact
summary: Singapore's 2025 growth forecast remains at 2.6%, with 3.8% growth expected in the first quarter, according to a quarterly survey of private-sector economists. Geopolitical tensions, including higher tariffs, are the top downside risk, but economists believe Indonesia's economic slowdown will have a limited impact. Inflation forecasts fell to 1.7% for full-year headline inflation and 1.5% for core inflation. Fewer respondents now expect monetary policy to be loosened in April, but more expect it in July.

images.alt_text: Their median forecasts for inflation in 2024 have slipped.

site_title: A beginner’s guide to art collecting without the jargon
summary: A new Singapore book, "Buy What You Love," offers practical guidance on art collecting without jargon, focusing on personal connection over prestige and provenance. The book, published by Family Office For Art (Fofa), demystifies the art-buying process, covering fundamentals, navigating museums and galleries, and displaying art. It encourages readers to collect what they love, keep what they buy, and pass it down to the next generation, rather than investing for profit. The book features interviews with Singapore collectors who prioritize personal connection over market trends.

images.alt_text: Supported by Art Basel and UBS, Singapore artist Ho Tzu Nyen used Artificial Intelligence to create lookalikes of Hong Kong screen legends, who will walk on the walls of M+ museum every night.
Singaporean musician and artist weish presents a hauntingly original musical exploration inspired by ancient texts and traditional songs.

site_title: China’s Ping An Insurance posts 48% rise in 2024 profit
summary: Ping An Insurance, China's largest insurance group, reported a 47.8% rise in net profit to 126.607 billion yuan in 2024, driven by growth in life and health insurance business. The company's new customers rose 9.8% to 32.07 million, and its investment portfolio achieved a 5.8% comprehensive yield. The growth was attributed to market demand recovery and reforms to improve insurance agents' quality.

images.alt_text: SGX now offers a total of 18 Singapore Depository Receipts including Ping An, Meituan and Xiaomi
The project should broaden institutional demand and may provide support to gold prices in China in the longer term depending on insurance funds’ appetite for participating in it.
Ping An Insurance Group posted 119.18 billion yuan (S$22 billion) in net profit.

site_title: The US establishment is scared of its own shadow
summary: US opposition to President Donald Trump's authoritarian tendencies is paralyzed by fear and a collective action problem. Trump's opponents, including Democrats and corporate leaders, have failed to act in defense of democracy due to fear of retribution. Judges have put speed bumps in Trump's path, but the president's allies, including Elon Musk, have called for their impeachment. Trump's actions, such as dismantling the Voice of America broadcaster, have further eroded democratic norms. The author argues that the US establishment is living in dread of Trump, and that only collective action can protect democracy.

images.alt_text: It is typical of personalistic leaders, like Trump, to pit allies (courtiers, really) against each other so that none amasses too much power.

site_title: China’s Zeekr, Xpeng to offer cars with L3 autonomy as auto battle heats up
summary: Chinese automakers Zeekr and Xpeng plan to introduce electric vehicles with Level 3 autonomous driving capabilities, allowing drivers to take their hands off the steering wheel. Zeekr will unveil its 9X SUV with this technology at the Shanghai auto show in April, while Xpeng aims to achieve L3 software capabilities in the second half of 2025. GAC also plans to start selling L3-ready models in 2025. Regulatory approval is required before these features can be used in public.

images.alt_text: Automakers are drawn to flying cars as a means to alleviate urban congestion and unlock new transportation efficiencies.
BYD has kept up its steady push into the region despite being subject to a 17 per cent add-on to the standard 10 per cent EU import duty.

XPeng and Volkswagen have signed a memorandum of understanding to open their respective fast-charging networks to each other’s customers, which comprise more than 20,000 charging piles across 420 cities in China, they said in a joint statement.

site_title: Nasa astronauts 'Butch and Suni' return to Earth after drawn-out mission in space
summary: NASA astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams returned to Earth after a nine-month mission in space, initially intended to be a week-long stay on the International Space Station. The faulty Boeing Starliner craft caused delays, leading NASA to switch them to a SpaceX Crew Dragon spacecraft. The crew splashed down off Florida's coast, marking the end of a protracted mission marked by technical troubles and uncertainty. The astronauts will undergo health checks and return home to their families, with NASA's Commercial Crew Program chief stating they deserve "well-deserved time off."

SpaceX’s Falcon 9 rocket has lifted off at 7.03 pm ET (2303 GMT) from Nasa’s Kennedy Space Center in Florida carrying four astronauts who will replace Wilmore and Williams.

site_title: COE prices rise across the board; Cat B and E cross S$116k
summary: COE prices rose across the board in Singapore, with Category B COE premiums reaching S$116,890, a 3.4% increase from the previous tender. Category A COE premiums rose 1.9% to S$94,502, and open category COE premiums increased 3.6% to S$116,991. The higher prices are expected to lead to increased car prices in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Are private-hire fleets partly responsible for higher COE premiums?
A passenger enters a Grab taxi private hire car outside Bishan Junction 8 December 11, 2020.
Premiums for all COE categories rose, except for Category A, which dipped by around 0.1 per cent.
The Open category increased a mere S$2 to S$110,002.

BYD SEALION 7 SUV AT SINGAPORE MOTORSHOW 2025. CAN ALSO BE USED AS GENERIC BYD OR EV PIC.

site_title: Heineken launches first global GenAI lab in Singapore to improve global operations
summary: Heineken has launched its first global GenAI lab in Singapore, a partnership with AI Singapore, to enhance global operations, growth, productivity, and customer engagement. The lab aims to develop scalable GenAI solutions, including autonomous problem-solving systems for marketing and financial reporting. By the end of 2025, the lab plans to assemble a core team, leveraging Heineken's industry expertise and AI Singapore's talent pool. The Economic Development Board has welcomed the initiative, which is expected to unlock new business value for Heineken in Singapore and serve as a platform to level up on AI talent and capabilities.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Cans of Dutch Heineken beer are offered at a supermarket of Swiss retail group Coop in Zumikon, Switzerland December 13, 2016.  REUTERS/Arnd Wiegmann/File Photo
Oracle's new AI centre of excellence in Singapore will accommodate both large and small enterprises.
The new brewery offers a look at the steps the Gulf’s rulers are taking to open their economies in a Muslim region with conservative social norms

site_title: Sembcorp, Sarawak Energy partner Prysmian to supply Singapore with green energy
summary: Sembcorp Industries and Sarawak Energy have partnered with Prysmian to supply Singapore with 1 gigawatt (GW) of green electricity from the Malaysian state of Sarawak. The agreement is part of Singapore's goal to increase its low-carbon electricity import target to 6 GW by 2035. The parties will work on designing and installing a subsea interconnector cable to facilitate the import of green electricity, subject to regulatory approvals. This project aims to support Singapore's transition to a more sustainable energy mix.

images.alt_text: sasembcorp06 - Sembcorp supports customers with stable power through its gas-fired cogeneration facility on Jurong Island, Singapore Credit: Sembcorp

site_title: Is Chinese tea the new coffee?
summary: Chinese tea is gaining popularity in Singapore as a premium, immersive experience, mirroring the trend of artisanal coffee and cocktails. New tea houses are emerging, offering sleek interiors and unique brews, such as Fujian teas and Wuyi rock-essence tea priced up to S$200 per box. This shift reflects changing consumer preferences, prioritizing experiences over luxury goods, and is driven by younger, affluent individuals seeking premium offerings.

site_title: Meta becomes final Magnificent Seven stock to turn negative in 2025
summary: Meta Platforms became the last of the "Magnificent Seven" stocks to turn negative for the year, falling 3.7% and extending its year-to-date decline to 0.5%. The decline comes after a historic 20-session rally, with Meta's stock erasing nearly 26% of its gains in 2025. Analysts attribute the decline to Meta's investments in artificial intelligence, citing "greater macro uncertainty" and fixed costs. The broader Nasdaq 100 Index is down 7.3% for the year, amid uncertainty and tariff threats.

images.alt_text: Both Meta and Apple have been in the European Commission’s crosshairs since last year for potential breaches of the Digital Markets Act which could cost companies as much as 10 per cent of their global annual sales.
Meta plans to work on its own humanoid robot hardware, with an initial focus on household chores.
Most Meta employees have been told they would receive about 10 per cent less equity this year, FT reported.
Meta plans to work on its own humanoid robot hardware, with an initial focus on household chores.

site_title: Lady Gaga Mayhem Tour shows could boost SIA Q1 earnings
summary: Lady Gaga's upcoming Mayhem Tour shows in Singapore are expected to boost Singapore Airlines' (SIA) Q1 earnings, driven by the "Taylor Swift effect," where mega events spur economic growth. The concerts, held from May 18-24, are the only Asian stop for Gaga's tour and are expected to fuel tourism, particularly among international visitors. This could lead to increased air travel demand, higher passenger traffic, and revenue for SIA.

images.alt_text: The airline aims to maintain its strong performance in passenger numbers by expanding and optimising routes said its CEO, Leslie Thng.
Cargo carriage, the weight of cargo and mail carried, was up 2.6 per cent year on year, largely due to increased cargo flow within East Asia, the group noted.
Lady Gaga performing at the Singapore Indoor Stadium in 2012. Her upcoming May concerts in Singapore will be her only Asia stop on her Mayhem tour.

site_title: Singapore’s retrenchments grow in Q4, but job vacancies also rise
summary: Singapore's retrenchments rose to 3,680 in Q4 2024, mainly due to the financial and insurance services sector. However, job vacancies also increased, with 70% of new vacancies filled by residents. This marks a turnaround from 2023's decline in resident employment, with overall employment expanding in 2024. The Ministry of Manpower's report highlights a shift in the labour market, with some sectors experiencing high costs leading to retrenchments.

images.alt_text: Training participation levels declined across the board last year – for both the employed and unemployed, across age groups, education levels and in almost all industries.
More fresh graduates were unemployed, with 12.9 per cent unable to find work in 2024.

site_title: BofA warns of Chinese stock correction ‘soon’ in 2015 repeat
summary: BofA Securities has warned that China's stock rally may face a "meaningful correction soon" due to similarities with the 2015 boom and bust cycle. The Hang Seng China Enterprises Index has surged 30% since mid-January, with strategists citing economic rebalancing and policy cycles as concerns. The HSCEI gauge tumbled 50% in 2015, and some investors see bubbles emerging in tech areas, prompting a cautious outlook despite a 23% year-to-date gain for the MSCI China Index.

images.alt_text: Recent weakness in the US stock market due to recession fears may encourage global capital to flow back into China’s long-shunned assets.
Despite this week’s global sell-off, the market watchers continue to be bullish on the outlook for Chinese stocks.

site_title: Curasia wants to be the ‘Grab’ of colorectal cancer detection
summary: Don Poh founded Curasia Endoscopy in 2021 to address Singapore's low colorectal cancer screening rates due to long waiting times at public hospitals. The company connects patients with specialist doctors for scopes in its facilities, offering a 30-40% discount on prices compared to private hospitals. With a focus on patient experience and accessibility, Curasia has turned profitable and is debt-free, despite operating at only 30% capacity. Poh plans to expand the business geographically and into additional specializations, with a goal of going regional in the next five years.

images.alt_text: Want to live a long life? Start by preventing the key causes of death.

site_title: Global investors to raise allocations to private markets, remain committed to clean energy: survey
summary: Global institutional investors plan to increase their investments in private markets and clean energy over the next five years, despite the current backlash against ESG investing. 73% of surveyed investors believe traditional and renewable energy sources are needed, and 44% have net-zero commitments. 66% plan to invest more in private markets, with 75% of Japanese and Australian investors increasing their allocations. Private infrastructure, credit, and equity are the top sectors drawing investor attention.

images.alt_text: The world is moving towards a "climate-impaired" and "carbon-constrained" future, said Menon.

site_title: Thai economy to grow slightly above 2.5%, recovery more uneven, central bank minutes show
summary: Thailand's economy is expected to grow slightly above 2.5% this year, with a more uneven recovery. The central bank cut the one-day repurchase rate by 25 basis points to 2%, citing a slowdown in the economy driven by structural factors. Household debt stands at 89% of GDP, seen as a significant constraint on consumption and growth. The government aims to surpass a 3% growth target through stimulus measures, while the central bank expects a high bar for further rate cuts.

images.alt_text: The event can create additional jobs and emerge as a new source of income for the services industry among others, the prime minister says.
Since July 2024, Thailand has allowed passport holders from 93 countries to enter the country for tourism for a period not exceeding 60 days.
Thailand is heavily reliant on exports, which make up about 60 per cent of it’s gross domestic product.

site_title: Centurion surges to 52-week high amid heavy trading
summary: Centurion Corp's shares surged to a 52-week high after reporting a 97% year-on-year increase in net profit to S$226.6 million for the six months ended Dec 31, 2024. Revenue rose 18% to S$129.2 million, and earnings per share increased to S$0.4101. The company is exploring the establishment of a Reit, which will "do the heavy lifting" of its assets, allowing it to focus on becoming asset-light.

images.alt_text: If the plan materialises, the Reit will be listed on the mainboard of SGX.
Revenue for the second half stood at S$129.2 million, 18 per cent higher from S$109.3 million in the year before.
“The Reit will be able to take the heavy lifting of our assets," says chief executive Kong Chee Min.

site_title: Couche-Tard met Seven & i investors to press case for takeover
summary: Alimentation Couche-Tard met with Seven & i Holdings investors to press for a potential takeover, citing business benefits and growth potential, particularly in Japan. However, US competition authorities' concerns over the overlap in businesses may hinder the deal. Couche-Tard founder Alain Bouchard made the case for the takeover in private meetings, discussing the attractiveness of the business and its potential for growth. The outcome of the negotiations is uncertain, with Seven & i's engagement with Couche-Tard indicating a willingness to discuss the possibility of a takeover.

images.alt_text: Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc.'s founder Alain Bouchard speaks during a press conference on their bid for 7-Eleven convenience store operator Seven & i Holdings in Tokyo, Japan, March 13, 2025.

Couche-Tard has been pursuing Seven & i for months even as it has received a frosty reception from the Japanese retail giant, in what would be Japan’s largest-ever foreign buyout if the deal is completed.
The Circle-K owner has been pursuing Seven & i for months even as it received a frosty reception from the Japanese retail giant.
Seven & i has been fending off the approach by pursuing an overhaul of the company to unlock shareholder value.
The company sees its valuation erode after a plan by the founding Ito family to take the company private collapsed last month.

site_title: Rate cuts to help Philippines hit 7% growth, finance chief says
summary: The Philippine economy is expected to grow as much as 7% this year, thanks to interest rate cuts that will support investment and consumption, according to Finance Secretary Ralph Recto. The country's inflation remains under control, and the peso has been relatively stable. Recto expects a total of 50-75 basis points in rate cuts this year, and the economy to expand by at least 6% as the central bank sees inflation staying within its target in the next two years.

images.alt_text: Philippine consumer prices rose 4.4 per cent on-year last month, exceeding the 4.1 per cent median forecast of economists in a Bloomberg News survey and surpassing the Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas’ target for the first time this year.
The Philippines was added to the grey list in June 2021 over a host of concerns, such as mitigating dirty money risks associated with casino junkets.

site_title: In tough global market, Bentley posts lowest revenue since 2020
summary: Bentley, a Volkswagen unit, reported its lowest annual revenue since the 2020 pandemic, with 2.648 billion euros in revenue, a 10% decline from 2023. Operating profit fell 37% to 373 million euros. Despite this, revenue per car increased 10% due to high-end customers investing in bespoke features. CEO Frank-Steffen Walliser stated that Bentley prioritizes "value over volume" as it launches its first electric car in 2026 and plans to go all-electric by 2035.

images.alt_text: Luxury car sales race back into the fast lane
For S$1,668,000 (without COE or options), the Bentley GT Mulliner is only available on special order, with each commission requiring a six-month wait.
Bugatti previewed its plug-in hybrid Tourbillon hypercar in Singapore,  costing 3.8 million euros (S$5.4 million) before taxes.

site_title: Gold hovers near record high as Mideast woes, US tariff concerns linger
summary: Gold prices hover near a record high as geopolitical tensions and US tariff concerns continue to support the metal. Spot gold fell 0.1% to $3,031.36 an ounce, while US gold futures eased 0.1% to $3,037.90. The recent Israeli airstrikes in Gaza and escalating US tariffs have driven investors to seek safe-haven assets, leading to a 15% gain in gold prices this year. The US Federal Reserve is set to announce its policy decision, with traders awaiting Fed Chair Jerome Powell's speech for clues on the central bank's monetary policy trajectory.

images.alt_text: Non-yielding gold is considered a hedge against political risks and inflation and thrives in a low interest rate environment.

site_title: India plans steel tariffs of 12% to prevent ‘permanent damage’
summary: India plans to impose a 12% safeguard duty on most steel imports for 200 days to prevent "permanent damage" to its domestic industry. This move follows a surge of steel imports from China, fueling concerns of a trade glut. India joins countries like Vietnam, Saudi Arabia, and Chile in imposing trade measures to limit cheaper steel inflows. The duty will bring relief to Indian steelmakers, who had requested protection from the government. The move aims to mitigate the impact of cheaper steel imports, which have grown 80% in the first seven months of 2024.

images.alt_text: Spools of steel at an ArcelorMittal Dofasco facility in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, March 12, 2025. Canada will keep its trade retaliation in place until the US lifts its own tariffs and commits to free trade, said Mark Carney, who will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s prime minister.
China, the world’s largest steel producer, churned out nearly 1.05 billion tonnes of steel in 2024.
A key US security ally in the Indo-Pacific, Australia is a small global exporter of steel although it is the world’s largest exporter of the main steelmaking raw material iron ore.

site_title: Indonesia rushes to ease buyback rules as market turmoil triggers urgent action
summary: Indonesia's securities regulator, the Financial Services Authority (FSA), has reinstated a buyback policy for publicly listed companies, allowing them to repurchase shares without shareholder approval for up to 20% of their paid-up capital. The move aims to restore investor confidence and stabilize the market, which has been hit by concerns over President Prabowo Subianto's policies and a sharp decline in the local stock market. The policy will be in effect for six months and follows a recent trading halt to stem further chaos.

images.alt_text: Traders walk as tickers display stock prices inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2015. Indonesian President Joko Widodo revamped his economic team in a cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday as China's currency devaluation spurred further declines in the rupiah. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg

site_title: UK pay rises fall back in line with inflation: Brightmine
summary: UK pay rises have fallen in line with inflation for the first time since October 2023, according to Brightmine data. The median pay award in the three months to February held steady at 3% for the third consecutive quarter, reflecting cautious employer approaches amid rising costs and payroll taxes. This development is likely to be welcomed by the Bank of England, which is monitoring inflation pressure in the jobs market.

images.alt_text: Anti-Brexit demonstrators protest outside the Houses of Parliament in Westminster, London.

The payments watchdog will instead be wrapped within the FCA, the UK government said, providing a single point of contact for businesses and ultimately reducing expenses, particularly for smaller companies aiming to expand.
Planning delays are widely blamed by housebuilders and government for the inability of new construction to keep up with population growth and for contributing to broader economic weakness.
Expectations of cheaper borrowing costs are easing some of the pressures on businesses.

site_title: Xiaomi plans to expand Beijing EV factory to meet surging demand
summary: Xiaomi plans to expand its Beijing electric vehicle factory to meet surging demand, with a new facility incorporating an adjoining 52-hectare plot. The company's first factory has a designed annual production capacity of around 150,000 vehicles, but has boosted output to help fill a backlog of orders. Xiaomi's electric vehicle business has contributed to its fastest revenue growth since 2021, with profits rising 90% in the fourth quarter, and shares quadrupling over the past year. The expansion aims to meet the demand for its popular SU7 electric sedan and Ultra race car versions.

images.alt_text: Xiaomi's revenue from EVs and “other new initiatives” reached 32.8 billion yuan last year.
Xiaomi won investors over by duplicating its smartphone success in China’s crowded EV market.
Best known for its budget-friendly handsets, Xiaomi has sought to climb up the value chain with a succession of camera-centric flagship models in recent years.

site_title: Tesla a step closer to ride-hailing with California permit
summary: Tesla has received approval from the California Public Utilities Commission to carry passengers in its vehicles, taking steps towards offering ride-hailing services. The permit allows Tesla to transport employees on a prearranged basis before later offering public rides, but does not permit autonomous vehicles. The approval comes as the company seeks to launch a ride-hailing business, putting it in competition with Uber and Lyft. Tesla's shares rose 0.4% on the news, with the company aiming to offer ride-hailing in California by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: In January 2024, Chancellor Kathaleen McCormick rescinded Elon Musk' pay package of stock options, calling it “unfathomable.”
In China – the world’s biggest EV market – Tesla is among the manufacturers struggling to keep up with domestic champion BYD.
BYD’s best-selling model this year in China has had its sticker price reduced by between 8 to 18 per cent, depending on the car’s specs.

site_title: Samsung CEO says company will pursue deals as it struggles for growth
summary: Samsung CEO Han Jong Hee announced plans to pursue major deals to drive growth as the company struggles with weak earnings and sagging share prices. Following a disappointing year, Samsung is considering expanding its stock-based performance system to employees and exploring mergers and acquisitions to boost competitiveness. The company faces challenges from US restrictions on high-end chip exports to China and rival SK Hynix's strong performance in AI projects. Han pledged to address shareholder concerns and vowed to "recover our fundamental competitiveness" in 2025.

images.alt_text: Samsung’s operating profit sank almost a third in the fourth quarter last year, owing to spending on research.
The decline at the beginning of this year coincides with the US implementing its export restrictions on cutting-edge semiconductors to China.
The latest tariffs add to trade measures introduced in Trump’s first term, removing exemptions for many nations and extending them to new categories of products.

site_title: Indonesia central bank holds rates amid market uncertainties
summary: Indonesia's central bank, Bank Indonesia, held interest rates steady for a second consecutive review amid market uncertainties, including concerns over global trade wars and the government's fiscal policy. The benchmark seven-day reverse repurchase rate remained at 5.75% and the overnight deposit facility and lending facility rates were left unchanged at 5% and 6.5%, respectively. Governor Perry Warjiyo stated that the rupiah should be strengthening based on Indonesia's fundamentals but is under pressure due to technical factors.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's Central Bank Governor Perry Warjiyo speaks during a press conference at Bank Indonesia's headquarters in Jakarta, Indonesia, January 15, 2025. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan
The Financial Services Authority and the Indonesia Stock Exchange announced the easing of share buyback policies to anticipate market volatility.
The average yield premium on US dollar-denominated Indonesian corporate bonds hit around 144 basis points over Treasuries at Tuesday’s close, the highest level since September.

Traders walk as tickers display stock prices inside the Indonesia Stock Exchange (IDX) in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Thursday, Aug. 13, 2015. Indonesian President Joko Widodo revamped his economic team in a cabinet reshuffle on Wednesday as China's currency devaluation spurred further declines in the rupiah. Photographer: Dimas Ardian/Bloomberg
A helicopter flies over Indonesia's capital Jakarta. The nation’s housing market is expected to remain strong for the rest of 2024.
The benchmark 10-year bond yield has dropped to around 6.77 per cent from as high as 7.30 per cent in the middle of January.
President Prabowo Subianto wants to build 3 million affordable houses each year.

Bank Indonesia governor Perry Warjiyo believed the rupiah would stabilise with a strengthening bias going forward, with the government’s new policy to make exporters retain foreign currency earnings for longer onshore expected to increase domestic US dollar supply.

Shipping containers at the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai, China. Higher tariffs are expected to hit the plus-three economies harder, particularly China, noted the macroeconomics surveillance organisation in its quarterly report.
The rupiah slid as much as 0.4 per cent to 16,318 per dollar on Wednesday, a level not seen since late July last year.
Indonesia's central bank, led by Governor Perry Warjiyo, has targeted inflation in 2024 and 2025 to be within a range of 1.5 per cent to 3.5 per cent.

site_title: Lady Gaga’s Mayhem Tour spurs rush for tickets in Singapore
summary: Lady Gaga's Mayhem Tour has sparked a rush for tickets in Singapore, with over 1.6 million fans pre-selling tickets for her four concerts in May. The pre-sales, which began on March 18, are the only Asian stop on her tour. Economists predict that the concerts will boost tourist spending, with retail sales rising 2.1% when Taylor Swift performed in Singapore last year. The event is also expected to benefit Singapore Airlines, with analysts forecasting a revenue and profit boost in the first quarter.

site_title: Cathie Wood says most memecoins will end up ‘worthless’
summary: Cathie Wood, CEO of ARK Investment Management, predicts most memecoins will become "worthless" due to their lack of substance and regulation. She advises investors to "buyer beware" as memecoins are not considered securities and may lose value. Wood remains bullish on larger, established cryptocurrencies like Bitcoin and Ether, predicting Bitcoin could surpass $1 million by 2030. The current value of Bitcoin is under $82,000, down 13% this year, following a trend of declining memecoins.

images.alt_text: The talks reportedly began when Binance approached Trump allies last year, offering a business deal with the family as part of a strategy to re-enter the US market.
Dollar-backed stablecoins distributed by the biggest issuers Tether and Circle are already used in billions of US dollars of transactions a day.
The ECB has been working on creating a digital euro since 2020, after Facebook announced a year earlier it wanted to launch its own digital currency called Libra.

site_title: GoTo reiterates no deal in place with any party as it addresses Grab buyout rumours
summary: GoTo, Indonesia's ride-hailing platform, has reiterated that there is no deal in place with Grab, amid reports of a potential buyout. Grab had begun due diligence on GoTo, citing people familiar with the matter, but the talks have stalled due to competition concerns. GoTo's shares rose 5% on the news, while Grab's shares increased 3.4%. GoTo's management has focused on business activities and achieving good performance, with no material corporate action plans in the next 12 months. The company has previously addressed market rumors and denied any material corporate action plans.

images.alt_text: A commuter enters a private-hire car in Singapore.
Grab has held on-and-off talks with GoTo, but a merger never materialised, partly because of antitrust concerns likely to arise from combining two dominant South-east Asian tech companies.

site_title: HSBC focuses on ‘jewel of the crown’ after investment-bank cuts
summary: HSBC Holdings is focusing on its investment-banking units, particularly debt capital markets and leveraged finance, as part of its biggest restructuring in at least a decade. The bank has jumped to No 10 in US investment-grade bond underwriting and No 17 in US leveraged loans. CEO George Elhedery is finalizing the review, and US CEO Lisa McGeough says the bank is simplifying and becoming more client-focused. This shift aims to make the firm more competitive and supportive of clients in financing and global transaction banking.

images.alt_text: HSBC’s new CEO Georges Elhedery is undertaking a broad restructuring plan that includes winding down various businesses and slashing management ranks.
HSBC will incur US$1.8 billion in charges over the next two years as it embarks on the global restructuring programme that has seen the lender reduce management ranks.
HSBC will soon start laying off around 100 staff at the Pinnacle fintech arm, with another 300 staff to be assigned to other business entities.

site_title: US: Stocks close lower amid geopolitical worries
summary: US stocks closed lower on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average down 0.6% at 41,581.31, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes down 1.1% and 1.7% respectively. Geopolitical worries over Ukraine and the Middle East, as well as uncertainty over President Trump's trade agenda, contributed to the decline. The Federal Reserve meeting is expected to maintain interest rates, but its commentary will be scrutinized for its views on growth and inflation.

images.alt_text: For Nasdaq, the move could also help it better compete with the New York Stock Exchange – which last month committed to launching an exchange in the state.

Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on March 7, 2025, in New York City. Wall Street stocks rose early March 7, digesting a mixed jobs report as markets seek a pivot from a rough period amid tariff uncertainty. The US added 151,000 jobs last month, up from January's revised 125,000 figure, but fewer than analysts estimates as unemployment ticked higher. (Photo by CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)

site_title: Asia: Markets mixed as geopolitics, trade wars deplete sentiment
summary: Asian markets were mixed on Wednesday as trade war concerns and geopolitical tensions cast a shadow, with the yen rising against the dollar and Japan's Nikkei 225 index rising. Gold hit a new record high amid fears of a fresh surge in hostilities in the Middle East. The Bank of Japan kept interest rates on hold, warning about the outlook amid "high uncertainties". Investors await central bank decisions in the US, UK, and Indonesia, while US President Donald Trump's trade policies continue to stoke uncertainty, with sweeping reciprocal measures set to kick in on April 2.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 gained 0.61 per cent to close at 554.30 points, with European banks leading gains on Tuesday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished down 0.6 per cent at 41,581.31 on Tuesday.

site_title: Oracle to provide cloud computing, AI services to Singapore military
summary: Oracle will provide Singapore's armed forces and defence ministry with an "air-gapped" isolated cloud computing infrastructure, offering AI services to counter escalating supply chain attacks in South-east Asia. The deal marks Oracle's first in the region, with the company investing in a cloud region in Malaysia. The isolated cloud will be used to analyze video streams and provide AI data and imagery capabilities, enhancing the military's cybersecurity.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Oracle signage is seen outside Mocsone Center during Oracle OpenWorld 2012 in San Francisco, California October 1, 2012. REUTERS/Stephen Lam

site_title: Stocks to watch: ST Engineering, Keppel DC Reit, Xiaomi
summary: ST Engineering targets S$17 billion in revenue by 2029, with improved net profit margin. Keppel DC Reit secured a loan facility of S$72.8 million. Xiaomi reported a 35% surge in annual revenue to S$67.4 billion, up 48.8% in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Thailand eyes hosting Formula 1 race from 2028, premier says
summary: Thailand is set to host a Formula 1 race from 2028, according to Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra. The event is expected to create jobs and generate income for the services industry. Thailand will study investment requirements and economic benefits before making a final decision. This marks a key milestone for the country's bid to host world-class events, following the success of hosting MotoGP races. The 2025 season will see a significant increase in street and hybrid circuit races, with about a third of the 24 scheduled events taking place on such circuits.

images.alt_text: Thailand is one of many countries eager to join the F1 circuit.

site_title: Bangkok Airways seeks 30 new jets as ‘White Lotus’ boosts tourism
summary: Bangkok Airways plans to order up to 30 new aircraft, including 20 single-aisle jets, to expand its fleet and capitalize on the popularity of the TV series "The White Lotus", which is expected to boost tourism in Thailand. The carrier aims to grow its fleet to 30 jets in the next four to five years, with a projected 10-20% increase in passengers to Koh Samui, driven by the show's filming location.

images.alt_text: The airline aims to maintain its strong performance in passenger numbers by expanding and optimising routes said its CEO, Leslie Thng.

site_title: Lens on Singapore: From margins to mainstream - Getting women into leadership
summary: A podcast by The Business Times explores the evolving landscape of gender equality in leadership roles in Singapore, featuring thought leaders Wong Su-Yen, Gregory Vijayendran, and Yeo Wan Ling. Statistics show women now hold over 20% of board positions, but 36% still have no female representation. The panelists discuss the importance of board readiness programs, open executive search processes, and ongoing dialogue to address the challenges and opportunities facing women in leadership roles. The episode encourages listeners to think deeply about the issues raised and advocate for change.

images.alt_text: Host Claressa Monteiro (left), with Andrew Blazey from the OECD (middle) and associate professor Terence Ho from the Singapore University of Social Sciences (right).
(From left) Hosts Claressa Monteiro and Howie Lim ask experts Dr. Mathew Mathews and Nicholas Fang what’s in store for the Singapore Budget this year.

site_title: Judge orders halt to Musk shutdown of US aid agency
summary: A federal judge ordered an immediate halt to the shutdown of the US Agency for International Development (USAID) by Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE), citing "multiple violations" of the US Constitution. The ruling came in response to a lawsuit brought by USAID employees and contractors challenging the billionaire's authority to slash federal spending and jobs. Judge Theodore Chuang's decision effectively blocks the dismantlement of the agency, which provides international aid and development assistance.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Elon Musk looks on during the day of a meeting with House Republicans to discuss the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C., U.S., March 5, 2025. REUTERS/Kent Nishimura/File Photo

site_title: After regional coups for Gaga and Swift, Singapore should aim to be the natural, not just negotiated, concert choice
summary: Lady Gaga's upcoming concerts in Singapore, her only Asia stop on her Mayhem tour, have sparked speculation about the price paid for exclusivity, following Taylor Swift's 2024 concerts in Singapore, which received a government grant. The deal was secured through negotiations by Sports Hub manager Kallang Alive Sport Management, with no government grants provided. The concerts are seen as part of Singapore's strategy to develop the city-state as a regional entertainment hub, showcasing its connectivity and suitability as a concert venue.

images.alt_text: Fans of Taylor Swift at the National Stadium where the pop star's concerts were held last year.

site_title: Sapura Energy’s fall from Malaysia’s oil and gas powerhouse to a debt-laden giant
summary: Sapura Energy, a Malaysian-listed oil and gas company, has collapsed from its peak in 2013 to a debt-laden giant. The company, once a crown jewel in Malaysia's oil and gas sector, now teeters on the edge of collapse with billions of dollars in debt. Job orders have dried up due to softer oil prices, and the company is clinging to a government rescue package for survival. Its shares have plummeted to RM0.045 apiece, a stark contrast to their RM4.94 peak in December 2013.

site_title: Crude palm oil prices to stay robust on inventory crunch, but may not lift all SGX agri counters
summary: Crude palm oil prices are expected to remain high in 2025 due to a tight supply and strong demand, leading to 12.4% earnings growth for plantation players. Inventories in Malaysia, the world's second-largest palm oil producer, have declined for five consecutive months, and prices are projected to reach S$1,289 per tonne. Analysts recommend Bumitama Agri and First Resources, with higher selling prices also expected to boost rubber prices. However, other agri-commodity players, such as Wilmar International and Olam, have suffered from rising prices and supply constraints.

site_title: China banks cut consumer loan rates to record low to spur demand
summary: Chinese banks are slashing consumer loan rates to record lows, with annual interest rates as low as 2.58%, to stimulate consumer spending and counter US President Donald Trump's tariffs. Beijing aims to make the economy less reliant on trade and exports, with a goal of 5% economic growth in 2025. The move puts banks in a tight spot as they compete for borrowers with low loan demand, raising concerns about default risks and the effectiveness of the stimulus.

site_title: Nvidia looks to expand its AI reign with robots, personal supercomputers
summary: Nvidia is expanding its AI capabilities with new partnerships and product developments. The company will help General Motors with driver-assistance technology and work on "AI-native" wireless network hardware for new 6G networks. Nvidia's CEO Jensen Huang also announced plans to create AI-native wireless network hardware for new 6G networks, the successor to today's 5G. The company's focus on AI is seen as a pivot moment, with investors questioning whether the AI boom is sustainable, but Nvidia's biggest customers remain committed to spending on AI infrastructure.

site_title: OpenAI’s first Stargate site to hold up to 400,000 Nvidia chips
summary: OpenAI's first Stargate data centre site in Abilene, Texas, is set to be completed by mid-2026 with a capacity of 1.2 gigawatts of power. The site will hold up to 400,000 Nvidia GB200 semiconductors, supporting hundreds of thousands of advanced AI chips. OpenAI has partnered with SoftBank Group and Oracle, with Oracle agreeing to use the site's full capacity. The facility is part of OpenAI's $100 billion Stargate infrastructure venture, which aims to provide physical infrastructure for advanced AI models.

site_title: Workato to Launch “The Work Revolution” National Developer Challenge
summary: Workato has launched "The Work Revolution" Developer Challenge, a nationwide competition in Singapore aimed at fostering innovation for the future of work. The challenge invites developers to create cutting-edge integration, automation, and AI solutions to transform workplace productivity. With a prize pool of over S$18,000 and hands-on experience with Workato's enterprise automation platform, the challenge focuses on five critical domains: security, employee experience, customer experience, operational excellence, and social sector impact. The competition aims to advance Singapore's Smart Nation vision and drive digital transformation through collaboration.

site_title: Morgan Stanley plans about 2,000 job cuts to keep a lid on costs
summary: Morgan Stanley plans to cut approximately 2,000 employees, or about 2.5% of its workforce, in its first major workforce reduction under CEO Ted Pick. The cuts, set to occur later this month, are aimed at keeping costs in check amid minimal attrition. This move adds to a series of workforce reductions across Wall Street, as firms navigate an uncertain economic outlook.
