site_title: Euro hits five-month high before German vote on massive spending surge
summary: The euro hit a five-month high against the US dollar on Tuesday, reaching $1.0954, as investors await the outcome of a massive spending surge vote in Germany. The vote, which could boost growth across the euro area, has boosted investor morale, with German investor sentiment index increasing to 51.6 points in March. Analysts predict the euro will rise to $1.15 by the end of 2025 due to policy uncertainty and fiscal tightening in the US.

site_title: New US home construction rebounds after storm-ridden month
summary: US housing starts rebounded in February, increasing 11.2% to an annualized rate of 1.5 million, exceeding forecasts. Single-family home construction rose 11.4% to a 1.11 million rate, while multi-family housing starts climbed 10.7%. However, builders still face an elevated number of unsold homes and high borrowing costs, which keep prospective buyers sidelined, indicating a soft spot for the economy without further decline in mortgage rates and more affordable homes.

site_title: How Trump could destroy his own political movement
summary: US President Donald Trump's policies are increasingly damaging to America, threatening the future of his own "Maga" movement. His obsession with tariffs, unpredictability, and authoritarian tendencies are causing economic instability, panic among consumers and investors, and putting Americans at risk. The administration's sycophants are allowing Trump to press ahead with damaging policies, including potential cuts to Social Security and government-funded health benefits. site_title: Singapore’s Employment Act review may include changes to leave entitlements, workers’ protection: observers
summary: Singapore's Employment Act review may include changes to leave entitlements, workers' protection, and clearer protections for employees affected by corporate restructuring. The review aims to balance worker protection with business flexibility, with suggestions including raising the minimum statutory annual leave entitlement, clearer protections for employees in corporate restructuring, and clearer definitions of workmen. However, a proposal to mandate employer justifications for dismissals is unlikely to be taken up due to concerns over imposing a significant burden on employers. The review is expected to be conducted with tripartite partners, with details to be announced later this year.

site_title: Majority of OCBC’s sustainable finance portfolio aligned with Singapore’s taxonomy: MAS
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) reported that a majority of OCBC's sustainable finance portfolio is aligned with the country's taxonomy, with over half of DBS' and 35-45% of UOB's portfolios also adhering to the criteria. The assessments were made retroactively, and the banks have updated their sustainable financing frameworks to incorporate the taxonomy. The MAS will use the taxonomy as a key reference tool for green and transition financing solutions, and foreign banks and companies have also started using it to screen their sustainable financing transactions.

site_title: US music industry posts 100 million paid streaming users
summary: The US music industry reached 100 million paid streaming subscriptions in 2024, according to the Recording Industry Association of America's latest report. Total revenue increased 3% to $17.7 billion, with paid subscription services accounting for 79% of streaming revenues and nearly two-thirds of total revenues. Meanwhile, music revenues on ad-supported services fell 2% to $1.8 billion, while vinyl sales grew for the 18th consecutive year, outselling compact discs for the third year in a row.

site_title: Citigroup slashes executive bonuses tied to bank’s turnaround
summary: Citigroup has cut payouts to hundreds of top executives as part of its three-year Transformation Bonus Programme, which tied compensation to the bank's progress on risk and regulatory matters. The final round paid out 68% of the target for 2024, down from 94% in 2022 and 80% in 2023. The cut follows a 33% increase in CEO Jane Fraser's total annual compensation, the largest among the six largest US banks. The bank cited areas where progress was slow, including data quality management, despite acknowledging progress in advancing the transformation.

site_title: Xiaomi posts 2024 revenue surge as EV push deepens
summary: Xiaomi reported a 35% increase in annual revenue to 365.9 billion yuan, driven by strong smartphone sales and a push into the electric vehicle sector. The company's revenue surged 48.8% year-over-year in the fourth quarter of 2024. Xiaomi's EV sales reached 136,854 vehicles in 2024, with a goal of delivering 350,000 vehicles by 2025. The company's traditional smartphone business still accounted for the bulk of sales, with revenue reaching 333.2 billion yuan.

site_title: Siemens to cut over 6,000 jobs worldwide
summary: Siemens plans to cut over 6,000 jobs worldwide, approximately 2% of its global workforce, due to weak demand and increased competition in China and Germany. The majority of job cuts will be made in its factory automation unit. The company attributes the decline to "muted demand primarily in the key markets of China and Germany coupled with increased competitive pressures."

site_title: Europe: Shares climb after German lower house passes fiscal reform bill
summary: European shares rose 0.61% to close at 554.30 points, with banks leading gains after Germany's lower house approved a fiscal reform bill, including a massive spending surge and a 500 billion euro fund for infrastructure. Defence stocks rallied, and the Stoxx 600 index hit an intraday record high. However, Fitch Ratings warned that Germany's top AAA credit rating could face pressure if the spending effort isn't offset by consolidation measures.

site_title: Oracle weighs security backstop, small stake to land TikTok deal
summary: Oracle is considering a proposal to purchase TikTok's US operations, providing security assurances and taking a small stake in a new entity, potentially leaving the app's algorithm in Chinese hands. The plan aims to avoid a TikTok ban under a US law requiring its Chinese owner ByteDance to divest for national security. With less than three weeks to reach a deal, US President Donald Trump has called for a sale that would allow TikTok to continue operating in the US.

Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky backed the energy truce, but expressed skepticism about a full ceasefire. The White House said broader truce talks would begin immediately in the Middle East, while the Kremlin emphasized its demands for a complete cessation of Western military and intelligence support to Ukraine's military.

site_title: New Trump tariffs may mar Ukraine endgame
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that April 2 may be the largest day yet of US trade tariffs under his administration, potentially targeting dozens of countries with reciprocal tariffs and sectoral ones. site_title: Navigating global sourcing uncertainty in 2025
summary: Retailers and brands are adapting to global trade uncertainty by diversifying supply chains, investing in advanced technologies, and strengthening supplier relationships. A recent survey found that 60% of companies are overhauling their supply chains to mitigate potential cost disruptions from tariffs. Strategies include optimizing cost structures, leveraging AI and predictive analytics, broadening sourcing networks, bolstering supplier partnerships, and embracing nearshoring and onshoring. By adopting these strategies, companies can reduce dependency risks, enhance supply chain resilience, and position themselves for sustainable long-term growth in volatile trade environments.

summary: A joint bid by SingHaiyi Group and Haiyi Holdings topped eight bids for the Bayshore plot, securing a record S$1,388 per square foot per plot ratio (psf ppr) offer, the highest land price for a 99-year private housing site in the suburbs. The 515-unit plot is the first GLS site in the new Bayshore precinct, attracting developers seeking a first-mover advantage. The high bid reflects pent-up demand for new private housing, including from HDB upgraders in nearby estates, and is expected to result in selling prices starting from S$2,700 psf at launch.

summary: A director at Singapore's Ministry of Transport, Foo Cexiang, has resigned and plans to run in the upcoming general election. Foo oversees private and future mobility, including electric vehicle policy, and has over a decade of experience. His last day is April 1. The move aims to cater to growing demand for philanthropy advisory services in the Asia-Pacific region, particularly in Singapore and Hong Kong.

summary: Oil prices fell 1% on Tuesday as US President Donald Trump and Russian President Vladimir Putin discussed a possible ceasefire in Ukraine, potentially easing sanctions on Russian fuel exports. Brent futures dropped 0.7% to $70.56 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 1.0% to $66.90. site_title: US manufacturing output accelerates in February
summary: US manufacturing production surged 0.9% in February, beating expectations, driven by a 8.5% increase in motor vehicle and parts output. The sector's recovery is being hindered by tariffs, with economists noting that no long-term improvement was seen in manufacturing during President Trump's first term. The Federal Reserve is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate in the 4.25-4.50% range, assessing the economic impact of the Trump administration's policies.

images.alt_text: Imported fuel prices increased 1.7 per cent in February after surging 3.5 per cent in January. Food prices were unchanged after climbing 0.2 per cent in January.

site_title: Lee Fung owner alleges US$56 million theft by Singapore-based family office staff
summary: A Chinese ultra-high net worth businessman, Zhong Renhai, is suing four former staff members of his Singapore-based family office for allegedly misappropriating US$56 million. The staff created fraudulent transactions and fabricated documents to misuse funds. A judge upheld a worldwide order to freeze the assets of the employees, who were based in Singapore. This case highlights the vulnerabilities of certain family office structures, which often lack the same level of checks and balances as banks. The incident underscores the need for increased scrutiny of financial institutions, particularly in Singapore's efforts to become a top wealth hub.

site_title: US import prices increase solidly in February
summary: US import prices increased 0.4% in February, matching January's upwardly revised gain, according to the Labor Department's Bureau of Labor Statistics. This rise was driven by higher costs for consumer goods, contradicting economists' expectations of a 0.1% decline. Imported fuel prices surged 1.7% in February, while food prices remained unchanged after a 0.2% climb in January. The unexpected increase in import prices raises concerns about the inflation outlook.

site_title: Women’s life-changing decisions: Big changes lead to big rewards
summary: Women who took calculated risks, reshaped their lives, and redefined success share their stories. They left corporate jobs, made bold investments, or moved to new countries, often leading to significant rewards. Key takeaways include embracing change, using skills to support passions, and making intentional, courageous choices that align with personal values and long-term goals. Successful women prioritize financial security, personal growth, and work-life balance, often through non-traditional paths, such as entrepreneurship, volunteering, or pursuing unconventional careers. Their stories demonstrate that success doesn't follow a conventional path, but rather one that is tailored to individual values and aspirations.

site_title: Israeli strikes kill 326 in Gaza, collapsing ceasefire with Hamas
summary: Israeli airstrikes on Gaza killed 326 people, collapsing a two-month ceasefire with Hamas. The strikes were in response to Hamas' refusal to release Israeli hostages and rejection of ceasefire proposals. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed to use force to free the hostages, with the military instructing "strong action" against Hamas. The United Nations urged for the ceasefire to be reinstated, as hospitals in Gaza struggled to cope with the influx of casualties. The situation has raised the prospect of Israeli ground troops resuming fighting and has spread to other parts of the Middle East.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 18)
summary: The Jakarta Composite Index plummeted by up to 5% on Tuesday, its sharpest intraday drop since the 2020 pandemic, amid fears of a slowing economy and political uncertainty in Indonesia. The market sell-off triggered a trading halt. Meanwhile, Singapore CEOs expressed improving confidence in business growth, despite global challenges, according to an EY-Parthenon survey. Alta Group plans to expand to the Middle East, while DBS rolled out an update to its transition finance framework. ST Engineering aims to reach $17 billion in revenue and a higher net profit margin by 2029.

site_title: Didi reports 7.1% revenue rise, swings to Q4 loss
summary: Chinese ride-hailing company Didi Global reported a 7.1% rise in Q4 revenue to 52.9 billion yuan, despite a net loss of 1.3 billion yuan for the quarter ended Dec 31. The company's recovery from a regulatory overhaul gathered pace, with 3.25 billion transactions completed during the quarter. Didi faced scrutiny in 2021 over its pursuit of a US IPO without approval and was fined $1.2 billion for a data security violation in 2022. The company's apps were removed from stores and it was delisted from the US in 2022.

site_title: Japan’s land prices rise at strongest pace in 34 years
summary: Japan's land prices rose at their fastest pace in 34 years, growing 2.7% in 2024, driven by sustained economic growth and a surge in inbound tourism. The four major regional cities saw a 5.8% gain, while Tokyo, Osaka, and Nagoya experienced a 4.3% increase for the fourth straight year. Land prices exceeded 2020 levels in 64% of plots, with concerns about higher construction costs and interest rate hikes by the Bank of Japan.

site_title: US: Wall Street opens lower with Fed meet, tariff impact in focus
summary: US stock indexes opened lower on March 18, 2025, due to concerns over the impact of US tariffs and economic growth. The Dow Jones fell 119.47 points, or 0.29%, to 41,722.1. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with losses of 0.46% and 0.84%, respectively. The Federal Reserve's monetary policy decision is expected to influence market sentiment.

site_title: Criticism of Panama ports deal deserves ‘serious attention’: Hong Kong leader
summary: Hong Kong leader John Lee has urged serious attention to criticism of CK Hutchison's sale of its Panama Canal ports to a US-led consortium, amid Beijing's repeated criticism of the deal. The sale was made following pressure from US President Donald Trump, who has complained about China's control over the Panama Canal. Senior Chinese leaders have ordered government agencies to scrutinize the deal, but it's unclear if follow-up action will be taken. Shares of CK Hutchison fell nearly 4% on the news.

CK Hutchison said last week it agreed to sell most of the global US$22.8 billion ports business, including assets it holds along the strategically important Panama Canal, to a group led by BlackRock.

REUTERS/Enea Lebrun
The decision to hire law firm Paul Hastings marked a shift for CK Hutchison – the Hong Kong conglomerate has worked on many of its deals with law firms such as Freshfields and Linklaters before.

site_title: Tencent touts open-source AI models to turn text into 3D visuals
summary: Tencent has released five new 3D-content generators built on its Hunyuan3D-2.0 model, which will be open-sourced to users. The AI models are designed to turn text or images into 3D visuals and graphics, and will power an upgraded version of Tencent's proprietary 3D engine for games and other content. This move comes as major industry players on both sides of the Pacific have rapidly developed AI model advancements, with Tencent and Alibaba Group Holding competing with OpenAI and Baidu in the rapidly growing AI market.

images.alt_text: Three of the top five most downloaded free apps are AI bots, with ByteDance’s Doubao joining Tencent and DeepSeek.

Tencent said that the Hunyuan Turbo S is able to reply to queries within a second, distinguishing itself “from DeepSeek R1, Hunyuan T1, and other slow thinking models that need to ‘think for a while before answering’”.
In a beta test, Weixin is testing access to DeepSeek for searches, Tencent said in a statement to Reuters.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends at near 3-week high on Wall Street gains, trading firms jump
summary: Japan's Nikkei index rose 1.2% to 37,845.42, its highest close since February 27, driven by gains in trading firms and Wall Street's overnight gains. The broader Topix index also rose 1.29%. Trading firms such as Mitsui & Co and Mitsubishi Corp jumped after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway raised its holdings in five Japanese trading houses. However, defence-related shares fell as investors remained cautious about the US tariff impact and economic outlook.

images.alt_text: epa11705282 A worker is seen as in the background a screen shows the Hang Seng index in Hong Kong, China, 06 November 2024. A few hours after the preliminary US presidential results were announced, Hong Kong's stock market, the Hang Seng Index, fell 2.23 percent.  EPA-EFE/LEUNG MAN HEI

site_title: Ride-hail drivers may remain in short supply even as Singapore’s demand keeps rising
summary: Singapore's ride-hail driver shortage may persist despite increasing demand, as earnings stagnate and costs rise. Rental and fuel costs are expected to continue increasing, making the sector less attractive for drivers. Ride-hailing platforms, including Grab and Gojek, anticipate growth in 2025, but drivers' earnings are a major concern. The shortage may be a long-term issue, as the sector's growth is fueled by a positive economic outlook and tourism, but drivers' earnings are not keeping pace with rising costs.

images.alt_text: A passenger enters a Grab taxi private hire car outside Bishan Junction 8 December 11, 2020.
The allocation between private hire cars and private cars is best left to the market, said Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor.
The Land Transport Authority said that all existing point-to-point sector operator licencees will have their respective licences renewed,
Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor said that having more platform operators means more competition and choice for both commuters and drivers.
Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme is for registrations of electric heavy vehicles with a maximum laden weight of more than 3,500 kilogrammes.

site_title: STI up 0.9% as regional stocks rise on strong US retail sales data
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.9% to 3,894.97, driven by gains in regional indices after better-than-expected US retail sales data. The top gainer, Seatrium, rose 2.8%, while the biggest decliner, CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, fell 0.9%. Market strategist Yeap Jun Rong attributed the positive sentiment to the US dollar's weakening and expectations of a more dovish Federal Reserve, as well as China's plans to strengthen domestic demand.

images.alt_text: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust is the largest S-Reit in Singapore, and it holds a diversified exposure including office and retail assets.
Tan Choon Siang was appointed as deputy CEO of CICT on Feb 1.
ST Engineering announced plans to propose an increase in its total dividend to S$0.18 per share for FY2025, up from the prior financial year’s proposed dividend of S$0.17 per share.

site_title: ST Engineering aims for S$17 billion in revenue, higher net profit margin by 2029
summary: ST Engineering aims to reach S$17 billion in revenue and increase its net profit margin by up to five percentage points annually by 2029. The company plans to grow its revenue from its commercial aerospace, defence and public security, and urban solutions segments, with a focus on digital business, defence, and smart mobility. ST Engineering will also explore new venture areas such as construction robotics, decentralised hydrogen production, and marine renewables, while maintaining its research and development spending at 4-5% of group revenue.

images.alt_text: Shares of ST Engineering (STE) soared over 8 per cent on Monday, as it continued building on big gains in the past week.
New York City’s congestion pricing programme began operating just last month, with drivers entering parts of Manhattan charged US$9 during peak hours.
The commercial aerospace segment clinched several new contracts across its maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO), as well as its aerostructures and systems sub-units.

site_title: Nasdaq to open Texas headquarters as companies relocate to state
summary: Nasdaq to open regional headquarters in Texas, deepening its presence in the state as a major financial hub rivaling New York. The move follows other companies such as Tesla, SpaceX, Oracle, and Hewlett Packard Enterprise, which have relocated to Texas due to its favourable tax climate, lower costs of living, and reduced energy costs. This expansion could help Nasdaq compete with the New York Stock Exchange, which is launching an exchange in the state, and the Texas Stock Exchange, set to launch early next year.

images.alt_text: The New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq have dominated the lucrative US listings market in a virtual duopoly since the 2000s.

site_title: The discipline of investing in small caps
summary: Investing in small caps can be a viable option for those looking to diversify their portfolios. Small companies tend to have simple business models, cleaner accounts, and more room to expand, but can be volatile due to low liquidity. To invest successfully, focus on companies with a good track record of growing revenues and profits, little or no debt, and a history of paying dividends. A diversified portfolio with a mix of shares can help reduce the impact of volatile share prices.

images.alt_text: It is important to be realistic about valuations. When a company's shares are valued at more than 50 times earnings, it is almost certainly priced for perfection.

Let’s not forget that America is a population of 335 million people. There are still 7.6 billion people that producers and manufacturers can sell to if America should decide to go down the path of mercantilism and impose penal tariffs on imports.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Tuesday, March 18, 2025
summary: Asian markets followed Wall Street gains, with Hong Kong stocks reaching a three-year high due to a positive China outlook. Japan's Nikkei ended at a near 3-week high, while trading firms jumped. However, Indonesian stocks dove, triggering a trading halt, and the Bank of Japan maintained its interest rate steady amid concerns over the global outlook.

images.alt_text: Shanghai stocks rose, along with Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Manila on Monday.

epa11954763 A passerby walks before a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 11 March 2025. The Nikkei stock index plunged over 2 percent during the morning trading session following concerns on US economy and overnight loss at the New York Stock Exchange.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
Japan’s benchmark 10-year bond yields have risen since the January meeting, hitting the highest level since 2008 last week.

site_title: MUFG to quit climate group as Japanese banks join Wall Street exits
summary: Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) plans to leave the Net-Zero Banking Alliance, following Tokyo-based rivals Nomura Holdings and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group. The move comes after US and Canadian banks, including JPMorgan Chase and Royal Bank of Canada, withdrew from the climate group in December. The exits are attributed to the shift in environmental policies under the new US administration, prompting lenders worldwide to reassess their approach to global warming. MUFG has yet to officially decide on its departure, but will continue to work on addressing climate change.

site_title: Indonesian stock dive triggers trading halt amid fears of economy stalling and political uncertainty
summary: Indonesia's Jakarta Composite Index plummeted by up to 5% on March 18, its sharpest intra-day drop since the 2020 pandemic, amid fears of a slowing economy and political uncertainty. The rupiah slid to 16,472 per US dollar, its steepest decline in Asia after the South Korean won, due to concerns over President Prabowo's administration and budget deficit. The index briefly dropped 7% after a trading halt, marking its lowest point since September 2011, and closed 3.8% lower, defying positive market sentiment in Asia.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker watches as trucks load up raw nickel near Sorowako, Indonesia's Sulawesi island, January 8, 2014.   REUTERS/Yusuf Ahmad/File Photo
Indonesia's crude and refined palm oil exports in February soared nearly 90% compared to last year, reaching a value of US$2.3 billion.

site_title: European assets back in the spotlight; defence spending could be a tailwind
summary: European assets are gaining momentum as the EU and Germany explore defense financing arrangements to bolster their defense capabilities. A dovish monetary policy stance and high consumer savings rate could support growth, while a potential end to the Ukraine war could alleviate geopolitical tensions and boost investor confidence. European equities, currently trading at low valuations relative to US peers, could become more attractive, driven by increased fiscal spending, infrastructure reconstruction, and a potential shift away from US exceptionalism.

images.alt_text: Fears of higher prices create a challenge for Federal Reserve officials as they consider the next steps for monetary policy.
The pan-continental Stoxx 600 climbed 1.1 per cent. Germany’s benchmark index gained 1.9 per cent, while mid-caps advanced 2.4 per cent. Small-caps climbed 3.3 per cent.
Inflation between 2025 and 2027 is seen at 2.2 per cent, 2 per cent and 2.1 per cent – slightly faster than in the previous round for each.

US stocks rose 2% on Friday, pulling the S&P500 out of correction territory, after several sessions of declines. Investors were rattled not only by US President Trump's on-again, off-again stance on tariffs, but also by potential retaliation from America's trading partners

site_title: The tycoon who ‘knew how to spend’: Hong Kong mourns death of property magnate Lee Shau Kee
summary: Hong Kong mourns the death of billionaire property magnate Lee Shau Kee, who died at 97. A self-made man, Lee was among the city's richest people and one of the world's top 100 billionaires, with a net worth of over $29 billion. He founded Henderson Land Group and made significant contributions to Hong Kong's economic development, donating land and funds to build schools and offer scholarships. Officials, including the Chief Executive and Financial Secretary, praised Lee's humility, kindness, and philanthropy, remembering him as a "patriot who loved the country and the city" and a "model for the Hong Kong business world".

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Tycoon Lee Shau-kee, 86, founder, Chairman and Managing Director of property conglomerate Henderson Land Development Company Limited, poses in front of a building model during a news conference in Hong Kong, China January 15, 2015. REUTERS/Bobby Yip/File Photo
Lee Shau-kee founded his property firm, Henderson Land, in 1976. He remained as chairman until his retirement in May 2019.

site_title: Europe must break free from its digital dependence
summary: The European Union is facing pressure to break free from its digital dependence on the US. After a series of US President Donald Trump's administration actions, including retaliating against foreign efforts to regulate American tech companies, European leaders are being forced to take action. A new initiative, EuroStack, aims to promote European digital industry and capabilities by leveraging manufacturing strength, repurposing industries, and creating partnerships. The goal is to shield Europe from a second "China shock" and achieve strategic autonomy, while also safeguarding the continent's digital assets and capabilities.

images.alt_text: The flag of the European Union flies at the EU headquarters during the Special European Council to discuss continued support for Ukraine and European defence, in Brussels on March 6, 2025. European Union leaders hold emergency talks in Brussels gathering as the Trump administration upends traditional alliances and retracts wartime backing of Ukraine. The summit brings all 27 EU leaders together for the first time since the explosive meeting between US and Ukraine presidents on February 28, 2025, with US military aid and intelligence sharing since suspended. (Photo by HATIM KAGHAT / BELGA / AFP) / Belgium OUT

site_title: More China consumers feel better off, Deutsche Bank survey shows
summary: China's consumer sentiment has improved sharply, with 54% of respondents feeling financially better off than a year ago, up from 44% in 2024, according to a Deutsche Bank survey. The proportion of those anticipating an income increase rose to 60% for the second straight quarter. Despite this, concerns about property volatility remain, with 63% of respondents citing it as a reason to cut spending. The government's efforts to boost household confidence and consumption appear to be paying off, with retail sales growth picking up more than forecast in the first two months of the year.

images.alt_text: China’s top leaders have maintained an economic growth target of “around 5 per cent” for 2025.

site_title: Asean’s appetite for Indonesian sand could hit fisheries, marine life: BMI
summary: Indonesia's legalization of sea sand exports to South-east Asia and mainland China may negatively impact its fisheries sector and marine life protections, according to research outfit BMI. The region imported $411 million worth of sand in 2023, with Singapore accounting for 55% of these imports. BMI warns that construction activity will sustain demand for Indonesian sand, leading to environmental degradation risks and undermining marine life protections, with only 3% of Indonesia's territorial waters protected.

images.alt_text: Speculation has been mounting across social media platforms in recent days amid local news reports that a Cabinet shake-up that could include Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati.

site_title: Alta to open Middle East branches, sees private deal flow jumping 10 times
summary: Alta Group, a digital securities exchange for alternative investments, plans to expand to the Middle East, with co-founder and CEO Kelvin Lee stating the company is likely to open two branches in the region, possibly in Saudi Arabia or the UAE, within the next few months. The expansion aims to tap into the growing wealth in the region and increase allocation to alternative assets, which are expected to drive a 10-fold increase in deal value within the next five years.

images.alt_text: Alta Exchange says the partnership will enable Pinetree Securities' investors to access alternative assets such as private equity credit funds and fine wine.

site_title: Bill Gates warns White House he can’t fill shortfalls in US global health funding
summary: Bill Gates is personally lobbying the Trump administration to maintain US funding for global health programs, including childhood vaccination and HIV treatment, due to his foundation's inability to fill gaps. The administration is reviewing foreign aid under its "America First" policy, with around 30 global health projects for consideration. Gates met with the National Security Council and lawmakers to press his case, following President Trump's move to exit the World Health Organization and cut over 80% of US Agency for International Development contracts.

images.alt_text: WHO’s eight-day executive board meeting in Geneva wrestled with the impact of US President Donald Trump’s Jan 20 decision to start the one-year process of withdrawing from the UN health agency.

People protesting outside the USAID building, after billionaire Elon Musk, who is heading US President Donald Trump's drive to shrink the federal government, said work is underway to shut down the US foreign aid agency USAID, Washington D.C., US, Feb 3, 2025.

site_title: Grab is said to move forward with talks to acquire rival GoTo
summary: Grab Holdings is moving forward with talks to acquire rival GoTo Group, a move that comes as both companies have seen significant growth slow due to inflation and interest rate concerns in South-east Asia. The Singaporean ride and delivery firm has begun due diligence on GoTo's accounts, contracts, and operations. Talks are ongoing and may not lead to a transaction, partly due to antitrust concerns. Grab, backed by Uber Technologies, has held on-and-off talks with GoTo since 2018, but a merger never materialized.

site_title: Airline power bank ban: Those who flout rules may be fined or have device confiscated, say experts
summary: Singapore Airlines and its low-cost arm Scoot will prohibit passengers from using or charging power banks in-flight starting April 1 due to a series of cabin fire incidents. Experts say airlines will first issue warnings, and if the issue persists, penalties may include fines or confiscation of the device. The ban comes after a 2016 ban on the Samsung Galaxy Note 7, and authorities are calling for stricter regulations to manage risks associated with personal devices.

images.alt_text: Singapore Air’s new rule will differ from Cathay, as the Hong Kong-based carrier still allows passengers to use power banks to charge devices during flights.

site_title: Nio shares rise 16.7% after announcement of its partnership with CATL
summary: Nio shares surged 16.7% after announcing a partnership with CATL to build the world's largest battery swap network for passenger vehicles. The deal aims to support the growing demand for electric vehicles. The stock price rose to $5.72, its highest level since October 2024, with around 405,200 securities changing hands. The partnership is expected to create a significant advantage for Nio in the electric vehicle market.

site_title: Indonesia calls reports of finance minister resignation a ‘hoax’
summary: Indonesia has denied reports that Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati is resigning, calling the rumors a 'hoax' that contributed to the country's benchmark stock index slumping by 7.1% on Tuesday, its largest decline since 2011. Despite the denials, Indrawati continues to serve as finance minister, and the government has assured investors that its fiscal position is strong. The stock market decline occurred amid speculation of a Cabinet shake-up, but the government's statements have calmed investors.

site_title: Google preparing to partner with Taiwan’s MediaTek on next AI chip: report
summary: Google is reportedly partnering with Taiwan's MediaTek to design the next version of its artificial intelligence chips, Tensor Processing Units (TPUs), set to be released next year. This move reduces Google's reliance on Nvidia and gives it a competitive edge in the AI race. Google designs its own AI server chips, which it uses for internal research and development and rents out to cloud customers. The partnership with MediaTek is seen as a cost-effective alternative, with the Taiwanese firm charging less per chip than Broadcom, Google's current exclusive partner.

images.alt_text: MediaTek is also benefiting from an improved outlook for smartphone chips, which still account for more than half of its revenue.

site_title: Chevron buys US$2.3 billion Hess stake on merger confidence
summary: Chevron has purchased nearly 5% of Hess shares, worth around $2.3 billion, to show confidence in the consummation of its pending acquisition of Hess amid an ongoing arbitration battle with ExxonMobil. The purchase reflects Chevron's confidence in winning the arbitration case, which could grant it a 30% stake in the world's fastest-growing major oil project in Guyana. The deal is part of a larger strategy to lower the cost of the transaction, assuming it wins at arbitration and the spread diminishes.

images.alt_text: Chevron’s data centres are not expected to be connected to the grid and would be primarily powered by natural gas.

Tax and royalty payments resulting from Chevron‘s license have provided a steady source of revenue to President Nicolas Maduro’s administration since early 2023, a source familiar with Venezuela’s oil industry said.

“Our new organisational structure and leadership appointments are designed to improve our operational efficiency and position Chevron for sustained growth,” Chevron CEO Mike Wirth said in a statement.
Chevron has said it is targeting up to US$3 billion in cost cuts through 2026 from leveraging technology, asset sales and changing how and where work is performed.

site_title: Ben Stiller plans new healthy soda brand named Stiller’s
summary: Ben Stiller plans to launch a low-sugar soda brand named Stiller's, a fruit-flavored, carbonated beverage. A trademark application was filed in November, and Stiller intends to star in advertisements promoting the product. This move comes amid a boom period for healthier soda alternatives, with major companies like PepsiCo and Coca-Cola also entering the market. Stiller's social media presence includes 5.3 million followers on X and 2.1 million on Instagram, indicating the potential for celebrity-backed marketing to drive the brand's success.

images.alt_text: PepsiCo is working to diversify away from its standard soda and snacks by making acquisitions of healthier brands.

site_title: Thailand plans to cut tourists’ visa-free stays to 30 days
summary: Thailand plans to reduce the visa-free stay for foreign tourists from 60 days to 30 days to combat exploitation of the waiver for illegal businesses. The move aims to target 40 million foreign tourist arrivals this year, breaking a 2019 record. The reduction could have a low-single-digit negative impact on tourism demand, according to data from ForwardKeys. The Thai government seeks to address concerns over foreigners engaging in illegal activities, such as condominium rentals, and maintain tourism as a key driver of the country's economy.

images.alt_text: People use their mobile phones as they watch the sun set at Jomtien beach in Pattaya on January 20, 2025. (Photo by Candida NG / AFP)

site_title: Thailand eyes EU free trade deal by year end amid US tariff risk
summary: Thailand aims to finalize a free trade deal with the European Union by the end of 2025, driven by US tariff risks and a reliance on exports accounting for 60% of its GDP. The deal would bolster economic security and help Thailand adjust to global competition. The country has also pursued free trade agreements with the UAE, Bhutan, Turkey, and Pakistan, amid a geoeconomic climate characterized by uncertainty. Thailand's Commerce Minister hopes to speed up negotiations with the EU and finalize the deal by Christmas.

site_title: First Resources unit signs deal for US$329 million stake in Indonesia-listed Austindo Nusantara Jaya
summary: First Resources' subsidiary Ciliandra Perkasa has entered a conditional agreement to acquire 91.2% of Austindo Nusantara Jaya, an Indonesia-listed oil palm company, for US$329.8 million. The acquisition will increase First Resources' planted area by 25% and crop yield by 25%, enhancing feedstock availability for its downstream operations. Following the acquisition, Ciliandra Perkasa will make a mandatory offer for the remaining shares, and the deal is expected to solidify First Resources' position as an integrated palm oil player.

images.alt_text: Fresh fruit bunches of oil palm tree are harvested at a palm oil plantation in Kuala Selangor, Selangor, Malaysia April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Hasnoor Hussain
Palm oil producer First Resources' sales for the second half rose 9.4 per cent to US$581.5 million from US$531.8 million, on the back of stronger palm oil prices.

Maybank upgraded the counter to “buy” from “hold”, and raised its target price to S$1.69 from S$1.60 previously. Meanwhile, RHB upgraded FR to “buy” from “neutral”, and raised its target price to S$1.85, from S$1.65 previously.

site_title: Elite women’s sports revenue to top US$2 billion, soaring 240% in four years: Deloitte
summary: Global revenues for women's elite sports are projected to reach $2.35 billion in 2025, a 240% increase from 2022, according to Deloitte. The growth is driven by commercial appeal and major events such as the 2025 Women's Rugby World Cup and the 2027 Fifa Women's World Cup. The two highest revenue-generating sports are basketball and football, with the industry shifting focus to evolving structures and legacy programs to drive domestic success. The commercial appeal of women's sports and its athletes has never been higher, according to Deloitte.

images.alt_text: Lydia Ko of New Zealand poses with the trophy after winning the HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club on Sunday.

Tanasugarn, who retired in 2016, now runs her own tennis academy in Bangkok where she coaches about 100 young players.
Elise Mertens shows her delight after bagging her ninth career singles title on the WTA Tour.

site_title: Google expands Reddit partnership
summary: Google has expanded its partnership with Reddit, gaining access to the platform's API for real-time, structured content. This change aims to improve the accuracy and relevance of displayed information. Following Google's algorithm change, Reddit saw a decline of 600,000 users in US-based daily active users arriving on the platform via Google search. Analysts warn that Reddit's growth is vulnerable to algorithm changes by Google, with shares down 5.6% in afternoon trading on Monday. The expanded partnership also enables Reddit to use Google's Vertex AI to enhance search on the platform.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Reddit app is seen on a smartphone in this illustration taken, July 13, 2021. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
The startup provides cloud-based cybersecurity solutions powered by artificial intelligence that help companies identify and remove critical risks on cloud platforms.

Google has made its own proposal that would loosen agreements with Apple and others to set Google as the default search engine on new devices.
Google is still advantaged by its access to current information from content across the web, its shopping data for billions of products.

site_title: iKare provides personalised care to improve mental well-being via Omnifit tech, one-to-one services
summary: iKare, a Singapore-based home-care provider, is using its Omnifit technology to offer personalized care to seniors, focusing on mental well-being and cognitive abilities. The program, Spark Plus, involves a headset and app assessment of physical traits and stress levels, followed by tailored brain-training and physical exercises. With a one-on-one approach, clients receive a unique program every week, and therapists convene weekly meetings to discuss progress and adjust the program as needed. The service aims to improve mental health and prevent cognitive decline, particularly for Singapore's aging population, with nearly a quarter expected to be 65 or above by 2030.

images.alt_text: SoundEye, one of the awardees this year, uses technology to detect and prevent falls for the elderly. It was established by Tan Yeow Kee in 2015.
Jalan Journey develops digital games with actionable outcomes to educate students about social and environmental causes, build empathy and encourage volunteerism.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SIA, ST Engineering, CICT, Sembcorp, First Resources
summary: ST Engineering plans to propose a 5.88% increase in its total dividend to S$0.18 per share for FY2025, up from S$0.17 per share. The company also announced a new dividend policy for FY2026, where it plans to pay out about one-third of its year-on-year increase in net profit as incremental dividends.

site_title: HSBC said to market A$13 billion home loans amid reorganisation
summary: HSBC is assessing interest in selling approximately A$13 billion (US$7 billion) of Australian home loans as part of its global restructuring plan under new CEO Georges Elhedery. The lender is also selling a French mortgage portfolio, equivalent to about US$7 billion. The move is part of HSBC's efforts to wind down various businesses and slash management ranks amid a broader overhaul of its operations.

site_title: China renews export registrations for US pork, poultry plants in relief to farmers
summary: China has renewed export registrations for US pork and poultry plants until 2030, providing relief to US farmers and meat companies amid trade disputes with major importers like China and Canada. The renewals come after lapses threatened shipments to the world's largest meat importer, allowing hundreds of US facilities to export to China. However, hundreds of US beef facilities remain listed as "expired" and will need to re-register to continue exports.

images.alt_text: In addition to providing revenues, President Trump believes that tariffs would help “levelling the playing field” by revoking international trade deals that worked to the disadvantage of the American people.

From Trump’s perspective, might is right, and the big powers have the right, if not the obligation, to govern the international system, with the rest of the world being required to follow the rules designed by the powerful players.
US President Donald Trump’s additional 10 per cent of tariffs on Chinese imports took effect on Mar 4, adding on to Feb 4 tariffs.

Xi Jinping is trying to reverse foreign investment outflows and persistent economic weakness.
On Wednesday, US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell may have to deliver some bracing news: the post-pandemic era of inflation may have been extended by the trade war.
Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One that “in certain cases, both” types of levies would be placed on foreign goods imported to the US.

site_title: French banks offer a bright spot: resilient results and stable credit profiles
summary: French banks, including BNP Paribas, Societe Generale, Credit Agricole, and BPCE, reported growth in revenue and net income in FY24 despite concerns over the country's financial stability. The banks' diversified business profiles and cautious approach to risk contributed to their resilience. Fitch's affirmation of France's sovereign credit rating at "AA-" offers relief, but the country's outlook remains negative. French banks' credit spreads surged after Moody's downgrade, but they have since stabilized. The banks' stable credit profiles and strong profitability have made them attractive investment opportunities, particularly in bonds.

images.alt_text: The Banque de France reduced its forecast for 2026 by 0.2 percentage points to 1.3 per cent - a figure it also expects for 2027.
S&P warned that any weakening of France’s 2023 pension reform - which sparked mass-scale protests across the country - “could create downward pressure on the ratings”.

site_title: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust appoints deputy CEO Tan Choon Siang as CEO from May 1
summary: CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) appointed Tan Choon Siang as CEO and executive director from May 1, succeeding Tony Tan, who will become chief corporate officer of CapitaLand Development. Tan Choon Siang, with over 22 years of experience in financial management, takes over the role after serving as deputy CEO since February. The appointment is part of CICT's succession planning and leadership renewal process.

images.alt_text: CICT, which purchased a 50 per cent interest in Ion Orchard and its connecting underpass last year,

site_title: US births fell in 2023 to lowest level in more than four decades
summary: US births declined to 3.596 million in 2023, the lowest level in over 40 years, a 2% drop from 2022. Global births have also been declining due to political instability and uncertainty. Americans are delaying parenthood due to high health costs and uncertainty, with the average age for a first-time mother reaching a record high of 27.5 years. The total fertility rate has declined to 1.6 births per woman, prompting concerns about the US's ability to sustain its population levels.

images.alt_text: The National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index dropped three points to 39 this month, the lowest level since August

epa11610755 Consumers shop at Walmart in Los Angeles, California, USA, 17 September 2024. US retail sales unexpectedly rose by 0.1% in August. Fears of higher prices create a challenge for Federal Reserve officials as they consider the next steps for monetary policy.

site_title: Hong Kong stocks at a three-year high on China outlook
summary: Hong Kong stocks reached a three-year high, with the Hang Seng index up 2% and a 23% year-to-date gain, driven by optimism over China's economic outlook. Recent data and promises to boost consumption have lifted investor sentiment. China's yuan hovered near its strongest levels of the year, and the New Zealand dollar surged to a three-month high. European markets also rose, with futures pointing to a strong start, as investors await a vote in Germany on borrowing that could boost the European economy.

images.alt_text: Shanghai stocks rose, along with Tokyo, Sydney, Seoul, Singapore, Taipei and Manila on Monday.

site_title: Asia: Markets track Wall Street gains as tech inspires Hong Kong
summary: Asian markets rallied on Tuesday, following a positive day on Wall Street, driven by US retail sales data easing recession fears and Chinese tech firms propelling gains in Hong Kong. Shanghai and Tokyo rose along with other markets, while safe-haven gold hit a record high due to uncertainty over US tariffs. Despite a surge in Chinese tech firms, investors remain cautious, with the US Federal Reserve's policy decisions this week expected to have little impact on interest rates.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering announced plans to propose an increase in its total dividend to S$0.18 per share for FY2025, up from the prior financial year’s proposed dividend of S$0.17 per share.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.9 per cent at 41,841.63 on Monday.

site_title: Sembcorp jumps 4.9% on talk of potential privatisation, asset sale
summary: Sembcorp Industries shares jumped 4.9% on Tuesday after a Bloomberg report suggested the company was conducting a strategic review of its business, potentially considering going private or selling assets. The company stated it continually reviews its portfolio to optimize shareholder value and may engage external advisers to consider options such as investments, divestment, or restructuring.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp’s shares have climbed more than 250 per cent since the end of 2020, giving the company a market value of S$10.7 billion.

site_title: Chocolate Finance says it has processed most withdrawal requests from first two days after halt
summary: Chocolate Finance has processed and paid out about 90% of withdrawal requests from Mar 10 and 73% from Mar 11, following a temporary suspension of instant withdrawals due to "high demand". The remaining redemptions are expected to be completed by Mar 18. The company's processing time remains standard, with requests received on or after Mar 12 being completed within three to six business days.

images.alt_text: Cash assets were approaching S$1 billion in Feb said Chocolate Finance CEO Walter de Oude.
The MAS has a two-stage test on what constitutes financial advice.

site_title: Vietnam developer proposes 15-year rescue for bank at heart of giant fraud, documents show
summary: Vietnam's central bank has proposed a 15-year rescue plan for Saigon Joint Stock Commercial Bank (SCB), which is facing significant financial losses due to a massive fraud. The bank received a 5% bailout of the nation's 2024 economic output, totaling nearly $26 billion. SCB's capital adequacy ratio has worsened to minus 176%, and the bank remains dependent on special loans from the central bank. The rescue plan aims to make SCB profitable again, with the lender repaying the central bank in 14 years, subject to market conditions.

images.alt_text: Truong My Lan sit during her trial at the Ho Chi Minh City People's Court in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, 11 April 2024.
Truong My Lan, chair of major developer Van Thinh Phat, was found guilty this month of swindling cash from Saigon Commercial Bank (SCB) over a decade.
The massive bailout of SCB’s depositors has so far cost the central bank the equivalent of 6 per cent of Vietnam’s 2023 gross domestic product in special loans.

site_title: Nvidia showcases AI chips as it shrugs off DeepSeek
summary: Nvidia CEO Jensen Huang is set to showcase the company's latest Blackwell line of graphics processing units, including new updates in the works, at its annual developers conference. The move comes as Nvidia shrugs off concerns about China's DeepSeek disrupting the market, with industry watchers expecting a boost from the AI boom. Despite a recent sell-off, Nvidia's stock is up 9% this year, driven by demand for its chips to power artificial intelligence in data centers, and the company projects record-high revenue for the current fiscal quarter.

images.alt_text: Intel will also restart plans to produce chips that power AI servers and look to areas beyond servers in several areas such as software, robotics and AI foundation models.
Samsung’s operating profit sank almost a third in the fourth quarter last year, owing to spending on research.

Nvidia has been a dominant player in AI computing in recent years, with its processors powering data centres that support chatbots and other tools. The company’s shares have been a safe bet for a long time, gaining nearly 900 per cent from the start of 2023 to late January.

site_title: Gold rises to record on Middle East tension, US economy concerns
summary: Gold rose to a record high of $3,017 an ounce as Middle East tensions and concerns over the US economy fueled demand for the metal as a store of value. The 0.6% increase followed a weaker-than-expected US retail sales data and escalating military strikes in Gaza. Despite this, investors remain cautious due to ongoing trade wars and economic uncertainty, with several major banks raising their price targets for gold. The metal is up 14% this year and is expected to continue rising, with some predicting a potential price of $3,100 an ounce within the next year.

images.alt_text: Gold is seen as a hedge against political risks and inflation, and has gained around 14 per cent so far in 2025.

site_title: Local construction companies adopt ESG registry to bolster competitiveness, secure project tenders
summary: Seven Singaporean construction companies have adopted ESGpedia, a local ESG registry, to bolster competitiveness and secure project tenders. The adoption comes amid the industry's push to green its supply chain, with the government now incorporating environmental-sustainability criteria into large project evaluations. The companies achieved better ESG compliance, man-hour savings, and enhanced data insights into greenhouse gas emissions. This move is part of Singapore's efforts to reduce its carbon footprint and align with international sustainability standards.

images.alt_text: GIC head of sustainability Emily Chew
Nomura says it will stick to its target set four years ago, to deploy US$125 billion of sustainable financing to March 2026.

site_title: Alphabet to buy cybersecurity startup Wiz for US$32 billion in biggest deal to boost cloud security
summary: Alphabet has agreed to buy cybersecurity startup Wiz for $32 billion, its largest deal, to bolster its cloud business with AI-powered cybersecurity solutions. The acquisition comes after Wiz rejected a $23 billion bid last year due to concerns over antitrust approvals. The deal aims to help Alphabet compete with Amazon and Microsoft in the cloud-computing industry. Regulatory scrutiny is expected, and the deal is expected to close in 2026.

images.alt_text: Founded in 2017, AdHawk has created chips, hardware and software to enable advanced eye tracking.
Google has made its own proposal that would loosen agreements with Apple and others to set Google as the default search engine on new devices.
Google is still advantaged by its access to current information from content across the web, its shopping data for billions of products.
A federal judge is set to rule on how Google must change its practices following hearings scheduled for next month.

site_title: DBS’ update to transition finance framework has strategic value for the bank
summary: DBS, a Singaporean bank, has updated its transition finance framework, aiming to support the decarbonisation of high-emitting sectors. The framework provides more details on how to report financed emissions and has been widened to include infrastructure adaptation and resilience. The bank's sustainable finance portfolio has expanded by 27% to $89 billion in 2024, with potential for new business opportunities in transition finance. However, the complexity of transition finance poses challenges, including the risk of greenwashing and the need for credible transition plans to avoid delaying the phasing out of high-emission assets.

images.alt_text: The world is moving towards a "climate-impaired" and "carbon-constrained" future, said Menon.
GIC head of sustainability Emily Chew
Tender evaluations for government projects now include an environmental-sustainability criteria.

site_title: ST Engineering stock surges on higher FY2025 total dividend, new dividend policy for next year
summary: ST Engineering's stock surged 2.7% on Tuesday after the company announced a new dividend policy, paying out a third of its year-on-year net profit increase as incremental dividends starting from FY2026. The company aims to grow revenue and net profit, with a target of S$17 billion in revenue by 2029. A higher total dividend of S$0.18 per share for FY2025 was proposed, with interim dividends and a final dividend subject to shareholder approval.

images.alt_text: The commercial aerospace segment clinched several new contracts across its maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO), as well as its aerostructures and systems sub-units.
Shares of ST Engineering (STE) soared over 8 per cent on Monday, as it continued building on big gains in the past week.
As at end-2024, ST Engineering's order book stood at S$28.5 billion.

site_title: Manulife appoints chief actuary as new Asia CEO, president amid leadership reshuffle
summary: Canadian insurer Manulife has appointed Steve Finch, its current chief actuary, as the new Asia CEO and president, effective May 9. Finch, a 32-year veteran of the company, previously served as chief financial officer of its US business, John Hancock. He will succeed Phil Witherington, who will become global CEO and president. The move comes as part of the insurer's leadership restructuring, with Roy Gori retiring as CEO and president. Finch's appointment marks a significant change in leadership at Manulife.

site_title: Portugal home prices to keep rising as demand outpaces supply
summary: Portugal's prime residential property prices are expected to continue rising in 2025 due to increasing foreign demand and a lack of new construction. Wealthy Americans, accounting for a third of all sales, have driven the market, making Lisbon's prices higher than those in Madrid, Berlin, and Amsterdam. The government has vowed to add 59,000 new homes and guarantee home purchase loans, but developers say it will take time to close the supply-demand gap and that rising construction costs will limit price drops.

images.alt_text: Residential and commercial buildings on the Lisbon city’s skyline. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg
Aima is struggling with a backlog of more than 400,000 visa applications after a sharp rise in immigration following the Covid-19 pandemic and the start of the war in Ukraine.

site_title: Why invest in Singapore
summary: Singapore's government has introduced measures to revitalize the stock market, including easing procedures and costs for new listings, and offering tax incentives to encourage companies to list. The Monetary Authority of Singapore has also launched a new S$5 billion fund to invest in Singapore equities. Despite perceptions that Singaporean stocks underperform, the country remains a hub for many types of investments, including private markets and family offices. The government's investments in various sectors, such as education and social support, also demonstrate confidence in the country's economy.

images.alt_text: With IPOs starting to pick up in the US, SGX anticipates a positive ripple effect on markets worldwide, including Asia and Singapore.
PM Wong taking pictures with residents at the Chingay@Heartlands celebration on Feb 22.
Budget 2025: Enhancing our Technology and Innovation Engines; Strengthening our Enterprise Ecosystem; Supporting our Enterprises in Workforce Transformation

site_title: Tech giants, stop trying to build godlike AI
summary: Tech giants' pursuit of "artificial general intelligence" (AGI) is raising concerns about the potential for unintended consequences. Despite lofty goals of curing cancer and solving climate change, the definition of AGI remains vague, and financial incentives may skew efforts towards benefiting corporations first. Experts warn that the pursuit of AGI could lead to existential risks and geopolitical ramifications. A more concrete and measurable approach to AI development, focusing on specific human needs, is recommended.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The ChatGPT logo, a keyboard, and robot hands are seen in this illustration taken January 27, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
For much of this year already, AI researchers have been looking at new paths for improving their models that don’t just involve throwing more data and computing power at them.
French startup Emobot has created a bot that uses AI to track the emotional state of the elderly to detect depression, anxiety and other mental health concerns.
Unlike earlier automation, which replaced routine jobs such as assembly line work and bookkeeping, AI may extend its reach to non-routine and creative work.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after latest economic data
summary: Wall Street's main stock indexes opened lower on Monday as investors assessed the impact of President Donald Trump's tariffs on the economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 61.79 points, or 0.15%, to 41,426.40. The S&P 500 lost 6.00 points, or 0.11%, and the Nasdaq Composite lost 25.41 points, or 0.14%. The lower opening is attributed to investors' assessment of Trump's latest tariff salvo on Canada.

site_title: Europe: Shares end higher on hopes of German reforms, Ukraine ceasefire
summary: European shares rose 0.79% on Monday, driven by gains in energy and healthcare stocks, amid hopes of German debt reform and a potential Ukraine ceasefire. The Stoxx 600 index ended at 550.94 points, extending its gains from Friday's 1.4% increase. Oil and gas stocks led the rally, while US vows to attack Yemen's Houthis contributed to higher crude prices. The positive start to the week is seen as a relief for investors amid ongoing Russia-Ukraine tensions.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 0.9 per cent at 41,841.63 on Monday.

site_title: Billionaire Cheng family in talks with Louis Vuitton on mega Hong Kong store: sources
summary: Billionaire Cheng family's real estate company New World Development is in talks with Louis Vuitton to open a mega store at K11 Musea mall in Hong Kong, occupying about 40,000 square feet. The store is expected to feature a museum, cafe, and lounge for VIP customers, making it one of Louis Vuitton's largest in Asia. This move is part of K11 Musea's pivot to luxury shopping, with other high-end labels such as Prada already opening new stores in the mall.

images.alt_text: New World has undergone two CEO changes in two months, with Adrian Cheng, stepping down in September, raising concerns over its corporate governance.
New World Development had consolidated net debt of HK$123.8 billion as at Jun 30, according to its 2024 annual report.
New World Development had consolidated net debt of HK$123.8 billion as at Jun 30, according to its 2024 annual report.
After New World posted its first loss in 20 years, Adrian Cheng stepped down as CEO in September in a surprise move. Just two months later, the company replaced his successor.

site_title: Indonesia to repatriate 561 Myanmar scam centre workers
summary: Indonesia will repatriate 561 Myanmar scam centre workers, mostly Indonesians, via Thailand in the coming days. The workers were lured with promises of high-paying jobs but were forced to commit online fraud. This is part of a larger effort to free around 7,000 workers from scam centres in Myanmar's lawless border areas. The repatriation comes after thousands of Indonesians were enticed abroad for better-paying jobs only to end up in the hands of transnational scam operators, with over 4,700 repatriated since 2020.

images.alt_text: Victims of scam centres who were tricked or trafficked into working in Myanmar, stuck in limbo at a compound inside the KK Park, a fraud factory, and a human trafficking hub on the border with Thailand-Myanmar after a multinational crackdown on the compounds run by criminal gangs.
Losses from cryptocurrency-related scams surged to 24.3 per cent of total scam losses last year - from about 6.8 per cent in 2023.
Battling scams has mainly been left up to banks, which have spent heavily on compensating customers and investing in education and warning systems.

site_title: US homebuilder sentiment drops to seven-month low in March
summary: US homebuilder sentiment has dropped to a seven-month low in March, reaching a level of 39 according to the National Association of Home Builders/Wells Fargo Housing Market Index. The decline is attributed to added cost pressures from tariffs on imported materials, with builders estimating a $9,200 cost effect per home. This marks a reversal of gains made after President Trump's election victory, mirroring losses in other confidence measures. Economists had forecast the index at 42.

images.alt_text: Bidding wars have become increasingly common in the hyper-competitive market, cultivated by real estate agents who urge potential tenants to offer to pay more than the asking price.

site_title: PepsiCo to acquire soda brand Poppi for nearly US$2 billion
summary: PepsiCo has agreed to acquire healthier soda brand Poppi for nearly $2 billion. The acquisition includes a net purchase price of $1.65 billion, with an additional $300 million in expected cash tax benefits. Poppi's functional sodas, which contain prebiotics, fruit juice, and apple cider vinegar, have five grams of sugar or less per serving, catering to the growing demand for lower-sugar beverages. The deal is seen as a strategic move by PepsiCo to diversify away from its standard soda and snacks, with the potential to make it the leader in the US prebiotic soda market.

images.alt_text: Tan Wern-Yuen is set to join Hillhouse Capital in March after helming PepsiCo's Asia Pacific operations for the past five years.
Alterno, winner of the 2024 cohort, provides thermal energy storage solutions using sand battery technology.

A survey by New York Attorney General Letitia James’ office found that PepsiCo’s plastic packaging was by far the greatest source of Buffalo River plastic pollution, three times as abundant as the next contributor, McDonald’s.

site_title: Audi to cut 7,500 jobs in Germany to become more efficient
summary: Audi plans to cut 7,500 jobs in Germany by 2029, approximately 14% of its workforce, without affecting factory workers. The move aims to improve profitability as the company invests around 8 billion euros in its German locations. Audi will introduce new cars in the US and China, including electric models, to compete in the market. The total potential job reductions across the Volkswagen group now exceed 40,000.

images.alt_text: Audi said a global fall in demand for high-end electric sport utility vehicles (SUVs) had tanked demand for its Q8 e-tron, to which the site was exclusively dedicated.
A new version of the Audi A5 saloon was launched at the debut of the Audi House of Progress showroom in Singapore on February 12, 2025.

site_title: Hugo Boss sees sluggish US, China demand at start of year
summary: Hugo Boss expects a sluggish start to the year due to weak consumer sentiment in the US and China, which may trend below its full-year guidance range. The company plans to pay a dividend of 1.40 euros per share, above analysts' estimates, and aims to return to profit growth despite a 35% drop in its stock price over the last 12 months. CEO Daniel Grieder cited challenges such as tariffs and the weak economic situation in China as risks to consumer sentiment in 2025.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A window display is seen at the Boss store in London, Britain, May 30,2024. REUTERS/Chris J. Ratcliffe/File Photo
The luxury sector is grappling with weaker sales and margin pressures as inflation-hit shoppers cut back spending on designer fashion.
Hugo Boss second-quarter operating profit (Ebit) amounted to 70 million euros on a preliminary basis, representing a “massive 33 per cent miss” compared with market expectations.

site_title: Trump taps Michelle Bowman to be US Fed vice-chair for supervision
summary: US President Donald Trump has nominated Michelle Bowman, a former community banker, to be the Federal Reserve's next vice-chair for supervision. Bowman, who was previously nominated by Trump in 2018, is seen as favoring a lighter touch to banking regulation. Trump praised Bowman's "know-how" to manage the economy, and the American Bankers Association has expressed strong support for her nomination, urging the Senate to quickly confirm her.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell may have to deliver some bracing news: the post-pandemic era of inflation may have been extended by the trade war.
European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says: “The level of uncertainty we are facing is exceptionally high. Maintaining stability in a new era will be a formidable task.”
DOGE’s approach at times has been so scattershot that key federal employees such as those who oversee the country’s nuclear stockpile and scientists combating bird flu have been fired and recalled.

site_title: US dollar hobbled by economic worries; euro remains in favour
summary: The US dollar faces a significant decline, hovering near a five-month low against major peers, due to President Trump's erratic trade policies and soft economic data. The euro, on the other hand, gains 0.2% against the US dollar, reaching its highest level since October 11. Analysts predict the euro will reach US$1.13 by year-end, while the Japanese yen strengthens against the US dollar. A fiscal deal in Germany is seen as a positive driver for the euro, while the US Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady.

images.alt_text: Commuters pass through a walkway near the construction site for the Stuttgart 21 railway and urban development project in Stuttgart, Germany, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. Chancellor-in-waiting Friedrich Merz plans to free Germany from the fiscal straitjacket that former leader Angela Merkel had locked her country into for more than a decade, a move that will revolutionize public finances and pave the way for Europe’s most powerful economy to bulk up the region’s defense. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

site_title: Trump says JFK assassination files to be released on Tuesday
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that remaining government files on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy will be released on Tuesday, fulfilling an executive order signed in January. The documents, totaling tens of thousands, were previously held back due to national security concerns. Trump stated that he will not redact any information and that the files will contain a "tremendous amount of paper" with new details on the case. The release is seen as a long-awaited move to quell conspiracy theories surrounding Kennedy's assassination.

images.alt_text: In addition to providing revenues, President Trump believes that tariffs would help “levelling the playing field” by revoking international trade deals that worked to the disadvantage of the American people.

From Trump’s perspective, might is right, and the big powers have the right, if not the obligation, to govern the international system, with the rest of the world being required to follow the rules designed by the powerful players.

On Wednesday, US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell may have to deliver some bracing news: the post-pandemic era of inflation may have been extended by the trade war.

site_title: Starbucks ordered to pay US$50 million for hot tea spill
summary: A California jury has ordered Starbucks to pay US$50 million to a customer, Michael Garcia, who suffered third-degree burns on his penis and groin after hot tea spilled on his lap at a drive-through in 2020. Garcia, who underwent multiple skin grafts, claims the server mishandled the drink, leading to his injuries. Starbucks plans to appeal the verdict, but the company had previously offered to settle for US$30 million. The award is the latest in a long line of high-profile cases, including the 1994 Stella Liebeck coffee case, which led to significant changes in US tort reform.

images.alt_text: Starbucks is testing new store designs in the US as it looks to reverse a sales slump.
Luckin Coffee shareholders vote to remove chairman, report says

site_title: TransportBT: Discover the driving forces behind the current COE landscape
summary: A podcast by BT Correspondents, TransportBT, examines the Certificate of Entitlement (COE) system in Singapore, exploring how private-hire fleets contribute to higher COE premiums. The podcast discusses government policies, including the recent decision against creating a separate COE category for Private Hire Cars (PHCs), and delves into the role of National Sales Companies (NSCs) in driving up COE prices. The episode provides insights into the complex dynamics of the COE market, shedding light on the broader economic implications and offering a nuanced understanding of the current COE landscape.

images.alt_text: A passenger enters a Grab taxi private hire car outside Bishan Junction 8 December 11, 2020.
A licence or special decal which private-hire car drivers who must display on their windscreens. Grab Affixing Centre at Midview City in Sin Ming Lane.
There are at least 15,000 EV charging stations around Singapore today.

site_title: BYD unveils battery system that charges EVs in five minutes, way ahead of Tesla’s superchargers
summary: Chinese automaker BYD has unveiled a new battery system that can charge electric vehicles (EVs) in just five minutes, surpassing Tesla's Superchargers. The new technology will be available in the Han L and Tang L SUVs, starting at $49,647 and $49,647 respectively. BYD plans to build over 4,000 charging stations to support the new technology, and chairman Wang Chuanfu expects it to boost the company's sales. The ultra-fast charging system could convince drivers to switch to EVs, potentially giving BYD an edge over Tesla in the global EV market.

images.alt_text: BYD’s best-selling model this year in China has had its sticker price reduced by between 8 to 18 per cent, depending on the car’s specs.
BYD plans to use the proceeds to invest in research and development, expand overseas businesses, supplement its working capital, and for general corporate purposes.
BYD is the best-performing stock in the Bloomberg World Auto Manufacturers Index this year, gaining around 40 per cent.

site_title: Trump is determined about tariffs, unfazed by electoral considerations or market pressure
summary: US President Donald Trump is determined to implement tariffs despite market pressure and electoral considerations. He believes tariffs will "level the playing field" by revoking international trade deals that benefit foreign companies at the expense of American citizens. Trump has modelled his trade policies after 19th-century President William McKinley, who raised tariffs to fund the federal budget. However, economists argue that tariffs would actually harm American manufacturers and consumers, and would require significant short-term costs for the economy and the president's own party.

images.alt_text: Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Stephen Miran's vision of a Mar-a-Lago accord includes a possible US debt restructuring, which would force some holders of Treasuries to swap them for perpetual bonds.

site_title: In corporate governance, good form is predicated on better substance
summary: Singapore-listed City Developments Ltd (CDL) recently faced a public dispute between its executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and group CEO Sherman Kwek, but the parties have since stood down their lawyers and agreed to work together. The controversy highlights the need for listed companies to prioritize substance over form in corporate governance. The Monetary Authority of Singapore's equities market review group has proposed a shift in regulatory approach towards more disclosure and less merit judgment, allowing the market to have more free play. Effective communication and stakeholder management are crucial in maintaining trust with investors.

images.alt_text: Can Kwek Leng Beng be able to work harmoniously with Sherman Kwek on the uphill battle to regain investor confidence at CDL?
On Feb 26, Kwek Leng Beng (right) said in a statement that he had filed court actions against his son Sherman Kwek for an attempted boardroom coup.
Hotelier Kwek Leng Beng had his start with a single hotel on Orchard Road, before rapidly expanding into a global hospitality group with over 145 hotels worldwide.
CDL saga: Kwek Leng Beng discontinues lawsuit against son Sherman Kwek

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, March 17, 2025
summary: Thailand's stock market continued its downward trend, with rescue efforts failing to stem the losses. South Korea's chip exports to China plummeted as US export controls tightened. Gold prices edged higher due to ongoing geopolitical and economic concerns. Meanwhile, the Malaysian ringgit declined as traders weighed the possibility of a rate cut.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Monday.
The gains follow a much-needed rally on Wall Street that was stoked by optimism US lawmakers would pass a spending bill to avert a painful government shutdown.
Thailand’s 2025 stock market tumble is at least double its peers as analysts point to more investors losing faith in the economic outlook.
The decline at the beginning of this year coincides with the US implementing its export restrictions on cutting-edge semiconductors to China.
Gold is seen as a hedge against political risks and inflation, and has gained around 14 per cent so far in 2025.
