site_title: Singapore stocks close higher on Monday amid regional gains; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% on Monday, ending at 3,859.36, amid regional gains. The index was led by Sembcorp Industries, while DFI Retail Group fell 1.8%. The gains were driven by China's plan to boost domestic consumption and Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) growth of 7.6% in February. Despite tariff worries, the market remained positive, with local banks ending higher.

images.alt_text: Shares of Sembcorp dropped on Friday (Mar 14) morning after a deal inked by one of its subsidiaries to import natural gas from Indonesia fell through.
Since Trump’s inauguration, US stocks have pulled back from all-time highs amid growing fears of stagflation or even an outright recession.

site_title: Considering a Sino-American ‘beautiful deal’: Could China and the US divide the world?
summary: US President Donald Trump is promoting a potential "big, beautiful deal" with China's Xi Jinping, despite campaign-trail vows to hit China with crippling tariffs. Trump has questioned the harm of Chinese-owned app TikTok to US national security and has invited China to help with peacemaking in Ukraine. He has also refrained from proclaiming US support for Taiwan in the event of a Chinese invasion. This could lead to a US-China condominium, where both countries avoid direct military conflict and create incentives for a more stable balance-of-power system in the Indo-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Vance did not provide any details on the participants in negotiations to purchase the app.
FILE PHOTO: China's and U.S.' flags are seen printed on paper in this illustration taken January 27, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Australia’s central bank still more cautious than market on prospect of more rate cuts
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) remains cautious about the prospects for further interest rate cuts, despite market expectations of a third cut by the end of the year. Governor Michele Bullock and Deputy Governor Andrew Hauser have stated that a series of rate cuts is unlikely. RBA Assistant Governor Sarah Hunter said the market is overly optimistic about the prospects for further easing, and the board is closely monitoring US policy settings. A pick-up in household consumption in the December quarter is seen as a genuine improvement in underlying momentum, rather than a seasonal bounce.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - Australia’s Reserve Bank Governor, Michele Bullock, speaks during the Monetary Policy Decision media conference in Sydney on February 18, 2025. Australia's central bank cut its key interest rate on February 18 for the first time in more than four years, but warned global turmoil could derail further easing. (Photo by DAVID GRAY / AFP)

site_title: AstraZeneca to buy EsoBiotec for up to US$1 billion
summary: AstraZeneca to acquire biotechnology firm EsoBiotec for up to $1 billion. EsoBiotec's ENaBL platform can genetically modify immune cells for transformative cell therapy treatments in minutes, replacing the current weeks-long process. AstraZeneca will pay $425 million upfront and up to $575 million in contingent consideration based on development and regulatory milestones. The deal is expected to close in the second quarter of 2025 and does not impact AstraZeneca's financial guidance for 2025.

site_title: Property developer Sunac China warns of wider loss for 2024
summary: Beijing-based property developer Sunac China Holdings expects to report a wider loss of between 25.5 billion yuan and 26 billion yuan for 2024 due to the absence of gains from last year's offshore debt restructuring. The company attributed this to the absence of gains after completing a comprehensive overhaul of its US$9 billion offshore debt. This comes as the company has borne the brunt of a struggling property sector in China, where several top developers have defaulted on debt repayment obligations.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo of property developer Sunac is seen outside a residential compound in Beijing, China September 19, 2023. REUTERS/Florence Lo/File Photo
Investors have grown increasingly anxious about Sunac's upcoming interest payments amid sluggish sales, which sent its shares and US dollar notes to their lowest levels in months last week.

site_title: Oil prices tick up on US attack on Houthis, China economic hopes
summary: US President Donald Trump vowed to hold Iran responsible for any attacks by the Houthi group it backs in Yemen, leading to a slight increase in oil prices. Brent futures rose 49 cents, or 0.7%, to US$71.07 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude futures gained 40 cents, or 0.6%, to US$67.58. Chinese economic data showed retail sales growth quickened, supporting prices, despite weak refining margins and rising unemployment. The US dollar eased against a basket of currencies, making oil less expensive for overseas buyers and boosting demand.

images.alt_text: Crude has fallen by more than US$10 a barrel from this year’s high in January.

site_title: Bank of Japan to hold rate steady as concern over global outlook mounts
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 0.5% as global economic concerns mount due to escalating trade tensions. Despite rising Japan's 10-year bond yields to the highest level since 2008, economists surveyed by Bloomberg predict the rate will remain steady. Governor Kazuo Ueda is likely to signal little concern over the global economy, and the BOJ will monitor steep gains in yields. The decision comes as the global economy faces uncertainty, with the BOJ aiming to keep rates on a gradual upward trajectory.

images.alt_text: The BOJ has long argued that generating a lasting cycle of rising wages, consumption and growth is worth the pain of adjusting to life with higher prices.

When inflation in Japan started to accelerate in 2022, wage gains lagged the increase in import costs, which kept real wages and consumption lacklustre, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda told parliament.
Kazuo Ueda’s remarks notwithstanding, the BOJ will keep a close eye on the bond market as it still holds about half of all outstanding government debt.
Japan’s benchmark 10-year bond yields have kept increasing over the past month, hitting the highest level since 2008 this week.

site_title: Carney says Canada ‘too reliant on US’ on UK, France trip
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney has warned his country must reduce its reliance on the US, citing a need to diversify trade and security ties. During his first trip abroad, Carney visited key European powers France and the UK, instead of the US, amid US President Donald Trump's threats to annex Canada and impose tariffs. Carney emphasized the importance of maintaining "reliable" European allies, while also retaining positive relations with Washington, and expressed support for Ukraine's sovereignty and security.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says: “The level of uncertainty we are facing is exceptionally high. Maintaining stability in a new era will be a formidable task.”

Commuters pass through a walkway near the construction site for the Stuttgart 21 railway and urban development project in Stuttgart, Germany, on Thursday, March 6, 2025. Chancellor-in-waiting Friedrich Merz plans to free Germany from the fiscal straitjacket that former leader Angela Merkel had locked her country into for more than a decade, a move that will revolutionize public finances and pave the way for Europe’s most powerful economy to bulk up the region’s defense. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg
Li Ka-shing is unlikely to be the last billionaire caught between the world’s two biggest economies.

NEW YORK, NEW YORK - SEPTEMBER 30: Shipping containers sit stacked in the Port of Newark on September 30, 2024 seen from New York City. A massive strike that could shut down ports across the East and Gulf coasts could begin at midnight as members of the International Longshoremen’s Association continue to make salary and other demands to the United States Maritime Alliance, which controls many of the ports across the country.   Spencer Platt/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by SPENCER PLATT / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 17)
summary: Singapore's total trade rose 4.6% year-over-year in February, slower than the 6.6% growth in the previous month. New home sales surged with a record 1,575 units sold for S$2 million or more. Meanwhile, Malaysia plans to establish a Brunei-Sarawak Special Economic Zone to boost trade and tap new growth opportunities, following Singapore's Johor-Singapore model.

site_title: Lee Shau Kee, founder of Henderson Land Group, dies at 97
summary: Hong Kong property magnate Lee Shau Kee, founder of Henderson Land Group, has died at 97. He was born into a middle-class family and moved to Hong Kong at 20, founding his property firm in 1976. Lee was one of the city's richest men, with a wealth estimated at $30 billion. He was a respected philanthropist and businessman, and his company's success was partly due to his good relationship with former Chinese leaders. Lee was known for his outspoken views and philanthropic efforts, leaving behind two sons and three daughters.

images.alt_text: The surge in finder’s fees reflects the weakness in Hong Kong’s commercial real estate market.
Sun Hung Kai Centre developed by Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd. stands in Hong Kong, China, on Thursday, September 13, 2018.
Paul Chan (above), Hong Kong's financial secretary, emphasises artificial intelligence as a core industry.
Hong kong property housing Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg
Hong kong property housing Photographer: Lam Yik/Bloomberg

site_title: US: Stocks gain as market looks ahead to Fed
summary: US stocks rose for the second consecutive day on Monday, driven by better-than-expected US retail sales data, which showed a 0.2% increase in February. The Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 0.9% to 41,841.63, while the S&P 500 rose 0.6% to 5,675.12. Markets are awaiting the Federal Reserve's decision on interest rates later this week, despite expectations of a rate hold. The data helped to keep market momentum alive, with individual stocks such as PepsiCo and Intel also seeing gains.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on March 7, 2025, in New York City. Wall Street stocks rose early March 7, digesting a mixed jobs report as markets seek a pivot from a rough period amid tariff uncertainty. The US added 151,000 jobs last month, up from January's revised 125,000 figure, but fewer than analysts estimates as unemployment ticked higher. (Photo by CHARLY TRIBALLEAU / AFP)

site_title: Fed likely to keep rates steady with markets ‘confused’
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to keep interest rates steady, defying market expectations of a potential rate cut, amid concerns over inflation risks due to the ongoing trade war. Despite recent economic data showing signs of slowing growth and consumer spending, the Fed is likely to prioritize inflation control over growth, citing the potential for "tariff-fuelled" inflation risks. This decision may dash hopes for a rate cut and put pressure on the stock market, which has been buoyed by consumer spending data and optimism about a potential rate cut.

images.alt_text: Over the years, Fed policymakers and economists have made a range of suggestions about how to improve the dot plot, which has been published in its current form since well before Powell became chair in 2018.
The Nasdaq plunged by 4.0 per cent, bringing it to 17,468.32 on Monday.
While Trump's administration pledged to capitalise the reserve with crypto seized in legal proceedings, the absence of fresh capital commitments disappointed investors.
European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde says: “The level of uncertainty we are facing is exceptionally high. Maintaining stability in a new era will be a formidable task.”

site_title: Indonesia extends Freeport Indonesia's copper export permit for six months
summary: Indonesia has extended Freeport Indonesia's copper export permit for six months, allowing the miner to export 1.2 million metric tons of copper concentrate. The extension was granted to expedite repairs to a smelter in East Java, which was halted due to a fire last October. The decision aims to generate state revenues from royalties.

site_title: Why did OCBC put Chulia Street redevelopment plans on the back burner?
summary: OCBC Bank has put its plans to redevelop its Chulia Street property on hold due to high development costs, estimated to be around S$2 billion, which would derail its plans to return capital to shareholders. The redevelopment would also require a substantial land betterment charge and construction costs have risen substantially post-Covid. With the bank's priority being to optimize capital for shareholder returns, the project's high costs and complexity have led to the deferral of the redevelopment plans.

images.alt_text: OCBC Centre South in the foreground. To the left behind it is the 50-storey OCBC Centre, where the bank's head office is located/
For the financial year 2025, OCBC is targeting a net interest margin (NIM) of around 2 per cent and a mid-single-digit loan growth.
The bank's properties include OCBC Centre, OCBC Centre South and OCBC Centre East.

site_title: ComfortDelGro deploys commercial robotaxis in Guangzhou
summary: ComfortDelGro, a transport giant, has launched its first commercial robotaxi programme in Guangzhou, China, in partnership with Pony AI. The two-year pilot aims to develop and refine capabilities for autonomous transport solutions, with a focus on future large-scale deployment in China and internationally. CEO Cheng Siak Kian views autonomous vehicle technology as "crucial" for future-proofing the transport industry, particularly due to driver shortages.

images.alt_text: The company will also focus its operations on international markets outside of the US, such as South Korea, Singapore and the Middle East, Peng says.
Generic pix of a woman getting into a ComfortDelGro taxi along Syed Alwi Road on Feb 20, 2023. Can be used for stories on transport, cab, hailing

site_title: Political inertia will end when climate-change impact is ‘too big to ignore’: Ravi Menon
summary: Singapore's Ambassador for Climate Action Ravi Menon says that political inertia on climate change will end when extreme weather and resource shortages disrupt livelihoods on a scale "too big to ignore". Menon notes that the world is moving towards a "climate-impaired" and "carbon-constrained" future, where businesses must transition planning to secure market leadership and attract sustainable capital. He identifies key risks, including rising carbon prices, failing to keep up with innovation in low-carbon technologies, and physical risks of climate change. Menon calls on businesses to take action, set climate targets, and work with government agencies to develop sector-specific road maps.

images.alt_text:
pasff - Mr Ravi Menon, chairman of the Global Finance & Technology Network (GFTN). The former chief central banker is also Singapore’s Ambassador for Climate Action. 

Credit: GFTN

site_title: Intel’s new CEO plots overhaul of manufacturing and AI operations
summary: Intel's new CEO, Tan Lip-Bu, is implementing a sweeping overhaul of the company's manufacturing and AI operations. The plan includes restructuring the company's approach to AI, staff cuts to address a slow-moving middle management layer, and restarting production of chips for AI servers. Intel will also focus on areas beyond servers, such as software, robotics, and AI foundation models. Tan aims to improve performance at Intel's manufacturing arm by wooing new customers and has little choice but to make the existing operation work in the short run. The company's financial success is tied to strong sales of its forthcoming chip, Panther Lake, equipped with AI features.

images.alt_text: Lip-Bu Tan has more than 20 years of semiconductor and software experience.
Lip-Bu Tan has more than 20 years of semiconductor and software experience.
Intel’s new leader will have to navigate approaches from suitors and decide whether to stick with Gelsinger’s stance that a breakup is unnecessary .

Intel senior principal engineer Steve Carson said Intel has produced 30,000 wafers, the large discs of silicon that can yield thousands of computing chips, in a single quarter with ASML’s high numerical aperture (NA) lithography machines.
Intel, once dominant in the chip industry, has struggled to regain its technological edge and lost market share to rivals in recent years.
Intel was among the largest beneficiaries of the US push to onshore critical chip manufacturing led by former president Joe Biden’s administration.

site_title: UK’s post-Brexit leadership tested by Ukraine
summary: The UK, with its unique global ties, is well-positioned to lead a "coalition of the willing" to help Ukraine, following the US's stance on the issue. Prime Minister Keir Starmer hosted a Lancaster House summit and a meeting of European leaders, including Turkish President Erdogan, Australian Prime Minister Albanese, and New Zealand Prime Minister Luxon. The UK is pushing for Russia to back a 30-day ceasefire plan, and Starmer has vowed to tighten sanctions if Putin stalls. The emerging coalition must navigate US security guarantees and the risk of a fast, rather than fair, deal with Russia.

images.alt_text: TOPSHOT - (L-R) Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky, Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer and France's President Emmanuel Macron embrace after holding a meeting during a summit at Lancaster House in central London on March 2, 2025. European leaders descend upon London today for talks to "drive forward" action on Ukraine, according to the office of UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer. The summit caps off a week of intense diplomacy for host Starmer, who met with President Donald Trump on Thursday in an effort to draw together the European and US approaches to the Ukraine conflict. (Photo by JUSTIN TALLIS / POOL / AFP)
Britain's Prime Minister Keir Starmer and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy shake hands during a bilateral meeting at 10 Downing Street ahead of a summit of European leaders.

site_title: Europe can easily safeguard Ukraine
summary: Europe can easily provide Ukraine with the necessary military supplies and financial support to counter Russia's aggression, despite US withdrawal. Europe has the resources to keep Ukraine in the fight, including access to advanced military systems and significant unspent funds in the NextGenerationEU pandemic-recovery fund. A European peace plan can succeed if Putin is convinced that the cost of continued assault on Ukraine would become untenable for Russia. Europe can also increase support for Ukrainian drone development and provide a credible security guarantee, but this would require significant increases in defense spending and mobilizing hundreds of thousands of troops.

images.alt_text: Anti-Brexit demonstrators protest outside the Houses of Parliament in Westminster, London.

site_title: Indonesia’s February trade surplus surpasses expectations, but risks loom
summary: Indonesia recorded a trade surplus of US$3.1 billion in February, surpassing expectations, driven by a surge in palm oil exports. The country's exports rose 14.1% year-on-year, with crude and refined palm oil shipments increasing by 90%. However, analysts warn that the global trade outlook remains precarious due to US trade policy uncertainties and potential trade war tensions. Despite this, Indonesia aims to break through the 5% growth barrier and is expected to maintain a manageable current account deficit.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A worker transports palm oil fresh fruit bunches during harvest at a plantation in Kampar regency, Riau province, Indonesia April 26, 2022. Picture taken April 26, 2022. Picture taken April 26, 2022. REUTERS/Willy Kurniawan/File Photo

site_title: UBS trims CEO Ermotti’s pay to 15m Swiss francs amid Swiss scrutiny
summary: UBS has reduced CEO Sergio Ermotti's compensation to 14.9 million Swiss francs (S$22.6 million) for 2024, below the maximum possible under rules adjusted last year. The package includes 2.8 million francs in fixed and 12.1 million francs in variable compensation. This move comes amid heightened scrutiny in Switzerland over bankers' pay, with lawmakers proposing to limit annual compensation to 3-5 million Swiss francs. The decision aims to address concerns while UBS faces a potential US$25 billion increase in capital requirements.

site_title: Sea’s billionaire founder Forrest Li confirms bid to become Singapore football chief
summary: Tech billionaire Forrest Li, founder of Sea Ltd, has confirmed his bid to become Singapore's football chief, running for the Football Association of Singapore (FAS) presidency. Li, 47, a naturalized Singapore citizen, has previously served as FAS council member and chairman of the Lion City Sailors. His bid follows the announcement of FAS' extraordinary congress and elections on April 28, with incumbent president Bernard Tan not confirming if he will stand for re-election. Li's success at the Sailors has been praised by former Singapore coach V Sundramoorthy, who sees his bid as a positive for Singapore football.

images.alt_text: ‘Firing on multiple cylinders’: Analysts hike target prices for Sea by 10-39%
Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee beat its original guidance for the full year.

Ryt Bank is jointly-owned by YTL Digital Capital and Singapore’s Sea. The joint venture was among five successful candidates that obtained digital banking licenses approved by the Ministry of Finance.
E-commerce players like Shopee are unlikely to employ the deep discounts of yester-year in growing their market share.

site_title: How to make an impact that outlives you
summary: A legacy is not solely measured by wealth, but by the lives touched, wisdom shared, and values upheld. Building a lasting legacy starts now, through daily actions and values, rather than waiting until later years. Key ways to create a legacy include passing on wisdom and values through writing, mentoring, building meaningful relationships, creating something lasting, and making a difference in the community. By prioritizing these aspects, individuals can shape future generations and leave a lasting impact.

images.alt_text: The closure of the CPF Special Account for those turned 55 from January 15 has raised questions on what to do with the SA funds which will be transferred to the Ordinary Account.

site_title: Samsung needs ‘do-or-die’ mindset to survive AI challenges: Yonhap
summary: Samsung's chairman, Lee Jae-yong, has urged the company to adopt a "do-or-die" mindset to confront the challenges posed by artificial intelligence, after struggling to meet Nvidia's requirements and facing a crisis. The company's operating profit sank 33% in the fourth quarter due to research spending. Lee emphasized the need to invest for the future, even if it means sacrificing short-term profits. This comes after Samsung acknowledged fundamental technological competitiveness issues and a future crisis.

images.alt_text: The Edge will use some of the same technologies as the new Ultra model, but fit them inside a slimmed-down design.
TM Roh says Samsung is still trying to determine the release date and price for that product but the level will not be based exclusively on manufacturing costs.
The Edge will use some of the same technologies as the new Ultra model, but fit them inside a slimmed-down design.
Samsung is counting on its unique market position as a leader in not just mobile devices but also home appliances such as refrigerators and washers, CEO Han Jong-Hee says.

site_title: Chinese data centre firm GDS seeks record US$3.4 billion loan
summary: Chinese data centre firm GDS Holdings is seeking a record $3.4 billion loan for its operations in Malaysia, its largest-ever loan and one of the largest financings by a borrower in Asia. The loan, syndicated to the broader market, will be used for refinancing and capital expenditure purposes. GDS has data centres in several countries, including Singapore, Malaysia, and Japan, and has been expanding its presence in Malaysia since 2021.

images.alt_text: Oracle already has two cloud computing centers in Singapore, and last year announced a US$6.5 billion plan to build a similar facility in Malaysia.
Singapore has cemented itself as a global digital hub, with cloud services and data centres forming the backbone of its digital economy.
Two new sets of advisory guidelines have been issued for data centre operators and cloud service providers to boost resilience and security.

site_title: Hong Leong Foundation commits more than S$2 million to NKF to upgrade dialysis centre
summary: The Hong Leong Foundation has committed over S$2 million to the National Kidney Foundation (NKF) to upgrade its dialysis centre in Aljunied Crescent, increasing its capacity to 28 dialysis stations and serving 168 patients. The donation also includes S$60,000 for expanding kidney screenings across Singapore to identify high-risk individuals, with the goal of screening 5,000 individuals annually. This move aims to tackle the rising 'kidney tsunami' in Singapore, with NKF's patient numbers tripling since 2006.

images.alt_text: Hong Leong Foundation governors Quek Kon Hui (second from left) and Michelle Kwek (third from left) playing rhythmic games with senior beneficiaries at Silver Dance Fiesta.

site_title: US retail sales rebound moderately in February
summary: US retail sales rose 0.2% in February, rebounding from a 1.2% decline in January, as the economy continued to grow at a moderate pace despite tariffs and mass firings weighing on consumer sentiment. The decline followed hefty gains in the fourth quarter and winter storms, while consumer sentiment sank to a near 2½-year low in March. Economists forecast the economy to grow at a 1.2% pace this quarter, down from a 2.3% growth rate in the fourth quarter.

images.alt_text: Dollar General says that some of its customers are under so much financial strain that they are pulling back on essential items, while higher-income consumers are shifting to shopping at discount chains.

site_title: Trump trade war to sap Canadian, Mexican and US growth, OECD says
summary: The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has forecast that President Donald Trump's tariff hikes will slow global growth, with the US, Canada, and Mexico experiencing economic slowdowns. Global growth is expected to slow from 3.2% in 2024 to 3.1% in 2025 and 3.0% in 2026. The tariff hikes will also drive up inflation, leading to higher interest rates and a potential economic drag on US households. The OECD estimates that the US economy will suffer a significant hit, with growth 0.7 percentage points lower than expected by the third year.

images.alt_text: On Wednesday, US Federal Reserve chairman Jerome Powell may have to deliver some bracing news: the post-pandemic era of inflation may have been extended by the trade war.
Trump told reporters aboard Air Force One that “in certain cases, both” types of levies would be placed on foreign goods imported to the US.

site_title: EC World Reit appoints new property managers, port operator
summary: EC World Reit, a Singapore-based real estate investment trust, has appointed new property managers and a port operator for its assets. The appointments follow a tender process due to concerns over the previous property manager, Yuntong Property Management, and unauthorized mortgages of three properties. Hangzhou Wangcheng Property Service and Hangzhou Chonghang Port Supply Chain have been appointed as the new property manager and port operator, respectively, with contract terms set to expire on December 31, 2025.

images.alt_text: Above: Stage 1 Properties of Bei Gang Logistics, one of six properties in EC World Reit’s portfolio.
Fu Heng e-commerce warehouse in Hangzhou owned by EC World REIT.
EC World Reit defers its H1 distribution due to insufficient funds.

site_title: Creative Technology cuts workforce, joining wave of tech layoffs
summary: Creative Technology, a Singapore-based electronics firm, has retrenched about 40 staff, or 14% of its workforce, amid a global tech trend of layoffs that started in 2022. The company cited restructuring and adapting to evolving market conditions as reasons for the move, which affected several departments, including sales and marketing. This is part of a larger trend in the technology industry, with hundreds of thousands of employees given the pink slip since 2022, including those at Meta, TikTok, and Google.

site_title: Asia: Markets start week on front foot as China unveils consumer plan
summary: Asian markets started the week on a positive note as China unveiled a plan to boost consumer spending, citing property reforms, stabilizing the stock market, and encouraging lenders to provide more consumption loans. The plan aims to promote reasonable wage growth and address economic weakness. Despite optimism from US lawmakers passing a spending bill, concerns about Donald Trump's tariffs war continue to cast a shadow over trading floors, with economists warning that China's consumer spending will remain weak.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s 2025 stock market tumble is at least double its peers as analysts point to more investors losing faith in the economic outlook.
Hong Kong stocks rose more than one per cent on Friday, recouping some of the losses suffered over the week.

site_title: Is GuocoLand right to grow in Johor and UOL wrong to wait?
summary: GuocoLand is expanding into the Johor market through its partnership with UEM Sunrise in the new Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ). The JS-SEZ aims to create 20,000 new jobs and strengthen the value proposition of Johor and Singapore in competing for global investments. Despite potential execution risks, GuocoLand's strong Malaysian connections and experience in property development and investment in Malaysia make it well-positioned to navigate the Johor market. The JS-SEZ's strong economic rationale and the potential for job creation and talent attraction in Johor make GuocoLand's decision to grow in the market a potentially rewarding one.

images.alt_text: Hafizuddin Sulaiman (left), UEM Sunrise officer in charge and chief financial officer,  and Cheng Hsing Yao (right), group chief executive officer of GuocoLand, at the memorandum of understanding signing on Thursday (Feb 27).
Residential sales momentum will continue with Singapore’s growing economy, said Liam Wee Sin,  chief executive of UOL.
The incentives by the Malaysian Investment Development Authority are available to both new and existing companies operating within the JS-SEZ’s flagship zones.

site_title: BCA board appoints deputy chairman Tan Thiam Soon as chairman
summary: The Building and Construction Authority (BCA) board has appointed Professor Tan Thiam Soon as its new chairman, effective April 1, succeeding Lim Sim Seng. Tan, an institute professor at the Singapore Institute of Technology, will oversee the organisation's refreshed Built Environment Industry Transformation Map and industry branding efforts. Three new members, including Tan Yoong Heng and John Lim, will also join the board. Nine current members will be reappointed for a two-year term, bringing the total board members to 14.

images.alt_text: A significant rollout of residential projects led to higher than expected demand in 2024.

site_title: Japan's Nomura ties up with regional bank Hyakujushi to boost wealth business
summary: Nomura Holdings, Japan's largest securities firm, has partnered with regional lender Hyakujushi Bank to boost its wealth management services. Hyakujushi will pass on customer accounts, such as stock and bond investment trust accounts, to Nomura, which will transfer staff and provide access to its financial platform. This partnership aims to tap into Japan's vast savings held by households, with around half currently in cash and deposits, and capitalize on the trend towards investing in higher-return financial products.

images.alt_text: Nomura says it will stick to its target set four years ago, to deploy US$125 billion of sustainable financing to March 2026.
Nomura is making a big push in private banking as part of its efforts to diversify revenue beyond investment banking and global markets.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Sats, Far East Orchard, Sin Heng
summary: Keppel's wholly owned subsidiary Kepland Investama is involved in a civil action over ownership rights for land plots in Jakarta, where the International Financial Centre Jakarta Tower 2 building complex is situated. Sats signed a MOU with Vietnam Airlines to build and operate an air cargo terminal. Far East Orchard's hotels were hit by a cybersecurity incident, while Sin Heng Heavy Machinery received a voluntary unconditional offer to take the company private at S$0.58 per share.

site_title: Thailand approves 200 billion baht of projects to expand Bangkok metro system, data-centre network
summary: Thailand approved 200 billion baht (S$7.9 billion) in projects, including a Bangkok metro line and three data centers, to boost economic growth. The government aims for a 3.5% growth rate this year, up from 2.5% in 2024. The approved projects include a 109 billion baht investment in Bangkok's Orange Line and a 72.7 billion baht data center in Rayong province. The government is also revising rules to encourage healthcare projects, offering longer tax holidays for companies building hospitals with at least 91 beds.

site_title: Gold edges higher as geopolitical and economic concerns linger
summary: Gold prices rose 0.2% to a record high of $3,004.86 per ounce, driven by geopolitical tensions, trade frictions, and interest rate cut hopes. US gold futures eased 0.1% amid a fragile ceasefire between Israel and Hamas. US consumer sentiment plummeted to a 2½-year low, fueling inflation concerns. The US Federal Reserve's monetary policy meeting on Wednesday is expected to influence gold prices.

images.alt_text: A selection of one kilogram gold bars at Conclude Zrt bullion dealer arranged in Budapest, Hungary, on Monday, Feb. 17, 2025. Gold advanced, following its biggest one-day decline in two months, on nervousness over President Donald Trump’s latest trade threats. Photographer: Akos Stiller/Bloomberg

site_title: Fashion retailer Forever 21 operator files for bankruptcy
summary: Forever 21, a US-based fashion retailer, filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy with assets ranging from $100 million to $500 million and liabilities of $1 billion to $10 billion. The company plans to wind down its US operations while exploring a going concern transaction or asset sale. This marks the second bankruptcy for the brand, which has over 540 locations globally and has struggled with high inflation, reduced clothing budgets, and increased online shopping.

images.alt_text: Efforts by Forever 21 to find a buyer to avoid liquidation have so far failed, said the people, who asked not to be identified discussing private information.

The Forever 21 trademark and intellectual property are owned by apparel and lifestyle label empire Authentic Brands, which licenses them to the operating company that would undergo a Chapter 11 process.
Authentic Brands Group bought the Forever 21 brand name out of bankruptcy in February 2020 and licensed it to Sparc Group.

site_title: Sembcorp is said to conduct strategic review of business
summary: Sembcorp Industries, backed by state-owned Temasek Holdings, is conducting a strategic review of its business, considering options such as going private or selling assets. The review is being carried out with a financial adviser and may result in a deal, but no decisions have been made yet. The company has assessed options to enhance shareholder value, including investments, divestments, restructuring, and capital management. Sembcorp's shares have climbed 250% since 2020, and the company has completed past divestments and restructurings.

images.alt_text: Sembcorp has opened a new power plant in Myanmar, with solar energy panels and advanced technology to maximise power output while minimising greenhouse gas emissions.
Shares of Sembcorp dropped on Friday (Mar 14) morning after a deal inked by one of its subsidiaries to import natural gas from Indonesia fell through.
This will not affect Sembcorp’s energy costs or its ability to meet gas supply requirements in Singapore, says Sembcorp.
The Manah II Solar Power Plant is Sembcorps first foray into the Middle East renewables market and also its largest utility scale solar farm in its global renewables portfolio.
For investors, Sembcorp’s missed target should be of little concern, the writer argues.
Profit from Sembcorp’s gas business has outpaced capacity growth over the past two years.
Sembcorp Energy Storage System (ESS) at Banyan in Jurong Island, on Feb 2, 2023.
Sembcorp Industries' proposed acquisition of Puente Al Sol will be its entry into the Philippines' renewable energy market.

A new solar farm located at Keppel Terminal has commenced operations, Sembcorp Industries said on Thursday (Jan 23). The 18 megawatt-peak facility is a joint project between Sembcorp Industries and PSA Singapore.
0806 TYM / SEMBCORP POSTS NET PROFIT OF S$540 MILLION IN 1H2024
Sembcorp says that the signing of MOUs is not expected to have a material impact on the earnings per share and net tangible assets per share for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2025.

site_title: SIA, Scoot passenger traffic eases in February amid post-holiday lull
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) and its low-cost arm Scoot reported a 0.5% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in February, amid a post-holiday lull. Scoot, however, saw a 9.3% drop in passenger traffic. The group's cargo carriage increased 2.6% year-on-year due to increased cargo flow within East Asia. SIA's passenger traffic rose 3.6%, while Scoot adjusted its China network, launching new flights and suspending others.

images.alt_text: In January, SIA carried 2.4 million passengers and Scoot ferried 1.2 million passengers.

site_title: What’s next for Asian high-yield bonds?
summary: Asian high-yield bonds rebounded 15% in 2024, outperforming European and American counterparts, despite sluggish inflows. The market's strong rebound was driven by supportive policy measures in China, idiosyncratic turnaround stories, and a favorable environment for risk assets. However, flows remain weak, and managers are taking a cautious approach in 2025, citing tight credit spreads and the risk of economic conditions weakening. Despite this, Asia's macro fundamentals remain strong, presenting a reasonable investment proposition, particularly for funds with experienced and capable teams and robust risk management practices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sale signs adorn residential buildings under construction in Huizhou, Guangdong province, China October 10, 2024. Picture taken through a windshield. REUTERS/Nicoco Chan/File Photo

site_title: Trump says both reciprocal and sectoral tariffs coming Apr 2
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to impose both reciprocal and sectoral tariffs on foreign goods imported to the US, starting April 2. Reciprocal tariffs, which target imports from each country based on its own tariffs, were previously discussed, while sectoral tariffs target specific industries such as autos, steel, and aluminium. The move is seen as more aggressive, despite initial market reactions and strained alliances, with Trump stating it will "liberate" the US and restore its wealth.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Donald Trump speaks to reporters aboard Air Force One on his return to Washington, D.C., U.S., March 16, 2025.  REUTERS/Kevin Lamarque      TPX IMAGES OF THE DAY

site_title: Volkswagen to launch 11 new models in China to claw back market share
summary: Volkswagen plans to launch 11 new models in China by 2026, including six electric vehicles, two plug-in hybrids, and two range-extended EVs, to regain market share. The new models will feature high-performance digital features like autonomous driving capabilities and over-the-air updates. Volkswagen aims to sell four million vehicles annually in China by 2030, with approximately 40 new models to be rolled out between 2025 and 2027, more than half of which will be electric vehicles.

site_title: Guess BT Editors’ Choice Award winners and stand a chance to win S$50 FairPrice vouchers
summary: The Business Times will hold its inaugural Editors' Choice Awards, recognizing top stories and commentary from 2024. Readers can predict the winners of Story of the Year and Commentary/Feature of the Year by visiting the contest site and submitting their choices. Five winners will receive $50 worth of FairPrice vouchers, with notification sent via email by April 14.

site_title: Banks boom and shoppers scrimp a year after Japan’s rate pivot
summary: Japan's banks are experiencing record profits a year after the Bank of Japan's (BOJ) historic rate hike, while consumers are struggling with steeper food bills and higher borrowing costs. The BOJ's rate hikes are seen as a step towards a lasting cycle of rising wages, consumption, and growth, but consumers are less convinced due to stagnant real wages and rising prices. The government's ability to rein in outlays is also being tested as higher borrowing costs and benchmark 10-year government bond yields surge to a 17-year high.

images.alt_text: When inflation in Japan started to accelerate in 2022, wage gains lagged the increase in import costs, which kept real wages and consumption lacklustre, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda told parliament.
Kazuo Ueda’s remarks notwithstanding, the BOJ will keep a close eye on the bond market as it still holds about half of all outstanding government debt.
With consumer inflation exceeding its target for nearly three years, the BOJ has signalled its readiness to raise interest rates further if the economy sustains a moderate recovery.
Japan’s benchmark 10-year bond yields have kept increasing over the past month, hitting the highest level since 2008 this week.

site_title: China planning for global CEOs to meet Xi in Beijing next week: sources
summary: Global CEOs, including Qualcomm's Cristiano Amon and Saudi Aramco's Amin Nasser, are set to attend the China Development Forum in Beijing next week, with some expected to meet President Xi Jinping. The event aims to reverse foreign investment outflows and address economic weakness. The gathering comes as the US and China negotiate tariffs, with Xi seeking to cast China as a supporter of private enterprise. The meeting may also touch on issues like fentanyl and economic stimulus.

images.alt_text: China’s top leaders have maintained an economic growth target of “around 5 per cent” for 2025.
The new plan is part of China’s drive to make domestic demand the main engine and anchor of its economic growth.
Spurring reluctant Chinese consumers to spend has been elevated to the top of Beijing’s to-do list for 2025, as lawmakers look to rectify imbalances in the world’s second-largest economy.
Wankelai store manager Leo Liu promotes a pair of shoes on discount to customers during a flash sale in Beijing, China, Feb 27, 2025.

site_title: ECB to cut rates by less as Europe ramps up spending: poll
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) is expected to cut interest rates two more times, with analysts predicting back-to-back cuts in April and June. However, unlike previous rounds, respondents now expect the deposit rate to stay at 2% until the end of the survey period. This shift in views is attributed to European governments' plans to boost investments in defense and infrastructure, which may lead to increased inflationary pressure in late 2026. Analysts still predict the euro-zone economy to gain momentum, with growth of 0.9-1.5% over the next three years.

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) Vice-President Luis de Guindos says: “What we’re seeing is that the new US administration isn’t very open to continuing with multilateralism, which is about co-operation across jurisdictions and finding common solutions for common problems."
The central bank lowered borrowing costs this month for the sixth time since June as inflation abates and the economy wobbles.
There’s been a lot of focus on the neutral rate of interest – a theoretical point at which policy neither stimulates nor holds back economic activity.
FILE PHOTO: EU flags flutter in front of European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany July 18, 2024. REUTERS/Jana Rodenbusch/File Photo

site_title: Singapore’s key exports up 7.6% in February, reversing from January drop
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) grew 7.6% in February, reversing from the previous month's 2.1% decline. However, the figure missed economists' median estimate of a 9.7% increase. Total trade climbed 4.6% year on year, slowing from the 6.6% growth in the preceding month. Electronics exports rose 6.9%, driven by increases in disk media, integrated circuits, and PCs. Private-sector economists warn that export growth could slow due to US President Donald Trump's further tariff threats, potentially impacting Singapore's integrated global supply chain.

images.alt_text: Singapore's total trade climbs 6.7 per cent from the corresponding year-ago period in January.。
Electronics shipments grew 8.2 per cent in 2024, compared to a 19.7 per cent contraction in 2023.

site_title: New home sales surge in February, with record number of suburban units sold for S$2 million or more
summary: Singapore's private home sales surged in February, with 1,575 units sold, a 10-fold increase from the previous year and a 45.4% rise from January. This marks a 13-year high for the month, with 603 units sold for at least S$2 million, the highest-ever number. The buying spurt, driven by lower mortgage rates and strong household balance sheets, is expected to continue into the coming months with several new launches. Analysts predict a strong demand for new homes, with some forecasting a 9,500-unit sales figure for the year, but concerns about declining housing affordability may prompt another round of property cooling measures.

images.alt_text: More Singapore residents now live in private condos, spurred by upgrader buying, higher incomes and shifting preferences.
Collective sales of mixed-use developments can be tricky as owners of the various components may have differing views.
An artist's impression of executive condominium project Aurelle of Tampines

site_title: Petronas says still in talks with Sarawak over gas aggregator role
summary: Malaysia's state energy firm Petronas continues discussions with Petros, Sarawak's state-run energy firm, over a gas aggregator role, despite a reported deadlock in negotiations. The talks, which began last year, concern the distribution of Petronas' gas reserves, with Sarawak holding more than 60% of Malaysia's reserves. Petronas stated that it is working closely with the federal government, Sarawak state government, and Petros to ensure all parties' rights and interests are addressed.

site_title: Reserve Bank of India tells IndusInd Bank to finish remedial action this quarter
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) has directed IndusInd Bank to complete remedial action by the end of the current quarter, following the discovery of discrepancies in its derivatives portfolio. The bank's financial health remains stable, but the RBI warns of a one-time hit on earnings. IndusInd's shares fell 27% on their worst trading day ever after the disclosure. The bank is well-capitalized, with a liquidity coverage ratio of 113%, exceeding the regulatory requirement of 100%. The RBI assures depositors that there is no need to react to speculative reports.

site_title: From Johor to Borneo: Malaysia plotting Brunei-Sarawak SEZ to tap new growth frontier
summary: Malaysia is planning a Brunei-Sarawak Special Economic Zone (SEZ) to boost trade and tap into a new growth frontier, similar to its Johor-Singapore model. Thousands of Sarawakians commute to Brunei for higher wages and a strong exchange rate, with Miri offering cost-competitive land, a skilled workforce, and abundant renewable energy. The SEZ aims to position northern Sarawak as a hub for green industries and advanced manufacturing, drawing in tourists and businesses alike.

images.alt_text: Miri offers cost-competitive land, a skilled workforce, and abundant renewable energy, positioning northern Sarawak as a hub for green industries and advanced manufacturing.
Sarawak is benefiting from federal and state government cooperation, aimed at driving high-value projects.
Malaysia’s Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said the Bill would help the country address climate change, while strengthening its position as a “regional frontrunner in low-carbon technologies.”
The Bill will govern the capture, transport, utilisation and storage of carbon dioxide, Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said.
Sarawak has been gaining control over key assets as it seeks greater political and economic autonomy from the federal government.

site_title: China’s property slump persists as stimulus struggles to stabilise sector
summary: China's property slump persisted in February, with new home prices falling 0.1% and 4.8% year-on-year, according to National Bureau of Statistics data. The slump is attributed to structural issues, including a demographic shift, stagnant income, and a glut of unsold homes. Government measures and promises of more stimulus failed to boost demand, with property investment and sales declining 9.8% and 5.1% year-on-year, respectively. Analysts predict a trough in prices in 2025, with a more likely L-shaped recovery than a U- or V-shaped one.

images.alt_text: China's housing minister Ni Hong says that “since January and February, the real estate market maintained a positive trend of stopping declines and returning to stabilisation”.
China’s property crisis has led to dozens of defaults and created a nearly US$160 billion pile of distressed debt.

Residential buildings at a government-subsidized rental housing complex in Beijing, China, on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024. China promised new measures to support the property sector and hinted at greater government borrowing to shore up the economy, as authorities seek to put a floor under the country’s growth slowdown. Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg

Investors said recent positive signs, from improving home prices in top cities to industry leader China Vanke’s recapitalisation plan, suggest this year will be the turning point for the real estate market.

site_title: World’s biggest stock rout deepens as Thai market rescue falters
summary: Thailand's stock market has plummeted over 16% this year, making it the world's worst performer among 92 indexes tracked by Bloomberg. A $4.5 billion rescue fund, Vayupak, has failed to revive the market, with foreign investors pulling out $4.2 billion over the past year. Analysts attribute the decline to concerns over high household debt, political uncertainties, and corporate scandals, as well as the US dollar's strength. The government's efforts to boost economic growth through infrastructure investments and tax incentives have been insufficient, and investors remain skeptical about the market's future.

images.alt_text: Thaksin Shinawatra, the de facto chief of the ruling Pheu Thai Party, says: “We want to be competitive in data centres and AI.”
Thailand is one of many countries eager to join the F1 circuit.
Bilateral trade between Singapore and Thailand reached S$44.5 billion in 2024.

site_title: India in talks with New Zealand on trade deal as US tariffs loom
summary: India is negotiating a free trade deal with New Zealand amid rising US tariffs uncertainty. India's Commerce Minister Piyush Goyal met with New Zealand's Trade Minister Todd McClay, aiming to achieve better market access and supply chain integration. The talks come as the US is set to impose blanket tariffs on April 2, affecting industries beyond steel and aluminum. New Zealand joins other nations, including the EU and UK, in trying to hammer out free trade agreements with India.

site_title: Australian inflation may quicken after cyclone, Treasurer Jim Chalmers warns
summary: Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers warns that consumer prices may rise after Cyclone Alfred causes significant economic damage, estimated to hit A$1.2 billion and potentially wiping 0.25% off quarterly economic growth. The cyclone's destruction of crops and homes could lead to upward pressure on inflation, affecting both consumers and the government ahead of the May 17 election.

images.alt_text: ASX’s group executive of listings, Blair Beaton, said dual-class shares had not been allowed in Australia previously which was placing the domestic market at a disadvantage compared to its major global rivals.
A key US security ally in the Indo-Pacific, Australia is a small global exporter of steel although it is the world’s largest exporter of the main steelmaking raw material iron ore.
A survey from National Australia Bank showed its index of business conditions edged up 1 point to +4 in February, but remained below long-run averages.

site_title: Shein says US tariff hit won’t stop fast-fashion flood
summary: Shein's executive chairman, Donald Tang, says US tariffs imposed on Chinese imports won't stop the company from operating in the US market. Despite allegations of forced labor and environmental concerns, Tang insists that Shein has a zero-tolerance policy for such practices and has implemented measures to ensure compliance. The company plans to continue delivering goods to customers and is exploring options for a market flotation, which Tang believes will reinforce trust.

images.alt_text: Shein’s executive chairman Donald Tang said in an interview that a listing would help the company earn public trust and increase transparency.
Shein’s net profit was down almost 40 per cent at US$1 billion in 2024, the report said, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.
The end of de minimis, a rule that had allowed American shoppers to avoid paying customs on most Shein purchases, was widely expected.
Shein shareholders are suggesting that an adjustment is needed to help get its potential initial public offering in the UK over the line.

site_title: South Korea’s chip exports to China sink as US controls tighten
summary: South Korea's semiconductor exports to China plummeted 31.8% in February, the largest decline in a year, due to US export restrictions on cutting-edge semiconductors. The decline coincides with the US implementing curbs on high-bandwidth memory chips to China, threatening global demand. The slowdown also follows a 2024 rally that fueled South Korea's economic growth. The impact on South Korea's economy is a concern, with the nation expected to lose momentum compared to last year due to US tariffs and weak private spending.

images.alt_text: cpu, chip, semiconductor

site_title: China’s January to February retail sales pick up as economy navigates tariff strains
summary: China's retail sales growth quickened to 4% in January to February, a welcome sign for policymakers as they navigate US trade pressure. Despite this, the economy still faces strains, including rising joblessness and factory output easing. China's top leaders have maintained an economic growth target of "around 5%" for 2025, but analysts say this may be a tall order given pressure on exports and tepid household demand. The US has piled additional 20% tariffs on Chinese goods, threatening more action, and China's industrial output grew 5.9% year-on-year in the first two months.

images.alt_text: Engineers work on humanoid robots at an Agibot factory in Shanghai, China March 12, 2025. REUTERS/Nicoco Chan

site_title: China February bank lending slows more than expected as US tariffs add to uncertainty
summary: China's bank lending slowed more than expected in February, with new yuan loans totaling 1.01 trillion yuan, the lowest since 2020. The slowdown was attributed to the escalating US-China trade war and uncertainty, despite the government's efforts to boost consumption and stimulate the economy. Analysts expect further weakness in bank lending, but non-bank credit growth is expected to remain strong. The central bank has pledged to cut interest rates and inject liquidity into the financial system to support economic growth.

images.alt_text: Premier Li Qiang, in a speech at the opening of the annual meeting of China’s parliament, warned that “changes unseen in a century are unfolding across the world at a faster pace”.
China is beefing up the strength of its banking system after enacting a string of stimulus policies including cuts to mortgage rates and key policy rates.

site_title: China maps out plan to raise incomes and boost consumption
summary: China's State Council plans to boost consumption by increasing wages, stabilizing the stock and real estate markets, and offering incentives to raise the birth rate. The measures aim to ease deflationary pressures and revive retail sales, which have been anaemic since the pandemic. The government will establish a sound mechanism for adjusting the minimum wage and consider setting up a childcare subsidy system to support consumption. This comes after the country's leadership made boosting consumption its top priority for the first time since President Xi Jinping took power over a decade ago.

site_title: Oil advances as China plans economic boost, Red Sea risks grow
summary: Oil prices rose for a second day as China announced plans to boost consumption and stimulate the economy, with Brent crude climbing above $71 a barrel. The move follows China's state-run news agency reporting that Beijing will implement policies to stabilize stock and real estate markets, lift wages, and boost the nation's birth rate. Meanwhile, US military strikes on Yemen's Houthi militants will continue until the group stops targeting civilian and military vessels in the Red Sea.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled 70 US cents, or 1 per cent, higher at US$70.58 a barrel, after falling 1.5 per cent in the previous session.

site_title: Joaquin Niemann closer to US Open berth after LIV Singapore win
summary: Joaquin Niemann secured a spot in the US Open with a five-shot win at the LIV Golf Singapore tournament. Niemann finished at 17 under par, ahead of Brooks Koepka and Ben Campbell. The victory moves him to the top of the LIV Golf standings, making him the top-ranked player eligible for the US Open's Major berth. The USGA will award the US Open spot to the top-ranked LIV Golf player who is not already exempt.

images.alt_text: Sergio Garcia (fifth from left) with young golfers from Tanah Merah Country Club. With them is Patricia Quek, head of UBS Wealth Management Singapore (far left).

site_title: China unveils plan to boost domestic consumption
summary: China has unveiled a plan to boost domestic consumption, aiming to stimulate the country's economy, which has struggled to sustain a strong recovery since the Covid-19 pandemic. The plan promises "special initiatives" to promote reasonable wage growth, property reform, and financial support for individual investors. It also includes measures to link consumer consumption to broader social goals and raise pension benefits. The plan is part of China's drive to make domestic demand the main engine of its economic growth, with a target of around 5% economic growth this year.

images.alt_text: Spurring reluctant Chinese consumers to spend has been elevated to the top of Beijing’s to-do list for 2025, as lawmakers look to rectify imbalances in the world’s second-largest economy.
Wankelai store manager Leo Liu promotes a pair of shoes on discount to customers during a flash sale in Beijing, China, Feb 27, 2025.
China's consumer price index declined 0.7 per cent from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said on Sunday, compared with a 0.5 per cent gain in the previous month.

China's exports rose just 2.3 per cent year-on-year, customs data showed on Friday, missing 5 per cent growth forecast in a Reuters poll of economists, and slowing from December’s 10.7 per cent increase.

site_title: Keppel unit faces civil claim of 2.28 trillion rupiah over ownership of Jakarta land
summary: Keppel's Indonesian unit, Kepland Investama, is facing a civil claim of 2.28 trillion rupiah (S$186.3 million) from Tumpal Hutabarat over ownership of land plots in Jakarta. Kepland denies the claim, citing acquisition of ownership rights in 2000 and possession of land certificates. The company plans to dismiss the claim, citing legal defects and lack of proof under Indonesian Agrarian Law.

images.alt_text: The Keppel Merlimau Cogen Plant is a 1,300 megawatt combined-cycle gas turbine power plant.

Pictured is Cable Retriever, one of Global Marine Group's six vessels. The subsea cable solutions provider provides maintenance and installation services for the global subsea fibre optic cable network.

site_title: US calls for better access to Korean market, South Korean trade minister says
summary: The US has called for better access to South Korea's market, particularly in agriculture and technology sectors, amid concerns over tariffs set to take effect on April 2. Trade Minister Cheong In-kyo asked for exemptions, but expected US President Donald to proceed with the tariffs. South Korea has restrictions on US beef imports due to mad cow disease concerns, and the US is also concerned about South Korea's regulations on technology firms. The US has warned of a potential approach by South Korea and the European Union to regulate US tech companies.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How geopolitical events impact your investments
summary: Geopolitical events, such as elections, wars, and terrorist attacks, can create market volatility, affecting investments. Financial experts advise investors to focus on investment fundamentals, ignoring short-term market noise. They recommend maintaining a long-term perspective, consulting financial advisors, and periodically reviewing portfolios. Singapore's unique position as a logistics hub and politically neutral country makes it adaptable and resilient, positioning it to navigate trade policy changes. By being vigilant and informed, investors can safeguard their investments against the uncertainties of geopolitical events.

site_title: China calls for AI skills training to help graduates find jobs
summary: China's education ministry has called on universities to add vocational courses and AI training to help graduates find jobs amid a record 12.22 million expected university graduates in 2025. The institutions must establish vocational training centers, collaborate with enterprises, and provide specialized AI training. This move comes as China's youth unemployment rate remains high, at 15.7% among 16-24-year-olds in December. The ministry aims to increase employability and address the growing number of graduates in the job market.

site_title: ‘Novocaine’ wins painful weekend for North America box office
summary: Novocaine, an action-comedy starring Jack Quaid, topped the North American box office with an estimated US$8.7 million in its debut weekend, a low-grossing start. Mickey 17, starring Robert Pattinson, took second place with US$7.51 million. Black Bag, starring Michael Fassbender and Cate Blanchett, debuted in third place. Marvel's Captain America: Brave New World remained in fourth place with US$5.5 million, while The Day the Earth Blew Up: A Looney Tunes Movie rounded out the top 10.

images.alt_text: "Mickey 17", starring Robert Pattinson, is director Bong Joon Ho'S first film after winning the best-picture Oscar with "Parasite".
"Captain America: Brave New World" earned an estimated US$15 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period, just over half of last weekend’s take, industry analyst Exhibitor Relations reported.

site_title: Trump-inspired turmoil may be positive for some less well-known markets – including Singapore
summary: US President Donald Trump's policies have created uncertainty, but not negatively impacted all global markets. Since the beginning of the year, the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index is up 21.8%, while the Stoxx Europe 600 is up 8.3%. In contrast, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 have declined 6.7% and 6.2%, respectively. Global capital may shift to less well-known markets, including Singapore, driven by the current turmoil. The Singapore market has attractive features, such as elevated profitability at major banks and real estate investment trusts, which could attract global investor attention.

images.alt_text: The current over-representation of US financial assets in global indices may be peaking.
MAS announced last week that the equities market review group has submitted proposals to boost the local market
By midday on Friday (Mar 7) in the US, the S&P 500 had given up all of its post-presidential election gains.

site_title: 65 Equity Partners’ two Singapore funds focus on driving growth in companies regardless of former listing status
summary: Singapore-based investment firm 65 Equity Partners plans to list two to three companies on the local bourse in the next two to three years. The firm, backed by Temasek Holdings, has S$4.5 billion in assets under management. One of its funds, the Anchor Fund @ 65, has deployed S$700 million into five companies, including Neon, Carsome, and Shopback, with one listing expected to happen soon.

images.alt_text: The move by 65 Equity Partners is happening against the backdrop of Singapore’s amped-up efforts to revive the ailing local equities market. In 2024, delistings from the Singapore Exchange outpaced new entrants to the bourse.
SGX has seen more efforts to invigorate its markets, with funds dedicated to getting listings and IPOs.
Neon has chosen DBS Group Holdings, HSBC Holdings, Morgan Stanley and UBS Group to help with the first-time share sale.
In 2024, a total of 20 companies delisted from the Singapore Exchange, with just four new entrants to the Catalist board.

site_title: Ringgit bears emerge as traders weigh a rate cut in Malaysia
summary: The Malaysian ringgit is expected to weaken to 4.6 US dollars by end-June as traders anticipate a higher risk of an interest rate cut amid trade tensions, particularly due to US tariffs on China, Malaysia's largest trade partner. Analysts at Credit Agricole and Malayan Banking predict the currency will fall to this level due to slowing global trade and Chinese growth. However, growing bets for interest-rate cuts from the Federal Reserve and fading US exceptionalism may support a ringgit move towards 4.35 US dollars by the end of the year.

images.alt_text: While currency volatility has picked up with the tariff measures and trade uncertainty, the impact remains highly uncertain, with developments very fluid, says BNM
The currency is one of the most vulnerable in the region to an escalating trade war given Malaysia’s larger proportion of trade with China.

site_title: Trump’s trade salvos test nerves of central bankers
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies are causing uncertainty among central bankers, with some considering doing nothing to assess their impact on the global economy. Officials from the European Central Bank to the Federal Reserve may keep interest rates unchanged, while others, such as Brazil's central bank, may raise borrowing costs to combat inflation. The high level of uncertainty is described as "exceptionally high" by European Central Bank President Christine Lagarde, who warns that maintaining stability will be a "formidable task."

images.alt_text: European Central Bank (ECB) Vice-President Luis de Guindos says: “What we’re seeing is that the new US administration isn’t very open to continuing with multilateralism, which is about co-operation across jurisdictions and finding common solutions for common problems."

site_title: New CEO insurer appointments in Singapore reflect wealth focus, regional hub status
summary: Singapore's insurance sector has seen new CEOs appointed, reflecting a growing focus on wealth management and regional hub status. The new leaders, including Chan San San from Prudential Singapore, Alistair Chamberlain from Tokio Marine Life Insurance Singapore, and Greg Hingston from Great Eastern, bring wealth management experience and a diverse mix of professional backgrounds. Industry observers say these appointments reinforce Singapore's strategic importance as a hub for insurers and highlight the sector's focus on wealth management and innovative products. The new CEOs are expected to drive growth and navigate the challenging insurance landscape.

images.alt_text: As at end-December, about 40,000 more Singaporeans and permanent residents were covered by integrated shield plans.
Wong Sze Keed, chief executive officer of AIA Singapore, notes the company's strong business performance across total weighted premium income and operating profit after tax in 2024.
The insurer's total weighted new sales in Q4 fell 16% to S$432.7 million from S$514.1 million.

site_title: China ramps up criticism of Li Ka-shing’s BlackRock ports deal
summary: China has increased pressure on CK Hutchison Holdings over its plan to sell its Panama ports stake, with the Hong Kong and Macau Affairs Office reposting a commentary attacking the deal. The commentary, published in Ta Kung Pao, questioned the deal's impact on China and accused CK Hutchison of "spineless grovelling" and "selling out" Chinese people. The move comes as the company agrees to sell 43 ports in 23 countries to a consortium led by BlackRock, generating over $19 billion in cash proceeds.

images.alt_text: Li Ka-shing is unlikely to be the last billionaire caught between the world’s two biggest economies.

site_title: London homebuyers in last ditch effort to dodge stamp duty hike
summary: London homebuyers are racing against time to complete purchases before a stamp duty tax hike, which could add up to £11,000 in extra charges. With the deadline looming, many first-time buyers are already financially strained, and some have abandoned previous purchases due to delays. The UK's economic pressures, including rate increases and inflation, are putting the market under strain, with buyers seeking to dodge the higher taxes. The deadline for completing deals is just before the end of the month, and buyers are urged to act quickly to avoid additional costs.

images.alt_text: Residential properties in view of the Canary Wharf financial, business and shopping district skyline in London, UK, on Monday, May 27, 2024. The UK's chronic housing shortage has become a key battleground between the ruling Conservative Party and the opposition Labour Party ahead of the general election. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

site_title: Vance tells NBC ‘high-level’ TikTok deal expected by deadline
summary: US Vice-President JD Vance expects a "high-level" deal to be reached for TikTok's US operations ahead of April 5 deadline, allowing the app to remain operational in the country. President Donald Trump is in talks with four potential buyers, including billionaire Frank McCourt and Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian, and a deal could come "soon." Vance hopes the administration can finalize the sale without an extension, but acknowledges paperwork could push the deadline.

images.alt_text: TikTok Live is one of the app’s most popular features, and has become even more central to the platform since the launch of TikTok Shop in late 2023.
The social media platform owned by China’s ByteDance is the latest in a string of big tech names to announce major spending projects in the kingdom, after Amazon, Google and Microsoft.
The e-mail to Singapore employees said the layoffs in the trust and safety team come after months of careful consideration.
Despite TikTok Shop’s breakneck growth, the video app’s future in the US is at doubt, given the continued threat of a ban should it fail to sell the US portion of its business.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Capesize market experienced a week of gradual strengthening, with positive momentum building. The C5 Timecharter Average declined $1,507 week on week to $22,190. In the North Atlantic, a few INL breaching fronthaul cargoes with mid-April loading were fixed, reflecting $42,313 on the C9 route. The Panamax market saw slow erosion, with the US Gulf market fundamentals remaining balanced. The Ultramax/Supramax sector experienced slightly positive gains, with the Asian arena seeing stronger levels due to better demand. The Handysize market saw minimal activity, while the VLCC market climbed early in the week but was nudged back down by Thursday. The LNG market continued trending upwards, with gains seen in both the Pacific and Atlantic Basins.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Mar 7, 2025).

site_title: Prabowo’s proposed tax hike rattles miners, jeopardises Indonesia’s downstream ambitions
summary: Indonesia's proposed tax hike on key commodities like copper, gold, and nickel has sent shockwaves through the mining sector. The Energy and Mineral Resources Ministry under President Prabowo Subianto has proposed higher mineral royalties, which could squeeze margins, spook investors, and cast a shadow over the country's downstreaming ambitions. Analysts warn that the move could chip away at the margins and cash flow of Indonesia's metal miners, posing a threat to the country's resource-rich economy.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of vehicles being charged at a Electric Vehicle (EV) charging station on Aug 5, 2022. Can be used for future Electric Vehicles, cars, vans/commercial vehicles and charging stories.
The shortfall stood at 31.2 trillion rupiah (S$ 2.5 billion) in the first two months of 2025, equivalent to 0.13 per cent of gross domestic product, Finance Minister Sri Mulyani Indrawati said.

TOPSHOT - Textile factory workers gather as they listen to a farewell speech during the mass layoffs, in Sukoharjo, Central Java, on February 28, 2025, after the country's Supreme Court declared the textile giant bankrupt as it failed to pay its debts and ceased operations. (Photo by DIKA / AFP)

site_title: Soilbuild Construction makes a comeback
summary: Soilbuild Construction, a Singapore-based construction company, has made a significant comeback after the pandemic years, with revenue rising 58% to S$391.8 million and earnings more than tripling to S$26.6 million in FY2024. CEO Lim Han Ren's experience in private equity has helped the company identify new opportunities, including digitalization and sustainability, to differentiate itself from competitors. The company has secured several high-profile contracts, including a S$647.5 million deal for the construction of a logistics facility, and is poised to capitalize on the growing demand for construction contracts in Singapore, with estimates suggesting S$47-53 billion will be awarded this year.

images.alt_text: XXX

Generic photo for stories related to Singapore Green Plan 2030. The Green Plan intersects with Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) and seeks to tackle climate change, and positions Singapore to achieve its long-term net-zero emissions aspiration.

site_title: Geely billionaire goes on a cost-cutting spree to catch rivals
summary: Li Shufu, Geely's billionaire CEO, has implemented a cost-cutting strategy to address declining profits at his companies. The Taizhou Declaration, a document outlining the strategy, aims to eliminate redundancies and increase internal synergies across the group's five main listed entities. Geely Automobile, Volvo Car, and Polestar are expected to benefit from the consolidation, with Polestar addressing its financial struggles and Volvo focusing on cash preservation. The move is a response to the slowdown in electric vehicle sales and increasing competition from rivals like BYD.

images.alt_text: he borrowing follows a series of refinancing exercises that replaced an original 2.3 billion euros five-year facility from 2017.
The latest agreement gives Geely better access to South America’s biggest economy.
The goal represents about 79 per cent growth from 2023, when Geely Holding sold 2.79 million units of passenger cars and commercial vehicles.

site_title: Thaksin vows cheaper power to turn Thailand into data centre hub
summary: Thailand aims to slash electricity costs by over 25% by next year to become a hub for data centers and artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure. The country's de facto chief, Thaksin Shinawatra, plans to lower the electricity tariff to 8 US cents per unit from 11 US cents, making it competitive with other countries. Thailand has secured billions of dollars in investment commitments from tech majors, and Thaksin believes that offering clean and cheap energy is crucial for the country's success in this area.

images.alt_text: Thailand’s Joint Standing Committee on Commerce, Industry and Banking, a private sector group, also proposed importing more US goods to reduce the trade gap with Washington.

site_title: US places visa curbs on Thai officials over Uyghur deportations
summary: The US has imposed visa restrictions on current and former Thai officials involved in the deportation of 40 Uyghurs to China, citing China's "acts of genocide and crimes against humanity." The move aims to combat China's efforts to pressure governments to forcibly return Uyghurs and other groups. The US Secretary of State, Marco Rubio, stated that the visa curbs will apply to any government officials who deport Uyghurs back to China, and that certain family members of the targeted individuals may also be affected. Thailand has defended the deportation, citing a desire to avoid a backlash from Beijing.

site_title: Getting the math right: Crunch time for shipping’s net-zero ambitions
summary: The shipping industry's pursuit of net-zero ambitions faces significant challenges as none of the alternative fuels currently being developed have the scalability to power the entire global merchant fleet. The International Maritime Organization (IMO) aims to reach agreements on green fuel standards and fossil fuel phase-out timelines in 2025, but current proposals may inadvertently favor liquified natural gas (LNG) over other alternatives. This could hinder the industry's progress toward net-zero emissions, with the pay-to-pollute principle becoming the most financially attractive strategy for shipping companies.

images.alt_text: A new technical reference on methanol bunkering has been published to provide a framework for safe and efficient use of methanol as an alternative in bunkering operations, said MPA.
Maersk's underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) came in at US$3.6 billion for the fourth quarter.

site_title: Li Ka-shing has little to lose as China threatens Panama deal
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's CK Hutchison Holdings agreed to sell its control over 43 ports in Panama to BlackRock for US$19 billion, appeasing US President Donald Trump. China has expressed displeasure, but the conglomerate's limited exposure to mainland China and Hong Kong may limit the impact of any political fallout.
