Li has diversified his business outside of China since the 1980s, and Beijing may think twice about taking coercive action that could destabilize the Hong Kong property sector. The deal has sparked concerns about the potential for further retaliation against CK Hutchison.

images.alt_text: CK Hutchison said last week it agreed to sell most of the global US$22.8 billion ports business, including assets it holds along the strategically important Panama Canal, to a group led by BlackRock.
The decision to hire law firm Paul Hastings marked a shift for CK Hutchison – the Hong Kong conglomerate has worked on many of its deals with law firms such as Freshfields and Linklaters before.

A view of the Balboa Port is pictured after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock Inc-backed consortium, amid pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump to curb China's influence in the region, Panama City, Panama, March 4, 2025. site_title: Hosen Group CEO Daniel Lim increases stake in the company
summary: Hosen Group CEO Daniel Lim has increased his stake in the company after acquiring 716,000 shares at an average price of S$0.44 apiece, raising his direct interest from 2.72% to 2.94%. This comes after Lim's previous acquisitions in early December. The company reported a FY2024 attributable net profit of S$2 million, with revenue increasing by 8.1% to S$72.8 million. Hosen Group focuses on providing high-quality, convenient food solutions to consumers through various channels.

images.alt_text: OVER the five trading sessions from Mar 7 to 13, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks.

site_title: ECB’s VP says uncertainty now higher than during pandemic
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Vice-President Luis de Guindos stated that current uncertainty is higher than during the COVID-19 pandemic, mainly due to the US administration's reluctance to continue multilateral cooperation. This uncertainty affects the economy, with ECB policymakers warning of a potential trade war and its impact on the global economy. Despite forecasts of 0.9% euro area growth, Guindos noted that consumption is not picking up due to consumer uncertainty about the economy's medium-term prospects.

images.alt_text: epa11863722 European Central Bank (ECB) President Christine Lagarde addresses a press conference following the meeting of the ECB Governing Council in Frankfurt am Main, Germany, 30 January 2025.  EPA-EFE/RONALD WITTEK

site_title: Euro gains after German fiscal deal raises hopes of reviving growth
summary: The euro rose 0.27% against the US dollar after German parties agreed on a fiscal deal, including a 500-billion-euro fund for infrastructure, and sweeping changes to borrowing rules. The deal is expected to boost defense spending and revive growth in Europe's largest economy. The euro also gained against the Swiss franc and British pound, while the dollar weakened against the euro and strengthened against the yen. US consumer sentiment plunged in March, but inflation expectations soared, suggesting the US Federal Reserve may be patient in cutting interest rates.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: U.S. Dollar and Euro banknotes are seen in this illustration taken July 17, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Indonesia’s credit conundrum: Risks and opportunities in a fast-growing debt market
summary: Indonesia's credit system is underdeveloped, with high non-performing loan (NPL) risks and increased provision costs for banks. Despite this, the country presents opportunities for fintech, embedded finance, and alternative credit solutions. Artificial intelligence (AI) is revolutionizing credit assessment by using alternative data, enabling more accurate and real-time credit scoring. Embedded finance models, such as those integrated into ride-hailing and e-commerce platforms, are also gaining traction. As the demand for credit is high, and traditional credit assessment methods are limited, investors who identify scalable, technology-driven credit solutions will be at the forefront of South-east Asia's next major financial revolution.

(Photo by DIKA / AFP)
A recent internal probe into the startup alleged that eFishery inflated its revenue and profit over several years.

The discipline and the rigour that founders place in undertaking a financial modelling exercise can also better prepare them for variables and enhance their sense of confidence in dealing with uncertainties ahead of them.

In the area of paediatric cardiology, for example, Indonesia's shortfall in  surgeons and particularly surgeons accredited to operate on infants is a disheartening problem that causes up to 7,000 post-natal fatalities each year.

site_title: DBS announces year-long ‘60-themed’ offers, additional support for SG60
summary: DBS Bank in Singapore has announced a range of year-long measures to commemorate SG60, including "60-themed" offers such as discounted grocery deals and meals, as well as 60% off selected attractions. The bank will also provide support for underprivileged seniors, including improved nutrition and social connections, and offer a one-time cash bonus of up to S$310 to customers who credit their salaries into a DBS or POSB account for three consecutive months.

images.alt_text: SoundEye, one of the awardees this year, uses technology to detect and prevent falls for the elderly. It was established by Tan Yeow Kee in 2015.

site_title: Has ‘US exceptionalism’ peaked? Consider exposure via non-US companies with US businesses
summary: US stocks rose 2% on Friday, pulling the S&P500 out of correction territory, after several sessions of declines. This surge comes amid uncertainty over American policies, particularly President Trump's on-again, off-again stance on tariffs, which has sparked concerns of potential retaliation from trading partners. Historically, the US stock market has delivered significantly higher returns, with US$1 invested in 1900 growing to US$2,911 by 2024, outperforming the rest of the world by 2.3% annually.

images.alt_text: While the S&P 500 has lost 4.5 per cent so far this year, a gauge of Chinese stocks listed in Hong Kong has surged 20 per cent, making it one of the best-performing indexes in 2025.
The decline in demand for euro-dollar options may be fuelled by how last week’s move in the pair affected the option market.
The current over-representation of US financial assets in global indices may be peaking.
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index has posted good performance over the last few weeks amid greater investor rotation into emerging markets.

site_title: Economic fear pummels stocks tied to Americans’ spending
summary: US stocks tied to consumer spending are experiencing a downturn, with the S&P 500 Consumer Discretionary Index falling 15% in the past month. Retailers, airlines, and restaurant operators are struggling due to budget-conscious Americans and uncertainty over the Trump administration's trade policies. Consumer sentiment has plummeted to a two-year low, and long-term inflation expectations have jumped. Companies are shifting to essential goods, and some have cut revenue and profit expectations. Investors are trimming consumer discretionary holdings and overweighting consumer staples companies, citing attractive equity valuations and essential goods.

images.alt_text: Fears of higher prices create a challenge for Federal Reserve officials as they consider the next steps for monetary policy.

site_title: Diversified S-Reits offer portfolio resilience with stable 2024 operating performance
summary: Diversified Singapore Reits (S-Reits) have demonstrated stable 2024 operating performance, with an average distribution yield of 7.6% and a slightly lower price-to-book ratio of 0.7 compared to the broader S-Reit market. The largest diversified S-Reits, including CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust, Mapletree Pan Asia Commercial Trust, and OUE Reit, have outperformed in the year-to-date, with some posting significant gains. This diversification allows S-Reit managers to build resilient portfolios and mitigate against potential slowdowns in individual sectors.

images.alt_text: IReit Global’s FY2024 gross revenue and NPI increased by 16.3 per cent and 7.2 per cent year on year respectively, driven by the B&M Portfolio and higher rents from the Decathlon Portfolio and Berlin Campus (above).

site_title: Gold’s relentless rally continues as technicals point to further upside
summary: Gold prices have surged 14% from the start of 2024, reaching US$2,990 as of March 14, 2025. The technical setup remains bullish, with gold finding support above 20 and 50-day EMA levels, a symmetrical triangle pattern, and an RSI above 50. A breakout from the triangle is expected to reach a measured technical target of US$3,033, with a longer-term objective of US$3,300. The bullish outlook remains intact, with no immediate signs of exhaustion in gold's price action.

images.alt_text: Gold is seen as a hedge against political risks and inflation.

site_title: Saudi Arabia raised by S&P as economic diversification pays off
summary: Saudi Arabia's credit rating was upgraded by S&P Global Ratings to A+, the same level as Japan and China, reflecting the kingdom's efforts to diversify its economy and improve governance effectiveness. The upgrade is a result of the government's spending on Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 strategy, which includes investments in electric vehicles, semiconductors, and tourism. The upgrade comes as the kingdom's economy grew 4.5% year on year in the fourth quarter, despite a projected budget deficit through 2027.

images.alt_text: Neom is a massive urban and industrial development project nearly the size of Belgium to be built along the Red Sea coast.
Apartment prices in the capital of Riyadh rose almost 11 per cent to the equivalent of about US$1,500 per square metre in 2024, according to the research firm.

site_title: GIC’s sustainability head sees investment opportunities in grid development
summary: Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC's head of sustainability, Emily Chew, sees investment opportunities in grid development as renewable energy capacity expands globally. Grid upgrades are crucial to accommodate intermittent renewable sources, and Chew believes this will be the next phase in the energy transition for renewable power generation to succeed. GIC is focusing on long-term asset values and structural trends, despite volatility in sustainable investing, and has a "stronger conviction" that the world is moving towards a scenario where global warming reaches 2-3°C, requiring investment in climate solutions and adaptation.

images.alt_text: The industry players regard Asean governments’ collaboration fundamental to enable a shared power grid in the region.

site_title: Oil rebounds 1% to end week steady amid prospect of Ukraine ceasefire
summary: Oil prices rebounded 1% on Friday, ending the week nearly unchanged, as investors weighed the prospects of a Ukraine ceasefire that could bring back Russian energy supplies. Brent crude futures settled at $70.58 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude closed at $67.18 a barrel. The ceasefire proposal has raised concerns about the potential for Russian oil to remain under sanctions, affecting oil prices.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled US$1.07, or 1.5 per cent, lower at US$69.88 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Trump launches military strikes on Houthi fighters in Yemen
summary: US President Donald Trump launched military strikes against sites in Yemen controlled by the Iranian-backed Houthi militia in response to disruptions to shipping lanes in the Red Sea. The strikes, described as more far-reaching than those under former President Joe Biden, targeted sites in Sana'a and Saada province, killing at least 15 people and wounding 19 others. Trump vowed to use "overwhelming lethal force" until his objective is achieved, while Russia's foreign ministry called for an immediate halt to using force in the region.

images.alt_text: U.S. President Donald Trump looks on as military strikes are launched against Yemen's Iran-aligned Houthis over the group's attacks against Red Sea shipping, at an unspecified location in this handout image released March 15, 2025. site_title: Apple’s Siri chief calls AI delays ugly and embarrassing, promises fixes
summary: Apple's Siri chief, Robby Walker, described delays to key features as "ugly and embarrassing," amid a crisis in the company's artificial intelligence (AI) field. The delays, which may push the enhancements to 2027, follow a public promotion of the technology before it was ready. Walker praised the Siri team for developing "incredibly impressive" features, but emphasized the need for quality over speed. The company is re-evaluating its priorities and will make management adjustments to address the crisis, with no immediate plans to fire top executives.

Apple is betting that a breakthrough new interface can help spur demand after a sluggish stretch.

site_title: Trump administration weighs travel ban on dozens of countries: memo
summary: The Trump administration is considering issuing a sweeping travel ban for the citizens of 41 countries, divided into three groups, as part of an immigration crackdown. The first group of 10 countries, including Afghanistan and North Korea, would face a full visa suspension, while the second group of 5 countries would face partial suspensions affecting tourist and student visas. The third group of 26 countries would face partial suspensions of US visa issuance if their governments address deficiencies within 60 days.

site_title: Spurred by Trump turnabout, European nations debate conscription
summary: European nations are debating reinstating compulsory military service to boost their defenses against Russian aggression following US President Donald Trump's comments on Europe taking care of its own security. Despite concerns about the threat, most of NATO's top spenders, including France, Germany, and the UK, are not planning mandatory military service due to recruiting and retention challenges. Some countries, like Poland and Lithuania, have reintroduced conscription, while others, like Sweden and Finland, have done so recently. Experts suggest that advocacy campaigns and improving military capabilities could convince Europeans to volunteer.

site_title: Sweden’s Klarna discloses 24% revenue surge in much-awaited US IPO filing
summary: Sweden's fintech company Klarna reported a 24% surge in 2024 revenue, reaching $2.81 billion, as it filed for a US IPO. The company expects to trade on the New York Stock Exchange under the symbol "KLAR" and aims to raise over $1 billion at a valuation exceeding $15 billion. Klarna's revenue growth is attributed to its partnerships with major brands, including Sephora, Nike, and Airbnb, and the projected BNPL market size of $160 billion by 2032. The IPO filing comes as stock market volatility threatens to stall recoveries in the IPO market.

site_title: Europe: German stocks lead gains after Merz secures support for historic debt reform
summary: European stocks rose 1.1% on Friday, led by German equities, after Chancellor-in-waiting Friedrich Merz secured support for a historic debt reform deal. The Stoxx 600 index gained 1.9%, with banks, industrial goods, and aerospace sectors advancing. The deal is expected to boost state borrowing, increasing the chances of a cyclical rebound. Despite renewed risk appetite, the Stoxx 600 index still logged a weekly loss, its worst since December, amid ongoing US-EU trade tensions and uncertainty about tariffs.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 closed 0.15 per cent lower at 540.44 points, after finishing higher on Wednesday.

site_title: US consumer sentiment plunges on tariff fears, inflation expectations jump
summary: US consumer sentiment plummeted to a nearly 2½-year low in March, falling to 57.9, amid worries about President Trump's tariffs and escalating trade tensions. Inflation expectations soared to 4.9%, the highest level since November 2022, with consumers predicting 3.9% inflation over the next five years. The decline in sentiment was across all political affiliations, with Democrats seeing a 24% drop in expectations, and is creating a challenge for Federal Reserve officials as they consider the next steps for monetary policy.

site_title: US court allows Trump to enforce ban on DEI programmes, for now
summary: A US appeals court allowed the Trump administration to temporarily enforce a ban on diversity, equity and inclusion (DEI) programs at federal agencies and businesses with government contracts. The ruling, made on March 14, disagreed with a previous judge's ruling that blocked the orders. The Trump administration claims the orders are constitutional and aimed at preventing unlawful discrimination, not suppressing speech. The decision does not necessarily mean the bans will remain in place, as two judges on the panel expressed concerns about the orders' constitutionality.

DEI policies became more widespread after nationwide protests in 2020 against police killings of unarmed Black people.

site_title: Kohl’s is latest retailer to move away from using DEI language
summary: Kohl's, a US retailer, has removed diversity, equity, and inclusion (DEI) language from its website and rebranded its chief DEI officer to "chief inclusion & belonging officer" under new CEO Ashley Buchanan. The move comes amid criticism from the Trump administration and amid broader industry trends of companies dropping DEI-related goals and initiatives. The company cited a focus on "inclusion and belonging" and a broader supplier diversity program, but its shares have plummeted due to poor sales projections.

site_title: Formula One boss to visit Thailand for talks on Bangkok race
summary: Formula One boss Stefano Domenicali is set to visit Bangkok for talks on a potential Formula One race in the Thai capital. This follows interest from Thailand to join the circuit, with the country envisioning a street circuit in the city's historic centre. Domenicali is keen to explore new markets as the sport gains popularity, with the majority of the 2025 calendar already locked in. Thailand is one of several countries vying for a new F1 race, including Rwanda and Turkey.

site_title: The markets never sleep, should trading?
summary: Nasdaq has begun exploring 24-hour trading five days a week, aiming to broaden investor access and expand wealth-building opportunities. The move follows a 97% increase in total foreign holdings of US equities to $17 trillion as of June 2024. Nasdaq plans to engage with regulators and industry stakeholders to enable the change, pending regulatory approval and alignment with critical infrastructure providers, expected in the second half of 2026. The goal is to enhance access for global investors, but careful planning is crucial to maintain liquidity, transparency, and integrity.

images.alt_text: Nasdaq's Cohen points to heightened interest in US markets from retail investors in different time zones.

site_title: US asks countries to help lower soaring prices of eggs
summary: The US Department of Agriculture has reached out to Denmark and other European countries to explore exporting eggs due to soaring prices caused by an accelerating outbreak of bird flu in laying hens. US wholesale egg prices shattered records, increasing 59% year-on-year in February. The US is seeking to import eggs as part of a $1 billion effort to combat the bird flu, with Denmark's egg association stating there is no surplus of eggs in Europe and exports are challenging due to regulations.

site_title: Baidu releases reasoning AI model to take on DeepSeek
summary: Baidu releases a new artificial intelligence (AI) model, Ernie X1, which articulates its reasoning and excels in areas such as daily dialogues, complex calculations, and logical deduction. The model is a response to up-and-coming rival DeepSeek, and Baidu also upgraded its flagship foundation model to Ernie 4.5, making its services, including the X1 model, free for chatbot users. The company plans to make Ernie AI models open-source on June 30, marking a strategic shift. This move follows a 26% jump in cloud revenue in Baidu's December-quarter results, driven by AI services.

images.alt_text: Alibaba accelerated efforts to carve out a leading position in AI after DeepSeek’s splashy debut in January.

site_title: Stuck Nasa astronauts one step closer to home after SpaceX crew-swap launch
summary: US astronauts Butch Wilmore and Suni Williams, who have been stuck on the International Space Station for nine months, are set to return to Earth after a crew-swap launch by SpaceX. The Crew-10 crew, consisting of NASA astronauts Anne McClain and Nichole Ayers, Japanese astronaut Takuya Onishi, and Russian cosmonaut Kirill Peskov, arrived at the station on Saturday. The mission, originally planned for March 26, was accelerated after pressure from US President Donald Trump and SpaceX CEO Elon Musk. The crew will stay on the station for six months, allowing Wilmore and Williams to depart on March 19.

site_title: Trump poised to launch new round of layoffs despite setbacks in court
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration is set to proceed with a second wave of mass layoffs, despite federal court rulings ordering the reinstatement of thousands of workers. The administration had faced a Thursday deadline to submit reorganization plans, which have led to over 100,000 job cuts, foreign aid freezes, and contract cancellations. Vice-President JD Vance acknowledged mistakes during the downsizing process, but defended most federal employees as hard-working. Trump's administration has vowed to fight back against the court rulings, which have dealt a significant setback to their efforts to radically remake the federal bureaucracy.

site_title: Book review: The Making of Modern Corporate Finance
summary: CFA Singapore Insights presents a book review of "The Making of Modern Corporate Finance" by Donald Chew. The book chronicles the development of corporate finance from the 1950s to the present, focusing on key ideas and innovations that underpin the global financial system. Chew explores how the US financial system has driven economic power and wealth creation, highlighting the importance of financial innovation, dynamism, and corporate governance. The book concludes that the US model remains superior, but also acknowledges the limitations of the system and the need for stakeholder engagement and government regulation.

site_title: Mark Carney sworn in as Canadian prime minister, now must face Trump
summary: Canadian ex-central banker Mark Carney was sworn in as prime minister on March 14, becoming the first without serious political experience. He reshaped his Cabinet to focus on US relations, with Finance Minister Dominic LeBlanc moving to international trade and Foreign Minister Melanie Joly staying in her post. Carney plans to address reporters and travel to London and Paris to shore up European alliances amid low US-Canada relations. He vows to deliver action and protect Canada's economy, but faces a potential snap election within two weeks.

site_title: MO Bar’s new menu waves to Singapore’s past, present and future
summary: Mandarin Oriental's MO Bar in Singapore has launched its new menu, "The Echoes of Singapore," which pays tribute to the city's past, present, and future through 15 cocktails across five chapters. The menu features drinks inspired by yesteryear, modern interpretations of iconic culture, and innovative creations. The bar's interior has been revamped with touches of wood and blues, including a retro Viewmaster that patrons can use to explore the cocktail selection. The menu will remain for about a year, with the bar manager stating that it's the hotel's way of "distilling the city's essence into a glass."

The bar’s signature is the Triple P – for “prolific pineapple pinery”, explains the menu, referring to the history of an area of Sentosa Island now known as Palawan Ridge.

site_title: Gen Z Americans don’t have enough saved to cover a single month of spending
summary: Younger Americans, born after 1995, lack sufficient savings to cover a month of expenses, with an average spending ratio of 2:1 in February. This is a significant increase from the past two years and higher than other generations. Gen Z consumers tend to spend more on necessities and discretionary categories, contributing to this trend. The report highlights a growing pessimism among US households about their financial situation, with expectations for finances a year from now at an all-time low.

site_title: Chocolate Finance says customers have started receiving funds; raises debit card spending cap to S$1,000
summary: Customers of Chocolate Finance have started receiving their funds after a four-day pause due to high demand. The fintech platform raised the spending cap on its Chocolate Visa debit card to S$1,000 from S$250 to manage liquidity. Withdrawals are expected to resume in accordance with the standard redemption process, with the company hoping to increase the spending cap again soon.

site_title: South Korea asks US for tariff exemption, trade ministry says
summary: South Korea's acting President Choi Sang-mok has ordered the government to actively communicate with the US administration to resolve misunderstandings over tariffs. The US has announced reciprocal tariffs on all trading partners from April 2, including South Korea, which has asked for tariff exemption. Trade Minister Cheong In-kyo met with US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer, stressing that South Korea should not receive unfavorable treatment. The move comes as US President Donald Trump announces the tariffs, which will affect all US trading partners.

site_title: Bitcoin rises from four-month low amid marketwide ‘relief rally’
summary: Bitcoin rebounded from a four-month low, rising 6.2% to US$85,301 on Friday, amid a global "relief rally" following US President Trump's decision to avoid a government shutdown. Other cryptocurrencies also saw significant gains, with Solana climbing 9% and Chainlink increasing 13%. The rebound was attributed to reduced uncertainty and macroeconomic factors, with investors focusing on lower-than-expected inflation figures.

site_title: Bank of America lays off 16 investment bankers in Hong Kong in global trim: sources
summary: Bank of America has laid off 16 investment bankers in Hong Kong as part of global cuts to its investment banking workforce, mirroring similar exercises at rivals JPMorgan and Goldman Sachs. The US lender is also eliminating 150 junior banker positions globally. The layoffs mainly targeted junior dealmakers, with most being offered positions in other departments. This move comes as deal volumes in Bank of America's home market in the US have fallen below expectations in the first half of the year.

images.alt_text: The return of price and wage growth, rising interest rates and corporate reforms are spurring activity in Japan, Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan said in an interview on Friday.

site_title: Rare iconic movie posters to be auctioned in US
summary: Rare and iconic movie posters from the 20th century, including those from King Kong, Casablanca, and 2001: A Space Odyssey, are set to be auctioned by Heritage showrooms in Dallas on March 27-28. Collected over 50 years by real estate agent Dwight Cleveland, the 500 posters and lobby cards are estimated to fetch between $1,000 and $2,000 each, with some items valued at $40,000 to $80,000. Cleveland is relinquishing his collection, which has been exhibited in several cities, and plans to donate or auction the remaining 10,000 lobby cards and 500 posters.

images.alt_text: “What sets the Joachim-Ma Stradivarius apart is its exceptional sound – rich, complex, and full of depth,” Sotheby’s says.

site_title: Intel’s new CEO gets pay package valued at about US$69 million
summary: Intel's new CEO, Tan Lip-Bu, will assume the role on March 18 and will receive a compensation package valued at approximately $69 million, including a $1 million salary, 200% performance-based bonus, and $66 million in long-term equity awards. Tan also agreed to purchase $25 million in Intel shares within the first 30 days of taking the job, reflecting his commitment to creating shareholder value.

site_title: UBS sets up wealth teams in Singapore for Australia and Japan
summary: UBS has established offshore wealth teams in Singapore for its clients in Australia and Japan, expanding its services in these markets. The move comes as the bank doubles down on its wealth-management ambitions in the Asia-Pacific region, where domestic wealth is growing. UBS has also returned to wealth management in Australia after exiting the market almost a decade ago. The new teams give customers options for services in Singapore, in addition to the bank's existing operations in both countries.

site_title: ABN Amro in Dutch central bank crosshairs over pay restrictions
summary: ABN Amro Bank faces potential financial penalties due to a disagreement with the Dutch central bank over alleged violations of pay restrictions. The bank claims it "carefully applies the laws and regulations regarding remuneration," while the central bank appears to have different views on a specific application. This dispute is related to formal discussions between the bank and the regulator regarding remuneration restrictions for employees. The outcome of these discussions could impact ABN Amro's ability to attract talent.

site_title: DBS raises US$2 billion through US dollar bonds, term sheet shows
summary: DBS Group, Southeast Asia's largest bank, raised US$2 billion through a US dollar senior bond issuance for general business purposes and treasury activities. The issuance consisted of two floating rate notes and a three-year fixed-rate note, with orders exceeding US$3 billion. Asian investors made up nearly half of the offers, driven by asset and fund managers, and banks, with interest reaching 63% on the five-year floating rate tranche.

site_title: Issue 139: DBS has transition in sights; Singapore-listed companies lag in utilising climate reporting
summary: DBS Bank has updated its transition finance framework, clarifying and expanding the scope of activities and assets eligible for sustainable financing. The framework aims to support the decarbonisation of high-emitting sectors and mitigate the risk of greenwashing. The bank's sustainable finance portfolio expanded by 27% to $89 billion in 2024, with a focus on transition finance. The update includes a widened eligibility taxonomy, minimum expectations for clients' transition plans, and the development of enabling activities. DBS is well-positioned to capitalize on the growth of transition finance, but faces challenges in reporting outcomes, including financed emissions.

site_title: Hotels under Far East Orchard’s hospitality joint venture hit by cybersecurity incident
summary: Hotels under Far East Orchard's hospitality joint venture, TFE Hotels, have been hit by a cybersecurity incident. The incident affected TFE Hotels' networks, but Far East Orchard's networks remain "completely independent." The incident occurred due to a vulnerability in TFE Hotels' networks, which are operated by Toga Hotel Holdings Unit Trust, in which Far East Orchard holds a 35% interest. The incident has not impacted Far East Orchard's networks, and the company is investigating the incident.

site_title: Singapore stocks end flat on Friday amid regional gains
summary: Singapore stocks ended flat on Friday, closing down 1.5 points at 3,836.02, despite regional gains. The benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) was led by Wilmar International, which added 1.9%, while Sembcorp Industries fell 2.1% after a deal to import natural gas from Indonesia fell through. US President Donald Trump's tariff threats against the European Union weighed on US stocks overnight, with the Federal Reserve expected to be slow to respond to weaker US growth.

site_title: Chief of one of Singapore’s oldest private education institutions resigns after 5 months
summary: Singapore Institute of Management (SIM) group chief executive Poon Joe Keen is resigning after just five months, citing a desire to "pursue personal interests". Poon, 54, will step down on March 31, and SIM Global Education president Wei Kwok Kee will succeed him as president and chief executive from April 1.

images.alt_text: SIM's mission is to provide accessible pathways for everyone – no matter their means or season in life, says chairman Euleen Goh.

site_title: US: Share gains cut into week’s losses
summary: US stocks rose 2.1% on Friday, but the week ended 2.3% lower due to recession worries over President Trump's shifting tariff policy. The S&P 500 finished at 5,638.94, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average gained 1.7% to 41,488.19. Analysts attributed the gains to diminished odds of a US government shutdown, as Democratic Senate Leader Charles Schumer backed a spending bill favored by Trump. A consumer survey showed expectations for the future deteriorated, citing uncertainty around policy and economic factors.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) at the opening bell on March 7, 2025, in New York City. Wall Street stocks rose early March 7, digesting a mixed jobs report as markets seek a pivot from a rough period amid tariff uncertainty. site_title: Japan’s GDP growth imperils 2% defence spending target
summary: Japan's economy expanded to a record 609 trillion yen in nominal terms last year, but the growth may imperil the country's target to spend 2% of GDP on defence by 2027. Currently, Japan spends about 1.4% of GDP on its military, and if it were to reach the 2% target, it would require an additional 9 trillion yen. The US has urged Japan to increase its military spending, with Elbridge Colby saying Japan should spend at least 3% of GDP on defence. The country's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba has stated that Japan will decide how much it spends on defence, not based on external pressures.

images.alt_text: When inflation in Japan started to accelerate in 2022, wage gains lagged the increase in import costs, which kept real wages and consumption lacklustre, Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda told parliament.

site_title: CEOs need to be on ‘high alert’ for AI impact on their businesses, says Bain’s global chief
summary: Global consulting firm Bain & Co's worldwide managing partner Christophe De Vusser warns CEOs to be on high alert for the impact of artificial intelligence (AI) on their businesses. Only 10-15% of companies are "really understanding how AI is going to impact them," and those that do are using it as a top priority to drive business transformation. De Vusser sees AI as a "once-in-a-generation" innovation and technology wave, with two-thirds of value coming from reinventing company processes and one-third from applying AI.

site_title: Bernard Arnault hints at leading LVMH until age 85
summary: LVMH billionaire Bernard Arnault, 76, is hinting at leading the luxury group until age 85, sparking speculation about his succession plans. The company will seek to raise the CEO and chairman age limit to 85 from 80 at the upcoming annual general meeting. Arnault has five children, all of whom hold key positions in the conglomerate, fueling succession rumors. Despite a series of management reshuffles, Arnault appears to be planning to stay on, with an estimated wealth of $179 billion, making him Europe's wealthiest person.

site_title: G7 ministers unite to back Ukraine and warn Russia of sanctions
summary: G7 foreign ministers have issued a joint statement backing Ukraine's territorial integrity and warning Russia of potential sanctions if it fails to agree to a ceasefire. The statement reaffirms support for Ukraine's freedom, sovereignty, and independence, and urges Russia to reciprocate with a ceasefire on equal terms. The move comes after weeks of tension between US allies and President Donald Trump over trade, security, and Ukraine policy. The G7 has also opposed any unilateral attempts to change the status quo in the Taiwan Strait and dropped language on a two-state solution for the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

site_title: Tariffs on goods may be a prelude to tariffs on money
summary: The US government is exploring a potential shift in economic policy, targeting capital inflows as a possible next step in President Trump's trade war. Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Stephen Miran's vision for a "Mar-a-Lago accord" includes a possible US debt restructuring, which could force holders of Treasuries to swap them for perpetual bonds. This move, backed by some influential advisers, aims to reset global trade and finance and potentially impose taxes on capital inflows, which could raise $2 trillion over the next decade.

site_title: Banyan Tree unit acquires stakes in two resort investment and development companies for S$5.5 million
summary: Banyan Tree Hospitality group has acquired stakes in two resort investment and development companies, Tropical Resorts and Donvale, from NSL Resorts International for S$5.5 million. This acquisition is expected to increase Laguna Resorts & Hotels Public Company's offshore resort investments and development portfolio, benefiting the overall group. The transactions were funded by internal resources and did not impact Banyan Tree's consolidated net tangible assets per share or consolidated earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Banyan Tree says the loan will support its commitment to responsible tourism.

site_title: BMW’s next big thing: adrenaline tourism
summary: BMW's high-performance division, BMW M, is expanding its customer base through unique driving experiences, such as the BMW M Experience, which combines racing, drifting, and other adrenaline-pumping activities. The events have led to a 50% conversion rate of attendees into M car buyers. BMW M has become a volume player in the performance world, selling 206,587 vehicles worldwide in 2024, a record for the 13th consecutive year. The brand's strategy to offer a range of combustion, hybrid, and electric models has been successful, with the i4 M50 being its best-selling M car for the third year in a row.

images.alt_text: The Hyundai Ioniq 9 is as stately and comfortable as a Range Rover, but far more sustainable and half as pricey.

site_title: Singapore and Thai businesses, associations ink 5 MOUs to strengthen trade and investment relations
summary: Singapore and Thailand have signed five memoranda of understanding (MOUs) to strengthen trade and investment relations between the two countries. The agreements cover areas such as cross-border trade, consumer protection, and fintech, and aim to deepen bilateral economic cooperation. Bilateral trade between Singapore and Thailand reached S$44.5 billion in 2024, with Singapore's exports to Thailand rising 14.2% to S$29.3 billion. The MOUs also promote cooperation in areas such as agri-trade, investments, and digital economy.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 14)
summary: Nvidia, a favorite US stock among Singapore investors, saw its market value drop after Chinese AI player DeepSeek emerged, wiping hundreds of billions off its value in January. Today, Nvidia trading on Tiger, Moomoo, and FSMOne surged after DeepSeek's recent loss, creating a buying opportunity.

site_title: Hong Kong’s CK Hutchison under fire after China criticism of ports sale to US
summary: China's governing body overseeing Hong Kong reposted a commentary criticizing CK Hutchison's port deal with US firm BlackRock as a betrayal of China, citing potential risks to China's maritime trade and supply chains. The deal, worth $22.8 billion, includes assets along the Panama Canal. CK Hutchison shares fell 6.4% after the repost, with investors worried the deal could be derailed without Beijing's backing. The move highlights the complex geopolitical pressures the firm faces, with US President Donald Trump praising the deal and threatening to charge fees for China-linked vessels at US ports.

site_title: Deutsche Bank sees more headwinds from commercial real estate
summary: Deutsche Bank expects headwinds in commercial real estate markets, particularly in the US, due to slower leasing activity and higher vacancy rates. The lender has set aside 664 million euros for expected credit losses from commercial real estate, a 44% increase from 2023. US office markets are struggling, with a 75% decline in Manhattan office values from their peak. Deutsche Bank is proactively working with landlords to offer loan amendments and extensions, but warns that stressed market conditions could further impact commercial real estate property values and loan-to-value ratios.

site_title: Vietnam reviewing duties to boost import of US LNG, agriculture, high-tech goods, PM says
summary: Vietnam's Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh announced plans to review duties on US goods, including liquefied natural gas, agriculture, and high-tech products, to boost imports and avoid reciprocal tariffs. The move aims to address a large trade surplus with the US, which exceeded $123 billion in 2024. The review is part of efforts to increase imports of key US products, such as agricultural products, liquefied gas, and high-tech goods, including AI-grade chips and semiconductors.

site_title: LIV Golf veterans Sergio Garcia, Phil Mickelson out to steal the show at Sentosa
summary: LIV Golf veterans Sergio Garcia and Phil Mickelson are expected to dominate the field at the Sentosa Golf Course in Singapore, where the league's three-day festival is underway. Garcia's Fireballs GC team won the double in Hong Kong last week, and they aim to continue their hot streak in Singapore. The two golfers are among the 54 top players competing in the event, which is considered one of the most challenging and scenic courses in the world.

site_title: Interest rate of 2% robust for current circumstances: BOT chief
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Sethaput Suthiwartnarueput has stated that the current interest rate of 2% is "robust" for the country's current circumstances, citing growth, inflation, and financial stability as key factors. Exports are expected to grow at a slower rate this year, at 5.8% last year, and the government aims for a 3% growth target. The governor also noted that inflation is expected to be 1.1% this year, within the central bank's target range of 1-3%.

site_title: US: Wall St opens higher but indexes on track for weekly losses
summary: US stocks rose on Friday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 244 points, or 0.60%, to 41,057.57, but all three main indexes are on track for weekly losses following a selloff earlier in the week due to concerns over a growth slowdown. The S&P 500 rose 42.3 points, or 0.77%, and the Nasdaq Composite rose 220.3 points, or 1.27%. The rebound comes after a week of declines triggered by fears of a growth slowdown due to the Trump administration's erratic trade policies.

site_title: Stronger investor protection in Singapore needed as gaps persist: Sias report
summary: A report by the Securities Investors Association (Singapore) highlights gaps in investor protection in the country's equities market, with 37% of investors facing difficulties in exercising their rights as shareholders. The study recommends lowering shareholding thresholds for minority shareholders to requisition an extraordinary general meeting, strengthening public enforcement for investor compensation, and introducing requirements for companies to explain actions taken in the event of significant shareholder dissent. The report aims to balance regulation with investor protection, as Singapore shifts towards a more disclosure-based regulatory regime.

site_title: Asean trade booms, poised to rank among world’s fastest by 2029: report
summary: South-east Asian countries, particularly Vietnam, Indonesia, and the Philippines, are set for accelerated trade growth over the next five years, with Asean projected to rank among the world's fastest-growing economies in trade volume by 2029. Global trade volumes are forecast to grow at a baseline compound annual rate of 3.1% from 2024 to 2029, driven by supply chain diversification strategies and macroeconomic fundamentals. Despite US President Donald Trump's proposed tariffs, global trade growth is still expected to continue, with the report noting that trade volumes are likely to shift away from the US and China.

site_title: What sparks an investing revolution?
summary: A new documentary, "Tune Out the Noise," explores how 1960s ideas from the University of Chicago's financial research led to a revolution in investing, changing the way people invest and generating trillions of dollars. The film highlights the role of chance and randomness in bringing together brilliant individuals, such as Eugene Fama, Myron Scholes, and David Booth, who put these ideas into practice. Their success was influenced by factors like a scholarship, a chance phone call, and better eyesight, rather than deliberate design. The documentary leaves viewers wondering where the next investing revolution will come from, and whether new innovations like cryptocurrencies will be more transformative.

site_title: ‘Finfluencers’ and their role in the investment sphere come under scrutiny in Chocolate Finance saga
summary: Finfluencers, or social media influencers promoting investment products, are under scrutiny following issues with Chocolate Finance, a digital wealth player that halted instant withdrawals. Observers warn consumers to be cautious and verify a finfluencer's qualifications and regulatory licenses before following their advice. Regulators, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), expect finfluencers to present information in a clear and balanced way, highlighting key features and risks. The MAS has guidelines on what constitutes financial advice, and finfluencers may face civil liability if they provide advice without a license.

site_title: UOB targets 10 million Asean retail card customers by 2027 as entertainment spending grows
summary: UOB aims to expand its Asean retail card customer base to 10 million by 2027, driven by rising affluence and purchasing power in the region. The bank has seen significant growth in card billings, particularly in the entertainment space, with a 35% surge during Taylor Swift's concerts in Singapore. UOB plans to partner with major entertainment acts and offer cashback, miles, and other value propositions to attract new customers. The bank also expects to drive up tourism receipts through its shopping, dining, and travel pillars.

site_title: Oracle in talks to establish data centre on Indonesia’s Batam Island: sources
summary: Oracle is in talks with Indonesia's government to establish a cloud services centre on Batam Island, a strategic location due to its free trade zone status, proximity to Singapore and Malaysia, and existing data centre presence. The island's Nongsa Digital Park offers electric power, security, and ideal seismic conditions, as well as access to international submarine fiber optic cables. This move aims to expand Oracle's data centre footprint in South-east Asia and support the growing demand for AI services. Discussions are ongoing, but no final agreement has been reached.

site_title: Apple plans AirPods feature that can live-translate conversations
summary: Apple is planning an AirPods software upgrade that will offer live-translation capabilities, allowing users to translate in-person conversations into another language in real-time. The feature will be tied to iOS 19 and will work by translating the speaker's words into the user's preferred language, while also translating the user's words into the other language. This will be the first time such a feature will be available on AirPods, following similar capabilities on rival earbuds like Google Pixel Buds.

images.alt_text: Alibaba accelerated efforts to carve out a leading position in AI after DeepSeek’s splashy debut in January.
According to one tech executive, not even the early developers of AI could have anticipated the speed of its advance today.

Meta Platforms' stock fell from US$187 per share in March 2022 to US$88 in November 2022. Today it is trading at above US$265. By investing between March and November 2022, investors would have made substantial gains even if they missed the lowest entry price.

site_title: Apple’s iPhone 16e is outselling iPhone SE but won’t reverse China slide
summary: Apple's iPhone 16e is outselling its predecessor, the iPhone SE, with 60% stronger sales in its opening three days. However, this won't reverse China's decline in iPhone sales, which are expected to drop 2% this year due to strong competition from budget Android alternatives and national subsidies. The iPhone 16e's limited features and price of $599 make it a tougher sell in China, where Apple is also working on bringing its Apple Intelligence suite to consumers.

images.alt_text: Apple’s iPhone 16e. Source: Apple

site_title: Singapore shipping firm hit by US sanctions over Iran oil links
summary: A Singapore-based shipping firm, Shipload Maritime, has been hit with US sanctions for allegedly facilitating a ship-to-ship transfer between an Iranian tanker and a Singapore-flagged vessel near Indonesia in December. The US Department of State sanctioned Shipload Maritime for "knowingly engaging in a significant transaction for the transport of petroleum or petroleum products from Iran." This is the first time a Singapore-based company has been penalized for assisting with oil transfers at sea. The sanctions aim to disrupt Iran's oil trade and generate revenue for Tehran-backed militia groups.

site_title: Putin raises ‘serious questions’ on Ukraine truce plan
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin expressed support for a proposed 30-day ceasefire in Ukraine, but raised "serious questions" about its implementation. Putin stated that Moscow is open to discussing the plan with US President Donald Trump, despite Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky condemning his comments as "very manipulative."

site_title: Xiaomi shares pricing ‘near-perfect execution’ after 300% rally
summary: Xiaomi's Hong Kong-listed stock has surged 340% in a year, making it one of China's most-expensive tech stocks, trading at 38 times forward earnings estimates. The company's success in duplicating its smartphone success in the crowded EV market has won investors, but now it needs to justify its share performance amid market concerns over its ability to execute growth plans and maintain sales. Xiaomi's upcoming results and electric SUV launch will be closely watched.

images.alt_text: SGX now offers a total of 18 Singapore Depository Receipts including Ping An, Meituan and Xiaomi
Best known for its budget-friendly handsets, Xiaomi has sought to climb up the value chain with a succession of camera-centric flagship models in recent years.

The stock has rallied 12 per cent this week, after Xiaomi said it will release two new products – a high-end SU7 Ultra vehicle and 15 Ultra phone – by month-end.

Xiaomi's revenue came in at 92.5 billion yuan (S$17.2 billion) in the quarter ended Sep 30, boosted by the launch of its SU7 EV.

site_title: Blackstone’s US$17 billion property lending arm isn’t giving up on its office bets
summary: Blackstone's US$17 billion property lending arm, Blackstone Mortgage Trust, is preparing to invest in a 50-storey building in Midtown Manhattan, signaling its confidence in the office market's rebound. The trust has untangled over US$1 billion of soured debt, mostly tied to offices, in the final quarter of last year. Despite still holding US$1 billion of troubled loans, Blackstone Mortgage Trust CEO Katie Keenan expects the sector to recover, with office loans throwing off cash. The trust is working to deploy near-record liquidity into new loans, and has received more financial wiggle room itself, loosening restrictions on its debt.

images.alt_text: London’s office market has seen anaemic activity since interest rates started rising in 2022.

site_title: BMW's profit slumps as weak China sales, brake problems plague earnings
summary: BMW's net profit slumped 33% to 7.68 billion euros in 2024 due to weak sales in China and Germany, as well as brake problems affecting 1.5 million cars. The company expects its earnings margin for cars to be 5-7% in 2025, a slight increase from last year's 6.3%. This forecast takes into account intensifying trade wars and tough competition in China. BMW also proposed a higher payout ratio of 36.7% for 2024.

site_title: UK economy shrinks in January in fresh setback for Labour
summary: The UK economy unexpectedly contracted by 0.1% in January, driven by declines in manufacturing and construction, according to the Office for National Statistics. This marks the second consecutive month of contraction, putting pressure on Chancellor Rachel Reeves to deliver on her promise to boost growth. Economists predict a return to steady growth this year, but risks are mounting due to the escalating trade war and fears of a global downturn. The Labour government faces criticism for failing to achieve momentum since returning to power last summer.

site_title: Sats inks MOU with Vietnam Airlines to build air cargo terminal, deepen partnership
summary: Sats, a Singapore-based ground handling company, signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) with Vietnam Airlines to build and operate an air cargo terminal at the new Long Thanh International Airport in Vietnam. The partnership aims to expand Vietnam Airlines' cargo handling capabilities and deepen cooperation in ground and cargo handling services. The two companies will share best practices, productivity indicators, and technologies to improve operational efficiency and quality of service. The air cargo terminal is expected to commence operations in the second half of 2026.

images.alt_text: In its outlook, Sats said that while tariff increases could negatively impact trade flows, it is confident that it will have the resilience to navigate the challenges.

site_title: Singapore-based Shein remains committed to IPO as firm weathers US tariff storm
summary: Shein's executive chairman, Donald Tang, remains committed to taking the fast-fashion retailer public despite US President Donald Trump's trade campaign targeting China. Tang believes a listing will increase transparency and earn public trust, helping the company navigate potential US tariff increases. Shein plans to cut costs by packing more products together and reducing waste, but may raise prices if the "de minimus" exemption is cancelled. The company has a "zero-tolerance" approach to forced labor and child labor, and has diversified its supply chain to Vietnam and Brazil.

images.alt_text: Zara owner Inditex pointed to “very satisfactory” sales which hit 38.6 billion euros in 2024, a 7.5 per cent increase from the previous year.
Clothing and accessories for sale at the new Urban Revivo store in the Soho neighborhood of New York, US, Feb 28, 2025. Urban Revivo is planning three new stores this year in New York and London.
Shein’s net profit was down almost 40 per cent at US$1 billion in 2024, the report said, citing two people with knowledge of the matter.

site_title: All eyes on Democrats as US barrels toward shutdown deadline
summary: The US government faces a deadline to fund the government or allow it to shut down this weekend, with a Senate vote set on a Trump-backed bill that would keep the government funded through September. Democrats are divided, with some backing the bill to avoid a shutdown, while others, including progressive representative Pramila Jayapal, warn of a "huge backlash" against Senate Democrats who support it. The bill includes spending cuts proposed by Trump's Department of Government Efficiency, which has been criticized for its methods and accuracy.

images.alt_text: US House Speaker Mike Johnson speaks to the media following a vote on the House floor at the US Capitol,  Washington, D.C., March 11, 2025. The vote secured the passage of a  continuous resolution on government funding by 217 to 213 votes, as the bill will now pass to the Senate to vote on before the deadline of March 14 to avert a shutdown of the US government.

site_title: Nvidia trading on Tiger, Moomoo, FSMOne explodes after DeepSeek beating opens buying opportunity
summary: Nvidia's stock surged 300% on Singapore trading platforms Tiger Brokers, Moomoo, and FSMOne after China AI player DeepSeek's market debut in January, wiping hundreds of billions off Nvidia's market value. DeepSeek's lower cost and power consumption led to a sell-off in Nvidia, whose top-end chips drive ChatGPT. This created a buying opportunity for Singapore investors, with Tiger Brokers reporting a significant jump in Nvidia shareholders. Brokers expect continued volatility-driven surges in Nvidia's stock price.

images.alt_text: Nvidia has been the biggest beneficiary of a massive surge in AI spending, doubling the size of its revenue in the past two years

site_title: USPS strikes deal with Elon Musk’s DOGE team for reform help
summary: The US Postal Service (USPS) has reached a deal with Elon Musk's DOGE government reform team to help the money-losing agency address "big problems." USPS Postmaster General Louis DeJoy plans to reduce the workforce by 10,000 workers through a voluntary early retirement program, and the agreement will allow DOGE to assist with identifying and achieving further efficiencies. The move comes as USPS has lost over $100 billion since 2007 and reported a fourth-quarter profit of $144 million last month.

images.alt_text: The US Postal Service has lost more than US$100 billion since 2007, including US$9.5 billion in the 12 months ending Sept 30. Earlier this month, however, it reported a fourth-quarter profit of US$144 million.

site_title: Oil settles down more than 1% on tariff worry, supply-demand expectations
summary: Oil prices fell 1-1.7% on Thursday due to concerns over tariff wars and uncertainty surrounding a potential Russia-Ukraine ceasefire. The International Energy Agency reported that global oil supply may exceed demand by 600,000 barrels per day this year, with global demand expected to rise by 1.03 million barrels per day. The US stock market fell, and investors are weighing the impact of tariffs on oil demand growth in 2025, with some analysts predicting prices could drop to $60 per barrel by the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Shares in French spirit makers moved lower on Thursday after US President Donald Trump said he would put a 200% tariff on wine and other alcoholic products coming out of EU countries if the bloc did not remove its tariff on whiskey.

site_title: EU parliament roiled by graft probe linked to China’s Huawei
summary: A graft probe linked to Chinese tech giant Huawei has rocked the European parliament, with police detaining multiple suspects in Belgium and Portugal. The probe, which began over two years ago, alleges corruption under the guise of lobbying for Huawei's benefit. Belgian media reported that more than a dozen parliamentarians were on the detectives' radar, but none were held for questioning. Transparency campaigners criticized the parliament's lack of reforms, calling for swift and deep change to prevent further corruption.

images.alt_text: The deal signed on Friday provides for Huawei and SAIC Motor to cooperate strategically on manufacturing, supply chain management and sales services.

site_title: South Korea says battery pack is possible cause of Air Busan fire
summary: A spare power bank is considered a possible cause of the January fire on an Air Busan plane, according to South Korea's transport ministry. Scorch marks on a power bank found near the fire suggest insulation breakdown may have started the blaze. Lithium batteries in devices can produce smoke, fire, or extreme heat when faulty or damaged. No issues with the plane's electrical systems were identified, and the investigation is ongoing. The fire destroyed the Airbus A321ceo plane, evacuating all 176 passengers and crew.

site_title: China tells lenders to boost financial support for consumption
summary: China's financial regulator has urged lenders to boost support for consumption, promising to relax consumer credit quotas and loan terms. The National Financial Regulatory Administration (NFRA) aims to increase credit supply to industries such as retail, accommodation, and tourism. Beijing seeks to spur reluctant Chinese consumers to spend, addressing imbalances in the world's second-largest economy amid a trade war with the US. The regulator encourages financial institutions to expand products and services to boost consumption and better meet financial needs in the consumer sector.

images.alt_text: Chinese bonds have come under pressure this year as the central bank has refrained from lowering interest rates or banks’ required reserve ratio since September.

summary: European stocks closed 0.15% lower at 540.44 points, weighed down by US President Trump's threat of 200% tariffs on EU wines and whiskey. The Stoxx 600 fell 0.15% as the food and beverages sector lost 0.2%, while automobiles and parts declined 1.7%. However, telecommunications gained 1.4% and healthcare stocks rose 0.5%, boosted by a 3.4% rise in Novo Nordisk. site_title: Asia: Most markets rise on hopes for bill to avert US shutdown
summary: Asian markets rose on Friday, recouping losses from the week, as hopes for a US bill to avert a government shutdown boosted investor sentiment. The US Congress is set to pass a spending package to keep the government running through September, alleviating fears of a shutdown. Despite concerns over a US recession and trade tensions, including Trump's threat of 200% tariffs on European wine, gold reached a record high. Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Shanghai, Tokyo, and Wellington, advanced, while Singapore, Seoul, Taipei, and Jakarta fell.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 1.3 per cent to 40,813.57, while the broad-based S&P 500 Index fell 1.4 per cent to 5,521.52 on Thursday.

summary: An American Airlines Boeing 737-800 experienced engine issues after landing in Denver, forcing the evacuation of 172 passengers and six crew members. The plane diverted from its planned destination of Dallas after the crew reported engine vibrations. Passengers evacuated using the plane's slides as smoke poured out the engine. The Federal Aviation Administration will investigate the incident, which is the latest in a series of high-profile aviation incidents raising questions about US aviation safety.

site_title: Japan PM Ishiba admits handing out gift vouchers to lawmakers
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba admitted to handing out gift vouchers to 15 lawmakers, valued at 100,000 yen each, as a token of appreciation for their families. Ishiba claimed he paid for the vouchers with his own money, but this move raised questions about whether he skirted political funding laws. The move comes as Ishiba faces pressure from within his own party ahead of a national election this summer, with his position as prime minister already tenuous.

site_title: Itching for a solution: Why eczema treatments are expanding – as are costs
summary: Eczema affects around 20% of school-going children and 10% of adults in Singapore, causing discomfort and sleepless nights due to constant itching. Moderate to severe cases have increased in prevalence over the years, leading to a wide range of treatment options, from creams to injections, with varying costs. The lack of standardized guidelines for treating eczema has resulted in its exclusion from the Chronic Disease Management Programme, despite a recent call to include it. New treatments, such as biologics and phototherapy, have emerged, offering hope for more effective management of the condition.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower after Trump's new tariff salvo
summary: Wall Street's main indexes opened lower on March 13, 2025, after President Donald Trump increased his tariff rhetoric against the European Union. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 70.9 points, or 0.17%, to 41,280.05. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 4.9 points, or 0.09%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 49.9 points, or 0.28%. The decline was partly offset by signs of cooling inflation.

site_title: Forever 21 weighs liquidation ahead of bankruptcy filing
summary: Forever 21, a US-based fast-fashion retailer, is preparing to file for bankruptcy and potentially close down its stores. Despite efforts to find a buyer, talks with one potential bidder have failed, leaving the company with no other option. The retailer, which once operated over 500 locations worldwide, is expected to close almost two-thirds of its locations. The Forever 21 trademark and intellectual property will continue to be licensed to new operating and e-commerce partners.

images.alt_text: The Forever 21 trademark and intellectual property are owned by apparel and lifestyle label empire Authentic Brands, which licenses them to the operating company that would undergo a Chapter 11 process.

site_title: Safari by gondola? Luxe African vacations get a cool new twist
summary: The Under Canvas founders, Jacob and Sarah Dusek, have introduced the Solfari, a solar-powered gondola system, to the Vhembe Biosphere Reserve in South Africa's Limpopo province. The six-seat gondola offers an unobtrusive view of wildlife, including giraffes, and will be part of the luxury lodge Few & Far Luvhondo, which aims to create a fully carbon-neutral safari experience. The Solfari is a sustainable innovation, complementing the lodge's initiatives to restore the area's degraded habitats and reintroduce wildlife. The gondola system will be expanded to a 40 km loop by 2026.

site_title: Sembcorp deal to import natural gas from Indonesia falls through
summary: Sembcorp Industries' deal to import natural gas from Indonesia has fallen through due to regulatory approval issues. The agreement, announced in September 2023, aimed to import up to 111 billion British thermal units per day of piped natural gas from Indonesia's Mako gas fields, with delivery expected to commence in 2026. The company stated that the deal's failure will not affect its energy costs or ability to meet gas supply requirements in Singapore.

images.alt_text: GAIA solar farm in Long An province was Sembcorp's first utility-scale acquisition in Vietnam.

site_title: Ahead of Yoon impeachment ruling, South Korea’s acting president calls for calm
summary: South Korea's acting President Choi Sang Mok called for calm ahead of a Constitutional Court's ruling on the impeachment of President Yoon Suk Yeol, who was impeached over his short-lived martial law order. Choi pledged to mobilize police resources to maintain order and respect for the decision, with security measures including a security bubble and barbed wire installed around the court. Thousands of Yoon supporters are expected to gather outside, prompting concerns of potential violence, with police ready to use pepper spray and batons if necessary. The ruling is due within days.

images.alt_text: The latest tariffs add to trade measures introduced in Trump’s first term, removing exemptions for many nations and extending them to new categories of products.

site_title: Taiwan tech giant Foxconn’s 2024 profit misses forecasts
summary: Taiwanese tech giant Foxconn reported a 7% rise in full-year net profit to NT$152.7 billion, missing forecasts. The company attributed the underperformance to consumer electronics underproduction, but cited a robust demand for its artificial intelligence servers. Revenue rose 11% to NT$6.9 trillion, beating market expectations. Foxconn has been expanding its AI server business, with revenue up 150% in the year. The company's earnings announcement comes amidst trade tensions and US President Donald Trump's tariff threats, which have impacted global markets.

site_title: Johns Hopkins University slashes 2,000 jobs after Trump administration grant cut
summary: Johns Hopkins University announced it will slash over 2,000 jobs globally due to the Trump administration's termination of $800 million in grants. This marks the university's largest layoff in history, affecting 247 domestic US workers and 1,975 international positions. The cuts impact the Bloomberg School of Public Health, medical school, and non-profit Jhpiego. The Trump administration's move follows a six-week review that canceled more than 80% of US Agency for International Development programs.

site_title: Trade war erodes oil demand as Opec+ boosts supply: IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) has reduced its forecast for global oil consumption growth this year to 1 million barrels a day due to the escalating trade war and Opec+ increasing supply. The trade tensions have led to a slower pace of oil deliveries, resulting in a projected surplus of 600,000 barrels a day in 2025, with Opec+ potentially adding another 400,000 barrels a day. Oil prices are trading near $71 a barrel, influenced by the cartel's decision to restart halted production and US President Donald Trump's tariff announcements.

images.alt_text: IEA has provided research and data to industrialised governments for more than half a century to guide policy on energy security, supply and investment.

The IEA increased its 2025 global oil demand growth forecast to 1.1 million barrels per day (bpd) from 990,000 bpd last month, “largely in Asian countries due to the impact of China’s recent stimulus measures”.

South-east Asia as a whole attracts only 2 per cent of global clean energy investment despite accounting for 6 per cent of global GDP, 5 per cent of global energy demand and being home to 9 per cent of the world’s population, according to IEA's report.
Energy security and affordability remains top priorities for South-east Asia, with the recent global energy crisis highlighting the region’s vulnerability to fuel price shocks.
“This year, global oil demand is very weak, much weaker than previous years, and we expect this will continue because of one word – China,” said Fatih Birol, the executive director of the IEA.
IEA now expects Chinese demand to grow by only 150,000 barrels per day in 2024, after consumption dropped by 500,000 bpd in August.

site_title: How the hit show The White Lotus is booking out Thailand’s luxury hotels
summary: Thailand's luxury hotels, particularly those on Koh Samui island, are experiencing a surge in bookings and room rates following the release of HBO's "The White Lotus" series. Room rates at four-star and five-star hotels have jumped 40-50% and flights to the island are becoming increasingly difficult to book. This phenomenon, known as the "White Lotus effect," has also affected Phuket and Phang Nga. The trend is expected to continue, with tourism experts predicting a strong year for the hotel industry, particularly for high-end establishments.

site_title: CDL’s EcoTrain, MicroForest boost climate education efforts for the public
summary: City Developments Ltd's (CDL) EcoTrain, a decommissioned train cabin, and MicroForest exhibit have opened to the public at City Square Mall in Singapore. The EcoTrain aims to educate children and youth on climate themes, featuring interactive panels, workshops, and informative panels on rainforests. The exhibit promotes sustainability and urban greening, raising awareness among the public. The initiative is part of CDL's efforts to boost climate education efforts for the public.

site_title: AIA Singapore’s value of new business rises 15% in 2024 to US$454 million
summary: AIA Singapore reported a 15% increase in value of new business (VONB) to US$454 million in 2024, driven by double-digit growth in agency and partnership distribution channels. The company's total weighted premium income (TWPI) grew 13% to US$4.4 billion, while operating profit after tax (OPAT) rose 1% to US$669 million. AIA Singapore will commence a new US$1.6 billion share buyback, and the group's VONB margin rose 1.9 percentage points to 54.5%.

site_title: AIA to start US$1.6 billion stock buyback, new business miss

The company's new business value reached US$4.71 billion, with US$1.2 billion from mainland China and US$1.8 billion from Hong Kong. AIA also announced a US$1.6 billion share buyback. Despite missing estimates, the company's growth potential remains strong, according to CEO Lee Yuan Siong, citing near-term geopolitical and macroeconomic uncertainty.

The move escalates the transatlantic trade war, with European stocks falling and the US Commerce Secretary warning that retaliatory measures could lead to a recession. The EU plans to impose duties on $37.7 billion worth of American products, and talks are planned between the two sides. Trump has also pledged separate sectoral tariffs on industries including autos, lumber, and semiconductors.

site_title: Sembcorp falls 4.9% as Indonesia gas deal gets scrapped amid regulatory hurdle
summary: Sembcorp shares dropped 4.9% after a deal to import natural gas from Indonesia was scrapped due to regulatory hurdles. The deal, which would have started gas delivery from 2026, was anticipated to boost the company's revenue. The last time shares traded at such levels was in February 2024. The company's shares closed 0.7% higher on Thursday before the news.

site_title: Spanish classics redefined at Sugarra
summary: Basque-influenced cuisine is redefined at Sugarra, a fine-dining restaurant in Resorts World Sentosa, Singapore. Chef Aitor Gonzalez, a protege of renowned chef Aitor Jeronimo Orive, has surpassed his boss's standards with consistency and clarity. The restaurant offers a generous spread of tapitas, deconstructed Spanish omelette, and other familiar Spanish dishes with a light, inventive touch. With a friendly and engaging nature, Gonzalez has created a worthy place to rediscover fine Spanish food, despite the initial drawback of the name "Sugarra". Rating: 7.

site_title: 👲🏻 Want to invest in China tech stocks? Here are some things to know
summary: Chinese tech stocks have rallied in recent months, with Alibaba's shares rising 15% after beating sales estimates. The rally is attributed to factors such as the entrance of DeepSeek, an AI model that competes with OpenAI's ChatGPT, and China's President Xi Jinping's meeting with tech leaders, signaling a potential end to the country's crackdown on the tech space. However, US tariffs and China's growth slowdown remain risk factors, and investors should be patient and selective. Chinese tech stocks may have "room to run," but regulatory risk remains, and diversification is key.

The highs and lows of CDL’s Millennium 
& Copthorne Hotels
summary: City Developments Ltd's (CDL) global hotel business, Millennium & Copthorne Hotels (M&C), is embroiled in a dispute after executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng accused his son, Sherman Kwek, of an attempted coup. Allegations were made that Dr. Catherine Wu, a long-time adviser to Kwek Leng Beng, wielded power and influence beyond her role at M&C. Dr. Wu has since resigned from her unpaid advisory position. The dispute centers around control of the group, with Kwek Leng Beng seeking to "set things right."

site_title: About US$390 million involved in alleged fraud linked to shipment to Malaysia of servers with Nvidia chips
summary: Three men, including a Chinese national and two Singaporeans, have been charged with alleged fraud linked to the shipment of servers with Nvidia chips to Malaysia. Li Ming faces two charges, including fraud and computer misuse, while Singaporeans Alan Wei Zhaolun and Aaron Woon Guo Jie face two fraud charges each. Bail was offered, ranging from $600,000 to $1 million, with the total amount involved estimated to be around $390 million. The investigation is ongoing, with the US government also looking into potential circumvention of export controls on advanced Nvidia chips.

site_title: ESR-Reit prices S$125 million securities at 5.75%
summary: ESR-Reit priced S$125 million in subordinated perpetual securities at 5.75% as part of its S$750 million debt issuance program. The net proceeds will be used to refinance or repay existing borrowings, finance or refinance acquisitions, and fund asset enhancement and working capital. site_title: Thai hotelier eyes US expansion to draw on ‘White Lotus’ craze
summary: Minor International, a Thai hospitality group, plans to expand into the US market, aiming to open its first Anantara hotel by early next year. The move follows the global success of the TV series "The White Lotus," which features Minor's hotels in Thailand. The company's founder, Bill Heinecke, credits the show for increasing international appeal and bookings, with a 41% rise in direct online bookings for the three Anantara resorts in Phuket and Koh Samui. Minor aims to expand to 850 hotels by 2027 and 1,000 hotels by 2030, with a focus on Thailand and Europe.

site_title: Vacheron Constantin celebrates 270th anniversary
summary: Swiss luxury watch brands Vacheron Constantin, Audemars Piguet, and Laurent Ferrier are celebrating significant milestones. Vacheron Constantin marks its 270th anniversary with the release of a stainless steel version of its Historiques 222, priced at S$46,100. Audemars Piguet celebrates its 150th anniversary with the Royal Oak Perpetual Calendar Openworked "150th Anniversary", while Laurent Ferrier commemorates its 15th anniversary with the Classic Traveller Globe Night Blue.

site_title: US producer inflation flat in February despite Trump tariffs
summary: US producer inflation remained flat in February, defying expectations of a 0.3% increase, as President Trump's tariff hikes targeting Chinese goods took effect. The producer price index (PPI) was unchanged, with a 0.3% increase in final demand goods offsetting a 0.2% decline in final demand services. Food prices rose 1.7%, while energy costs cooled. The PPI is up 3.2% compared to a year ago, with some sectors experiencing significant price increases, including chicken eggs and pork.

site_title: US CEOs need to find their missing backbones
summary: US CEOs are urging President Donald Trump to adopt more business-friendly policies to avoid long-term economic damage. The S&P 500 index has recorded its worst performance compared to the rest of the world this century, with the US dollar weakening and inflation rising. Key business leaders, including Ford's Jim Farley and Costco's Tony James, have expressed concerns about the impact of Trump's tariff proposals and uncertainty on investment. Businesspeople are seen as the only ones with the power to restrain Trump and limit the damage, but many are reluctant to speak out due to fear of retribution.

The app is part of Alibaba's efforts to keep pace with Chinese AI rivals, following the debut of DeepSeek's AI model in January. New Quark will be available to users gradually, starting with a pilot launched on March 13, and is seen as a gateway to endless possibilities with AI, according to Alibaba's CEO.

The potential investment could be made directly by the Trump family or through World Liberty Financial, a cryptocurrency venture backed by the Trumps.
