site_title: US: Stocks slump after new Trump tariff threat
summary: US stocks plummeted 1.3-1.4% on Thursday, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 indices falling 40,813.57 and 5,521.52, respectively. The decline came after US President Donald Trump threatened a 200% tariff on EU wines and champagnes in response to EU countermeasures on US steel and aluminum tariffs. Despite flat producer inflation, investors are wary of the impact of Trump's tariffs, with the S&P 500 tumbling into a correction.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall amid labour market stability
summary: US weekly jobless claims fell 2,000 to 220,000 for the week ended March 8, indicating a stable labour market. However, sharp government spending cuts and an escalating trade war pose a downside risk. The federal government's layoffs, including those by Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency, have not yet significantly impacted official labour market data. The number of people receiving benefits decreased 27,000 to 1.870 million, and policy uncertainty is eroding business confidence and making companies hesitant to increase headcount.

site_title: The silent whistle
summary: A study by the Centre for Investor Protection found that many Singaporean companies have room for improvement in their whistle-blowing policies. 29.3% of companies did not disclose the number of complaints received, and nearly two-thirds disclosed zero complaints. Companies were often vague in their disclosures, and some claimed to have no misconduct despite receiving WB reports. However, Singtel stood out for its transparency, with 103 WB reports in FY2024. To improve their policies, companies should ensure that the type of reportable breaches is not overly narrow, publish detailed policies, and provide multiple channels for reporting.

site_title: Americans will miss their government when it’s gone
summary: The US government is experiencing a mass exodus of experienced professionals, including career civil servants, administrators, and experts, as part of the Trump administration's purge of key agencies. This has led to fragmentation, inefficiency, and dysfunction, as seasoned officials are replaced by political loyalists. The loss of institutional knowledge and expertise will undermine governance, national security, and US foreign policy, while also compromising research and technological innovation. The attempt to run public administration like a private company has proven disastrous, with examples such as the Danish tax authority scandal. The result is a chaotic and incapable government, with a leader who is increasingly isolated and unable to trust anyone.

site_title: Senior establishment figures mediated between CDL’s Kwek Leng Beng and son Sherman, sources say

site_title: Euro holds near highs as traders watch German spending debate
summary: The euro remained near multi-month highs against the US dollar, as investors awaited the outcome of a German spending debate and potential fiscal reforms. summary: Thailand has approved a US$1 billion investment from China's Sunwoda Electronic to build an electric vehicle battery plant, creating 1,000 jobs for lithium-ion battery cell production. site_title: Deutsche Bank bonuses rise to decade high on trading, deals

site_title: AmCham Singapore launches expanded hub in Shaw Centre

site_title: Oracle launches AI Centre of Excellence in Singapore to collaborate with customers
summary: Oracle has launched an AI Centre of Excellence in Singapore, offering training and experimentation services to upskill students and professionals in cloud and AI technologies. The centre will collaborate with customers, including large enterprises and small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), and partner with companies such as ST Engineering and Singtel's NCS. The goal is to build an agile and adaptable workforce equipped to leverage new technology effectively, with outcomes determining the success of the centre.

images.alt_text: The new tooreplaces OpenAI’s Assistants API, which is set to be phased out by the second half of 2026.
Under Prime Minister Keir Starmer, the Labour-led government has made increasing productivity a key priority as it seeks to repair a hole in its finances amid anaemic growth.
The GenAI Playbook aims to make AI adoption more accessible for enterprises across different stages of digital maturity.

site_title: SingPost shareholders vote overwhelmingly in favour of A$1 billion sale of Australian business
summary: SingPost shareholders overwhelmingly voted in favor of selling its Australian logistics business, Freight Management Holdings (FMH), for A$1 billion (S$856.5 million). The sale will generate A$775.9 million in gross proceeds and a capital gain of about S$289.5 million. The company plans to invest S$30 million to install new e-commerce parcel sorting equipment at its Tampines facility, increasing its capacity to 300,000 parcels per day. The sale will allow SingPost to focus on its core Singapore and international e-commerce logistics businesses, which are facing competitive challenges.

site_title: Samsonite to progress with US listing as weak consumer sentiment hits profits
summary: Samsonite International is progressing with a potential dual listing in the US, despite weak consumer sentiment and slower retail traffic globally. The company's net sales fell 2.5% to $3.59 billion for 2024, missing analysts' consensus, and net income declined to $345.6 million from $396.9 million in 2023. China was particularly impacted by macroeconomic conditions, while revenue in the country fell only 2%. The company plans to enhance its brand portfolio through accretive mergers and acquisitions in the long term.

site_title: Couche-Tard says ready to boost bid if Seven & i engages
summary: Canadian convenience store operator Alimentation Couche-Tard Inc. has stated it could increase its offer to acquire Seven & i Holdings, the parent company of 7-Eleven stores, if the latter engages in takeover talks. Couche-Tard's founder and chairman Alain Bouchard said they may enhance their proposal through due diligence access to financials. This comes after an unusual press conference in Tokyo, where Couche-Tard's executives promoted their multi-billion dollar bid. The company's willingness to boost its offer suggests a strong interest in acquiring Seven & i Holdings.

images.alt_text: Couche-Tard has been pursuing Seven & i for months even as it has received a frosty reception from the Japanese retail giant, in what would be Japan’s largest-ever foreign buyout if the deal is completed.
The Circle-K owner has been pursuing Seven & i for months even as it received a frosty reception from the Japanese retail giant.
Seven & i has been fending off the approach by pursuing an overhaul of the company to unlock shareholder value.

site_title: Bank of Japan expects consumption to improve on solid wage gains: Governor Ueda
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Kazuo Ueda expects Japan's consumption to improve due to moderate inflation and strengthening wage growth. Real wages and consumption had been lacklustre due to lagging wage gains in 2022. The central bank aims to scrutinize its balance sheet reduction, taking cues from other central banks. Ueda noted the BOJ's balance sheet is "somewhat too big," prompting a reduction in bond buying. This suggests a possible shift in monetary policy, but no specific timeline has been set.

site_title: LVMH’s Sephora overhauls Asia leadership after setback in China
summary: Sephora, a luxury cosmetics retailer owned by LVMH, has overhauled its Asia leadership after struggling to win customers in mainland China, where it has incurred millions of US dollars in losses. Guillaume Motte, Sephora's CEO, has taken personal charge of its operations in China, replacing Alia Gogi, who resigned in 2020. The move aims to revive sales and market share in the region, which is crucial for LVMH's second-largest brand. The retailer plans to update its product range and feature more Chinese home-grown brands in stores.

images.alt_text: Bernard Arnault says 2025 has started relatively well, with Louis Vuitton posting double-digit growth so far this year.
The luxury goods companies, including LVMH and Kering, are hoping US shoppers will come to the rescue after relying on brisk business from Chinese buyers for decades.
Bvlgari's Serpenti Infinito Exhibition in Shanghai is staged in the historic shikumen compound of Zhangyuan.
LVMH is already facing pressure due to slowing sales.

site_title: ‘Forced Joy’ is a miserable corporate trend
summary: Corporate culture has become increasingly focused on "forced joy" as companies like Starbucks and Tiffany & Co require employees to manufacture a feeling of positivity and enthusiasm, often through artificial means. The trend is driven by a desire to boost employee engagement, which has reached a 10-year low according to a Gallup poll. However, critics argue that this approach can come across as insincere and may not lead to genuine employee satisfaction. The article suggests that companies should focus on creating an environment where workers can effectively do their jobs and find their own sources of workplace joy, rather than relying on forced enthusiasm.

images.alt_text: Starbucks is testing new store designs in the US as it looks to reverse a sales slump.
Business leaders must walk the talk

site_title: Thai consumer confidence falls in February
summary: Thai consumer confidence fell to 57.8 in February, the lowest level in five months, due to uncertainty from US trade policies, higher living costs, and the slow recovery of the Thai economy. This marks the first decline in consumer confidence since August 2022. The decline is attributed to concerns over the impact of US trade policies on Thailand's economy.

site_title: CDL saga: Will peace hold? It’s time for a comprehensive strategic review
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) has temporarily resolved its leadership dispute after Kwek Leng Beng dropped his lawsuit against his son Sherman Kwek and six other board members. The group's share price rallied, but concerns over the father-son relationship and governance issues remain. CDL's board should launch a comprehensive strategic review to improve the group's performance, focusing on five key areas: improving financial performance, working the balance sheet harder, examining the ownership structure, studying the hotel business' positioning, and looking at leadership succession.

images.alt_text: CDL saga: Kwek Leng Beng discontinues lawsuit against son Sherman Kwek
Dr Catherine Wu has been an independent adviser to the board of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels since since August 2024.
Second generation Kwek family members may hold the keys to Kwek Leng Beng's fate in his tussle with son Sherman at CDL.

CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng (right) said he has filed court papers to deal with the attempted coup by Sherman Kwek, Philip Lee, Wong Ai Ai and a group of directors acting with them to allegedly consolidate control of the board and the group.

site_title: Latest Singapore six-month T-bill cut-off yield falls to 2.56%
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore announced a 2.56% cut-off yield for the latest six-month Treasury bill, down from 2.75% in the previous auction. The auction received S$19.8 billion in applications for the S$7.5 billion on offer, with a bid-to-cover ratio of 2.64. This marks a decrease in demand and median yield, with the average yield rising to 2.41%. Experts attribute the lower cut-off yield to lower Singapore dollar interest rates, which are expected to be more limited in the future, as the government plans to issue up to S$450 billion in government securities.

images.alt_text: DBS analysts say a “wall of money” could soon flow into S-Reits, as retail investors turn away from T-bills.

site_title: HSBC places some bankers on short-term retention amid overhaul
summary: HSBC is embarking on a global restructuring program, reducing management ranks and incurring $1.8 billion in charges over two years. The bank is placing some investment bankers on short-term retention agreements to wind down various businesses, including selective investment-banking units. Many vice-chair roles are also being cut. The overhaul, led by new CEO Georges Elhedery, aims to focus on areas where HSBC can have a competitive advantage and serve corporate and institutional clients.

images.alt_text: Contract hiring allows large-scale headcount changes to be made without severance payouts, as firms have the flexibility to simply not renew contracts, said HR firms.

A photo illustration taken in Beijing on March 11, 2025 shows a mobile phone displaying an introduction screen for the AI assistant tool Manus, released by Chinese startup Butterfly Effect. (Photo by ADEK BERRY / AFP)
While the S&P 500 has lost 4.5 per cent so far this year, a gauge of Chinese stocks listed in Hong Kong has surged 20 per cent, making it one of the best-performing indexes in 2025.

site_title: Hong Kong clears rule for indexed life policy to lure the rich
summary: Hong Kong authorities have relaxed rules to allow high net worth individuals to access an indexed universal life insurance policy, which allows premium holders to pledge assets to the insurance company as a custodian. The product, previously unavailable due to regulation and risk concerns, has gained traction in the US, Bermuda, and Singapore. HSBC plans to launch a product in Hong Kong catering to ultra-high net worth clients, seeking to develop the city's HK$31 trillion wealth management business and compete with other financial hubs.

site_title: Singapore Airlines, Cathay split on banning power bank use on flights
summary: Singapore Airlines will ban the use of portable power banks on flights starting next month, differing from regional rival Cathay Pacific Airways. The move follows rising incidents of battery-related fires or smoke on planes, including a suspected fire on an Air Busan plane in January and a Batik Air plane cabin filling with smoke. The Singapore Air group will allow power banks in cabin baggage, but not in checked luggage, and will not permit recharging via in-seat USB ports. This rule change aims to mitigate potential safety hazards.

site_title: Indonesia posts rare, early budget deficit as revenues slump
summary: Indonesia posted a rare early budget deficit in the first two months of 2025, with a shortfall of 31.2 trillion rupiah (S$ 2.5 billion), equivalent to 0.13% of gross domestic product. This reverses the 0.11% budget surplus of the same period last year, and is the first time the country has posted a deficit this early in the year since 2021. The decline in state revenues is attributed to a double-digit drop.

images.alt_text: The wealth fund is seen as a key tool to help Prabowo achieve his strategic goals and return Indonesia to the 8 per cent economic growth levels it last posted in the mid-1990s.

TOPSHOT - Textile factory workers gather as they listen to a farewell speech during the mass layoffs, in Sukoharjo, Central Java, on February 28, 2025, after the country's Supreme Court declared the textile giant bankrupt as it failed to pay its debts and ceased operations. (Photo by DIKA / AFP)

Indonesia’s President Prabowo Subianto, who also serves as the chairman of the Great Indonesia Movement Party (Gerindra), celebrates the party's 17th anniversary with supporters in Bogor, West Java, on February 15, 2025 (Photo by ADITYA AJI / AFP)
Prices of several food items saw a dip in February, including chicken meat, shallots, red chilies, bird’s eye chilies, tomatoes, and chicken eggs.
The rupiah has come under mounting pressure this year, following Bank Indonesia’s unexpected rate cut in January.

Indonesia's President Prabowo Subianto (centre) deposits a gold bar during the inauguration of the bullion banking service by Indonesia's state-owned pawnbroker and financial services company Pegadaian and Bank Syariah Indonesia on Feb 26.

site_title: Gold breaks through US$3,000 as Trump turbocharges record rally
summary: Gold prices have broken through the $3,000 an ounce barrier, driven by a surge in US prices and a central bank buying spree, amid economic fragility and President Donald Trump's aggressive trade policy. The metal has risen 10-fold in the past quarter century, outperforming the S&P 500. The rally is also attributed to concerns about the US dollar's role in the global economy, high inflation, and investor fears of missing out on gold's gains. With the US trade deficit at a record high, gold's value as a store of value in turbulent times is being reinforced.

images.alt_text: Gold is seen as a hedge against political risks and inflation.

site_title: Japan eyes boosting rice exports eightfold by 2030
summary: Japan aims to boost rice exports eightfold by 2030, driven by a long-term national policy to increase overseas shipments and make farming more efficient. The move comes as the country faces a domestic rice shortage and a shrinking ageing population. Japan's rice consumption has halved over the past 60 years, shifting towards more energy-dense foods. The new target is part of efforts to boost the industry and meet growing global demand.

images.alt_text: Government-stockpiled rice piled up at a warehouse in Saitama prefecture, Japan, Feb 18, 2025. Rice shortages driven by factors from poor harvests caused by hot weather to panic-buying over a “megaquake” warning last summer have caused prices to nearly double over a year.

Workers harvesting rice in Thailand using their sickles, before the threshing and winnowing. With climate change, rising sea levels are threatening rice fields and the region’s supply of the grain will come under more pressure.

Toyota, Japan’s top carmaker and the bellwether for the country’s manufacturers, agreed to hikes of up to 24,450 yen (S$220) in monthly pay as well as a bonus equivalent to 7.6 months’ worth of salary.
With consumer inflation exceeding its target for nearly three years, the BOJ has signalled its readiness to raise interest rates further if the economy sustains a moderate recovery.
“Rising energy and food costs are hurting households and companies, so we need to scrutinise how souring households’ sentiment could affect consumption,” Japan’s Economy Minister Ryosei Akazawa said.

site_title: Trump administration unveils sweeping environment rollbacks
summary: The US Trump administration has unveiled 31 environmental rollbacks targeting Biden-era green policies, including carbon limits on power plants, tailpipe emissions standards, and protections for waterways. The rollbacks include revisiting a 2024 rule that would have required coal-fired plants to eliminate nearly all their carbon emissions, and eliminating the nation's environmental justice offices. Environmental groups have hailed the move as a "gamechanger" for corporate polluters, while critics warn of mass layoffs and increased pollution.

images.alt_text: Women walk on a road in India's capital as the sky is enveloped with smog, in New Delhi, India, Nov 19, 2024. India, fifth in the smog rankings behind Chad, Bangladesh, Pakistan and the Democratic Republic of Congo, saw average PM2.5 fall 7 per cent on the year to 50.6 mg/cu m.

Smoke rises from the chimneys of the Suralaya coal-fired power plant in Cilegon, Indonesia, Sept 14, 2023. Since US President Donald Trump returned to office in January, Washington has slashed foreign aid and championed development of fossil fuels.

0608CKT 照片来源：GenZero　
照片描述：Genzero投资加纳的恢复项目，旨在通过相应的调整产生碳信用额
Construction of clean energy bases in the nation’s deserts will be accelerated, and more will be done to integrate renewables into local grids.
Thailand aims to have an emissions trading system in full operation by 2030, and is preparing to impose a carbon tax of 200 baht a tonne on oil products.

site_title: Trump’s US$1.4 trillion tariff threat spurs companies to seek cover
summary: US President Donald Trump's $1.4 trillion tariff threat has prompted companies worldwide to seek cover, with many planning to increase local production or pass on higher costs to consumers. The tariffs, which target goods from Canada, Mexico, and China, are expected to disrupt global supply chains and drive up costs for industries such as automotive, pharmaceuticals, and retail. Companies like Boeing, Novo Nordisk, and Walmart are preparing for the worst, while some, like Galderma and Eli Lilly, are exploring alternative markets to offset the impact. The uncertainty is causing financial markets to fluctuate.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows aluminium bars produced at the Krasnoyarsk Aluminium Smelter (KrAZ) of Rusal in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, Russia July 17, 2024. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk/File Photo
The consumer price index (CPI) came in at 2.8 per cent last month from a year ago, down from 3.0 per cent in January.

Even if not all of Asia is directly affected, the impact of rising tariffs and trade wars could cause major disruptions to supply chains and slow trade and investment flows, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong said.

European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen says:  “We firmly believe that in a world fraught with geo-economic and political uncertainties, it is not in our common interest to burden our economies with such tariffs.”

FILE PHOTO: U.S. President Donald Trump speaks in the Oval Office, on the day he signs executive orders, at the White House in Washington, D.C., U.S. March 6, 2025. REUTERS/Evelyn Hockstein/File Photo

site_title: Blackstone ups bid for ‘Can of Ham’ London tower to £330 million
summary: Blackstone has increased its bid for London's Can of Ham skyscraper to £330 million, a significant wager on rising office rents in the city. The 24-storey tower, completed before the pandemic, has several leases set to expire soon, providing Blackstone with an opportunity to earn more from tenants. A deal, if successful, would value the building at a yield of less than 6% and be one of London's largest office sales in recent years, amid a supply crunch in the city's office market.

images.alt_text: Blackstone is a major owner of commercial real estate globally and its real estate debt group manages US$77 billion of assets.
The shopping mall has brands such as Zara, Sephora and Marks & Spencer in addition to movie theatres and a gaming arena.
Blackstone’s deal for CMIC is the second by a major global private equity firm in the past month in Japan’s pharmaceutical sector.

site_title: Duterte says he is ‘responsible’ as ICC takes him into custody
summary: Former Philippines president Rodrigo Duterte was taken into custody by the International Criminal Court (ICC) on Wednesday, facing charges over his war on drugs. Duterte, 79, has admitted to being responsible for the anti-drug campaign, which rights groups estimate killed tens of thousands of people. The ICC believes there are "reasonable grounds" to charge him with murder as a crime against humanity. Duterte will be held in court custody until an initial court appearance, likely in the coming days.

images.alt_text: Duterte's arrest marks the biggest step yet in the ICC’s probe into alleged crimes against humanity during an anti-drugs crackdown that killed thousands and drew condemnation around the world.
Protesters demonstrate demanding justice for drug war victims, after the arrest of Rodrigo Duterte, in Quezon City on March 11.
Former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte speaking to his supporters during a gathering at a gymnasium in Hong Kong.

site_title: Anwar denies Malaysia bailing out Sapura Energy with investment
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim denied that a RM1.1 billion investment in cash-strapped oil and gas firm Sapura Energy was a bailout. Anwar ordered an audit and a change of management before approving the investment, which will be used to repay vendors. He stated that the funds are not a bailout like past instances and that Sapura Energy's new management is expected to repay the government in full, with conditions including the departure of the chairman and senior management.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo of TotalEnergies is seen at an electric vehicle fuelling station in the La Defense business district in Courbevoie near Paris, France, February 8, 2023. REUTERS/Sarah Meyssonnier/File Photo

site_title: US trading partners hit back on steel, aluminium tariffs
summary: US trading partners, including the European Union, Canada, and China, have announced countermeasures against the US tariffs on steel and aluminium imports, which took effect on Wednesday. The EU has imposed tariffs on $28 billion of US goods, while Canada has imposed tariffs on $20.7 billion of US products. China has vowed to take "all necessary measures" in response. The move has raised concerns of an all-out trade war, with US President Donald Trump vowing to respond to the countermeasures.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows aluminium bars produced at the Krasnoyarsk Aluminium Smelter (KrAZ) of Rusal in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, Russia July 17, 2024. REUTERS/Alexander Manzyuk/File Photo

Even if not all of Asia is directly affected, the impact of rising tariffs and trade wars could cause major disruptions to supply chains and slow trade and investment flows, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong said.
US President Donald Trump delivers remarks at the Business Roundtable's quarterly meeting in Washington, D.C., March 11, 2025.
The back-and-forth squabble between the US and Canada has further unsettled financial markets already battered by Donald Trump‘s focus on tariffs.

Uncertainty sparked by constant White House pivots on tariffs has potentially delayed business investments and prompted consumers to pull back on spending, said Paul Gruenwald, global chief economist at S&P Global Ratings.

site_title: Adobe gives tepid revenue outlook with focus on AI tools
summary: Adobe provided a disappointing revenue outlook for the current quarter, estimating $5.77 billion to $5.82 billion in sales, below analysts' average estimate of $5.8 billion. The company's focus on monetizing its AI features, including Firefly in Photoshop and Premiere, has raised concerns about competition and the impact on its products' profitability. Despite this, Adobe's fiscal year outlook remains unchanged, with revenue and profit projections unchanged at $23.3 billion to $23.6 billion and $20.20 to $20.50 per share, respectively.

images.alt_text: The free version of the Photoshop app will have features such as splitting a photo into separate layers, masking off parts of it and adding text.
Adobe’s model differs from its rivals because it is geared towards generating clips that will fit into how film and television studios use Premiere Pro.
Adobe says the video model is trained on public domain or licensed content that it has permission to use, and not on any Adobe customer content.
Adobe has staked its future on building models trained on data that it has rights to use, ensuring the output can be legally used in commercial work.

site_title: South Korea braces for market disruptions after Trump tariffs
summary: South Korea, the fourth-largest economy in Asia, is bracing for market disruptions after US President Donald Trump imposed 25% tariffs on global steel and aluminum imports. Acting President Choi Sang-mok urged policymakers to prepare for disruptions and ordered officials to ensure a smooth supply of steel materials. Seoul sent its trade minister to Washington to accelerate negotiations, while the government plans to introduce countermeasures, including monitoring imports and circumvention efforts. The tariffs add to existing trade measures and pose a risk to steelmakers worldwide.

images.alt_text: The  Bank of Korea has cut its benchmark interest rate three times since October, when it pivoted policy, as it has viewed inflationary trends staying largely in line with its expectations.
South Korea in recent years has designated 12 industries as “national strategic technologies” with targeted financial support.
The trade-reliant economy faces headwinds from an escalating trade war among major countries.

site_title: Manhattan apartment rents jump to record as bidding wars spread
summary: Manhattan apartment rents have reached a record high in February, with new leases signed at a median of $4,500, a 6.4% increase from last year. Bidding wars have become increasingly common, with 27% of new leases signed after negotiations, a record share. The market's competitiveness is attributed to economic uncertainty and potential renters holding off on buying, with prices also rising in Brooklyn and northwest Queens. The vacancy rate has fallen for a fourth consecutive month, making it one of the most challenging times to be a renter.

images.alt_text: Apartment buildings stand in New York, U.S., on Thursday, March 19, 2008. Manhattan apartment sales declined 23 percent last year as the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell the most since the Great Depression. Now co-operative and condominium prices are dropping as Wall Street firms cut the bonuses that contributed to the property market boom of the past decade. Photographer:  JB Reed/Bloomberg News

site_title: Singapore’s Sembcorp, SP Group caught in Vietnam’s clean energy U-turn
summary: Singapore's Sembcorp and SP Group, along with 17 other global firms, are facing uncertainty due to a sudden rule shift in Vietnam that affects 173 renewable energy projects worth US$13 billion. The projects, including those backed by the two companies, are tied to a compliance dispute over tariff and eligibility. The affected projects, which collectively have a capacity of over 400 MWp, are at risk of investment loss, spooking investors from Singapore, the Philippines, and the EU. The rule shift may impact US$13 billion in renewable energy investments.

images.alt_text: In recent years, Vietnam experienced a boom in renewable energy investments driven by generous feed-in tariffs, under which the state committed to buying electricity for 20 years at above-market prices.
The Hoa Binh Hydropower Plant that is owned by Vietnam Electricity. The new scheme is expected to ease the investment burden on EVN for power generation and transmission.
Vietnam's northern province of Bac Giang, home to suppliers for Apple, Samsung Electronics and other MNCs, struggled with blackouts in 2023.
Vietnam seeks to collect emissions-based environmental protection fees from greenhouse-gas-emitting facilities

site_title: Nomura exits bank climate group, joining Wall Street exodus
summary: Nomura Holdings is withdrawing from the Net-Zero Banking Alliance (NZBA), joining other global banks in exodus due to US climate policy shift. The move comes as the US has withdrawn from the Paris Agreement and expressed support for the fossil-fuel industry. Despite this, Nomura will stick to its target of deploying $125 billion of sustainable financing to March 2026. The remaining Japanese megabanks, Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group and Mizuho Financial Group, will vote on a revised strategy that removes a key requirement for lenders to align portfolios with a 1.5-degree Celsius warming goal.

site_title: Who is Intel’s new CEO Tan Lip-Bu?
summary: Intel has appointed Tan Lip-Bu, a 65-year-old Singapore-raised semiconductor veteran, as its new CEO, effective March 18. With over 20 years of experience in the industry, Tan will lead the US chip giant from a challenging period, including fierce competition, debt, and market share loss. His predecessor, Pat Gelsinger, was ousted from the board for perceived failure to revive Intel's product lineup. Tan's compensation package includes a $69 million value, and he will also return to the board after stepping down in August 2024.

images.alt_text: Intel, once dominant in the chip industry, has struggled to regain its technological edge and lost market share to rivals in recent years.
Intel was among the largest beneficiaries of the US push to onshore critical chip manufacturing led by former president Joe Biden’s administration.

site_title: CDL shares climb 4% after Kwek Leng Beng discontinues lawsuit against son Sherman Kwek
summary: CDL shares rose 4% after executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng dropped his lawsuit against son Sherman Kwek and other board members, clearing the way for Sherman to continue as group CEO. Kwek Leng Beng stated that all directors, including Jennifer Duong Young and Wong Su-Yen, will remain on the board, and they will focus on strengthening the company's business. The decision marks a resolution to the attempted boardroom coup, which was sparked by Kwek Leng Beng's concerns over his son's leadership and the influence of long-term adviser Catherine Wu.

images.alt_text: Dr Catherine Wu has been an independent adviser to the board of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels since since August 2024.
Singapore investor's watchdog has asked CDL to clarify its appointment process for its newly appointed directors.
CDL saga: Kwek Leng Beng discontinues lawsuit against son Sherman Kwek

site_title: Why open innovation is key for Singapore amid deglobalisation
summary: Singapore's future in a deglobalized world depends on bold leadership, collective action, and transformation. The nation must adapt to a rapidly evolving business environment by fostering collaboration in critical areas like technology, talent, and sustainability. Companies must thrive in uncertainty by embracing a proactive, agile mindset, leveraging tools like AI and predictive analytics, and prioritizing sustainability. This requires a shift in mindset, bold transformations, and collective intelligence. By doing so, Singapore can become a global model for navigating constant change and thriving in an era of complexity.

images.alt_text: Deep transformation or shallow transition?
Evolution or extinction? Leadership through innovation in a time of crisis

site_title: Asia: Stocks wobble as US inflation fails to ease trade worries
summary: Asian stocks wavered on Thursday amid ongoing US trade tensions, despite a slight easing of inflation concerns. Below-forecast US inflation data provided a brief reprieve, but markets remain uncertain about President Trump's tariff agenda and its potential impact. Shares in Tokyo, Shanghai, and other Asian markets rose, while Hong Kong, Sydney, and Singapore fell. Investors remain wary of the potential for a recession and further interest rate hikes, with the US-EU trade talks and the April 2 reciprocal tariff deadline looming.

images.alt_text: Spools of steel at an ArcelorMittal Dofasco facility in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, March 12, 2025. Canada will keep its trade retaliation in place until the US lifts its own tariffs and commits to free trade, said Mark Carney, who will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s prime minister.
The Stoxx 600 closed 0.81 per cent higher at 541.25 points on Wednesday, snapping its longest losing streak since December.
The broad-based S&P 500 Index gained 0.5 per cent to 5,599.30 while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index surged 1.2 per cent to 17,648.45 on Wednesday.

site_title: Walmart faces heat from Beijing after demand for price cuts
summary: Chinese authorities have summoned Walmart executives over reports that the US retailer asked suppliers to bear rising costs incurred by increased US tariffs, sparking concerns about a potential fracturing of the global supply chain. The move comes as Beijing targets US businesses operating in the country, and Walmart's strategy of sourcing goods at low prices to stay competitive is seen as a threat to Chinese exporters. Chinese authorities have warned that being condescending to suppliers could prompt local consumers to seek out alternatives, and the industry body has pledged to take measures to protect its members' interests.

images.alt_text: Walmart’s push shows how rising geopolitical tensions are set to reshape global supply chains and pile pressure on US consumers already grappling with cost-of-living stresses.
Walmart bonuses largely exceed targets but dip from prior year
Walmart is also closing its office in Charlotte, North Carolina, and is cutting corporate roles as part of the process, according to the memo.

site_title: US: Stocks mostly rise as tech shares jump
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, with the S&P 500 Index gaining 0.5% to 5,599.30 and the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index surging 1.2% to 17,648.45, despite concerns about the US economy. The Dow Jones Industrial Average lost 0.2% to 41,350.93. The cooler-than-expected consumer price index (CPI) for February, which rose 2.8% from a year ago, eased investor jitters. However, tariff worries lingered, with President Trump's tariff policies potentially impacting the economy.

images.alt_text: The biggest decliner on the STI index is national carrier Singapore Airlines. The counter slid 1.6 per cent or S$0.11 to S$6.65.
A trader works on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., February 24, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Starbucks to add seating, power outlets to attract customers
summary: Starbucks is testing new store designs in the US to reverse a sales slump. The company plans to add seating, power outlets, and a redesigned espresso bar to create a more inviting atmosphere, encouraging customers to linger and order more items. This shift marks a reversal from the company's previous focus on prioritizing to-go service, which led to less seating. CEO Brian Niccol aims to make stores more welcoming, citing the need to "fix" past mistakes.

site_title: Bitterness from Chocolate Finance fallout could cloud its future if trust melts away
summary: Chocolate Finance, a Singapore-based fintech platform, has suspended instant withdrawals and debit card transactions after facing criticism and a potential liquidity crisis. CEO Walter de Oude assured investors that their funds are secure, but negative sentiment online indicates investors may withdraw their money. The platform's assets under management (AUM) could decline by up to 50% if investors withdraw, potentially affecting its growth and partnerships. Regulated by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, Chocolate Finance may struggle to regain trust, but its high interest rate could attract customers if instant withdrawals resume.

images.alt_text: Chocolate Finance founder and chief executive Walter de Oude assured that despite a spike in withdrawals, all requests are being processed in an orderly manner.
Transactions made on AXS, and e-wallet top-ups are no longer supported, said Chocolate Finance.
Chocolate Finance's competitors say that there was no spike in withdrawals or enqueries following the suspension of instant withdrawals.
Founder and chief executive Walter de Oude explained that a spike in withdrawals would deplete the firm's liquidity buffer, which is why a temporary pause is required.
Instant withdrawals are temporarily unavailable at Chocolate Finance, which was founded by Walter de Oude.

site_title: Hong Kong mulls lowering threshold to buy most expensive stocks
summary: Hong Kong's stock exchange is considering lowering the minimum trading unit, or board lot, for some of the city's most expensive stocks to boost trading. The current unit can range from 100 shares to thousands, making it costly for investors to buy partial shares. Officials are exploring options to streamline the unit, potentially allowing for trading of single shares, which could boost liquidity among the wider public. The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) has already lowered stamp duty, shrunk the bid-ask spread, and removed settlement fees to enhance liquidity.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stock Paul Yeung/Bloomberg
Signs point to this historic outperformance continuing, despite Trump increasing tariffs on Chinese exports.
Chinese stocks listed in Hong Kong have been on a tear this year, thanks to the emergence of an artificial-intelligence model from startup DeepSeek that was considered a game-changer in the industry.
The Hong Kong Stock Exchange is now seeking market feedback to allocate a maximum of 20 per cent to retail investors in hot IPOs.

site_title: London to suffer UK’s worst drop in house prices, surveyors predict
summary: London is predicted to experience the UK's largest drop in house prices in the near term, according to property agents. The Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors' indicator of new buyer enquiries weakened to its lowest level since November 2023, with a fall in agreed home sales in February. London's property transactions and demand have also declined, with agents expecting a drop in home values over the next three months. Rising food, energy, and rent costs are making it harder for first-time buyers to save for deposits, with pricey areas like London being most affected.

images.alt_text: Britain’s headline rate of inflation hit a 10-month high of 3 per cent in January and the Bank of England forecasts it will reach 3.7 per cent in the third quarter of this year.
Morale among consumer-facing UK firms remained at its joint-lowest since August 2022 at -55 in February.

“Securing a trade deal with what is soon-to-be the third-biggest economy in the world is a no-brainer, and a top priority for me and this government,” says Business and Trade Secretary Jonathan Reynolds before flying to India.

site_title: China says US owes ‘big thank you’ on fentanyl, urges talks
summary: China has claimed to have effectively controlled the fentanyl trade, asking the US to express gratitude for its efforts, amid stalled talks between the two nations. China's success in cracking down on the illicit trade comes after the US imposed tariffs on Chinese imports, citing the fentanyl crisis. China's Foreign Ministry officials stated that they have done the US a favor and called for dialogue to lift the tariffs, but the US has rejected their assertion, saying detailed steps from China are needed.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: China's and U.S.' flags are seen printed on paper in this illustration taken January 27, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
China, the world’s largest steel producer, churned out nearly 1.05 billion tonnes of steel in 2024.
Xi (right) and Trump (left) have not spoken since both leaders pledged to retain “strategic communication channels” in a phone call days before the Republican took office.
Chicken, wheat, corn and cotton from the United States will now be subject to Chinese tariffs.
China’s measures hit goods the Asian nation can source from other countries, shielding the domestic economy from blowback.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, Mapletree Logistics Trust, Boustead, Del Monte
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng has discontinued his lawsuit against his son Sherman Kwek and six other board members, allowing them to continue in their roles. The decision comes after the parties agreed to put aside their differences for the greater good of CDL and its stakeholders. CDL shares rose 0.2% to S$4.94 following the announcement. Meanwhile, Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) has agreed to divest a logistics property for S$7.8 million, with the proposed divestment expected to be completed by the second quarter of FY2025/2026.

site_title: India inflation eases further, boosting rate cut hopes
summary: India's inflation eased to a 7-month low in February, reaching 3.61% from a year earlier, aligning with the Reserve Bank of India's target. This easing inflation provides space for policymakers to reduce borrowing costs, with most economists forecasting another 50 basis point rate cut in 2025. However, a weaker rupee poses a challenge, putting pressure on prices. The RBI's benchmark rate was lowered for the first time in almost 5 years in February, raising hopes for further rate cuts.

site_title: Greenback struggles to lift off lows as global trade war ramps up
summary: The US dollar struggled to recover from its lowest level since October 16, edging up 0.1% at 103.6 against a basket of six major currencies. The global trade war escalated as the European Union imposed counter tariffs on $37.8 billion worth of US goods, while a potential Russia-Ukraine ceasefire was announced. The US inflation data, due later, is expected to fuel market volatility, with investors concerned about the economy's growth outlook.

images.alt_text: The consumer price index (CPI) came in at 2.8 per cent last month from a year ago, down from 3.0 per cent in January.
US President Donald Trump delivers remarks at the Business Roundtable's quarterly meeting in Washington, D.C., March 11, 2025.

site_title: Democrats playing defence; perhaps they should play dead
summary: The Democratic Party is struggling to regroup after a disappointing 2024 presidential election, where they lost ground among various demographics, including non-white and working-class voters. Moderate Democrats believe the party swerved too far to the left, alienating core constituents. In response, they're trying to shift towards a more centrist message, exemplified by Senator Elissa Slotkin's recent address. However, progressive Democrats disagree, advocating for a more aggressive resistance movement against President Trump's policies. The party must now redefine its message to counter the president's dominance and appeal to voters.

images.alt_text: Americans seem so far unconvinced that the future will be as bright as Donald Trump promises, even after the Republican campaigned hard on cost of living issues in his election battle with Democrat Kamala Harris.

US Vice-President JD Vance (top left) and US House Speaker Mike Johnson (top right) applaud as US President Donald Trump addresses a joint session of the US Congress in the House Chamber of the US Capitol, Washington, D.C., March 4, 2025.

site_title: Couche-Tard goes on charm offensive for Seven & i with Tokyo visit
summary: Alimentation Couche-Tard is visiting Tokyo to address antitrust concerns and push forward its US$47 billion bid for Seven & i, operator of 7-Eleven convenience stores, in what would be Japan's largest-ever foreign buyout. Despite months of pursuit, Couche-Tard has received a frosty reception from Seven & i, and the Canadian company aims to win over a Japanese public skeptical of a foreign takeover of a prized national asset. A press conference in Tokyo will mark the company's efforts to address concerns and secure the deal.

images.alt_text: The Circle-K owner has been pursuing Seven & i for months even as it received a frosty reception from the Japanese retail giant.
Seven & i has been fending off the approach by pursuing an overhaul of the company to unlock shareholder value.

Seven & i, which has more than 80,000 7-Eleven stores in 20 countries and regions, will hold a board meeting and then announce the leadership change along with plans including the sale of non-core assets to Bain Capital, sources said.
The company sees its valuation erode after a plan by the founding Ito family to take the company private collapsed last month.

site_title: CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng drops lawsuit against son Sherman Kwek
summary: Singapore's City Developments Ltd (CDL) executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng has dropped his lawsuit against his son Sherman Kwek, effectively ending a high-profile dispute that had shaken the company. All current directors will remain on the board, and Sherman Kwek will continue as group CEO. Kwek Leng Beng stated that the board members have agreed to put aside their differences for the greater good of CDL and its stakeholders, allowing them to focus on strengthening the company's business and maximizing shareholder value.

images.alt_text: CDL exec chairman Kwek Leng Beng is suing his son and other directors over an "attempted coup” by his son and CEO Sherman Kwek.
Second generation Kwek family members may hold the keys to Kwek Leng Beng's fate in his tussle with son Sherman at CDL.
Singapore investor's watchdog has asked CDL to clarify its appointment process for its newly appointed directors.
Dr Catherine Wu graced the cover of a magazine in Taiwan.
Dr Catherine Wu has been an independent adviser to the board of Millennium & Copthorne Hotels since since August 2024.
The elder Kwek had sought an injunction against the two new directors, Jennifer Duong Young and Wong Su-Yen, to prevent them from exercising the powers of a director.
The pall of uncertainty hanging over CDL could begin to clear when it holds its AGM on Apr 23.

site_title: ‘Pokemon Go’ games unit sold to Saudi group for US$3.5 billion
summary: Saudi sovereign wealth fund-backed Scopely has agreed to buy Niantic's gaming business, including Pokémon Go, for US$3.5 billion. Niantic's games encourage players to explore their neighborhoods, generating over US$1 billion in revenue last year. Scopely will not acquire Niantic's mapping technology business, which will continue under the new name, Niantic Spatial. The deal includes acquisition of Pokémon Go, Pikmin Bloom, and Monster Hunter Now, along with the teams working on them.

images.alt_text: In August, Niantic signed a deal with Savvy to help it expand in Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Egypt.

site_title: Spirit Airlines exits bankruptcy after four-month restructuring
summary: Spirit Airlines emerged from bankruptcy protection on March 12, 2025, after completing a four-month restructuring process. The carrier, now known as Spirit Aviation Holdings, has reduced its flying capacity by up to 20% and received a $350 million equity infusion from existing investors. The funds will be used to introduce premium offerings and expand its services. Spirit filed for Chapter 11 protection in November to restructure $1.6 billion in debt, following losses due to the pandemic and engine manufacturing defects. The carrier has achieved its goal of emerging from bankruptcy protection with "significantly less debt and greater financial flexibility".

images.alt_text: The restructuring deal that Lane approved on Thursday was widely supported by Spirit lenders, who will own the company out of Chapter 11.

site_title: Hong Kong’s stock market booms with Wall Street in turmoil
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng benchmark has surged 21% since US President Donald Trump's presidency, making it the world's top performer. Despite Trump's increasing tariffs on Chinese exports, global investors are pouring funds into the Hong Kong market, drawn by China's AI advancements. The city's US$6 trillion bourse benefits from being a preferred home for Chinese tech listings and a liquid equities market. Analysts expect the outperformance to continue, with some upgrading China's stocks and downgrading US shares. Hong Kong's status as a financial hub is also boosted, with deals picking up again amid rising market speculation.

images.alt_text: Chinese stocks listed in Hong Kong have been on a tear this year, thanks to the emergence of an artificial-intelligence model from startup DeepSeek that was considered a game-changer in the industry.
The Hong Kong Stock Exchange is now seeking market feedback to allocate a maximum of 20 per cent to retail investors in hot IPOs.

site_title: ECB’s wage tracker indicates steep slowdown likely this year
summary: The European Central Bank's wage tracker predicts a sharp slowdown in 2025, with annual salary growth forecast to rise by 1.5% in the fourth quarter, down from a peak of 5.3% last year. This moderation in pay increases is expected to support the bank's goal of reaching 2% inflation by early 2026. The ECB's decision to lower borrowing costs earlier this month suggests a continued easing phase, but may be nearing its end. Markets have pared bets on future rate cuts amid increased defence spending and infrastructure investments in European countries.

images.alt_text: There’s been a lot of focus on the neutral rate of interest – a theoretical point at which policy neither stimulates nor holds back economic activity.
FILE PHOTO: EU flags flutter in front of European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany July 18, 2024. REUTERS/Jana Rodenbusch/File Photo
The breakdown meant some ordinary bank payments, such as wages, pensions and social welfare transfers, have been delayed and could take several hours longer than usual to arrive.
The consensus is that the ECB will take this year’s staff changes in its stride, with markets still very much focused on data rather than personnel as they calibrate their interest-rate bets.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to sell warehouses at 31 Penjuru Lane for S$7.8 million
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is selling its 31 Penjuru Lane property for S$7.8 million, a 6.8% premium over its valuation of S$7.3 million as of November 28. The three-storey warehouse and 28-year-old warehouse will be sold to an unrelated third party. The sale is part of the trust's efforts to rejuvenate its portfolio through selective divestments, with released capital providing greater financial flexibility for future investments. The proposed divestment has received in-principle approval from JTC Corporation and is expected to be completed by the second quarter of FY2025/2026.

site_title: BMW to absorb tariff costs on some Mexican-built models
summary: BMW will "price protect" US sales of its 3 Series sedan and 2 Series coupe built in Mexico until May 1, absorbing the added cost of new tariffs. The company aims to mitigate the impact of tariffs on its imports from Mexico, which account for about 10% of US sales. This move is part of BMW's efforts to maintain competitiveness in the US market amid escalating trade tensions.

images.alt_text: A logo of BMW is seen inside a car dealer in Nijmegen, Netherlands February 26, 2025. REUTERS/Piroschka van de Wouw

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 12)
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lawrence Wong and Communist Party of Vietnam General Secretary To Lam announced a partnership upgrade to Comprehensive Strategic Partnership, marking the first between a Singaporean government and an Asean member state. The partnership aims to enhance bilateral ties, promote economic cooperation, and strengthen security and defense relations. The upgrade is seen as a significant move to deepen ties between the two nations, with Singapore and Vietnam aiming to expand their cooperation in areas such as trade, investment, and tourism.

site_title: Companies more inclined to hire contract staff to avoid complexities of layoffs
summary: Companies in Singapore are increasingly turning to contract staff to avoid complexities of layoffs amid economic uncertainty. This approach allows for flexible workforce scaling and reduces severance payouts. According to HR firms, contract hiring is common in sectors undergoing digital transformation, such as tech, finance, and healthcare. While some workers are warming to contract employment, concerns remain about job security, benefits, and the lack of long-term commitment. The trend is also driven by the rise of one-year contracts and the displacement of manual roles by AI.

images.alt_text: A majority of retrenched non-resident workers were from the electronics manufacturing, information and communications, and wholesale trade sectors.
From tech to retail, media and finance, major companies are starting to shed employees as they undergo restructuring and adapt to changing market conditions.
Piyush will hand over the CEO's reins to Tan Su Shan on Mar 28.

site_title: GIC-backed Razorpay eyes group profit, expands to Singapore
summary: Indian fintech firm Razorpay has expanded into Singapore, aiming to tap into the country's e-commerce market, valued at $40 billion in the next three years. The company, backed by GIC, plans to boost revenues by launching in Thailand, Vietnam, the Philippines, and the Middle East. Razorpay wants to capture $5 billion in total payment volume from the region, with a focus on real-time payments and cross-border transactions. The company aims to achieve group profitability within the next three years, paving the way for a potential IPO.

images.alt_text: L to R: Shashank Kumar, managing director and co-founder, Razorpay and Angad Dhindsa, South-east Asia head, Razorpay Singapore.

site_title: Canada announces C$29.8 billion in retaliatory tariffs on US
summary: Canada is imposing C$29.8 billion in retaliatory tariffs on the US, targeting steel products worth C$12.6 billion, aluminium products worth C$3 billion, and additional imported US goods. The tariffs, effective March 13, respond to the US President's steel and aluminium tariffs and affect products like computers, sports equipment, and cast iron products. The move escalates the US-Canada trade war, coinciding with Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's handover to successor Mark Carney.

images.alt_text: The back-and-forth squabble between the US and Canada has further unsettled financial markets already battered by Donald Trump‘s focus on tariffs.

site_title: GE2025: New battlegrounds, higher uncertainty
summary: Singapore's next General Election (GE2025) will feature five new Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and six new Single Member Constituencies (SMCs), marking significant changes to electoral boundaries. This is the largest shake-up in recent years, with only a few constituencies remaining unchanged. The changes will affect a sizable number of voters, who will find themselves in a different constituency this time. The GE2025 is expected to be fought on mostly new battlegrounds, increasing uncertainty and competitiveness in the election.

images.alt_text: Singapore election 2025: GE2025 could feature several new GRCs and Single Member Constituencies (SMC) due to population shifts and the emergence of new estates since the last boundary delineation exercise.
Singapore election 2025: The EBRC report recommended widespread changes, with only five GRCs and four SMCs untouched.
Singapore election 2025: Changes to Singapore’s electoral divisions with more MPs, new GRCs and SMCs

site_title: Europe: Shares rebound as Ukraine ceasefire hopes, US inflation data uplift sentiment
summary: European shares rebounded on Wednesday, snapping their longest losing streak since December, as hopes for a Ukraine-Russia ceasefire and a cooler-than-expected US inflation report lifted sentiment. The Stoxx 600 closed 0.81% higher at 541.25 points. The US agreed to resume military aid and intelligence-sharing with Ukraine following a 30-day ceasefire proposal, while a lower-than-expected inflation report also boosted markets.

images.alt_text: The broad-based S&P 500 Index gained 0.5 per cent to 5,599.30 while the tech-heavy Nasdaq Composite Index surged 1.2 per cent to 17,648.45 on Wednesday.

site_title: DHL to hire hundreds in Malaysia if shipping loophole nixed
summary: DHL plans to hire hundreds of workers in Malaysia if the US removes the de minimis rule, which allows for tax-free imports of items worth $800 or less. The exemption has been exploited by Chinese retailers like Temu and Shein to expand US sales. If reinstated, DHL could hire around 200 workers to process shipments, potentially increasing bulk imports and fulfillment in the US rather than overseas. Despite on-again, off-again tariff announcements, DHL expects demand for express shipping to grow this year.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A truck parks at a DHL delivery facility in Manhattan, New York City, U.S., May 9, 2022. REUTERS/Andrew Kelly/File Photo
DHL Indianapolis Logistics Center is a single storey, fully occupied logistics building Whiteland, Indianapolis, Indiana.
A fireman walks past DHL cargo plane wreckage at the crash site near Vilnius International Airport, Lithuania, Nov 25, 2024.

site_title: Intel names industry veteran Tan Lip-Bu as next CEO of one of world’s biggest chipmakers
summary: Intel has appointed Tan Lip-Bu, a 65-year-old Malaysian-born semiconductor veteran, as its new CEO, effective March 18. Tan, who previously led Cadence Design Systems, aims to restore Intel's fortunes, which have been marred by market-share losses, manufacturing setbacks, and declining earnings. He plans to continue Intel's efforts to become a chip foundry and improve its products. The appointment comes as Intel faces significant challenges, including a precipitous decline in its earnings, debt, and recent job cuts. Shares jumped over 11% on the news, and Tan signaled that he will work to restore Intel's position as a world-class products company.

images.alt_text: Intel senior principal engineer Steve Carson said Intel has produced 30,000 wafers, the large discs of silicon that can yield thousands of computing chips, in a single quarter with ASML’s high numerical aperture (NA) lithography machines.
Intel, once dominant in the chip industry, has struggled to regain its technological edge and lost market share to rivals in recent years.
Intel was among the largest beneficiaries of the US push to onshore critical chip manufacturing led by former president Joe Biden’s administration.
The recent gain has only taken shares to their highest since December, and has done little to offset last year’s 60 per cent collapse.

site_title: Del Monte Q3 loss widens to US$35.9 million
summary: Del Monte Pacific reported a net loss of US$35.9 million for the third quarter, primarily due to higher operational costs and increased interest expenses at its US subsidiary. Despite a 2.5% revenue increase to US$663 million, the loss widened from US$29 million in the previous year. The group remains focused on long-term growth and profitability through asset consolidation, inventory reduction, and cost lowering. Del Monte Philippines is experiencing good momentum, with the group committed to consumer engagement and cost optimization.

The US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) on January 15, 2025 announced a ban on Red Dye No. 3, a controversial food coloring long known to cause cancer in animals, decades after scientific evidence first raised alarm. (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP)
Canned food brand Del Monte Pacific's gross profit falls by 19.1 per cent to US87.6 million for Q1.

site_title: Trump uncertainty brings risk of ‘avoidable’ recession: economist
summary: A top economist at S&P Global Ratings warns that President Trump's constant White House pivots on tariffs have delayed business investments and prompted consumers to pull back on spending, potentially raising the risk of a "largely avoidable" US economic downturn. This uncertainty has been driven by the administration's drive to shrink government spending and reduce waste, overseen by billionaire Trump advisor Elon Musk.
