site_title: State Street’s lost mandates expose growing risk in Europe
summary: US asset managers, such as State Street Global Advisors, are facing backlash from European institutional investors due to their downplaying of climate risks. State Street has lost mandates with pension funds in the UK and Scandinavia, with more investors reviewing their relationships with US managers. The trigger for this shift is the US administration's demonization of net-zero financed-emission goals, which scientists say are necessary to limit global warming to 1.5C. European investors prioritize sustainability and responsibility in their investments, leading them to reevaluate their ties with US managers.

images.alt_text: Generic pictures for sustainable and ESG investing
BlackRock chief Larry Fink has dropped the use of the term ESG, as it has been "entirely weaponised", he has said.

site_title: In deflation-hit China, one store holds flash sales four times a day
summary: In deflation-hit China, a store in Beijing, Wankelai, holds four flash sales daily to reduce inventory pressure and attract customers. The store sells clothing, snacks, and household products at deeply discounted prices, with some items sold at a loss. This trend is exacerbating deflationary pressures, which could drag on growth, as seen in Japan in the 1990s. China's consumer price index fell 0.7% in February, while producer prices dropped 2.2%, further fueling deflation. The government has flagged a focus on boosting household spending and cutting the inflation target to 2% in 2025.

images.alt_text: China's consumer price index declined 0.7 per cent from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said on Sunday, compared with a 0.5 per cent gain in the previous month.
Chicken, wheat, corn and cotton from the United States will now be subject to Chinese tariffs.
Xi has a delicate balancing act to maintain in providing the right dose of stimulus to hit the growth target while ensuring aid goes to the parts of the economy that need it most.
Trump, Xi wait to see who blinks first as trade fight heats up
Luckin Coffee shareholders vote to remove chairman, report says

site_title: US: Wall Street drops on trade war concerns; Tesla slides
summary: US stocks fell on Monday, with the Dow Jones and S&P 500 experiencing their largest drops in five months. The tech-heavy Nasdaq also hit a five-month low. Tesla's 7% decline was the largest since November, following UBS's downgrade of its first-quarter forecast and price target. Other mega-cap growth stocks, such as Nvidia and Meta, also dropped, while banks like JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs fell more than 3%. The declines were attributed to concerns over a potential trade war, which could spark an economic slowdown.

site_title: Singapore working with Indonesia on extraditing fugitive businessman: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore has received a formal extradition request from Indonesia to send a fugitive businessman, Paulus Tannos, to face corruption charges in Indonesia. Tannos, a 60-year-old Indonesian national, was arrested in Singapore in January over his alleged involvement in a corruption case in Indonesia. The extradition request is the first since the extradition treaty between the two countries took effect in March 2024. Singapore's Attorney-General's Chambers will try to expedite the process, which may take two years or more due to Tannos' intention to contest extradition.

site_title: White House pushes back against recession talk as household worries grow, stocks tank
summary: The White House is pushing back against recession talk, despite growing household worries and plunging US stocks. Kevin Hassett, head of the National Economic Council, expressed optimism about the US economy, citing the impact of Trump's tariffs on manufacturing and jobs. He attributed the tariffs' effect to bringing jobs back to the US, despite predictions of a potential contraction in gross domestic product in the first quarter and concerns about inflation.

images.alt_text: epa11947306 Director of the National Economic Council Kevin Hassett speaks briefly to the media while he walks into the White House in Washington, DC, USA, 07 March 2025. Hassett spoke about the February jobs report, which stated the US added 151,000 jobs.  EPA-EFE/CHRIS KLEPONIS / POOL
FILE PHOTO: The exterior of the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve Board Building is seen in Washington, D.C., U.S., June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Sarah Silbiger/File Photo
The largest crypto asset is currently down about 28 per cent from its record high of US$109,241.
The Nasdaq plunged by 4.0 per cent, bringing it to 17,468.32 on Monday.

site_title: Apple, Meta likely to face modest fines over DMA breaches: sources
summary: Apple and Meta are likely to face modest fines for allegedly breaching the Digital Markets Act, a landmark EU rule aimed at reining in their power. The companies could face fines of up to 10% of their global annual sales. The EU's antitrust enforcer is focusing on compliance rather than sanctions, citing the short duration of the alleged violations and geopolitical climate. A final decision on the size of the fines is expected this month, following a compliance report from Meta and a DMA compliance report from Apple.

images.alt_text: The lawsuit alleged Apple violated antitrust law by coercing customers to use the company’s iCloud service to back up core data and device setting files.
Google has made its own proposal that would loosen agreements with Apple and others to set Google as the default search engine on new devices.
Meta and Carousell have shown improvement during their assessment period and will not be required to identify all its sellers, said MHA.

site_title: Oil settles down 1.5% as tariffs prompt fears of slow demand
summary: Oil prices fell 1.5% on Monday as investors feared US tariffs on Canada, Mexico, and China would slow global economies and slash energy demand. Brent crude oil futures settled at $69.28 a barrel, down $1.08, while US West Texas Intermediate futures fell to $66.03 a barrel. The decline marks the seventh consecutive weekly drop for WTI and the third consecutive week for Brent. Investors worry about a possible economic slowdown, which could curtail oil demand, amid rising tariffs and sanctions on Russia and Iran.

images.alt_text: Brent crude fell 25 cents, or 0.4 per cent, to US$70.11 a barrel by 0037 GMT after settling up 90 cents on Friday.
The next chapter for oil may entail an outsize focus on macroeconomic data out of the US and China, the world’s largest crude consumers, according to traders and analysts.

site_title: Oracle gives strong outlook, fuelling Stargate cloud optimism
summary: Oracle reported a surge in bookings, exceeding estimates, and gave a revenue forecast for the fiscal year that topped expectations, fuelling optimism about its cloud infrastructure business. The company signed cloud agreements with major tech companies, including OpenAI and Nvidia, and expects a 15% increase in revenue in the next fiscal year. Oracle's efforts to become a major player in the cloud infrastructure market are validated by its joint venture, dubbed Stargate, with OpenAI and Softbank to spend at least $100 billion on data centers for AI startups.

images.alt_text: To power those features, Oracle has decided to skip the costly race to develop huge AI models and instead works with partners such as Canadian startup Cohere.
Under the new law, TikTok can remain in the US if ByteDance executes a “qualified divestiture”.

(From left) US President Donald Trump delivers remarks on AI infrastructure next to Oracle co-founder Larry Ellison, SoftBank CEO Masayoshi Son and OpenAI CEO Sam Altman at the White House, Washington, D.C., Jan 21, 2025.

site_title: China’s Manus challenges US tech firms in race to build AI agents
summary: China's Manus AI has launched a general AI agent that can perform complex tasks, sparking questions about the US lead in AI. The company claims its product is "truly autonomous" and has raised over $10 million in financing. Manus' agent has performed better on some fronts than OpenAI's Deep Research, but early user reactions have been mixed, with some praising its quality and others criticizing its speed and accuracy. The launch has reignited concerns about the US lead in AI development, particularly in the product category seen as a key investment area.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: AI (Artificial Intelligence) letters and robot hand are placed on computer motherboard in this illustration taken, June 23, 2023. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo
Three of the top five most downloaded free apps are AI bots, with ByteDance’s Doubao joining Tencent and DeepSeek.
AI developers from Alibaba to Baidu have since sped up efforts to advance their large-language models, intensifying competition both at home and with US rivals.

site_title: I’ll have my bots call your bots
summary: Citigroup's recent payment transfer blunders, which nearly sent $6 billion to a wealth account and $81 trillion to another account, have raised questions about human fallibility. The bank has since automated the process and learned from its mistakes, with CEO Jane Fraser acknowledging that some tasks are better left to machines. The article's author suggests that humans should "surrender to our bot overlords" and that technology, such as agentic chatbots, may eventually help with complex tasks, reducing human intervention and errors.

images.alt_text: The incidents highlight Citigroup’s ongoing struggle to improve risk and controls after it was slapped with regulatory penalties and restrictions because of its poor systems.
There were 10 near misses of US$1 billion or more at Citi last year, down from 13 the year before, according to an internal report seen by the FT
As many financial institutions have discovered over the years, an extra zero here or there can make a huge difference.

site_title: Indonesia tells Grab, GoTo to give drivers holiday bonuses
summary: Indonesian President Prabowo Subianto has ordered ride-hailing firms GoTo Group and Grab Holdings to give holiday bonuses to their drivers, aiming to boost consumer spending ahead of the Eid al-Fitr holiday. The bonuses will be calculated based on drivers' work activity and will be disbursed at least seven days before the holiday starts on March 31. This move follows a larger-than-expected minimum wage hike and the rollback of a planned VAT increase, as Prabowo seeks to lift economic growth to 8% during his term.

images.alt_text: The unprofitable firms have held on-and-off talks for years, targeting a combination that would reduce costs and competitive pressure in the region.

VinFast had signed an MOU with Gojek last year to provide an electric vehicle fleet in Indonesia. However, with little progress on the collaboration, VinFast chose to independently launch Xanh SM in the country.
Grab has signed new Memoranda of Understanding (MoUs) with four autonomous technology companies to explore the impact and role of autonomous vehicles (AVs) in Southeast Asia.
The company is acquiring Everrise supermarkets from Navis Capital Partners, giving it 19 stores in the eastern Sarawak state.

Nasdaq-listed Grab’s Q4 profit falls to

HSBC predicts “robust” growth for Grab’s on-demand gross merchandise value at a 14 per cent compound annual growth rate from 2024 to 2026.
Oxford calculated the direct GDP contribution using the sum of Grab’s earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortisation, wages paid to employees, and taxes incurred.

site_title: Gold rush could herald boom for mining stocks, but analysts warn it’s not all glitter
summary: Gold prices continue to rise amid geopolitical risks and economic uncertainties, but analysts warn investors to tread with caution when investing in mining stocks. CNMC Goldmine, a Singapore-listed gold mining company, has seen a 25.6% return in 2024, but its stock is trading at 9.6 times its latest earnings, making it an "attractive stock to dive into at current levels." However, industry watchers note that mining operations are susceptible to weather disruptions and power outages, and companies like Wilton Resources have struggled with mounting operating expenses. Analysts recommend diversifying into mining stocks via mutual funds managed by experienced professionals.

images.alt_text: Processing facilities stand at Freeport McMoRan Inc.'s Grasberg copper and gold mining complex in Papua province, Indonesia, on Wednesday, April 22, 2015. Freeport is the world's largest publicly traded copper producer. Photographer: Dadang Tri/Bloomberg

site_title: Tariff turmoil and the Fed: A stagflation minefield
summary: The Federal Reserve has paused further rate cuts amid fresh risks from US tariffs, which could reignite inflation. The reintroduction of tariffs under President Trump's trade policies has complicated the inflation and growth outlook, and recent surveys indicate early signs of inflation unease. The Fed must balance the risk of cutting rates too soon, which could weaken growth, against keeping them too high, which may weaken employment. The outlook for interest rates remains uncertain, with the Fed likely to wait for clearer signals from economic data.

images.alt_text: The Fed is expected to hold its benchmark interest rate steady in the current 4.25 to 4.5 per cent range at its Mar 18-19 policy meeting.

(FILES) US President Joe Biden meets with US President-elect Donald Trump in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on November 13, 2024. President Trump said on February 7, 2025, he was revoking his predecessor Joe Biden's security clearance, which entitles former presidents to receive sensitive information even after they have left office. "We are immediately revoking Joe Biden's Security Clearances, and stopping his daily Intelligence Briefings," Trump said on his Truth Social network, adding in capitals: "JOE, YOU'RE FIRED." site_title: Philippines' Duterte says he will accept arrest if ICC issues warrant
summary: Former Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte said he is willing to accept arrest if the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a warrant over his "war on drugs" campaign, which resulted in thousands of deaths. Duterte, who is currently in Hong Kong, claimed he did everything for the Filipino people's peace and well-being. The ICC has no comment on the reports, while the Philippine government indicated that Duterte could be handed over if Interpol requests it. Duterte is expected to return to Manila on Tuesday, where he will campaign for his senatorial candidates in upcoming elections.

images.alt_text: Duterte's (R) decision to run for mayor follows a bitter, public falling out with the family of Philippines President Ferdinand Marcos (L) ahead of presidential elections in 2028.

site_title: Why ignoring diversification could cost you in the future
summary: The US market, particularly technology shares, have declined by 12% from their peak this year, while European and Hong Kong/China markets have seen double-digit gains. Complacency from recent double-digit gains in major US equity indices has led to a lack of diversification, leaving investors vulnerable to market fluctuations. A diversified portfolio is essential to minimize risk and participate in global opportunities. Experts warn that ignoring diversification could cost investors in the future, as the broader market trends show a significant gap between the US and other regions.

site_title: Airport strike hits German air travel
summary: A 24-hour strike at German airports, involving over 13 airports, has resulted in thousands of flight cancellations due to a dispute over workers' pay. The Verdi union is demanding an 8% wage increase or $380 more per month, as well as higher bonuses and additional time off. The strike has affected over half a million people, with Frankfurt airport experiencing the most significant disruptions, where 1,050 of 1,116 planned flights were cancelled. Negotiations between the union and employers are set to continue later this month.

images.alt_text: Frankfurt Airport said more than 150,000 passengers would be affected by the walk out.

site_title: SGX teams up with Brazil’s B3 to launch real futures in 2025
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has partnered with Brazil's B3 to launch real futures contracts in 2025, aiming to cater to growing global interest in Brazilian markets and manage currency risks. This move marks SGX's first foray into emerging markets currencies outside Asia. The contracts, expected to receive regulatory approval, will help investors hedge currency risks around-the-clock, particularly in light of increasing trade tensions and geopolitics. Brazil's decision to remove import taxes on essential products also underscores the country's efforts to boost trade and reduce food prices.

site_title: G7’s 50th birthday year sees Trump as party pooper
summary: US President Donald Trump's second term has brought significant geopolitical and economic turbulence, with the US appearing to split from key Western partners, including Canada, the UK, Japan, France, Germany, and Italy, in areas such as trade, climate change, and the Ukraine war. This has led to speculation about a "G6 plus 1" format, with some calling for Russia's re-entry into the G7. The Canadian-led G7 summit, marking its 50th anniversary, is set to begin on March 12, with a focus on stability in the Asia-Pacific region, crises in Haiti and Venezuela, and peace and security in Africa.

images.alt_text: Former Bank of Canada and Bank of England governor Mark Carney is the front-runner to lead Canada’s Liberal Party.

site_title: Tariff and growth worries boost safe-haven yen, Swiss franc
summary: The Japanese yen and Swiss franc strengthened against the US dollar on Monday, driven by concerns over US tariffs and economic slowdown. The yen rose 0.7% to 147.035 per dollar, its strongest in five months, while the Swiss franc reached 0.87635 per dollar, its highest in three months. Investors have reduced their long dollar positions to $15.3 billion, citing fears of a US economic slowdown. The euro also edged higher against the dollar, with European Union finance ministers meeting to discuss funding options for defense spending.

images.alt_text: Both Bitcoin (above) and Ether fell in the midst of a summit of industry leaders at the White House on Friday.

site_title: Crypto slump deepens as macro headwinds offset Trump push
summary: US cryptocurrency prices slumped as macroeconomic headwinds offset President Donald Trump's crypto-friendly policies. Despite Trump's announcement of a US Bitcoin reserve and a summit with industry leaders, investors remained skeptical due to the absence of fresh capital commitments. Market sentiment remained unchanged, with Bitcoin falling 4.5% to $79,334, while other top cryptocurrencies also slid. Analysts attributed the downturn to worsening tariff war tensions and diminishing prospects of Federal Reserve rate cuts, as well as concerns over the Trump administration's handling of the crypto reserve.

images.alt_text: SGX hopes to act as a bridge between regulated financial markets and the freewheeling world of cryptocurrency trading.
Rodney Hood, acting comptroller, says that the new guidance makes clear banks must have risk management in place regardless of technology.
Trump’s campaign pledge to create a strategic Bitcoin reserve was one of many promises designed to appeal to an industry.

Bitcoin fell more than 17 per cent in February, clocking its biggest monthly percentage fall since June 2022 and losing more than a third of its price since topping US$105,000 in early January.

site_title: Tesla suffers worst fall in 4 years on pullback in sales estimates
summary: Tesla's stock plummeted 15% on Monday, extending a 45% decline in 2025, amid concerns over demand for electric cars. Analysts lowered delivery projections, citing a 16% reduction in first-quarter deliveries and a 5% annual drop in 2025. The company's struggles in China, where domestic champion BYD is gaining market share, and Elon Musk's public comments, including on Germany's federal election, are contributing to the decline. Tesla's stock has lost all its gains since Donald Trump's US presidential election in November.

images.alt_text: BYD’s best-selling model this year in China has had its sticker price reduced by between 8 to 18 per cent, depending on the car’s specs.
Some investors have also grown worried that Musk’s foray into politics has become a distraction from his job as the EV giant’s CEO.
Tesla is coming off a tough 2024 in China, when it recorded its first-ever drop in annual shipments from the Shanghai plant since the facility started mass production in 2020.
The company’s executives have said Tesla will return to growth this year despite the first annual sales decline in more than a decade in 2024.

site_title: Low-cost carrier Scoot to focus on South-east Asia, India for more thrust as rivalry causes yields to thin
summary: Scoot, a low-cost carrier of Singapore Airlines Group, plans to focus on South-east Asia and India to drive traffic and revenue, amid a decline in yields due to increased competition. The airline aims to maintain its strong performance in passenger numbers by expanding and optimizing routes. Despite supply chain issues hindering fleet growth and capacity, Scoot expects yields to remain significantly above pre-Covid levels. The airline is also eyeing India, a market with immense outbound potential, and will receive Embraer E2 jets to mitigate delays in Airbus and Boeing deliveries.

images.alt_text: Asia-Pacific is expected to lead the world in air travel growth at 5.1 per cent per year, with South-east Asia and India heading that expansion.
The CAAS will invest S$1 billion in improving connections to other cities and enhancing aviation infrastructure, technology and manpower.
The SIA group carried 29.4 million passengers in the nine months of FY2025, 9.6 per cent higher than the corresponding period of the prior year.

site_title: Japan’s 10-year bond yield hits 16-year high amid weak auction, rate-hike bets
summary: Japan's 10-year bond yield surged to a 16-year high at 1.57% amid weak auction results and bets on additional interest rate hikes. The five-year yield also rose, while benchmark futures slid. The weak auction results, with a low bid-to-cover ratio, contributed to the market's focus on the Bank of Japan's spring wage negotiations, which could lead to more aggressive rate hikes if wage growth is strong. Global uncertainties, including trade tensions and US economic growth concerns, also loom over the market.

images.alt_text: Uchida’s remarks come as BOJ watchers are looking for any hints that the next upward move could come earlier than the consensus view that projects the move will come in the summer.
JGB yields have risen recently on mounting market expectations the BOJ will raise rates again soon and may take borrowing costs higher than initially thought.
The increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes fresh food prices, compared with a median market forecast for a 3.1 per cent gain and followed a 3.0 per cent rise in December.

site_title: The US economy is heading for recession
summary: The US economy is heading for recession due to a combination of factors, including decreased consumer confidence, rising inflation and unemployment expectations, and uncertainty from President Trump's policy agenda. Consumers are struggling with debt and high spending on essentials, while businesses face tariffs, customs rules, and uncertain policymaking, leading to a contraction in sales and employment. Analysts predict a slowdown in the economy, with some forecasting a recession in 2025, and warn of potential financial risks, including a tightening of financial conditions and a possible devaluation of the US dollar.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The exterior of the Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve Board Building is seen in Washington, D.C., U.S., June 14, 2022. REUTERS/Sarah Silbiger/File Photo

With major exchange traded funds (ETFs) tracking stocks, Treasuries and corporate bonds falling an average 2 per cent, the market endured the worst across-asset selloff since October 2023.
Money managers and corporate executives are struggling to cope with the volatility created by Donald Trump’s threatened tariffs.
Lower-income households in the US have been struggling, burdened by dwindling savings, maxed-out credit cards and mounting debt.

site_title: WealthBT: Investment-linked insurance plans costs, myths, and realities
summary: Sales of investment-linked insurance plans (ILPs) in Singapore rose 41% to S$2.25 billion in 2024. The growth is attributed to increasing demand for these plans, which offer a combination of insurance and investment benefits. Experts emphasize the importance of understanding the costs, risks, and realities of ILPs before making an investment decision. The article aims to provide in-depth analysis and practical advice to help individuals make informed choices about ILPs.

images.alt_text: Because of costs, investment-linked insurance plans' returns may be far lower than initially projected.

site_title: Number of Singapore residents living in private condos doubles over last 15 years
summary: Singapore residents have seen a significant shift towards private condominiums and apartments over the past 15 years, with the number of residents living in these properties doubling to 220,756 households in 2024. This increase is driven by upgraders buying into private housing, higher incomes, and shifting preferences. Data from the Singapore Department of Statistics shows that the proportion of residents living in private non-landed homes rose to 16.9% in 2024, while those living in HDB flats decreased to 76.3%. The median income for resident households increased by 78% to S$9,541 a month, contributing to the trend.

images.alt_text: Collective sales of mixed-use developments can be tricky as owners of the various components may have differing views.
An artist's impression of executive condominium project Aurelle of Tampines
Housing developers will now have more flexibility developing large scale projects, with the extension to the critical sales deadline.

site_title:
Singapore Global Trust edge out Team Boss 
on countback for first-round honours
summary: The first leg of the 2025 Business Times Corporate Golf League concluded at Tanah Merah Country Club's Tampines course, with Singapore Global Trust (SGT) emerging as the leader in the Competitive category after edging out Team Boss on countback. SGT's golfers, including Winson Oh, Kenneth Oh, and Joey Chang, scored a total of 107 points. Team Gayatri, led by Casey Tan's individual title with 38 points, finished third. The second leg will be played on March 21, with the eventual champions crowned on May 9.

images.alt_text: HSBC Women's World Championship 2025 winner Lydia Ko (centre, in yellow) together with the Hugo Boss team that's taking part in this year's BT Corporate Golf League.

site_title: Over US$13 billion in solar, wind investment at risk in Vietnam, industry letter says
summary: Vietnam's plans to retroactively change rules on subsidized prices for wind and solar energy could affect over $13 billion of investments, according to a letter from over 20 foreign and Vietnamese investors. The policy change could undermine financial stability and erode confidence in the country as it plans to expand its renewable energy capacity. The investors warned that a permanent revision or end of agreed tariffs could result in equity write-offs of nearly 100% for affected projects, jeopardizing investments. Vietnam's state-owned power utility EVN is already delaying payments or partially paying for electricity generated by renewable projects.

images.alt_text: Vietnam posted a trade deficit of US$1.55 billion in February, after a US$3.02 billion surplus in January, the General Statistics Office said. It was only the third monthly deficit since the start of 2023, as per GSO and London Stock Exchange Group data.

site_title: DFI Retail Group logs 29.7% growth in underlying profit to US$200.6 million, ups dividend
summary: DFI Retail Group reported a 29.7% increase in underlying profit to US$200.6 million for its full year ended Dec 31, 2024, driven by improved performance in its food and convenience sector. However, full-year revenue fell 3.3% to US$8.9 billion. The group declared a final dividend of US$0.07 per share, up from US$0.05 per share in the previous year, and expects underlying profit to be between US$230 million and US$270 million in 2025.

images.alt_text: Like-for-like sales in 7-11 Hong Kong are adversely impacted by reduced cigarette demand, says DFI Retail.
The company’s food division saw its revenue fall marginally to US$1.6 billion
DFI, a multi-format retailer that counts CS Fresh, Giant and Guardian under its brands, also operates 7-Eleven stores in Singapore, Hong Kong, Macau and China’s Guangdong province.
The Giant supermarket at Toa Payoh Lorong 4 is the supermarket brand's ninth closure this year.

site_title: Singapore shares fall as regional markets end mixed; STI drops 0.4%
summary: Singapore shares fell 0.4% on Monday, March 10, as regional markets ended mixed. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped 15.41 points to 3,899.07. Hongkong Land was the biggest decliner, while Frasers Logistics & Commercial Trust was the top gainer. The mixed regional market performance was attributed to the ongoing trade tensions between the US and China, with the Hang Seng index shedding 1.9%.

images.alt_text: Singapore's assets under management grew exponentially from S$25.6 billion in 1991 to S$5.41 trillion as at 2023.

The STI closed lower on Friday, mirroring regional indices.

site_title: Jardine Matheson posts 11.4% drop in underlying profit to US$1.5 billion
summary: Jardine Matheson Holdings reported an 11.4% drop in underlying profit to US$1.5 billion for its full-year 2024, down from US$1.7 billion in the previous period. Revenue fell 0.7% to US$35.8 billion. The group attributed the decline to lower contributions from Hong Kong-listed automotive dealership group Zhongsheng and non-cash impairments. Despite this, resilient performance from Indonesia businesses contributed to about two-thirds of the group's profit. The company also announced a final dividend of US$1.65 per share.

images.alt_text: The rise in Jardine Matheson's underlying profits is due to the reopening of markets post-pandemic, says its executive chairman.

site_title: Foxconn unveils first large language model
summary: Taiwan's Foxconn has unveiled its first large language model, "FoxBrain," trained on 120 Nvidia H100 GPUs and completed in four weeks. Based on Meta's Llama 3.1 architecture, FoxBrain will improve manufacturing and supply chain management. Foxconn, which assembles iPhones for Apple and produces Nvidia's AI servers, aims to leverage the technology for enhanced efficiency and productivity.

images.alt_text: Foxconn is currently in the process of obtaining permits from the municipal government of El Salto to start the construction of the new plant, says Cindy Blanco.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 10)
summary: Singapore residents have doubled their living in private condos over the last 15 years, driven by upgrader buying, higher incomes, and shifting preferences. Over 80% of Singapore's financial sector workforce is comprised of locals, offering the highest median gross incomes. Indonesia's job market is experiencing a crisis, with a 20.2% surge in mass layoffs. Chocolate Finance has suspended instant withdrawals due to high demand. Singapore remains the world's top port for the 12th consecutive year, with FedEx partnering with a Singapore startup to deploy robots for deliveries.

site_title: Meta, Carousell show improvements at combating scams: MHA
summary: Meta and Carousell have shown improvements in combating scams, with reported e-commerce scams on Carousell decreasing by 11% and Facebook Marketplace scams falling by 55% over a six-month assessment period. Carousell's enhanced verification measures, which included verifying user identity against government records, led to the decrease. Meta plans to verify the identities of all Marketplace sellers by end-June 2025, while Carousell will not be required to verify all sellers unless the scam situation worsens.

images.alt_text: Singapore has clamped down on money mules, as they are the main way overseas scammers launder their ill-gotten gains and transfer it out of the city-state, said Sun Xueling, Minister of State for the Ministry of Home Affairs.
Losses from cryptocurrency-related scams surged to 24.3 per cent of total scam losses last year - from about 6.8 per cent in 2023.

Victims of scam centres who were tricked or trafficked into working in Myanmar, stuck in limbo at a compound inside the KK Park, a fraud factory, and a human trafficking hub on the border with Thailand-Myanmar after a multinational crackdown on the compounds run by criminal gangs.

site_title: ServiceNow nears deal to buy AI assistant maker Moveworks
summary: ServiceNow is nearing a deal to acquire AI firm Moveworks for approximately US$3 billion, its largest acquisition to date. Moveworks, which provides AI assistants to handle employee requests, has received backing from investors including Kleiner Perkins and Bain Capital Ventures. The acquisition comes as ServiceNow continues to integrate generative AI features into its products, following a 12% rise in shares over the last 12 months, valuing the company at around US$175 billion.

site_title: Mainland Chinese investors buy record amount of Hong Kong stocks
summary: Mainland Chinese investors purchased a record HK$29.6 billion (S$5.1 billion) worth of Hong Kong stocks on March 10, surpassing the previous record in early 2021. This surge in buying is driven by the emergence of an artificial-intelligence model from startup DeepSeek, considered a game-changer in the industry. Chinese equities in Hong Kong have outperformed the onshore benchmark, with the Hang Seng China Enterprises Index up nearly 20% this year, as mainland investors speculate on favorable policy towards the AI industry.

images.alt_text: The five-year average is a 0.1 per cent discount for Alibaba ADRs.
The Hong Kong Stock Exchange is now seeking market feedback to allocate a maximum of 20 per cent to retail investors in hot IPOs.
BYD plans to use the proceeds to invest in research and development, expand overseas businesses, supplement its working capital, and for general corporate purposes.
Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index on Friday (Feb 28) slumped over 3 per cent, its largest one-day decline since October 2024.
The profit attributable to shareholders of HKEX rose to HK$13.05 billion (S$2.3 billion) last year from HK$11.86 billion in 2023, according to its earnings statement.
The Hang Seng Index jumped 1.2 per cent to as high as 24,076.53 on Wednesday, its highest level since February 2022.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Monday, March 10, 2025
summary: China has implemented retaliatory tariffs on US farm goods, sparking market volatility. Meanwhile, investors are dumping Indonesia stocks as Prabowo, a market influencer, flexes his muscles. Thailand is preparing a 27 billion baht cash handout to stimulate growth. These developments are part of a mixed day for markets in Asia, with Hong Kong and Shanghai being among the lead losers.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong stocks, which have surged 20 per cent this year to a three-year high, lost more than one per cent and Shanghai was off around 0.4 per cent on Monday.
The wealth fund is seen as a key tool to help Prabowo achieve his strategic goals and return Indonesia to the 8 per cent economic growth levels it last posted in the mid-1990s.
Thai Finance Minister Pichai Chunhavajira said the government was targeting export growth of more than 4 per cent this year.

site_title: Singapore Cancer Society raises S$1.1 million to date from Relay For Life 2025
summary: Singapore Cancer Society raised S$1.1 million from Relay For Life 2025, a 25% increase from last year. The event, which featured over 5,000 participants, raised funds for the organization's programs, including cancer screenings, hospice services, and rehabilitation care. The funds will also support caregiver services and financial aid for patients. The organization aims to reduce cancer incidence, increase survivor rates, and promote cancer awareness and prevention.

images.alt_text: Kim Yew managing director Patrick Tan (left) presents a cheque to BT editor Chen Huifen (centre) and TRCL's head of partnership development Elaine Tan.

site_title: Japan auctions emergency rice reserves as prices soar
summary: Japan's government has begun auctioning emergency rice reserves to combat surging prices, nearly doubling over a year due to rice shortages caused by poor harvests and panic-buying. The country has about 1 million tons of rice stockpiled for emergencies, with 150,000 tons to be auctioned off this week. Experts attribute the crisis to factors like climate change, a tourism boom, and inventory hoarding, with the government aiming to relieve hardship for consumers by improving the distribution network.

images.alt_text: The figures come as annual wage negotiations between unions and employers are set to culminate later this week with the initial results of this year’s deals.
The higher cost of food is forcing the Japanese to scrimp and bargain hunt as their purchasing power drops.
The pace of inflation in the capital has been slower than the national trend due in part to education subsidies that are only in effect in Tokyo.
The increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes fresh food prices, compared with a median market forecast for a 3.1 per cent gain and followed a 3.0 per cent rise in December.
The level of fresh food prices has risen 71.9 per cent since 2010, about five times more than that of inflation excluding it.

site_title: Japan's tightening job market pushes more firms under, survey shows
summary: Japan's job market is tightening, leading to a surge in corporate bankruptcy cases. A survey by a think tank predicts 11-year highs in bankruptcy cases due to labor shortages, which are inflicting strain on the economy. The Bank of Japan's past monetary policies have contributed to rising wages and inflation, prompting major firms to offer bumper wage hikes to attract talent. The intensifying labor shortages are expected to continue, with firms likely to offer higher wages to compensate workers and attract talent.

images.alt_text: The figures come as annual wage negotiations between unions and employers are set to culminate later this week with the initial results of this year’s deals.

site_title: Parktown Residence’s sizzling sales: perks and perils of buying into large integrated developments
summary: Parktown Residence, a large integrated development in Tampines, sold 87% of its 1,193 units at an average price of S$2,360 per square foot. This success highlights the demand for large-scale developments, where buyers expect capital appreciation. However, collective sales of mixed-use developments can be challenging due to differing views among owners of various components, potentially leading to conflicts and difficulties in the future. The project's sales demonstrate the allure of integrated developments, but also underscore the complexities involved in such transactions.

images.alt_text: The 99-year leasehold condominium spans 12 blocks.

site_title: Global art market slumps as Chinese auction sales plummet
summary: The global art market experienced a significant slump in 2024, with auction sales falling by 33% to $9.9 billion, the lowest level since 2009. Major art hubs such as New York, London, and Paris saw declines of 29%, 28%, and 21%, respectively. The Chinese market plummeted 63% to $1.8 billion, while the value of Picasso sales dropped to $223 million. Experts attribute the decline to global economic uncertainty, wars, and higher interest rates, with some high-end sellers postponing or cancelling sales.

images.alt_text: Khairulddin Wahab's installation at Art SG.

site_title: Reining in the vassal states
summary: US President Donald Trump's trade policies, including tariffs on vassal states like Mexico and Canada, are sparking concerns about the economy. Despite initial optimism, investors are now in a bearish mood, and consumer confidence is sagging. Trump's focus on deals with Russia and China, rather than traditional trade partners, is seen as a departure from conventional wisdom. The shift in mood reflects growing doubts about the president's ability to deliver on his promises of deregulation and tax cuts, and the impact of his policies on inflation and the global economy.

images.alt_text: The next chapter for oil may entail an outsize focus on macroeconomic data out of the US and China, the world’s largest crude consumers, according to traders and analysts.
Trailer trucks queue to cross into the United States at the Otay Mesa Port of Entry, in Tijuana, Mexico, February 10, 2025. REUTERS/Jorge Duenes
It is typical of personalistic leaders, like Trump, to pit allies (courtiers, really) against each other so that none amasses too much power.

site_title: Renters turn to lottery in Spain's housing crisis
summary: In Spain's housing crisis, 44,000 people participated in a municipal lottery to rent social housing flats, with 63 winners selected. The lottery aims to provide affordable housing, with winners paying up to 30% of their monthly income. However, the shortage of social housing units remains a significant issue, with only 1% of demand met. Rents in Madrid have risen by 82% in the past decade, and the country's housing crisis has sparked protests and calls for government action.

images.alt_text: spain13 - Spain's Most Aggressive Rent Controls To Hit Barcelona. Sunlight hits residential apartments in the Sant Antonio neighborhood of Barcelona, Spain, on Tuesday, June 4, 2019. After seeing housing costs jump by more than 50% in the past five years, officials in Barcelona are moving to introduce Spain's most aggressive rent controls. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

site_title: UK's Deliveroo quits Hong Kong market
summary: Deliveroo is exiting its Hong Kong market after a deal with local competitor foodpanda. The British food delivery firm will close its operations by selling assets and closing others by April 7. Hong Kong represented 5% of Deliveroo's gross transaction value in 2024, with a negative impact on international growth. The decision follows growing competition in the market, including the entry of KeeTa, an app by Chinese e-commerce giant Meituan, in 2023. Deliveroo will sell assets to foodpanda to manage the closure.

images.alt_text: Deliveroo’s Editions site at Alice@Mediapolis in One-North – which spanned over 3,000 square feet – had opened in March 2019 to much fanfare.

site_title: South Korean President Yoon released after January arrest
summary: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol was released from prison after a court decision allowed him to be freed, following his complaints about the validity of his January arrest. Prosecutors have seven days to challenge the decision, but Yoon still faces a trial for his actions in a criminal court. He is awaiting a separate verdict from the Constitutional Court on a parliamentary motion that suspended him from power in December.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: South Korean President Yoon Suk Yeol delivers an address to the nation at the Presidential Office in Seoul, South Korea, December 12, 2024.   The Presidential Office/Handout via REUTERS   ATTENTION EDITORS - THIS IMAGE HAS BEEN SUPPLIED BY A THIRD PARTY/File Photo

site_title: Thailand readies 27 billion baht in new cash handout to spur growth
summary: Thailand's government plans to distribute 27 billion baht (S$1.1 billion) in cash handouts to 2.7 million beneficiaries aged 16-20, worth 10,000 baht each, to boost spending and alleviate household debt burdens. The move aims to push the country's economic growth beyond 3% this year, despite high household debt levels and global trade tensions. The cash handout plan follows previous stimulus efforts and is part of Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's efforts to revive the economy.

images.alt_text: Workers harvesting rice in Thailand using their sickles, before the threshing and winnowing. With climate change, rising sea levels are threatening rice fields and the region’s supply of the grain will come under more pressure.
Thailand aims to have an emissions trading system in full operation by 2030, and is preparing to impose a carbon tax of 200 baht a tonne on oil products.
Piti Disyatat, Bank of Thailand deputy governor says the bank's latest cut is calibrated to be robust to many scenarios, including the escalation of tariffs.

site_title: Xpeng shares jump on plans to make flying cars, humanoid robots
summary: Xpeng shares rose 7.1% after the company's chairman announced plans to mass-produce flying cars and industrial robots by 2026. The stock has nearly doubled this year, outperforming peers in the global electric vehicle market. Strong order momentum for its new battery EV models, driven by competitive pricing and autonomous driving features, has also contributed to the surge. Investors are drawn to high-tech companies, including Xpeng, as part of Hong Kong's artificial intelligence-led equity rally.

site_title: What are fund managers and how can they revive the market via new MAS incentives?
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has set up a review group to revive the Singapore equity market. The group unveiled measures targeting fund managers, including tax exemptions and enhanced concessionary tax rates, as well as a S$5 billion investment initiative called the Equity Market Development Programme (EQDP). The measures aim to attract more fund managers and drive interest in the market. However, experts note that more needs to be done to boost liquidity, particularly in smaller-cap stocks, and improve corporate governance to unlock profitability and value.

images.alt_text: Further details on these proposed tax incentives, introduced last Thursday (Feb 13) as part of the review group’s initial measures to strengthen Singapore’s equities market, will be announced this Friday (Feb 21).
Chee Hong Tat, Minister for Transport, Second Minister for Finance and Deputy Chairman, MAS, delivering a speech at the launch of SIAS Corporate Governance Week 2024 on September 16, 2024
Will MAS review group's plan transform SGX or fall short?
The MAS equities review group previously stated it will continue to study the necessary and complementary measures for an effective disclosure-based regime.

site_title: Warburg Pincus enters South Korea’s senior housing market with SK Group
summary: US private equity firm Warburg Pincus has entered a partnership with South Korea's SK Group to invest in the country's senior housing market, focusing on the Greater Seoul area. The joint venture aims to capitalize on South Korea's aging population and growing demand for senior housing. With over $87 billion in assets under management, Warburg Pincus will partner with SK D&D and D&D Investment to develop and acquire senior housing assets. The partnership is Warburg Pincus' third venture in South Korea and marks a significant entry into the country's senior housing market.

site_title: Reserve Bank of India’s pivot drives investors to bet on gain in Indian bonds
summary: India's 10-year bond yields have declined by about 18 basis points from their January high of 6.87%, with some predicting a drop to 6.4% by June and as low as 6.25% by December. The Reserve Bank of India's pivot to lower interest rates is driving investors to bet on a rally in Indian bonds, with two more debt buying operations planned this month. The decline in yields could help lower borrowing costs for the government and corporate sector, supporting India's infrastructure push amid slowing annual growth.

images.alt_text: The central bank has infused over 4.5 trillion rupees into the banking system since the middle of January.
The Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) intervention was brought on by a build-up in bearish bets against the rupee and the currency’s sharp slide over the past four months.

site_title: AirAsia owner Capital A says US$226 million private placement is ‘done’
summary: Capital A, owner of AirAsia, has completed a US$226 million private placement to raise RM1 billion, aiming to exit PN17 status and maintain its stock exchange listing. The company plans to retain 18% of the resulting AirAsia airline group and non-aviation businesses. AirAsia was founded in 2001 and has become one of Asia's largest budget airline operators. Capital A expects to be profitable in the first quarter and achieve PN17 status by May, which would allow it to sell its AirAsia aviation business to AirAsia X.

images.alt_text: AirAsia is seeking funds to reboot its growth ambitions after years of Covid-induced losses.

AirAsia owner Capital A said it expects to post earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) from continuing operations of between RM500 million and RM600 million this year.
Tony Fernandes predicts a full recovery next year and forecasts that 2026 will be the industry’s “golden year”.

site_title: China-US trade war heats up as Beijing’s tariffs take effect
summary: China has imposed tariffs on US agricultural goods, including chicken, wheat, corn, and cotton, in retaliation for President Donald Trump's latest hike on Chinese imports. The 10-15% tariffs will hurt Trump's voter base while allowing room for a trade deal. China's exports have slowed, with a 2.3% year-on-year growth in the first two months of 2025, and the government's official growth target for the year ahead is set at around 5%, considered ambitious given the economic hurdles.

images.alt_text: ISA Brown chickens in a chicken coop at an egg farm in Mason, Michigan, US, on Monday, March 3, 2025. Egg prices have soared to a record of over $8 a dozen, driven by the worst-ever outbreak of avian flu in the US and contributing to broader inflation pressures. Photographer: Emily Elconin/Bloomberg

site_title: Bank of Singapore appoints Joey Tang as Hong Kong head of investment solutions group
summary: Bank of Singapore has appointed Joey Tang as Hong Kong head of its investment solutions group, effective immediately. Tang brings nearly 30 years of experience in investment banking and private banking, previously holding roles at Bank of China (Hong Kong) and Citigroup Global Markets. He will lead product and solutions strategy, driving innovation to support clients in the Greater China region, and reports to Vivienne Chia and Rickie Chan. The appointment aims to provide personalized wealth management solutions to meet client demand for sophisticated product offerings amid heightened macro uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Since Trump was inaugurated, there has been a flurry of executive orders and policy maneuvers across immigration, defence and trade policies, with heightened risks for economies and companies.
Jacky Ang, the former Southeast Asia chief operating officer (COO) of Credit Suisse, will join Bank of Singapore as the next global COO with effect from Sep 13.

site_title: Asia: Hong Kong, Shanghai lead losers on mixed day for markets
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks declined on Monday, with Hong Kong losing over 1% and Shanghai falling around 0.4%, amidst concerns over China's economy. The mixed Asian market day followed data showing Chinese consumer prices slipped into deflation, and uncertainty over US trade policy, including President Trump's tariff threats, further rattled confidence.

images.alt_text: China's consumer price index declined 0.7 per cent from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said on Sunday, compared with a 0.5 per cent gain in the previous month.
The aura of US economic and market exceptionalism, which dominated for more than a decade, is looking shaky.
Trump’s on-again, off-again tariff policies have rattled investors, triggering a sell-off in technology shares and levels of volatility not seen in years.
Chicken, wheat, corn and cotton from the United States will now be subject to Chinese tariffs.

site_title: Indonesia’s layoff crisis deepens as factories shut; growth hangs in the balance
summary: Indonesia's manufacturing sector is experiencing a deepening crisis, with mass layoffs surging by 20.2% last year, wiping out 78,000 jobs. The sector's decline is attributed to rising costs, cheap imports, and weak government support. The country's 5% growth target for the first quarter now seems uncertain, with economists warning of a deeper crisis of "premature deindustrialisation" that could erode household purchasing power and hit the middle class hardest. The government is racing against time to reignite growth, but the situation is worsened by the looming spectre of US President Donald Trump's potential trade tariffs.

images.alt_text: Indonesia’s President Prabowo Subianto, who also serves as the chairman of the Great Indonesia Movement Party (Gerindra), celebrates the party's 17th anniversary with supporters in Bogor, West Java, on February 15, 2025 (Photo by ADITYA AJI / AFP)

site_title: Chocolate Finance halts instant withdrawals following a run, but customer money not at risk: CEO
summary: Chocolate Finance, a Singapore-based financial services firm, temporarily halted instant withdrawals due to "high demand" and "increased transaction volumes." The company, which manages nearly $1 billion in assets, assured investors that customer money is not at risk. The pause, which affects up to $20,000 per day, is a "matter of managing liquidity" and not a liquidity issue, according to CEO Walter de Oude. The platform's partnership with rewards platform HeyMax was a success for customer acquisition but was unsustainable for the company.

images.alt_text: Entrepreneur Walter de Oude believes every Singaporean has spare cash earning next to nothing. Chocolate Finance steps in as a liquid alternative with higher yields.

site_title: In China, a designer rethinks lingerie for women who have had breast cancer surgery
summary: Chinese designer Emily Yu has patented a foam breast prosthesis that fits into pockets in bras, providing comfort and confidence for women who have undergone mastectomy surgery. Her company, Ginger Ah, offers bras and prostheses in seven sizes and two colors, addressing the gap in the market for post-mastectomy lingerie. Yu's designs also include adjustable bra straps for restricted arm movement and aesthetically pleasing options, aiming to restore women's confidence and beauty post-surgery.

images.alt_text: Want to live a long life? Start by preventing the key causes of death.

site_title: Japan sees fastest base pay gains in 32 years in boost for Bank of Japan
summary: Japan's workers saw their base pay rise by 3.1% in January, the largest advance in 32 years, sending a positive signal to the Bank of Japan as it weighs demand-driven economic growth. Despite slower nominal cash earnings growth and a 1.8% drop in real cash earnings, underlying wage trends remain solid, indicating the BOJ may continue gradual rate increases to sustain growth momentum and normalize policy settings.

images.alt_text: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba stressed the importance of articulating how Japan's investments benefit not only Japan but also contribute to US job creation and economic expansion, as he did during a summit meeting with US President Donald Trump last month.

Striking the right balance between economic efficiency and economic security is “a major policy issue today,” given the emerging trend of reconsidering the value of globalisation and rising protectionism, Atsushi Mimura said.
Japan’s exit from decades of deflation has allowed companies to raise prices to pass on rising costs, which in turn boosts profits to fund more investment.

site_title: Grab inks MOUs with four firms to explore self-driving vehicles’ role in South-east Asia
summary: Grab signed MOUs with four autonomous technology companies to explore the impact and role of autonomous vehicles in South-east Asia. The partnership aims to assess how AVs can improve safety and reduce road accidents, while also evaluating opportunities for drivers and delivery partners to upskill and analyse AVs' cost structure. Grab will work with Autonomous A2Z, Motional, WeRide, and Zelos to pilot delivery and mobility services using shuttles, buses, cars, and bots, with a focus on long-term viability and emerging roles in the autonomous industry.

images.alt_text: Grab added S$5.2 billion to Singapore’s economy in 2023 through its on-demand services such as ride-hailing and delivery, says Oxford Economics.

site_title: UK seeks to scale back reviews that delay new housing projects
summary: Britain's housing ministry plans to scale back lengthy public reviews that delay housing developments, aiming to meet its goal of 1.5 million homes built in the next five years. The review process, which involves over 25 agencies and can result in costly modifications, is blamed for delays and economic weakness. The proposed changes would reduce the number of agencies consulted and instruct local planning authorities to stick to standard rules and deadlines, aiming to speed up construction and address the UK's housing shortage. Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner says the goal is to ensure a "sensible and balanced" system.

images.alt_text: Under Prime Minister Keir Starmer, the Labour-led government has made increasing productivity a key priority as it seeks to repair a hole in its finances amid anaemic growth.
Rachel Reeves’ plan to scrap the preferential tax regime and replace it with a residency scheme has provoked the ire of the ultra-rich.
Morale among consumer-facing UK firms remained at its joint-lowest since August 2022 at -55 in February.

site_title: Investors dump Indonesia stocks as Prabowo flexes market muscles
summary: Indonesia's newly launched sovereign wealth fund, Danantara, has raised concerns among investors due to its potential for political influence and lack of transparency. The fund, which will have an initial capital of $20 billion and eventually $900 billion, has been given a direct reporting line to President Prabowo Subianto. Its control of seven state-owned enterprises, including three major banks, has sent shares tumbling, putting pressure on the already struggling Indonesian stock market. Investors worry about the sustainability of dividend payouts and potential changes in strategy, leading to a risk-off stance until more details are announced.

images.alt_text: The Financial Services Authority and the Indonesia Stock Exchange met with market stakeholders, including blue-chip shareholders, on Monday to discuss strategies for tackling stock market volatility.

site_title: Five things to watch out for in GE2025
summary: Singapore is set to hold its 15th General Election (GE2025) under Prime Minister Lawrence Wong's leadership, with several key factors to watch out for. The election will feature 18 new Group Representation Constituencies (GRCs) and 15 new Single Member Constituencies (SMCs), resulting from population shifts and new housing developments. The ruling People's Action Party (PAP) is expected to defend its 4th generation (4G) leadership team, while opposition parties, including the Workers' Party (WP), are expected to contest GE2025, potentially leading to multi-cornered fights.

images.alt_text: Singapore election 2025: Changes to Singapore’s electoral divisions with more MPs, new GRCs and SMCs
Singapore election 2025: With the formation of the committee, the next General Election (GE) – due by November 2025 – could just be months away.
Singapore election 2025: Forward Singapore, launched by Prime Minister Lawrence Wong, is expected to be a platform in the PAP's campaign.
In Tampines GRC, what used to be a single polling district in Tampines North is now six.

site_title: Local workforce makes up over 80% of Singapore’s financial sector: Alvin Tan
summary: Singapore's financial sector has a predominantly local workforce, with over 80% of its employees being locals, according to Minister of State for Trade and Industry Alvin Tan. The sector, which is home to over 2,500 licensed financial institutions and employs nearly 200,000 workers, added over 25,000 jobs between 2018 and 2023, with locals filling more than 90% of these positions. The government closely monitors the workforce profile and provides support through programs such as the Talent and Leaders in Finance Programme to develop local talent.

The respective bank managements also shared mixed sentiments on their 2025 outlook.
To date, over 10,000 staff have commenced their respective learning roadmaps, including on skills such as artificial intelligence (AI) and data, said DBS.
Market players say that financial services firm are looking more to hire internally, reskilling their employees and using more flexible leadership structures.

site_title: UK pay growth at four-year low as employers brace for tax hit
summary: The UK's pay growth has slowed to its lowest pace in four years, with new hires seeing a 0.5% increase in February, according to a survey. Businesses are bracing for a £26 billion increase in payroll taxes and a higher minimum wage, which are set to take effect in April. This has led to a decline in job postings and hiring activity, with recruiters reporting a slowdown in the labour market. The economic statement due on March 26 is unlikely to provide relief, and the Bank of England may need to pause rate cuts due to ongoing cost pressures.

images.alt_text: Britain’s headline rate of inflation hit a 10-month high of 3 per cent in January and the Bank of England forecasts it will reach 3.7 per cent in the third quarter of this year.
Some economists think the BOE is underestimating the inflation coming in the next few months.
Morale among consumer-facing UK firms remained at its joint-lowest since August 2022 at -55 in February.

site_title: Floods hit eastern Australia, 200,000 properties blacked out
summary: Torrential rain from the remnants of Cyclone Alfred caused widespread flooding in eastern Australia, affecting over 200,000 homes and businesses. The tropical depression dumped 30 cm of rain in 24 hours in Brisbane, leading to flash flooding and river flooding. Emergency services rescued 17 people, and a 61-year-old man lost his life after being swept away by floodwaters. Utility companies were working to restore power, with over 210,000 homes and businesses still blacked out in Queensland. Authorities issued flood and severe weather warnings across a 400-km stretch of coast, with more intense flooding expected.

images.alt_text: More than 1,400 people were affected by flooding following heavy rains, and thousands of homes were damaged in Jakarta, Bogor, Depok, and Bekasi, according to the National Board for Disaster Management (BNPB).

site_title: Singapore launches new standard for methanol bunkering
summary: Singapore has launched a new technical reference for safe and efficient use of methanol as an alternative fuel in bunkering operations. This move aims to facilitate methanol bunkering at scale as the shipping industry explores alternative fuels. Following Singapore's completion of the world's first ship-to-container methanol bunkering operation in July 2023 and a simultaneous methanol bunkering and cargo operation in May 2024, the new standard provides a framework for methanol bunkering. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to promote the use of alternative fuels and solidify its position as the world's largest bunker hub.

site_title: Singapore, Hong Kong face growth risks over US tariff war with China
summary: Singapore and Hong Kong's growth outlook is lowered due to US President Donald Trump's imposition of higher tariffs on China's exports. Singapore's growth is expected to slow to 1.3% and 1.6% in the third and fourth quarters, while Hong Kong's growth outlook is cut to 2.6% and 2.4% for the same periods. Analysts warn of significant downside risks due to rising geopolitical tensions and elevated trade policy uncertainty. The annual outlook for both countries remains at 2.6% and 2%, respectively.

images.alt_text: The Fed is expected to hold its benchmark interest rate steady in the current 4.25 to 4.5 per cent range at its Mar 18-19 policy meeting.
Bitcoin plunged as much as 5.7 per cent after Trump signed an executive order to establish a “Strategic Bitcoin Reserve” without planning any public purchases of the cryptocurrency.
Money managers and corporate executives are struggling to cope with the volatility created by Donald Trump’s threatened tariffs.

site_title: Keppel Infrastructure Fund leads acquisition of subsea cable solutions provider Global Marine Group
summary: Keppel's private investment vehicle, Keppel Infrastructure Fund, has acquired a 100% stake in Global Marine Group, a UK-headquartered subsea cable solutions provider, for an undisclosed sum. Global Marine operates a fleet of six vessels providing maintenance and installation services for the global subsea fibre optic cable network. The acquisition marks Keppel's first investment in its flagship infrastructure fund and is expected to support long-term sustainable growth, driven by a 45% compound annual growth rate in the market for maintenance and installation services.

images.alt_text: Loh Chin Hua, CEO, Keppel
Keppel DC Singapore 7 and 8, located in the Keppel Data Centre Campus at 82 Genting Lane. Basic earnings per share is up 41.9 per cent at S$0.349, from S$0.246 previously.

site_title: Mark Carney wins race to replace Canada’s Trudeau
summary: Former Bank of Canada and Bank of England governor Mark Carney won the leadership race of Canada's ruling Liberal Party, succeeding Justin Trudeau as prime minister. Carney secured 86% of votes cast, beating former finance minister Chrystia Freeland. He will take over at a tumultuous time for Canada, amidst a trade war with the US under President Donald Trump. Carney vowed to revive the party and oversee trade negotiations with Trump, who is threatening additional tariffs that could cripple Canada's export-dependent economy.

images.alt_text: China will apply a 100 per cent tariff to Canadian rapeseed oil, oil cakes and pea imports, and a 25 per cent duty on Canadian aquatic products and pork, the ministry says.

US President Donald Trump signed orders on Thursday to delay fresh levies for Canadian and Mexican imports covered by a North American trade agreement, though he dismissed suggestions that his decisions were linked to market turmoil.
General Motors shares were up 7.2 per cent and Ford gained 5.8 per cent on Wednesday, but both companies’ shares are still down on the year.
“Canada initiated dispute proceedings yesterday against the US at the WTO on the additional tariffs”, following a similar complaint filed by Beijing over fresh US levies on Chinese goods.

Analysts and businesses have warned that the higher import costs could increase prices for US consumers, which may complicate efforts to bring down inflation, one of the issues that got Donald Trump elected.

Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks during a news conference about the US tariffs against Canada in Ottawa, Canada, March 4, 2025. Trudeau said that US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on Canada to destroy the country's economy to make it easier for the US to annex its northern neighbour.

site_title: Gold edges higher on US dollar weakness, safe-haven flows
summary: Gold prices rose 0.1% to $2,914.42 an ounce on Monday, driven by a weaker US dollar and safe-haven flows amid fears of a global trade war. US President Donald Trump declined to predict a recession, despite stock market concerns over his tariff actions on Mexico, Canada, and China. Investors await further clues on the Federal Reserve's interest rate stance, which could impact gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation and political risks.

images.alt_text: Gold bars sit stacked in this arranged photograph at Solar Capital Gold Zrt. in Budapest, Hungary, on Thursday, March 10, 2016. Gold advanced to the highest level in a year after the European Central Bank indicated it wouldnÕt cut interest rates further, boosting the euro and making dollar-denominated bullion less expensive for investors. site_title: China’s retaliatory tariffs on US farm goods take effect Monday
summary: China's retaliatory tariffs on US farm goods took effect on March 10, 2025, with levies as high as 15% on various agricultural commodities. The move shields China's domestic economy from the impact of US tariffs, which doubled to a blanket tariff on all Chinese exports. The tariffs also suspend soybean imports from three US entities and halt purchases of American logs. Chinese officials appear confident in navigating trade tensions with US President Donald Trump.

images.alt_text: Speaking at a press conference on the sidelines of a key political meeting, China's foreign minister Wang Yi warned the “law of the jungle” could take hold in the world if nations were to pursue purely their own interests.
Chinese authorities will need to step in with forceful measures to help the property market bottom out, if Trump tariffs rise significantly, economists say.
China has the world’s largest shipbuilding sector, producing more than half of the merchant vessels globally, while the US industry has been in decline.

site_title: US-based casino group Bally’s proposes funding to Australia’s Star Entertainment
summary: US-based casino group Bally's has proposed a funding deal to Australia's Star Entertainment, offering A$250 million in capital. This funding would come from a capital raise by Bally's and would be matched by Star issuing convertible notes to its existing senior lenders. The proposal aims to stabilize Star's finances and potentially take control of the casino group, which has been embattled.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: How Budget 2025 can shape your investment strategy
summary: Budget 2025 in Singapore aims to alleviate commercial concerns and provide investment opportunities through key measures, including a 50% corporate income tax rebate for companies with local residents, significant funds for innovation, technology, and talent development, and investments in industries like aviation, biotech, and semiconductors. The government also focuses on revitalizing the Singapore stock market and supports the adoption of AI through the Enterprise Compute Initiative.

images.alt_text: Can you manage your finances yourself or is help really needed?
How to get financially prepared for retrenchment.

site_title: Oil prices decline as investors continue to fret over tariff impact
summary: Oil prices fell on Monday as investors fretted over the impact of US import tariffs on global economic growth and fuel demand. Brent crude declined 0.4% to $70.11 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude fell 0.4% to $66.76 a barrel. The decline was attributed to US tariff uncertainty, concerns over US growth, and Opec+ producers increasing output. Despite some recent price recovery, prices are expected to remain volatile, with weekly support around $65-$62 holding firm before a potential recovery back to $72.00.

images.alt_text: The next chapter for oil may entail an outsize focus on macroeconomic data out of the US and China, the world’s largest crude consumers, according to traders and analysts.

site_title: Chemicals, steel firms in Europe squeezed by China, tariff woes
summary: Europe's materials industry is underperforming, with over 65% of companies missing earnings per share (EPS) estimates for the fourth quarter. Weak demand in China, US tariffs, and higher raw materials prices are dragging down the sector. Chemicals and basic resources are particularly vulnerable, with companies like Nestle and Unilever seeing volume slowdowns. However, some construction materials companies, such as Heidelberg Materials, may benefit from infrastructure projects and domestic demand. Expectations for materials companies have been dialled down throughout the season, with Goldman Sachs analysts warning of potential capacity cuts and lower commodities prices.

images.alt_text: A F35 fighter jet of the Royal Netherlands Air Force in Amari, Estonia, Dec 16, 2024. The United States consolidated its position as the world’s top weapons exporter - accounting for 43 per cent of global exports - far ahead of the second largest, France, which accounted for 9.6 per cent.

site_title: Japan credit investors seek shield from M&A risks as deals boom
summary: Japanese corporate bond investors are increasingly seeking protection against potential credit deterioration due to takeover activity, with some issuers seeing yield premiums jump amid takeover bids. Change of Control covenants, which give bondholders rights to redeem debt before maturity in case of significant ownership changes, are becoming more common in the 100 trillion yen Japanese credit market. Industry groups and analysts are calling for the introduction of these clauses to provide reassurance for investors, who may demand higher premiums on bonds of companies with low price-to-earnings and price-to-book ratios.

images.alt_text: The figures come as annual wage negotiations between unions and employers are set to culminate later this week with the initial results of this year’s deals.
Japan’s exit from decades of deflation has allowed companies to raise prices to pass on rising costs, which in turn boosts profits to fund more investment.
The higher cost of food is forcing the Japanese to scrimp and bargain hunt as their purchasing power drops.

site_title: China’s property sector is showing positive changes, minister says
summary: China's housing minister Ni Hong says the real estate market has maintained a positive trend since January and February, stopping declines and returning to stabilization. This comes as policymakers aim to set a more optimistic tone for the economy amidst US trade pressure. Analysts expect home prices to drop further this year but predict a market recovery by 2026. The government plans to provide more financial support to qualified developers and expand urban village renovation efforts to stabilize the market.

images.alt_text: China's consumer price index declined 0.7 per cent from a year earlier, the National Bureau of Statistics said on Sunday, compared with a 0.5 per cent gain in the previous month.

site_title: Black comedy from award-winning ‘Parasite’ director tops North American box office
summary: Oscar-winning director Bong Joon-ho's black comedy "Mickey 17" topped the North American box office with an estimated $19.1 million, despite its $118 million production cost. The film, starring Robert Pattinson and Steven Yeun, takes the lead from Marvel's "Captain America: Brave New World", which earned $8.5 million. The weekend's box office was slow, but analysts say it will rebound.

images.alt_text: Actress Pamela Anderson poses on the red carpet upon arrival at the Bafta British Academy Film Awards in London, Britain, Feb 16, 2025.
Unlike some competitors, Prime Video said its approach combines artificial intelligence with human expertise, as localisation professionals collaborate with AI technology to ensure quality control.

Director Sean Baker accepts the Oscar for Best Picture for "Anora" as producers Samantha Quan, Alex Coco, and Best Actress in a Leading Role winner Mikey Madison look on at the 97th Academy Awards in Los Angeles, California, March 2, 2025.
"Captain America: Brave New World" earned an estimated US$15 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period, just over half of last weekend’s take, industry analyst Exhibitor Relations reported.

site_title: Philippines has priciest property stock on business hub plan
summary: The Philippines' Golden MV Holdings, a cemetery chain, has seen its stock price surge to a record high, trading at 100 times its book value, making it the priciest property stock on the Bloomberg World Real Estate Index. The company's chairman, Manuel Villar Jr., has a net worth of $24 billion, and its Villar City project, a 3,500-hectare estate, is expected to reach ten times the size of New York's Central Park. Analysts question the valuation, citing a speculative multiple and lack of official ratings or earnings estimates.

images.alt_text: Malaysia emerges as this year’s IPO winner in terms of deal number and size, on the back of positive economic indicators and robust investor support.

site_title: How sustainability can modernise rice farming
summary: Thai farmer Khun Thanu has adopted modern tools and techniques, such as drones and direct-seeding machines, to reduce his reliance on chemical inputs and improve water management. As part of Olam Agri's Better Rice Initiative Asia, Thanu has reduced his seed usage per rai from 10 kg to 3.5 kg, increasing his yield to three tonnes per hectare and earning a net profit of 140,000 baht annually. The initiative aims to promote sustainable growth in the rice industry, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and improving soil fertility and productivity.

images.alt_text: Tax professionals can help companies in their sustainability journey
Varaha is an Indian startup that works with smallholder farmers and develops carbon removal projects in Asia using biochar.
By integrating ESG principles into their operations, charities can garner greater stakeholder support, attract new funds and enhance operational efficiency.

In a world now concerned about the fallout from climate change and what it is doing to the environment (the “E”), and how businesses can get on the right side of the laws enacted (the “G”), the “S” or social aspect part of the equation is the forgotten middle child.

site_title: Arsenal held by Manchester United in latest blow to Premier League title bid
summary: Manchester United held Arsenal to a 1-1 draw at Old Trafford, dealing a blow to Arsenal's Premier League title bid. Bruno Fernandes scored the opening goal from a freekick in first-half stoppage time, but Declan Rice equalized for Arsenal in the 74th minute. The draw left United down in 14th and Arsenal 15 points behind Liverpool, who are now just one game away from winning the title.

images.alt_text: Arsenal midfielder Kai Havertz (in red) fights for the ball with Newcastle's Sven Botman in the Carabao Cup semi-final on Feb 5. The two clubs are likely to play at Singapore's National Stadium in July.
