site_title: Stocks to watch: Keppel, Sabana Reit, Hongkong Land
summary: Hongkong Land reported a 44% decline in underlying profit to US$410 million for the fiscal year ended Dec 31, 2024, due to non-cash provisions from its Chinese mainland business. Keppel's private investment vehicle acquired a 100% stake in Global Marine Group, marking its first investment. Sabana Reit's former director, Lin Duanliang, was sentenced to three days' jail for contempt of court. Units of Sabana Reit rose 1.4% and Hongkong Land's counter fell 2.6% following the announcements.

site_title: New Zealand needs to assess risk weights used by banks, ANZ says
summary: New Zealand's ANZ Bank urges the government to reassess the risk weights used by banks to ensure they are not too conservative compared to other nations. ANZ CEO Antonia Watson told a parliament select committee that banks should assess how much prudential risk they want to take compared to allowing more competition. The current risk weights, introduced in 2019, have pushed up borrowing costs and are being progressively imposed over seven years. The move comes as Finance Minister Nicola Willis takes advice on the amount of capital banks hold and follows Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor Adrian Orr's resignation.

images.alt_text: The construction industry has struggled to recover after being impacted in early 2024 by rising costs for both materials and finance.
The interest rate on a one-year fixed-rate home loan is as low as 5.19 per cent at one local bank, down from an average of 7.3 per cent at the start of 2024.
Bank of New Zealand Governor Adrian Orr (pictured) has resigned. Deputy Governor Christian Hawkesby will be the acting governor until March 31, a central bank statement said.

site_title: Family office Royal Group picks Sunset Hospitality to manage hotel off Orchard Road
summary: Royal Group of Companies, a Singapore-based single-family office, has appointed Dubai-based Sunset Hospitality Group (SHG) to manage its upcoming 165-room hotel, Casa Mett, set to open in early 2027. Located at 21 Cuscaden Road, the hotel will feature three F&B concepts and a rooftop pool, with room rates expected to be S$450 to S$500 per night. The hotel is part of a larger redevelopment project, which will also include a 100m-tall, 12,132 sq ft freehold site. This marks SHG's second hotel management in Singapore, following the upcoming Hotel Fort Canning.

Ming Arcade’s owners are represented by Thomas Toh, solicitor of CTLC Law Corporation.

site_title: Mexico president says ‘dialogue prevailed’ in Trump tariff dispute
summary: Mexico's President Claudia Sheinbaum said "dialogue prevailed" in the dispute over US tariffs, with US President Donald Trump offering temporary relief on tariffs imposed on Mexican goods. Sheinbaum credited the agreement with a "very good" relationship between the two leaders, but warned Mexico cannot give up its sovereignty. The decision comes after Trump's initial threat to impose 25% tariffs on imports from Mexico, which would have damaged both economies. Sheinbaum declared herself "optimistic" about the future of the trade relationship.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump signed orders on Thursday to delay fresh levies for Canadian and Mexican imports covered by a North American trade agreement, though he dismissed suggestions that his decisions were linked to market turmoil.
US President Donald Trump’s second act promises a return of the much-dreaded tariffs that put Asean smack in the crosshairs of collateral damage.
Trump’s on-again, off-again tariff policies have rattled investors, triggering a sell-off in technology shares and levels of volatility not seen in years.

site_title: Further downside expected for Philadelphia Semiconductor Index
summary: The Philadelphia Semiconductor Index (SOX) is expected to experience further downside due to various factors, including concerns over China's low-cost artificial intelligence tool DeepSeek, potential semiconductor restrictions on China, and policy changes imposed by the Trump administration. The index has already underperformed the Nasdaq Composite Index, with a 22% decline from its July 2024 peak. Technical indicators also suggest bearish momentum, with the MACD line approaching below zero for the first time since January 2023. Support levels at 4,300 and 3,875 points are expected to be tested.

images.alt_text: The workforce reduction will cost HPE about US$350 million over the next two years, the company says.

site_title: More drone applications in South Asia, greater demand for retirement living in Australia to drive Thakral’s growth
summary: Thakral Corporation, a Singapore-based diversified company, reported a 36% year-on-year increase in revenue to $288.8 million, driven by the growing demand for drones in South Asia and investments in its associate GemLife, a resort living developer targeting retirees in Australia. DJI's drone applications, including environmental monitoring, surveillance, and last-mile delivery, are expected to drive growth for Thakral. The company's net profit more than tripled to $28.8 million, with GemLife contributing $22.5 million. Thakral's CEO, Inderbethal Singh Thakral, attributes the growth to a "smart capital" approach, which allows the company to generate returns without requiring a large balance sheet.

images.alt_text: Thakral's H1 net profit surges to S$8.9m on lifestyle, fragrance product growth

site_title: Tesla is flailing in China and the rapid rise of BYD is to blame
summary: Tesla's electric vehicle sales in China have plummeted for the fifth consecutive month, with shipments declining 49% in February to 30,688 vehicles. This slump is attributed to BYD's rapid rise, which has captured a significant market share, particularly with its affordable and feature-rich models. BYD's best-selling Song Plus has seen its sticker price reduced by 8-18%, making it more competitive with Tesla's offerings. Tesla's sales in other regions, including Germany, have also declined, while its sales in the US have been stable. To regain market share, Tesla may need to recalibrate its pricing strategies and integrate more locally sourced components.

images.alt_text: Some investors have also grown worried that Musk’s foray into politics has become a distraction from his job as the EV giant’s CEO.
Tesla is coming off a tough 2024 in China, when it recorded its first-ever drop in annual shipments from the Shanghai plant since the facility started mass production in 2020.
The company’s executives have said Tesla will return to growth this year despite the first annual sales decline in more than a decade in 2024.

site_title: US markets are trailing the world as aura of America first fades
summary: The US economy and markets are trailing the world as the "aura of America first" fades. The S&P 500 Index has underperformed globally, and the US share of world market capitalization has slipped. The US dollar has weakened, and Treasury yields have tumbled on bets that the economy is stumbling. European markets, particularly Germany's, are gaining momentum, and Asian tech companies are benefiting from the shift. The US economy has become a source of worry, with recession concerns and a weakening dollar. Investors are looking outside US markets, and the Trump bump has turned into a Trump slump.

images.alt_text: Trump’s on-again, off-again tariff policies have rattled investors, triggering a sell-off in technology shares and levels of volatility not seen in years.

site_title: Investor pushes Seven & i to engage with Couche-Tard
summary: A shareholder of Japan's Seven & i Holdings is urging the company to engage more deeply with Alimentation Couche-Tard over its US$47.5 billion buyout offer, citing unanswered questions about potential conflicts of interest and the best path forward for the company. Seven & i has been fending off the approach by pursuing an overhaul to unlock shareholder value, including a new CEO and restructuring. The shareholder, Artisan Partners, has expressed concerns about the company's governance and the lack of transparency in the negotiations.

site_title: More than 1,000 homes sold at 3 launches in one weekend; 93% of Lentor project taken up
summary: Singapore's new condominium launches saw over 1,150 units sold in the first weekend of March, with Lentor Central Residences taking up 93% of its 477 units and Tampines EC Aurelle selling 90% of its 760 units. This marks the highest first-quarter sales since 2021, with more than 3,200 units sold. The strong demand is attributed to fundamentals such as rising wealth and interest rate cuts, but Mogul.sg chief research officer Nicholas Mak warns that this could lead to a "two-speed market" with high-end projects struggling to sell.

site_title: Europe’s dependence on US arms rose in last five years: report
summary: Europe's dependence on US arms has increased over the past five years, with 60% of arms imports coming from the US. The Stockholm International Peace Research Institute found this in a report, coinciding with European Union states' plans to strengthen their defense capabilities in response to a US foreign policy shift. Ukraine became the world's largest arms importer between 2020 and 2024, further highlighting the US's dominant position as the world's top weapons exporter.

images.alt_text: The 21st century brought another shift in the distribution of power, usually described as the rise (or more accurately, the recovery) of Asia.

site_title: CDL shares are a gamble, not an investment
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) is facing uncertainty after its executive chairman, Kwek Leng Beng, accused his son, CEO Sherman Kwek, of a "coup" in February. The company's shares have been slashed by research houses, and its annual general meeting (AGM) on April 23 may provide insight into the rift between the Kwek family members. CDL needs to address governance lapses, clarify roles of Kwek family members and associates, and forge a more aggressive business strategy to unlock shareholder value.

site_title: S-Reits’ DPU may rise in FY2025 as interest costs peak
summary: Analysts expect S-Reits' office rents to rise in FY2025 due to tightening vacancy rates. Despite high financing costs weighing on Singapore-listed real estate investment trusts (S-Reits), interest costs are expected to peak, allowing for a potential rise in distribution per unit (DPU) in FY2025. In the latest reporting season, 19 out of 34 S-Reits posted declines in distributions and 21 reported lower DPU, highlighting the challenges faced by the sector.

site_title: Stoneweg European Reit eyes growth with a new sponsor as property in Europe rebounds in 2024
summary: European commercial property deals rebounded in 2024, with a 11% increase in transaction value to 55.6 billion euros, driven by strong demand and investor confidence. Prime yields shifted inward, particularly in logistics and offices, supporting the recovery. Real estate investors prioritize residential, industrial, and student accommodation for 2025, reflecting sectors with robust fundamentals and growth potential.

site_title: Lack of clarity on Asia’s climate adaptation plans hinders private investment: report
summary: A recent report by the Asia Investor Group on Climate Change (AIGCC) highlights significant gaps in climate adaptation plans among Asian regulators. The report found that investors in the region want clearer policy frameworks and multi-stakeholder partnerships to build climate change resilience. However, existing data and methods to quantify financial implications of physical risks remain nascent. Governments are urged to develop open and granular information platforms, mandate climate disclosure, and integrate interregional aspects into national climate risk assessments. Currently, only Indonesia and China have started outlining action plans and implemented pilot initiatives to facilitate private-sector engagement and funding in adaptation planning.

site_title: UK will slash civil service jobs and use AI to boost efficiency
summary: The UK government, led by Prime Minister Keir Starmer, plans to slash civil service jobs and implement artificial intelligence to boost efficiency. A senior Cabinet minister, Pat McFadden, stated that the central civil service will become smaller, but did not provide a specific number of jobs to be reduced. The Labour government aims to increase digitalization, with 10% of civil servants in digital or data roles within five years, and eliminate tasks where AI can perform better, quicker, and with the same quality.

summary: US President Donald Trump said the economy faces a "period of transition" rather than a recession, despite a 6% decline in the stock market since its peak on Feb 19. Trump's comments align with his administration's argument that tax cuts and future tariff revenue will spur the economy. His on-again, off-again tariff policies have rattled investors, triggering a sell-off in technology shares and record levels of volatility.

site_title: Greenback sags after weaker-than-expected jobs data, Powell’s comments
summary: The US dollar fell to multi-month lows against the euro and yen, and declined against most currencies, after weaker-than-expected jobs data showed the labor market in the US slowed last month. The Federal Reserve is expected to cut interest rates multiple times this year, with the first rate reduction likely in June. Fed Chair Jerome Powell repeated comments that the Fed will wait for clarity on the new Trump administration's policies before cutting rates, citing concerns over inflation and the economy.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Euro currency bills are pictured at the Croatian National Bank in Zagreb, Croatia, May 21, 2019. REUTERS/Antonio Bronic

site_title: US drops bid to make Google sell AI investments in antitrust case
summary: The US Department of Justice dropped a proposal to force Google to sell its investments in AI companies, including Anthropic, as part of an antitrust case. The proposal aimed to address Google's alleged search monopoly, but the DOJ cited concerns about unintended consequences in the evolving AI space. Google will appeal the decision and has made its own proposal to loosen agreements with Apple and others to set Google as the default search engine. A trial on the proposals is scheduled for April.

images.alt_text: Google is still advantaged by its access to current information from content across the web, its shopping data for billions of products.
A federal judge is set to rule on how Google must change its practices following hearings scheduled for next month.
The retrenchment comes in the wake of slower growth from Google’s cloud business, as well as massive spending aimed at supporting the tech giant’s ambitions in AI.
The Digital Markets Act, which came into effect in March 2024, sets out a list of dos and don’ts for digital gatekeepers such as Google as part of the EU’s goal of securing a level playing field.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia’s Kwek Leng Peck raises stake after 35% rise in FY2024 net profit
summary: Hong Leong Asia's executive chairman Kwek Leng Peck raised his stake in the company after a 35.3% rise in FY2024 net profit. The company's FY2024 attributable net profit was S$1.29 billion, driven by strong performances from its powertrain solutions and building materials businesses. Meanwhile, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks, with a net institutional outflow of S$1.23 billion for the year to Feb 28. DBS and OCBC were among the top stocks experiencing net institutional outflows, while Singapore Airlines and ST Engineering led the net institutional inflows.

images.alt_text: Over the five trading sessions from Feb 21 to Feb 27, institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks.

site_title: EU sees no need to de-risk relations with US: Von der Leyen
summary: European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen stated that the EU has no need to de-risk its relationship with the US, despite "decades-old certainties crumbling" in Europe's relations with other countries. Von der Leyen plans to hold regular security meetings to review potential threats, particularly in defense and energy. The EU is also proposing a 800 billion euro security plan, which may boost defense spending in member states. However, Hungary's Prime Minister Viktor Orban has refused to back plans to support Ukraine's military capabilities, highlighting the bloc's challenges in bolstering support for Ukraine.

images.alt_text: President of the European Commission Ursula von der Leyen prepares for the weekly college of commissioners at the EU Commission headquarters in Brussels on March 5, 2025. (Photo by Nicolas TUCAT / AFP)

site_title: China’s inflation declines below zero for first time in 13 months
summary: China's consumer price index declined 0.7% from a year earlier, the first time below zero in 13 months, according to the National Bureau of Statistics. This drop is attributed to seasonal distortions but also highlights persistent deflationary pressures in the economy. Core CPI, excluding food and energy, decreased for the first time since 2021, and factory deflation extended into its 29th month. Experts say China's economy still faces deflationary pressure, with domestic demand remaining weak, and the government aims to bring consumer-price growth to around 2% in 2025.

images.alt_text: China's exports rose just 2.3 per cent year-on-year, customs data showed on Friday, missing 5 per cent growth forecast in a Reuters poll of economists, and slowing from December’s 10.7 per cent increase.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The tanker and dry bulk market saw positive momentum this week, with the Capesize market starting strong and rates in the Pacific surging past $10.00. Despite some midweek volatility, the market ended on a positive note, with the BCI 5TC rising by $2,817 on the day and gaining $3,660 over the week to close at $20,084. The Panamax sector continued to be turbulent, with rates mostly broadside, while the Ultramax/Supramax sector saw a mixed performance. The LNG market continued its positive momentum, with further rate increases across key routes driven by tightening tonnage availability.

images.alt_text: A roundup of the week’s tanker and dry bulk market (Feb 28, 2025).

site_title: Mirrors, marble and mud: Desert X returns to California
summary: The Desert X biennial outdoor art festival has returned to California, featuring 100+ works by artists from around the world. The event, which drew 600,000 visitors in its last edition, showcases installations that reflect the North American desert landscape. Artists such as Jose Davila, Ronald Rael, and Sarah Meyohas have created pieces using marble, 3D-printed mud, and metallic mirrors to explore themes of climate, politics, and the environment. The festival aims to spark conversation and inspire change, with artistic director Neville Wakefield acknowledging the challenges posed by recent tariffs and border tensions.

images.alt_text: Artist Agatha Lee uses organza from discarded wedding dresses to craft a fragile coral reef-like art installation.

site_title: Nasdaq joins exchanges in move to round-the-clock trading
summary: Nasdaq plans to introduce 24-hour trading on its equities exchange, starting in the second half of 2026 pending regulatory approval. The move aims to capitalize on growing global demand for US stocks, particularly from retail investors in different time zones. Nasdaq president Tal Cohen cited heightened interest in US markets but warned of risks associated with increased volatility and higher transaction costs. The plan follows similar moves by other exchanges, including Cboe Global Markets and the New York Stock Exchange, which have also filed applications for extended trading hours.

images.alt_text: A poster of Nvidia's Jensen Huang. Technology is the second worst-performing S&P 500 sector year-to-date with about an 8 per cent loss.
With major exchange traded funds (ETFs) tracking stocks, Treasuries and corporate bonds falling an average 2 per cent, the market endured the worst across-asset selloff since October 2023.
Some investors have also grown worried that Musk’s foray into politics has become a distraction from his job as the EV giant’s CEO.

site_title: Green investors are finding bargains in Trump’s Big Oil era
summary: Green investors are capitalizing on a buyer's market for wind, solar, and battery projects as US President Donald Trump's shift towards fossil fuels boosts Big Oil's plans. Despite a slump in clean-energy stocks, infrastructure investors are snatching up green bargains, citing strong fundamentals for renewable power. Annual wind farm additions in the US are expected to increase by 40% this year, driven by growing demand for low-carbon investments. Experts see this as a "very good opportunity" for investors to make acquisitions at attractive entry prices.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view of the turbines at Orsted's offshore wind farm near Nysted, Denmark, September 4, 2023. REUTERS/Tom Little/File Photo
BP had aimed to cut oil and gas output by 40 per cent by 2030, but was last year reported to have abandoned the target.

site_title: ‘Impossible trinity’ conundrum has caused a cash crunch in Asia
summary: Asia's central banks face a cash crunch due to their efforts to defend currencies against the strong US dollar. The "impossible trinity" concept, which states that countries cannot simultaneously control currencies, set interest rates, and allow free capital movement, is being tested. Rising interbank rates and liquidity shortages could hit the wider economy, discouraging banks from lending and potentially crimping economic growth. Some central banks, such as the Reserve Bank of India, are injecting liquidity into the financial system, while others, like the People's Bank of China, are focusing on currency defense.

images.alt_text: Over the years, Fed policymakers and economists have made a range of suggestions about how to improve the dot plot, which has been published in its current form since well before Powell became chair in 2018.

site_title: Fed chair Powell signals possible tweaks to ‘dot plot’ rate-path forecasts
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell signaled potential changes to the "dot plot" interest-rate projections, which are used to guide monetary policy decisions. The dot plot has been criticized for being a poor predictor of actual Fed rate moves, with past projections often differing significantly from actual rates. Powell mentioned a review of the SEP and comparison with other central banks' approaches, which could lead to tweaks to the dot plot. The review is expected to wrap up by the end of summer, with some suggesting changes to show underlying economic assumptions and alternative scenarios.

images.alt_text: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Sunday, Jan. 12, 2025. The US Treasury market is leading a reset higher in borrowing costs, with potentially wide-ranging consequences. Photographer: Samuel Corum/Bloomberg

site_title: Bankers race to catch up with EU defence goals in stunning reset
summary: European banks are facing pressure to ease lending restrictions on arms manufacturers, amid a surge in defense spending in the region. Unlike the US, where major banks provide billions of dollars in financing to the defense industry, European banks have been hesitant to do so due to environmental, social, and governance (ESG) concerns. Defense industry executives and politicians are calling for regulatory changes to simplify and harmonize ESG definitions, making defense a more "bankable" sector. Several European banks, including Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank, have expressed a willingness to support defense companies, but smaller firms continue to face significant barriers in accessing financing.

images.alt_text: France's President Emmanuel Macron is one of a long line of French leaders to be wary of US pre-eminence in Nato.

site_title: Baidu seeks US$2 billion in bonds exchangeable into Trip.com shares
summary: Baidu raised $2 billion in exchangeable bonds due in 2032, priced at a 43% premium over Trip.com shares, to repay debt and fund general corporate purposes. The bonds, arranged by JPMorgan Chase and others, will be listed on the Frankfurt Stock Exchange. This comes as Baidu seeks to raise cash amid a rally in Chinese stocks, following other companies such as BYD and Trip.com.

images.alt_text: Baidu aims to raise as much as 10 billion yuan in the sale.
The financings come at a time when major industry players on both sides of the Pacific have rolled out artificial intelligence models at a rapid clip, from OpenAI to Alibaba.
Baidu founder Robin Li said in 2020 the deal would “catapult Baidu into a leading platform for live-streaming and diversify our revenue source”.

site_title: Robinhood paying US$29.75 million to end US regulator’s probes
summary: Robinhood Markets agreed to pay US$29.75 million to resolve Financial Industry Regulatory Authority (Finra) probes into supervision and compliance practices. The brokerage will pay a US$26 million civil fine and US$3.75 million in restitution to customers, stemming from violations of anti-money laundering rules and failure to respond to "red flags" of potential misconduct. Finra accused Robinhood of numerous rule violations, including missing suspicious or unauthorized trading and hacking of customer accounts.

images.alt_text: The US Securities and Exchange Commission has moved to ease its crypto-related regulations under Trump’s leadership.
Robinhood intends to roll out the services with guidance from local regulators by late 2025, although it has not yet set a launch date.
Robinhood has global ambitions for 2025, with plans to launch in Asia with a Singapore home base.

site_title: Hedge funds give up half of 2025 gains in ‘challenging’ markets: Goldman Sachs
summary: Hedge funds, which had anticipated significant gains in 2025, have given up around half of their projected earnings due to a tech-driven sell-off, according to a Goldman Sachs note. The sell-off was driven by stock plunges in technology, media, and telecommunications companies, where hedge funds had held long bets. This marks a challenging year for the markets, with the Nasdaq confirming a correction since its peak in December.

images.alt_text: Index rebalancing involves betting on which companies enter or exit various stock indexes, and it can be lucrative for giant multimanager hedge funds such as Millennium.
With major exchange traded funds (ETFs) tracking stocks, Treasuries and corporate bonds falling an average 2 per cent, the market endured the worst across-asset selloff since October 2023.

site_title: Immigration is essential and existential for Singapore’s survival: SM Lee
summary: Senior Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the importance of immigration in Singapore's survival, stating that new arrivals bring "fresh experiences, diverse perspectives, and global connections." He noted that cities like London, New York, and Shanghai became great centers of culture and prosperity by attracting talent and creating an environment of innovation and enterprise. Lee highlighted the need for Singapore to continue attracting and integrating talent to stay relevant and thrive as a regional hub and global node.

images.alt_text: In the past two years, there have been various forms of assistance to support its citizens with immediate cost-of-living concerns, with more help expected at the upcoming Budget, he says
Trends such as offshoring, talent migration, and a widening artificial intelligence (AI) skills gap could erode Singapore’s long-term competitiveness, noted the association.

site_title: Beijing to roll out AI courses for kids to boost sector’s growth
summary: Beijing is introducing AI courses for primary and secondary students in the fall semester, aiming to boost the sector's growth. The courses will provide at least eight hours of AI education per academic year, with schools able to integrate them into existing curriculum. This plan follows the government's pledge to support the application of large-scale AI models and development of new-generation intelligent equipment. The move aims to strengthen China's goal to dominate the AI sector, following a recent breakthrough by startup DeepSeek, which released a model comparable to those made by large US companies with fewer resources.

site_title: Canada markets airports to investors in push to attract capital
summary: Canada is encouraging private investors to support the development of its airports, aiming to boost domestic investment and alleviate economic pressures amid a trade war with the US. The government will consider longer subleases on federal land to attract investors, with a focus on pension funds. Most airports in Canada are run by private authorities with long-term ground leases, and the government seeks to increase investment in the sector to support the country's growing air transportation system.

images.alt_text: “Canada initiated dispute proceedings yesterday against the US at the WTO on the additional tariffs”, following a similar complaint filed by Beijing over fresh US levies on Chinese goods.

Analysts and businesses have warned that the higher import costs could increase prices for US consumers, which may complicate efforts to bring down inflation, one of the issues that got Donald Trump elected.

Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks during a news conference about the US tariffs against Canada in Ottawa, Canada, March 4, 2025. Trudeau said that US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on Canada to destroy the country's economy to make it easier for the US to annex its northern neighbour.
Shipping containers at the Port of Los Angeles. The extra 10% duty on Chinese goods adds to a 10% tariff imposed by President Trump on Feb 4 to punish Beijing over the US fentanyl overdose crisis.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 snaps 10-week winning streak as US tariff uncertainty weighs
summary: Europe's Stoxx 600 index fell 0.5% for the week, snapping a 10-week winning streak, amid US tariff uncertainty and a softer-than-expected US jobs report. US President Donald Trump suspended tariffs on Canada and Mexico, but China imposed a 20% duty on its exports to the US. Luxury stocks declined, while telecommunications led gains. The European Central Bank's interest rate cut and Germany's infrastructure plans also influenced market sentiment, with some indexes showing signs of recovery.

images.alt_text: The Stoxx 600 recovered from a 0.9 per cent decline to close flat at 555.90 points on Thursday.

site_title: China hits back at Canada with fresh agriculture tariffs
summary: China has imposed tariffs on over $2.6 billion worth of Canadian agricultural and food products, including rapeseed oil, aquatic products, and pork, in retaliation against Canada's tariffs on Chinese goods. The move, set to take effect on March 20, aims to warn Canada against aligning too closely with US trade policy. China's delayed response reflects capacity constraints and strategic signalling, with the commerce ministry stretching thin in juggling trade disputes with the US and European Union.

images.alt_text: China's exports rose just 2.3 per cent year-on-year, customs data showed on Friday, missing 5 per cent growth forecast in a Reuters poll of economists, and slowing from December’s 10.7 per cent increase.
Most at risk are China’s fleet of small, independent refiners, largely located in Shandong province, that account for about a fifth of the nation’s processing capacity.

site_title: Microsoft creates in-house AI models it believes rival OpenAI’s
summary: Microsoft has developed in-house AI models, called MAI, that are competitive with industry leaders, including OpenAI. The models have been tested on various tasks and have shown promising results. Microsoft has also incorporated OpenAI's o1 reasoning model into its Copilot products. The company's AI efforts are aimed at reducing its reliance on OpenAI, with which it has a $13 billion partnership. Microsoft is also developing reasoning models and reselling AI models from other companies, providing users with a choice.

images.alt_text: Microsoft’s results in late January underlined both why it has lately failed to excite investors, and also why few are throwing in the towel.
When Microsoft tried to stretch the Skype brand into the workplace, it lost out to Slack Technologies.
The push towards AI comes as videogame development costs continue to rise.
Microsoft’s announcement indicates that its engineers have found a way to deploy the particles that make quantum computing possible in a system.

site_title: The new great game
summary: US President Donald Trump's "America First" focus prioritizes domestic interests, potentially benefiting US consumers but risking strained international relations. The new administration's shift away from globalization and free trade may lead to retaliatory measures from other countries, including China, the EU, and Russia. This could result in increased tensions and trade wars, potentially affecting corporate earnings, financial markets, and individual investors. A diversified portfolio is crucial to navigate the uncertainty, as deglobalization reshapes supply chains and geopolitical gambles test markets.

images.alt_text: Utility construction company workers repair a section of downed power line shortly after a severe storm with gale-force gusts swept through the southeastern part of the country, in Burlington, North Carolina, U.S., March 5, 2025.     REUTERS/Jonathan Drake

site_title: China central bank buys gold for 4th month as prices hit record
summary: China's central bank, the People's Bank of China (PBOC), bought gold for the fourth month in February, increasing its reserves by 0.16 million troy ounces. This move highlights the PBOC's commitment to diversifying its reserves as part of a global trend of central banks investing in gold. The precious metal has set records this year, driven by haven demand and central bank buying, with analysts predicting it could rise to $3,300 an ounce by the end of the year.

site_title: Misfiring Wall Street wealth machine is anxious omen for economy
summary: Wall Street experienced its worst cross-asset selloff since October 2023, with major exchange-traded funds tracking stocks, Treasuries, and corporate bonds falling an average 2% last week. The market downturn, driven by tariffs, softening growth, and a potentially revitalized Europe, has raised concerns about its implications for the US economy. The "wealth effect" suggests that a decline in market wealth could lead to a decrease in consumer spending, which is already slowing due to weak housing and labor market data. Economists warn that a stock market correction of more than 12-15% could derail the economy.

images.alt_text: TYSONS, VA - AUGUST 22: A hiring sign is posted on the exterior of Urban Outfitters at the Tysons Corner Center mall on August 22, 2024 in Tysons, Virginia. According to reports, over 800,000 fewer jobs were created within the U.S. economy than originally reported in the 12-month period, 30% less than the previously reported 2.9 million from April 2023 through March, 2024.   Anna Rose Layden/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Anna Rose Layden / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)

site_title: Trump’s Bitcoin reserve disappoints market, weighs on crypto
summary: US President Donald Trump signed a long-awaited order creating a strategic Bitcoin reserve and an additional stockpile of other digital assets. The move was met with disappointment in the crypto industry, with Bitcoin falling 5.7% and other digital tokens also experiencing declines. Despite praise from crypto executives on social media, the market reaction was largely negative. The order was one of Trump's campaign promises to appeal to the industry.

images.alt_text: Bitcoin plunged as much as 5.7 per cent after Trump signed an executive order to establish a “Strategic Bitcoin Reserve” without planning any public purchases of the cryptocurrency.
The SEC appealed that ruling. While the SEC has wiped clean its slate of many crypto enforcement actions, the Ripple appeal has not yet been dropped.

site_title: Crypto exchange Kraken preparing for IPO in 2026
summary: Kraken, a global cryptocurrency exchange, is preparing to go public in 2026, with plans announced by the company and confirmed by sources. The firm, which has seen significant growth in revenue to $1.5 billion in 2024, aims to pursue public markets as it makes sense for clients, partners, and shareholders. Kraken has had ambitions to go public for years, but regulatory challenges under the Biden administration delayed plans. With a friendlier regulatory climate under President Trump, Kraken is now poised to list on public markets, joining other major crypto companies such as Coinbase and Gemini.

images.alt_text:
Kraken cryptocurrency exchange logo is seen in this illustration taken July 28, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration

(Downloaded from Reuters Connect on Sep 28, 2023)

site_title: Oil’s bearish lurch has speculators betting worse is yet to come
summary: Oil prices have broken out of a months-long slump, reaching a three-year low, as traders grapple with bearish factors. The Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) plans to boost supplies, US President Donald Trump's trade policies threaten demand, and geopolitical risks are cooling. Speculators are betting the slide isn't over, with hedge funds reducing long positions. Morgan Stanley and Goldman Sachs now expect Brent crude to average around $70, down from previous forecasts. The US is preparing to withdraw Chevron's licence to pump and sell Venezuelan crude, and the looming threat of fresh flare-ups in the Israel-Hamas conflict could support prices.

images.alt_text: Brent crude futures settled at US$70.36 a barrel, up 90 US cents, or 1.3 per cent.

site_title: Alibaba’s sudden ADR discount shows fear of US-China decoupling
summary: Alibaba's US shares traded at a 2.1% discount to Hong Kong peers, the widest since 2022, amid US President Donald Trump's push to restrict US investments in China. This divergence follows Trump's directive to tighten scrutiny of pension funds' investments into Chinese stocks. Analysts warn that this could become more common as Trump takes an increasingly hawkish stance towards China, testing the tight link between Chinese shares trading in New York and Hong Kong. The discount is a significant departure from the five-year average of a 0.1% discount.

images.alt_text: Alibaba has pledged to invest more than 380 billion yuan on AI infrastructure such as data centres over the next three years.
AI developers from Alibaba to Baidu have since sped up efforts to advance their large-language models, intensifying competition both at home and with US rivals.
The models are available globally on Alibaba Cloud’s ModelScope and HuggingFace platforms for academic, research and commercial.

site_title: WHO rolls out early retirement to slash costs ahead of planned US exit
summary: The World Health Organization (WHO) is offering voluntary early retirement packages to eligible employees, including four months' pay, to cut costs ahead of the US's planned exit. The program is open to staff 55 or older by June, with a July 15 departure deadline. The move follows the US President Donald Trump's 12-month withdrawal process, which has reduced the WHO's funding by 18%. The agency aims to reduce costs by cutting travel expenditure and halting recruitment.

site_title: Millennium loses US$900 million on strategy roiled by market chaos
summary: Millennium Management, a US hedge fund, has lost approximately $900 million so far this year from two index rebalancing teams, due to market volatility. The teams, led by Glen Scheinberg and Pratik Madhvani, bet on companies entering or exiting stock indexes, but the strategy has been marred by significant losses. This is not the first time the strategy has soured returns, with a decline in 2022. Despite the losses, Millennium's overall performance was down less than 1% for the year to February.

images.alt_text: The expansion comes as Hong Kong gets squeezed by geopolitical spats and China’s economic slowdown.
BlackRock has been on an acquisition spree this year as it looks to become an all-in-one platform for investors by integrating public and private markets.

site_title: Blackstone gets US$8 billion in commitments for property debt fund
summary: Blackstone secured US$8 billion in capital commitments for its new real estate debt fund, Blackstone Real Estate Debt Strategies V. The fund will invest globally using lending, liquid securities, and structured solutions. This move comes as the US commercial property market recovers from the pandemic, with office space leasing showing signs of strength. The fund's manager, Tim Johnson, expressed enthusiasm for the opportunities ahead, citing the investors' support during a period of market dislocation.

site_title: US: Stocks end higher after Powell remarks
summary: US stocks ended higher on Friday after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks reassured investors about the central bank's monetary policy stance. The S&P 500 rose 0.6% to 5,770.20, while the Dow Jones Industrial Average and Nasdaq Composite Index gained 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively. Despite a disappointing jobs report showing a slowdown in job growth, investors were heartened by Powell's calm tone, which led to a rebound from a losing week.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The Wall Street entrance to the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is seen in New York City, U.S., November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: City Law denies having advised claimant in ‘99-to-1’ lawsuit
summary: City Law, a law firm, is being sued by Melvin Li for about S$1.2 million over two "99-to-1" property deals. Li claims the firm advised him that the transactions were legal, but City Law denies this, stating it only assisted with conveyancing and did not advise on the structure or legality of the transactions. The firm also claims that numerous such transactions have been conducted without issue and that banks have granted loans to fund full purchases, making it unreasonable for conveyancing lawyers to advise further. Li is suing City Law, PropNex Realty, and its agent Ian Sng for their alleged wrongful advice and actions.

images.alt_text: PropNex's wholly owned unit PropNex Realty has been named as one of the three co-defendants.

site_title: Oil up, but off highs as Trump warns new Russia sanctions possible
summary: US President Donald Trump has threatened to impose sanctions on Russia if it fails to reach a cease-fire with Ukraine, causing oil prices to rise before retreating from session highs. Brent crude futures settled at $70.36 a barrel, up 1.3%, while West Texas Intermediate (WTI) futures finished at $67.04, up 1.02%. Trump's comments overshadowed other news, including a planned Opec+ oil production increase and US job growth. Oil prices have been volatile due to fluctuating trade policy and geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Brent futures settled up 16 cents, or 0.2 per cent, at US$69.46 a barrel on Thursday.

site_title: Tesla erases US$700 billion ‘Trump bump’ as sales slide globally
summary: Tesla's shares plummeted 4.6% on Friday, erasing their $700 billion post-election gain, as the electric vehicle maker's sales continue to slide globally. The decline follows a series of blows to investor confidence, including a report showing sales dropped for the first time in a decade last quarter. Some investors worry that CEO Elon Musk's foray into politics is a distraction from his job, while others cite concerns over new car sales and valuation. The stock is now trading at 88 times forward earnings, a valuation comparable to the S&P 500 Index.

images.alt_text: Tesla is coming off a tough 2024 in China, when it recorded its first-ever drop in annual shipments from the Shanghai plant since the facility started mass production in 2020.
The company’s executives have said Tesla will return to growth this year despite the first annual sales decline in more than a decade in 2024.

SEATTLE, WASHINGTON - FEBRUARY 22: Demonstrators gather for a protest against Elon Musk and electric car maker Tesla on February 22, 2025 in Seattle, Washington. Hundreds rallied at various entrances to the University Village shopping mall, in addition to the Tesla showroom's storefront at the mall.   David Ryder/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by David Ryder / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
Tesla shares are now by far the biggest decliner among the mega-cap technology stocks, weighing heavily on the group’s overall performance.

site_title: Powell says tariffs could feed inflation, Fed must wait to determine the impact
summary: US Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell stated that tariffs could potentially lead to inflation, but the impact is still uncertain. The Fed is expected to hold its benchmark interest rate steady at 4.25-4.5% at its upcoming policy meeting. Powell emphasized the need to consider the "net effect" of the Trump administration's policies, including tariffs, and longer-term inflation expectations. The Fed will assess the impact of tariffs, regulatory changes, and other policies, and will wait for greater clarity before making any adjustments.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller’s comments come as anxiety over the economic outlook is mounting, as the Trump Administration presses ahead erratically with major tariffs on America’s largest trading partners.

Compared with January, the Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" survey reflected growing anxiety among businesses across most districts about how Donald Trump’s plans to increase import duties and restrict immigration could affect demand and prices.

“The Fed’s job is to monitor and adapt to the conditions, whatever they are,” Chicago Fed President Austan Goolsbee told AFP in an interview, adding that the independent US central bank had made “a lot of progress” on inflation.

site_title: Singaporean charged with US$230 million Bitcoin theft blows US$500,000 a night in clubs; gives designer bags to models, influencers
summary: A Singaporean, Malone Lam, and his US co-accused, Jeandiel Serrano, have been arrested and charged with stealing over 4,100 Bitcoins worth $450 million. Lam, 20, spent up to $500,000 a night at clubs and gave designer bags to models and influencers. The trial is set for October 6, and Lam was seen in a green prison jumpsuit in a Washington court. The case involves a major cryptocurrency theft in the US.

images.alt_text: XRP is the cryptocurrency associated with Ripple Labs, the company run by Brad Garlinghouse.

site_title: Rio Tinto scraps plans to raise up to US$5 billion in share sale
summary: Rio Tinto has scrapped plans to raise up to $5 billion in a share sale, following significant investor pushback. The fundraising, which could have helped pay for its $6.7 billion Arcadium Lithium takeover and rebalance its shareholding between UK and Australian investors, was deemed unnecessary. The company will instead use an existing bridge loan facility to fund the acquisition. Rio Tinto's share register is heavily weighted to London, with about three-quarters of its stock there, and the company has faced calls to unify its dual listing into an Australian-domiciled holding company.

images.alt_text: Rio expects total losses of 13 million metric tonnes of iron ore from tropical cyclones that have hit Australia’s west coast and snarled iron ore shipments so far this year.
Rio Tinto is the world’s second-biggest miner.
Rio would gain access to lithium mines, processing facilities and deposits across four continents to fuel decades of growth, as well as a customer base that includes Tesla, BMW and General Motors.
Any deal would require Rio to win over the Arcadium board and shareholder support.

site_title: Star Entertainment sells Brisbane assets to Hong Kong partners for financial lifeline
summary: Star Entertainment, an Australian casino group, has sold its 50% stake in the Queen's Wharf project in Brisbane to Hong Kong partners Far East Consortium International and Chow Tai Fook Enterprises for A$53 million. The move is a last-minute bailout to avoid voluntary administration, following mounting financial pressures. The complex, developed for A$3.6 billion, will retain its original ownership structure. The sale will provide a financial lifeline to the cash-strapped company, which has suspended its ASX-listed shares due to the failure to publish half-year results.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Sydney's Star Casino complex is seen illuminated at night, February 15, 2016. REUTERS/Jason Reed/File Photo

Chow Tai Fook Enterprises and Far East Consortium, which are joint investors in the company’s Queen’s Wharf precinct in Brisbane, are on the brink of providing a loan worth up to A$50 million (S$42.2 million) to Star, AFR reported.

site_title: Hongkong Land’s underlying profit down 44% at US$410 million for FY2024
summary: Hongkong Land reported an underlying profit of US$410 million for FY2024, down 44% from US$734 million the previous year, and a net loss of US$1.4 billion. Revenue rose to US$2 billion, up from US$1.8 billion, while underlying earnings per share decreased to US$0.1856. The company plans to simplify its business, focusing on ultra-premium mixed-use commercial properties, and expects a partial recovery in underlying profits in 2025.

images.alt_text: HongKong Land, which owns 100 per cent of MCL Land, is seeking to divest the Singapore-based company at a premium to its book value of S$1.1 billion.
Hongkong Land's crown jewel is its Hong Kong Central portfolio.
Hongkong Land says the new business strategy will generate growth in long-term recurring income.

site_title: Sri Lanka signs US$2.5 billion debt deal with Japan
summary: Sri Lanka signed a US$2.5 billion debt deal with Japan, marking the first agreement with a bilateral creditor under a comprehensive debt treatment plan. The deal was facilitated by Japan, which played a "pivotal role" in helping Sri Lanka restructure its debt. The agreement comes as Sri Lanka seeks to recover from a debt crisis that led to a default in 2022 and was later bailed out by the International Monetary Fund. The deal is seen as essential for Sri Lanka's economic recovery, with Japan intending to further contribute to the country's sustainable development.

images.alt_text: This handout photograph taken on September 25, 2024, and released by Sri Lanka's President Office shows the country's newly elected President Anura Kumara Dissanayake, as he addresses the nation in Colombo. Sri Lanka's new president called on September 25, for restarting talks with the IMF "immediately" over a $2.9 billion bailout that threw a lifeline to his bankrupt country but imposed painful austerity. site_title: US consumer borrowing growth slows after near-record surge
summary: US consumer borrowing growth slowed in February after a near-record increase in December, with total credit rising $18.1 billion. This was below the median estimate of $14.9 billion. Stubborn inflation and high borrowing costs continue to affect household finances. Outstanding credit card debt increased $9 billion, while non-revolving credit, such as loans for vehicle purchases, also advanced by a similar amount. The US economy faces a weak backdrop, with rising unemployment and concerns about inflation, leading the Federal Reserve to consider keeping interest rates steady.

images.alt_text: The advance in hiring was led by healthcare, transportation and financial activities.

TYSONS, VA - AUGUST 22: A hiring sign is posted on the exterior of Urban Outfitters at the Tysons Corner Center mall on August 22, 2024 in Tysons, Virginia. According to reports, over 800,000 fewer jobs were created within the U.S. economy than originally reported in the 12-month period, 30% less than the previously reported 2.9 million from April 2023 through March, 2024.   Anna Rose Layden/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by Anna Rose Layden / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The value of imports rose 10 per cent to a record US$401.2 billion, while exports increased 1.2 per cent.

site_title: ECB needs open mind on April cut due to uncertainty, according to Governing Council member
summary: European Central Bank (ECB) Governing Council member Martins Kazaks suggests keeping an open mind for the April interest rate decision due to uncertainty from geopolitical shocks, including a possible ramp-up in European defense spending. Markets have pared bets on further rate cuts, and officials are divided on whether to reduce rates further or pause. Kazaks also notes that the economy has largely behaved as expected, but inflation dynamics are still uncertain, and the ECB has cut rates by 150 basis points already, with more easing possible.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: EU flags flutter in front of European Central Bank (ECB) headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany July 18, 2024. REUTERS/Jana Rodenbusch/File Photo
The breakdown meant some ordinary bank payments, such as wages, pensions and social welfare transfers, have been delayed and could take several hours longer than usual to arrive.
The consensus is that the ECB will take this year’s staff changes in its stride, with markets still very much focused on data rather than personnel as they calibrate their interest-rate bets.

European Central Bank president Christine Lagarde says Europe’s economy will remain frail in the near term, with risks to the outlook still tilted to the downside due to the possibility of greater global trade frictions.

site_title: US regulator clears path for banks to engage in some crypto activities
summary: The US Office of the Comptroller of the Currency (OCC) has cleared the path for national banks to engage in some crypto activities, including crypto-asset custody, stablecoin activities, and participation in distributed ledger networks. The new guidance removes the need for advance permission from regulators and emphasizes the importance of risk management, regardless of technology. This move aims to facilitate banks' participation in the crypto market while ensuring regulatory oversight and controls.

images.alt_text: Trump’s campaign pledge to create a strategic Bitcoin reserve was one of many promises designed to appeal to an industry.
Ether has fallen more than 50 per cent from its high in December.
FILE PHOTO: Representations of cryptocurrencies are seen in this illustration, August 10, 2022. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Wall St opens lower as jobs data disappoints; Powell's remarks awaited
summary: US stocks opened lower on Friday, March 7, after disappointing job growth data in February. The Dow Jones fell 76 points, the S&P 500 dropped 12.5 points, and the Nasdaq Composite declined 39.4 points. Investors await Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell's remarks, which may impact market sentiment. The disappointing job growth data and Powell's comments contributed to the decline, with investors weighing market outlook, tariffs, and sanctions.

site_title: The future of world order
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration has cast serious doubts on the postwar international order, siding with Russia and undermining cooperation on global issues. This shift has troubling implications for world order, potentially allowing Russia to dominate Europe and China to assert itself in Asia. The future of the global trading system and institutions, such as the Paris climate agreement and the World Health Organization, are also at risk. Analysts debate whether the US is entering a period of decline or if the Trump administration's attacks will prove to be a cyclical disruption, with some suggesting the international order may evolve incrementally rather than undergo a clear paradigm shift.

images.alt_text: It is typical of personalistic leaders, like Trump, to pit allies (courtiers, really) against each other so that none amasses too much power.
US President Donald Trump speaks in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on March 3, 2025. (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP)

A press briefing at the White House. The US desperately needs media outlets that take the trouble to discern which Trump pronouncements are backed by dedicated policymaking teams and bureaucracies, with the intent to follow through, and which are not.
So, what is globalisation's future? Long-distance interdependencies will remain a fact of life as long as humans are mobile and equipped with communication and transportation technologies.

US President-elect Donald Trump speaks to members of the media following a meeting with Republican Senators at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Jan. 8, 2025. A faction of Trump's allies is harboring doubts about Republicans' chances of passing a sweeping tax bill in 2025 amid party infighting and strategy disputes. Photographer: Valerie Plesch/Bloomberg

site_title: Family doctors can become specialists to handle complex cases; TCM practitioners will be able to advertise
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 aims to enhance the healthcare sector by introducing specialized family doctors, relaxing advertising rules for allied health professionals and TCM practitioners, and establishing a national register of psychologists. Family doctors with advanced training will be recognized as specialists to handle complex cases, while TCM practitioners will be allowed to advertise their services under specific guidelines. The register of psychologists will focus on those providing direct patient care and high-risk assessments, raising professional standards and safeguarding patient safety.

images.alt_text: From Oct 1, the annual withdrawal limit under the Flexi-MediSave scheme will rise to S$400, from S$300 now.

site_title: Aramco cuts oil prices to Asia as Opec+ eases output curbs
summary: Saudi Aramco cuts oil prices to Asia by 40 US cents a barrel for April, marking the first reduction in three months. The price cut follows Opec+ easing restrictions on production, amid pressure from US President Donald Trump for lower prices. The decision comes as the market is expected to be oversupplied, with Brent futures falling below US$70 a barrel for the first time since October. Saudi Aramco also reduced prices to northwest Europe and the Mediterranean, but held prices steady in the US.

site_title: Hewlett Packard Enterprise plunges most since 2020 on weak profit outlook, job cuts
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) stock plummeted 16% after reporting weak profit outlook, citing tariffs, low server margins, and execution issues. The company also announced plans to cut 3,000 jobs, costing around $350 million over two years. Earnings per share are expected to be $1.70-$1.90, below analyst estimates of $2.12. This is the largest intraday decline for HPE since March 2020.

images.alt_text: Logos of Hewlett-Packard Enterprise (HPE) and HP Inc on building at the tech firm's Alexandra Road office. HPE logo is a green box signifying a window of future opportunities. The old logo with a blue background is retained by HP Inc. The tech giant has just been split globally into the two companies, with HPE selling business IT solutions and services, and HP Inc focusing on PCs and printers.

site_title: Germany's airports to be hit by 24-hour strike on Monday
summary: A 24-hour strike at Germany's airports on Monday, March 10, is expected to affect over 150,000 passengers, with massive restrictions on departures and arrivals, including flight cancellations. The strike, called by trade union Verdi, marks a major escalation in negotiations after previous walk-outs at some airports. Passengers are advised to prepare for disruptions, as nearly all airports in Germany will be impacted.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: An Airbus A320-214 passenger aircraft of Lufthansa airline, takes off from Malaga-Costa del Sol airport, in Malaga, Spain, May 3, 2024. REUTERS/Jon Nazca/File Photo

site_title: Steady hiring with higher joblessness shows US labour softening
summary: US job growth steadied in February with a 151,000 increase in non-farm payrolls, but the unemployment rate rose to 4.1%. The labour market is showing signs of softening, with more people permanently out of work, fewer workers on federal payrolls, and a jump in part-time workers. The mixed report comes as President Trump's policies raise concerns about the broader economy.

images.alt_text: Housing inflation has remained stubbornly high month after month amid a national shortage, becoming a major issue for voters in the recent election.
FILE PHOTO: The Wall Street entrance to the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) is seen in New York City, U.S., November 15, 2022. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Apple says some AI improvements to Siri delayed to 2026
summary: Apple has delayed some AI improvements to its voice assistant Siri until 2026, citing a need to maintain its privacy stance while delivering AI features. The company had previously indicated the features would come in 2025. Apple is building a vast new cloud computing infrastructure to support these features, which include more personalized Siri and the ability to take action within and across apps. Siri fields 1.5 billion user requests per day. The company did not give a reason for the delay.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: Customers walk past an Apple logo inside of an Apple store at Grand Central Station in New York, U.S., August 1, 2018.  REUTERS/Lucas Jackson/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: SGX securities turnover value up 18% yoy in February; STI logs consecutive highs
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) reported a 18% year-over-year increase in securities turnover value to S$29.6 billion in February, with the benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) setting record highs on three consecutive days. This is the STI's second consecutive month of highs, with a 2.7% year-to-date price return and 3.1% total return. SGX commodities also saw a three-month high in total volume, rising 3% year-on-year.

images.alt_text: SGX now offers a total of 18 Singapore Depository Receipts including Ping An, Meituan and Xiaomi
SGX statistics for January 2025 showed records set in ETF assets under management and record demand for Indian rupee futures

site_title: Paving the way for more women leaders
summary: Women remain underrepresented in corporate leadership, with women holding just 8.4% of board seats and 6% of CEO seats globally. Companies with higher gender diversity on their boards are more likely to deliver above-average profitability, but systemic barriers hinder women's advancement. To create conditions for more women leaders, organisations must address the "broken rung" – the disparity in the first step-up from entry-level to manager – and modernise policies to support employees, including flexible work arrangements, extended paid leave, and wellness benefits. A shift in collective mindsets is also needed to celebrate diverse approaches to leadership and move beyond traditional gendered expectations.

images.alt_text: The Council for Board Diversity found that 38 per cent of all 630 SGX-listed companies in 2023 still have no women on their boards.
Breaking the boardroom bias: a case for women in leadership
Created with Artificial Intelligence, Shavonne Wong's Eva can interact with visitors at the Columns Gallery and have conversations on various topics.

site_title: Annual MediSave limit for outpatient scans doubles to S$600; more subsidies for dental care announced
summary: The Singapore government has announced key changes in the country's healthcare and dental care systems. The annual MediSave limit for outpatient scans will double to S$600 from January 2026, making scans more affordable for Singaporeans. The withdrawal cap under the Flexi-MediSave scheme will also rise to S$400 from October 2025. Additionally, subsidies for dental care will be increased, with higher limits for restorative procedures and more preventive care options. The government aims to make healthcare more accessible and affordable for Singaporeans.

images.alt_text: Investigations into the other five providers are ongoing.
Telemedicine regulations remain valid, no review needed despite MaNaDr case: Ong Ye Kung

site_title: ‘Active recovery’ after exercise is supposed to improve performance – but does it really work?
summary: Active recovery, a practice of low-to-moderate intensity exercise after intense workouts, may improve recovery and reduce muscle soreness. Research suggests that 6-10 minutes of light-to-moderate exercise can enhance recovery, regardless of intensity. However, its benefits may be small and not significant in scientific literature. Active recovery appears useful in situations where multiple bouts of exercise occur within a short time frame or when intense exercise is followed by another session within 24 hours. To get the most out of active recovery, aim for 6-10 minutes of easy exercise after intense workouts.

images.alt_text: Exercising with friends or in groups sets one up to get twice the oxytocin boost -- first from the physical activity,  and from the social interaction.
For more experienced athletes, heart rate zone training can help improve speed and endurance.

site_title: Wee Cho Yaw’s heirs get access to his US$10 billion estate in UOB, UOL stakes
summary: Wee Cho Yaw's estate has transferred control of the US$10 billion UOB and US$1.4 billion UOL Group to his heirs, marking one of Singapore's biggest wealth transfers in decades. The transfers, completed over several months, relinquish control of UOB and UOL Group, with Wee's wife, sons, and daughters now owning the family's holding companies. Wee Cho Yaw, the late patriarch of UOB, passed away at 95 in February last year, leaving behind a legacy as a key figure in the bank's growth and expansion.

images.alt_text: Wee Cho Yaw, who played a pivotal role in the growth of UOB, has passed away at the age of 95.
UOB partners an education technology in Indonesia to provide 90,000 children in South-east Asia access to educational resources.

site_title: US job growth picks up in February; unemployment rate rises to 4.1%
summary: US job growth increased by 151,000 jobs in February, following a downwardly revised 125,000 jobs added in January. The unemployment rate rose to 4.1%, surpassing economists' forecasts. Uncertainty over trade policy and deep federal government spending cuts may erode the labor market's resilience in the coming months.

images.alt_text: The value of imports rose 10 per cent to a record US$401.2 billion, while exports increased 1.2 per cent.

site_title: Stock markets, bitcoin down as Trump policies roil markets
summary: US President Donald Trump signed an executive order establishing a "Strategic Bitcoin Reserve" without planned public purchases, causing Bitcoin to plummet 5.7%. Global stock markets, including European and Asian equities, fell due to uncertainty over Trump's trade policies, including delayed tariffs on Canadian and Mexican goods. The US dollar retreated, while the euro gained support due to inflation concerns and potential interest rate cuts from the European Central Bank. Investors remain cautious amid ongoing tariff threats and economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: Ether has fallen more than 50 per cent from its high in December.
Japan’s Nikkei index dropped more than 1.5 per cent at the open while shares in South Korea and Australia also fell more than one per cent on Friday.

site_title: New playbook, online tool to help Singapore SMEs adopt AI; SkillsFuture scheme to be updated with AI content
summary: Singapore has launched the GenAI Playbook and GenAI Navigator to guide companies in adopting artificial intelligence solutions, making AI adoption more accessible to enterprises across different stages of digital maturity. The GenAI Playbook provides guidelines and case studies, while the GenAI Navigator recommends pre-approved solutions for small and medium-sized enterprises. The tools are available on the Infocomm Media Development Authority's platform. Additionally, the SkillsFuture for Digital Workplace 2.0 programme will be updated with AI and GenAI content to strengthen workers' AI capabilities.

images.alt_text: Budget 2025: Enhancing our Technology and Innovation Engines. More investment will go to developing "bilingual" scientific talent: researchers with expertise in both AI and domain knowledge.
DPM Gan also gave details of the S$1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund, which PM Wong had said would provide “more financing options for high-growth local enterprises”.

site_title: Hyundai Ioniq 9 review: Long range rover
summary: Hyundai's Ioniq 9, its flagship electric SUV, boasts a 110.3 kWh battery and offers various drivetrain configurations, including Long Range rear-wheel drive and all-wheel drive. The Performance AWD model accelerates to 100 km/h in 5.2 seconds. With its smooth lines, sculpted aerodynamics, and advanced features like Level 2 autonomy, the Ioniq 9 provides a luxurious and comfortable ride. The car's spacious cabin, massive boot, and frunk also make it an ideal choice for long-haul trips. With a starting price estimated at around S$370,000, the Ioniq 9 aims to challenge the premium electric vehicle market in Singapore.

images.alt_text: The Utopia Roadster made its South-east Asian debut on Feb 27 at ONE°15 Marina Sentosa Cove.
The Jaecoo J6's twin-motor set-up delivers 279 hp and 385 Nm, enough to give it seriously punchy acceleration.

site_title: RWS, Art:Dis make a splash for SEA Aquarium’s 12th anniversary with art exhibit, workshops
summary: SEA Aquarium is celebrating its 12th anniversary with a series of exhibits and workshops, including a vibrant artwork series "Evolving Oceans: A Symphony of Life" created by artist Eugene Soh, who is a person with disabilities. The collaboration with Art:Dis aims to promote marine education, conservation, and appreciation, while also providing a platform for artists with disabilities. The aquarium has also set up specially curated zones, including the Wall of Fame, Treasures of Curios, and Marine Mirage, and is hosting marine-themed art workshops. The partnership is part of the broader RWS Cares programme, which focuses on climate change, education, and support for local enterprises.

images.alt_text: Wong's style evolved from geometric drawings and dot paintings to her current paper-cutting style.
Chefs setting up the 88-m-long stollen on Wednesday.

site_title: UK house prices dip in February, demand slows
summary: UK house prices unexpectedly fell by 0.1% in February, reversing a 0.6% rise in January, and were below economists' forecast of a 3.1% annual increase. Prices remain 2.9% higher in annual terms, the same as January. The slowdown is attributed to a decline in demand from buyers rushing to purchase homes before tax incentives expired on March 31.

images.alt_text: Houses under construction at Whitstable Heights, a new housing development in Whitstable, UK, on Wednesday, July 31, 2024. Deputy Prime Minister Angela Rayner said the UK’s new government will make it easier for councils to build on the green belt and restore mandatory local housing targets as she fleshed out Labour’s plans aimed at delivering 300,000 new homes a year this Parliament. Photographer: Chris J. Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

site_title: US firm Western Digital’s new Singapore CEO sees AI driving a ‘massive opportunity’ for hard-disk drives
summary: Western Digital's new CEO, Irving Tan, sees artificial intelligence driving a "massive opportunity" for the company's hard-disk drive business. Following the separation of its flash business, Tan believes AI's impact on industries and data generation will lead to increased hard-disk drive shipments. The company, with a "deep legacy" in hard-disk drive technology, aims to collaborate with customers and partners to meet their needs. Western Digital's Singapore office is currently growing in staff numbers, with a focus on expanding talent and capabilities in engineering and innovation.

images.alt_text: Budget 2025 moves AI beyond the realm of research and pilot projects into everyday impact across businesses and industries
South-east Asia’s second-largest economy expects overall investment applications to reach 800 billion baht for 2024.

site_title: South Korea court cancels President Yoon's arrest warrant
summary: South Korea's Seoul Central District Court cancelled President Yoon Suk Yeol's arrest warrant on Friday, March 7, citing the timing of the indictment after the initial detention period had expired. The court noted "questions about the legality" of the investigation process involving two separate agencies. Yoon's lawyers said the ruling showed the country's rule of law is still alive, but he may not be immediately released as prosecutors can appeal. The decision paves the way for Yoon's potential release from jail following his arrest in mid-January on insurrection charges related to a brief martial law imposition.

images.alt_text: An effigy of impeached South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol is seen behind bars during a rally against Yoon near his residence in Seoul on January 5, 2025.
