An effigy of suspended President Yoon Suk-yeol during a protest against him; Yoon plunged the country into political chaos on Dec 3 with the bungled martial law declaration and has since holed up in his residence, surrounded by hundreds of security officers resisting arrest efforts.

site_title: Swedish home prices stage recovery after central bank rate cuts
summary: Sweden's home prices have staged a recovery, with the average price of apartments increasing by 5% and detached houses by 3.1% compared to a year ago, according to data published by Svensk Maklarstatistik. The Riksbank's rate cuts, totaling 175 basis points, have benefited homeowners with mortgages tied to short-term rates. The number of homes sold also increased, with 4,200 detached houses and 9,300 apartments sold in February, a 13% and 3% increase, respectively, compared to the previous year.

site_title: HI Mobility’s yellow smiling buses hit the road to a RM116 million IPO
summary: HI Mobility, Malaysia's only bus operator serving the Johor-Singapore border, is set to raise RM116 million in an initial public offering (IPO) to expand its fleet and adopt electric buses. The company, founded by Lim Han Weng in 1994, will debut on Bursa Malaysia's Main Market on March 28 with a valuation of around RM610 million. The IPO will be used to strengthen the company's core competencies, including expanding its fleet, replacing aging buses, and transitioning to electric buses. About 60.4% of the funds raised will go towards expanding the fleet, with the goal of increasing electric bus adoption and reducing operational costs.

images.alt_text: Sunway Group founder Jeffrey Cheah and Malaysia's Transport Minister Anthony Loke (second and third standing from left) witnessed the signing of the partnership agreement between Sunway Property CEO Chong Sau Min (second from left) and MRT Corp CEO Mohd Zarif Hashim (third from left).
Closer Johor-Singapore ties could mean more residents here relocating to Johor Bahru.
Numerous project launches surrounding the upcoming RTS station are in the pipeline.
Malaysia's Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said: "The real potential of Johor and Singapore can only be unlocked if we address the bottlenecks hindering seamless movement."

site_title: Singapore considers cybersecurity requirements for vendors with access to sensitive government data
summary: Singapore's Cyber Security Agency (CSA) is assessing the need for enhanced cybersecurity measures for vendors with access to sensitive government data or systems. These vendors may be required to obtain Cyber Essentials or Cyber Trust marks before being licensed to bid for government contracts. The government aims to raise national cybersecurity standards and protect higher-risk organizations. The Cyber Essentials mark will be updated to cover cloud and artificial intelligence security in the first half of 2025.

images.alt_text: DPM Gan also gave details of the S$1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund, which PM Wong had said would provide “more financing options for high-growth local enterprises”.

site_title: Prabowo hosts Indonesian billionaires to discuss key programmes
summary: President Prabowo Subianto hosted eight Indonesian billionaires to discuss his key programmes, including providing free meals to schoolchildren, building infrastructure, and developing a sovereign wealth fund. The meeting aimed to strengthen collaboration between the government and private sector. Prabowo is seeking funding for his programmes, as state revenue is impacted by the cancellation of a value-added tax hike. The meeting follows spending cuts and a commitment from Bank Indonesia to help fund his public housing programme.

site_title: Australia PM Albanese signals election to come in May
summary: Australian Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has ruled out calling an election before May, pushing the vote to May 3, 10, or 17. The decision comes as Cyclone Alfred approaches, and Albanese stated his focus is on helping Australians during this time. The original election date was set for April 12, but due to holidays and other factors, a May election is now unavoidable, with the Labor government expected to hand down a national budget on March 25.

images.alt_text: The Australian Bureau of Statistics’ monthly household spending indicator (MHSI) showed a seasonally adjusted rise of 0.4 per cent in January from December, when it rose by 0.2 per cent.

site_title: Gold eases but eyes weekly gain; US payrolls data on tap
summary: Gold eased 0.2% to $2,904.98 an ounce, but is on track for a weekly gain due to uncertainty around US President Donald Trump's tariff plans and anticipation of US non-farm payrolls data. Investors await the data, which is expected to show a gain of 160,000 jobs, and the ongoing trade tensions, inflation uncertainty, and a weaker dollar are seen as bullish for gold. Despite higher interest rates dampening its appeal, gold has gained 1.6% so far this week.

images.alt_text: Silver bars are stacked in the safe deposit boxes room of the Pro Aurum gold house in Munich, Germany, January 10, 2025. REUTERS/Angelika Warmuth
Gold is seen as a hedge against political risks and inflation but higher interest rates dampen the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: Singapore shares end lower on Friday; STI edges down 0.1%
summary: Singapore shares declined 0.1% on Friday, mirroring regional indices, as growth concerns persist. The Straits Times Index (STI) ended at 3,914.48, with decliners outnumbering advancers 287 to 247. The top loser was Hongkong Land, while UOL was the top gainer. IG market strategist Yeap Jun Rong noted that a stronger catalyst is needed for a sustained turnaround, citing concerns over consumer spending and trade uncertainties.

images.alt_text: The bourse operator announced several changes to its foreign exchange (FX) and technology management teams on Thursday, including two resignations.

site_title: Singapore’s tripartite workgroup on senior employment to form Alliance for Action for multi-stage careers
summary: Singapore's Tripartite Workgroup on Senior Employment will form an Alliance for Action to empower multi-stage careers for mature workers, promoting age-friendly jobs and workplaces. The workgroup, co-chaired by Senior Minister of State for Manpower Koh Poh Koon, will study policy recommendations and collaborate with employers to create practical solutions. The Alliance for Action will engage stakeholders to understand key changes needed to improve senior employment, with funding and consultancy support.

images.alt_text: Finance Minister Lawrence Wong notes that more seniors are staying employed as the population ages.
Minister for Manpower Tan See Leng says the government is working with insurance companies and hospitals to manage the gradient of any healthcare cost increases.
Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong has said that training, skills and jobs will be a major theme of Budget 2025.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, March 7, 2025
summary: Asian markets fell on Friday as US President Trump backed off on Mexico and Canada tariffs following market backlash. Bitcoin tumbled after an executive order for a Bitcoin reserve disappointed investors. Meanwhile, Saudi's sovereign wealth fund is set to invest $100 million in AirAsia, boosting ties to the region. These events contributed to a market downturn, with stocks and bitcoin experiencing significant losses.

images.alt_text: Japan’s Nikkei index dropped more than 1.5 per cent at the open while shares in South Korea and Australia also fell more than one per cent on Friday.

US President Donald Trump signed orders on Thursday to delay fresh levies for Canadian and Mexican imports covered by a North American trade agreement, though he dismissed suggestions that his decisions were linked to market turmoil.
AirAsia is seeking funds to reboot its growth ambitions after years of Covid-induced losses.

site_title:
Singapore clarifies rules for real estate agents 
in anti-money laundering Bill
summary: Singapore has introduced a Bill to amend the Estate Agents Act, requiring licensed estate agents to conduct counterparty due diligence measures to detect money laundering, proliferation financing, and terrorism financing. The proposed amendments, made in response to the Financial Action Task Force's recommendations, aim to strengthen the real estate industry's anti-money laundering efforts. The Bill, tabled in Parliament, will also provide support to gatekeepers and engage non-regulated sectors to raise awareness of money laundering risks.

site_title: Europe’s football giants set for friendly matches in Singapore, Malaysia, Hong Kong
summary: European football giants such as Manchester United, Liverpool, and AC Milan are set to play friendly matches in Singapore, Malaysia, and Hong Kong this summer. Arsenal and Newcastle United are also expected to visit Singapore, while Liverpool may play in Hong Kong and potentially in Japan. The matches, which could take place in late May and early August, are part of the teams' pre-season tours. Barcelona is also rumored to play up to four friendlies in Asia, with two in Japan and two in South Korea.

site_title: China will ‘firmly counter’ US trade pressure: top diplomat
summary: China's foreign minister Wang Yi vowed to "firmly counter" US trade pressure, warning that pursuing purely national interests could lead to a "law of the jungle" in the world. This comes after US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on Chinese goods, sparking a trade war between the two economies. Wang emphasized Beijing's cooperation in the US fight against the fentanyl epidemic and urged Washington to reciprocate with kindness rather than resentment. The warning suggests China is prepared to defend its interests against US pressure.

site_title: Workers must perform job-search activities for payouts in Singapore’s re-employment support scheme
summary: Singapore's re-employment support scheme will require retrenched workers to perform job-search activities to receive payouts. The activities include going for training, career coaching, and job matching, "carefully curated" based on research with jobseekers. Payouts will be made over six months, starting at S$1,500 in the first month and tapering down to S$750 per month for the last three. The scheme aims to support workers in finding new employment.

images.alt_text: Associate Professor Walter Theseira, a labour economist from the Singapore University of Social Sciences, said: “The scheme by quantum is targeted more at lower income workers, as the payout amounts are quite low by international standards for replacement-income type schemes for middle income workers.”

One suggestion is for structured transition support to help older workers remain employed.

site_title: Japanese barber, 108, crowned world's oldest
summary: A 108-year-old Japanese woman, Shitsui Hakoishi, has been certified as the world's oldest barber by Guinness World Records. Born in 1916, Hakoishi became a barber at 14 after an apprenticeship and has continued to work, even after her husband's death and a devastating war. Despite living in a care home, she remains able to look after herself and plans to work until at least 110 years old. Her record supersedes that of the oldest male barber, Anthony Mancinelli, who passed away at 107.

images.alt_text: Artist Lim Tze Peng at his house and studio in Telok Kurau in October 2024. He was hospitalised for pneumonia in January and died on Feb 3.

site_title: How Trump’s ‘Liberation Day’ tariffs could upend South-east Asian trade – in 7 charts
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to unveil reciprocal tariffs on April 2, potentially upending trade in South-east Asia. The tariffs, targeting North America, hint at the economic fallout on the region. Asean currencies are at risk, with some countries like Vietnam and Indonesia experiencing a surge in business missions from US firms seeking to capitalize on the tariff turmoil. Analysts warn that Trump's tariffs could sideline South-east Asia's economic aspirations, while others predict a rebound in GoTo shares after a significant sell-off. The region braces for potential economic fallout from Trump's tariff decisions.

site_title: ‘Firing on multiple cylinders’: Analysts hike target prices for Sea by 10-39%
summary: Analysts have increased their target prices for Sea by 10-39% after the company reported a Q4 net profit of US$237.6 million, reversing a loss in the same period last year. The strong performance was driven by its e-commerce arm Shopee, with analysts citing "stellar" delivery and "attractive valuations." Sea's guidance for higher 2025 growth and profitability for Shopee has also boosted expectations, with analysts predicting 20% GMV growth and improving profitability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A person stands in front of a signage of Southeast Asian e-commerce and gaming group Sea Ltd's, at their office in Singapore March 5, 2021. REUTERS/Edgar Su/File Photo
Sea's e-commerce arm Shopee beat its original guidance for the full year.

site_title: Leong Mun Wai’s affordable housing plan a step back from ‘social compact’; HDB flats now a store of value: Desmond Lee
summary: Singapore's proposed affordable housing scheme by the Progress Singapore Party (PSP) is deemed a step back from the country's "strong social compact" on housing, according to Minister for National Development Desmond Lee. The scheme would price flats based on construction costs, not land costs, allowing for potential appreciation in resale value. Lee argued that the current public housing market is different from the 1979 model, with modern amenities and better transport connectivity, and that HDB flats have become a store of value for Singaporeans, enabling them to monetize their value in retirement.

images.alt_text: Housing developers will now have more flexibility developing large scale projects, with the extension to the critical sales deadline.
The new Mount Pleasant housing estate will see 5,000 new homes across six Build-to-Order projects.
The Senior Housing Bonus scheme, which incentivises seniors to downsize to a smaller flat, will be extended to inlcude more private property owners.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei ends at 6-month low as tech shares fall, stronger yen weighs
summary: Japan's Nikkei index closed at a 6-month low of 36,887.17, down 2.17% from its previous close, as technology stocks declined and a stronger yen weighed on exporters. The broader Topix also fell 1.56%. The decline follows overnight Wall Street losses, with the Nasdaq confirming a correction since December due to US trade policy uncertainty. The yen's strength hurt shares of exporters, including Toyota and Honda, while a stronger currency and renewed expectations of Bank of Japan interest hikes contributed to the market's decline.

images.alt_text: Japan’s Nikkei index dropped more than 1.5 per cent at the open while shares in South Korea and Australia also fell more than one per cent on Friday.

site_title: Issue 138: Singapore’s green transformation commitment; carbon capture gets a boost
summary: Singapore reaffirms its commitment to a green economy, with Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean stating that the country's climate goals are "an investment in long-term survival and growth". The government aims to achieve net zero emissions by 2050, despite the high physical risk of climate change. Singapore is also investing in carbon capture technology, with a S$300 million pilot project planned over five years. The country's green transformation is seen as a long-term strategy, with a focus on building climate resilience and driving sustainable consumption and investment decisions.

images.alt_text: Marco Polo Marine was looking to pivot into the renewable energy sector, but a vessel charter from a Taiwanese company helped guide the way, said Marco Polo Marine CEO, Sean Lee.
Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme is for registrations of electric heavy vehicles with a maximum laden weight of more than 3,500 kilogrammes.
BYD’s entrance in July into Vietnam underscores both the opportunities and challenges Chinese companies face as they seek to push into South-east Asia.
Thailand aims to have an emissions trading system in full operation by 2030, and is preparing to impose a carbon tax of 200 baht a tonne on oil products.
Construction of clean energy bases in the nation’s deserts will be accelerated, and more will be done to integrate renewables into local grids.

site_title: Apple gets local content certificates in Indonesia, still needs more permits
summary: Apple has received local content certificates in Indonesia for 20 products, including the iPhone 16, following a $300 million investment announcement last month. The company still needs permits from the communications and digital ministry and the trade ministry to sell the products. The certificates were issued after Indonesia banned iPhone 16 sales last year due to Apple's failure to meet requirements on locally-made components.

images.alt_text: Apple has been in discussions with the government over an investment package that would lift the restrictions.

site_title: Life after work: Preparing for a rewarding retirement
summary: A DBS research report suggests a comfortable retirement nest egg of between S$550,000 and S$1.3 million is an appropriate target to meet. This range assumes a 20-year drawdown from age 65, with CPF annuity payouts, CPF savings, and other income sources supplementing the nest egg. The report found that retirees with conservative spending habits need at least S$550,000, while those with more aspirational lifestyles require S$1.3 million. Building multiple passive income flows, leveraging CPF savings, and investing in a diversified portfolio can help achieve retirement goals.

images.alt_text: The "true'' golden years are likely the period of maximum potential enjoyment, because it includes a good mix of health and wealth.
Retiring comfortably is within everyone's reach but we have to take the first step to make retirement planning a priority.

site_title: Singapore’s renewable fuel exports to US might be at risk
summary: Singapore's exports of sustainable aviation fuel and renewable diesel to the US may be at risk due to a change in US regulations. The transition from Blenders Tax Credit to Clean Fuel Production Credit affects these products and may impact Neste's refinery in Singapore, which has a significant production capacity. The US Treasury restricts the use of imported used cooking oil as a feedstock, creating a challenging landscape for US importers. Neste has not confirmed its export levels to the US, but the company is formulating responses based on different scenarios.

images.alt_text: Neste produces renewable fuels, mainly from waste and residues such as used cooking oil and animal fat from food industry waste.

site_title: Average of 2,680 non-resident workers retrenched each year from 2021 to 2023 in Singapore
summary: Singapore saw an average of 2,680 non-resident workers retrenched each year between 2021 and 2023, with total figures reaching 8,020 in 2021, 6,440 in 2022, and 14,590 in 2023. About 90% of affected workers received a retrenchment benefit. The Ministry of Manpower collects data on retrenched employees based on residential status, not work pass type. Employers are expected to conduct retrenchment responsibly and sensitively under the Tripartite Advisory for Managing Excess Manpower and Responsible Retrenchment.

images.alt_text: From tech to retail, media and finance, major companies are starting to shed employees as they undergo restructuring and adapt to changing market conditions.
Business reorganisation or restructuring continued to be the primary reason for lay-offs in 2024.
Generic photo people at shenton way traffic crossing. For stories related to Labour, Employment, Wages and Productivity.

site_title: US homebuilders face a supply chain snarl from tariff battles
summary: US homebuilders face uncertainty due to ongoing tariff battles with Canada, which has halted efforts to import lumber from the country. President Trump's push for tariffs has frozen markets, making it difficult for businesses to trust price stability and causing supply chain disruptions. The National Association of Home Builders warns that tariffs risk worsening housing affordability, while the US Lumber Coalition argues that lumber prices are only a fraction of homebuilding costs. The situation is particularly concerning for builders and homeowners seeking to rebuild after devastating wildfires.

images.alt_text: Housing inflation has remained stubbornly high month after month amid a national shortage, becoming a major issue for voters in the recent election.

site_title: Goldman Sachs gives managers a choice: Dallas, Salt Lake City or leave
summary: Goldman Sachs is relocating some managers to Dallas, Salt Lake City, or leaving London, as part of an effort to trim $1.3 billion in operating costs. The initiative, dubbed "Project Voyage," aims to drive down costs and tap talent from emerging regions. The bank has already grown its presence in Dallas, while staffing in New York has stagnated, and is seeking to build out more functions in these locations. The move is part of CEO David Solomon's efforts to reshape US operations geographically and rein in expenses.

images.alt_text: Money managers and corporate executives are struggling to cope with the volatility created by Donald Trump’s threatened tariffs.

A view of the Balboa Port is pictured after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock Inc-backed consortium, amid pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump to curb China's influence in the region, Panama City, Panama, March 4, 2025. REUTERS/Enea Lebrun
The planned cuts are in line with the bank’s typical approach as it seeks to keep a lid on costs and make room to enlist new talent.

site_title: Greenland’s future must be decided by its people
summary: Greenland is set to head to the polls on March 11, with Prime Minister Mute B Egede's Inuit Ataqatigiit party favoring independence from Denmark. However, concerns about living standards and the island's reliance on Denmark's annual fiscal transfer of $623 million remain. US President Donald Trump has expressed interest in acquiring Greenland, but a recent poll shows 85% of Greenlanders reject the idea. Local leaders should focus on maintaining inclusive institutions, ensuring full economic and political rights for all inhabitants, and exploring alternative development strategies, such as attracting European and American investors in the tourism sector.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump speaks in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on March 3, 2025. (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP)

In an interview, US Secretary of State Marco Rubio played down the threat of the United States using military force against Denmark, a Nato ally, but said of Donald Trump’s remarks on Greenland, “This is not a joke.”
A member of Trump's family on a private visit to Greenland.

site_title: Australian household spending rises for fourth month in January
summary: Australian household spending rose for the fourth consecutive month in January, driven by a 0.4% seasonally adjusted increase from December, primarily due to a 1.5% rise in services. This growth slowed the annual pace to 2.9% from 4.2% in the previous month. Consumers reduced spending on goods, taking advantage of promotional events, and spent more on health services, air travel, and sports. The Australian Bureau of Statistics' monthly household spending indicator (MHSI) will replace the current retail sales report, covering 68% of household consumption.

images.alt_text: The Aussie rose 0.3 per cent to hit a one-week high of US$0.6354, having surged 1 per cent overnight.
The study revealed that post-pandemic, higher incomes have grown faster than middle incomes, while the growth of lower incomes has stagnated, further exacerbating inequality.
Australia’s business conditions have also been quite buoyant and retail sales strengthened in five of the six months to January.
Two of Australia's biggest pension funds say they have excess capital to deploy to real estate, with one already diversifying to the UK in late 2023.

site_title: China’s January-February exports, imports weaker than expected
summary: China's exports rose 2.3% year-on-year in January-February, missing the 5% forecast, and imports shrank 8.4%, also missing expectations, amid escalating trade tensions with the US. The slowdown in exports and imports, combined with China's focus on boosting consumption and domestic demand, reflects the country's growing reliance on exports and its vulnerability to external pressures. Chinese policymakers have vowed to restructure the growth model to reduce dependence on manufacturing and trade.

images.alt_text: Speaking at a press conference on the sidelines of a key political meeting, China's foreign minister Wang Yi warned the “law of the jungle” could take hold in the world if nations were to pursue purely their own interests.

Americans seem so far unconvinced that the future will be as bright as Donald Trump promises, even after the Republican campaigned hard on cost of living issues in his election battle with Democrat Kamala Harris.

US President Donald Trump signed orders on Thursday to delay fresh levies for Canadian and Mexican imports covered by a North American trade agreement, though he dismissed suggestions that his decisions were linked to market turmoil.

site_title: Stocks to watch: UMS, NetLink NBN Trust, ComfortDelGro, Singapore Exchange
summary: The Singapore Exchange announced changes to its foreign exchange and technology management teams, including the resignation of Lee Beng Hong, who will be replaced by Jean-Philippe Male. Meanwhile, UMS Integration received upgrades from three brokerages on a positive outlook for 2025, despite missing earnings estimates. NetLink NBN Trust will replace ComfortDelGro on the Straits Times Index reserve list, starting March 24.

site_title: US withdraws from plan to help major global polluters move from coal
summary: The US has withdrawn from the Just Energy Transition Partnership (JETP), a global collaboration to help developing countries transition from coal to cleaner energy. The move, consistent with President Donald Trump's executive order, affects South Africa, Indonesia, and Vietnam, which had received loans, financial guarantees, and grants from the US to support their energy transitions. The US had committed over $5 billion to these countries, but the withdrawal leaves these nations with uncertain funding for their energy transition plans.

site_title: China tech stocks: Time for investors to dive in?
summary: China's tech sector is experiencing a resurgence, with investors warming up to Chinese tech stocks after a bruising rout. The Hang Seng Tech Index has rallied 32.1% this year, driven by breakthroughs such as DeepSeek's AI model, which performs on par with ChatGPT. Analysts see opportunities in chip manufacturing, cloud computing, and electric vehicles, but caution investors to be mindful of risks, including US tariffs, China's growth slowdown, and the monetization model for large language models. Despite these risks, many industry players believe that Chinese tech stocks have room to run and that the country's innovation is not to be bet against.

images.alt_text: Alongside DeepSeek, major Chinese tech companies from Baidu to Tencent have invested money to develop their own AI models.

site_title: Bank of America CEO willing to hire in Japan as market revives
summary: Bank of America CEO Brian Moynihan is open to hiring more employees in Japan as the local economy revives. The return of price and wage growth, rising interest rates, and corporate reforms are spurring activity in the country, prompting asset managers and brokers to consider investing. Moynihan plans to hire both internal and external candidates, citing Tokyo as an "exciting city" to live in. This move follows a recent surge in Japan's stock market and a strengthening of Bank of America's Japan analysis offerings.

images.alt_text: At its debut investor day in 2020, Goldman Sachs outlined plans to trim US$1.3 billion in operating costs by shedding some managers and moving employees to lower-cost locales.

US President Donald Trump signs an executive order to create a US sovereign wealth fund on Feb 3. The fund could be used as a catalyst for American investment in areas considered national security priorities, says a source.

site_title: Fresh grad employment broadly stable; year-to-year fluctuations are cyclical: Gan Siow Huang
summary: Employment rates for Singaporean autonomous university graduates aged 25-29 have remained stable over the decade, with some fluctuations due to cyclical changes. According to the 2024 Joint Autonomous Universities Graduate Employment Survey, fewer graduates found full-time work six months after graduation, but median salaries increased. The government monitors medium-term outcomes and notes that some sectors, such as health sciences and business, continue to have strong employment outcomes, while others face challenges in attracting graduates.

images.alt_text: Elysia Tan
More fresh graduates were unemployed, with 12.9 per cent unable to find work in 2024.
The overall supply and demand for tech grads appear to still balance out. But a fast-changing landscape will keep students on their toes, according to watchers.

site_title: Rattled markets, negative polls: Trump’s honeymoon over
summary: US President Donald Trump's honeymoon period appears to be over, as his approval rating remains middling and the country faces economic concerns, including high prices and a record trade deficit. Trump's volatile trade policy and mass firings at the Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE) have created unease, and experts say he needs to pivot to policies boosting the economy. Trump's approval ratings are low, with only 22% of respondents saying the country is moving in the right direction on cost of living issues, and consumer confidence has taken a nosedive.

images.alt_text: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller’s comments come as anxiety over the economic outlook is mounting, as the Trump Administration presses ahead erratically with major tariffs on America’s largest trading partners.
It is typical of personalistic leaders, like Trump, to pit allies (courtiers, really) against each other so that none amasses too much power.
The value of imports rose 10 per cent to a record US$401.2 billion, while exports increased 1.2 per cent.

US President Donald Trump signed orders on Thursday to delay fresh levies for Canadian and Mexican imports covered by a North American trade agreement, though he dismissed suggestions that his decisions were linked to market turmoil.

site_title: Cuts to national parks couldn’t have come at a more dangerous time
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration laid off 3,400 probationary employees from the US Forest Service, a move critics say puts Americans at greater risk during the tourist season, when wildfires are more frequent and unpredictable. Many of the fired employees were secondary firefighters and wildfire prevention specialists, leaving the agency vulnerable to devastating fires. The cuts come as climate change makes wildfires more destructive, and experts warn that clear-cutting national forests will only increase the risk. The move is part of the Trump administration's Project 2025, which aims to open more federal lands to commercial logging.

images.alt_text: Tens of thousands of Canadians flee huge forest fires
While Donald Trump and Elon Musk have claimed that US$2 trillion could potentially be saved, most experts believe this is not realistic without cuts to crucial services or benefits.

site_title: World’s sea ice cover hits record low in February
summary: Global sea ice cover reached a record low in February 2025, with temperatures near the North Pole soaring 11°C above average, according to Europe's climate monitor. This marks the third-hottest February on record, continuing a warming trend since 2023 due to greenhouse gas emissions. The combined Antarctic and Arctic sea ice cover dropped to a record minimum extent of 16.04 million sq km.

site_title: Broadcom rallies after AI fuels stronger-than-expected forecast
summary: Broadcom's stock rose over 10% in extended trading after the company reported stronger-than-expected sales of $14.9 billion for the first quarter, beating analyst estimates. The chip supplier's data centre customers continue to invest in AI computing infrastructure, driving sales growth. CEO Hock Tan cited AI spending as a key driver, with sales from that area expected to total $4.4 billion in the current period. The results follow a poorly received earnings report from Marvell Technology, and Broadcom's stock has risen 23% in 2025, pushing its market value above $1 trillion.

images.alt_text: Apple said that it plans to spend US$500 billion in the US over the next four years, though that figure includes everything from purchases from US suppliers to US filming of television shows and movies for its Apple TV+ service.
Intel, once dominant in the chip industry, has struggled to regain its technological edge and lost market share to rivals in recent years.
Intel was among the largest beneficiaries of the US push to onshore critical chip manufacturing led by former president Joe Biden’s administration.
Arm, led by CEO Rene Haas, has sought to recruit executives from licensees, two sources familiar with the matter told Reuters.

site_title: Nissan board to meet next week to discuss CEO Uchida’s fate
summary: Nissan's board is set to meet on March 11 to discuss the future of CEO Makoto Uchida amid another poor fiscal quarter and the fallout from its potential tie-up with Honda Motor. The automaker is considering replacing Uchida with three foreign candidates, including CFO Jeremie Papin, CPO Guillaume Cartier, and CPO Ivan Espinosa. Nissan is struggling with revolving-door leadership, outdated products, and competition in the US and China, making a change in leadership a potential lifeline.

images.alt_text: Nissan motor President and CEO Makoto Uchida attends a press conference at the company’s headquarters in Yokohama city of Kanagawa prefecture on February 13, 2024. (Photo by Yuichi YAMAZAKI / AFP)

site_title: Asia: Stocks, bitcoin down as trade uncertainty roils markets
summary: Asian stocks declined on Friday due to uncertainty over US President Donald Trump's trade policies, with Japan's Nikkei index dropping 1.5% and shares in South Korea and Australia falling over 1%. Bitcoin plummeted 5.7% after Trump signed an executive order establishing a "Strategic Bitcoin Reserve." Despite a delay in tariffs targeting Canada and Mexico, Trump has vowed to implement tariffs on steel and aluminum imports, causing market volatility and limiting business planning decisions.

images.alt_text: Americans seem so far unconvinced that the future will be as bright as Donald Trump promises, even after the Republican campaigned hard on cost of living issues in his election battle with Democrat Kamala Harris.

US President Donald Trump signed orders on Thursday to delay fresh levies for Canadian and Mexican imports covered by a North American trade agreement, though he dismissed suggestions that his decisions were linked to market turmoil.
The STI reached a new record in February, trading as high as 3,943.23.
The Stoxx 600 recovered from a 0.9 per cent decline to close flat at 555.90 points on Thursday.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished one per cent lower at 42.579.08 on Thursday, after spending the entire session in negative territory.

site_title: Maga wants to end capitalism as we know it
summary: US President Donald Trump's administration aims to dismantle the managerial corporation, a key pillar of post-war US prosperity, with tariffs and new regulations. The plan, backed by influential figures such as Kevin Roberts and US Senator Josh Hawley, seeks to reverse the managerial revolution, promote ownership and control, and create an "active commerce" for the 21st century. Critics argue that this approach is overly nostalgic, neglecting the role of family capitalism in the business class and ignoring real problems with the focus on numbers over quality and the massive overexpansion of the managerial class.

images.alt_text: as transitions often are. In the first instance, it means greater volatility, which in the capital markets means risk. It also means uncertainty, and the lack of visibility is often associated with cautiousness on the part of business in making investment decisions.

site_title: Casino tycoon administrators seek to defend magnate Stanley Ho’s estate
summary: Macau casino magnate Stanley Ho's estate administrators are defending the billionaire's assets in a court case involving his late sister's estate executor, Winnie Ho. The administrators, Patrick Cowley and Lui Yee Man, are seeking a judge's direction on payment of costs and expenses related to defending the estate in the case. 18 of Ho's descendants, including his children and grandchildren, have been called to attend the court hearing, but administrators claim there is no dispute between them and the beneficiaries.

Thailand’s potential as a gaming destination, with casinos proposed in the capital Bangkok, on the holiday island of Phuket, and three other sites, is underpinned by its role as a regional magnet for tourism.
Revenue from Macao operations fell about 5 per cent to US$1.86 billion.

site_title: Investors flock to South-east Asia markets on renewed interest in tech, safe-haven factor
summary: Investors are flocking to South-east Asia, particularly Singapore and Malaysia, due to the region's lower volatility and abundant resources. The MSCI Asean Index has logged returns of 16% over the past year, outperforming the S&P 500. Banks and semiconductors are top sectoral picks in both countries, driven by their strong financial and industrial sectors. Analysts expect continued growth in the region, citing favourable demographics, global supply chain diversification, and historically low allocation by global investors. Despite some lagging markets, South-east Asia is seen as a "safe haven" for investors, with the region's economies underpinned by demographics and long-term growth.

A simple handshake between President Xi Jinping and once-shunned entrepreneur Jack Ma sent Chinese tech stocks booming in recent weeks as it was interpreted as the latest sign the sector is being brought in from the cold -- though experts advise caution. Alongside DeepSeek, major Chinese tech companies from Baidu to Tencent have invested money to develop their own AI models.

site_title: SBI denies report it is negotiating with SK Hynix, UMC on Japan chip plant
summary: SBI Holdings has denied a report that it is negotiating with SK Hynix and UMC to collaborate on a chip plant in Japan's Miyagi prefecture. The report, published by Nikkan Kogyo, claimed SBI was seeking to partner with the South Korean and Taiwanese companies on back-end DRAM processes and vehicle chips. SBI previously announced it would dissolve a joint venture with Taiwan's Powerchip Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. and consider partnering with other firms on chip-related business. The company stated the Nikkan Kogyo report was not true and not based on any credible sources.

site_title: The coming showdown in Trumpworld
summary: A coalition of incompatible financial and ideological interests, including economic nationalists, techno-rightists, and free-speech absolutists, surrounds Donald Trump, prioritizing their agendas over democratic principles. Despite Trump's authoritarian tendencies, these groups see him as a promising ally, but their differing visions for America are likely to lead to a showdown, potentially causing the Trump coalition to implode. The clash between economic nationalists and techno-rightists is the sharpest, with the former seeking to restore American industrial glory and the latter envisioning a technological utopia.

images.alt_text: US President Donald Trump speaks in the Roosevelt Room of the White House in Washington, DC, on March 3, 2025. (Photo by ROBERTO SCHMIDT / AFP)

site_title: TSMC’s CEO says US expansion driven by strong customer demand
summary: TSMC CEO CC Wei stated that the company's US$100 billion investment plan in the US is driven by strong customer demand, with production lines already fully booked for this year and the next two years. Despite concerns about potential damage to Taiwan's semiconductor industry, TSMC plans to build 11 new production lines in Taiwan this year, in addition to three new lines in the US. The company's expansion plans also include projects in Japan and Germany.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as tariff uncertainty prevails, chipmakers slide
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday as uncertainty over a trade war fueled by US tariffs clouded sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 158.1 points, or 0.37%, to 42,848.49. Chip stocks slid after Marvell's forecast raised concerns about slowing demand for AI infrastructure. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also declined, with the S&P 500 falling 56.8 points, or 0.97%, to 5,785.87, and the Nasdaq Composite dropping 348.2 points, or 1.88%, to 18,204.528.

site_title: Europe: Stoxx 600 closes flat as ECB boost counters pressures from yields
summary: European stocks closed flat at 555.90 points on Thursday, recovering from a 0.9% decline, after the European Central Bank's interest rate cut boosted bank stocks. The ECB reduced rates as expected and signaled more cuts, offsetting pressures from rising long-term bond yields. Construction and materials stocks rose 2.2% and 0.9% respectively, while British banks declined 2.7%. The EU's largest economic policy upheaval in decades is driven by a looming trade war with the US and plans to boost military spending.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished one per cent lower at 42.579.08 on Thursday, after spending the entire session in negative territory.

site_title: Gold standard in haute horlogerie
summary: Luxury watchmakers Omega, Richard Mille, and Hermes have unveiled new creations featuring gold, a material that redefines the boundaries of haute horlogerie. Richard Mille's RM 74-02 Automatic Tourbillon in Gold Quartz TPT boasts an exclusive composite material, while Omega's Seamaster 300M is crafted from its proprietary Bronze Gold alloy. Meanwhile, Hermes' Slim d'Hermes Cheval brosse features an azure enamel sky with a vibrant horse motif, all powered by in-house movements. These innovative timepieces showcase the perfect blend of artistry and technical precision.

images.alt_text: The BR-03 Astro emphasises the expressive magic of space, with Earth at its center, surrounded by the Moon (minutes), Mars (hours) a small satellite (seconds).

site_title: BlackRock-CK Hutchison port deal shines light on US law firm Paul Hastings
summary: CK Hutchison Holdings has sold the bulk of its ports, including in Panama, to a consortium led by BlackRock for US$19 billion, marking one of the biggest acquisitions of the year. The deal, facilitated by US law firm Paul Hastings, is a significant shift for CK Hutchison, which previously worked with top law firms. Goldman Sachs Group has reportedly taken a prominent role in the deal, with Weil, Gotshal & Manges providing legal advice to the BlackRock consortium. The sale is seen as a major infrastructure deal and has implications for the global trade landscape.

images.alt_text: A view of the Balboa Port is pictured after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock Inc-backed consortium, amid pressure from U.S. President Donald Trump to curb China's influence in the region, Panama City, Panama, March 4, 2025. The sale includes 90% of Panama Ports Company, which has operated the Balboa (pictured) and Cristobal ports in the Central American country for over two decades, CK Hutchison said.

China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs' spokesperson Lin Jian says: "We hope that Panama will make the right decision based on the overall situation of bilateral relations and the long-term interests of the two peoples, and eliminate external interference."

site_title: Longer support, broader criteria in M-SEP foreign labour flexibility scheme
summary: Singapore's Manpower for Strategic Economic Priorities (M-SEP) scheme will be extended to three years, allowing companies to access additional foreign labour. The scheme now allows firms to hire foreign workers for two years, if they meet two conditions: contributing to economic priorities through investment, innovation, or internationalisation, and committing to hiring and training locals. The government will also introduce a fourth way for firms to satisfy the local workforce condition by sending locals on overseas training programs, and expand the list of qualifying programs.

images.alt_text: Freelancers can also access allowances for training under selected programmes.

site_title: Federal Reserve’s Waller, leaning against March cut, sees easings later in year
summary: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller expressed skepticism about a rate cut at the upcoming policy meeting, citing uncertainty over inflation data and the impact of President Trump's trade agenda. Waller leans against a rate cut, but believes cuts later in the year may still be necessary if inflation pressures abate. This comes as anxiety over the economic outlook mounts amid major tariffs on America's largest trading partners.

images.alt_text: Compared with January, the Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" survey reflected growing anxiety among businesses across most districts about how Donald Trump’s plans to increase import duties and restrict immigration could affect demand and prices.
Lower-income households in the US have been struggling, burdened by dwindling savings, maxed-out credit cards and mounting debt.
Most of the federal layoffs have been in Washington DC, which has lost 61,795 jobs so far this year compared with only 60 in 2024.

Rising price pressures could be worsened by a trade war, triggered by President Donald Trump’s new 25 per cent tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada, which took effect on Tuesday, along with a doubling of duties on Chinese goods to 20 per cent.

site_title: JD.com sales rise most in years after China consumers awaken
summary: JD.com reported its fastest revenue growth in at least two years, with sales rising 13% to 347 billion yuan (S$63.8 billion) for the three months ended December. The company's net income more than doubled to 9.9 billion yuan. JD's results follow Alibaba's better-than-anticipated numbers and signal a more buoyant mood among Chinese tech companies, driven by Beijing's renewed support for the private sector and consumption-led growth policies.

images.alt_text: Shein shareholders are suggesting that an adjustment is needed to help get its potential initial public offering in the UK over the line.
Clothing and accessories for sale at the new Urban Revivo store in the Soho neighborhood of New York, US, Feb 28, 2025. Urban Revivo is planning three new stores this year in New York and London.

site_title: ECB cuts interest rates and keeps door ajar to more easing
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) lowered its deposit rate to 2.5% in a bid to slow inflation and boost economic growth, marking the sixth interest rate cut since June. ECB President Christine Lagarde warned that rising trade tensions with the US could dampen exports and weaken the global economy. The bank's growth forecast for 2025 was also revised downward to 0.9%, citing lower exports and investment due to high trade uncertainty. The move keeps the door open for further rate cuts, with markets pricing in almost two more rate cuts this year.

site_title: Trump backs off on Mexico, Canada tariffs after market blowback
summary: US President Donald Trump has delayed fresh levies on Canadian and Mexican imports covered by the North American trade agreement, providing some reprieve to companies and consumers after market turmoil. The halt, which lasts until April 2, comes after stock markets tumbled and economists warned that blanket levies could weigh on US growth and raise inflation. Trump signed orders to delay tariffs on about 62% of Canadian imports, with about half of Mexican imports also exempt. The move is seen as a recognition of economic reality, acknowledging that tariffs disrupt supply chains and burden consumers.

site_title: SGX announces leadership changes to its FX and technology teams
summary: SGX announces leadership changes to its FX and technology teams, including two resignations, as the exchange seeks to strengthen its capabilities for continued growth. Lee Beng Hong, head of wholesale markets and platforms, and Thijs Jacobs, group chief technology officer, are leaving their positions. Jean-Philippe Male, co-founder and CEO of BidFX, will replace Lee as CEO of SGX FX, while Tinku Gupta will cover Jacobs' responsibilities until a replacement is found. The changes follow several other high-profile resignations at SGX amid efforts to revive Singapore's equity market.

site_title: Oil steadies in choppy trading on tariff uncertainty, Opec+ hike plans
summary: Oil prices steadied on Thursday, with Brent futures closing at US$69.46 a barrel, up 16 cents or 0.2% from the previous day. The gain was driven by uncertainty over Opec+ plans to raise output, as well as a Russian/Ukraine peace deal and tariff fluctuations. US President Donald Trump exempted Canadian energy imports from tariffs for a month, while the US is set to increase sanctions on Iran to collapse its oil exports. Analysts predict downside risks on demand outweigh supply-side risks, with spare capacity offsetting supply losses.

images.alt_text: Most at risk are China’s fleet of small, independent refiners, largely located in Shandong province, that account for about a fifth of the nation’s processing capacity.

site_title: Volvo unveils China-made electric sedan as tariff tensions rise
summary: Volvo unveiled its new China-made electric sedan, the ES90, in Stockholm, amid rising trade tensions. The car, priced at 71,990 euros, boasts a 700-kilometer range before needing a recharge. This comes as Volvo faces declining sales of its fully electric models, with a 15% drop in the last month. The automaker, controlled by Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, is expanding its production in China to mitigate the impact of US tariffs on the automotive industry.

site_title: JPMorgan sours on hard currency sovereign debt
summary: JPMorgan has downgraded its recommendation on sovereign and semi-sovereign dollar debt in emerging markets to "underweight" from "market weight" due to signs of weakness in the US economy. The bank's head of emerging markets sovereign strategy, Ben Ramsey, stated that valuations near historical lows may not withstand a larger correction in risk assets. This move suggests that investors may need to reassess their exposure to emerging markets debt.

China is beefing up the strength of its banking system after enacting a string of stimulus policies including cuts to mortgage rates and key policy rates.

site_title: Why silver is the new gold
summary: Silver's price has soared by nearly 60% since the start of 2023, outperforming gold over the past five years and almost keeping pace with it over the past year. The metal's "safe-haven" appeal and industrial demand, driven by solar panels, have driven the price increase. Central banks, including Russia, are now buying silver, and traders are snapping up the metal in anticipation of a widening supply and demand gap, expected to boost its price for some time.

summary: Saudi Arabia's sovereign wealth fund, Public Investment Fund (PIF), is set to invest $100 million in Malaysian carrier AirAsia, boosting ties between the two countries. The investment, part of a fundraising targeted at $1 billion, will play the single biggest role in AirAsia's fundraising efforts. The move aims to reboot AirAsia's growth ambitions after years of losses, as the airline seeks funds to purchase 100 regional jets. This investment aligns with Saudi Arabia's efforts to diversify its economy and become a travel hub, led by Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman.

summary: Walgreens Boots Alliance to be taken private by Sycamore Partners in a US$10 billion deal. Sycamore will pay US$11.45 per share, a premium of 8% to the stock's closing price. The deal will close out nearly a century of trading on public markets for the US pharmacy giant.

site_title: US: Stocks tumble again on slowdown worries
summary: US stocks declined on Thursday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average falling 1% to 42,579.08, and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes down 1.8% and 2.6%, respectively. Despite President Trump's temporary tariff rollback, markets remained uncertain, with tech firms such as Netflix, Tesla, and Nvidia experiencing significant losses. Analysts attribute the slowdown to ongoing trade policy uncertainty, which is affecting consumer sentiment and business investment.

site_title: Regulators should step up cybersecurity accountability
summary: Regulators globally are cracking down on companies that fail to prioritize cybersecurity, with the US Securities and Exchange Commission and Australian Information Commissioner taking action against companies such as SolarWinds and Medibank. In Singapore, the SGX is considering more stringent guidelines to encourage companies to disclose their cybersecurity controls and risk management systems, amid a growing number of ransomware incidents and high cybersecurity threats.

site_title: Trump says he will visit Saudi Arabia for major business deal
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to visit Saudi Arabia, citing a major business deal, despite the country's human rights record and ties to Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman. Trump said he would meet with Saudi leaders if they agreed to invest $1 trillion in US companies over four years, a deal he claims has already been agreed upon. This visit comes after Trump forged close business ties with Saudi Arabia, including the Trump Organization's recent announcement of a Trump Tower in Jeddah.

site_title: US trade deficit surges to a record ahead of Trump tariffs
summary: The US trade deficit surged to a record $131.4 billion in January, a 34% increase from the prior month, as companies scrambled to secure goods before President Trump imposed tariffs on major trading partners. Imports rose 10% to a record $401.2 billion, while exports increased 1.2%. This marks the largest trade deficit on record.

site_title: 🎻 Are women doomed to play second fiddle to men at work?
summary: Women in Singapore's workforce have made progress, with a 78.3% female employment rate in 2024, up from 76.3% in 2023. However, despite this increase, women still face challenges, including a 15% pay gap and 23% reporting of gender discrimination in the workplace. To overcome these obstacles, experts recommend embracing one's core competencies, such as empathy and intuition, and setting clear boundaries to achieve peak professionalism. Women should not feel pressured to conform to traditional masculine norms but rather, leverage their unique strengths to succeed in their careers.

site_title: EU shifts on defence - and concedes maybe ‘Macron was right’
summary: The European Union has shifted its stance on defense, aligning with France's long-held view that Europe must guarantee its own security. Following US President Donald Trump's rapprochement with Russia, the EU has given the European Commission approval to mobilize hundreds of billions of euros to boost Europe's defenses. This move reflects a growing consensus among European capitals that the US may not be a reliable partner. French President Emmanuel Macron's 2017 call for European autonomy in defense has been vindicated, with Germany also suggesting stricter EU spending rules to allow for more long-term defense expenditure.

site_title: Mid-career allowance for part-time courses applies to transition programme, full qualifications up to undergrad degree
summary: The Singapore government has allocated S$400 million to an Enterprise Workforce Transformation Package, which includes a SkillsFuture Workforce Development Grant, higher funding support for job redesign, and a revamped SkillsFuture Enterprise Credit system. The Mid-Career Training Allowance for part-time courses will be available for the SkillsFuture Career Transition Programme and full qualifications up to undergraduate degree levels, with S$300 monthly allowance for part-time training and S$3,000 monthly allowance for full-time training. Freelancers can also receive these allowances.

site_title: Sias questions CDL on role of Catherine Wu, board appointments, management reporting lines
summary: Singapore's investor watchdog, Sias, has questioned City Developments Ltd (CDL) on the role of former adviser Catherine Wu, board appointments, and management reporting lines amid a boardroom tussle. Sias asked for clarity on Wu's role, the nomination process for two new directors, and the reporting lines for group CEO Sherman Kwek and COO Kwek Eik Sheng. The watchdog also urged directors to make statements on the current situation on SGXNet first, rather than via the media, to ensure compliance with SGX listing rules.

images.alt_text: The elder Kwek had sought an injunction against the two new directors, Jennifer Duong Young and Wong Su-Yen, to prevent them from exercising the powers of a director.

The property giant said its business operations “remain fully functional and unaffected”.
The High Court has directed both sides “to refrain from taking any action in relation to Singapura Developments and Millennium and Copthorne Hotels", said CDL on Monday (Mar 3).

site_title: Singapore adds Bhutan, Cambodia, Laos as non-traditional sources of work permit holders
summary: Singapore has expanded its non-traditional sources of work permit holders to include Bhutan, Cambodia, and Laos, starting June 1. This move aims to build a more skilled and resilient workforce in sectors such as construction, marine shipyard, and process industries. The expansion will also raise the age limit for work permit holders to 63 and remove the maximum employment period, allowing firms to retain experienced workers and reduce training costs.

site_title: Germany's DHL to cut 8,000 jobs this year after annual operating profit falls 7.2%
summary: DHL plans to cut 8,000 jobs this year, about 1% of its workforce, in the Post & Parcel Germany division as part of its "Fit for Growth" programme to save 1 billion euros by 2027. The company reported a 7.2% fall in annual operating profit to 5.89 billion euros in 2024, ahead of expectations. DHL CEO Tobias Meyer expects a volatile global economic situation in 2025, with an operating profit forecast of over 6 billion euros.

images.alt_text: DHL reported a third-quarter Ebit of 1.4 billion euros, in line with market expectations.

site_title: Walmart asks Chinese suppliers for major price cuts amid Trump tariff impact
summary: Walmart has asked Chinese suppliers to lower prices by up to 10% per round of tariffs, essentially absorbing the full cost of President Trump's duties. The move aims to mitigate the impact of tariffs on US consumers, who are already grappling with cost-of-living stresses. Suppliers have largely resisted, with some refusing price cuts greater than 2-3% due to razor-thin margins. The decision reflects the shifting global supply chain landscape amid rising geopolitical tensions.

images.alt_text: Walmart bonuses largely exceed targets but dip from prior year
Walmart is also closing its office in Charlotte, North Carolina, and is cutting corporate roles as part of the process, according to the memo.
Walmart is looking to better compete against Amazon.com and other rivals by adding more brands.
Walmart joins at least 10 other companies from Deere to Boeing who have pulled back on their DEI commitments in recent months.
Walmart said in the third quarter total e-commerce sales rose 27 per cent, compared to the 21 per cent in the prior quarter.
Walmart, the world’s biggest retailer, has slashed Christmas imports deeply, shipping at least 340,000 kilos of products described as “Christmas” goods into the US in the 12 months ending Sep 30.

site_title: US to name Morgan Stanley banker to lead sovereign wealth fund: sources
summary: US President Donald Trump has tapped Michael Grimes, a former Morgan Stanley banker, to lead the country's planned sovereign wealth fund, aimed at investing in national security priorities. Grimes will oversee the Commerce Department's efforts, part of a public-private collaborative initiative. The fund's creation follows Trump's February executive order to establish a US sovereign wealth fund. The exact details and timeline of the fund's implementation remain unclear, but Grimes' appointment marks a key step in the process.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President JD Vance (top left) and US House Speaker Mike Johnson (top right) applaud as US President Donald Trump addresses a joint session of the US Congress in the House Chamber of the US Capitol, Washington, D.C., March 4, 2025.

site_title: Thailand seeks cooperation with India, Vietnam to support falling rice prices
summary: Thailand is seeking cooperation with India and Vietnam to reduce competition and stabilize rice prices in the global market, amid a 30% year-on-year drop in paddy prices to 8,600 baht (S$339.87) per ton. The country aims to create a balance in rice prices and support farmers with stable income. Talks with India and Vietnam are underway, with the Thai commerce minister hoping to find ways to reduce competition and increase rice prices. Thailand, the world's second-largest rice exporter, expects a 24% year-on-year decline in rice exports this year.

site_title: How ECB dodged a payment disaster in 10 hours of tech meltdown
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) narrowly avoided a payment disaster when its tech system crashed, causing delays in welfare payments and salaries for thousands of people in Greece and Austria. The malfunction was attributed to a defective hardware component, which took hours to identify after an initial misdiagnosis of database issues. ECB staff worked throughout the night to fix the problem, clearing a backlog of transactions in time for payday. The incident highlights concerns about the ECB's payment system's reliability, with lawmakers and experts calling for improved backup systems and crisis management procedures.

images.alt_text: The breakdown meant some ordinary bank payments, such as wages, pensions and social welfare transfers, have been delayed and could take several hours longer than usual to arrive.
The consensus is that the ECB will take this year’s staff changes in its stride, with markets still very much focused on data rather than personnel as they calibrate their interest-rate bets.

site_title: Euro rallies as ECB cuts rates again
summary: The euro surged 0.25% to US$1.0815 after the European Central Bank (ECB) cut interest rates for the third time this year, citing strong economic growth and inflation expectations. The move has lifted European bond yields and boosted the euro's value. However, analysts warn that the rally may be short-lived if US growth slows down, with the dollar index on a four-day losing streak. The ECB also revised its economic growth and inflation forecasts, while a looming trade war with the US and plans to boost military spending in Europe continue to pose economic uncertainty.

site_title: US weekly jobless claims fall more than expected
summary: US weekly jobless claims dropped 21,000 to 221,000 for the week ended March 1, beating economists' forecasts of 235,000 claims. Most federal layoffs occurred in Washington DC, with 61,795 jobs lost so far this year. The stable labor market suggests that the economic impact of tariffs on imports and government spending cuts may be limited for now.

images.alt_text: Rising price pressures could be worsened by a trade war, triggered by President Donald Trump’s new 25 per cent tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada, which took effect on Tuesday, along with a doubling of duties on Chinese goods to 20 per cent.

site_title: Indonesia’s gummy giant Yupi sets sights on sweet growth with 2.1 trillion rupiah IPO
summary: Yupi Indo Jelly Gum, Indonesia's leading jelly gum producer, plans to raise 2.1 trillion rupiah (S$171 million) through an initial public offering (IPO) on March 21. The company aims to use 77% of the proceeds to build a new factory in East Java by 2026, while the remaining will fund domestic and regional expansion. Yupi has a 65% market share in Indonesia's soft-candy market and has also expanded to nine South-east Asian countries and 36 other markets, posting a 38% surge in profit in 2023.

images.alt_text: The Financial Services Authority and the Indonesia Stock Exchange met with market stakeholders, including blue-chip shareholders, on Monday to discuss strategies for tackling stock market volatility.

site_title: Ministers Shanmugam, Tan See Leng say parts of Bloomberg article on GCB deals calculated to disparage them
summary: Singapore's Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam and Manpower Minister Tan See Leng have filed defamation suits against Bloomberg and journalist Low De Wei over an article published in 2024, claiming the article was false, baseless, and calculated to disparage them. The article discussed non-caveated purchases of good class bungalows (GCBs) in Singapore, referencing the ministers' respective properties. Bloomberg and Low denied the claims, stating the article was focused on highlighting the benefits of non-caveated purchases and was not intended to impugn the ministers' reputations.

images.alt_text: In identical Facebook posts on Dec 16, 2024, Law and Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam (left) and Manpower Minister Tan See Leng (right) said Bloomberg’s article is libellous..

site_title: NetLink NBN Trust to replace ComfortDelGro on STI reserve list
summary: NetLink NBN Trust will replace ComfortDelGro on the Straits Times Index's (STI) reserve list, following the index's March 2025 quarterly review. The change takes effect on March 24 and does not alter the STI constituents. The reserve list comprises the five highest ranking non-constituents by market capitalization, with NetLink NBN Trust and four other companies currently on the list.

site_title: JTC extends land leases for new industrial sites, offers more flexible renewals for businesses
summary: Singapore's JTC (JTC Corporation) has introduced changes to its industrial land lease framework, offering longer leases and more flexible renewal terms to businesses. New greenfield allocations will be granted three additional years of lease, allowing companies to enjoy the full 20 or 30-year intended lease term. A new scheme will also allow companies to extend their leases in shorter periods for incremental business investments, with eligible companies able to extend their leases by up to two tranches of five years. The changes aim to promote value creation and productivity, and are part of the government's efforts to support business competitiveness.

site_title: Malaysia's palm oil production in two states hit by infestations
summary: Malaysia's palm oil production in Johor and Perak states has been hit by infestations of leaf-eating pests, particularly bagworms. The attacks, which have been reported in several areas, have affected 1.01 million hectares of the country's 5.61 million hectares of oil palm plantations. The Malaysian Palm Oil Board (MPOB) is controlling the infestation through biopesticide products and planting beneficial crops, with an allocation of RM5 million requested to strengthen control efforts. This comes as the country recovers from floods that disrupted production, hitting a six-month low.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 6)
summary: Singapore's government has announced plans to support innovation and economic growth through various initiatives. The country aims to nurture strong enterprises through innovation, and has launched a new S$500 million national fab facility for semicon companies, including startups. The government also extended land leases for new industrial sites and offered more flexible renewals for businesses. Additionally, a S$200 million long-term investment fund will be established to support enterprises with longer, complex growth trajectories. The government will also support sustainable aviation through a new centre in Asia-Pacific.

site_title: Higher S Pass qualifying salary of S$3,300 from Sep 1; levy raised to S$550
summary: Singapore's minimum qualifying salary for S Pass applicants will rise to S$3,300, starting from September 1, 2025, and to S$4,800 for those in their mid-40s. The levy will also increase to S$650, equal to the Tier 2 levy. The government aims to ensure S Pass holders are comparable to the top third of local associate professionals and technicians. Additionally, the Manpower for Strategic Economic Priorities (M-SEP) scheme will be enhanced, providing longer work permit and S Pass holder access and more overseas training opportunities.

site_title: DBS updates transition finance framework; notes higher oil and gas portfolio emissions in 2024
summary: DBS, Southeast Asia's largest bank, has updated its transition finance framework to provide clarity on which areas of hard-to-abate sectors are eligible for transition financing. The revision aims to support companies in decarbonizing their carbon-intensive business activities, such as sustainable aviation fuels development. Despite setbacks in global climate commitments, DBS remains committed to supporting climate action for a low-carbon and climate-resilient economy. The updated framework is part of DBS' 2024 sustainability report, which also provides an annual update on the bank's net-zero progress.
