site_title: India central bank announces over US$21 billion liquidity infusion to support growth
summary: The Reserve Bank of India (RBI) announced a US$21 billion liquidity infusion into the banking system to support economic growth. The central bank will conduct two open market operations and a US dollar-rupee buy-sell swap to ease lending conditions. This move follows a 25 basis point interest rate cut last month and comes after liquidity conditions remained tight since mid-December. The RBI aims to boost economic growth, which expanded 6.2% in October to December, and maintain comfortable liquidity conditions.

images.alt_text: The Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) intervention was brought on by a build-up in bearish bets against the rupee and the currency’s sharp slide over the past four months.

India’s government has forecast annual growth of 6.4 per cent in the year ending in March, below the lower end of its initial projection, weighed by a weaker manufacturing sector and slower corporate investments.

The infusion takes the amount poured into India’s banking system to US$7.3 billion in the past two days and is part of the Reserve Bank of India’s (RBI) broader US$18 billion plan to address the tightness in domestic money markets.

site_title: Blackstone nears US$400 million deal for India’s South City Mall
summary: Blackstone is nearing a deal to acquire South City Mall in Kolkata, India for up to $400 million. The shopping mall, owned by South City Projects, features brands like Zara and Sephora, and would mark Blackstone's entry into retail malls in the city. The acquisition is part of Blackstone's strategy to tap into consumer spending, which drives 60% of India's GDP, and extends its investment in brick-and-mortar stores following its investments in e-commerce warehouses.

images.alt_text: Blackstone’s deal for CMIC is the second by a major global private equity firm in the past month in Japan’s pharmaceutical sector.
Most of Steve Schwarzman’s annual windfall came in dividends, not fund profits.
The three projects for sale are part of assets under DragonCor, a portfolio company owned and managed by Blackstone real estate funds set up around 2018.
Blackstone has structured its fund so that investors can withdraw as much as 3 per cent of the fund’s net asset value each quarter.

site_title: Agatha Lee: Turning Singapore’s waste crisis into sustainable art
summary: Artist Agatha Lee is transforming Singapore's waste crisis into sustainable art by repurposing discarded textiles into intricate tapestries and installations. Using materials like organza from wedding dresses, Lee's delicate embroidery encourages mindfulness and slow consumption. Her art pieces convey powerful narratives about waste, renewal, and the environment, aiming to reconnect people with nature and each other.

images.alt_text: Created with Artificial Intelligence, Shavonne Wong's Eva can interact with visitors at the Columns Gallery and have conversations on various topics.
Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.
O2genes is one of the players in the longevity market, specialising in oxygen therapy.

site_title: Malaysia discussing response to US chip tariffs with companies
summary: Malaysia is discussing potential tariffs imposed by the US on semiconductors, which could impact its export-driven economy. Trade Minister Tengku Zafrul Aziz said the government is exploring whether companies can absorb the costs or if consumers will bear the burden. The country, home to top US multinationals, is one of the top exporters of chips to the US, with last year's exports valued at $16.2 billion. The government has not discussed financial support to offset tariffs, but data centres are unlikely to be affected due to strong demand for artificial intelligence.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s Minister of Investment, Trade and Industry Zafrul Aziz said the Digital Economy Framework will facilitate e-commerce and enable Asean countries to thrive collectively.

site_title: DBS says Piyush Gupta led bank to be among the top-performing globally, as handover to Tan Su Shan nears
summary: DBS, Singapore's largest bank, is celebrating its 15-year tenure under CEO Piyush Gupta, who is set to retire this month. The bank's return on equity (ROE) more than doubled to 18% in 2024, placing it among the top-performing banks globally. Gupta credited his digital transformation efforts, including culture change, for the bank's success. Deputy group CEO Tan Su Shan will replace him as CEO, promising to focus on growing high-ROE businesses and addressing macroeconomic challenges.

images.alt_text: Piyush Gupta will be retiring at the upcoming AGM “as part of the board renewal process”.

site_title: Indian payments firm Razorpay launches in Singapore
summary: Indian payments firm Razorpay launched in Singapore, its second market in South-east Asia, focusing on real-time payments to set itself apart from competition. The company aims to tap the growing digital payments market, forecasted to grow to US$180 billion by 2029. Razorpay will leverage Singapore's stability and regional hub status to reach customers, with plans to double its Singapore team and expand into multiple markets by 2027.

images.alt_text: India's Razorpay raises US$160m from investors including GIC
Razorpay raises US$100m in Series D round co-led by GIC: TechCrunch

site_title: Alibaba shares jump 7% after unveiling latest DeepSeek contender
summary: Alibaba unveiled its QwQ-32B model, a deep learning AI contender that outperforms DeepSeek with significantly less data, resulting in a 7% surge in its Hong Kong stock. The company has pledged to invest over 380 billion yuan in AI infrastructure, including data centers, over the next three years. This move underscores Alibaba's ambitions in AI and comes as investors recognize the value of AI in its cloud computing business. The company's growing prowess in AI and Beijing's support have contributed to its comeback.

site_title: Singapore to start S$200 million long-term investment fund for enterprises with longer, complex growth trajectories
summary: Singapore will launch a new $200 million Long Term Investment Fund to support enterprises with longer, complex growth trajectories. The fund, part of the $1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund, will provide non-dilutive, customised financing for high-growth local enterprises, including those in niche and nascent sectors. The government aims to reduce regulatory burden and support heartland businesses, introducing initiatives such as streamlined processes and a one-year Vibrant Heartland Programme.

images.alt_text: Singapore Prime Minister and Finance Minister Lawrence Wong says
Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme is for registrations of electric heavy vehicles with a maximum laden weight of more than 3,500 kilogrammes.

site_title: Malaysia aims to be ‘global leader’ in carbon capture
summary: Malaysia's parliament has passed legislation to become a "global leader" in carbon capture, utilisation and storage (CCUS), a technology aimed at reducing planet-warming emissions. The Bill provides a framework for CCUS, which could generate up to US$250 billion in economic growth and create hundreds of thousands of jobs by 2050. The regulations come into force on March 31, focusing on Peninsular Malaysia and the Federal Territory of Labuan, with eastern states of Sabah and Sarawak excluded.

images.alt_text: The Bill will govern the capture, transport, utilisation and storage of carbon dioxide, Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said.
XXX
The Northern Pathfinder (pictured) is one of the first vessels globally for large-scale CCS.
BP added that CO2 recovered from its first carbon capture, utilisation and storage project in Indonesia would be used to boost production at the Tangguh facility.

site_title: Adidas to cut 500 jobs, says Yeezy trainers are history
summary: Adidas plans to cut up to 500 jobs at its headquarters in Herzogenaurach, Germany, on a voluntary basis, as part of its efforts to drive efficiency and continue its revival after a tumultuous split with Kanye West. The move comes after Adidas sold off its last remaining Yeezy trainers in the last quarter of 2024. Despite the loss, Adidas has seen a significant recovery, with a net profit of 824 million euros in 2024 and expected high-single-digit sales growth in 2025.

images.alt_text: Adidas sales grew by 15 per cent in North America, a key battleground in its attempt to take market share from bigger rival Nike. Revenues were up 25 per cent in Europe, 31 per cent in Latin America, and 16 per cent in Greater China in the quarter.
Adidas said it wanted to ensure “long-term success” and had “begun examining how to adapt the business’s structures to the reality of the work.”
The results mark a significant recovery for Adidas from an annual loss in 2023 for the first time in more than 30 years.

site_title: Thai business group urges action from government amid ‘panic’ over US trade policy
summary: The Thai Chamber of Commerce urged the government to take action over US trade policy uncertainty, citing a 18.3% share of US$54.96 billion in exports and a $35.4 billion trade surplus with the US. The chamber proposed establishing a special working group to address US trade policy issues and importing more US goods to narrow the gap. The proposal comes amid rising global trade disputes and US President Donald Trump's recent trade memorandum ordering federal agencies to complete comprehensive reviews of trade issues by April 1.

images.alt_text: Thailand aims to have an emissions trading system in full operation by 2030, and is preparing to impose a carbon tax of 200 baht a tonne on oil products.
Thailand is in early discussions with carmakers to introduce a car trade-in and scrapping scheme in a bid to revive an industry hit by its biggest crisis in decades.
Thai exports increased 13.6 per cent in January from a year earlier, beating a forecast for a 7.15 per cent rise in a Reuters poll, and compared with December’s 8.7 per cent increase.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher on Thursday; STI up 0.5%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore closed up 0.5% on Thursday, tracking regional indices, with local banks OCBC, DBS, and UOB rising 0.1%, 0.7%, and 1.2% respectively. The top gainer was Sats, up 2.3%, while Seatrium was the biggest loser, down 1.4%. Regional indices, including the Kospi and Nikkei 225, also ended higher, while the Bursa Malaysia KLCI slipped 0.4%. Chinese Premier Li Qiang's comments on strengthening the platform economy may provide a boost to offshore Chinese equities.

images.alt_text: Mandarin Oriental International posted an underlying profit of US$74.7 million for FY2024, down US$81 million from a year ago.

site_title: Australian, New Zealand dollars hit one-week highs amid tariff reprieve, euro strength
summary: The Australian and New Zealand currencies reached one-week highs amid US tariff relief for automakers, while the euro's strength pinned the US dollar at four-month lows. The Australian dollar rose 0.3% to US$0.6354, and the New Zealand dollar rose 0.3% to US$0.5743, marking four consecutive gains. Analysts expect the AUD/USD to break above the 200-day moving average, indicating an end to the downtrend, but others predict a rebound in the US dollar in Q2.

images.alt_text: New Zealand and Australian dollars are arranged for a photograph in Sydney, Australia, on Tuesday, Oct. 22, 2007. The Australian dollar rose to the highest in almost three months and New Zealand's reached the strongest since October against the euro as the extra yield offered by the two nations' bonds over German debt increased. Photographer: Jack Atley/Bloomberg News
The study revealed that post-pandemic, higher incomes have grown faster than middle incomes, while the growth of lower incomes has stagnated, further exacerbating inequality.
Bank of New Zealand Governor Adrian Orr (pictured) has resigned. Deputy Governor Christian Hawkesby will be the acting governor until March 31, a central bank statement said.
Australia’s business conditions have also been quite buoyant and retail sales strengthened in five of the six months to January.
Two of Australia's biggest pension funds say they have excess capital to deploy to real estate, with one already diversifying to the UK in late 2023.

site_title: New Zealand home building declines for ninth straight quarter
summary: New Zealand's residential construction declined for the ninth consecutive quarter, with spending in constant prices falling 4.9% to NZ$4.5 billion in the latest quarter. This is the lowest level since the second quarter of 2020. The construction industry has struggled due to rising costs and finance, despite falling interest rates. Non-residential construction also declined, and building consents fell 7.2% over the past 12 months. The decline suggests the economy may post modest growth, contradicting expectations of a stronger rebound.

images.alt_text: The interest rate on a one-year fixed-rate home loan is as low as 5.19 per cent at one local bank, down from an average of 7.3 per cent at the start of 2024.
Bank of New Zealand Governor Adrian Orr (pictured) has resigned. Deputy Governor Christian Hawkesby will be the acting governor until March 31, a central bank statement said.
The statistics agency publishes fourth-quarter GDP data on Mar 20.

site_title: Lufthansa 2024 profits dive amid strikes, rising costs
summary: Lufthansa reported a 2024 net profit of 1.38 billion euros, down 18% from the previous year, amid strikes, rising costs, and delays in aircraft deliveries. The airline's revenues increased by 6% to 37.6 billion euros. Despite a better-than-expected forecast, Lufthansa attributed the decline to strikes and higher costs. However, the company has launched a turnaround plan, which aims to boost earnings this year and achieve "significantly higher" operating profits in 2025.

images.alt_text: Lufthansa now has operational control of ITA, even if Italy - which previously had a 100 per cent stake - retains the right of review over strategic decisions.

site_title: Seven & i said to plan large-scale share buyback
summary: Seven & i Holdings is planning a large-scale share buyback, valued at about 2 trillion yen ($13.4 billion), in an effort to boost its valuation. The company's stock surged 10% in Tokyo trading after the announcement, following a 20% decline this year due to pressure from a potential takeover by Alimentation Couche-Tard. The buyback plan is expected to be voted on by the board on Thursday, with the company having a remaining buyback budget of 100 billion yen.

images.alt_text: Seven & i, which has more than 80,000 7-Eleven stores in 20 countries and regions, will hold a board meeting and then announce the leadership change along with plans including the sale of non-core assets to Bain Capital, sources said.
Bain Capital and Seven & i are hammering out details of a transaction that could be announced as soon as this week.
The retailer’s market capitalisation is about 5.2 trillion yen, below the US$47 billion takeover proposal by Couche-Tard, owner of Circle K shops.
If Couche-Tard succeeds in winning control of Seven & i, it would be the biggest takeover of a Japanese company.
As well as expanding in Europe, Seven & i aims to re-enter Indonesia “at all costs” after it withdrew in 2017, Wakabayashi says.

site_title: Boeing needs to change its insular culture, CEO says in company-wide meeting
summary: Boeing CEO Kelly Ortberg has called for a cultural change within the company, citing its insular culture and lack of communication across divisions as major issues. The company, which lost nearly $12 billion in 2024, is struggling to produce its best-selling 737 MAX and other programs. Ortberg plans to develop an action plan based on an employee survey, which he described as "brutal to leadership." He emphasized the importance of improving management and employee morale, and praised employees for their commitment to the company despite its struggles.

images.alt_text: The order reflected an expected increase in passenger demand, including from overseas visitors, to Japan.
Mike Delaney was appointed Boeing's chief aerospace safety officer in 2021.
The Seattle-based aerospace manufacturer said it will issue 60-day notices of involuntary layoffs to the affected employees in the coming weeks.

site_title: Japan PM Ishiba says high US tariffs make investment difficult
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba stated that high US tariffs imposed by President Donald Trump's administration make investments in the US difficult. Ishiba emphasized the importance of highlighting how Japanese investments benefit both Japan and the US economy. Almost 90% of Japanese companies expect Trump's policies to hurt business, according to a Reuters survey. Ishiba plans to send Industry Minister Yoji Muto to the US for talks with Trump administration officials.

site_title: Malaysia central bank keeps key rate at 3%, as expected
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, maintained its benchmark interest rate at 3% on Thursday, in line with market expectations. The bank forecasts the economy to expand between 4.5% and 5.5% in 2025, with inflation expected to remain manageable. Despite global economic uncertainties, the central bank expects sustained economic activity driven by domestic demand. Analysts predict potential inflation increase in 2026 due to planned fuel subsidy cuts.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's central bank left the benchmark interest rate unchanged for the ninth monetary policy meeting, noting that the country's economic momentum continues.

site_title: Hong Kong investors to bail out Australia’s Star Entertainment, AFR reports
summary: Hong Kong investors Chow Tai Fook Enterprises and Far East Consortium are set to provide a loan of up to A$50 million to struggling casino operator Star Entertainment to prevent it from going into voluntary administration. The loan will allow Star to dispose of its Brisbane-based casino and avoid insolvency. The investors had previously offered to acquire a 50% stake in Star's Destination Brisbane joint venture, but the company declined, citing insufficient value. The deal aims to save Star from financial collapse.

site_title:
Vietnam’s February data signals growth risks 
amid subdued demand, tariff woes
summary: Vietnam's economy posted a monthly trade deficit of $1.6 billion in February, marking its first deficit in nine months, as imports surged amid subdued demand and tariff woes. The country's growth target for the first quarter is at risk, with trade, production, and consumption growth below official targets. Foreign investment pledges, particularly from China, surged, with China accounting for 31% of new projects and 31% of pledged capital. This trend is expected to continue as manufacturers seek alternative production hubs due to US-China trade tensions, posing a challenge to Vietnam's ambitious 8% growth target for 2025.

images.alt_text: Last year, Vietnam’s GDP expanded by 7.09%, one of the fastest rates in Asia. The growth figure also beat forecasts of most major international think tanks, including that of the Asian Development Bank and International Monetary Fund.
The reflection of the VinFast logo is seen on a car's window during India's five-day auto show in New Delhi, India, January 18, 2025. REUTERS/Priyanshu Singh
Chubb has in recent years been boosting its presence in Asia.
Washington has already imposed anti-dumping duties on multiple Vietnamese steel exports and producers, in some cases even higher than 25 per cent

site_title: Gold little changed; investors await US payrolls data
summary: Gold prices remained steady at US$2,917.90 an ounce as investors awaited US non-farm payrolls data to assess the Federal Reserve's interest rate trajectory amid growing trade tensions. US President Donald Trump exempted automakers from his 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico for a month, while trade tensions with Canada, Mexico, and China continue to strain relations. Higher interest rates have dampened gold's appeal as a hedge against inflation and political risks. Market attention now shifts to the non-farm payrolls report on Friday for further policy cues.

images.alt_text: Spot gold slipped 0.1 per cent to US$2,916.09 an ounce.

site_title: China’s fuel production cuts could undermine global oil demand
summary: China's top economic planner has ordered the country's oil refiners to cut fuel output and increase production of chemicals. This move could undermine global oil demand, particularly for traditional suppliers, as China's refining industry is already struggling with overcapacity. The country's small, independent refiners, mainly located in Shandong province, are most at risk, and the shift away from transport fuels could exacerbate the issue.

images.alt_text: Teapots, which handle over a fifth of the country’s oil refining, are particularly vulnerable because they already operate on razor-thin margins.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Mandarin Oriental, Sats
summary: Mandarin Oriental International posted an underlying profit of US$74.7 million for FY2024, down 8% from the previous year. The hotelier attributed the loss to lower branding fees, offset by strong growth in recurring hotel management fees. Sats announced plans to invest S$100 million to upgrade Changi Airfreight Centre terminals, aiming to raise cargo handling capacity by 30%.

site_title: Singapore semicon companies, including startups, can tap new S$500 million national fab facility by 2027
summary: Singapore has announced a new S$500 million national fabrication facility for its semiconductor industry, set to be completed by 2027. The facility, under the National Semiconductor Translation and Innovation Centre (NSTIC), aims to support the scaling and translation of research and development (R&D) in advanced packaging. The government also plans to enhance its Global Innovation Alliance to support startups, and invest in biomedical R&D infrastructure, with a focus on cell therapy and biopharma manufacturing. The government aims to drive economic growth through nurturing strong enterprises through innovation, strengthening connectivity, and investing in people.

images.alt_text: DPM Gan also gave details of the S$1 billion Private Credit Growth Fund, which PM Wong had said would provide “more financing options for high-growth local enterprises”.
Singapore’s foreign policy must always be a balance between realism and idealism. Despite its size however, Dr Balakrishnan said Singapore has refused to adopt a “fatalistic posture”.
Budget 2025: S$3 billion top-up to National Productivity Fund; S$1 billion for biotech, semicon R&D
The acceleration programme will involve partnerships with corporate giants in Sweden, such as Arla Foods and H&M.
The S$180 million National Semiconductor Translation and Innovation Centre will be open in Fusionopolis from April this year.

site_title: Singapore to launch request for proposal to buy carbon offsets
summary: Singapore plans to launch a request for proposal to buy carbon offsets and commit S$62.5 million to develop a test-bedding facility for less mature low-carbon solutions. The country aims to reduce emissions to 45-50 million tonnes by 2035, with carbon credits and decarbonizing its power sector as key strategies. The low-carbon technology translational test bed will support companies in scaling up low-carbon solutions, and Singapore has signed agreements with three countries, including Bhutan, to meet Paris Agreement requirements.

Transition credits are being piloted in two coal plants in the Philippines. One of these plants is the South Luzon Thermal Energy Corporation’s plant in Batangas, which is owned by Acen, the energy arm of Philippine Stock Exchange-listed Ayala Group.

site_title: Logitech targets US$2 billion share buyback, confirms 2025 outlook
summary: Logitech International plans to buy back US$2 billion worth of shares over three years, increasing its current program by US$600 million. The company confirmed its 2025 sales outlook, forecasting growth of 1-3% to reach US$4.53-4.71 billion. Logitech aims for long-term annual sales growth of 7-10%, with a focus on expanding into education, healthcare, and selling products directly to businesses. CEO Hanneke Faber emphasized the company's strategy to extend leadership in core categories, enter new verticals, and leverage AI.

images.alt_text: Logitech expects non-GAAP operating income to be between US$720 million and US$750 million for the year.
Daniel Borel, co-founder of Logitech, speaks during the Annual General Meeting of Logitech.

site_title: Japan’s Seven & i appoints first foreign CEO, announces restructuring
summary: Seven & i Holdings, Japan's operator of the 7-Eleven convenience store chain, appointed its first foreign CEO, Stephen Dacus, to fend off a US$47 billion overseas takeover bid from Canadian Circle-K operator Alimentation Couche-Tard. As part of its restructuring plan, the company will sell its superstore unit to Bain Capital for 814.7 billion yen and buy back about two trillion yen worth of shares through fiscal year 2030. The move aims to engineer a recovery and boost market value, but some analysts question whether it will be enough to deter the takeover bid.

images.alt_text: Bain Capital and Seven & i are hammering out details of a transaction that could be announced as soon as this week.
The retailer’s market capitalisation is about 5.2 trillion yen, below the US$47 billion takeover proposal by Couche-Tard, owner of Circle K shops.
If Couche-Tard succeeds in winning control of Seven & i, it would be the biggest takeover of a Japanese company.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Thursday, March 6, 2025
summary: Stocks rose on Thursday as US President Trump exempted some automakers from tariffs for one month, boosting the sector. Alibaba shares jumped 7% after unveiling its latest DeepSeek contender. Japan's 10-year bond yield reached its highest since 2009, while Malaysia is discussing ways to absorb the impact of US tariffs on the semiconductor industry. These market movements were seen as a response to Trump's announcement and a sign of the ongoing global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: General Motors shares were up 7.2 per cent and Ford gained 5.8 per cent on Wednesday, but both companies’ shares are still down on the year.
Alibaba has pledged to invest more than 380 billion yuan on AI infrastructure such as data centres over the next three years.
Japanese yields are also rising as investors speculate that the Bank of Japan will continue to hike rates.
Tengku Zafrul Aziz, Malaysia’s Minister of International Trade and Industry, says: “We built a strong ecosystem around the semiconductor industry and it has been a major part of our exports.”

site_title: Financial penalties for public agencies ‘not meaningful’; officers held accountable for NRIC disclosures: SM Teo
summary: Senior Minister Teo Chee Hean stated that imposing financial penalties on a public agency for a breach, such as the disclosure of full NRIC numbers on Acra's Bizfile portal, is "not meaningful" as the costs would be borne by the public purse. Instead, "necessary actions" will be taken against responsible officers, including counselling, retraining, and performance grade reductions, with the ministers overseeing Acra and the Smart Nation initiative facing evaluation by the Prime Minister.

images.alt_text: Head of civil service Leo Yip said the disclosures were caused by a “confluence of several shortcomings”.

This comes amid public confusion towards the government’s stance towards the use of NRIC numbers after it emerged that NRIC numbers were disclosed in full on the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority’s (Acra) Bizfile portal.

site_title: Air New Zealand CEO Greg Foran resigns amid broader industry challenges
summary: Air New Zealand CEO Greg Foran has announced his resignation in October after five years at the helm, amid industry challenges. Foran led the airline through global supply chain disruptions and engine maintenance issues, including a recent grounding of up to 11 aircraft. Despite these challenges, the airline reported an 18% drop in first-half profit in February. The company has begun a global search for a new CEO, with Chair Therese Walsh praising Foran's leadership in mitigating disruptions and maintaining customer service.

images.alt_text: Qantas announced a special dividend of 9.9 Australian cents per share, its first since fiscal 2000.
Qatar Airways is still awaiting government approval for its purchase of a 25 per cent stake in Virgin Australia from the US private equity firm Bain Capital.
The change applies to all visitor visas, including tourists and people visiting family, as well as partners and guardians on longer-term visas.

site_title: Japan’s top currency diplomat calls for balance between economic efficiency, security
summary: Japan's top currency diplomat, Atsushi Mimura, emphasized the need to strike a balance between economic efficiency and security amid rising protectionism and a reevaluation of globalization's value. He warned that an overemphasis on security could decrease global efficiency and increase tensions. Mimura urged policymakers to find a "middle way" that addresses globalization's negative aspects while avoiding protectionism. This balance is crucial in maintaining the global economy's stability.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: Japan's newly-appointed Vice Finance Minister for International Affairs, the country's new top currency diplomat, Atsushi Mimura speaks during an interview with Reuters at the Finance Ministry in Tokyo, Japan July 30, 2024. REUTERS/Issei Kato/File Photo

site_title: Home of Japanophiles
summary: A Singapore penthouse, dubbed "Mado Apartment," reflects the homeowners' love for Japanese culture and design. The 3,500 sqft home, designed by Melvin Keng, incorporates traditional Japanese elements such as shoji screens, lacquerware, and tea caddies. The interior design prioritizes functionality and flexibility, with features like sliding glass doors, round windows, and ample storage. The couple, who are avid collectors of Japanese pop culture and art, have infused their passions into every aspect of the home, creating a unique and sophisticated space that balances comfort and privacy.

images.alt_text: This old apartment in Laguna Park has been turned into a dual key home.

site_title: Xi’s growth goal will need big stimulus if trade war escalates
summary: China's President Xi Jinping has set an ambitious growth goal of 5% for 2025, despite a looming trade war with the US. If US tariffs rise further, analysts say Beijing may need to unleash significant stimulus to hit the target. Unleashing big stimulus would undermine Xi's efforts to rein in surging debt, and Chinese officials are trying to balance projecting strength while managing financial risks. A deal with the US or devaluing the currency could help mitigate the impact, but Xi is keeping calm and has vowed to "fight till the end" if war is what the US wants.

images.alt_text: China has the world’s largest shipbuilding sector, producing more than half of the merchant vessels globally, while the US industry has been in decline.
Shipping containers at the Port of Los Angeles. The extra 10% duty on Chinese goods adds to a 10% tariff imposed by President Trump on Feb 4 to punish Beijing over the US fentanyl overdose crisis.
The US has argued that China supplies chemicals used in fentanyl production.
Xi has a delicate balancing act to maintain in providing the right dose of stimulus to hit the growth target while ensuring aid goes to the parts of the economy that need it most.

site_title: Ares, Indonesia wealth fund partner for investment opportunities
summary: Ares Management has partnered with Indonesia's Indonesia Investment Authority to invest in the country through hybrid capital and securitization, with a potential annual investment of up to $500 million. This partnership comes as sovereign wealth funds increase their stakes in the private debt market due to banks' pullback from riskier lending. Ares Asia Credit funds have $11.5 billion in assets under management, and the agreement is seen as a strategic move to tap into Indonesia's growing economy.

images.alt_text: Indonesia plans to launch a second sovereign wealth fund named Danantara Indonesia on Feb 24, which aims to manage assets exceeding US$900 billion.

site_title: Piyush Gupta reflects on his 15 years as DBS CEO as he prepares to hand reins to Tan Su Shan
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta is retiring on March 28 after 15 years, handing over to deputy CEO Tan Su Shan. Gupta reflects on the bank's digital transformation, citing the challenges and successes, including changing the culture to be more innovative and entrepreneurial. He emphasizes the importance of creating a common vision, empowering employees, and leveraging technology, artificial intelligence, and Managing through Journeys to drive growth. Gupta expresses gratitude to the board, management, and employees, confident that Su Shan will lead the bank to further success.

images.alt_text: Piyush Gupta will be retiring at the upcoming AGM “as part of the board renewal process”.
DBS deputy chief executive and incoming CEO Tan Su Shan during an interview with The Straits Times at DBS HQ on Aug 12, 2024.

site_title: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta gets a S$17.6 million pay package for 2024, a jump of 56.5% from 2023 and up 14.3% from 2022
summary: DBS CEO Piyush Gupta received a total remuneration of S$17.6 million for the 2024 financial year, a 56.5% year-on-year increase. The package includes a base salary of S$1.5 million, a higher cash bonus of S$6.6 million, and deferred remuneration of about S$9.4 million. Gupta will retire at the upcoming AGM as part of the board renewal process, with Deputy CEO Tan Su Shan succeeding him. DBS reported a record full-year net profit of S$11.29 billion and a 51% total shareholder return for 2024, the highest in the bank's history.

images.alt_text: CMG20241203-LongKH03/龙国雄/DBS [Marina Bay Financial Centre]

site_title: Analysts upgrade UMS Integration to ‘buy’ on positive FY2025 outlook
summary: Analysts from UOB Kay Hian, Maybank, and DBS have upgraded UMS Integration to "buy" with target prices of S$1.21, S$1.16, and S$1.31, respectively, due to its positive FY2025 outlook. The semiconductor manufacturer's production is set to ramp up, with a new key customer contributing S$20 million to FY2024 revenue, expected to grow to S$50 million in FY2025. Despite missing consensus earnings estimates, analysts expect improved execution and higher margins, with DBS raising its earnings estimates for FY2025 and FY2026 by 7% and 8%, respectively.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s government and central bank have forecast the economy to expand between 4.5 per cent and 5.5 per cent in 2025, following 5.1 per cent growth in 2024.

Maybank upgraded the counter to “buy” from “hold”, and raised its target price to S$1.69 from S$1.60 previously. Meanwhile, RHB upgraded FR to “buy” from “neutral”, and raised its target price to S$1.85, from S$1.65 previously.

site_title: New charges for 3 men allegedly linked to servers that likely contained Nvidia chips
summary: Three Singaporean men, Aaron Woon Guo Jie, Alan Wei Zhaolun, and Li Ming, have been charged with fraud related to allegedly exporting computer servers containing Nvidia chips to Malaysia. The servers were linked to US firms Dell and Supermicro, and investigators have seized 42 devices and requested bank statements. The men, who worked at Aperia Cloud Services, were accused of making false representations about the servers' final destination. Li, who was already facing a fraud charge, was remanded for eight days due to concerns about collusion and contamination of evidence.

images.alt_text: SANTA CLARA, CALIFORNIA - FEBRUARY 26: The Nvidia logo is displayed on a sign at the Nvidia headquarters on February 26, 2025 in Santa Clara, California. Technology company Nvidia will report fourth-quarter earnings today after the closing bell.   Justin Sullivan/Getty Images/AFP (Photo by JUSTIN SULLIVAN / GETTY IMAGES NORTH AMERICA / Getty Images via AFP)
The trio’s cases have been adjourned to Mar 7.

site_title: US takes down list of federal properties for possible sale
summary: The US General Services Administration (GSA) removed a list of 443 federal properties for possible sale, including iconic buildings such as the Old Post Office in Washington, after receiving an "overwhelming amount of interest". The list was initially posted on March 5, 2025, but was taken down the following day. The move comes as part of President Donald Trump's downsizing drive, which has already led to 100,000 workers taking buyouts or being fired. The GSA plans to release a new list in the near future.

images.alt_text: Among the departments whose buildings are up for sale are Agriculture, Energy, Health and Human Services, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Justice and Veterans Affairs.

site_title: Candy maker Mars is selling biggest US bond of year to fund Kellanova buy
summary: Mars, the US-based candy maker, sold $26 billion in US high-grade bonds to fund its acquisition of rival foodmaker Kellanova, the largest US corporate bond sale of the year. The deal saw strong demand, with investors placing orders for $114.4 billion worth of notes, and resulted in Mars' credit ratings being cut by one level by both S&P Global Ratings and Moody's Ratings. The acquisition, valued at nearly $36 billion, will bring brands including Pringles and Cheez-It to Mars, further diversifying its portfolio.

images.alt_text: Depending on its final size, Mars' bonds offering could feature among the top 10 largest M&A financing deals in the investment-grade bond market since 2013, according to Informa Global Markets data.

site_title: Amazon Prime Video tests AI-assisted dubbing
summary: Amazon Prime Video is testing AI-assisted dubbing for its international content, combining AI technology with human expertise to ensure quality control. The pilot program will feature 12 licensed movies and series with English and Latin American Spanish dubbing options. This move aims to make content more accessible to viewers worldwide, following similar efforts by YouTube and other companies. Amazon's approach differs from some competitors, prioritizing human expertise alongside AI technology.

site_title: Apple’s use of SiTime in iPhone 16e fuels stock rally for chipmaker
summary: Apple's use of SiTime's custom modem chip, C1, in the iPhone 16e model has fueled a 20% stock rally for chipmaker SiTime, with shares rising to $182.19 on Wednesday. The company, which generates $200 million in revenue annually, has a significant contract with Apple, with TechInsights estimating the cost per SiTime part in each phone to be around 50 US cents. SiTime's precision-timing technology has potential applications beyond smartphones, including in cars and military navigation systems.

images.alt_text: The M4 chip comes to the MacBook Air after first launching in the iPad Pro last May.

site_title: US Senate confirms ex-Trump lawyer to number two Justice job
summary: The US Senate confirmed Todd Blanche, President Donald Trump's former personal lawyer, as deputy attorney general, the second-highest ranking job in the Justice Department, with a 52-46 vote. Blanche defended Trump in his hush money trial and federal cases. Trump has named three of his former lawyers to top Justice Department jobs, following a wave of firings and demotions since he took office. The appointments include Emil Bove as principal associate deputy attorney general and John Sauer as Solicitor General.

images.alt_text: Workers pack avocados at a packing plant in Michoacan, Mexico, Feb 5, 2025. site_title: Australia’s economic inequality rises to highest in 20 years
summary: Australia's economic inequality has reached its highest level in over 20 years, according to a recent survey. Higher incomes have grown faster than middle incomes, while lower incomes have stagnated, exacerbating inequality. The Gini coefficient, a key measure of income inequality, rose to 0.32 in 2022, the first time it exceeded 0.31 since 2001. This is partly due to the decline in real incomes, with more than half of respondents reporting a decline between 2021 and 2022. The survey also found increased inequality among women, with full-time female employees experiencing a 4.8% drop in earnings.

images.alt_text: Australia’s business conditions have also been quite buoyant and retail sales strengthened in five of the six months to January.
Consumers have also benefited from a slowdown in inflation and the large cuts to income taxes.
The trend of employees returning to office has continued to gain momentum in Australia and could pick up further this year, says CBRE.

site_title: Google tests new AI Mode to handle more complicated queries
summary: Google is testing a new AI-powered search mode, AI Mode, which allows users to ask multipart questions and receive a cohesive answer summarizing multiple lines of inquiry. The feature, set to roll out to users who have signed up for experimental features, uses Google's Gemini 2.0 AI model to process text, images, and video. AI Mode aims to address the growing competition from OpenAI and other startups, but has raised concerns about the potential impact on website traffic and revenue.

images.alt_text: A federal judge is set to rule on how Google must change its practices following hearings scheduled for next month.
The retrenchment comes in the wake of slower growth from Google’s cloud business, as well as massive spending aimed at supporting the tech giant’s ambitions in AI.
The Digital Markets Act, which came into effect in March 2024, sets out a list of dos and don’ts for digital gatekeepers such as Google as part of the EU’s goal of securing a level playing field.

Chegg, an online education company that offers textbook rentals, homework help, and tutoring, said in the lawsuit filed in Washington, D.C., that Google is co-opting publishers’ content to keep users on its own site, erasing financial incentives to publish.

site_title: Japan’s 10-year bond yield reaches highest since June 2009
summary: Japan's 10-year government bond yield reached 1.5% on March 6, its highest since June 2009, amid rising investor expectations that the Bank of Japan will continue to hike interest rates. The move follows a significant sell-off in German bunds, which soared to 31 basis points. The Bank of Japan's deputy governor, Shinichi Uchida, signaled that the benchmark interest rate remains on a gradual upward path. This comes as investors also show caution ahead of a 30-year bond auction later Thursday.

site_title: Elon Musk says US Post Office, Amtrak should be privatised
summary: Elon Musk advises US President Donald Trump to privatize the US Postal Service and passenger railroad Amtrak, citing their financial losses. The US Postal Service has lost over $100 billion since 2007, while Amtrak reported an adjusted operating loss of $705 million for the 12 months ending September 30. Musk believes privatization could improve efficiency, but the move would require congressional approval. Amtrak has seen a record high in ridership, while the Postal Service has reported a fourth-quarter profit of $144 million.

images.alt_text: Musk’s Doge has said it has saved US$105 billion so far, in part by cancelling leases on government properties.

site_title: Smaller family offices may face ‘onerous’ challenges due to proposed tweaks to GIP: observers
summary: Singapore's Global Investor Programme (GIP) may pose diversification challenges for smaller family offices due to proposed tweaks, which require new applicants under the "family office" option to allocate at least S$50 million of assets to Singapore-listed equities. The move aims to boost the local stock market, but observers note that it may deter some investors, particularly those with smaller assets. The changes are seen as a step in the right direction, but may not be a game-changer for diversifying portfolios in the small Singapore market.

images.alt_text: With IPOs starting to pick up in the US, SGX anticipates a positive ripple effect on markets worldwide, including Asia and Singapore.

site_title: Deluge of Trump tariffs seen hitting household budgets
summary: US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Mexico, Canada, and China are expected to lead to a 1.0-1.2% hike in consumer prices, a yearly toll of $1,600-$2,000 per household. Tariffs on Canadian crude will also raise petrol prices, with potential increases of 40 cents per gallon. The tariffs are expected to raise up to $1.5 trillion for the US government in 2025, but are characterized as regressive taxes that disproportionately affect low-income consumers. Industry experts warn of potential price increases for electronics, fresh produce, and automobiles.

images.alt_text: Rising price pressures could be worsened by a trade war, triggered by President Donald Trump’s new 25 per cent tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada, which took effect on Tuesday, along with a doubling of duties on Chinese goods to 20 per cent.

site_title: Building a reputation with lighter, greener construction materials
summary: Singapore-based Buildo Engineering is revolutionizing the construction industry with its innovative, lighter, and greener materials, including autoclaved lightweight aerated concrete (ALC) panels and cork-based products. ALC panels reduce the carbon footprint of construction projects by up to 80% and provide better thermal insulation, while cork is a renewable, sustainable alternative to wood. With its commitment to sustainability and employee well-being, Buildo has transformed Singapore's skyline and won several awards, including the Enterprise 50 Award and the Special Recognition – Sustainability Innovation Award 2023.

site_title: Bain nears deal to buy Seven & i’s Supermarket assets: sources
summary: Bain Capital is nearing a deal to acquire Seven & i Holdings' supermarket business, with a potential deal valued at over $6.3 billion. The US-based private equity firm is hammering out details with Seven & i, which plans to hold a board meeting on Thursday to vote on the deal. The sale follows years of calls from investors to hive off the lower-margin supermarket business and focus on the company's higher-margin convenience store business. Talks are ongoing, and the deal may still fall apart.

site_title: South Korea’s inflation eases as energy and food prices steady
summary: South Korea's inflation eased in February, with consumer prices advancing 2% from the previous year, slower than the 2.2% rise in January. The Bank of Korea has cut its benchmark interest rate three times since October to support the economy amid a trade-dependent economy facing headwinds from the Trump administration's protectionist policies. The country's export sector is slowing, and the outlook for global trade is weakening due to rising protectionism. The government is working on an extra budget to boost consumption and other sectors.

images.alt_text: South Korea in recent years has designated 12 industries as “national strategic technologies” with targeted financial support.

US President Donald Trump during a joint session of Congress in the House Chamber of the US Capitol in Washington, D.C., March 4, 2025. Trump said that the planned natural gas pipeline in Alaska would be one of the largest in the world.

site_title: Trump exempts some automakers from Canada, Mexico tariffs for one month
summary: US President Donald Trump has exempted some automakers from his 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico for one month, as long as they comply with the existing US-Mexico-Canada Agreement. This reprieve sparked a rebound in auto stocks, with General Motors and Ford gaining 7.2% and 5.8% respectively. However, the tariffs remain a threat to US businesses and consumer confidence, and trade tensions with Canada and Mexico continue to escalate. The exemptions apply to vehicles that meet the USMCA's content rules, which require 75% North American content for duty-free access to the US market.

site_title: US services sector expands; price growth accelerates amid tariffs
summary: US services sector growth unexpectedly picked up in February, with the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) survey showing a non-manufacturing purchasing managers index (PMI) of 53.5, above the forecast of 52.6. However, rising price pressures, triggered by President Trump's new tariffs on imports from Mexico and Canada, and a doubling of duties on Chinese goods, may worsen inflation and slow economic growth. The combination of high inflation and slowing economic growth could lead the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates, while some businesses report "chaos" and "great uncertainty" due to the tariffs.

site_title: Saudi Aramco weighs bid for BP’s Castrol lubricant assets
summary: Saudi Aramco is considering a potential bid for BP's Castrol lubricant assets, valued at around $10 billion, as part of its strategy to deepen its reach in oil-consuming countries. Aramco may combine the Castrol assets with its Valvoline lubricants unit, and is particularly interested in India and other fast-growing markets. The deliberations are still in the early stages, and other bidders are also interested in the assets.

images.alt_text: BP had aimed to cut oil and gas output by 40 per cent by 2030, but was last year reported to have abandoned the target.
BP’s profit after tax tumbled to US$381 million last year from US$15.2 billion in 2023 in the face of higher costs and weaker oil and gas prices.
The Castrol brand serves customers in more than 150 countries in the automotive, marine, industrial, aerospace and energy production sectors.

site_title: Trump vows to ‘usher in the greatest and most successful era’ in America’s history. But is his honeymoon over?
summary: US President Donald Trump's honeymoon period may be over as his approval ratings continue to drop, with recent polls showing 49% disapproving and 45% approving of his presidency. Trump's tariffs program, which aimed to fight inflation, is now seen as a potential cause of upward pressure on prices, while his federal cuts are unpopular with many voters. The president's forceful start to his presidency has led to a decline in his approval ratings, with many Americans questioning his ability to handle the economy, and nearly 60% expecting grocery store prices to rise in the coming months.

site_title: Everything, bar the kitchen sink, to upend trans-Pacific sea trade
summary: The US Trade Representative (USTR) has proposed a series of restrictions and levies on Chinese state-owned Cosco container ships, effectively stopping them from calling at US ports. The proposed levies range from $500,000 to $1.5 million, targeting Chinese-built vessels, and would also impose additional fees on shipping firms with orders for Chinese-made vessels. The USTR aims to eliminate China's dominant position in shipbuilding, logistics, and container production, citing concerns over market power, pricing, and access.

images.alt_text: Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was one of the Singapore Exchange’s top-performing stocks in 2024.

site_title: US economic activity up slightly as tariff worries rise: Federal Reserve survey
summary: US economic activity rose slightly but unevenly since mid-January, with employment increasing and prices rising modestly. Businesses and households expressed optimism despite rising uncertainty about President Trump's policies, which include increasing import duties and restricting immigration. The Federal Reserve's "Beige Book" survey noted growing anxiety about tariffs, with 49 mentions of tariffs, up from 23 in December. The Fed plans to keep interest rates steady at their March 18-19 meeting, citing a healthy labour market and slow but bumpy progress toward its 2% inflation goal.

site_title: Europe: Shares recover after Germany agrees to debt rules overhaul, creates special fund
summary: European shares recovered 0.91% to 556.09 points on Wednesday after Germany agreed to overhaul borrowing rules to boost defense spending and revive growth. The move led to gains in construction and defense stocks, with cement maker Heidelberg Materials rising 17.5% and defense stocks Rheinmetall and Renk up 7.2% and 6.8% respectively. The 500-billion-euro infrastructure fund and loosening of federal debt brake are expected to have a bigger impact on growth, with wage growth and inflation likely to be stronger than anticipated.

images.alt_text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished 1.1 per cent higher at 43,006.59 on Wednesday.

site_title: New Zealand housing market shows signs of life as prices gain
summary: New Zealand's housing market showed signs of life in February, with prices rising 0.3% from January, the largest increase since January 2024. This signals the market's response to falling interest rates, which have been cut by 175 basis points since August. Prices have been little changed since August, after a 4.1% drop in the preceding six months. Experts predict a gradual rise in property values over the medium term, driven by falling mortgage rates and improved economic conditions.

site_title: Oil settles more than 2% lower after US crude stocks build, Opec+ hike, US tariffs
summary: Oil prices dropped for the fourth consecutive session, with Brent futures settling at $69.30 a barrel and US West Texas Intermediate crude settling at $66.31 a barrel, down 2.45% and 2.86%, respectively. The decline was driven by a larger-than-expected build in US crude oil stockpiles, Opec+ plans to increase output in April, and US tariffs on Canada and Mexico. Investors also expressed concerns about a slowdown in economic growth and its impact on energy demand.

site_title: Apple debuts new MacBook Air, Mac Studio with AI-ready chips
summary: Apple has released updated MacBook Air laptops and Mac Studio desktops, featuring the M4 chip, a speedier and AI-focused processor. The new MacBook Air starts at $999 and features a 12-megapixel camera and dual-monitor support, while the Mac Studio offers a choice between M4 Max and M3 Ultra configurations, priced from $1,999 and $3,999, respectively. These updates aim to maintain Apple's sales resurgence and provide consumers with new options for their computer line.

site_title: Singapore to invest S$1 billion in Changi air hub, beyond S$5 billion fund top-up in Budget 2025
summary: Singapore plans to invest S$1 billion over five years to support the development of Changi air hub, in addition to a S$5 billion fund top-up in Budget 2025. This investment aims to enhance connections to other cities, improve aviation infrastructure, technology, and manpower. CAAS plans to increase air links to over 200 cities by the mid-2030s, and develop a 10-year aviation technology road map. The move is expected to boost Changi's capacity by over 50% and support Singapore's position as a key air hub in the Asia-Pacific region.

images.alt_text: Asia-Pacific is expected to lead the world in air travel growth at 5.1 per cent per year, with South-east Asia and India heading that expansion.
Asia-Pacific also saw the most growth and remained the biggest market in both passenger and cargo aviation in 2024.

site_title: More teams, stronger sides as BT Corporate Golf League 2025 tees off
summary: The Business Times Corporate Golf League 2025 is set to tee off on March 6 at Tanah Merah Country Club's Tampines course, with five top golf courses in Singapore hosting the tournament. Nine competitive teams, including defending champions Singapore Pools and last year's runner-up Singapore Global Trust, will compete in a System 36 modified stableford format. The league, which has grown in stature and numbers since its inception in 2010, also features teams from various corporate sponsors and social clubs, aiming to provide a platform for networking and socializing.

SPRINGFIELD, NJ - JUNE 25: Winner, Ruoning Yin poses with the trophy after the final round of the KPMG Women's PGA Championship at Baltusrol Golf Club on Sunday, June 25, 2023 in Springfield, New Jersey. (Photo by Darren Carroll/PGA of America)
From left: Golfers Yin Ruoning, Jeeno Thitikul, Hannah Green, Shannon Tan, Lilia Vu and Charley Hull by the SkyPark Infinity Pool at Marina Bay Sands.

Hannah Green of Australia reacts in jubilation after sinking a birdie on the 18th to win the HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club’s Tanjong Course on March 3, 2024. Fellow golfer Andrea Lee (back facing camera) of USA raises her arm simultaneously to celebrate her competitor’s win.

site_title: Singapore shares mirror Asian indices on Wednesday; STI up 0.2%
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.2% on Wednesday, mirroring regional indices, with 1.5 billion shares changing hands. Yangzijiang Shipbuilding was the top gainer, increasing 3%, while DFI Retail Group was the biggest loser, shedding 1.9%. The broader market saw advancers outnumber decliners 338 to 205. Regional indices, including the Kospi and Nikkei 225, also closed higher, while trade tensions weigh on the US earnings outlook, prompting investors to favor Treasury bills and gold.

images.alt_text: Spot gold slipped 0.1 per cent to US$2,916.09 an ounce.
As of Friday (Feb 28), the counter ended the week at a closing price of S$2.38, plunging  26.1 per cent or S$0.84 from the closing price of S$3.22 on Feb 21 one week prior.
HPL, through a wholly owned subsidiary, proposed to acquire InterContinental Auckland in New Zealand for NZ$180 million (S$138.5 million), the group announced on Tuesday (Mar 4).

site_title: Singapore offers S$40,000 incentive for electric heavy vehicles; co-funds up to S$30,000 for chargers
summary: Singapore has introduced the Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme, offering S$40,000 incentives for new fully electric heavy vehicles (EHVs) and S$30,000 co-funding for chargers, both running for three years from 2026 to 2028. The scheme aims to encourage adoption of cleaner heavy vehicles and reduce emissions. The move is part of Singapore's efforts to decarbonize its land transport sector, with around 52,000 heavy vehicles accounting for 31% of land transport emissions.

images.alt_text: Chinese EV maker BYD has the largest eHGV fleet on the road in Singapore currently, with 44 units owned by waste disposal companies SembWaste and 800 Super.
The opening of the 2,000 square foot BYD showroom comes after Inchcape was appointed as a distributor of the brand in 2023.
A lorry emitting clouds of white smoke on the Pan-Island Expressway (PIE) on 8 February 2012.
The surcharge for vehicles in Band C, that are mostly diesel vehicles, will be raised from the current S$15,000 to S$20,000.
Bugatti previewed its plug-in hybrid Tourbillon hypercar in Singapore,  costing 3.8 million euros (S$5.4 million) before taxes.
The Yutong C11H plug-in hybrid bus is an example of extended-range electric vehicle technology that is gaining ground in China.

site_title: US tariffs will raise drug prices for patients, Sandoz CEO says
summary: US tariffs on imported ingredients and medicines are expected to increase drug prices for patients, according to Sandoz CEO Richard Saynor. The tariffs, aimed at bringing production back to the US, will likely lead to pricing increases and limit access to generic medicines, particularly biosimilars. Saynor warns that this will drive patient-access instability, and pricing increases will be passed on to payers and ultimately to patients. The move is seen as counterintuitive to the interests of patients and healthcare in the US, and Sandoz is working to introduce more biosimilars to capitalize on the opportunity.

images.alt_text: Richard Saynor, chief executive officer of Sandoz Group, speaking during the drugmaker's listing ceremony in Switzerland on Oct. 4.

site_title: Former ST Engineering CEO Tan Pheng Hock dies at 68
summary: Former ST Engineering CEO Tan Pheng Hock, 68, died on March 4, 2025. He grew the company from a Singapore-centric to a global engineering group through significant acquisitions and investments. Tan served as CEO from 2002 to 2016 and received numerous accolades, including the Best CEO Award and Asia's Business Leader of the Year. He also served on the board of Frasers Property and the Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore until his retirement in 2025. The company's board and management described Tan as "deeply saddened" by his death, praising his commitment and passion for the company.

images.alt_text: Shares of ST Engineering (STE) soared over 8 per cent on Monday, as it continued building on big gains in the past week.
ST Engineering led gains on the STI, up xx per cent or xx to xx.

site_title: US: Trump car tariff pause boosts automakers, stocks
summary: US stocks rose 1.1% on Wednesday, led by a pause in tariffs on the car industry, boosting automakers and the broader market. The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished at 43,006.59, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Index rose 1.1% and 1.5% respectively. US automakers, including Stellantis, Ford, and General Motors, saw their shares rise by 6% or more, and auto supply companies gained as well. The move was seen as a positive sign for investors, with some analysts suggesting that President Trump is watching the markets and trying to avoid a bear market.

images.alt_text: Money managers and corporate executives are struggling to cope with the volatility created by Donald Trump’s threatened tariffs.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.6 points, or 0.01 per cent, at the open to 42,518.37.

site_title: Singapore to get new regulations to tackle online sale of non-compliant mobility devices
summary: Singapore will introduce new regulations to tackle the online sale of non-compliant mobility devices, including e-scooters, bicycles, and scooters. The move follows an increase in device-related fires in 2024, with 67 fires involving active mobility devices, up 21.8% from 2023. Enforcement officers will be trained to detect illegal modifications, and retailers will face fines up to S$40,000 for selling non-compliant devices. The government will also increase inspections and collaboration with authorities to curb the import of non-compliant devices.

images.alt_text: Heavy Vehicle Zero Emissions Scheme is for registrations of electric heavy vehicles with a maximum laden weight of more than 3,500 kilogrammes.
The allocation between private hire cars and private cars is best left to the market, said Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor.

site_title: US recession odds are becoming unsettlingly high
summary: US recession odds are increasing due to a combination of policy uncertainties, fragile financial markets, and disappointing economic data releases. Lower-income households are struggling with dwindling savings, maxed-out credit cards, and mounting debt, while the corporate sector is adopting a wait-and-see approach. Inflation is proving stubborn, raising concerns about stagflation and potential policy missteps by the Federal Reserve. While some factors offer a counterweight, such as lower energy prices and deregulation, the balance of risks has shifted, with economist Mohamed El-Erian increasing his recession probability to 25-30%.

images.alt_text: Consumers in the Conference Board survey were less optimistic about the outlook for business conditions and their own income prospects.
The automobile industry is likely to take the biggest hit from tariffs.

People work in an avocado plantation, Jalisco, Mexico, Jan 30, 2025. A gamut of products - ranging from automobiles and avocados from Mexico, to fowl and petroleum from Canada and iPhones from China - will be affected by Donald Trump's tariffs.

site_title: South Korea prepares US$34 billion fund for national strategic industries
summary: South Korea plans to establish a $34 billion policy fund to support domestic companies in strategic industries such as semiconductors, autos, and biopharmaceuticals amid intensifying global competition and protectionism. The fund, managed by the Korea Development Bank, will offer cheap loans and investments to companies in designated national strategic technologies over the next five years. This move aims to enhance national economic security and competitiveness in the face of US President Donald Trump's tariff threats and protectionism.

images.alt_text: The trade-reliant economy faces headwinds from an escalating trade war among major countries.

Outbound shipments from South Korea stood at US$52.60 billion, up 1.0 per cent from a year earlier, preliminary trade data showed on Saturday, weaker than a median 3.8 per cent increase forecast in a Reuters poll of economists.
At the end of 2024, South Korea’s household debt stood at 1,927.3 trillion won (S$1.8 trillion), up 2.2 per cent from a year earlier and the fastest growth in 2-1/2 years.

site_title: EU’s era-defining Clean Industrial Deal for business
summary: The European Union has launched the Clean Industrial Deal (CID), a package aimed at reconciling ambitious decarbonisation goals with global competition. President Ursula von der Leyen seeks to make it an era-defining initiative, but its success depends on adapting to political and economic constraints. The 100 billion euro package pools existing funds to revitalise the EU's clean manufacturing sector, with the goal of leveraging 400 billion euros with private funds. However, critics argue the scale of the investment is modest compared to other countries, such as the US and China, and that the EU's strategy risks falling short without a bolder commitment.

Demonstrators take part in a rally after the announcement of the results of the first round of French parliamentary elections, at Place de la Republique in Paris on June 30, 2024.. site_title: Europe’s property market draws Asian investors fleeing China
summary: Asian investors are shifting their focus away from China's struggling property market, with European private equity players optimistic about the prospects of UK housing and other sectors. China's lacklustre economic growth has led to a decline in interest from Asian investors, who are instead allocating funds to European residential, students' accommodation, and warehouses. European real estate has traditionally appealed to Asian investors, but they are now focusing on specific sectors, according to industry experts.

images.alt_text: The student housing sector has become a core pillar in many property players and investors' investment strategy, given its resilient nature and attractive returns.

site_title: West Coast MRT extension to link Jurong Region Line with Cross Island Line, Circle Line; 2 new lines being studied
summary: Singapore's 2025 budget includes a West Coast MRT extension to the Jurong Region Line, connecting it to the Cross Island Line and Circle Line. The first phase will link the Jurong Region Line's Pandan Reservoir station to the Cross Island Line's West Coast station by the late 2030s. The expansion will improve rail connectivity, increase network flexibility, and reduce travel time for commuters. The government will also invest up to S$1 billion to improve rail reliability over the next five years, focusing on managing rail assets and manpower capabilities.

images.alt_text: The two state land sites at Dairy Farm Walk and Tengah Garden Avenue is expected to yield around 1,400 new private homes.

The upcoming Jurong Region Line will span 24 MRT stations and connect key activity nodes in the western part of Singapore, such as the Jurong Industrial Estate, Jurong Innovation District, Nanyang Technological University and the Tengah new town.
Kassia occupies a site area of 150,839 sq ft with a plot ratio of 1.53.
