site_title: Wall Street banks say markets are flashing signs of rising US recession risk
summary: US recession risk is rising, according to Wall Street banks, with market-implied probability of an economic downturn increasing to 31% from 17% in November, according to JPMorgan Chase. Goldman Sachs also suggests recession risk is edging up at 23% from 14% in January. Economic indicators such as five-year Treasuries and base metals show a toss-up chance of a contraction, with recession probability estimated at 50% by JPMorgan. President Trump's threatened tariffs have contributed to the volatility, with US factory activity and consumer confidence hitting lowest levels since 2021.

images.alt_text: President Donald Trump addresses a joint session of the US Congress at the US Capitol in Washington, D.C., March 4, 2025.

US Vice-President JD Vance (top left) and US House Speaker Mike Johnson (top right) applaud as US President Donald Trump addresses a joint session of the US Congress in the House Chamber of the US Capitol, Washington, D.C., March 4, 2025.
“Canada initiated dispute proceedings yesterday against the US at the WTO on the additional tariffs”, following a similar complaint filed by Beijing over fresh US levies on Chinese goods.
Trailer trucks queue to cross into the United States at the Otay Mesa Port of Entry, in Tijuana, Mexico, February 10, 2025. REUTERS/Jorge Duenes
The US has argued that China supplies chemicals used in fentanyl production.
Consumers may find some vehicles vanish altogether as automakers stop producing models squeezed especially hard.
Trump’s comments sent US stocks down sharply in late afternoon trading.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 5)
summary: Housing developers in Singapore will have more flexibility in large-scale projects, with a six-month to one-year extension of the critical sales deadline. COE premiums rose in most categories except for mainstream cars. Family offices in Singapore and Asia-Pacific have shown sustained interest in real estate investments despite macroeconomic uncertainty. The first Mount Pleasant BTO flats will be launched in October. The Silver Housing Bonus scheme has been extended to more private property owners who downsize. The Straits Times Index rose 0.2% on Wednesday, mirroring regional indices.

site_title: Family offices to increase real estate bets ahead of rebound
summary: Family offices are increasing their real estate bets ahead of a rebound in the commercial real estate market. 44% of surveyed family offices plan to boost their real estate allocations, with a focus on residential and industrial sectors. The market has seen an 8% increase in global real estate investment to $806 billion, driven by the industrial sector. Family offices are investing in their home countries, with US, New Zealand, and Australia being the most active buyers. This trend is expected to drive renewed momentum in 2025, according to Knight Frank's head of UK commercial research.

images.alt_text: Most family offices viewed real estate investments with a medium to long-term time horizon and a minority considered them to be short-term investments.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as investors focus on data, tariffs
summary: US stocks opened flat on Wednesday, March 5, 2025, amid concerns of a slowing economy and potential trade policy changes. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 2.6 points, while the S&P 500 rose 3.2 points. The Nasdaq Composite rose 27.8 points, despite investors waiting for President Trump's approach on trade policy, which may soften tariffs.

site_title: Emirates says aircraft retrofit programme pushing US$5 billion
summary: Emirates is investing around $5 billion in retrofitting existing aircraft, such as the Airbus A380 and Boeing 777, to extend their lifespan and bridge delays with new models. The airline's president, Tim Clark, stated that the company took control of its destiny due to anticipated problems with new models from Boeing. Emirates will consider the Airbus A350-1000, but engine reliability is a concern. Clark expressed concerns about the global economy's impact from tariffs, which may affect travel demand, but remains optimistic about the outcome of trade negotiations.

images.alt_text: In September, Boeing reported orders from unnamed buyers for 11 777F freighters, but did not supply details.
In September, Boeing reported orders from unnamed buyers for 11 777F freighters, but did not supply details.

site_title: Oei Tiong Ham Park GCB on the market for S$42.8 million
summary: A freehold Good Class Bungalow (GCB) in Oei Tiong Ham Park is up for sale with a guide price of S$42.8 million, translating to S$2,800 psf. This rare opportunity is driven by younger Singaporean high-net-worth individuals, with interest in the GCB market reigniting last year. The sale price is expected to match or exceed last year's tally of 26 GCB transactions, valued at S$1.15 billion.

images.alt_text: The property sits on one of two land lots held by Ong Tze Guan, the older son of Singapore’s first elected president, and his former sister-in-law Wang Yi Yi.
A house on Gallop Park Road is being sold by Lily Yeo, the wife of the late Alan Yeo of Yeo Hiap Seng. The price is understood to be in the low-S$40 million range.

site_title: From coalitions to tariffs: The US economic reset and its impact on Asia
summary: US President Donald Trump and Joe Biden share the same economic objectives, but their strategies differ. Biden's "friend-shoring" strategy aims to reduce dependence on China without decoupling, while Trump's approach treats allies as competitors with a zero-sum policy. Biden's tariffs for allied nations created loopholes, whereas Trump's approach uses direct pressure to extract concessions. Biden's industrial revival policy drove US manufacturing growth, but increased public debt. Trump prioritizes deregulation, green industrial policy, and punitive tariffs to boost domestic production, despite potential costs to competitiveness. US trade policy's unpredictability will impact Asia, particularly if companies redirect investments to the US.

images.alt_text: (FILES) US President Joe Biden meets with US President-elect Donald Trump in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, DC, on November 13, 2024. President Trump said on February 7, 2025, he was revoking his predecessor Joe Biden's security clearance, which entitles former presidents to receive sensitive information even after they have left office. "We are immediately revoking Joe Biden's Security Clearances, and stopping his daily Intelligence Briefings," Trump said on his Truth Social network, adding in capitals: "JOE, YOU'RE FIRED." (Photo by SAUL LOEB / AFP)

site_title: Oil drops for third day on Opec+ output increase, Trump tariffs
summary: Oil prices fell for a third consecutive day, with Brent futures dropping $1.02, or 1.44%, to $70.02 a barrel, and US West Texas Intermediate crude declining $1.33, or 1.95%, to $66.93 a barrel. The decline was attributed to OPEC+ plans to increase output by 138,000 barrels per day from April, and escalating trade tensions due to US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Canada, China, and Mexico, which sparked swift reprisals from the affected countries.

images.alt_text: Opec and its allies will decide in the next few weeks whether to press on with plans for resuming halted production from April.

site_title: Malaysia probes server shipments connected to Singapore fraud case
summary: Malaysia is investigating whether local laws were breached in the alleged shipment of US-sanctioned AI chips from Singapore to Malaysia. The servers, supplied by US firms and linked to a Singapore fraud case, may have contained Nvidia chips. The government is working closely with the US and Singapore to address the issue. Malaysia's trade ministry stated that the country is taking necessary actions to establish whether laws were breached. The US is also investigating whether a Chinese AI firm, DeepSeek, has been using US chips not allowed to be shipped to China.

site_title: Robust demand propels India’s services sector growth in February: PMI
summary: India's services sector expanded 6.2% year-over-year in February, driven by robust demand and government spending. The HSBC services Purchasing Managers' Index rose to 59.0, above the 50-mark separating expansion from contraction since mid-2021. Growth in foreign orders reached its highest in six months, and companies hired additional staff to meet rising demand. The rate of cost price inflation slipped to a four-month low, but firms passed on some costs to customers, leading to a higher increase in charge inflation.

images.alt_text: Money managers have been moving to the United Arab Emirates in recent years, lured by its tax-free income, year-long sunny weather and a timezone conducive to trading across Asia, the UK and Middle Eastern markets.

An oil pipeline in Pangerang in Malaysia's southern state of Johor. The network that India is planning will be capable of annually transporting about 8.3 million tons of LPG, or about 25 per cent of India’s total demand.

site_title: Mandarin Oriental FY2024 underlying profit drops to US$74.7 million
summary: Mandarin Oriental International posted an underlying profit of US$74.7 million for FY2024, down 8% from a year ago, primarily due to lower one-off residences branding fees. The group's revenue decreased 6% to US$525.8 million, while loss per share was US$0.0622. A dividend of US$0.05 per share was proposed, unchanged from the previous year. Despite a decrease in underlying profit, the majority of the group's hotels delivered "solid revenue and profit growth," with occupancy strengthening across all regions.

images.alt_text: Nuss Bar has an amazing view of the Wat Pho in Bangkok.
Prices are holding up because New York faces a tough housing shortage.
Mandarin Oriental, Singapore reopened in Sep 2023.
Mandarin Oriental is selling the two retail units adjoining its Paris hotel at 148 million euros.
Mandarin Oriental trims full-year loss to US$141.4m

site_title: Silver Housing Bonus scheme extended to more private property owners who downsize
summary: Singapore's Silver Housing Bonus (SHB) scheme will now extend to more private property owners who downsize to a smaller public housing flat and top up their retirement accounts. The scheme aims to encourage seniors to "rightsizing" and monetize their homes for a cash bonus of up to S$40,000. The enhanced scheme will now cover over 15,000 additional seniors and more than three-quarters of residential properties.

images.alt_text: The new Mount Pleasant housing estate will see 5,000 new homes across six Build-to-Order projects.
Housing developers will now have more flexibility developing large scale projects, with the extension to the critical sales deadline.
The government has already made several such changes in the last few years, to boost affordability and reduce wait times for first-time Build-to-Order (BTO) flat applicants.

site_title: Women in sustainability
summary: International Women's Day highlights women making sustainability a priority in their lives. Chef Chudaree "Tam" Debhakam of Baan Tepa champions local ingredients and no-waste policy, while Agatha Lee creates sustainable textile artworks from discarded materials. Yuko Tsukada, a former media executive, now runs a sustainable jewelry brand. These women are part of a growing movement, inspiring others to adopt environmentally-friendly practices. Their stories showcase the impact of women in sustainability, promoting a more eco-friendly future.

site_title: Goldman wins rare solo role on CK Hutchison’s blockbuster US$19 billion port deal
summary: Goldman Sachs has secured a rare solo role in advising on the sale of CK Hutchison Holdings' ports to a BlackRock consortium for $19 billion. The deal includes two ports on either side of the Panama Canal, coveted by former US President Donald Trump. Goldman's Hong Kong to New York team, led by John Waldron and Raghav Maliah, hammered out the transaction in just a couple of weeks, beating out other investment banks like Blackstone and KKR. The deal is a significant boost for Goldman, which is leading the global M&A league table this year.

images.alt_text: A ship sails near the Balboa Port after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock-backed consortium, amid pressure from US President Donald Trump to curb China's influence in the region, Panama City, Panama, March 4, 2025.
The sale includes 90% of Panama Ports Company, which has operated the Balboa (pictured) and Cristobal ports in the Central American country for over two decades, CK Hutchison said.

China's Ministry of Foreign Affairs' spokesperson Lin Jian says: "We hope that Panama will make the right decision based on the overall situation of bilateral relations and the long-term interests of the two peoples, and eliminate external interference."
Since winning the November US election, Donald Trump has refused to rule out the use of force to seize the canal, through which 40 per cent of US container traffic passes.

site_title: US mortgage rates near three-month low in boost to demand
summary: US mortgage rates have declined to a nearly three-month low, reaching 6.73% for a 30-year mortgage, after falling 15 basis points in the final week of February. The rate drop is attributed to a decrease in Treasury yields, which have fallen amid a selloff in stocks and weak economic data. This decrease in mortgage rates is expected to boost demand for home refinancing and purchases, providing a welcome sign for the struggling housing market.

site_title: Philippine inflation slows more than expected in February as rice prices drop
summary: The Philippines' inflation eased more than expected in February, driven by slower increases in food and utility costs. The consumer price index (CPI) rose 2.1% in February, below the 2.6% median forecast, marking the slowest annual increase since September 2023. Core inflation eased to 2.4% in February, down from 2.6% in January. The central bank may resume cutting interest rates, with a possible 25-basis-point rate cut as early as the April meeting, according to economists.

images.alt_text: The Philippines was added to the grey list in June 2021 over a host of concerns, such as mitigating dirty money risks associated with casino junkets.
The BSP has flagged a fourth consecutive 25 basis point rate cut at its Feb 13 meeting.

A woman carries a plastic bag of rice during a coastal cleanup program which provides rice to volunteers in exchange of plastic waste, in Mabini, Batangas province, Philippines, June 15, 2024. REUTERS/Lisa Marie David
Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas will review the key rate on Feb 13.

site_title: Euro rallies as Germany’s historic debt overhaul boosts growth outlook
summary: The euro has rallied nearly 3% this week, its best week since November 2022, following Germany's proposed 500 billion euro infrastructure fund and overhaul of borrowing rules, boosting Europe's growth prospects despite global trade tensions. The single currency rose 0.52% against the US dollar to US$1.0682, firming against other currencies. The move is seen as a positive sign for the eurozone's economic outlook, with investors seeking safe-haven assets amid global economic uncertainty.

images.alt_text: China’s yuan rose around 0.3 per cent to 7.265 per US dollar.

site_title: COE premiums close mostly higher, mainstream car premium almost flat
summary: Singapore's Certificate of Entitlement (COE) premiums rose across most categories in the first round of March bidding, except for Category A, which dropped 0.1%. Category B premiums increased 3.1%, while Category C rose 2.8%. The motorcycle category, D, saw the largest increase of 4.7%. The mainstream car premium rose 9.2% to S$92,850, the lowest level in nearly a year. The government's COE supply hikes in 2025 may not necessarily lead to lower premiums.

images.alt_text: Generic photo of people browsing cars on display at car show The Car Expo, October 2024 in Singapore. PHOTO: DERRYN WONG ,BT
The Open category increased a mere S$2 to S$110,002.

site_title: Disney to cut nearly 6% staff across units: WSJ
summary: Disney plans to cut approximately 200 positions, or 6% of staff, across ABC News Group and the Disney Entertainment Networks unit. The layoffs are expected to be announced as early as Wednesday. ABC shows "20/20" and "Nightline" will consolidate into one unit, and the political and data-driven news site 538 will be eliminated, affecting about 15 employees. The cuts come as Disney deals with declining television viewing and shifting consumer habits towards streaming.

images.alt_text: Director Sean Baker accepts the Oscar for Best Picture for "Anora" as producers Samantha Quan, Alex Coco, and Best Actress in a Leading Role winner Mikey Madison look on at the 97th Academy Awards in Los Angeles, California, March 2, 2025.
"Captain America: Brave New World" earned an estimated US$15 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period, just over half of last weekend’s take, industry analyst Exhibitor Relations reported.
The merger comes as part of a broader trend of consolidation in India’s satellite TV sector, driven by the rise of video streaming platforms and a shrinking pay-TV subscriber base.

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Wednesday, March 5, 2025
summary: China sets its GDP growth target at 5% for 2025, amid concerns of "changes unseen in a century." The country has ramped up stimulus measures to protect its economy. Asian markets have surged after China's announcement, while Indonesia's nickel boom is forcing its own smelters to shut down, negatively impacting the country's economy.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Wednesday.

Chinese Premier Li Qiang (front) delivers his speech during the opening ceremony of the Third Session of the 14th National People's Congress of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, March 5, 2025.
Premier Li Qiang, in a speech at the opening of the annual meeting of China’s parliament, warned that “changes unseen in a century are unfolding across the world at a faster pace”.
While the policies did boost Indonesia’s export earnings and created thousands of jobs, the surge in processing capacity has far outpaced demand for nickel.

site_title: China to mandate steel output cuts to ease glut, restore profits
summary: China's government will mandate steel output cuts to ease a massive glut and restore profitability at mills. The country, the world's largest producer and consumer of steel, aims to reduce production by 50 million tonnes a year. Annual production remains above 1 billion tonnes despite efforts to guide output lower by linking it to carbon emissions. The move is part of a broader effort to meet carbon targets and restore profitability, following a decade-long supply-side reform launched by President Xi Jinping.

images.alt_text: Steel rolls at ArcelorMittal steel plant in the Basque town of Etxebarri, Spain, Feb 28, 2025. Donald Trump earlier this month ordered a 25 per cent tariff on steel and aluminum imports, and in the process announced he would rescind all existing country-level exemptions.
Washington has already imposed anti-dumping duties on multiple Vietnamese steel exports and producers, in some cases even higher than 25 per cent
Steelmakers have suffered from a collapse in earnings and the industry lost money for most of last year.

site_title: Developers to get extended ABSD remission deadline for big en bloc rebuilds and complex ‘urban transformation’ projects
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 introduced changes to the Additional Buyer's Stamp Duty (ABSD) regime for large-scale urban transformation projects. Developers can now extend their critical sales deadline by 6 months to 1 year, giving them more flexibility in construction and sales timelines. The revised regime applies to projects with at least 700 units and complex technical or infrastructure requirements. Property players welcome the changes, but call for further adjustments to align rules with current market conditions, such as commencing the 5-year deadline when developers obtain key approvals and waiving ABSD for projects sold at 95% capacity.

images.alt_text: The new Mount Pleasant housing estate will see 5,000 new homes across six Build-to-Order projects.
The Senior Housing Bonus scheme, which incentivises seniors to downsize to a smaller flat, will be extended to inlcude more private property owners.

The 54-storey V on Shenton (left) comprises 510 apartments. It is part of a mixed-use project by Singapore Land Group that also includes the adjacent 23-storey UIC Building, comprising mostly offices.

site_title: Trump says Japan and South Korea want to partner with the US in Alaska pipeline
summary: US President Donald Trump announced that Japan and South Korea are interested in partnering with the US in a massive natural gas pipeline in Alaska, with potential investments of trillions of dollars. Trump claimed the pipeline would be one of the largest in the world. South Korea's industry ministry confirmed discussions with US officials, but no specific details have been decided. A working-level group will be established to discuss the pipeline and other issues, including tariffs and trade barriers.

images.alt_text: US Vice-President JD Vance (top left) and US House Speaker Mike Johnson (top right) applaud as US President Donald Trump addresses a joint session of the US Congress in the House Chamber of the US Capitol, Washington, D.C., March 4, 2025.
President Donald Trump addresses a joint session of the US Congress at the US Capitol in Washington, D.C., March 4, 2025.
Among the departments whose buildings are up for sale are Agriculture, Energy, Health and Human Services, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Justice and Veterans Affairs.

site_title: Canada files WTO complaint against US tariffs
summary: Canada has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against the US over President Trump's tariff increases, following a similar complaint filed by Beijing. The US imposed blanket 25% tariffs on imports from Canada and Mexico, citing concerns over immigration and drug trafficking. Canada retaliated, prompting the US to threaten further tariffs. Canada's ambassador to the WTO, Nadia Theodore, said the US decision "leaves us with no choice" and initiated dispute proceedings against the US at the WTO.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A logo is seen at the World Trade Organization (WTO) headquarters before a news conference in Geneva, Switzerland, October 5, 2022. REUTERS/Denis Balibouse/File Photo

site_title: Trump seeks revival of US shipbuilding to counter China
summary: US President Donald Trump announced plans to revive the US shipbuilding industry, citing China's dominance in the sector. He proposed creating a new office in the White House and offering tax incentives to bring back shipbuilding to America. The move aims to counter China's production of over half of the world's merchant vessels. Additionally, Trump stated his administration will "reclaim" the Panama Canal, which is currently controlled by a Hong Kong-based conglomerate, with a BlackRock-led consortium set to buy key ports near the waterway.

site_title: Gold slips as Treasury yields climb; Trump tariff moves on radar
summary: Gold prices slipped 0.1% to $2,916.09 an ounce due to rising US Treasury yields, while investors track the impact of US President Donald Trump's tariffs on inflation and global trade. Trump's 25% tariffs on Mexican and Canadian imports and 20% on Chinese goods took effect, sparking retaliatory measures from China and Canada. Federal Reserve Bank of New York president John Williams believes US tariffs will drive inflation higher but doesn't need changes to interest rate policy, awaiting the ADP employment report and nonfarm payrolls report for further insights.

images.alt_text: Higher inflation may force the Federal Reserve to keep rates higher for longer, which would dent non-yielding gold’s appeal.

site_title: First Mount Pleasant BTO flats to be launched in October
summary: Singapore's first batch of Housing and Development Board (HDB) Build-To-Order (BTO) flats in the new Mount Pleasant housing estate will be launched in October, comprising around 1,500 two to four-room flats and public rental flats in residential blocks exceeding 40 storeys.

images.alt_text: Housing developers will now have more flexibility developing large scale projects, with the extension to the critical sales deadline.
The Senior Housing Bonus scheme, which incentivises seniors to downsize to a smaller flat, will be extended to inlcude more private property owners.
Singapore condos are seen as good stores of value in an uncertain world.

site_title: China ramps up stimulus to guard economy from changes 'unseen in a century'
summary: China has increased fiscal stimulus to support consumption and cushion the impact of the escalating trade war with the US, aiming for a 5% growth rate in 2025. Premier Li Qiang warned of "changes unseen in a century" and vowed to boost consumption, technology, and infrastructure. The government plans to issue 1.3 trillion yuan in special treasury bonds and allocate 300 billion yuan for consumer subsidies. Analysts expect the measures to alleviate deflationary pressures and reduce reliance on exports and investment.

images.alt_text: Members of the People's Liberation Army (PLA) band take their position to perform ahead of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference at the Great Hall of the People, Beijing, China, March 4, 2024. China has the world’s second-largest military budget, but lags well behind the United States, its primary strategic rival.

Chinese Premier Li Qiang (front) delivers his speech during the opening ceremony of the Third Session of the 14th National People's Congress of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, March 5, 2025.
A collapse in earnings at steel mills and accusations that China is dumping its surplus overseas are now forcing the government to mandate cuts.

site_title: Trump warns of tariff ‘disturbance’ as he defends economic plans
summary: US President Donald Trump defended his economic plans, warning of a potential "disturbance" from tariffs, despite stagnant factory activity, simmering inflation, and declining consumer confidence. Trump argued that his policies will make America "rich again" and "great again," despite economic headwinds. His speech comes as stocks lag behind international markets and policymakers face pressure to address slowing GDP growth in China. Trump predicted a "little disturbance" but expressed confidence that the US economy will rebound.

images.alt_text: Among the departments whose buildings are up for sale are Agriculture, Energy, Health and Human Services, Housing and Urban Development, Labor, Justice and Veterans Affairs.

Union leaders and workers rally outside the Office of Personnel Management (OPM) headquarters in Washington, D.C., March 04, 2025. Workers gathered to protest recent cuts made to the department by Elon Musk's Department of Government Efficiency (DOGE).

A ship sails near the Balboa Port after Hong Kong's CK Hutchison agreed to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock-backed consortium, amid pressure from US President Donald Trump to curb China's influence in the region, Panama City, Panama, March 4, 2025.

Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau speaks during a news conference about the US tariffs against Canada in Ottawa, Canada, March 4, 2025. Trudeau said that US President Donald Trump imposed tariffs on Canada to destroy the country's economy to make it easier for the US to annex its northern neighbour.
All three major US indices finished lower on Tuesday after the United States proceeded with new tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China.

site_title: Women’s art reclaimed: 6 exhibitions for International Women’s Day
summary: Six exhibitions in Singapore celebrate the diverse perspectives of contemporary female artists, reclaiming traditionally feminized mediums and challenging biases in the art world. Exhibits include textile arts, digital portraits, and sculptures that explore themes of suffering, resilience, identity, and resistance. Artists such as Sunaina Bhalla, Shavonne Wong, and Charmaine Poh showcase their works, which put women's creativity and resistance at the center of the conversation, offering a powerful challenge to patriarchal expectations and traditional notions of art. These exhibitions celebrate women's art and its evolving narrative, declaring women's art as conceptual, radical, and essential.

images.alt_text: Some Labubu plush toys are being resold for more than twice or thrice their retail prices.
Coming from a broken family, Kim Whye Kee has served three prison sentences.
Juliette Yu-Ming Lizeray employs a variety of painting styles to bring Singapore snakes to vivid life.

site_title: Japan’s top labour union body says its members seek 6.11% average wage hike
summary: Japan's top labour union group, UA Zensen, is seeking a 6.11% average wage hike for its 1.9 million workers, surpassing the baseline 6% target set in January. This increase is almost the same as last year's biggest wage hike in three decades. For part-time workers, the union group is asking for a 7.16% wage hike, exceeding the baseline 7% target. The 2025 wage negotiations typically conclude in mid-March and are expected to impact the economy as the Bank of Japan monitors wage growth.

images.alt_text: Japan is riding a confluence of factors that make it attractive for investors, said Ken Chan, CEO, Patience Capital.
Japan’s exit from decades of deflation has allowed companies to raise prices to pass on rising costs, which in turn boosts profits to fund more investment.
The retailer’s market capitalisation is about 5.2 trillion yen, below the US$47 billion takeover proposal by Couche-Tard, owner of Circle K shops.

site_title: Singapore rejects separate COE category for private-hire cars, but will further support taxi fleet growth
summary: Singapore has rejected a separate Certificate of Entitlement (COE) category for private-hire cars, citing fluctuations in demand and the need to balance COE prices. Instead, the government will introduce more regulations to support taxi fleets and level the playing field against chauffeured private-hire cars. Taxi operators will be allowed to convert used passenger vehicles into taxis and sell them as PHCs or passenger cars, while larger ride-hailing platforms will face additional requirements, including higher data disclosure obligations.

images.alt_text: A new rule mandates a three-year lock-in period for recently acquired private hire cars in Singapore.
A licence or special decal which private-hire car drivers who must display on their windscreens. Grab Affixing Centre at Midview City in Sin Ming Lane.
Senior Minister of State for Transport Amy Khor said that having more platform operators means more competition and choice for both commuters and drivers.
Major updates to improve taxi, private-hire car sector in Singapore effective from January

site_title: Geely signs 2.4 billion euros loan to refinance Volvo truck deal
summary: Zhejiang Geely Holding Group, a Chinese billionaire-led company, has secured a 2.4 billion euros (S$3.4 billion) three-year loan to refinance its 2018 acquisition of Volvo. The loan replaces an original 2.3 billion euros five-year facility and will be used to refinance a 2.7 billion euros three-year loan due in May. Geely is shifting towards a more upscale product portfolio to boost profitability and compete with local peers in electric vehicles. The deal was arranged by BNP Paribas, HSBC Holding, and Standard Chartered, with over 20 lenders participating in the syndication.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A view shows the logo of Chinese automobile manufacturer Geely at a dealership in Moscow, Russia, March 23, 2023. REUTERS/Maxim Shemetov

site_title: Singapore retail sales up 4.5% in January, swinging from year-end decline
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 4.5% year on year in January, reversing a year-end decline ahead of Chinese New Year. Excluding motor vehicles, sales increased 4.8% year on year. The improvement was partly due to the celebration of Chinese New Year in January, with sales growth in categories such as supermarkets, food and alcohol, and watches and jewellery.

images.alt_text: December’s total retail sales stood at S$4.6 billion. Online sales accounted for 13.4 per cent, compared with 14.7 per cent recorded in November.

site_title: Bank of Japan’s deputy chief hints at more rate hikes, without rushing
summary: Bank of Japan deputy governor Shinichi Uchida hinted at more interest rate hikes, but without rushing, amid high global economic uncertainties. Uchida stated that the bank will continue to raise the policy interest rate and adjust monetary accommodation if the economic outlook is realized, aiming to achieve its 2% price stability target. He also suggested that the benchmark rate could rise to at least 1% by the end of fiscal 2026, and that the bank will monitor the economy's reaction to every rate hike, making an early move unlikely.

images.alt_text: JGB yields have risen recently on mounting market expectations the BOJ will raise rates again soon and may take borrowing costs higher than initially thought.
Hedging costs for Japanese investors having largely fallen since October.
Bank of Japan board member Hajime Takata said the BOJ must keep raising interest rates if companies continue to increase prices, wages and investment.

site_title: Adidas sees growth at high single-digit rate in 2025
summary: Adidas expects annual revenues to increase at a high single-digit rate in 2025, lower than the 12% growth in 2024. The company reported strong sales growth in key markets, including North America (15% increase), Europe (25%), Latin America (31%), and Greater China (16%). Operating profit is expected to reach $1.8-$1.9 billion, up from $1.34 billion in 2024. The company's brand sales are expected to deliver double-digit growth in North America and Greater China.

site_title: Food Bank Singapore joins MBS, Las Vegas Sands programme to enhance community impact
summary: Food Bank Singapore has joined the Sands Cares Accelerator programme, a partnership with Marina Bay Sands (MBS) and Las Vegas Sands, to enhance its community impact. The non-profit will receive $100,000 annually and guidance to expand its Bank Card Programme, simplifying food distribution processes. The programme aims to increase outreach to more beneficiaries, particularly youths in tertiary institutions, and improve operational efficiency. Food Bank will focus on digitalising its processes, with the goal of serving vulnerable members of the community effectively while emphasizing the importance of nutrition.

images.alt_text: The Sands Innovative Arts Fund is part of MBS’ community engagement programme, Sands Cares, of which support for the arts is a key pillar.
Nicholas Ionides, MBS’ vice-president of communications and corporate affairs, with a senior at the reunion lunch organised by MBS and Care Corner.
The outdoor festival at Event Plaza features performances by local artists and food stalls from MBS' restaurants.

site_title: China to give cities more room to purchase unsold homes
summary: China's central government has pledged to give city governments more autonomy in buying unsold homes, aiming to stem the country's property decline amid weak domestic demand and job woes. The move will allow local officials to set standards on which homes to purchase and decide acquisition prices. The government vows to "fully unleash the demand" of buyers in need of homes and "effectively prevent debt defaults" by real estate companies, signaling a shift towards aiding the industry. China's property crisis has led to dozens of defaults and a $160 billion pile of distressed debt.

images.alt_text: Residential buildings at a government-subsidized rental housing complex in Beijing, China, on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024. China promised new measures to support the property sector and hinted at greater government borrowing to shore up the economy, as authorities seek to put a floor under the country’s growth slowdown. Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg

Investors said recent positive signs, from improving home prices in top cities to industry leader China Vanke’s recapitalisation plan, suggest this year will be the turning point for the real estate market.
The latest improvement follows pledges from the country’s top leaders, who vowed to stem the decline in the real estate market in late September.

site_title: Trump government walks back order to mass fire new federal employees
summary: The US government, under President Donald Trump, has walked back an order to mass-fire federal employees still serving their probationary periods. The updated guidance, issued by the Office of Personnel Management, was made after a federal judge in California ruled that the original directive was "unlawful" and ordered it to be temporarily rescinded. The updated guidance states that agencies have ultimate decision-making authority over personnel actions, effectively reversing the mass firing plan.

site_title: SoftBank’s Arm to drive Malaysia’s RM1.2 trillion chip goals
summary: Malaysia has signed a 10-year deal with SoftBank's ARM Holdings worth $250 million to acquire semiconductor-related licenses and know-how. The pact aims to help Malaysia move beyond chip assembly to more valuable semiconductor production, with a goal of achieving $1.2 trillion in exports by 2030. The deal will provide chip designs and technology to aid local companies in designing their own chips, with the goal of creating 10 chip companies with $20 billion in annual revenue.

The Bill will govern the capture, transport, utilisation and storage of carbon dioxide, Economy Minister Rafizi Ramli said.
Chinese chip designers are attracted by its lower costs, but the government has yet to mention it in policy.

site_title: China’s 5% GDP target for 2025 a sign of confidence, but warrants stronger policy support: analysts
summary: China maintained its 2025 GDP growth target at around 5% for the third consecutive year, despite US tariffs. Analysts say this confidence in the economy's resilience warrants stronger policy support to achieve the target. The Chinese economy has struggled with a property crisis, slowing exports, population decline, and weak consumer and business confidence. Despite a 3% growth in 2024, the economy still faces challenges, including a painful restructuring of the real estate market and anaemic consumer demand. The unchanged growth target reflects policymakers' confidence in the domestic outlook and preparedness to adjust policies in case of headwinds.

images.alt_text: Xi has a delicate balancing act to maintain in providing the right dose of stimulus to hit the growth target while ensuring aid goes to the parts of the economy that need it most.

Chinese Premier Li Qiang (front) delivers his speech during the opening ceremony of the Third Session of the 14th National People's Congress of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, March 5, 2025.

site_title: Australia’s economy accelerates, backing RBA’s hawkish tone
summary: Australia's economy accelerated in the final three months of last year, growing 0.6% in line with economists' estimates, providing a more optimistic outlook despite growth still being below peak levels. The Reserve Bank of Australia's cautious approach to further policy easing is supported by the acceleration, which also saw business conditions remain buoyant and retail sales strengthen in five of the six months to January. GDP expansion of 1.3% from a year earlier matches forecasts, with modest growth seen across the economy, driven by public and private spending, a rise in exports, and a moderation in government spending.

images.alt_text: Consumers have also benefited from a slowdown in inflation and the large cuts to income taxes.
The trend of employees returning to office has continued to gain momentum in Australia and could pick up further this year, says CBRE.
The Australian economy created some solid 44,000 new jobs in January, while the jobless rate remained low at 4.1 per cent.

site_title: Hakuhodo & SC Ventures partner to expand Japanese IPs globally
summary: Hakuhodo DY Media Partners and SC Ventures have partnered to expand Japanese IPs globally through fintech and tokenization. The two companies will explore business initiatives aimed at accelerating the overseas growth of Japanese IPs, including anime and manga. A business study will focus on promoting expansion and acceleration of overseas business, while also considering the use of tokens and fintech technology to enable creators to tokenize their content and offer it to investors worldwide.

site_title: New Zealand central bank governor Adrian Orr resigns
summary: New Zealand's Reserve Bank of New Zealand Governor Adrian Orr has resigned after a seven-year term, ending three years early. Orr cited consumer price inflation at target and an economy in a cyclical recovery following the pandemic. The decision comes amid criticism from the National Party-led government, which blamed Orr for high interest rates and inflation. Deputy Governor Christian Hawkesby will act as governor until March 31, when Finance Minister Nicola Willis will appoint a permanent replacement.

images.alt_text: The statistics agency publishes fourth-quarter GDP data on Mar 20.
The Australian economy created some solid 44,000 new jobs in January, while the jobless rate remained low at 4.1 per cent.
The RBNZ estimates the economy grew 0.3 per cent in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Elias Green condo up for en bloc sale at S$928 million guide price
summary: The Elias Green condominium in Pasir Ris, Singapore, is up for en bloc sale with a guide price of S$928 million, representing a 19% increase from its 2018 price tag. The sale includes a 48,019 sq m land area, translating to a land rate of S$1,355 psf ppr, after factoring in a 10% bonus gross floor area and an estimated land betterment charge of S$150.8 million. The sale is set to launch on March 6.

images.alt_text: Developers pay an LBC for the right to enhance the use of some sites or to build bigger projects on them.
2024 has been an unprecedented one for Singapore's private residential market, with contrasting performance in new home sales and non-awards for state land tenders.

site_title: China to ramp up military spending by 7.2% while US looks to cut costs
summary: China is set to increase its defense spending by 7.2% in 2025, reaching 1.78 trillion yuan (S$328 billion), as President Xi Jinping aims to build a military that can challenge the US. This contrasts with the US, which plans to cut military funding by 8% over the next five years. China's military ambitions face challenges, including corruption, as it aims to achieve a modern military by 2027 and surpass the US by 2049.

images.alt_text: Chinese Premier Li Qiang (front) delivers his speech during the opening ceremony of the Third Session of the 14th National People's Congress of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, March 5, 2025.

Singapore offers a good example of small countries not refraining from calling out the dangers of great powers going rogue.

site_title: Germany’s Merz vows billions for defence, economy
summary: Germany's Chancellor-in-waiting Friedrich Merz has proposed a package of billions of euros in extra spending on defense and infrastructure to boost the country's economy, which is threatened with a third straight year of recession. Merz plans to exempt defense spending from Germany's debt brake once it exceeds 1% of GDP, with a target of 45 billion euros. The proposal also includes a 500 billion euro fund for infrastructure investment and an immediate 3 billion euro aid package for Ukraine.

site_title: Tesla’s China sales slump adds to worrying global slowdown
summary: Tesla's China sales plummeted 49% in February to 30,688 vehicles, the lowest monthly figure in over 2½ years, amid a global slowdown. The decline follows a weak start in China and a string of sales declines across Europe, despite industrywide EV sales surging. The weak performance in China may be due to domestic manufacturers offering more affordable and tech-laden cars, and Tesla's shares fell 4.4% on Monday. The decline in China's largest auto market adds to concerns about Tesla's sales and the global automotive industry's slowdown.

images.alt_text: The company’s executives have said Tesla will return to growth this year despite the first annual sales decline in more than a decade in 2024.

site_title: Google urges Trump DOJ to reverse course on breaking up company
summary: Google is urging the US Justice Department to reverse its push to break up the company, citing national security concerns. The Biden administration had called for Google to sell its Chrome web browser and make other changes to its business. In a meeting last week, Google representatives asked the government to take a less aggressive stance, arguing that breaking up the company could harm national security and the US economy. This is Washington's first attempt to break up a major tech company since Microsoft in 2001.

images.alt_text: The Digital Markets Act, which came into effect in March 2024, sets out a list of dos and don’ts for digital gatekeepers such as Google as part of the EU’s goal of securing a level playing field.

Chegg, an online education company that offers textbook rentals, homework help, and tutoring, said in the lawsuit filed in Washington, D.C., that Google is co-opting publishers’ content to keep users on its own site, erasing financial incentives to publish.
AI is being increasingly deployed in the workplace, from answering calls to carrying out legal research, following the success of ChatGPT and similar models over the past year.

site_title: Tesla offers buyer perks to drum up interest with sales slumping
summary: Tesla is offering buyer perks, including free lifetime supercharging and cheap financing, to boost sales amid a significant slump in the first quarter. The company's shares fell 4.7% amid concerns over a global trade war and consumer backlash against CEO Elon Musk's political moves. Vehicle sales and shipments have dropped year-over-year in key markets, including China, France, and California, with a 49% drop in China, a 45% decline in Europe, and a 36% drop in California. Tesla expects to lose weeks of output this quarter due to factory upgrades.

site_title: Ports sale to BlackRock offers Panama way out of Trump row: experts
summary: Panama has secured a way out of its diplomatic crisis with US President Donald Trump by allowing Hong Kong's CK Hutchison to sell its interests in a key Panama Canal port operator to a BlackRock-backed consortium. The deal, which has been welcomed by experts, offers Panama a convenient solution to appease Trump's pressure to curb China's influence in the region. Trump had threatened to use force to seize the canal, claiming China's ownership gave it control over the strategic waterway. The sale is seen as a relief for President Jose Raul Mulino, who had been under fierce pressure to reduce China's footprint in the country.

site_title: Family offices in Singapore, elsewhere have ‘huge, sustained interest’ in real estate investments: report
summary: Family offices globally, particularly in Singapore and Asia-Pacific, have shown a "huge, sustained interest" in real estate investments, with 44% of surveyed family offices looking to increase allocations to the sector. The majority view real estate investments as medium to long-term, with 37.3% made with an outlook of nine years and longer. The top objectives for investing in real estate are growth and capital appreciation, followed by wealth preservation and income generation. Family offices in the region are diversifying into high-growth sectors like data centers and luxury residential, and prefer domestic real estate investments, with 70% focusing on local portfolios.

images.alt_text: Observers say it is still too early to tell if Forest City could truly become a wealth hub; more clarity needs to be given for its tax incentives and legal frameworks first.

Singapore can consider including insurance products in the definition of designated investments for the single family office tax exemption schemes.

site_title: Country Garden misses self-imposed target date on debt overhaul
summary: Country Garden Holdings, a Chinese property developer, has missed its self-imposed target date to reach a debt restructuring plan, with its next winding-up hearing scheduled for May 26. The company, which defaulted on US dollar debt in 2023, has struggled to gain support from creditors over terms such as mandatory conversion bond prices and debt payment dates. The developer's sales have also slumped, dropping 38% in February from a year earlier, further exacerbating its financial woes.

images.alt_text: Despite government support, many buyers prefer second-hand homes due to concerns that developers will still struggle to finish construction on presold projects.

Country Garden has now been granted an adjournment until May 26 in a court hearing held to gauge the extent to which its debt restructuring is proceeding ahead of a decision on a liquidation petition.
Country Garden continues to struggle amid the nation’s property crisis and its path forward remains difficult.

site_title: Thailand plan would allow polluters to offset 15% of emissions
summary: Thailand is considering allowing businesses to offset up to 15% of their greenhouse gas pollution with carbon credits in its planned emissions trading system. The move is part of the country's efforts to achieve net zero emissions by 2065. The system, set to be operational by 2030, will also impose a carbon tax of 200 baht a tonne on oil products. The proposal aims to stimulate the development of Thailand's voluntary carbon market, particularly for forestry projects.

images.alt_text: Paetongtarn will likely be a prime target of the no-confidence debate late this month amid weak economic data.
Thailand is in early discussions with carmakers to introduce a car trade-in and scrapping scheme in a bid to revive an industry hit by its biggest crisis in decades.
Foreign tourists take photographs at a shopping district in Bangkok, Thailand, Feb 24, 2025.
In December, concerns about factory hygiene prompted China to suspend imports of syrup and premixed powder from Thailand, the world’s second-largest sugar exporter.

site_title: Microsoft’s fading AI mojo keeps shares in lengthy purgatory
summary: Microsoft's shares have been in a lengthy period of stagnation, failing to hit a fresh record, with a 18% decline from its peak in July. The company's struggles are attributed to repeated earnings disappointments and the lack of clear growth from its AI investments, despite spending billions on AI data centers. Analysts remain optimistic about its long-term potential, but the stock's valuation has decreased, with shares trading at a 10-year average multiple. Despite this, over 90% of analysts recommend buying the stock, citing its durable growth and quality characteristics.

images.alt_text: When Microsoft tried to stretch the Skype brand into the workplace, it lost out to Slack Technologies.
The push towards AI comes as videogame development costs continue to rise.
Microsoft’s announcement indicates that its engineers have found a way to deploy the particles that make quantum computing possible in a system.

site_title: China vows to expand carbon market in push to control emissions
summary: China's top leaders have pledged to expand the country's emissions trading system, aiming to cover more industries and accelerate the transition to cleaner energy sources. The government plans to add steel, aluminium, and cement producers by 2025, and will launch initiatives for carbon emissions statistics and accounting. Construction of clean energy bases in deserts will be accelerated, and more will be done to integrate renewables into local grids. However, China's target of a 3% reduction in energy use per unit of gross domestic product is below last year's 3.8% mark, attributed to rapid growth in energy consumption.

images.alt_text: China is beefing up the strength of its banking system after enacting a string of stimulus policies including cuts to mortgage rates and key policy rates.

Chinese Premier Li Qiang (front) delivers his speech during the opening ceremony of the Third Session of the 14th National People's Congress of China at the Great Hall of the People in Beijing, China, March 5, 2025.
Policymakers face increased pressure to unveil consumer-focused policies with a longer-term impact when China’s rubber-stamp parliament begins its annual meeting on Mar 5.

site_title: From an NTU eatery to 7 outlets, A Hot Hideout spices up Singapore’s mala scene
summary: Singapore's A Hot Hideout, a mala restaurant chain, is expanding rapidly with 7 branches by end-2025. Founded by Lee Ray Sheng, the brand offers unique, drinkable collagen broths and Singaporean takes on stir-fried mala xiang guo and broth-based mala. Lee, who left McKinsey to focus on the business, aims to open 10 outlets and diversify into retail sales and mergers and acquisitions. The brand has seen significant revenue growth, with over S$10 million in 2024, and is exploring halal-certified mala options for international markets.

From left: Pinnacle Marine's business development manager Ken Lee; chairman Laurence Chua and CEO Fabian Lim at the group's new shipyard, which was acquired for S$6 million.

site_title: Baidu markets debut dim sum bond in first offering since 2021
summary: Chinese tech giant Baidu is marketing its first yuan-denominated dim sum bond offering in five and 10-year tenors since 2021, aiming to raise up to 10 billion yuan (S$1.8 billion). The bonds have an initial price guidance of 3% and 3.4% annual coupon rates, respectively. If successful, the deal would be Baidu's first bond offering since 2021 and its first-ever yuan-denominated note.

site_title: Stocks to watch: HPL, Singapore Exchange, CDL
summary: Hotel Properties Ltd (HPL) proposed to acquire InterContinental Auckland in New Zealand for NZ$180 million (S$138.5 million), funded by a third-party loan and internal resources. The Singapore Exchange launched its second batch of Hong Kong Singapore Depository Receipts (SDRs), targeting yield-seeking investors. Meanwhile, City Developments Ltd (CDL) announced the resignation of unpaid independent adviser Dr Catherine Wu, following a father-son rift within the company, which will be heard on April 11.

site_title: Europe: Shares log worst day in over six months after Trump’s tariffs materialise
summary: Europe's stocks logged their worst day in over six months after US President Trump's tariffs on Canada, Mexico, and China took effect. The Stoxx 600 index closed 2.14% lower, its worst day since August 2024, with automakers and financial services sectors heavily impacted. Investors fear similar tariffs on Europe and the hit to global growth, with the Euro Stoxx Volatility Index surging to a high of 22.90 points.

images.alt_text: All three major US indices finished lower on Tuesday after the United States proceeded with new tariffs on Canada, Mexico and China.

site_title: Trudeau dismisses ‘very dumb’ tariffs, says Trump wants to ruin Canadian economy
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau dismissed US President Donald Trump's tariffs on Canadian imports as "a very dumb thing to do" and vowed to retaliate with 25% tariffs on $30 billion in US imports. Trudeau accused Trump of wanting to ruin the Canadian economy and said Ottawa would challenge the US measures at the World Trade Organization. The move is expected to hurt both Canadian and US economies, with economists predicting a recession in Canada unless the tariffs are lifted quickly.

site_title: Handbags, watches and more: Best performing luxury investments in 2024
summary: Luxury assets, such as handbags, watches, and classic cars, outperformed other investments in 2024, with handbags rising 2.8% and watches gaining 1.7% over the past 12 months, according to the Knight Frank Luxury Investment Index. On a five-year basis, handbags soared 34% and watches gained 52.7%. Classic cars, despite a "sharp bear market" in 2023, grew 1.2% through the year. The index fell 3.3% for a second year in a row, but still rose 21.5% on a five-year basis.

images.alt_text: Linda Neo started collecting art as a means of sharing a common interest with her husband, Albert Lim.

site_title: Trump wants to kill US$52.7 billion semiconductor chips subsidy law
summary: US President Donald Trump called for the repeal of the $52.7 billion semiconductor subsidy law, known as the Chips Act, which was signed by President Joe Biden in 2022. The law aimed to revive American semiconductor manufacturing and invested $39 billion in grants, loans, and tax breaks. Trump urged US House Speaker Mike Johnson to eliminate the law, suggesting the remaining funds be used to reduce the national debt. The law had secured binding agreements with major chipmakers, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing and Intel, prior to Biden's departure.

site_title: Crowdstrike forecasts first-quarter revenue below estimates
summary: Crowdstrike forecasts its first-quarter revenue to be below estimates, falling 6% in extended trading. The company expects revenue between $1.1 billion and $1.11 billion, slightly below analysts' estimates. This marks a contrast with competitors Palo Alto Networks and Fortinet, who had forecast annual revenue above estimates. The weak spending on cybersecurity products is attributed to high inflation and uncertain macroeconomic environment. Despite this, Crowdstrike expects its 2026 revenue to be in line with estimates, between $4.74 billion and $4.81 billion.

images.alt_text: Businesses are increasingly investing in Crowdstrike’s comprehensive cybersecurity services to combat the widespread threat of online hacking and digital fraud.
Delta, which has purchased CrowdStrike products since 2022, said the outage forced it to cancel 7,000 flights, affecting 1.3 million passengers over five days.

site_title: China plans to issue 500 billion yuan in special bonds for big banks
summary: China plans to issue 500 billion yuan (S$92 billion) in special sovereign bonds to boost capital at its biggest state-owned banks and support the economic recovery. The move aims to replenish core tier-1 capital, bolster operations, and enhance the banks' ability to service the real economy. The plan was first announced in September and is part of the government's efforts to address record low margins, slowing profit growth, and rising bad debt among lenders.

site_title: Apple debuts faster iPad Air, low-end model in new product wave
summary: Apple has debuted a new iPad Air with faster performance, upgraded to the M3 chip, which provides twice the processing power of the previous M1 model. The device, priced at $599 and $799, also features improved AI capabilities, a new Magic Keyboard accessory, and an updated low-end iPad model. The new iPad Air is available for pre-order and will ship on March 12, with the company also introducing a new lower-end Magic Keyboard for the device.

site_title: ByteDance to buy back US staff shares at US$312 billion valuation
summary: ByteDance, the owner of TikTok, plans to buy back employee shares at a valuation of approximately $312 billion, marking a significant markup from previous levels. The company is offering US staff around $189.90 per share, up from $181 six months ago. This move comes as investors have been optimistic about Chinese tech shares, despite US edicts forcing a sale or blockade of TikTok. The deal reflects ByteDance's strength in artificial intelligence and its brightening outlook for the Chinese tech sector.

images.alt_text: TikTok’s fate has been up in the air since a law requiring ByteDance to either sell it on national security grounds or face a ban took effect on Jan 19.
The spending will help ByteDance defend its AI lead at home. Having begun 2024 as a laggard, it now has over 15 standalone AI applications – more than rivals such as Baidu and Tencent Holdings.

site_title: Anthropic’s mega valuation mints seven new AI billionaires
summary: Anthropic, a US-based AI startup, has raised $3.5 billion in funding, valuing the company at $61.5 billion. This round, led by Lightspeed Venture Partners, has made seven co-founders, including siblings Dario and Daniela Amodei, billionaires. Anthropic plans to use the funds to develop next-gen AI systems, expand computing capacity, and accelerate international expansion. The company's valuation surpasses that of OpenAI rival, and the funding round highlights ongoing investor demand for US-based AI startups, despite the market shock of DeepSeek, a Chinese AI model.

images.alt_text: Anthropic, which develops large language models, is one of the leading AI companies in an era where investors are eager to write big checks for the sector.
Anthropic is best known for its Claude family of large language models, which compete with ones made by OpenAI.

site_title: Backlash to crypto-reserve plan raises doubts on its prospects
summary: The US government's plan to create a strategic cryptocurrency reserve has faced backlash due to concerns over its feasibility and potential impact on the economy. The Trump administration's proposal to include Bitcoin and three other tokens, XRP, SOL, and ADA, in the reserve has sparked debate among experts, with some questioning the government's ability to acquire these tokens and others expressing skepticism about the reserve's purpose and value. The decline in value of the proposed tokens has also raised concerns, with some experts arguing that the reserve's value could be volatile.

site_title: Canada, Mexico could see relief from tariffs, Trump official hints
summary: US Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick hinted that President Donald Trump may dial down tariffs on Canada and Mexico this week, potentially lowering the 25% tariffs imposed on imports from the two countries. The tariffs, aimed at addressing illegal immigration and drug trafficking, have sparked a trade war with Canada and Mexico, leading to retaliatory measures and concerns about inflationary effects on US consumers. Trudeau has criticized the US for targeting a close ally, while China has vowed to fight the trade war to the "bitter end."

site_title: Singapore to pilot carbon capture and storage technology at waste-to-energy plants
summary: Singapore plans to pilot carbon capture technology at its waste-to-energy plants by 2026, investing S$300 million over five years. The government aims to achieve net-zero emissions by 2050 and has set a target of reaching net-zero emissions by 2045 for the public sector. The S$300 million fund will also support energy efficiency projects in public sector buildings and test bed innovative solutions.

site_title: Trump seeks to put 443 federal properties up for sale
summary: The US government is considering selling 443 federal properties across 47 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico, with an estimated annual savings of $430 million in operating costs. The General Services Administration has posted a list of non-core assets, including historic properties, courthouses, and regional offices, which could be sold to other federal agencies, state and local governments, or non-profits. The move aims to reduce government spending, eliminate underutilized space, and centralize property management, but may threaten the already struggling DC office market.

site_title: Thank you for the money; how else can Singapore enhance its social compact?
summary: Singapore's Budget 2025 allocated significant funding for social initiatives, including a S$250 million matching grant for charity fundraising and a S$270 million top-up for the Tote Board's Enhanced Fund-Raising Programme. This amounts to over S$600 million in matching funds to support social causes. The government encourages both companies and individuals to take an active role in achieving the goals of Budget 2025 and the Forward Singapore initiative.

site_title: Far-flung Singapore investors can’t ignore Trump’s far-reaching tendencies
summary: US President Donald Trump's recent policy moves have had a significant impact on Singapore-listed companies, despite seeming unrelated at first glance. The sale of CK Hutchison's Panama ports to a US-led consortium and the proposed fees on Chinese-built vessels entering US ports have affected local stocks. Meanwhile, some sectors, such as shipping and manufacturing, may be impacted by Trump's trade policies. Investors in Singapore need to stay vigilant and assess their portfolios to mitigate negative effects and seize opportunities as Trump's rhetoric and policies continue to shape global events.

summary: Oil prices dropped 0.8% on Tuesday, settling at a 6-month low of $71.04 a barrel, after Opec+ announced a planned 138,000 barrel per day output increase in April, its first since 2022. US tariffs on Canada, Mexico, and China also weighed on prices, with China retaliating with tariffs on US agricultural and food products. The US-Ukraine minerals deal is expected to be signed soon, reducing geopolitical tension. Oil prices are expected to remain volatile due to supply and demand imbalances.

site_title: China sets GDP target at about 5% despite US tariffs
summary: China has set its economic growth goal for 2025 at about 5% despite ongoing trade tensions with the US, according to Premier Li Qiang's annual work report. This marks the third consecutive year China has maintained a 5% GDP target, but repeating it may be challenging. China also set a fiscal deficit target of around 4% of GDP, the highest level in over three decades.

site_title: US: Stocks fall again as more Trump tariffs take effect
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as new tariffs on Canada, Mexico, and China took effect, exacerbating inflation concerns and recession fears. The US implemented 25% tariffs on Canada and Mexico, while doubling tariffs on China. The move led to a decline in all three major US indices, with worries about the impact on global trade and economic growth.

site_title: GIC’s former Japan head sets sights on 25 billion yen fund to target residential properties in Japan
summary: Patience Capital Group, led by former GIC Japan head Ken Chan, is raising a new 25 billion yen (S$225.5 million) fund focused on residential properties in Japan. This comes after the successful closure of its first residential fund in 2020, which has already divested assets and returned capital to investors. Chan believes macro conditions will provide a conducive environment for the new fund, citing factors such as rising interest rates, inflation, and a tourism rebound in Japan.

images.alt_text: Ken Chan, the former Japan head of Singapore sovereign wealth fund GIC, is looking to invest big in Myoko Kogen in Japan.
Myoko is about 200 km north-west of Tokyo, and cold winds coming off the Sea of Japan produce some of the deepest snow in the world.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 4)
summary: Singapore has cracked down on money mules, which are key channels for overseas scammers to launder their gains. The government is also exploring measures to combat scams on Telegram, including legislative actions. The city-state's business aviation sector is expected to grow at a faster pace than the global average, with a 2.1% annual increase. Meanwhile, an edtech startup has released digital games to teach students about social issues, such as navigating challenges faced by wheelchair users.

site_title: EU chief unveils 800-billion-euro plan to 'rearm' Europe
summary: European Union President Ursula von der Leyen unveiled a 800-billion-euro plan to 'rearm' Europe, aiming to provide immediate military support for Ukraine amid US suspension of aid. The five-part plan includes suspending budget rules, providing 150 billion euros in loans, and repurposing EU funds for defence investments. The proposal also involves the European Investment Bank and a savings and investments union to help companies access capital. Von der Leyen described the situation as a "clear and present danger" and called for joint action on European security, saying "Europe faces a momentous and dangerous time."

images.alt_text: Ursula von der Leyen, president of the European Commission, says: “We want AI to be a force for good.  AI needs competition, but AI also needs collaboration.”

site_title: Prada profit surges 21% as speculation swirls over Versace bid
summary: Prada reported a 21% surge in operating profit in 2024, beating analysts' forecasts, amid speculation about a potential Versace acquisition. The company's net revenues grew 17% to 5.43 billion euros, driven by double-digit growth across all regions except the Americas. Retail sales rose 18% in the fourth quarter, mainly due to Miu Miu brand growth. Prada's chief executive, Andrea Guerra, expressed confidence in continuing to drive market share and consolidate Miu Miu's success, citing a net cash position of 600 million euros to potentially fund a deal.

site_title: CK Hutchison shares jump 22% after Panama Canal stake sale to BlackRock
summary: CK Hutchison shares surged 22% after the Hong Kong conglomerate sold a majority stake in a US$22.8 billion ports unit to a group led by BlackRock, including 90% of Panama Ports Company. The sale involves CK Hutchison's 80% stake in Hutchison Ports and will control 43 ports in 23 countries. The conglomerate will receive over US$19 billion following repayment of shareholder loans, while Singapore's PSA International retains the remaining stake.

site_title: Honey, candles and California: Meghan Markle’s new show goes live
summary: Meghan Markle's new Netflix lifestyle series, "With Love, Meghan," has gone live, showcasing the Duchess of Sussex's domestic life in California. The show features Markle harvesting honey, making pasta, and mixing bath salts, as well as appearances from chef Alice Waters and actress Mindy Kaling. The series coincides with a rebranding of Markle's online retailer, "As Ever," and follows her efforts to establish her own financial independence after being cut off from the royal purse. Early reviews have been mixed, with some critics calling the series an "exercise in narcissism" and others praising its "effortlessly chic" atmosphere.

site_title: Trump’s tariffs will hurt Mexico – and America
summary: US President Donald Trump's decision to impose a 25% tariff on Mexican goods could push Mexico into a recession, driving more migration northward and undermining Trump's immigration goals. The tariffs will cripple Mexico's economy, given its heavy reliance on trade with the US, with 80% of exports destined for the US. A recession in Mexico could fuel even greater migration pressure, threatening the US economy's long-term prospects and undermining the foundations of the international economic order.

summary: Singapore Exchange (SGX) has expanded its Hong Kong depository receipts (SDRs) with the addition of Ping An Insurance, Meituan, and Xiaomi, offering investors direct access to these blue-chip stocks. The exchange plans to include more Thai and Hong Kong SDRs by mid-2025, with the new offerings targeting "yield-seeking investors." The move aims to increase accessibility and flexibility for investors, with SDRs allowing for lower entry costs and the ability to trade in Singapore dollars.

site_title: Singapore banks return capital but draw mixed sentiments; earnings stay resilient in Q4
summary: Singapore banks posted stable earnings in Q4 2024, driven by a resilient Asean economy. site_title: Dividend appeal of Singapore banks remains compelling
summary: Singapore's three largest banks, DBS, UOB, and OCBC, delivered positive net profit growth in 2024 due to higher net interest income and non-interest income led by their wealth management arms. The banks' share prices rose strongly, driven by the full-year results and certainty on their capital management plans. The banks' dividend appeal remains compelling, with Sora forecast to stay above the pre-pandemic level of 2%, providing a supportive macroeconomic environment.
