site_title: Blackstone buys Japan drug trial firm, adding to private equity health deals
summary: Blackstone, the world's largest alternative asset manager, agreed to purchase 60% of Tokyo-based CMIC, a contract research organization, in a deal valued in the hundreds of millions of US dollars. This acquisition marks the second major global private equity firm deal in Japan's pharmaceutical sector in the past month. Blackstone aims to streamline Japan's clinical trial process, contributing to the growth of pharmaceutical deals amid a widening "drug lag" issue in the country. The deal will help bring new drugs to Japan faster, addressing the growing need for pharmaceutical solutions with Japan's ageing population.

images.alt_text: The Blackstone Group LP logo hangs in the company's offices in New York, U.S., on Tuesday, June 4, 2013. Blackstone Group LP, the second-biggest U.S. office landlord, has said it expects strong interest from sovereign-wealth funds for properties it plans to sell starting this year. BLOOMBERG
Most of Steve Schwarzman’s annual windfall came in dividends, not fund profits.
The three projects for sale are part of assets under DragonCor, a portfolio company owned and managed by Blackstone real estate funds set up around 2018.
Blackstone has structured its fund so that investors can withdraw as much as 3 per cent of the fund’s net asset value each quarter.

site_title: Genting’s leadership shake-up signals new era for one of Asia’s most powerful family empires
summary: Genting Berhad, a Malaysian conglomerate and one of Asia's largest family-run empires, has undergone a leadership shake-up with the departure of CEO Lim Kok Thay after nearly two decades. Lim Kok Thay, 73, will remain as executive chairman, while Tan Kong Han, who has served for 18 years, will take over as CEO. The move aims to strengthen governance, reassure investors, and address succession risks. Analysts see the transition as a positive step, but note that the Lim family will likely maintain control. Genting shares have declined amid weaker-than-expected earnings, but experts expect a rebound in foreign visitors to boost the company's performance.

images.alt_text: On Thursday, it was announced that Lim Kok Thay will step down as chief executive of Malaysia’s Genting after nearly two decades at the helm.
The 73-year-old Lim Kok Thay will remain as executive chairman of Genting Bhd.
Genting Singapore said that it remains committed to its RWS 2.0 investments, such as the opening of a super luxury all-suite hotel and the Singapore Oceanarium in the third quarter of 2025.

site_title: Gold gains on softer US dollar, mounting Trump tariff concerns
summary: Gold prices rose 0.3% to US$2,868.29 an ounce, driven by a weaker US dollar and concerns over US President Trump's tariff threats, potentially leading to a global trade war and inflation. US gold futures rose 1.1% to US$2,880.70. The US Commerce Secretary confirmed tariffs on Canada and Mexico will go into effect on Tuesday, while Trump plans to impose a 10% tariff on Chinese goods. This news fueled safe-haven demand for gold, a trend that could continue if inflation rises.

images.alt_text: Gold is seen as a hedge against political risks and inflation, but higher interest rates dampen the non-yielding asset’s appeal.

site_title: Garuda set to replace head of low cost unit in push for recovery
summary: Garuda Indonesia plans to replace the head of its low-cost unit, Citilink Indonesia, amid efforts to boost profitability and recover from the pandemic's impact. Former Thai Lion Air executive Darsito Hendro Seputro is a leading candidate to take over the role currently held by Dewa Kadek Rai. The move is part of new CEO Wamildan Tsani Panjaitan's efforts to consolidate power and address the carrier's financial struggles, which include a US$10 billion debt restructuring and a net loss of US$29.6 million in the last quarter.

images.alt_text: Irfan Setiaputra, who served as Garuda CEO for more than four years, said that he accepted the decision professionally and was grateful for the trust that had been given to him.

Despite the almost US$10 billion debt restructuring in 2022 that saw its fleet shrink from about 210 aircraft, Garuda is still struggling to generate a profit amid increased competition with privately-held Lion Mentari Airlines.
SIA first announced plans to enter into a joint venture with Garuda Indonesia  in May 2023.
The tie-up is unlikely to reduce competition, said SIA and Garuda, as they will continue to face “intense” rivalry from low-cost carriers.

site_title: Servers likely containing Nvidia chips exported to Malaysia may have been bound elsewhere: Shanmugam
summary: Singapore's Home Affairs and Law Minister K Shanmugam announced a police investigation into computer servers potentially containing Nvidia chips exported to Malaysia, with possible false representations of the final destination. Preliminary investigations suggest servers from US firms Dell and Supermicro were sent to Singapore-based companies, then exported to Malaysia. Shanmugam warned that if there were false representations, an offence under Singapore laws has been committed, and Singapore will take firm and decisive action. The case is linked to a separate fraud case involving three men charged with Nvidia chip-related fraud.

images.alt_text: The trio’s cases have been adjourned to Mar 7.
Nvidia has been the biggest beneficiary of a massive surge in AI spending, doubling the size of its revenue in the past two years

site_title: China could restart import controls on coal as oversupply mounts
summary: China may re-establish import controls on coal due to a mounting oversupply, according to Morgan Stanley. The country's leading industry groups warned of a rapid decline in mine profitability and continuous drop in prices. China's coal imports have exceeded 300 million tonnes, with demand falling short of expectations. To cope with high inventories, miners are advised to control output and importers to curb lower-quality fuel shipments. The move could discourage imports, rather than a complete ban, given China's obligations to the World Trade Organization.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is the world’s largest coal exporter and China, the top importer, is its biggest market.
Long-term coal-power contracts are also reinforcing the fuel’s dominance at the expense of renewables.
Mongolia benefits from its proximity to China and is seeking to cement that with better rail connections.

site_title: Japan’s top currency diplomat cautious about how FX could impact wage growth
summary: Japan's top currency diplomat, Atsushi Mimura, has expressed caution about the impact of foreign exchange on the country's goal of achieving real wage growth. A 10% yen depreciation could push up inflation by 0.3%, exacerbating the issue. Mimura noted that rising wages are a bright spot in Japan, with companies expecting strong wage increases in annual labor-management negotiations. The diplomat emphasized the need to address the issue of a weak yen, which accelerates inflation and weighs on consumption, as a key policy priority.

images.alt_text: The higher cost of food is forcing the Japanese to scrimp and bargain hunt as their purchasing power drops.

site_title: US traders’ gold rush sparks Singapore’s bullion boom
summary: US traders are stockpiling gold amid trade disruptions and the US's tariff-free status on the metal, sparking a "bullion boom" in Singapore. The city-state has seen a surge in gold exports to the US, with 11.3 tonnes shipped in January alone, nearing last year's total. This has boosted export figures in several countries, including Thailand, where gold shipments rose by nearly 14%. Despite concerns about physical supply, Singapore's retail gold market remains robust, with demand continuing to rise. The US traders' demand for bullion is also expected to boost demand further, potentially elevating prices.

images.alt_text: Gold is seen as a hedge against political risks and inflation, but higher interest rates dampen the non-yielding asset’s appeal.
Spot gold was up 0.1 per cent at US$2,918.22 an ounce.
Bitcoin down 25% from all-time high as crypto sell-off deepens

site_title: Father-son feud: BT looks at CDL shares’ highs and lows under Sherman Kwek’s watch
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng disputes his son Sherman Kwek's fitness to run the company, citing a dismal share price since Sherman Kwek's appointment as CEO in 2018. The company's share price has fluctuated over the past seven years, with peaks and troughs. Kwek Leng Beng's reasons for questioning Sherman Kwek's leadership include the share price decline and other unspecified factors. The ongoing battle for board control highlights the challenges facing the company under Sherman Kwek's leadership.

site_title: Star Entertainment faces trading suspension after earnings delay
summary: The Australian Securities Exchange suspended trading in Star Entertainment Group shares on Monday after the casino operator missed its first-half earnings report deadline. The company had been waiting to receive bailout offers and faces financial difficulties. Star Entertainment and its CEO, Steve McCann, are scrambling to secure funding to prevent the business from collapsing. This is the latest challenge for the company, which has also faced regulatory issues.

site_title: Asia: Markets climb on China fiscal hopes against Trump tariffs
summary: Asian markets rose on Monday as investors hoped for a Chinese fiscal stimulus package to counter US President Donald Trump's looming tariffs. Hong Kong's Hang Seng and Japan's Nikkei climbed over 1%, while Shanghai also increased. Traders are watching for last-minute deals to ward off tariffs on Mexico, Canada, and China, set to take effect Tuesday. China's National People's Congress meeting, starting Wednesday, is seen as a key event for a potential stimulus package. Bitcoin slipped 1.3% on Asian markets after a six-per-cent surge on Sunday on Trump's consideration of adding digital assets to US reserves.

images.alt_text: Cordlife's loss per share for the half-year period came in at S$0.0247.
The Dow Jones Industrial Average finished up 1.4 per cent at 43,840.91 on Friday.

site_title: New Zealand exports outpace imports in positive sign for economy
summary: New Zealand's exports outpaced imports in the fourth quarter of last year, driven by a surge in meat shipments. Export volumes rose 1.3% and net exports became positive for the first time since early 2024, contributing to a potential GDP expansion. The country's meat and dairy industries benefited from good growing conditions, while the local dollar dropped 9.5% against the greenback. This positive sign comes after a sharp recession that saw the economy contract 2.1% in the previous six months.

images.alt_text: The RBNZ estimates the economy grew 0.3 per cent in the fourth quarter.

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has now cut rates by 175 basis points since August, with a slowdown in inflation giving policymakers leeway to extend their easing efforts in a much needed boost for an economy struggling to emerge from a deep recession.
Net arrivals of foreigners dropped by more than 97,000 from 2023 but were still the second-highest on record at around 74,100, today’s report showed.

site_title: China bubble tea chain Mixue pops 47% on debut as Hong Kong IPO volumes rebound
summary: China's largest bubble tea chain, Mixue Group, made a 47% gain in its Hong Kong IPO debut, with shares rising to HK$298 from HK$262. The company raised US$444 million in an initial public offering, with retail investors subscribing 5,258 times more shares than offered. The strong start to the year in Hong Kong IPOs, with US$1.44 billion raised so far, is seen as a sign of hopes for a strong year in new equity issuances by Chinese companies amid a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Mixue is best known for selling fruit and tea drinks, coffee and ice cream, typically for about US$1.
Mixue plans to start trading on the Hong Kong Stock Exchange in early March.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Haw Par, UOI, Japfa, Cordlife, UMS, Elite UK Reit
summary: Stocks to watch on Monday include Haw Par, which may see a potential takeover after minority shareholders of United Overseas Insurance proposed distributing its shares to UOI shareholders. Japfa posted a net profit of US$61.9 million for H2 FY2024, while Cordlife reported a net loss of S$6.3 million for the same period. UMS Integration fell 29% year-on-year in earnings, and Elite UK Reit divested a property for £1.2 million, using the proceeds to repay outstanding borrowings.

site_title: UOB commits S$30 million to support disadvantaged students across Asean
summary: UOB commits S$30 million to support disadvantaged students across Southeast Asia, aiming to provide educational resources to over 120,000 children. The bank partners with an education technology platform in Indonesia to offer coding and computational training to 90,000 children from underprivileged families. Additionally, UOB's My Digital Space programme will provide digital learning tools to 20,000 more students, while The Straits Times School Pocket Money Fund will give 11,000 students 90 days of pocket money for school expenses. The initiatives align with UOB's 90th anniversary and its focus on investing in the region's collective future.

images.alt_text: UOB volunteers at a Christmas carolling session, which was organised as part of its Christmas charity pop-up event.

Mr Wee Ee Cheong, UOB’s Deputy Chairman and CEO (centre) and Mr Ted Tan, Vice Chairman, Community Chest (fourth from left, in white) with UOB colleagues at the start line of the 2024 UOB Heartbeat Run.

site_title: Australia job ads fall 1.4% m/m in February: ANZ-Indeed data
summary: Australia's job advertisements decreased 1.4% in February from January, offsetting the previous month's 1.3% rise. Despite this, job ads remained 14.7% higher than pre-pandemic levels. The economy created 44,000 new jobs in January, maintaining a low jobless rate of 4.1%. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates for the first time in over four years, but policymakers remain cautious due to a tight labour market.

site_title: Seven & i finalising plan for president Isaka to step down: sources
summary: SEVEN & i Holdings, a Japanese retail giant, is finalising a plan for President Ryuichi Isaka to step down, likely to be replaced by director Stephen Dacus, who heads a special committee evaluating a $47 billion takeover bid from Alimentation Couche-Tard. This would be the largest takeover of a Japanese company. Isaka's resignation and Dacus' potential appointment are part of the company's efforts to address the takeover bid and maintain stability.

images.alt_text: As well as expanding in Europe, Seven & i aims to re-enter Indonesia “at all costs” after it withdrew in 2017, Wakabayashi says.

The failure of Seven & I Holdings' buyout heightens the likelihood of Couche-Tard pulling off a mammoth acquisition of one of Japan’s best-known and most beloved retailers, which owns 7-Eleven convenience stores.
The retailer has sought to separate non-core businesses that include its supermarket operations into York Holdings.

site_title: Chubb is said to near buying Liberty Mutual Thai, Vietnam units
summary: Chubb is nearing a deal to acquire Liberty Mutual's businesses in Thailand and Vietnam, boosting its presence in South-east Asia. The acquisition, valued at a few hundred million US dollars, would follow previous disposals by Liberty Mutual to streamline operations. Chubb has been expanding its Asian operations, including a 2022 deal to buy Cigna's Asia-Pacific businesses for over US$5 billion. The transaction could be announced as early as Monday, March 3, pending final details.

site_title: Singapore billionaire Peter Lim denies media reports he’s putting up Valencia football club for sale
summary: Singapore billionaire Peter Lim has denied media reports that he is putting Valencia football club up for sale, citing a statement from Meriton Holdings, his vehicle holding his stake in the team. The club, facing a battle against relegation, is reportedly seeking 400 million euros (S$562 million) for Lim's majority stake. Despite previous reports of interest from potential buyers, Lim has shown no interest in selling the club, which has been plagued by financial difficulties and poor performances in recent years.

site_title: China’s factory activity picks up but trade uncertainties weigh: Caixin PMI
summary: China's manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in three months in February, driven by stronger supply and demand, including a rebound in export orders. The Caixin/S&P Global manufacturing PMI rose to 50.8, beating analysts' forecasts, but rising input costs and declining employment weighed on profit margins. Despite these challenges, business sentiment improved, buoyed by signs of recovering domestic demand and expectations of additional government support.

images.alt_text: BYD’s entrance in July into Vietnam underscores both the opportunities and challenges Chinese companies face as they seek to push into South-east Asia.
Xi has a delicate balancing act to maintain in providing the right dose of stimulus to hit the growth target while ensuring aid goes to the parts of the economy that need it most.

site_title: Australian house prices rebound in February, spurred by rate cut
summary: Australian house prices rebounded 0.3% in February, driven by expectations of lower interest rates following the Reserve Bank of Australia's rate cut. The rebound was seen in major cities, with Sydney and Melbourne recording gains, except for Darwin. Improved buyer sentiment and modest value rises led to an increase in auction clearance rates. The RBA's rate cut, its first in over four years, eased pressure on buyers and triggered a rapid response in the property market.

site_title: BYD maintains fast start to year with strong February sales
summary: BYD, China's top-selling auto brand, maintained its strong start to the year with a 161% year-over-year increase in February sales, selling over 318,000 pure electric and hybrid passenger vehicles. The company's overseas sales also hit a record month with 67,025 units. BYD is the best-performing stock in the Bloomberg World Auto Manufacturers Index, gaining around 40% this year, while its nearest challenger, Geely Automobile Holdings, posted an 84% increase in February sales.

images.alt_text: BYD’s entrance in July into Vietnam underscores both the opportunities and challenges Chinese companies face as they seek to push into South-east Asia.

site_title: ST Engineering shares soar over 8% as analysts raise target price
summary: ST Engineering's shares surged over 8% after analysts raised the target price, driven by a 9.9% revenue rise to S$5.8 billion, mainly from defence and public security, as well as commercial aerospace segments. The company reported a 19.6% increase in net profit to S$365.7 million for the second half. Analysts expect ST Engineering to maintain strong earnings growth momentum in 2025, with potential dividend hikes.

images.alt_text: As at end-2024, ST Engineering's order book stood at S$28.5 billion.
New York City’s congestion pricing programme began operating just last month, with drivers entering parts of Manhattan charged US$9 during peak hours.
The commercial aerospace segment clinched several new contracts across its maintenance, repair and overhaul (MRO), as well as its aerostructures and systems sub-units.

site_title: Japan’s consumers hunt for bargains as food inflation bites
summary: Japan's consumers are feeling the pinch as food inflation bites, with purchasing power dropping 25% in the past year. The cost of staples like rice, eggs, and cabbage has surged, forcing many to cut back on fresh produce and eat in. A 35-year-old housewife, Taemi Komiyama, has increased her monthly food budget to 50,000 yen, up 25% from last year. As a result, she's cutting back on fresh vegetables and considering rejoining the workforce to cope with the rising costs.

images.alt_text: The pace of inflation in the capital has been slower than the national trend due in part to education subsidies that are only in effect in Tokyo.
Japan's manufacturing sector has stayed lukewarm, even before US tariffs on cars and other key Japanese export items are set to take effect.
The increase in Japan's core consumer price index, which excludes fresh food prices, compared with a median market forecast for a 3.1 per cent gain and followed a 3.0 per cent rise in December.
The level of fresh food prices has risen 71.9 per cent since 2010, about five times more than that of inflation excluding it.

site_title: Malaysian stem cell therapy provider Yakin Medic aims to raise RM100 million in Catalist IPO: report
summary: Yakin Medic, a Malaysian stem cell therapy provider, plans to list on the Catalist board of the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in the fourth quarter of 2025 or early 2026, aiming to raise RM100 million (S$30.2 million). The funds will be used to develop a factory lot in Malaysia, expand into overseas markets, enhance research and development, and establish satellite laboratories. Singapore-based Evolve Capital Advisory will be the IPO's sponsor and issue manager, while Malaysian private equity firm MCI Capital has secured a cornerstone investment.

images.alt_text: O2genes is one of the players in the longevity market, specialising in oxygen therapy.
The MAS equities review group previously stated it will continue to study the necessary and complementary measures for an effective disclosure-based regime.

site_title: Investment-linked insurance: No panacea for returns or protection
summary: Singapore's investment-linked insurance (ILP) sales surged 41% to $2.25 billion in 2024, outpacing participating and non-participating insurance plans. ILPs offer higher potential returns but also come with uncertain investment returns, minimal death benefits, and high fees. Experts warn that ILPs may not provide sufficient protection, with death benefits as low as 101-105% of premiums, and that consumers should prioritize core life coverage first. High costs and penalties for early withdrawals also deter investors, with lower-cost options available through robos and banks offering better value.

images.alt_text: As at end-December, about 40,000 more Singaporeans and permanent residents were covered by integrated shield plans.
Financial advisory firm Providend has sworn off product commissions and only charges a fee for advice. Its new sister company Havend will focus on insurance advisory and retain product commissions.

site_title: China may be ready to use nuclear fusion for power by 2050
summary: China aims to commercialize nuclear fusion technology for emissions-free power generation by 2050, surpassing the US and France as the world's largest reactor fleet by 2030. China National Nuclear Corporation (CNNC) plans to start commercial operation of its first power generation project around 2045, following a demonstration phase starting in 2045. This is a significant achievement, as nuclear fusion is a notoriously difficult process to sustain and use for energy.

site_title: Oil recovers as upbeat Chinese manufacturing data increases some optimism
summary: Oil prices rose 1% on Monday as China's manufacturing activity expanded at the fastest pace in three months, boosting fuel demand optimism. Brent crude climbed to $73.57 a barrel, while US West Texas Intermediate crude reached $70.51 a barrel. Despite uncertainty about global economic growth due to US tariffs, analysts from Goldman Sachs suggest stable to slightly better economic activity in China. However, a new round of US tariffs on Chinese exports set to start on March 4 may prompt retaliatory measures.

BP had aimed to cut oil and gas output by 40 per cent by 2030, but was last year reported to have abandoned the target.

site_title: Xi prepares to unveil China stimulus plan as trade war heats up
summary: China is poised to unveil a stimulus plan to boost its economy, which has been hit by a trade war with the US. President Xi Jinping's government will lift its official budget deficit target to around 4% of GDP from 3% in 2024, aiming for a growth rate of around 5%. The package will include trillions of yuan in new special sovereign bonds and local government bonds to stimulate domestic demand. Analysts warn that the measures may not be enough to counter the impact of US tariffs, and the government must balance stimulus with managing local debt risks and inflation.

images.alt_text: China's official non-manufacturing purchasing managers’ index, which includes services and construction, rose to 50.4 from 50.2 in January, according to the National Bureau of Statistics.

site_title: CDL saga: High Court ordered both sides to withhold action on Singapura Developments, M&C ahead of Tuesday hearing
summary: The High Court has ordered both sides in the City Developments Ltd (CDL) saga to refrain from taking any action related to Singapura Developments and Millennium & Copthorne Hotels ahead of a Tuesday hearing. This comes as CDL shares resumed trading on Monday after a trading halt, falling 7% to S$4.76. The conflict centers on the appointments of two new independent non-executive directors, which the elder Kwek chairman alleged were "irregular" and part of an "attempted coup" by his son Sherman Kwek.

images.alt_text: CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng said he has filed court papers on Feb 25 to deal with the “attempted coup” by his son and group chief executive, Sherman Kwek.

site_title: Trump heads towards tariff barrage on Canada, Mexico, China
summary: US President Donald Trump is set to impose new tariffs on Canada and Mexico, doubling a levy on China to 20%, affecting $1.5 trillion in annual imports. The tariffs aim to secure the US border from migrants and drugs, particularly fentanyl. Canada and Mexico have worked to address border security concerns, but the move risks weakening the US economy, triggering inflation, and disrupting North American supply chains. The tariffs may lead to retaliatory measures from Canada and China, and could be delayed or delayed further as negotiations continue.

images.alt_text: Demand has been a long-running drag on the world’s second-largest economy, fuelling a deflationary spiral that has kept prices stubbornly low.
US President Donald Trump said on Thursday (Feb 27) in a social media post that drugs from the country’s North American neighbours are still entering “at very high and unacceptable levels.”
US data show that imports from China declined to 13.4 per cent of total imports in 2024 from 21.6 per cent in 2018.

site_title: ‘Captain America’ stays on top of North American box office
summary: "Captain America: Brave New World" stayed on top of the North American box office with an estimated US$15 million for the Friday-through-Sunday period, half of last weekend's take. The slowest Oscar weekend in years, the film outperformed other new releases, including "Last Breath" and "The Monkey". The poor performance reflects the disappointing showing of big-budget films and the availability of Oscar-nominated films on streaming platforms.

site_title: Green insurance: A commitment to sustainability
summary: The insurance industry is integrating climate risk into underwriting and investment decisions, developing green insurance policies, and leveraging data analytics to better predict and manage risks. The global green transition presents opportunities for insurers to close the protection gap, enhance business resilience, and foster sustainable development through investments. However, establishing a universally accepted definition of "green" poses challenges, and insurers must adapt to this evolving landscape by gathering new data and refining risk assessments. Key players like Generali Group and Generali China Insurance are leading efforts to support clients through tailored insurance solutions and investments in adaptation technologies.

images.alt_text: At a time of rising protectionism, pursuing open trade requires the establishment of a special green free-trade arrangement, involving sharp reductions in tariffs and non-tariff barriers on goods and services that deliver environmental and climate benefits.

site_title: Number of tech startups in Hong Kong hits record high in 2024
summary: Hong Kong has reached a record high of 4,694 tech startups in 2024, a 10% increase from 2023, with 17,651 employees. The city's tech scene is driven by its proximity to the Chinese mainland market, international outlook, and robust intellectual property protection. This has led to Hong Kong surpassing Shenzhen as a hub for unicorns, with nine tech companies valued over $1 billion, compared to six in Shenzhen. The Hong Kong government aims to boost its unicorn count to 30 by 2032, with local entrepreneurs representing 72% of startup founders.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong’s benchmark Hang Seng Index on Friday (Feb 28) slumped over 3 per cent, its largest one-day decline since October 2024.
New World has undergone two CEO changes in two months, with Adrian Cheng, stepping down in September, raising concerns over its corporate governance.

site_title: Most Thais not confident in Paetongtarn’s government: poll
summary: A recent poll conducted by the National Institute of Development Administration (Nida) found that 63% of Thais are not confident in Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra's government due to its failure to revive the economy over the past six months. The government has a growth target of 3-3.5% for this year, but its current economic data suggests a lower growth rate. Paetongtarn's government has implemented cash handouts and stimulus measures, but the gross domestic product grew only 2.5% in 2024. The poll also showed that 55% of participants are dissatisfied with the coalition government's performance.

Thai exports increased 13.6 per cent in January from a year earlier, beating a forecast for a 7.15 per cent rise in a Reuters poll, and compared with December’s 8.7 per cent increase.

site_title: France, UK propose one-month Ukraine truce: Macron
summary: French President Emmanuel Macron and UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer have proposed a one-month truce in Ukraine, covering "in the air, at sea and on energy infrastructure." However, the truce would not initially cover ground fighting. Macron stated that peacekeepers would be deployed at a later date and that European troops would not be deployed on Ukrainian soil in the coming weeks. He also emphasized the need for European countries to increase defense spending to 3-3.5% of GDP to respond to changing global priorities.

images.alt_text: The euro slumped after the meeting and was last down 0.29 per cent at US$1.0367 after dropping to US$1.0359, its lowest since Feb 12.

site_title: China’s EV makers are facing a reality check in South-east Asia
summary: Chinese electric vehicle (EV) makers are facing challenges in South-east Asia as the region's upwardly mobile population aspires to own EVs but may be priced out. BYD's entry into Vietnam in July highlights the opportunities and challenges Chinese companies face in the region. Despite a youthful population keen on EVs, Vietnamese EV maker VinFast Auto reports a steady stream of customers, with 20 daily visits during weekdays, while BYD's showroom remains empty. This disparity suggests that affordability remains a significant barrier to EV adoption in the region.

site_title: US Republicans suggest Zelensky may have to step down
summary: US Republicans are suggesting that Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky may have to step down if a peace deal with Russia is to be reached, following a contentious Oval Office meeting between President Donald Trump and Zelensky. National Security Advisor Mike Waltz stated that Zelensky's personal motivations or political motivations must align with ending the war, while some Republicans argue that Zelensky poses a greater obstacle to peace. Trump has shifted his approach to the war with Russia, and senior Democrats are pushing back against his comments, calling the White House an "arm of the Kremlin".

site_title: Honor Device pledges US$10 billion for AI in bid to be more than a phone maker
summary: Honor Device, a Chinese smartphone maker, plans to invest $10 billion over five years to develop an AI-centric ecosystem. The company aims to become a contender in the AI race, collaborating with global partners such as Google and Qualcomm. Honor joins other companies, including Huawei and Chinese internet giants, in accelerating AI updates. The move aims to drive user engagement and upgrades in hardware, but questions remain about the monetization potential of AI technologies.

site_title: ILPs: Invest with eyes wide open
summary: Investment-linked insurance plans (ILPs) are complicated due to their complex cost structure, especially dual accounts with varying fees. Policyholders may face lower returns than projected, and recurring annual charges can significantly impact the effective rate of return. ILPs use a "carrot and stick" approach, offering bonus units to attract buyers but imposing hefty charges for withdrawals or surrender. It is essential to evaluate cash flow needs and consider alternative, cost-efficient options before committing to an ILP.

images.alt_text: money, savings, piggy
As at end-December, about 40,000 more Singaporeans and permanent residents were covered by integrated shield plans.

site_title: Trump sparks crypto rally by saying more coins to be in reserve
summary: US President Donald Trump has sparked a cryptocurrency rally by announcing a plan to create a strategic crypto reserve, with the XRP and ADA tokens included. The announcement led to gains across most digital assets, with both XRP and ADA experiencing huge rallies. However, details of the plan, including the amount to be purchased and funding, remain unknown.

images.alt_text: Memecoins are a type of crypto asset that are seeded by an Internet meme or a joke.
The world’s largest digital asset has come under pressure this week, with its price sinking to its lowest level since mid-November after hitting an all-time high earlier this year.

Stablecoins often serve as a bridge between crypto and the traditional financial system, in addition to being used to facilitate trades and serving as a haven from the price volatility of most other cryptocurrencies.
Losses from cryptocurrency-related scams surged to 24.3 per cent of total scam losses last year - from about 6.8 per cent in 2023.

site_title: Chaos at CDL: Crossing the Rubicon
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng accused his son, CEO Sherman Kwek, of orchestrating a boardroom coup by merging the nominating and remuneration committees. Kwek Leng Beng claimed this stripped him of authority and gave the majority bloc "unrestricted control" over CDL's leadership. The dispute centers on the appointment of two new independent directors, which bypassed the nominating committee and was not approved by a board meeting. A court case is underway, with Kwek Leng Beng likely to step down, and directors who backed the withdrawing party may also quit.

images.alt_text: CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng is suing his son and group CEO Sherman Kwek over an  'attempted coup'.

Good boards and management usually don’t have soap-opera-worthy drama, the writer says.
CDL posts basic earnings per share (EPS) of S$0.121, compared with an EPS of S$0.27 in the year-ago period.
Dr Wu (front row, right) and CDL a Millennium Hotels and Resorts London Townhall.

site_title: Food From The Heart rallies automotive community for food drive
summary: Food From The Heart (FFTH) partnered with Wearnes Automotive to collect over 33,000 food items in the third edition of Heart On Wheels, surpassing its target of 28,000. The event, which ran from March 1-2, involved 260 cars and over 16 car and bike clubs, as well as volunteers, donating nearly S$125,000 worth of food items. FFTH aims to reach 3,500 more lower-income households with these items and funds, and plans to open more community shops and increase donations by S$5-8 per household by 2027.

images.alt_text: Chefs setting up the 88-m-long stollen on Wednesday.

site_title: Samsung broadens AI phone lineup with US$300 5G Galaxy models
summary: Samsung expands its AI phone lineup with three 6.7-inch 5G handsets starting at $299.99, featuring improved photo editing and search capabilities. The Galaxy A26 and A56 models also offer night photography and Best Face features. This move aims to bring more users into the fold, competing with Apple's recently released iPhone 16e. Samsung combines its AI tools with Google's, while Apple develops its Apple Intelligence suite, tapping outside providers for components. The rollout comes as all AI developers invest heavily in scaling up, marking an effort to bring more users into the fold.

site_title: BT Money Hacks: Retrenchment survival guide financial tips
summary: A recent podcast episode, "BT Money Hacks: Retrenchment Survival Guide," offers actionable financial tips for managing finances post-retrenchment. Experts Daphne Tan and Zac Ng discuss the drivers behind retrenchments, the importance of building an emergency fund, and balancing long-term financial goals with short-term liquidity needs. They also emphasize the need for proactive financial planning and provide advice on maintaining investments and insurance policies during uncertain times. By understanding these key aspects, individuals can better prepare for unexpected financial setbacks.

images.alt_text: Getting the right partner is the key to success, according to Annabella Patisserie’s founder.
True financial freedom goes beyond balancing budgets and mastering spreadsheets.
Can you manage your finances yourself or is help really needed?

site_title: Shell mulls sale of European, US chemicals assets: WSJ
summary: Shell is considering the sale of its European and US chemicals assets, according to a Wall Street Journal report. The energy group has hired Morgan Stanley to conduct a strategic review of its chemicals operations. Potential buyers include private equity firms and Middle Eastern entities seeking to expand their Western presence. The review is in its early stages, and Shell has not made any definitive decisions. One of the assets under review is Shell's Deer Park facility in Texas, adjacent to a refinery previously sold to Pemex. This sale would be the latest move by Shell to cut costs and focus on its most profitable sectors.

images.alt_text: BP had aimed to cut oil and gas output by 40 per cent by 2030, but was last year reported to have abandoned the target.
BP’s profit after tax tumbled to US$381 million last year from US$15.2 billion in 2023 in the face of higher costs and weaker oil and gas prices.
Industry forecasts LNG demand to reach between 630 million and 718 million tonnes a year by 2040, Shell said in its 2025 annual LNG outlook.

site_title: Singapore corporate insolvencies reach highest level since 2010
summary: Singapore experienced its highest corporate insolvencies since 2010 in 2024, with 307 firms shuttered, up from 201 the previous year. This is the highest number of compulsory liquidations since 2010. The country's economy is expected to grow 1-3% this year, down from 4.4% in 2024, due to its vulnerability to protectionism.

site_title: Focus on corporate governance as Singapore shifts to more disclosure-based regulatory regime
summary: Singapore's Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has recommended shifting towards a more disclosure-based regulatory regime for the equities market. This approach aims to improve market integrity, investor protections, and minority shareholder rights. The success of this approach depends on active participation from the investment community, including buy and sell-side investors, and other key stakeholders. Industry experts emphasize the need for stronger enforcement levers and legal reforms to protect shareholders. A key regulatory measure involves adopting a more targeted approach to post-listing queries, alerts, and trading suspensions, while removing the financial "watch list" to balance market discipline with investor protection.

Chee Hong Tat, the Second Minster for Finance and chair of the MAS equities market review group, said that having more regulatory rules may not mean more protection for investors.

site_title: Is investing in the S&P 500 good enough?
summary: The S&P 500 index has delivered strong returns over the past 20 years, with a 23% gain last year. Investing in this index is a popular choice due to its diversified exposure and low fees. However, relying solely on the S&P 500 may limit exposure to emerging markets and other sectors, and could increase volatility due to its high concentration in the tech sector. A diversified portfolio with a mix of equities, bonds, and other assets may be a better strategy for investors, especially those with lower risk appetites.

images.alt_text: Fees on new ETFs are rising, rather than falling, as had been the trend for decades. Most funds set up in the past few years have fees of 0.5 per cent or higher.

site_title: Record high levels of undeployed capital, demand for exits seen to drive continued momentum for venture capital deals
summary: Venture capital deal momentum is expected to continue into Q1 2025, driven by record high levels of undeployed capital, demand for exits, and improved investor sentiment. Despite South-east Asia's lack of exits, VC firms are stepping up with exits and returns of over $270 million, with sectors like AI, healthcare, and cleantech likely to see more investment activity. However, exits remain a challenge, and limited partners will remain cautious until the exit environment improves.

site_title: Q&M Dental’s H2 net profit falls 22% to S$4.8 million on lab licence expiry
summary: Q&M Dental Group's net profit for the second half of 2024 fell 22% to S$4.8 million due to a decline in revenue from its Singapore dental clinics and the cessation of its medical laboratory business. Revenue dropped 4% to S$91.5 million, mainly due to a 2% decline in its core dental business and a 46% drop in its other businesses. The company's board proposed a second interim dividend of S$0.007 per share. Despite this, the group's full-year net profit rose 27% to S$14.6 million.

site_title: Euro falls to more than 2-week low after Trump, Zelensky meeting
summary: The euro fell to a 2-week low after a tense meeting between Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky and US President Donald Trump, dashing hopes for a peace deal in the war with Russia. The meeting ended without a deal, and Zelensky left the White House early. The euro dropped 0.29% to US$1.0367, its lowest since February 12, amid uncertainty and market volatility.

site_title: Energy majors hold back on renewables, focus more on fossil fuels: research report
summary: Energy giants such as BP, Shell, and Equinor are shifting focus from renewable energy to fossil fuels due to rising costs and supply chain disruptions in wind and hydrogen power. Despite ambitious net-zero emissions targets, many companies are weakening or dropping their renewable energy goals. Instead, they are investing in oil and gas projects, including bioenergy and electric vehicle charging infrastructure, to secure higher short-term returns. BMI notes that profit margins in the oil and gas business are expected to narrow, leading companies to prioritize short-term gains over long-term sustainability.

images.alt_text: BP’s profit after tax tumbled to US$381 million last year from US$15.2 billion in 2023 in the face of higher costs and weaker oil and gas prices.

site_title: China’s February second-hand home prices narrows for seventh straight month: report
summary: China's second-hand home prices fell 7.3% year-on-year in February, marking the seventh straight month of decline, according to a report. Meanwhile, the average price of new builds in 100 cities increased by 2.7%. The Chinese real estate market is expected to stabilize in March, with some urban centers potentially experiencing a "Mini Spring" rally, driven by policy support and the post-holiday property transactions.

site_title: Malaysia’s ex-PM Ismail declares wealth to anti-graft agency amid seizure of assets
summary: Malaysia's former Prime Minister Ismail Sabri Yaakob has declared his wealth to the anti-graft agency amid a corruption and money laundering probe. The investigation focuses on government publicity expenditure and procurement during his premiership from August 2021 to November 2022. Authorities have seized nearly $40 million in assets linked to him, and four senior officials have been detained. Ismail Sabri has also recorded a statement with the agency, which may call him back for further questioning.

site_title: Duxton Reserve, Park Avenue Changi hotels in due diligence by prospective buyers
summary: Duxton Reserve Singapore, a 49-room boutique hotel, is undergoing exclusive due diligence by a prospective buyer with a price tag of about S$80 million. Meanwhile, Weave Living is in due diligence for the 251-room Park Avenue Changi hotel in Changi Business Park, with a price of around S$120 million. The sale of these properties reflects the growing demand for hospitality assets in Singapore, driven by the increasing number of tourist arrivals and events.

site_title: Prada said to move closer to Versace deal for up to 1.5 billion euros
summary: Prada is moving closer to a deal to buy Versace from Capri Holdings for nearly 1.5 billion euros, according to sources. The Italian luxury clothier's sales surged in the third quarter, and a potential acquisition would allow Prada to create a larger Italian player to compete with global luxury groups. Despite the deal, Prada will be worth a fraction of its biggest competitors, and a finalized agreement is still uncertain.

Global luxury brands are increasingly returning to Hong Kong’s core business districts, attracted by property prices that are much lower than pre-pandemic levels.

site_title: Sherman Kwek ropes in Davinder Singh for court battle; CDL shares drop 7% to lowest level since 2009 before recovering
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) shares plummeted 7% to their lowest level since 2009 after a trading halt was lifted, recovering 3.52% by 3 pm. The company's CEO, Sherman Kwek, has roped in Senior Counsel Davinder Singh to represent him in a court battle against his billionaire father, Kwek Leng Beng, who accused Sherman of orchestrating an "attempted coup" to consolidate control of the board. The dispute centers on corporate governance issues, with Sherman claiming a "very serious issue" involving Dr Catherine Wu. The case will be heard in Singapore's Supreme Court on March 4.

site_title: CDL bypass of nominating committee may seem ‘unusual’ but current rules open to interpretation: observers
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng has filed court papers to deal with the "attempted coup" by his son, Sherman Kwek, who had bypassed the nominating committee (NC) to appoint two new directors. Industry observers say the actions are "unusual" and against corporate governance rules, citing the Singapore Exchanges (SGX) Listing Rules and the Code of Corporate Governance. The court can determine if the directors' appointments are in accordance with CDL's constitution, but regulators may also step in to ensure compliance with listing rules.

site_title: Cordlife sinks into red with S$6.3 million H2 loss on fallout from storage lapses
summary: Cordlife, a private cord-blood bank, reported a net loss of S$6.3 million for the second half of 2024, compared to a net profit of S$1.3 million in the same period last year. The loss was largely due to the fallout from lapses in the storage of its cord-blood units, which led to a 32% decline in revenue to S$18.7 million. The company remains cautiously optimistic about its financial performance for FY2025, but notes that a potential settlement of claims from affected clients could have a negative impact on its financial position.

images.alt_text: Cordlife also announced that Yuen Wai has been appointed as an independent director with effect from Feb 19.
Cordlife says that the pace of its recovery for FY2025 remains uncertain.

site_title: Investors are scouring emerging markets for Trump-proof bets
summary: Investors are shifting their focus to emerging markets as a hedge against the unpredictability of US President Donald Trump's trade agenda. These markets offer protection from US tariffs, interest-rate cuts, and a weak US dollar. Key investments include companies like Alibaba Group Holding, which focuses on China's domestic AI adoption, and countries with stable currencies, such as the UAE, Saudi Arabia, and Qatar. Emerging market debt and currencies are also gaining traction, with local-currency bonds expected to outperform this year. However, some investors caution against extrapolating gains to the full year, as the market can be fragile in the face of tariff escalation.

images.alt_text: The US dollar is likely to remain strong due to a robust US economy and a cautious Fed, creating headwinds for EM local markets.
The Malaysian ringgit climbed more than 1 per cent on Friday to the highest since November, the biggest gainer in Asia.

Authorities in developing economies are on the defensive as the greenback’s strength wreaks havoc across global markets.

The International Finance Corporation and HSBC Holding's new partnership aims to help banks in emerging markets increase lending for trade.

site_title: Stars gather for Oscars as ‘Anora,’ ‘Conclave’ vie for top prize
summary: The 97th Academy Awards, hosted by Conan O'Brien, kicked off on March 2, 2025, with Hollywood's A-listers on the red carpet. The best picture prize is seen as a nail-biter between "Anora" and "Conclave", with "Anora" being the frontrunner due to its Palme d'Or win and polarizing sex worker aspect. "Conclave" has won over late voters with its timely theme and all-star cast. Adrien Brody is the current favourite for best actor, but Timothée Chalamet's win could be a spoiler. Demi Moore is a strong contender for best actress, with Mikey Madison from "Anora" also in the running.

site_title: All in the family: An interactive look at the Kwek clan
summary: The Business Times examines the Kwek clan, focusing on the power struggle at CDL, led by executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng and his son, CEO Sherman Kwek. The family's business interests are deeply intertwined, raising concerns about corporate governance. The article also touches on other business developments, including NTT DC Reit's oversubscribed public offer and the potential impact of Trump's tariffs on the US market. Additionally, it highlights other global business news, such as Creative Technology's revenue warning and Indonesia's graft case involving Trafigura.

site_title: Dynasty: Who’s who in the Kwek family tree behind CDL, Hong Leong
summary: City Developments Ltd (CDL) executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng is suing his son and other directors over an "attempted coup" by CEO Sherman Kwek. The Kwek family tree is explored, tracing back to founder Kwek Hong Png in 1941. Sherman Kwek, the son of Kwek Leng Beng, is also a key player in the family business, alongside cousins Quek Leng Chan and Kwek Leng Peck. The family's business interests are held through various investment vehicles, highlighting the complex web of family ties and business relationships within the company.

site_title: US firm Firefly makes its first moon landing with uncrewed Blue Ghost spacecraft
summary: Firefly Aerospace successfully landed its uncrewed Blue Ghost spacecraft on the Moon, marking the second private firm to achieve this feat. The Blue Ghost, carrying 10 scientific payloads, touched down near an ancient volcanic vent on Mare Crisium, and will conduct a 14-day research mission. Firefly declared itself the first company to make a "fully successful" soft landing, surpassing Intuitive Machines' previous attempt. This mission is part of a growing private lunar market, with NASA's Commercial Lunar Payload Services program aiming to stimulate low-cost and routine lunar treks.

site_title: Hospitality S-Reits focus on active portfolio management to drive growth
summary: Hospitality real estate investment trusts (S-Reits) in Singapore have focused on active portfolio management to drive growth in 2024. CapitaLand Ascott Trust (CLAS) and Far East Hospitality Trust (FEHT) reported mixed results, with CLAS' gross profit rising 8% and FEHT's gross revenue and net property income both increasing 0.2%. CDL Hospitality Trusts (CDLHT) completed two acquisitions and is diversifying its portfolio, while Acrophyte Hospitality Trust reported a 3.8% decline in revenue. Despite challenges, the managers remain cautiously optimistic about the sector's prospects, citing Singapore's ease of interest rates and its status as a premier destination for business and tourism.

site_title: Baltic Exchange Shipping Insights
summary: The Baltic Exchange reports a strong week for the tanker and dry bulk market, with the Capesize market surging $6,454 to $15,074, driven by improved sentiment and increased coal cargoes. The Panamax market saw significant losses, with rates dropping in the Atlantic, while the Ultramax/Supramax sector remained stable. The Handysize market showed mixed performance, with modest movements in the Continent and Mediterranean regions. LNG rates increased significantly in the Atlantic basin, particularly for 174k cbm vessels, driven by tighter available tonnage.

site_title: First meeting with CDL’s Kwek Leng Beng felt like a job interview, says Catherine Wu
summary: Dr. Catherine Wu, the only daughter of six siblings, discussed her personal and professional life in a 2024 talk show. Born in Taiwan, Wu pursued music education, eventually obtaining a doctorate from New York University. She released her first piano album in 1990 and hosted a music show in Taiwan. Wu joined City Developments Ltd (CDL) in 1992 after meeting chairman Kwek Leng Beng, who asked her to research properties. Wu has since become a cybersecurity expert and brought an international cyber-security contest to Singapore. However, her official position as adviser to the CDL board has been disputed by Sherman Kwek, Kwek Leng Beng's son, who claims she interferes in matters beyond her scope.
