site_title: Retail S-Reits’ high occupancy, firm yields keep analysts positive
summary: Retail-focused real estate investment trusts (Reits) in Singapore reported improved operating metrics despite slowing retail sales and tenant exits. Malls maintained high occupancy and firm earnings, with top-tier Reits posting positive rent reversions of 5-9% in FY2024. Analysts expect similar rent increases this year, making retail plays attractive as landlords hold prime assets. Key picks include CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT), Starhill Global Reit, and Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT), which have acquired prime retail assets, including Northpoint City's South Wing.

images.alt_text: Difficult trading conditions cut across diverse market segments, with brands ranging from famed US import eggslut to Chinese fast fashion retailer Urban Revivo closing stores in Singapore.

site_title: DBS, UOB, OCBC chiefs’ salary packages still lag global peers
summary: DBS, UOB, and OCBC CEOs' salaries increased in 2024, with DBS' Piyush Gupta's package rising 56.5% to S$17.6 million. Despite this, their remuneration is still lower than global peers, such as Citigroup's Jane Fraser (US$34.5 million) and UBS' Sergio Ermotti (S$22.7 million). The Singapore banks have generated double-digit returns on equity and are better capitalized to withstand global macroeconomic uncertainties, with DBS and OCBC leading in this regard. However, the trio of local banks are not immune to global restructuring efforts, with DBS planning to cut 4,000 contract and temporary staff.

images.alt_text: Piyush Gupta will be retiring at the upcoming AGM “as part of the board renewal process”.
Wee Ee Cheong, CEO and deputy chairman of UOB, notes that the bank’s financial performance remained resilient in 2024, with total income up 3% year on year to S$14.3 billion.
OCBC group chief executive officer Helen Wong received S$1.2 million in base salary for FY2024.

site_title: Kwek vs Kwek: CDL court hearing, trading status in spotlight this week
summary: The Kwek family feud at City Developments Ltd (CDL) has escalated, with the company's shares expected to resume trading on March 3 amidst corporate governance scrutiny and succession uncertainty. Elder Kwek Leng Beng accused his son Sherman Kwek of an "attempted coup" to consolidate control of the board and group, citing "troubling matters" involving adviser Catherine Wu's "enormous influence". Sherman Kwek countered that the move was about addressing corporate governance issues, not ousting his father. The dispute will be heard in Singapore's Supreme Court on March 4, with CDL's future stability and leadership under review.

images.alt_text: CDL exec chairman Kwek Leng Beng is suing his son and other directors over an "attempted coup” by his son and CEO Sherman Kwek.
CDL executive chairman Kwek Leng Beng said he has filed court papers on Feb 25 to deal with the “attempted coup” by his son and group chief executive, Sherman Kwek.
Good boards and management usually don’t have soap-opera-worthy drama, the writer says.
Billionaire Kwek Leng Beng could look to drive value unlocking at CDL if he is firmly in the driver's seat.

site_title: Dream come true for Lydia Ko as she finally adds ‘Asia’s Major’ to trophy haul
summary: Lydia Ko of New Zealand won the HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club, claiming her first victory in 11 attempts and adding the title to her trophy haul. Ko, a three-time Major winner and Olympic gold medalist, finished with a 69 to take the lead, four shots ahead of joint-second finishers Jeeno Thitikul and Ayaka Furue. Ko's dominant performance earned her the US$360,000 prize money and her 13th LPGA win.

images.alt_text: SPRINGFIELD, NJ - JUNE 25: Winner, Ruoning Yin poses with the trophy after the final round of the KPMG Women's PGA Championship at Baltusrol Golf Club on Sunday, June 25, 2023 in Springfield, New Jersey. (Photo by Darren Carroll/PGA of America)

Hannah Green of Australia reacts in jubilation after sinking a birdie on the 18th to win the HSBC Women's World Championship at Sentosa Golf Club’s Tanjong Course on March 3, 2024. Fellow golfer Andrea Lee (back facing camera) of USA raises her arm simultaneously to celebrate her competitor’s win.
From left: Golfers Yin Ruoning, Jeeno Thitikul, Hannah Green, Shannon Tan, Lilia Vu and Charley Hull by the SkyPark Infinity Pool at Marina Bay Sands.

site_title: How far can the Hang Seng Tech Index rise with AI and Beijing’s private-sector shift?
summary: The Hang Seng Tech Index Futures contract, tracking the 30 largest tech stocks in Hong Kong, rebounded following DeepSeek's artificial intelligence breakthrough and Beijing's renewed support for the private sector. The index surged 26% in February, entering a bull market, as investors optimism over AI adoption and application grew. Despite US President Trump's "America First Investment Policy" memo curbing Chinese-affiliated investments, the index reversed losses and soared to an intraday high of 6,026. Analysts expect bullish momentum to persist, driven by technological breakthroughs, Beijing's conciliatory tone, and potential structural shift in market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The Nasdaq-100 Index remains in a strong uptrend, trading within a rising trend channel, that reflects increasing investor optimism.

site_title: Marco Polo Marine bets on renewables for future growth
summary: Marco Polo Marine, a shipping company, is pivoting into the renewable energy sector, despite initially planning to focus on oil and gas. A vessel charter from a Taiwanese company in 2020 sparked the idea, and the company designed and built its own Commissioning Service Operation Vessel (CSOV), the MP Wind Archer, to support offshore wind farms. The vessel, equipped with comforts like a cinema and massage chair, has charters for three years and is expected to contribute to the company's financial performance from the second half of 2025. While the revenue mix will still rely on oil and gas in the short term, CEO Sean Lee believes it will become more balanced between the two sectors in the future.

images.alt_text: Institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks from Feb 7 to Feb 13, leading to net institutional inflow of S$63 million.
Even though the company's revenue declined in FY2024, its gross profit and adjusted net profit after tax had a year-on-year increase of 6 per cent and 4 per cent respectively.
Over the five trading sessions from Nov 29 to Dec 5, institutions were net buyers of Singapore stocks, leading to a net institutional inflow of S$418 million.
Its shipyard operated at a higher average utilisation rate of 91 per cent for FY2024.

site_title: China’s central bank, regulators hold symposium on support for private companies
summary: China's central bank and regulators held a symposium with private companies and financial institutions, vowing to increase lending and support the private economy. PBOC governor Pan Gongsheng said the central bank will adopt an "appropriately loose" monetary policy to maintain market liquidity and ensure low financing costs for private enterprises. The central bank will also create a favorable environment for private enterprises and work on supply chain financing to help small- and medium-sized enterprises. Financial institutions such as ICBC and CITIC Securities have committed to providing significant investment and financing to private enterprises over the next three years.

images.alt_text: News footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured) at a shopping complex in Beijing, China, Feb 17, 2025.

A giant screen shows news footage of Huawei founder Ren Zhengfei speaking next to BYD CEO Wang Chuanfu and New Hope's founder and Chairman Liu Yonghao at a symposium on private enterprises with Chinese President Xi Jinping (not pictured), at a shopping complex in Beijing, China February 17, 2025. REUTERS/Florence Lo
Since 2023, Xi’s government has eased off on the campaign and indicated that it still sees the trillion-dollar technology sector as an important part of the country’s economy.

FILE PHOTO: Paramilitary police officers stand guard in front of the headquarters of the People's Bank of China, the central bank (PBOC), in Beijing, China September 30, 2022. REUTERS/Tingshu Wang/File Photo
Encouraging domestic consumer spending may prove crucial to China this year.
The People’s Bank of China has not cut interest rates in nearly half a year despite its most pro-easing stance in 14 years.
The central bank has been draining funds in most daily operations this year, widening the gap between the benchmark money market rate and the policy rate to the most in four years.
Yields have been rising as the PBOC held back on further monetary easing to prioritise yuan stability in the wake of a renewed trade war with the US.
China's one-year loan prime rate (LPR) was kept at 3.10 per cent, while the five-year LPR was unchanged at 3.60 per cent.
Spot gold was up 0.2 per cent at US$2,847.33 per ounce.

site_title: Australia’s Star Entertainment expects rescue offers, warns earnings may miss deadline
summary: Australia's Star Entertainment expects to receive rescue offers, but warned that it may not be able to file its first-half earnings report by the end of the day, citing uncertainty over its ability to continue as a "going concern." Shares dropped by a fifth to 10 Australian cents after the company said it would receive liquidity proposals on Friday. Star Entertainment has been struggling due to costs from compliance upgrades and weaker discretionary spending, and is expected to report an underlying loss of $79.5 million for the six months ended December 31.

images.alt_text: Star, which has casinos entangled in a web of regulations even as its cash reserves deplete and bills stack up, is due to release its first-half results on Friday.

A person inside a casino in the Philippines. Seven South-east Asian nations – Singapore, Malaysia, the Philippines, Vietnam, Cambodia, Myanmar and Laos – have already legalised gambling to varying degrees.

site_title: Seoul overtakes Paris in beauty boom with dealmakers rushing in
summary: South Korean cosmetics have gained popularity globally, overtaking France as the top exporter of cosmetics to the US in 2024, with total shipments reaching a record $10.2 billion. The industry has seen a surge in dealmaking demand, with 18 deals worth 2.3 trillion won (S$2.1 billion) in 2024, according to advisory firm MMP. Private equity funds are paying attention to Korean cosmetics, expecting the mergers and acquisitions boom to continue this year. Korean brands have cornered about 22% of foreign cosmetics products in the US and 40% in Japan, with companies like CosRX and Amorepacific seeing significant growth in the US and Europe.

images.alt_text: In mainland China, Sephora has incurred millions of US dollars in losses in its efforts to win customers.

site_title: UK, France and Ukraine will present peace deal to Trump: Starmer
summary: UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer announced plans to work with Ukraine and France to present a peace deal to US President Donald Trump, following a clash between Trump and Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at the White House. Starmer urged world leaders to "work together" to end the three-year-old conflict, and the UK, France, and possibly one or two others will collaborate with Ukraine on a plan to stop the fighting. A £2.26-billion loan agreement was also unveiled to support Ukraine's defense capabilities.

images.alt_text: Trump denounced Zelenskiy as “a dictator without elections" after the latter said the US President was trapped in a Russian disinformation bubble.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky reacted to US President Donald Trump’s attacks by accusing him of succumbing to Russian “disinformation.”

US President Donald Trump (left) said his team has been speaking “long and hard” with Russian officials, including his Middle East envoy Steve Witkoff whom the president said met with Vladimir Putin (right) for about three hours recently.
Russian President Vladimir Putin last week said Moscow would hold talks with Ukraine, but ruled out speaking directly to Volodymyr Zelensky (pictured).
US President Donald Trump (right) and Ukraine's President Volodymyr Zelensky (left) argue in the Oval Office of the White House in Washington, D.C., Feb 28, 2025.

site_title: South Korea’s exports barely grow in February as Trump’s tariffs weigh
summary: South Korea's exports grew 1.0% in February to $52.60 billion, missing market expectations, due to a global trade war triggered by US President Trump's tariffs. Shipments to China fell 1.4%, while those to the US rose 1.0%. Exports to the European Union dropped 8.1%. The country's industry minister has requested a tariff exemption from the US, amid plans to introduce reciprocal tariffs on trading partners.

images.alt_text: At the end of 2024, South Korea’s household debt stood at 1,927.3 trillion won (S$1.8 trillion), up 2.2 per cent from a year earlier and the fastest growth in 2-1/2 years.
South Korea’s government has spent hundreds of billions of US dollars over the years in a campaign aimed at encouraging more people to get married and procreate.

A supporter of South Korea President Yoon Suk Yeol waves a flag during a rally in Seoul, South Korea, Feb 25, 2025. Yoon’s policy to grow more closely aligned with Washington amid trade tensions between China and the US has increased South Korea’s reliance on the US market, leaving its businesses more vulnerable to potential tariff changes.

site_title: Malaysia’s national pension fund EPF declares 6.3% dividend, highest since 2017
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) announced a 6.3% dividend for both conventional and syariah savings accounts in 2024, the highest payout since 2017. The fund's higher-than-expected return is driven by an 11% increase in investment income to RM74.5 billion. This move is expected to spur more voluntary contributions, with economists noting that the high dividend rate exceeds Malaysia's long-term inflation rate of 2.5%. The fund's total contributions rose 11% to RM108.2 billion, and its asset class performance was strong, with equities contributing RM49.8 billion to total returns.

images.alt_text: Malaysia’s economy grew more than expected in the second quarter of 2024, exceeding the 5.8 per cent advance estimates made by the Department of Statistics Malaysia.
Malaysia's Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said one in four EPF members actually exhausted their EPF savings within five years after reaching withdrawal age.
MAHB manages 39 airports in Malaysia, including Kuala Lumpur International Airport (KLIA).
Khazanah managing director Amirul Feisal Wan Zahir was positive on Malaysia’s growth prospects due to increasing foreign direct investments, a solid domestic economy, and higher household spending.

site_title: Grubhub cuts 23% of staff after Wonder deal, signals changes
summary: Grubhub is cutting 23% of its workforce, approximately 500 positions, as part of its integration with Wonder Group, following its $650 million takeover in November. The company aims to reduce management layers, bring leaders closer to the business, and remove duplication. Despite the job cuts, Grubhub achieved positive free cash flow in 2024 and has seen growth in order volume and a significant lift in order frequency in its loyalty program tie-up with Amazon Prime.

images.alt_text: DoorDash revenue beats estimates as food-delivery boom continues, shares soar 24%
EU targets Uber, Deliveroo model with gig workers' rights plan
Food-delivery apps sue New York City over fee limits
Uber Eats, DoorDash, Grubhub sue New York City over legislation on commission caps

site_title: Dynastic clashes in fragile states
summary: Former Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte has been dispatched to the Hague for an International Criminal Court trial, sparking concerns about the integrity of the country. The move has fueled separatist sentiment in the southern province of Mindanao, where Duterte comes from, and has raised tensions between the Marcos and Dutertes. Duterte's proposal for a separate Mindanao nation has been seen as a way to avoid an ICC trial, and his son Paolo is now facing trial in the Philippines Senate for making threats to officials. The situation has raised concerns about the fragility of the country and the potential for subversion in Mindanao.

images.alt_text: Supporters of Philippine former president Rodrigo Duterte gather at the central area for a rally in Davao City, in the southern island of Mindanao on March 28, 2025. Family and supporters of former Philippine president Rodrigo Duterte rallied on March 28 to mark his 80th birthday and protest against his detention in The Hague on a charge of crimes against humanity. (Photo by Ferdinandh CABRERA / AFP)

site_title: China’s February manufacturing activity hits three-month high
summary: China's manufacturing activity rebounded in February with a three-month high of 50.2, surpassing the 50-mark separating growth from contraction. The move indicates the government's stimulus measures are helping shore up the economy. China's $18 trillion economy met its 5% growth target in 2024, but analysts are uncertain about reviving sluggish demand amid US President Trump's punitive trade curbs. Policymakers have pledged higher fiscal spending and monetary easing to sustain growth and counter external pressures.

images.alt_text: Clothing and accessories for sale at the new Urban Revivo store in the Soho neighborhood of New York, US, Feb 28, 2025. Urban Revivo is planning three new stores this year in New York and London.

The company’s board proposed a final cash dividend of S$0.023, compared with the S$0.013 in the year-ago period, to  be paid upon shareholders’ approval at its upcoming annual general meeting, at a payment date that will be announced later.

Residential buildings at a government-subsidized rental housing complex in Beijing, China, on Sunday, Oct. 13, 2024. China promised new measures to support the property sector and hinted at greater government borrowing to shore up the economy, as authorities seek to put a floor under the country’s growth slowdown. Photographer: Na Bian/Bloomberg

site_title: Shipping profit boom evaporates on US tariffs, Red Sea reopening
summary: US tariffs on Chinese goods are expected to reduce container shipping demand by 1.5-2 percentage points in 2025, according to analysts. The reopening of the Red Sea route, potentially by mid-year, could reduce demand by 6%. This may lead to a decline in liner rates by 30-40% compared to 2024. Companies like Maersk, Cosco, and Evergreen Marine are forecast to see profit declines in 2025 due to the impact of tariffs and the potential reduction in shipping demand. The industry is vulnerable to booms and busts, with analysts warning of a volatile outlook for 2025.

images.alt_text: China’s share of global shipbuilding capacity has surged over the past decade to account for around half of new builds, partly driven by its own domestic demand for more ships.
Maersk's underlying earnings before interest, tax, depreciation and amortisation (Ebitda) came in at US$3.6 billion for the fourth quarter.
From left: Pinnacle Marine's business development manager Ken Lee; chairman Laurence Chua and CEO Fabian Lim at the group's new shipyard, which was acquired for S$6 million.
Shipping carries more than four-fifths of world trade, but relies on traditional fuels at present to power most of the fleet.
Hutchison Ports operates two of the five ports adjacent to the Panama Canal, one on each side.
The electric supply boat, called PXO-EXL-1, can accommodate a payload about four times that of a conventional supply boat.
PSA’s record throughput came amid increasing geopolitical uncertainty that has impacted the shipping industry worldwide.
Murali Pillai, Minister of State for Law and for Transport, noted that the new records were achieved against a backdrop of geopolitical conflicts and strained global supply chains.

An undated photo of a VLCC (Very Large Crude Carrier) manufactured by the Universal Shipbuilding Corporation sailing off the coast of Japan. Source: Universal Shipbuilding Corporation via Bloomberg News.

site_title: Pro golfers share life lessons to inspire youths
summary: Professional golfers Shannon Tan and Lauren Coughlin visited Trybe's office in Singapore, meeting with 7 youths to share life lessons about overcoming challenges. The golfers discussed the importance of persistence, community support, and resilience, inspiring the youths to pursue their goals. The event was part of HSBC's initiative to support youths aged 12-25, particularly those from the out-of-home care sector, and raised funds for Trybe through a digital golf game, "Play it Forward."

images.alt_text: SPRINGFIELD, NJ - JUNE 25: Winner, Ruoning Yin poses with the trophy after the final round of the KPMG Women's PGA Championship at Baltusrol Golf Club on Sunday, June 25, 2023 in Springfield, New Jersey. (Photo by Darren Carroll/PGA of America)
Miguel Ko (left), chairman of CHF and chairman of CapitaLand Investment, during the CapitaLand Hope School programme in India in 2023. Education is one of the initiative's focus impact areas.

site_title: South Korea’s industry minister seeks exemption from Trump’s tariffs
summary: South Korea's industry minister, Ahn Duk Geun, requested tariff exemptions from the US administration during talks with US officials, including Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick and Trade Representative Jamieson Greer. The request comes amid US plans to impose new tariffs, including a 25% tariff on steel and aluminium globally. South Korea views the measures with increasing concern, given its status as a major global exporter and top trading partner with the US. The countries agreed to set up a working-level channel to discuss tariff-related issues and cooperation in shipbuilding.

images.alt_text: At the end of 2024, South Korea’s household debt stood at 1,927.3 trillion won (S$1.8 trillion), up 2.2 per cent from a year earlier and the fastest growth in 2-1/2 years.
South Korea’s government has spent hundreds of billions of US dollars over the years in a campaign aimed at encouraging more people to get married and procreate.

Outbound shipments from South Korea stood at US$52.60 billion, up 1.0 per cent from a year earlier, preliminary trade data showed on Saturday, weaker than a median 3.8 per cent increase forecast in a Reuters poll of economists.

site_title: China’s February non-manufacturing activity accelerates expansion
summary: China's non-manufacturing activity accelerated its expansion in February, with the official non-manufacturing purchasing managers' index (PMI) rising to 50.4 from 50.2 in January. This marks the first time the index has exceeded 50 since August 2022. The increase is attributed to a stronger services sector, with the NBS composite PMI of manufacturing and services reaching 51.1 in February, up from 50.1 in January. This suggests that China's economy is showing signs of recovery and growth.

site_title: Blackstone’s Schwarzman takes home more than US$1 billion in pay and dividends
summary: Blackstone CEO Steve Schwarzman received over $1 billion in pay and dividends in 2024, primarily in dividends rather than fund profits. He holds almost 20% of Blackstone's stock, valued at $37 billion. This comes as Washington considers taxing private equity profits. Schwarzman's 2024 earnings were 11.5% higher than the previous year due to $916 million in dividends.

images.alt_text: The three projects for sale are part of assets under DragonCor, a portfolio company owned and managed by Blackstone real estate funds set up around 2018.
Blackstone has structured its fund so that investors can withdraw as much as 3 per cent of the fund’s net asset value each quarter.
Blackstone has structured its fund so that investors can withdraw as much as 3 per cent of the fund’s net asset value each quarter.

site_title: BOC Aviation buys 120 single-aisle jets from Airbus, Boeing
summary: BOC Aviation, a Singapore-headquartered aircraft lessor, has purchased 120 single-aisle jets from Airbus and Boeing, its single-largest aircraft purchase. The deal includes 70 Airbus A320Neo family jets and 50 Boeing 737-8 aircraft, as part of its plan to expand its fleet to 1,000 aircraft by 2030. The purchase is a strong run for Boeing's 737 jet, following recent orders from Malaysia Airlines, Japan Airlines, and ANA. Deliveries are expected by 2031 and 2032.

site_title: Buybacks surge as corporate earnings season nears end
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Institutions were net sellers of Singapore stocks from Feb 21 to Feb 27, with a net outflow of S$265 million, bringing the year-to-date net institutional outflow to S$1.1 billion. The top-selling stocks included OCBC, Yangzijiang Shipbuilding, and UOB. In contrast, stocks like Singapore Airlines, Singapore Exchange, and Sembcorp Industries saw significant net institutional inflows. Meanwhile, 24 primary-listed companies conducted share buybacks, with DBS leading the consideration tally. Wilmar International reported a 44% decline in core net profit for the second half of FY2024, but expects FY2025 results to be satisfactory.

images.alt_text: SGX Centre 新加坡交易所。SGX logo in front of the SGX Centre building at Shenton Way.

site_title: Looming Trump tariffs make US steel too expensive at home
summary: US steel prices have surged to over $900 a ton due to impending 25% tariffs on foreign imports, now exceeding domestic prices. The tariffs, set to take effect in two weeks, have led to a surge in shipments from countries such as Egypt, Algeria, and Vietnam. Domestic steel demand remains unchanged, and producers like Nucor Corp and Cleveland-Cliffs have raised prices, passing the costs to customers. Canadian and Mexican steelmakers are also facing pressure, with some refusing new orders. The industry is expected to pass higher costs onto customers rather than divert shipments elsewhere.

images.alt_text: A worker cuts steel sheets at an auto parts manufacturer in San Luis Potosi, Mexico, Feb 17, 2025. The value of Mexico's exports to the United States now far exceeds that of its imports from its northern neighbour - a major bone of contention for Donald Trump.

(FILES) Black Friday shoppers make their way through the Opry Mills Mall in Nashville, Tennessee, on November 25, 2022. US shoppers are coming out in force this 2024 holiday season, but the festiveness is being tempered by inflationary pressures that have abated but not completely faded. Americans are "ready to open their wallets this holiday season," said the Conference Board ahead of Black Friday -- the day after Thanksgiving, which this year, falls on November 28 -- that traditionally sees US stores kick off the Christmas shopping season with steep discounts. (Photo by SETH HERALD / AFP)
Washington has already imposed anti-dumping duties on multiple Vietnamese steel exports and producers, in some cases even higher than 25 per cent
US President Donald Trump said on Thursday (Feb 27) in a social media post that drugs from the country’s North American neighbours are still entering “at very high and unacceptable levels.”

site_title: A startup founder’s dilemma
summary: A startup founder's survival in Singapore hinges on protecting intellectual property (IP). IP theft can cripple a company, undermining investor confidence, disrupting business models, and forcing innovative companies to shut operations. To prevent IP theft, startups should set clear expectations through employment contracts, and the courts must enforce the law by awarding damages and injunctive relief. The US case Waymo versus Uber (2018) highlights the importance of robust legal safeguards in protecting innovative companies' competitive IP. Singapore's jurisdiction should step up to protect startups from devastating breaches, ensuring comprehensive protection for intangible assets underpinning innovation.

images.alt_text: Globally, corporate research and development expenditure reached a historic high of US$1.1 trillion in 2022, primarily driven by ICT companies.

site_title: Enamelling: The latest iteration of Van Cleef & Arpels’ beloved ladybirds
summary: Van Cleef & Arpels has unveiled its latest Coccinelles (Ladybirds) collection, featuring three-dimensional, enamelled ladybirds in a range of artistic designs. The creations, crafted in the brand's Geneva workshops, showcase the art of enamelling, a technique that involves blending silica powder and pigments to achieve a deep, vibrant red finish. The ladybirds are adorned with diamonds, onyx heads, and handcrafted goldwork, making them a sumptuous and whimsical take on the classic motif.

images.alt_text: Fred's Force 10 Rise collection as seen on global ambassador, BTS’ Jin.
Illustrations by French comic-book artist and writer David Beauchard accompany the Treasure Island collection by Van Cleef & Arpels.
Just  one of several magnificent necklaces from Van Cleef & Arpels' Treasure Island high jewellery collection.

site_title: US: Wall St opens slightly higher after Trump-led rally
summary: US stocks rose slightly on Tuesday, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average increasing 108.37 points, or 0.25%, to 42,691.69. The gains were attributed to investors reassessing the implications of potential leniency in US President Donald Trump's trade policy approach. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also saw gains, despite a volatile market outlook and ongoing trade tensions with Canada and Europe.

site_title: Annyeong, investors: ‘Strategic’ JS-SEZ projects can get customised incentives, says Malaysian official
summary: Malaysian Investment Development Authority (Mida) has announced that foreign investments with strategic significance for Malaysia can receive customised incentives beyond tax perks when entering the Johor-Singapore Special Economic Zone (JS-SEZ). Mida will assess projects based on factors such as spurring local employment and will request investors to provide a "wish list" of desired incentives. The agency is open to flexibility on details such as tax break tenure, which can be tailored to a project's requirements, and is considering customised incentives for companies in the logistics sector.

images.alt_text: The project will be built in two phases, with construction on the hospital block and the central lift core to start by the end of the year or the first quarter of 2026.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp, Nio, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Sinarmas Land, SingPost
summary: Sembcorp Industries signed a 25-year renewable energy purchase agreement with Meta Platforms' subsidiary Malkoha, with the goal of building a 150 megawatt-peak floating solar photovoltaic system on Kranji Reservoir. Nio announced plans to raise HK$4 billion (S$688 million) for research and development of smart EVs, causing its shares to fall. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's director Mark Yeo will retire after the annual general meeting. Sinarmas Land received a voluntary unconditional cash offer for S$1.32 billion. SingPost completed the divestment of its Australian logistics business for A$1 billion (S$845 million).

site_title: Microsoft pulls back from more data centre leases in US and Europe: analysts
summary: Microsoft has abandoned data centre projects in the US and Europe due to an oversupply of capacity relative to its demand forecast. The tech giant's decision not to support OpenAI's ChatGPT training workloads led to the pullback. This move has increased investor skepticism about the hefty AI spending by US tech firms, with Alphabet's Google stepping in to fill the gap and Meta backing up capacity in the US. Microsoft's plans to spend $80 billion on AI infrastructure this fiscal year remain on track.

images.alt_text: The new cloud region will generate US$10.9 billion in new revenues and create 37,575 jobs in Malaysia by 2028, including 5,700 skilled IT positions, projects Laurence Si, managing director of Microsoft Malaysia.
Microsoft is also developing so-called reasoning models, which are designed to field more complex queries and display human-like problem-solving, the source says.
Microsoft’s results in late January underlined both why it has lately failed to excite investors, and also why few are throwing in the towel.

site_title: SGX listcos with Indonesia exposure stay resilient amid market meltdown
summary: Singapore-listed companies with significant exposure to Indonesia, such as Wilmar International and Golden Agri-Resources, have remained resilient despite the market meltdown in the country. These companies have seen no significant institutional outflows from the sector since the start of 2025, with Wilmar logging a net institutional inflow of S$51.1 million in the year to date. Analysts attribute their defensive performance to the companies' relatively diversified exposure to various commodities, which has shielded them from the impact of the Indonesian market downturn.

images.alt_text: Projected earnings growth for plantation players in 2025 is driven by firm selling prices amid tight supply and strong demand.
Wild price swings in stocks are a common and increasingly problematic feature of Indonesia’s equity market.

“Looking forward, Bank Indonesia will continue to observe prospects of inflation and economic growth to take advantage of room for a BI rate cut, while considering the rupiah movement,” governor Perry Warjiyo told.

site_title: Singapore’s prime office rents in Q1 weighed down by global retrenchments, trade tensions
summary: Singapore's prime office rents in Q1 2025 increased by 0.5% to S$11.60 per square foot per month, following a 0.4% increase in Q4 2024. The modest growth is attributed to a challenging global economic climate and ongoing geopolitical tensions. Occupancy levels in the CBD stood at 93.5% in Q1, with landlords prioritizing building occupancies amid uncertainty. The limited supply pipeline is expected to fuel landlord expectations, with Knight Frank predicting prime rental growth to range between -1% and 2% for 2025.

images.alt_text: Generic photo for stories related to Singapore economy, CBD, GDP.

The 54-storey V on Shenton (left) comprises 510 apartments. It is part of a mixed-use project by Singapore Land Group that also includes the adjacent 23-storey UIC Building, comprising mostly offices.

site_title: More South-east Asian countries are ‘in the line of fire’ from Trump’s reciprocal tariffs: Maybank
summary: US President Donald Trump's plans to introduce reciprocal tariffs are expected to bring a substantial slowdown to Indonesia, the Philippines, Malaysia, and Thailand, according to a report by Maybank. The tariffs will be based on five components, including value-added taxes, non-tariff barriers, and exchange rates, potentially putting these countries in the line of fire. However, the tariffs may also increase Chinese demand for Asean products, particularly food and agricultural products, as China retaliates against US products.

images.alt_text: Trump has also pledged to pair those with sectoral tariffs on autos, semiconductor chips, pharmaceutical drugs and lumber.
Nations in the crosshairs of US tariffs have rushed to set up meetings with Trump administration officials to offer concessions and other defensive responses.

Even if not all of Asia is directly affected, the impact of rising tariffs and trade wars could cause major disruptions to supply chains and slow trade and investment flows, Deputy Prime Minister Gan Kim Yong said.

Trade Minister Zafrul Aziz said that the US government was demanding Malaysia closely track the movement of high-end Nvidia chips that enter the country over suspicions that many are ending up in China, according to the report.

site_title: Investment bankers finally start to take Trump literally
summary: US President Donald Trump's chaotic policymaking has led to a slowdown in deal flow, causing investment bankers to reassess their expectations. The transformation he's planning during his second term will be painful, with potential economic and financial consequences. Investment banks' trading operations are expected to be a bright spot in the first quarter, but investors are adopting a wait-and-see approach due to the uncertainty. The US domestic economy is also at risk, with widespread pain among financials and a potential threat to consumer spending.

images.alt_text: Chairman of the Council of Economic Advisers Stephen Miran's vision of a Mar-a-Lago accord includes a possible US debt restructuring, which would force some holders of Treasuries to swap them for perpetual bonds.
That tension between Trump the genius and Trump the moron is dangerous for the Maga movement that he created and leads.

site_title: Gaggan is best restaurant; seven Singapore restaurants in Asia’s 50 Best list
summary: Bangkok's Gaggan restaurant has won the Best Restaurant in Asia award for the fourth consecutive year, beating Hong Kong's The Chairman to the top spot. Singapore's Odette took 7th place, while Les Amis jumped 10 places to 28th. The list reflects the changing dining scene in Asia, with a focus on sustainability and heritage ingredients. Chef-owner Gaggan Anand expressed emotion after his win, crediting his team and stating the award is not just for him, but for those who doubted him.

images.alt_text: The refurbished restaurant takes over from the group's steamboat eatery.

site_title: Singapore shares rise after Fed rate cut pause; STI up 0.6%
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.6% to 3,930.49 after the US Federal Reserve held off on interest-rate cuts, citing rising economic uncertainty. The decision provided Asian markets with more room for certainty. The top gainer was ST Engineering, while DFI Retail Group saw the biggest declines. Across the broader market, 286 gainers outnumbered 243 losers after 1.1 billion securities worth S$1.4 billion changed hands.

images.alt_text: US Federal Reserve chair Jerome Powell says that the Fed will hold interest rates steady for now.

ST20240207_202454992664: Gin Tay/ mystengg07/ Mike Yeo/
The ST Engineering logo on one of its hangars at Seletar Aerospace Park used for Passenger-to-freighter (P2F) aircraft conversion works.
(photographed on Feb 7, 2024)
ST Engineering is eyeing a revenue of S$17 billion and a net profit improvement that outpaces its top-line increases by up to five percentage points annually over the next five years.

site_title: BOJ keeps interest rates steady as Trump risk looms
summary: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) kept interest rates steady at 0.5% as it monitored global economic uncertainty, particularly due to US President Donald Trump's tariff policy. Governor Kazuo Ueda warned of heightening inflation risks, driven by rising food costs and stronger-than-expected wage growth. The BOJ will review its forecasts in April, with economists expecting a potential rate hike in July. The decision comes as the US Federal Reserve is also expected to keep interest rates steady, amid concerns about the impact of Trump's planned tariff hikes on the global economy.

images.alt_text: Japan's exports rose 11.4 per cent year-on-year in February, data showed, less than a median market forecast for a 12.1 per cent increase and following a 7.2 per cent rise in January.
Average nationwide land prices, across residential and commercial, grew 2.7 per cent as of Jan 1, the fourth straight year of gains.

epa11954763 A passerby walks before a stock market indicator board in Tokyo, Japan, 11 March 2025. The Nikkei stock index plunged over 2 percent during the morning trading session following concerns on US economy and overnight loss at the New York Stock Exchange.  EPA-EFE/FRANCK ROBICHON
MUFG follows Tokyo-based rivals Nomura Holdings and Sumitomo Mitsui Financial Group in quitting the climate group.
Japan’s benchmark 10-year bond yields have risen since the January meeting, hitting the highest level since 2008 last week.

site_title: Celebrate spring with novelties from four French jewellery brands
summary: Four French jewellery brands, Fred, Dior, Chaumet, and Boucheron, have introduced new spring collections. Fred's Force 10 Rise features sailing-inspired designs with braided cables and pave diamonds, while Dior's Diorette collection celebrates nature with flowers and ladybirds in pastel hues. Chaumet's Bee de Chaumet collection features a dozen new iterations of its iconic bee and honeycomb motifs. Boucheron's Serpent Boheme Vintage collection channels the 1970s with bold, floral motifs and brilliant-cut diamonds.

images.alt_text: The ladybird appears in an enamelled, three-dimensional form in the Coccinelles creations.

site_title: Mazda makes cost-saving effort as inflation threatens to drive up investment spending
summary: Mazda Motor plans to maintain its investment of around 1.5 trillion yen (S$13.4 billion) for its electrification efforts up to 2030, despite inflation threatening to increase costs. The automaker will achieve this through partnerships and utilizing existing manufacturing plants, reducing the investment by 85% compared to building a dedicated EV plant. Mazda aims to launch an electric vehicle in 2027 on an existing production line, cutting production lead time by around 80%. The company's "lean asset" strategy aims to maintain international competitiveness in the automotive industry.

images.alt_text: Toyota hopes a more compact engine will help revamp vehicle design by saving space under the hood.
Nissan has introduced two battery electric vehicle (EV) concept cars and two plug-in petrol-electric hybrids, all from a joint effort with local partner Dongfeng.
On the surface, the Mazda CX-60 is just another family car – albeit a handsomely sculptural one, with polished lines and clean-cut looks.
Mazda is a small player in China, where its best-seller is the Mazda 3.

site_title: How to unlock Europe’s super strong stock market year
summary: Investors should position for 2025 by diversifying their portfolios, even in a Europe-led year. Using a broad benchmark, such as the MSCI World Index, and analyzing its components is key. Diversifying outside of Europe, particularly with stocks from the US, Asia, and other regions, can help minimize risk. Europe's dominant sectors, including value stocks, will likely lead the market, with countries like the UK, Spain, Italy, and France offering opportunities for exposure. Modestly overweighting Europe and underweighting the US can help balance the portfolio.

images.alt_text: 'Extreme' years are more common for stock markets than 'average' ones, the writer argues.
An Ukrainian soldier on the front line, amid the ongoing conflict in the region.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as Trump's auto tariffs sap sentiment
summary: US stocks opened lower on March 27, 2025, as President Donald Trump's auto tariffs negatively impacted market sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 110.22 points, or 0.26%, to 42,344.57. The S&P 500 lost 16.77 points, or 0.30%, to 5,695.16, and the Nasdaq Composite fell 67.55 points, or 0.38%, to 17,831.47. The losses were attributed to Trump's latest tariff move, which has affected auto stocks.

images.alt_text: Traders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., March 19, 2025.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid

site_title: Singapore CEOs turn more cautious even as global corporate chiefs’ confidence improves
summary: Singapore CEOs have become more cautious due to concerns over inflation, with overall confidence dropping from 72% to 54%. Despite this, 56% of Singapore respondents remain confident in reimagining their business model for the future. The survey also found that CEOs are prioritizing strategic vision, employee upskilling, and striking a balance between human talent and technology. A significant number of Singapore CEOs plan to pursue transaction initiatives, including M&As, divestments, and IPOs, with 98% intending to pursue transactions in the next 12 months.

images.alt_text: Bank of America’s buildup of advisory work on upcoming mergers and acquisitions is strong, while its pipelines for IPOs “are full and ready to go,” CEO Brian Moynihan told attendees at the Clearing House Annual Conference, New York City, US, Nov 13, 2024..
A port in Indonesia. It is among the key Asean economies that are forecast to rank among the top 30 countries in both the speed of growth and absolute increase in trade volume.

site_title: What Gen Z’s micro-retirement means for companies
summary: Gen Z's concept of a "micro-retirement" is gaining attention, but it's not just about individual burnout or personal passions - it's about companies. Unlike traditional sabbaticals, micro-retirement isn't employer-granted and isn't meant to be a temporary escape. Instead, it's a routine lifestyle choice to combat burnout and pursue passions, which companies should take note of. With Gen Z entering the workforce, companies may need to adapt to their changing needs and priorities, potentially leading to new approaches to employee wellness and work-life balance.

site_title: ‘A Synergy of Arts in Singapore’ – SG60 exhibition raises funds for Drama Box
summary: The exhibition "A Synergy of Arts in Singapore" at Pan Pacific Singapore commemorates SG60 and raises funds for charity organization Drama Box. The exhibition features 40 artworks by 18 artists, available for purchase with proceeds going towards Drama Box's community engagement projects. The artworks depict Singapore's past and present, including icons, landmarks, and kampungs, and will be open until June 1. The funds raised will support Drama Box's initiatives, such as Project 12 and Arts in the Commons, which focus on community engagement and sustainability.

images.alt_text: St Lukes ElderCare, which participated in Great Singapore Give, says the campaign helped it reach a wider audience.

site_title: Giant, Cold Storage turn profitable in Singapore; owner DFI sees growth potential from 7-Eleven
summary: Singapore Exchange-listed DFI Retail Group's supermarket operations in Singapore became profitable in 2024, with a strategy of closing underperforming stores and reopening them in more lucrative locations. The group expects stable supermarket revenue due to intense competition, but sees growth potential in its 7-Eleven convenience business. DFI has refocused on product offerings, closing 11 Giant outlets and opening five new stores, and has launched a 7-Eleven app to capitalize on shifting consumer behavior. The company reported a 30% year-on-year increase in profit to US$201 million, and announced a final dividend of seven US cents.

images.alt_text: CS Fresh is operated by mainboard-listed DFI Retail Group. The supermarket and retail store operator declared a final dividend of 7 US cents per share.
DFI, a multi-format retailer that counts CS Fresh, Giant and Guardian under its brands, also operates 7-Eleven stores in Singapore, Hong Kong, Macau and China’s Guangdong province.

site_title: Didi’s self-driving unit said to seek funds at US$5 billion value
summary: Didi Global's autonomous driving unit is seeking $5 billion in funding, valuing the company at around this amount, as Chinese tech firms ride a wave of investor enthusiasm. The unit operates a fleet of over 200 self-driving vehicles that have conducted trials in major Chinese cities. Proceeds from the funding round could be used to develop autonomous-driving technologies and speed up mass production of robotaxis. The move comes amid a recent rally in China's equity markets, fueled by the arrival of low-cost robotaxi models and President Xi Jinping's backing of the nation's tech companies.

images.alt_text: Didi Global swung to a net income of 929 million yuan (S$172 million) for the September quarter, versus a year-ago loss.
Didi plans to sell the assets to AutoAi, a provider of intelligent cockpits-related software and hardware, in exchange for a stake in AutoAi.
The company now aims to list on the Hong Kong stock exchange, though the timeline for that remains unclear.
Didi Global saw revenue rise 4.1 per cent to 50.9 billion yuan for the quarter.

site_title: Europe’s Competitiveness Compass points in the wrong direction
summary: The European Union's Competitiveness Compass has reaffirmed the creation of a European Competitiveness Fund, but its proposal to finance the fund through the EU Budget may be too little, too late to strengthen the bloc's competitiveness. The EU needs a direct subsidy mechanism, such as issuing joint debt, to support European manufacturing, particularly in the automotive industry. This would address the bloc's inability to produce clean technologies at competitive prices, a challenge exacerbated by China's massive production and low margins.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today (Mar 7)
summary: Singapore's affordable housing scheme, proposed by the Progress Singapore Party, aims to recover construction costs, not land costs. HDB flats are now seen as a store of value with potential for appreciation. The annual MediSave withdrawal limit for outpatient scans doubles to S$600 from Jan 1, 2026. Singapore remains the world's top port for 12th consecutive year, with FedEx partnering a local startup to deploy robots for deliveries. The government also sets up a centre to advance sustainable aviation in Asia.

images.alt_text: Singapore’s R&D efforts have helped develop a strong pipeline of innovative startups, many of which are deep tech ones, DPM Gan Kim Yong noted.

site_title: Yuko Tsukada: From grief to sustainable jewellery for cat lovers
summary: Yuko Tsukada, a former Bloomberg creative director, created her sustainable jewelry brand Catastrophy after the loss of her two 19-year-old cats in 2017. The brand, which features Victorian-inspired, edgy designs made from recycled silver, aims to bring solace and peace to cat lovers. With a focus on sustainability, vegan materials, and eco-friendly packaging, Catastrophy has become the first jewelry brand to be certified vegan by The Vegan Society. Tsukada's journey has also been one of self-discovery, as she leaves her corporate life behind to build a business that reflects her true identity.

images.alt_text: Artist Agatha Lee uses organza from discarded wedding dresses to craft a fragile coral reef-like art installation.

site_title: How Asia’s best female chef navigated an industry that favours seniority and men
summary: Thai chef Chudaree "Tam" Debhakam, owner of eco-restaurant Baan Tepa, has been named Asia's best female chef in the 2025 Asia's 50 Best Restaurants awards. Five years after opening her restaurant, Tam has achieved her goal of creating a fully sustainable restaurant, sourcing ingredients locally and promoting local producers. She credits her grandmother and younger female colleagues for shaping her into the person she is today. Tam's recognition highlights the need for more support and equality in the industry, particularly for women who want to balance family life and careers in hospitality.

images.alt_text: Yuko Tsukada's Catastrophy line of sustainable jewellery was born out of devastation following the death of two of her cats.
Artist Agatha Lee uses organza from discarded wedding dresses to craft a fragile coral reef-like art installation.

site_title: Singapore’s logistics giant YCH targets four US$300 million SuperPorts across Asean by 2030
summary: Singapore logistics giant YCH Group plans to invest at least $300 million in four SuperPorts across Southeast Asia by 2030, starting with hubs in Vietnam and Cambodia. The first phase of Vietnam SuperPort began in 2023, with the second stage in development. The project aims to create a transhipment hub, improve China-Asean connectivity, and become South-east Asia's first net-zero multimodal logistics port by 2040. YCH Group's goal is to enhance regional connectivity, foster innovation, and improve the efficiency of cargo flows, capitalizing on the growing demand for supply chain diversification amid geopolitical shifts.

images.alt_text: The first phase of Vietnam SuperPort, located in the northern province of Vinh Phuc, has been operational since Jan 2023.

site_title: Indonesia posts first annual deflation in 25 years at 0.09% in February
summary: Indonesia recorded its first annual deflation in 25 years, with an annual rate of 0.09% in February, driven by lower staple food prices and reduced electricity rates. This deflation is a concern for consumer purchasing power in South-east Asia's largest economy. The central bank, Bank Indonesia, may consider another rate cut due to the deflation. However, analysts predict this trend to be temporary, with inflation expected to rise to 2.33% by the end of 2025 as the electricity tariff discount expires and Ramadan-driven demand increases.

images.alt_text: Elisa Valenta
The rupiah has come under mounting pressure this year, following Bank Indonesia’s unexpected rate cut in January.

site_title: Chevron advances plans to develop US data centres with power generation
summary: Chevron plans to develop US data centers, which are expected to triple in energy use over the next three years due to the growing demand for artificial intelligence. The oil major will develop data center sites and power plants, primarily powered by natural gas, and not connected to the grid. Chevron's data centers are expected to be built in the south, western interior, and Midwest regions, with a focus on scale, speed, and reliability. The company's move is part of Big Oil's shift to power generation for data centers, which is upending the country's power industry.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: The logo and trading information for Chevron is displayed on a screen on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., June 27, 2022.  REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo

site_title: Nominations now open for EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2025 awards
summary: Nominations are now open for the EY Entrepreneur of the Year 2025 awards in Singapore, with a call for public and business community nominations until April 1. The annual awards recognize innovative and passionate entrepreneurs across four globally benchmarked criteria: entrepreneurial spirit, growth, purpose, and impact. The winner will be selected as the EY Entrepreneur Of The Year 2025 Singapore and represent the country at the EY World Entrepreneur Of The Year award next year.

images.alt_text: From left to right: Edy Tan Wei Hock, chief executive officer for Chye Thiam Maintenance and winner in the environmental services category; Samuel Yik, managing director of Dian Xiao Er Group abd winner in the food and beverage category; Anthony Chow, chief executive officer and co-founder of igloocompany and winner in the technology solutions category; Zachary Wang, chief executive officer and co-founder of Neuron Mobility and winner in the mobility category.
Zachary Wang, co-founder and chief executive of e-scooter sharing startup Neuron Mobility, beat three other category winners to clinch the top honour.

site_title: Tiong Bahru heritage neighbourhood gets new hipster eatery Magpie
summary: Magpie, a new hipster eatery in Tiong Bahru, Singapore, has opened its doors with a "borderless" menu that blends various international flavors. Helmed by a New Zealand chef, the restaurant serves hefty portions and features a laid-back atmosphere. However, critics find the food messy and lacking nuance, with a focus on bold flavors and heavy ingredients. Despite this, Magpie shows good intentions and a desire to be part of the neighborhood, and the restaurant has already gained popularity among locals. The restaurant offers a unique dining experience, but may require a more refined approach to elevate its offerings.

images.alt_text: Bon Broth's elegant interiors.

site_title: BT Mark to Market: Reviving Singapore’s stock market
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has implemented measures to revive the Singapore stock market, including streamlining the listing process, providing corporate tax rebates, and the Equity Market Development Programme (EQDP). However, there is skepticism about the effectiveness of these measures, citing strong performance of the US market and conflicting views on corporate governance standards in Singapore. Despite these concerns, the MAS review group's efforts aim to fix the Singapore market, including modernizing market infrastructure and enabling investors to seek recourse for market misconduct.

images.alt_text: Claressa Monteiro
SGX's share price shot up following strong earnings report, but subsequently fell back on concerns the MAS review group's recommendations would disappoint
MAS announced last week that the equities market review group has submitted proposals to boost the local market

site_title: Market Focus Daily: Friday, March 14, 2025
summary: Asian markets rose on hopes for a US bill to avert a government shutdown, with gold surging to a record high as investors sought safety. Chinese stocks rallied ahead of government measures to boost consumption. In contrast, Sembcorp fell 4.9% after an Indonesia gas deal was scrapped due to regulatory hurdles.

images.alt_text: Market updates for Friday.

site_title: Musk says X hit by major cyberattack
summary: Elon Musk confirmed that the X social media platform was hit by a major cyberattack, causing intermittent outages and disruptions. Musk attributed the attack to a "massive cyberattack" and speculated that it was the work of a country or large coordinated group. Cybersecurity experts agree that the duration of the trouble is a sign of an attack, and some have linked the incident to nation-state aggression. The attack raises concerns about the stability and security of the platform, which has experienced technical issues under Musk's ownership.

images.alt_text: (FILES) (COMBO) This combination of pictures created on October 10, 2023, shows (L) SpaceX, X and electric car maker Tesla CEO Elon Musk in Paris, on June 16, 2023 and (R) the new Twitter logo rebranded as X, pictured on a screen in Paris on July 24, 2023. Elon Musk said X was hit by a "massive" cyberattack on March 10, 2025, as outages plagued users of the platform once known as Twitter. Musk blamed a cyberattack, providing no evidence, for crashing the site last year when an interview with Donald Trump was to be streamed. (Photo by Alain JOCARD / AFP)

site_title: Renewed investor interest in Orchard Road malls a positive for S-Reits with prime central assets: DBS
summary: DBS analysts Geraldine Wong and Derek Tan say renewed investor interest in Orchard Road malls, driven by the sale of Ion Orchard's stake and Paragon Reit's privatisation offer, is a positive for Singapore-listed S-Reits. The analysts name CapitaLand Integrated Commercial Trust (CICT) and Lendlease Global Commercial Reit as top picks, assigning "buy" ratings and price targets above current prices. They expect rental recovery in Orchard Road to come soon, driven by luxury spending and a tight retail supply landscape.

images.alt_text:
Ion Orchard as seen before the WWF Earth Hour Switch Off moment on March 23, 2024.

For an hour from 8.30pm on March 23, all non-essential lights were switched off at establishments along Orchard Road in a display of support for WWF Earth Hour Switch Off for the first time in the iconic shopping district. 

At Wisma Atria, a venue partner for the event, a festival of activities and performances – including thematic art performances, educational booths around climate change, and talks by WWF-Singapore’s subject matter experts - concluded with the symbolic switching off of lights within the shopping centre.

More than 1000 individuals and businesses around Singapore joined in the collective act  to pledge their commitment towards a climate-resilient future.

site_title: Sin Heng Heavy Machinery receives privatisation offer with S$0.58 per share cash option
summary: A consortium led by executive directors of Sin Heng Heavy Machinery has made a voluntary unconditional offer to take the company private at S$0.58 in cash per share. The offeror, Tal United, aims to delist and privatize Sin Heng to gain greater management flexibility and reduce listing costs. The offer price represents a premium of 6.4% over the last trading price and is higher than the closing share price over the past five years. Tal United has received irrevocable undertakings from 58.51% of shareholders, and the offer is expected to provide a clean cash exit opportunity for investors.

Crane tower operator  ,塔式吊车司机

site_title: Shell overhauls executive team, integrated gas and upstream director to leave
summary: Shell overhauls executive team, appointing Cederic Cremers as president of Integrated Gas and Peter Costello as president of Upstream, replacing Zoe Yujnovich after nearly a decade. The changes are part of Shell's strategy to streamline its senior management structure and simplify its business. CEO Wael Sawan stated that the moves will reflect the company's three primary business areas: Integrated Gas, Upstream, and Downstream, Renewables and Energy Solutions. Shell also plans to integrate technical divisions into its business lines by 2026.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: FILE PHOTO: The logo of British multinational oil and gas company Shell is displayed during the LNG 2023 energy trade show in Vancouver, British Columbia, Canada, July 12, 2023. REUTERS/Chris Helgren/File Photo/File Photo

site_title: Manhattan office leasing posts strongest start since 2014
summary: Manhattan office leasing has started the year strongly, with 5.13 million square feet leased in January and February, the most since 2014. The office availability rate decreased to 18.4% in February, down from a month prior. Tenants favor newer and renovated properties, and building owners are seeing a shift in power as incentives declined. Concessions remain 30% higher than pre-pandemic levels, and lower-tier building owners continue to struggle to fill space.

images.alt_text: empire state, building, city

site_title: Musk launches appeal to restore US$56 billion Tesla payday
summary: Elon Musk has launched an appeal to restore his US$56 billion Tesla payday, which was rescinded by a Delaware court in January 2024. The court ruled the pay package unfair to shareholders, citing Musk's control over negotiations and withheld information from investors. Musk argues the ruling defies Delaware law and common sense, and that the court applied a "license to sue" to Tesla shareholders. The appeal comes as Tesla faces challenges, including a sharp stock fall and President Trump's government efficiency effort.

images.alt_text: FILE PHOTO: A 3D-printed miniature model of Elon Musk and the Tesla logo are seen in this illustration taken January 23, 2025. REUTERS/Dado Ruvic/Illustration/File Photo

site_title: Khazanah in talks to buy INCJ’s stake in tower firm Edotco
summary: Malaysia's sovereign wealth fund Khazanah Nasional is in talks to acquire Innovation Network Corp of Japan's (INCJ) 21% stake in Edotco Group, a telecommunications tower company. The deal reflects the strong relationship between Malaysia and Japan. Khazanah already owns about 37% of Malaysia's largest cellular firm Axiata Group, which controls 63% of Edotco. No transaction value has been disclosed.

images.alt_text: Khazanah is studying the impact on the economy and commodity prices, as well as possible shortages, as markets face waves of volatility following Russia's widening assault on Ukraine.

site_title: Pamela Anderson finally feels like an actress, 32 years after ‘Baywatch’
summary: Pamela Anderson, 57, says playing a fading showgirl in "The Last Showgirl" has made her feel like a real actress for the first time after 32 years of acting, including her iconic role in "Baywatch." The film, directed by Gia Coppola, earned her rave reviews, including a Golden Globe nomination. Anderson, who has been open about her tumultuous past, is now exploring theatre and hopes to perform in a Tennessee Williams play, seeking to reinvent herself beyond her early career as a glamour model.

images.alt_text: Canadian-US actress and model Pamela Anderson poses on the red carpet upon arrival at the BAFTA British Academy Film Awards at the Royal Festival Hall, Southbank Centre, in London, on February 16, 2025. (Photo by Ben STANSALL / AFP)

site_title: Former director of Sabana Reit’s ex-tenant jailed for contempt of court in ongoing tussle over unpaid rent
summary: Former director of Kleio One-Solution, Lin Duanliang, was sentenced to three days' jail for contempt of court in an ongoing dispute over unpaid rent with Sabana Real Estate Investment Trust (Reit). Lin failed to comply with court orders, including a medical leave excuse, and missed a court examination in September 2024. The issue began in November 2023 when Sabana Reit sought a court order for possession and payment of around S$2.1 million in arrears.

site_title: Japan’s exports expand in February on stockpiling amid tariff fears
summary: Japan's exports rose 11.4% year-on-year in February, exceeding the 7.2% rise in January, driven by stockpiling amid US President Donald Trump's tariff policies. Exports to the US and China increased, with 10.5% and 14.1% year-on-year gains, respectively. Imports dropped 0.7% year-on-year, resulting in a trade surplus of 584.5 billion yen. The increase in exports is seen as a temporary boost, with Japanese companies stockpiling inventory ahead of potential tariffs on autos and other key exports.

images.alt_text: Cargo containers are seen at the Aomi Container Terminal in Tokyo on February 5, 2025. (Photo by Philip FONG / AFP)
